On the very first song on their very first album
column3: Coldplay introduced themselves with a heartfelt declaration: ""We live in a beautiful world."" Fifteen years and some 80 million albums sold later
column4: the British quartet haven’t elaborated on that philosophy—they’ve just amplified it. Where massive success has a tendency to make bands more jaded and aloof
column5: Coldplay only seem more gobsmacked and in awe of life itself. Their songs aren’t just designed to uplift
column6: they’re often about the very sensation of being uplifted. But on the band’s seventh album
column7: A Head Full of Dreams
column8: the band’s relentless campaign to raise our spirits is liable to induce altitude sickness.

column1: Of course
column2: there’s a perfectly logical reason for the album’s oversold optimism—A Head Full of Dreams is a reactionary retort to 2014’s Ghost Stories
column3: a low-key response to a high-profile split that literally wore its (broken) heart on its sleeve. The new album
column4: by contrast
column5: is Martin’s unconscious recoupling record
column6: the sound of a freshly single man stepping out onto the dancefloor to lose his mind and find new love. ""You make me feel like I’m alive again
column7: he sings atop the slinky disco of lead single ""Adventure of a Lifetime""
column8: a lyric that succinctly sums up the spirit of the record like a movie poster tagline.

column1: A Head Full of Dreams is Coldplay’s chance to reassert the eager-to-please exuberance that Ghost Stories deliberately downplayed
column2: and prove that Adele isn’t the only artist who can mobilize a monoculture in 2015. Though written off by detractors as middle of the road
column3: Coldplay’s centrist position is what ultimately makes them so singular—they’re the only rock band that could (and would want to) wrangle Beyoncé
column4: Noel Gallagher
column5: Tove Lo
column6: Norwegian Top 40 architects Stargate
column7: Kendrick Lamar producer Daniel Green
column8: alt-rock lifer Nik Simpson
column9: and “Gimme Shelter” scene-stealer Merry Clayton on the same record. A Head Full of Dreams is emblematic of Coldplay’s burning desire to be all things to all people
column10: rolling up symphonic Britpop bluster
column11: club-thumping bangers
column12: dentist-office soft rock
column13: finger-snapping R&B
column14: and even some trippy touches that remind you of a time when this band just wanted to be as popular as Mercury Rev.

column1: But the album has bigger ambitions. By weaving a spoken-word reading of an inspirational 13th-century Persian poem and a sample of Barack Obama reciting ""Amazing Grace"" into the mix
column2: the album essentially conflates Martin’s post-rebound optimism with an all-encompassing
column3: heal-the-world mission. His relentless need to take us higher feels most genuine when we get a sense of what got him so low in the first place. ""Everglow"" and the Tove Lo collab ""Fun"" bring ultimate closure to the Gwyneth saga with a pledge to enduring friendship (and
column4: to prove it
column5: the former track features Martin’s ex on backing vocals). And despite bearing a title that isn’t going to dispel their poor-man’s U2 rep
column6: ""Amazing Day"" is a sweet ode to blossoming
column7: post-divorce romance that channels the winsome charm of early singles like ""Shiver"". Best of all is ""Birds""
column8: a shot of taut
column9: Phoenix-styled motorik pop that provides a rare moment of intensity on an album that’s all about arm-swaying
column10: Super Bowl-crashing bombast.

column1: Even when A Head Full of Dreams hints at experimentation
column2: it inevitably drifts back onto predictable paths. The title track eases us into the album on a glistening groove but halts its momentum for a now-obligatory ""woah oh oh oh"" breakdown that sounds like it was focus-grouped into the song. When Martin sings ""I feel my heart beating"" on ""Adventure of a Lifetime""
column3: the arrangement drops out
column4: save for a throbbing bassline that mimics the sound of
column5: well
column6: take a guess. And the readymade
column7: gospelized charidee-anthem-in-waiting ""Up&Up"" sees many of the aforementioned guests get together to sing
column8: ""we’re gonna get it together
column9: before Gallagher delivers a send-off guitar solo that essentially turns the track into Coldplay’s Perrier Supernova. At one point in the song
column10: Martin asks
column11: ""How can people suffer/ How can people part/ How can people struggle/ How can people break your heart?"" He doesn’t profess to understand the root of all our problems
column12: but he’ll do his damnedest to provide a cure anyway.

column1: For all the record's eclecticism
column2: Coldplay remain a band that put the ""us"" in ""obvious
column3: blowing up the simplest sentiments for maximum appeal. Nearly every song is about ascension and transcendence
column4: be it through intoxicants (the Beyoncé-assisted ""Hymn for the Weekend"")
column5: rocket ships (the unlisted
column6: listless slow jam ""X Marks the Spot"")
column7: out-of-body experiences (bonus track ""Miracles"")
column8: large ocean waves (""Fun"")
column9: rooftop stargazing (""Amazing Day"")
column10: winged creatures (""Birds"")
column11: or just sheer force of will (""Up&Up""—and this from a band that’s already written a song called ""Up With the Birds""). But Martin has a tendency to sing of extraordinary
column12: mind-expanding experiences in muddled metaphors (""My army of one is going to fight for you … my heart is my gun"") and rote ""high""/""sky"" rhymes. And with his many wide-eyed ruminations on stars and moons and hearts and diamonds
column13: it can sound like he gets his lyrical inspiration from a spoonful of Lucky Charms. Martin recently told the Wall Street Journal that he wanted ""Hymn for the Weekend"" to be the sort of single that would soundtrack a bottle-service bender at a nightclub and
column14: essentially
column15: that spirit of bonhomie permeates the entirety of A Head Full of Dreams. Except too often
column16: the album’s pat platitudes place us on the other side of the velvet rope
column17:
left to ponder the sight of some self-satisfied people having the time of their lives.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22594/homepage_large.f88751f5.jpg|iLoveMakonnen 2|32436.0|iLoveMakonnen|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.'
column2:
'OVO Sound']|2015-12-04 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:25.733452|"

The sense of intimacy social media allows with stars can be tricky. Even in the most naturalistic and organic-feeling social media moments—a Snap of DJ Khaled extolling the virtues of water and cocoa butter; unscheduled Twitter rants that turn into full-blown hip-hop feuds—an element of pre-meditated performance still exists. These guys wouldn't be successful entertainers without that instinct.

column1: iLoveMakonnen is one of a few genuinely engaging artists on Snapchat. When he Snaps himself covered in blankets in a cold hotel room
column2: or of himself confronting pre-show jitters
column3: his personality comes through so clearly it's hard to not feel moved. He's always seemed like a genuinely unique and humble guy
column4: maybe somewhat performatively so. But what social media isn't in some way performative?

column1: This matters in perceiving Makonnen's art because his relatability has always worked in his favor
column2: even when some of his songs threaten to go off-the-rails
column3: since his limited voice can only take him so far. He seems like a guy you know. ""Tuesday"" was a giant hit because it nailed something about the melancholy one feels when out on a weekday—it feels liberating
column4: because so few people are out
column5: but it can also be a stark reminder of the aimlessness that comes when you're unemployed
column6: or depressed
column7: or
column8: in the conceit of the song
column9: dealing drugs on the weekend. But those details didn't matter. We've all had a Tuesday (or Wednesday
column10: or Thursday) night end far later than it should have. And it struck the kind of relatable chord that Drake does well
column11: which naturally led to his golden co-sign.

column1: Fast-forward a year and after this spring's experimental but quietly compelling Drink More Water 5 mixtape
column2: and Makonnen has released the official follow-up to his first EP on OVO Sound. Some of these songs have floated around for a year or so and are staples of his live performances. But more than even the first EP
column3: which delivered a handful of great hip-hop-indebted pop songs
column4: this sequel EP bursts with a confidence that's earned after you go through the hit-song-now-what? grinder. Compared to his last mixtape
column5: the hooks are sharp enough to cut glass
column6: and the sequencing ensures that every facet of Makonnen—from Heartbroken Makonnen to Riotous Makonnen to Warble Makonnen to Onomatopoeia Sex Jam Makonnen—alternates every song.

column1: On the lights-down
column2: open-curtain starter ""Forever""
column3: Makonnen hits the ground running: ""I remember when you said you needed a love that lasted forever
column4: before the ominous beat finally drops. The open-throated ballad kicks off his second EP as ably as Tom Cruise scaling a mountain during the first moments of Mission: Impossible 2. By the time Santigold shows up to memorably rap a few bars
column5: the hooks (literal and figurative) have sunken in—Makonnen is aiming for the fences with his pop instincts.

column1: However
column2: the record is at its best in the contemplative heartfelt-loner love songs
column3: like ""Second Chance"" and ""Being Alone With U""
column4: in which Makonnen embodies his hip-hop-Morrissey role. Closer ""I Loved You"" perfects this formula with a stark piano on a trap beat. Makonnen offers formulaic Drake-isms like ""I know you think about me when I'm not around
column5: but they feel fresh in context because we feel like WeKnowMakonnen.

column1: ""Trust Me Danny"" is the EP's signature moment
column2: a windows-down banger that pays homage both to Makonnen's producer Danny Wolf and a viral Vine. It encapsulates Makonnen's aesthetic as well as his target audience—fans and students of hip-hop who recognize that hooks need to sail for maximum effect for a track to land as a rap anthem. Makonnen isn't another ""weird"" rapper cashing in
column3: making disposable jokes and internet references for a Twitter-ready crowd before everyone wakes up and goes
column4: ""Where are the hits? Where are the hooks?"" On this EP
column5: he's angling to be a real pop star
column6: to step out of the OVO shadow (which hasn't produced a major pop crossover artist since the Weeknd) and onto the radio. It's hard to know if that'll happen
column7: but coming with a likable persona
column8: real pop-songwriting chops
column9:
and an established audience never hurt anybody.

At this point it seems that Underworld are remembered
column2: at least by casual observers
column3: as the rave act most like a rock band. There's nothing really harmful about this interpretation
column4: but acting like a rock band—a euphemism for ""had a frontman""—isn't really what separated Underworld from their peers. After all
column5: the Prodigy and the Chemical Brothers both worked in the album format to great effect
column6: and
column7: like Underworld
column8: their live shows and general demeanor had more in common with Oasis than with
column9: say
column10: Spiral Tribe. In fact
column11: what truly makes Underworld unique
column12: and what coincidentally most closely aligns them with rock bands
column13: is that they took themselves really seriously; their ambitions leaned to the serious and important. Unlike most people—lots of ravers included—they thought these things could be achieved using the rave template.

column1: Second Toughest in the Infants is the band's second
column2: spectacular attempt at making big
column3: important rave music
column4: and their second with young fusionist DJ Darren Emerson helping steer the ship (frontman Karl Hyde and Rick Smith had been making music
column5: in one style or another
column6: since the early '80s). It was reissued for its 20th anniversary this November
column7: in both two- and four-CD editions
column8: remastered and bundled with exclusive and/or unreleased extras. You can see the band posing in the album title
column9: a funny little comment made by Smith's nephew that conveniently reads like poetic word soup. You see this
column10: probably
column11: before you realize the album opens with a 16-minute
column12: three-part suite entitled ""Juanita : Kiteless : To Dream of Love"" and follows that with a 15-minute
column13: two-part suite entitled ""Banstyle/Sappys Curry"". There it is
column14: comrades: a heaping helping of Big
column15: Important Music. If you want funny voices and funny haircuts
column16: the Prodigy are in the tent to the left.

column1: The great thing about mid-'90s Underworld is they made this beat-poetry-cum-rave-anthem splice work against the odds. Their secret was to act as if Hyde was not a vocalist at all but rather a particularly charismatic sampler: spitting out short
column2: repetitive phrases that were afforded little more purchase on a track's mix than any other melodic curlicue. As an album
column3: and as disc one of this reissue
column4: Second Toughest holds up marvelously
column5: dominated by the shapeshifting opening tracks but also featuring fan-favorite ""Confusion the Waitress"" and the stupefying ""Pearl's Girl""
column6: perhaps the fist-pumping-est epic in a discography chockablock with them. ""Stagger""
column7: the tormented kosmische saga that closes the affair
column8: betrays the band's album-centric aspirations and beats Thom Yorke to the meandering electro-ballad by a decade.

column1: The band's profile raised considerably with Second Toughest
column2: which roughly coincided with the release of Trainspotting
column3: the film making prominent use of non-album track ""Born Slippy.NUXX"". The track's popularity
column4: and its association with the movie
column5: perhaps unfairly tethers the band's sound to the '90s
column6: though there's some comfort in remembering a time when music this loopy and progressive could dominate (European) airwaves.

column1: Disc two reproduces all of the exclusive material from the absurdly good Pearl's Girl EP—five long pieces over 35 minutes that would stand as most band's best work even before adding the worthy reworks of the title track—and adds ""Born Slippy (Instrumental Version)""
column2: which functionally has almost nothing to do with the more famous NUXX version
column3: as well as ""Born Slippy.Nuxx (Deep Pan)""
column4: an intriguing but ultimately boring remix.

column1: Disc three offers a full slate of unreleased material
column2: some of which (""D+B Thing""
column3: ""Techno Thang""
column4: ""D'Arbly St"") gives away its throwaway nature by its title. ""D'Arbly""
column5: meanwhile is seven minutes of downtempo lounge noodling. Only an extra version of ""Pearl's"" and ""Bloody 1""
column6: yet another loopy 16-minute epic (Underworld could do no wrong in this format in the mid '90s)
column7: rescue this disc. Disc four offers seven (!) different versions of ""Born Slippy.NUXX"" (often simply titled ""Nuxx"")
column8: several of them live. The main takeaway here is that you do not
column9: in fact
column10: want Hyde's scintillating vocal melody to continue for the entire runtime
column11: no matter how much you think you love the opening minutes. But the disc also illustrates how much Underworld has in common with a jam band
column12: iterating over long passages
column13: massaging a track into form.

column1: Second Toughest marks the last time Underworld's blend of ferocity
column2: earnestness
column3: and expanse felt transcendent. By the time they returned with Beaucoup Fish in 1998 they seemed more like an institution than a contender. But there's an absolute trove of potent material associated with Second Toughest; lesser bands might've mined this period for two or even three albums. The remasters sound great
column4: and the two-disc version makes exploration reasonable for the unfamiliar
column5: though both the original album and the essential Pearl's Girl EP can be had for a song in your local used bin. For the fanatic
column6: the four-disc version offers a couple of gems and a thorough examination of the genesis of the band's most famous track
column7: i.e. exactly the type of thing you might hope for from a not-explicitly-necessary reissue. Underworld made a point of going deeper
column8: and carrying on for longer
column9:
than most bands would dare; they're worthy of a reissue that does the same.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22619/homepage_large.73d64618.jpg|100 Ladies EP|33348.0|Zora Jones|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fractal Fantasy']|2015-12-04 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:26.548496|"

 Zora Jones has described 2010 as her year zero. She saw DJ Rashad spin for the first time at a party in Montreal
column2: where it was pretty much everyone's first encounter with footwork in a club setting. She and her friends ended up spending a week with the Chicago DJ
column3: and he gave them a batch of tracks he'd produced with his Ghettoteknitianz crew. It opened up a whole new world for her. ""That folder is still one of the main folders I go to for inspiration
column4: she told The Fader. ""Those tracks are so crisp to me and so influential. 2010 was the year for me.""

column1: You can hear the late Rashad's influence on Jones' debut EP
column2: 100 Ladies—or at least
column3: you can deduce it. Many of her tracks move at 160 BPM
column4: smack in the middle of footwork's sweet spot. But in the past five years
column5: Jones has also established her own sound
column6: one that's indebted to footwork (and also to grime)
column7: but irreducible to either of those genres. It's several steps removed—and that's a direct result of the work that she's put in.

column1: The title of the Austria-born
column2: Barcelona-based producer's EP is a reference to a pact that she made with herself: to make 100 tracks before she released anything. This isn't the first thing she has unveiled; there have been collaborations with Sinjin Hawke and DJ Taye on FractalFantasy (the imprint she runs with Hawke
column3: which began life as an online outlet for audiovisual productions)
column4: and she's posted the odd solo track to her SoundCloud account. But this is her first extended statement
column5: and the singularity of her vision is immediately apparent.

column1: Aside from the occasional anchoring 808 kick
column2: she favors thin
column3: silvery sounds: brittle rimshots
column4: tinny hi-hats
column5: and 808 toms tuned toward their upper limits. Her main instrument is the voice—resampled
column6: stacked in dizzying fifths
column7: pitched up near dog-whistle frequency
column8: and painted on in bright
column9: loopy brushstrokes. Put together
column10: these elements combine to suggest club music injected with helium and sent bobbing high overhead.

column1: Of the album's seven tracks
column2: only two come anywhere close to resembling established forms. ""Zui""
column3: with its shuddering 808 patterns and stuttering monosyllables
column4: wears its footwork influences proudly on its sleeve
column5: and the lurching cadence of ""Too Many Tears"" sounds like an outgrowth of the ""weightless"" style of grime favored by Mumdance
column6: Rabit
column7: and Murlo. Again
column8: though
column9: her wordless vocal melodies stand proudly apart; they're eerie
column10: shapeshifting things
column11: part violin and part warbling bird
column12: and their effect is spellbinding.

column1: The EP is bookended by its best tracks. The footwork-tempo closer ""First Light"" pumps away like Philip Glass rearranged for tin whistle
column2: Gameboy
column3: and chipmunk
column4: while the opening ""Oh Boy"" forsakes drums entirely; it's just wordless vocal trills pitched up into icy configurations accompanied by the hollow hum of whirly tubes. Despite their novelty
column5: both songs remain unusually moving; for all the flyaway nature of her sounds
column6: her compositions carry real emotional weight. They offer the equivalent of a solid musical form being melted down and channeled into tiny
column7:
sidewinding rivulets; it will be fascinating to see where these streams carry her next.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22623/homepage_large.4fede3dc.jpg|Rivers and Streams|5407.0|Lubomyr Melnyk|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Erased Tapes']|2015-12-04 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:27.707169|"

Ukrainian pianist and composer Lubomyr Melnyk has spent his career developing a method of performance called ""continuous music."" In pieces that stretch anywhere from 10 minutes to nearly an hour in length
column2: Melnyk delivers a sustained flurry of high-speed arpeggiated notes. By holding down the sustain pedal
column3: he allows tones to ring out indefinitely
column4: creating droning ambience and phantom melodies.

column1: The pursuit of continuous music has brought Melnyk impressive chops—his website boasts that he is the fastest pianist in the world—but little in the way of critical recognition or financial reward. In interviews
column2: he has expressed some disappointment at falling through the music industry's cracks
column3: his playing too unorthodox for the classical establishment and too traditional for the experimental music community. However
column4: in the last several years
column5: Melnyk has begun to connect with a larger audience through releases on small labels like Unseen Worlds and Erased Tapes
column6: which concentrate on modern classical and electronic music.

column1: Rivers and Streams is Melnyk's third release for Erased Tapes. In execution
column2: it's not too different from his previous works for the label. The music is busy and technique-intensive
column3: but tuneful and meditative. As Melnyk plays
column4: his melodies meld together
column5: shifting in tone and volume. Because he allows the piano to resonate
column6: the sound blurs
column7: turning concise and complex patterns into aural fog. According to the composer
column8: the album is a meditation on water—not a huge stretch given the steady
column9: trickling
column10: ambient nature of Melnyk's style. The performances are enhanced via co-production from label founder Robert Raths and London-based composer
column11: Jamie Perera
column12: who modestly augment Melnyk's arrangements with guitar.

column1: Informed by the work of American minimalists like Steve Reich and Terry Riley
column2: Melnyk's music draws on repetition and also a certain degree of impromptu inspiration. However
column3: those composers—Riley in particular—often employed alternate tunings and distinctive harmonies that helped to distance their compositions from Western classical music. Melnyk's music is just as expansive
column4: but more conservative in its approach to harmony. He's more overtly romantic. Listening to the plaintive minor key melodies on ""Parasol""
column5: you can understand how
column6: for some
column7: the pianist's sensibility might have crossed the sometimes-thin line that divides minimalist classical and new age.

column1: However
column2: this is less of a liability than it might have been in the past. New age is no longer the reviled genre it once was. And there are other
column3: more appropriate modern parallels. Melnyk's shifting chords and rising crescendos will click easily for those who follow post-rock bands like Godspeed You! Black Emperor or Explosions in the Sky. And in continuous playing
column4: sustained repetition
column5: and simple harmony you can also hear him as a more organic cousin to the burbling synthesizer music of '70s groups like Tangerine Dream or Ashra. This is not machine music
column6: though. It's very human—serenity delivered through sustained concentration and ecstatic energy
column7:
via a lifetime of practice and perfection rather than the twist of a knob.

column3: Sunn O))) played a short series of duo concerts meant to acknowledge the band's modest
column4: mimetic origins. Sunn O))) began as a tribute of sorts to Earth
column5: the influential duo whose low
column6: slow riffs and steadfast amplifier worship established the doom-metal mold that Greg Anderson and Stephen O'Malley were trying to fill anew. And for the first few years
column7: that was the limit of the pair's output—lumbering riffs
column8: played at a near-tectonic pace and deliriously high volumes.

column1: During the next half-decade
column2: however
column3: Anderson and O'Malley evolved. They incorporated a constellation of metal
column4: noise and experimental guests into a series of high-concept records—White1
column5: White2
column6: and Black One
column7: each of which expanded the pair's personnel and possibilities.They staged high-profile
column8: full-length collaborations with counterparts and heroes. They turned concerts in clubs and cathedrals alike into frame-shattering
column9: wall-shaking temporary installations
column10: where robes
column11: fogs
column12: and a shrine of their namesake amplifiers shaped a sort of heavy-metal happening. More than a 10-year anniversary
column13: those 2008 shows represented chances to jettison the excess and prove that the anchoring idea—chords played so long and loud the listener heard every overtone and felt every subtle change—remained potent. The new art-metal masters wanted to show they could still get back to basics.

column1: A year after those concerts
column2: Sunn O))) issued Monoliths & Dimensions
column3: an aptly named colossus that folded a horn section
column4: a choir
column5: a string section
column6: a blown conch shell and black metal legend Attila Csihar speaking slowly into four pieces that were just ridiculous and divergent enough to work. In the years since
column7: collaborations with Ulver and Scott Walker have also pushed Anderson and O’Malley farther beyond the early
column8: atavistic comforts of Earth. Kannon is the first complete Sunn O))) since Monoliths & Dimensions
column9: and it likewise documents a return to the elements for Anderson and O'Malley. Cut with a cast of familiar collaborators playing mere support roles to Anderson
column10: O'Malley
column11: and their amplifiers
column12: Kannon reneges on that progression with a triptych of elegant yet underwhelming arcs and drones. It is typically loud. It is often pretty. It is
column13: cumulatively
column14: the first minor full-length studio album of Sunn O)))'s career.

column1: There are
column2: no doubt
column3: many beautiful and bracing passages throughout Kannon. Few musicians can summon the same mix of patience
column4: intensity
column5: roar
column6: and meticulousness as Anderson and O'Malley; it's wonderful to hear them interact in the pristine
column7: refined acoustic setting offered by producer Randall Dunn. Near the midsection of ""Kannon 1""
column8: the bass
column9: guitar
column10: Csihar's obscured voice
column11: and a capillary of feedback lock into a perfect unison. Even delivered through headphones
column12: the sound is somehow paralyzing and exhilarating
column13: as though a team of masseurs has just found all the right pressure points. The playing is so careful and the recording so crisp that
column14: during ""Kannon 3""
column15: you can listen to chords and notes arrive one by one and track their slow disappearance into the din around them. It's like watching time-lapse footage of solitary raindrops forming a deep puddle.

column1: But where Kannon exceeds as a collection of moments
column2: it fails as both an album and an experience
column3: especially given the general Sunn O))) scale. Brevity may be the only truly new idea the band incorporates here
column4: as these three tracks just break the 33-minute mark. But Anderson and O'Malley don't seem to have squeezed the normal complications and layers into a tighter space so much as omitted them altogether. ""Kannon 1"" slowly gathers its riffs
column5: pulling back the stage curtains for the subterranean rattle of an oddly subdued Csihar. ""Kannon 2"" begins with a wrestling match with a guitar that resolves in feedback and
column6: again
column7: introduces a familiar choir of incantatory voices
column8: all surrounded by a wispy veil of electronic oscillations. The album's most unexpected instant actually comes at that song's end
column9: when one massive
column10: static bass note hangs still in the air. Percussion jostles beneath it
column11: as though the enormous tone were rattling a household cupboard. Rather than explore the strange sound
column12: Sunn O))) simply shut down the amps and discard it. And that's the problem

""Pope Francis releases prog-rock album"" could only be a better punchline if the genre was swapped out with ""chillwave

column1: Pope John Paul II
column2: for context
column3: released three albums during his papacy. They consisted of classical sacred music
column4: and none inspired fond remembrances by the executives who released them (the Pope's records ""shipped gold and returned platinum""
column5: one industry insider<a href=""shipped%20gold%20and%20returned%20platinum
column6: %22""> recently quipped to Billboard). Pope Francis might be different: He is our meme Pope

column1: With collaborators that include a folk-swami

column6: building momentum that halts when Pope Francis starts speaking. The opening track is ""Annuntio Vobis Gaudium Magnum!""
column7: the Latin for ""we announce with great joy."" Following that phrase is an assumed ""habemus papem
column8: or ""we have a new pope

column1: The song titles in Wake Up!

column3: are in many ways better than the songs themselves. There’s a climate change track (""Cuidar El Planeta""); another track whose title translates to ""The Church Cannot Be an NGO!""
column4: and one in Spanish that translates to ""Faith is whole
column5: does not liquefy!"" There’s a track in Italian whose title translates to ""Do not steal the hope!""

column1: On it

column4: the track gridded loosely by a high-hat. ""It is a duty to be vigilant

column6: to a crowd in South Korea

column8: the temptations and the sins to dull our sensibility of the beauty of holiness."" But

your graceless way of saying Yes.

In the late 1980s and early '90s
column2: Kenneth ""Babyface"" Edmonds
column3: along with songwriting partners Daryl Simmons and L.A. Reid
column4: developed a form of pop soul that's as geometrically precise as it is weightless. Songs like Toni Braxton’s ""Breathe Again""
column5: Madonna’s ""Take a Bow""
column6: and Boyz II Men’s ""Water Runs Dry"" occur in a seamless universe
column7: all undisturbed surfaces that relentlessly shimmer. In 1995
column8: ""Water Runs Dry"" itself seemed the most formally perfect incarnation of one of Babyface's primary pop expressions
column9: the vaporous ballad; it’s gently animated by a brushed snare and an acoustic guitar
column10: over which the members of Boyz II Men weave their voices together in fluid braids.

column1: Babyface’s aesthetic is a distant refinement and elaboration of Prince and
column2: beyond that
column3: Curtis Mayfield
column4: both of whom condensed pop and soul into irreducible collage. He’s capable of elastic funk and vast balladry but both are organized by an unusual pop sensitivity. Return of the Tender Lover

column6: is part a period of renewed productivity for Babyface. Last year he released an album with Toni Braxton called <i>Love
column7: Marriage & Divorce
column8: which described the length of a relationship through both gliding surfaces and reduced
column9: raw circumstances; this year he contributed minimal blossoms of acoustic guitar to the Ty Dolla $ign single ""Solid"". But his new album is a kind of retreat—Babyface reduced to plush textures. Though Return of the Tender Lover deliberately references his sophomore album
column10: 1989’s Tender Lover
column11: nothing here is as dry and muscular as ""It’s No Crime""
column12: or generously expansive as ""Whip Appeal"". In their place is buoyant
column13: effortless pop soul.

column1: It sometimes feels like a conscious inversion of Love
column2: Marriage & Divorce; where that record was often capable of a fluorescent hostility
column3: Return of the Tender Lover almost exclusively communicates security and support. ""We've Got Love"" and ""Love and Devotion"" convey an inflexible confidence
column4: and the songs also seem supportive in their structure
column5: as if engineered for maximum uplift. Babyface’s voice is as smooth as it's ever been
column6: but it’s also always been somewhat granular in design; it sounds like a bloom of smoke.

column1: El DeBarge appears on ""Walking on Air""
column2: his first duet with Babyface since 1994’s ""Where Is My Love""; like Babyface
column3: DeBarge has been minimally present in the music industry over the past ten years
column4: except for a solo album
column5: Second Chance
column7: and in brief flourishes on DJ Quik records. His presence here is satisfying both texturally and textually
column8: and ""Walking on Air"" is as rich and vivid as their previous collaborations. DeBarge’s voice is miraculously preserved
column9: an incandescent peal capable of infinite ascent; in ""Walking on Air""
column10: it seems to land somewhere in the troposphere. The only other collaboration on the record is with After 7
column11: an R&B group from the '90s that contains two of Babyface’s brothers. On ""I Want You""
column12: they supply harmonies

column14: and repeating the title until it melts into a kind of plural exhalation.

column1: The collaborations on Return of the Tender Lover and the design of its production feel traditional
column2: in the sense that they don't attempt to update Babyface's sound and instead lean comfortably on a long
column3:
established career. This dedication to tradition and honoring of his craft is less a throwback than a micro-adjustment of an enduring formula.

There's little better than the mixture of punk speed and metal riffs. Punk tempo supplies the adrenaline injection that metal's compositional superiority clearly needs. Massachusetts' Magic Circle are a variation on this principle: its members come from a variety of hardcore and punk bands
column2: such as Mind Eraser
column3: the Rival Mob
column4: Innumerable Forms
column5: and Doomriders
column6: and they make traditional metal with a deceptively youthful spunk. Even as most of its members were known figures in their home state
column7: Magic Circle's debut still came out of nowhere in a sense: who knew they were capable of this? Their second record
column8: Journey Blind
column9: doesn't have the mystique of the first
column10: but it makes up by being more assertive.

column1: With its faster rhythms paying homage to that nook when NWOBHM was picking up but thrash hadn't quite emerged
column2: the lead-off title track shows the influence of Stone Dagger
column3: which features bassist Justin DeTore
column4: vocalist Brendan Radigan
column5: and guitarist Chris Corry
column6: bleeding into Magic Circle. Don't get fooled by the Mellotron intro and think this will be a prog effort. Corry
column7: along with Dan Ducas
column8: turn every melody and lead into a hesher motivational speech. ""The Damned Man"" takes the majesty of the title track and gives it a more proto-thrash
column9: biker-like thrust. Radigan is the ideal vocalist for this material
column10: going in for maximum horn-raising wailing while maintaining a tough edge in most of the verses.

column1: Another spirit that Magic Circle absorb
column2: albeit not as obvious
column3: is that of early Pentagram. Radigan's vocal range is greater than that of Bobby Liebling's
column4: but he is able to convey darkness with a light of hope shining through
column5: like Liebling before he descended into the path that's been covered to death elsewhere already. ""Ghost of the Southern Front"" is where the Pentagram influence really emerges
column6: with Corry and Ducas adding a macabre boogie to their riffing. Their ending solos have that purgatorial feeling of Pentagram's ""Death Row""
column7: perfect for looping. Closer ""Antedivullan"" begins with a softer passage not unlike Black Sabbath's ""After Forever""
column8: and when they rage into their standard battle charge
column9: the song's placements gives it a do-or-die urgency. Much like Metallica's ""Damage Inc.""
column10: it's a choice anthem for going down swinging.

column1: Magic Circle belong to a special group of new traditionalist bands alongside High Spirits
column2: Crypt Sermon
column3: Ranger
column4: Iron Age
column5: and (on the more progressive
column6: much weirder end) VHÖL. All of these bands wear their influences on their battle jackets while bringing a real hunger to the table. Journey isn't just a great heavy metal record
column7: it also dismantles the narrative that punk was put on earth to rid rock of its excesses. Hardcore kids can do something with more complicated structures too
column8:
and can draw the same sense of purpose that metal has been excellent in instilling for decades.

Across several albums and EPs
column2: the singer and composer Diggs Duke has channeled the greats of '90s hip-hop and soul

column4: he caught the attention of British DJ and tastemaker Gilles Peterson

column6: and made what I thought was a nice splash on 2014’s The Upper Hand & Other Grand Illusions

column1: On Civil Circus

column3: yet the vibe here is firmly rooted in jazz. Album opener ""Busker""
column4: with its mix of saxophones and live drums

column1: Civil Circus is full of shape-shifting compositions that make the album feel longer than its 26-minute runtime in a good way. The music feels remarkably spacious
column2: and Duke’s songwriting is equally abstract and observational: Civil Circus conveys Duke’s innermost thoughts

column4: and Civil Circus feels like a deep chat with a close friend. It’s almost gospel-like
column5: and ""Compensation""—a poem by Paul Laurence Dunbar—hits the theme head-on: ""God
column6: in his great compassion/ Gave me the gift of song."" ""Stoplight Lessons"" speaks to the newness of life and uncertainty of growing older. ""Old enough to crawl
column7: Duke hums atop an acoustic guitar

column1: The album's structure gives way to a loose instrumental procession toward the end: ""Street Preacher"" and ""Bumper to Bumper"" stamp the LP’s panoramic view; ""Damn Near Home""
column2: with its light horns and scenic moans
column3: sets the scene for album closer ""We Don’t Need Love""
column4: which chides superficiality. It’s a fitting end for the album and the impressive career Diggs has built so far. Civil Circus is about being honest and vulnerable. It's about looking up to observe the small things that make life so fruitful

and taking the time to appreciate what's normally taken for granted.

When music from the project SOPHIE first emerged in 2013
column2: it sounded state-of-the-art. It was the work of a producer who had rarely been photographed and who never gave interviews
column3: which seemed appropriate if also tiresome. Such mystery had long become a cliché by this point
column4: but uncertain authorship suited these bulbous
column5: sparkly audio objects
column6: which seemed to float down out of the sky like a cluster of neon-colored balloons ready to pop. ""Bipp"" and ""Elle""—the former impossibly buoyant with an earworm vocal line
column7: the latter featuring deep bass and chasms of space
column8: a bright and twinkly counterpoint to the grim tone common to dubstep—promised that future music was going to be weirder and more disorienting than we imagined but that it would also function as a bent version of popular song.

column1: Two years and several singles later
column2: SOPHIE—long known to be the work of London-based producer Samuel Long—is now understood mostly in the context of PC Music
column3: a loose UK collective centered on producer A. G. Cook that recasts brazen commercialism as a kind of winking postmodern art project. PRODUCT
column4: which collects the SOPHIE singles to date and adds some new songs
column5: was released in limited-edition versions that packaged it with a jacket
column6: sunglasses
column7: and platform shoes
column8: as well as a version sold with an object that looked like a sex toy. When you take into account that bounty of merch
column9: and add the fact that SOPHIE’s ""Lemonade"" has in the last year been used to soundtrack a McDonald’s commercial
column10: of all things
column11: it’s clear that the act of buying and selling is deeply embedded within this project.

column1: You might look at all this as a Warholian transformation of commerce into art or you might just see a run-of-the-mill cash-in
column2: but neither of these perspectives adds much to the enduring brilliance of SOPHIE’s first pair of singles. Following on ""Bipp"" and ""Elle""
column3: ""Lemonade"" intensifies the sound
column4: like switching from a freshly squeezed glass of the titular drink to drinking Minute Maid concentrate right out of the cardboard can. Befitting music constructed at least in part as a critique of consumerism
column5: SOPHIE’s tracks are gleaming and immaculate on the surface and hollow to the core beneath it. ""Hard""’s chiming synths and rippling bass are again set against wide spaces of unnerving silence
column6: a void where a deeper sense of meaning might be.

column1: These tracks argue
column2: often convincingly
column3: that the surface is everything. It’s Turing Test pop: if its exterior catches your ear and makes you feel things
column4: that communication is proof enough that some kind of soul resides inside the machine. The closing track here
column5: ""Just Like We Never Said Goodbye""
column6: shows this contrast in widescreen. It’s a melodic construction worthy of Max Martin
column7: but the pitched-up voice
column8: drum-free production
column9: and generally half-finished feel highlight all the immediate pleasures of pop music while completely erasing the idea of a point of view. It’s so ""almost there"" you can’t help but play it over and over.

column1: But SOPHIE is not
column2: alas
column3: an album-length proposition. Even at 26 minutes
column4: the record drags
column5: and the three song stretch of ""MSMSMSM""
column6: ""Vyzee""
column7: and ""L.O.V.E.""—that’s 38 cents of your album dollar—is depressingly skippable. These tracks either recycle bits from the earlier singles (chirpy vocals
column8: squeaky percussion) or fold in new elements that sound mundane (trap percussion
column9: doomy synths)
column10: leading to tracks that sound like they could have come from anybody. That these are the newer songs doesn’t help matters or bode particularly well for what might come next. And then there’s the fact that music this compressed and this syrupy is best heard in small doses
column11: before your ear gets tired listening to it.

column1: So the main problem with PRODUCT
column2: ironically enough
column3: is one of format. Every industrialist wanting to get his or her goods to the world knows that you have to package them properly. Heard individually and spaced many months apart
column4: the best tracks here were diamond-hard realizations of very specific sonic ideas; placed on an album alongside songs that use similar ingredients but are markedly inferior
column5: they rattle around in the can
column6:
perfect objects in search of the right container.

Jlin's debut album Dark Energy felt like a keyhole peek into a bedroom producer's mind. In the broad array of vocal and synth samples
column2: off-beat time signatures that varied from song to song
column3: and even within the song itself
column4: the conjunction of tens of ideas competing for dominance
column5: you could hear a singular aesthetic being forged. One can imagine Jlin (Jerrilynn Patton) spent hours crafting the music in a way that spoke to her.

column1: On her new EP
column2: Free Fall
column3: this same excitement is still at work
column4: though not in a manner as excitingly weird as Dark Energy. Dark Energy was a record for the individual
column5: feeling more at home for solo listening than in a club setting. Free Fall feels like a tribute to the sounds that brought her to where she is. It is critical that these tracks are gathered on a single EP; it's not that they don't have a place in her larger oeuvre
column6: but they also feel distinctly familiar in a way that Dark Energy did not. But because Patton is still smarter than almost any of her peers
column7: it means that Free Fall creates the kind of thrills that only she can provide. The EP builds to peaks that grip the heart in a joyful vice; the listener will feel both excited and overwhelmed and unsure which emotion to embrace over the other.

column1: Certain songs elicit this feeling more than others. ""Eu4ria""
column2: like the aptly named ""Guantanamo"" from her debut
column3: layers piercing screams and yells to create a horror-laden universe in three minutes. The track also sounds connected to Dark Energy closer ""Abnormal Restriction""
column4: as definitive a statement about Patton's musical identity as you'll get. Populated with samples of Faye Dunaway's turn as Joan Crawford in Mommie Dearest
column5: ""Abnormal Restriction"" added a blood-freezing exclamation point to the end of the album. ""Eu4ria"" is lighter; Patton sampled an iconic phrase from the original film version of Stephen King's Carrie. ""They're all gonna laugh at you
column6: Carrie's mother yelled to her daughter in the film. Here
column7: the phrase is interspersed in a frenetic beat that transforms it from a cry of anger and desperation to one of defiance.

column1: ""I Am the Queen"" and ""BuZilla"" are two biting pieces of footwork that don't let up and shouldn't. It's not the sometimes lovely structural sonics of classic Chicago South Side footwork. Instead
column2: like the EP itself
column3: the tracks push things into weirder realms of aural storytelling in a matter of minutes. ""BuZilla"" reuses the phrase ""live and let die."" The longer one listens to the track
column4: the more it feels like a call that refuses to wait for a response. Whatever happens will happen. Patton will continue to create regardless. It's an aggressive and focused answer to her ""genre."" Whereas Dark Energy was fueled by a personal
column5: cinematic vision of doom
column6: Free Fall is an invigorating wash of sounds
column7:
a collection of ideas that meld together the past with Patton's present to form another hard-won and potent artistic statement.

In the half-decade since Swans reformed
column2: they have hammered away at a monolithic
column3: all-consuming sound with unwavering focus. The three albums they've released since Michael Gira resurrected the project—2010's My Father Will Guide Me Up a Rope to the Sky
column4: 2012's The Seer
column5: and 2014's To Be Kind—taken together with contemporaneous tours and live albums
column6: all feel like variations upon a single theme
column7: expressions of an essential Swans-ness.

column1: For a while
column2: though
column3: they were the most mutable of bands. In a half-decade span beginning in the mid '80s
column4: they swiftly transformed from bone-crushing no wave brutalists to God-fearing gothic rockers
column5: and then to featherweight neo-folkies. White Light from the Mouth of Infinity and Love of Life
column6: originally released in 1991 and 1992
column7: respectively
column8: marked the end of that metamorphosis
column9: as the band settled into a sound at once songful and vast
column10: luminous as a glass menagerie and forceful as a falling anvil.

column1: The two albums have long been treated as minor works in Swans' discography: out of print for years
column2: they were cherry-picked (alongside selections from 1989's major-label fiasco The Burning World and the Gira/Jarboe side project the World of Skin) for 1999's inauspiciously titled Various Failures 1988-1992. ""I'm ambivalent about much of it
column3: but then what do I know????"" Gira has written of the music on that anthology. ""Some of it is genuinely good I think. Anyway
column4: I was learning (how to write a song) as I went.""

column1: It's true that the period marked a shift from pummeling mantras to something more ""musical
column2: with singing instead of shouting and cascading chords instead of just drop-tuned gut-punches. That said
column3: even here
column4: Gira's concept of ""songwriting"" remains idiosyncratic: there's little in the way of verse/chorus structures
column5: mainly just mantra-like incantations and chords wreathed around gleaming pedal tones surrounded by wide-open expanse. Drummers Anton Fier (White Light) and Vincent Signorelli and Ted Parson (Love of Life) lay into their snares with military gusto
column6: driving the music forward in surging tattoos
column7: and their nonstop rattle contributes to a sensation of overwhelming excess. Close your eyes
column8: and you can practically see the sounds exploding like fireworks against the darkness of your lids.

column1: The textures and tone colors are well suited to Gira's favorite themes
column2: like love
column3: death
column4: and the sublime. Where early Swans lyrics were notable largely for their grueling power dynamics and limitless abjection—see ""Raping a Slave""
column5: ""Filth""
column6: ""Cop""
column7: etc.—here Gira explores a more nuanced perspective. It's hardly all kittens and rainbows; both albums are littered with ugliness
column8: from the dirge-like ""Better Than You"" (""So glad I'm better than you
column9: he sings
column10: in the world's most dead-eyed Dear John letter) to the claustrophobic ""Amnesia""
column11: where he tells us ""sex is a void filled with plastic"" and ""everything human's necessarily wrong."" Gira has rarely wallowed as beautifully as he does on ""Failure""
column12: one of the great nadirs—in the best way possible—of the band's catalog. Over bluesy acoustic guitar and frigid digital synthesizers
column13: his preacher's drawl drips like blood from a stone; it would be hard to imagine a voice with more gravitas.

column1: But Gira has never met a dichotomy he could resist—he eats love and hate

column3: for breakfast—and here we can see the pendulum beginning to tip from darkness back to daylight. ""Her"" wraps clanging
column4: Children of God-style thunderbolts around one of the tenderest love songs Gira has ever written
column5: and ""Song for the Sun""
column6: ""Love of Life""
column7: and ""The Sound of Freedom"" all stretch their arms wide to embrace the limitless possibility of the universe
column8: anticipating the way that love and spiritual ecstasy will return to the fore in the group's post-reunion work
column9: particularly on 2014's To Be Kind.

column1: A bonus disc accompanying the reissues is mostly anticlimax. It features a handful of alternate takes and mixes from both albums

In the half-decade since Swans reformed
column2: they have hammered away at a monolithic
column3: all-consuming sound with unwavering focus. The three albums they've released since Michael Gira resurrected the project—2010's My Father Will Guide Me Up a Rope to the Sky
column4: 2012's The Seer
column5: and 2014's To Be Kind—taken together with contemporaneous tours and live albums
column6: all feel like variations upon a single theme
column7: expressions of an essential Swans-ness.

column1: For a while
column2: though
column3: they were the most mutable of bands. In a half-decade span beginning in the mid '80s
column4: they swiftly transformed from bone-crushing no wave brutalists to God-fearing gothic rockers
column5: and then to featherweight neo-folkies. White Light from the Mouth of Infinity and Love of Life
column6: originally released in 1991 and 1992
column7: respectively
column8: marked the end of that metamorphosis
column9: as the band settled into a sound at once songful and vast
column10: luminous as a glass menagerie and forceful as a falling anvil.

column1: The two albums have long been treated as minor works in Swans' discography: out of print for years
column2: they were cherry-picked (alongside selections from 1989's major-label fiasco The Burning World and the Gira/Jarboe side project the World of Skin) for 1999's inauspiciously titled Various Failures 1988-1992. ""I'm ambivalent about much of it
column3: but then what do I know????"" Gira has written of the music on that anthology. ""Some of it is genuinely good I think. Anyway
column4: I was learning (how to write a song) as I went.""

column1: It's true that the period marked a shift from pummeling mantras to something more ""musical
column2: with singing instead of shouting and cascading chords instead of just drop-tuned gut-punches. That said
column3: even here
column4: Gira's concept of ""songwriting"" remains idiosyncratic: there's little in the way of verse/chorus structures
column5: mainly just mantra-like incantations and chords wreathed around gleaming pedal tones surrounded by wide-open expanse. Drummers Anton Fier (White Light) and Vincent Signorelli and Ted Parson (Love of Life) lay into their snares with military gusto
column6: driving the music forward in surging tattoos
column7: and their nonstop rattle contributes to a sensation of overwhelming excess. Close your eyes
column8: and you can practically see the sounds exploding like fireworks against the darkness of your lids.

column1: The textures and tone colors are well suited to Gira's favorite themes
column2: like love
column3: death
column4: and the sublime. Where early Swans lyrics were notable largely for their grueling power dynamics and limitless abjection—see ""Raping a Slave""
column5: ""Filth""
column6: ""Cop""
column7: etc.—here Gira explores a more nuanced perspective. It's hardly all kittens and rainbows; both albums are littered with ugliness
column8: from the dirge-like ""Better Than You"" (""So glad I'm better than you
column9: he sings
column10: in the world's most dead-eyed Dear John letter) to the claustrophobic ""Amnesia""
column11: where he tells us ""sex is a void filled with plastic"" and ""everything human's necessarily wrong."" Gira has rarely wallowed as beautifully as he does on ""Failure""
column12: one of the great nadirs—in the best way possible—of the band's catalog. Over bluesy acoustic guitar and frigid digital synthesizers
column13: his preacher's drawl drips like blood from a stone; it would be hard to imagine a voice with more gravitas.

column1: But Gira has never met a dichotomy he could resist—he eats love and hate
column2: sprinkled with a bit of good and evil
column3: for breakfast—and here we can see the pendulum beginning to tip from darkness back to daylight. ""Her"" wraps clanging
column4: Children of God-style thunderbolts around one of the tenderest love songs Gira has ever written
column5: and ""Song for the Sun""
column6: ""Love of Life""
column7: and ""The Sound of Freedom"" all stretch their arms wide to embrace the limitless possibility of the universe
column8: anticipating the way that love and spiritual ecstasy will return to the fore in the group's post-reunion work
column9: particularly on 2014's To Be Kind.

column1: A bonus disc accompanying the reissues is mostly anticlimax. It features a handful of alternate takes and mixes from both albums
column2: along with a Burning World-era B-side
column3: selections from the World of Skin's Ten Songs for Another World
column4: and a few live songs from Omniscience and Anonymous Bodies in an Empty Room
column5: plus another live cut
column6: ""The Unknown""
column7: that doesn't seem to have been released before but probably could have stayed that way. There's a fair amount of overlap with Various Failures
column8: and the sequencing is haphazard
column9: zigzagging from release to release without much rhyme or reason.

column2: and her a cappella rendering of ""Drink to Me Only with Thine Eyes""
column3: a centuries-old popular English song
column4: is a welcome addition. (Both are from the World of Skin's 1990 album Ten Songs for Another World.) That the bonus disc leaves off ""God Damn the Sun""
column5: The Burning World's heartbroken highlight
column6: seems like a missed opportunity. In fact
column7: at this point
column8: a full Burning World reissue (along
column9: perhaps
column10: with both the band's 1988 ""Love Will Tear Us Apart"" covers) is long overdue
column11: no matter how much Gira professes to regret making that album. Who knows
column12: maybe he'll eventually come around. But for now
column13: for anyone who wants to understand Swans' path from atonal self-flagellators to beatific supplicants of the sublime
column14: these two reissues light the way

Jadakiss' first LP in over six years had its title as far back as 2010
column2: when ""Top 5 Dead or Alive"" appeared on The Champ is Here 3 as a teaser for a record due later that year (and then in 2012). Like the original Champ is Here mixtape
column3: 3 proved far superior to Kiss tha Game Goodbye and Kiss of Death
column4: but it was bittersweet all the same for highlighting Jadakiss' strengths (spitting raspy punchline bars over someone else's beats) and admitting to his weaknesses by omission (putting actual songs together
column5: getting those beats for himself). Impressive first-week sales notwithstanding
column6: no one expects Jadakiss to be a commercial force anymore
column7: which would presumably work to his advantage. Without the temptation to cater to a non-existent audience clamoring for him to make pop songs
column8: you'd figure the boundaries between ""album"" and ""mixtape"" would no longer exist. This is kinda true of Top 5 Dead or Alive; the problem is that one of the world's best and most frustratingly aimless rappers ends up in the same no-man's land he always does.

column1: The good news is that Jadakiss' typical means of scoring a chart hit is completely outmoded in 2015
column2: so there aren't any chintzy Neptunes beats
column3: unctuous R&B hooks or blatant attempts to recreate ""Why"" in its entirety. Yeah
column4: Future shows up on the ""street single""
column5: but he did the same favor for Uncle Murda this year—don't confuse his appearance for a guarantee of any kind of chart success. While Jadakiss can wild out on his own terms
column6: the gothic turn-up of ""You Can See Me"" is a long way from the Tunnel; for not a single second are we led to believe that We the Best producer Lee on the Beats
column7: Future and Jadakiss were ever in the same room
column8: let alone the same frame of mind here.

column1: Otherwise
column2: Jadakiss continues to show why he was a perfect fit to do player introductions for the Brooklyn Nets back in October—Top 5 Dead or Alive is likewise an intermittently entertaining
column3: but dead-end collective of big-money heavyweights long past their prime. Puff Daddy's yelling spree on ""You Don't Eat"" might as well have been sourced from a Bad Boy conference call in 1996. On ""Kill
column4: Lil Wayne continues his path towards tragicomic
column5: Neil Hamburger-esque performance art: ""She a Cancer
column6: I hit her with that chemo dick"" would be a prime candidate for Weezy's preeminent sad trombone line of 2015 if he didn't just quote Smash Mouth on No Ceilings 2. While Jeezy occupies a similar ""veteran hardhead"" ground as Jadakiss at this point
column7: ""Critical"" doesn't try to find common ground; instead
column8: it's the kind of hyperactive hi-hat beat that predates Thug Motivation 101 with Jada on a double-time Dirty South flow that interrupted ""who's the best MC?"" discussions during the late 90s in New York.

column1: Despite its street-level money
column2: power and respect rhymes
column3: almost all of it feels divorced from reality
column4: free of any kind of narrative grounding or personal disclosure: ""you can call me Paul/ long as Peter pay
column5: ""If you ain't in the circle
column6: for a square I'll get you lined"" are typical punchlines that generate a smirk and disappear completely
column7: mildly impressive feats of wordplay that only have meaning within the format's strictures. You might as well be watching Jadakiss solve crossword puzzles.

column1: There are brief indications that Top 5 Dead or Alive was workshopped within the past three years. There's a track about smoking weed and
column2: wouldn't you know
column3: Wiz Khalifa is on it instead of Redman. The chorus of ""Jason"" gives brief mentions to Eric Garner and Ferguson. Otherwise
column4: Jadakiss has to remind you of a time when ""top 5 dead or alive"" was something fans of mainstream rap actually discussed: ""Synergy"" is the requisite give-n-go tandem rap with Styles P and it's flagrantly modeled after ""We Gonna Make It""
column5: right down to the cadence of the hook. Even if there isn't the requisite track here in the style of ""Why
column6: Jada can't help but invoke its most infamous line (the one about Bush knocking down the towers). In the most desperate recall of his glory days
column7: Jadakiss spits
column8: ""you heard my name on the last verse of 'Ether
column9: '"" which is technically true but feels like the equivalent of a boxing judge taking credit for Ali/Frazier.

column1: Beyond muddled aims
column2: extremely confusing and tone-deaf skits also seem to be a constant on Jadakiss projects. ""Ahaa Interview"" is a Madd Rapper-style Q&A where a salty veteran claims he's going solo over his resentments towards Jadakiss. You'd swear this was a scorched-earth attack on Sheek Louch
column3: except the guy shows up two tracks later. I mean
column4: Puff Daddy is here too
column5: so I guess he didn't take ""Rape'n U Records"" skit to heart either. More importantly
column6: a patron who sure sounds a lot like Busta Rhymes starts complaining about how heads don't check for ""bars"" anymore and now it's all about dancing and wearing blouses. You'd swear this was a diss against Young Thug
column7:
who's frankly been packing more inventive wordplay into a single verse these days than Jada does on the entirety of this ""rapper's rapper"" album.

Junglepussy is working within a lineage of comedic rappers
column2: from Biz Markie to Ghostface Killah to Cam'ron and Action Bronson
column3: rappers who elevate the muck and mundanity of life with zany non-sequiturs
column4: ad libs
column5: and references. In terms of sharp-witted artists who led to the increasingly rare seismic belly laughs on the subway this year
column6: she's up there with novelist Paul Beatty
column7: whose 2015 book The Sellout sent up American politics and culture in a way that proves good satire can change your truth. Junglepussy's Pregnant With Success is another reminder of how humor can bring the audience closer and form an emotional connection. It's as bright as Beatty's novel is dark
column8: but they're both charmingly demented
column9: sharp-witted
column10: and necessary social critiques. They remind me how humor can transform literature and music
column11: forms that often aren't as empirically funny as film and television
column12: bringing the audience closer and forming an emotional connection.

column1: She has a rare confidence that's rooted in playfulness: ""This pussy don't pop for you
column2: she gloats on ""Pop For You""
column3: a song with watery snares and a glitchy melody. The hook feels like she's playing a character
column4: a parody of contemporary male rappers
column5: but it's more of a roast that has its roots on the surreal experience of being a woman in 2015. It also riffs on the language of the oppressor
column6: so to speak. Junglepussy spits: ""You look up to these dudes to tell you who to screw/ What she'll look like if she your type/ Compliment her if she's light/ If she's black don't get her hype."" The joke comes at the end
column7: when she compares a guy who takes her to the zoo versus one who buys her leopard print lingerie: ""I got niggas taking me to see live animals and you're pulling up with animal prints?""

column1: It's her perspective as a black woman
column2: a regular woman
column3: from New York City that makes this album transgressive. She raps as much about her voracious appetite as she does about fashion and sex. She references Money and Violence and haute Japanese eatery Nobu over a series of glossy melodies and booming bass courtesy of producer Shy Guy. She swiftly cycles through cadences that approximate the balloon-lunged bellowing of Ludacris and a spiky Da Brat flow. On ""Country Boy""
column4: a song that feels like a nod to her Trinidadian and Jamaican roots
column5: she channels Lady Saw's squawk and the grim commands of Buju Banton before issuing a whimsical sign-off: ""I be dutty winin' down the Yellow Brick Road!"" The beat on ""Get to Steppin'"" is the album's most aggressive: a synthetic Orientalist synth loop fights with battering bass and Junglepussy is in your face
column6: exhorting you to step off whilst bigging herself up (""I was fuckin' with me when you wasn't""). It ends with a hilarious outro
column7: a dorky jingle about online shopping and a rush of true swagger: ""When your Fendi boots come in the mail
column8: time to front on everyone in here.""

column1: But mostly Junglepussy is pure idiosyncratic id; she is unapologetically crass (""If your face ain't a sitting place
column2: fuck up out my face"") and freewheeling. Pregnant With Success' appeal lies largely in hearing Junglepussy talk shit like one of the girls
column3: with the aim of pulling apart the patriarchy as she experiences it. She uses humor
column4: the voice curling with every joke
column5: to replicate the situations and street corners of her own life. And when you're listening and laughing out loud on the subway
column6:
that's Junglepussy's smart truth-telling finding its way into yours.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22546/homepage_large.541e5a18.jpg|But You Caint Use My Phone|537.0|Erykah Badu|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-12-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:35.299081|"

When Erykah Badu found out that her friend and collaborator J Dilla passed away in February 2006
column2: her mind reeled. The producer was just 32
column3: felled by a rare blood disease that clogged his body with clots and a case of lupus that caused his immune system to go haywire. Badu thought of a story Dilla's mother told her about her son's dying days
column4: when she would find him having conversations with an unseen companion. One time
column5: when she asked him who he was talking to
column6: he said it was Ol' Dirty Bastard
column7: who had died in 2004. As Badu recounted years later
column8: Dilla explained to his mom: “He was telling me what bus to get on when I cross over. He said
column9: ‘Don’t get on the red bus
column10: get on the white bus. The red bus looks fun
column11: but that’s not the one.’” That memory inspired Badu to write a song called ""Telephone""
column12: which starts: ""Telephone
column13: it's Ol' Dirty/ He wants to give you directions home/ Said it won't be too long.""

column1: ""Telephone"" originally appeared on Badu's 2008 album New Amerykah Part One (4th World War) and it's reprised in chopped-and-screwed form as a tribute to another late rap producer
column2: DJ Screw
column3: on the singer's new mixtape
column4: But You Caint Use My Phone. For the 44-year-old ankh-worshipping R&B iconoclast
column5: phones aren't just emoji factories or Candy Crush receptacles—they're mystic devices that can span time and space
column6: heaven and Earth. According to Badu
column7: phones can enhance our ability to communicate deep desires across oceans
column8: but they can also jumble our meaning with static or frustrate with busy signals and voicemail. As an extension of ourselves
column9: phones can be heartbreaking
column10: lustful
column11: smart
column12: dumb
column13: noisy
column14: distracting
column15: powerful.

column1: But You Caint Use My Phone is a mixtape in the true hip-hop sense
column2: as it largely finds Badu putting her spin on other artists' songs. Created alongside a young producer and fellow Dallas denizen named Zach Witness in just 12 days
column3: the tape feels off-the-cuff
column4: yet also steeped in history and wisdom. This paradoxical quality can be found in much of Badu's work over the last two decades as well as on her initial inspiration for this tape
column5: Drake's ""Hotline Bling""
column6: the SoundCloud loosie-turned-smash about late-night buzzes with a beat taken from Timmy Thomas' 1972 anti-war plea ""Why Can't We Live Together"". ""Hotline Bling"" is old and new
column7: R&B and hip-hop
column8: serious and fun—it's a song that might not exist without the pioneering work of Erykah Badu
column9: so it only makes sense for her to reclaim it.

column1: But rather than putting her stamp on a slew of 2015 hits
column2: Badu reaches back across the last 40 years of phone-related pop
column3: patching the Isley Brothers
column4: Usher
column5: Egyptian Lover
column6: and New Edition through her own frequency. As a kid who grew up listening to her family's Marvin Gaye
column7: Stevie Wonder
column8: and Chaka Khan records before falling in love with hip-hop in the '80s—her first concert was Run-D.M.C. and she began her musical career as a rapper known as MC Apples—Badu has always been ideally positioned between the reverence of classic soul and the irreverence of hip-hop. And on But You Caint Use My Phone she taps into her own language and influence along with everyone else's.

column1: The title of the tape and its blaring opening suite reference her 1997 kiss-off ""Tyrone""
column2: and the playful ""Dial’Afreaq""
column3: a remake of the early electro-rap hit ""Dial-A-Freak"" by Uncle Jamm's Army and the Egyptian Lover
column4: offers a brief history of Baduizm: ""'On & On' and Mama's Gun/ Underwater ill motherfucker from the other sun."" Further referential depth comes courtesy of producer Witness
column5: a one-time child turntable prodigy who was a toddler when Badu started her career. He first came to the singer's attention through his remix of ""On & On""
column6: and he melds his star's offbeat spontaneity and cosmic funk with a sleek SoundCloud-ready sheen. Another relatively unknown new artist Badu brought on for the project
column7: rapper ItsRoutine
column8: doesn't come off as well. His two Drake-impersonating verses (""Erykah on my hotline
column9: he misdirects) are bizarrely
column10: well
column11: phoney—annoying prank calls on what should be a highly protected line.

column1: Badu
column2: a self-described ""analog girl in a digital world
column3: has a clear fondness for old-school
column4: pre-cell models with buttons that pushed and dials that turned. It's a nostalgic stance from someone who became famous a decade before the introduction of the iPhone
column5: but it can also be convincing. ""Phone Down"" has Badu pleading for someone to disconnect from the grid and plug into real life
column6: but the track's sinister synths and her melancholy delivery suggest that she knows it's probably too late.

column1: And yet. The mixtape's final track
column2: a revamp of the Todd Rundgren/Isley Brothers '70s hit ""Hello It's Me""
column3: features André 3000—aka the father of Badu's only son
column4: Seven—leaving his phone on the table in an effort to find some clarity
column5: and it works. In the late '90s
column6: Badu and Dre were a much-celebrated hip-hop couple
column7: a model of black enlightenment and creativity. They broke up after a few years but remained close
column8: and André famously apologized to Badu's mother on OutKast's ""Ms. Jackson""
column9: promising his commitment to fatherhood: ""Know that everything's cool/ And yes
column10: I will be present on the first day of school
column11: and graduation."" And as Seven turned 18 last month
column12: his parents are still talking
column13: still figuring things out
column14: still collaborating on art. As their duet fades out here
column15: both voices come together
column16:
and the conversation keeps going.

column2:
We Didn’t Talk|32264.0|GoldLink|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Soulection']|2015-12-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:35.941294|"

On GoldLink's 2014 debut mixtape The God Complex
column3: the then-20-year-old rapper nailed a difficult balance: soft sounds
column4: hard rhymes. The music—an uptempo mixture of house music and hip-hop signifiers (GoldLink coined the term ""future bounce"" for it)—offset lyrics full of hypermasculine
column5: purposefully exaggerated sexual boasts and street-savvy narratives. There was something indescribable about hearing the high-voiced rapper spit something like ""Dick to the face
column6: might choke"" 0ver bubbly champagne synths
column7: and the tape caught on
column8: along with its signature hit ""Ay Ay"". The Washington
column9: D.C. rapper toured alongside Mac Miller
column10: as well as electronic producers like SBTRKT and Kaytranada. He even caught the attention of Def Jam founder/music visionary Rick Rubin
column11: who has served as a mentor for his debut album
column12: <i>And After That
column13: We Didn't Talk.

column1: And After That
column2: We Didn't Talk is not a significant sonic departure from Link's previous work
column3: but it carries more thematic weight. The album concerns a relationship and subsequent breakup he had when he was 16
column4: but telling a six-year-old story also leaves the door open for very selective memory. The woman in question remains nameless throughout the album
column5: and though he freely talks about a ""Que"" (with whom she was cheating on Link)
column6: an ""Allan"" (a likely previous boyfriend)
column7: and sprinkles other biographical notes
column8: the bigger picture of why this moment and this person matter so much to Link that he dedicated his first studio album to her is often missing.

column1: Instead
column2: And After That communicates GoldLink's state of mind. He is reflective on the opening track
column3: ""After You Left""
column4: hopeful on ""Zipporah""
column5: with its gospel chant bridge
column6: ""Lord
column7: Lord
column8: I need your help
column9: Lord."" The following three songs (""Dark Skin Women""
column10: ""Spectrum""
column11: and ""Dance on Me"") best encapsulate his hip-hop/dance hybrid sound
column12: and find Link returning to the sexual braggadocio of The God Complex
column13: which is often where he finds the most joy as a writer (listen to his very vivid description of cunnilingus on ""Dance on Me"").

column1: Toward the album's end
column2: Link ventures into R&B and
column3: at times
column4: completely abandons rapping. He sings about his obsessive love on ""Palm Trees""
column5: and while it's still unclear why he's obsessed
column6: his pained vocals make you believe. The same emotion comes through on ""Polarized"" when he sings
column7: ""Go down South to Atlanta with your sister and/ I'll fly you myself
column8: if I have to."" In that song
column9: all we learn about the subject is that she's a 5'7"" model
column10: but Link is convincing enough as a communicator to make up for the lyrical gaps.

column1: And After That
column2: We Didn't Talk is not quite as immediately exciting as its predecessor
column3: which was a burst of aphrodisiac energy. GoldLink feels tugged down occasionally by the story he is trying to tell. As he said in an interview with Pitchfork
column4: ""I feel like 99% of niggas lie in they raps; I don't."" The literal truths
column5: however
column6: distract from how he expresses them. GoldLink is a total-package artist
column7: someone who does not have to rely entirely on facts to succeed as a rapper. His music works when every element blends together
column8: and <i>And After That
column9:
We Didn't Talk is most interesting when he shares only the most vital details from a moment. It's then that he can wring his experiences for their emotions and convey feelings with more than just words.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22596/homepage_large.af6a97c4.jpg|Broken Flowers EP|32521.0|Danny L Harle|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['PC Music']|2015-12-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:36.597465|"

""Broken Flowers"" is often cited as the most fully-realized PC Music single
column2: a polished gem of a track released on a famously ephemeral label. Its author
column3: Danny L Harle
column4: is a shadowy figure
column5: even by PC Music standards. We do know that he's a childhood friend of label head A. G. Cook (with whom he performs in Dux Content)
column6: a classically trained composer
column7: and seems to have played a foundational role in defining the PC Music aesthetic. And yet
column8: he's only released a few solo tracks since the label's emergence—he might be the least prolific SoundCloud phenom this side of Jai Paul.

column1: Anticipation for new music from Harle is understandably high

column5: and the heart and soul behind every lab creation."" Clocking in at 4 songs and just under 15 minutes
column6: the Broken Flowers EP is a focused
column7: purposeful release
column8: clearly meant to introduce the PC Music sound to new listeners and commercial heights.

column1: The EP is bookended by the titular single—closing track ""Awake for Hours"" is really just a remix of ""Broken Flowers"" that speeds up the original to a breakneck pace. Luckily
column2: ""Broken Flowers"" is still a thrilling listen two years on. This is the closest thing the label has to a deep-house cut
column3: a song that would feel at home on almost any dancefloor despite its winkingly maudlin lyrics. The track builds with impressive precision
column4: with sinuous arpeggios
column5: marimba notes
column6: and reverberating vocal samples clicking into place atop a driving 4/4 beat. What's more
column7: it sounds as if Harle has rebuilt the song from scratch for this release; where the original reveled in cliché house sounds

column1: The two new songs

column3: don't disappoint
column4: even as they diverge from the template Harle sketched out on ""Broken Flowers"". Both tracks hew much closer to the PC Music playbook
column5: with chirpy
column6: pitched up vocals sitting atop glistening
column7: Technicolor synths. ""Without You"" is a clear standout

column9: exploring the tension between helium-inhaling vocals and confessional lyrics. The implication here is unclear—we're either being invited to dismiss the heartbroken pop song as naive or confront the infantilization of female narrators in pop. Harle's role as the male auteur behind the curtain further complicates our understanding
column10: lending the song the sort of discomfiting air that's become a PC Music trademark.

column1: As compelling as the music on the Broken Flowers EP is

column5: maybe/ This could be real

column7: ironically
column8:
""Trust me.""

column1: Deep Inside You is the centerpiece of Love Is a Hurtin' Thing
