column7: Taylor was actually born in a coal-mining town in West Virginia and is still very much with us.

column1: That Gloria Ann Taylor didn't become a household name isn't of much concern now. It's difficult to become a star
column2: much easier to be star-crossed
column3: to find your music lost to time. So the fact that she never made it is not cosmic injustice so much as the actual indifference of the universe. It was in fact at the start of Taylor's career as a soul singer based in Toledo that she had her best shot at stardom. Compared favorably to Aretha Franklin
column4: she had a powerful
column5: church-bred voice that caught the attention of one of James Brown's arrangers and associates
column6: Walt Whisenhunt
column7: fresh off of working on Doris Troy's ""Just One Look"". They became both musical partners and a couple.

column1: The number of forgotten
column2: obscure
column3: or lost soul singers revived in the 21st century runs long and deep
column4: the ""personal sacrifice
column5: failed relationships
column6: and missed opportunity"" that these notes describe are all attendant of this peculiar genre. But before allowing hard-knock biography to color the reception of Love Is a Hurtin' Thing
column7: just listen to the opening seconds of the title track. A blistering psychedelic guitar solo
column8: like something left off of Nuggets
column9: flares across the opening 10 seconds
column10: but 20 seconds in

column1: As production choices for a potential hit single in the early 1970s go

column3: where the strings

column5: and Taylor's voice are all doused in heavy reverb

column7: yet at that

column9: only to sidle back into darkness
column10: perching at the edge of the void.

column1: Harrowing and feverish as these sides are

column3: a befuddling megamix comprised of the original version of the track as well as chunks of previous singles ""How Can You Say It"" and ""Music""

column9: magnificent and forlorn
column10: defiant and defeated
column11: an emotional speedball. Heard in 2015
column12: the music is as indelible and inscrutable as ever. Or
column13:
as Taylor once sang about love: ""It's a mystery no one can explain.""

In any given year

column8: Ty Rex

column1: Ty Rex arrived two months before Goodbye Bread

column3: ""Imaginary Person""
column4: etc.)

column9: lizard-brained Segall took a step back. Instead
column10: he showed restraint
column11: recording an aesthetic stepping stone between the fuzz pop fury of Melted and the comparative lethargy of Goodbye Bread.

column1: He didn't just run through the hits
column2: either. It opens with ""Fist Heart Mighty Dawn Dart""

column5: and the vocal melody is smoothed out from Bolan's stilted chorus. Segall's groove is even more gradual on his reading of the 1968 track ""Salamanda Palaganda""

column2: which features demos and acoustic versions of Slider songs. It's Bolan at his most restrained and pared back—proof that his songs were already gold before he slathered on the extra gilding (string sections
column3: layered electric guitar solos
column4: and so on). Ty Rex is also an album-length acknowledgment of Bolan's core strengths. Throughout
column5: Segall plays it straight—the solos are never excessively flashy (sticking close to the originals) and the recording quality is slightly muffled. He never attempts a Bolan impression
column6: either
column7: and he largely forgoes any untethered Slaughterhouse wildness to play up Bolan's melodies
column8: chord progressions

column10: and you don't attempt to outswagger one of rock'n'roll history's most confident heartthrobs.

column1: Of course

column3: so he still brings some of that fire. His previously unreleased version of ""20th Century Boy"" is Ty Rex at its most fuzzy and abrasive
column4: packing the record's most impressive
column5: sky-high guitar solo. But every pound of rock'n'roll aggression is tempered by more withdrawn performances
column6: like the slow burn of ""The Motivator""
column7: ""Cat Black""
column8: and ""The Slider"". That's what the best T. Rex records are like
column9: too—for every ""Rip Off""

column1: Clearly
column2: Segall could do more than one installment of Ty Rex. During his Ty Rex set at Gonerfest 12
column3: people went nuts at just the suggestion of ""Bang a Gong"". There are several reasons why Segall is well-suited to this material—he's a guitar hero and his voice is in exactly the right register. He's an excellent showman and a rock'n'roll screamer

column5: deft
column6: and exciting performances
column7:
Segall also clearly has a reverence for these songs. As Segall works through Bolan's discography—from the early acoustic stuff to the big tent T. Rex singles—he's offering a convincing invitation to deep dive into Bolan's discography.

Dave Grohl is as much of a rock 'n' roll ambassador as he is a rock musician at this point

column1: The same unintended gap in perspective between Grohl's aw-shucks persona and his output defines Saint Cecilia

column1: Whenever that reputation threatens to stick

column2: he is further than ever from having a distinct voice; Foo Fighters remain our most unknowable and emotionally blank rock stars. Grohl's hooks are wide enough to catch any feeling
column3: —""Things are gonna go
column4: no matter what I say/Nothing's set in stone
column5: no matter what I say""; ""Who you runnin' from?""; ""No one lets everyone in."" Foo Fighters are a power-pop band in this sense. But amidst the plodding alt-roots of ""Iron Rooster""

The Olympia
column2: Wash.
column3: trio Beat Happening were a band often labelled ""twee"" or ""love rock"" because of their stripped-down instrumentation and childlike art direction and song titles
column4: but their music had a darker cast. I remember seeing them perform at Wetlands in New York City in the 1990s
column5: and how unnerving it was when bandleader and K Records cofounder Calvin Johnson made eye contact with the crowd and held you in his gaze while he rubbed his belly and sang in his deep baritone. Johnson's presence carried weight. Beat Happening toured with Fugazi and were covered by Seaweed. Kurt Cobain got a tattoo of the K Records logo. There was an edge to this music
column6: and it’s still there.

column1: Beat Happening's lyrics
column2: which included images of hand-holding and hot chocolate
column3: scan as innocent
column4: but the guy in ""Hot Chocolate Boy"" got his name because he’s ""deep sweet and bitter
column5: watching TV alone and wishing he had a girlfriend. The songs are populated with zombies
column6: witches
column7: blood sucking. Even on their most famous song
column8: ""Indian Summer""
column9: with its idyllic sense of longing

column1: History is never complete
column2: which is why compilations like Look Around are helpful. Easy downloads and streaming can definitely bring into question the need for compilations—why buy a collection of previously released songs when you can find most of them online? But what you’re paying for—or at least scanning the track list for—is the curation. The 23-song Look Around is perfect in that regard. There will always be favorites missing—it’s the nature of compilations—but there are no major oversights or head-scratching inclusions here. It’s a great primer for new Beat Happening fans
column3: and as it turns out
column4: an excellent reminder for those of us who’d kind of forgotten about them. The songs are presented in chronological order
column5: so it feels like a distilled time capsule
column6: and it offers a chance to watch patterns emerge and themes continue in time-lapse.

column1: It’s not the first compilation to focus on the band. There was the now out-of-print 7xCD Crashing Through box set contained all their albums
column2: plus some rarities. The 15-song Music to Climb the Apple Tree By
column3: which focused on just B-sides
column4: felt a bit thin. Here we get a taste of each era. The selections are pretty evenly distributed
column5: with a few songs from 1985’s self-titled debut (the one with the cartoon cat driving a rocket ship on the cover)
column6: 1988’s Jamboree (featuring a drawing of a heart-shaped strawberry)
column7: 1989’s Black Candy (a simple drawing of black candy)
column8: 1991’s Dreamy (the only album featuring the band on the cover)
column9: and 1992’s You Turn Me On (which featured a tasteful artistic nude). They’ve also appended 2000’s ""Angel Gone""
column10: from a single produced by Phil Elverum (the B-side
column11: ""Zombie Limbo Time""
column12: appeared on Music to Climb the Apple Tree By). These songs still sound fresh. Maybe because the arrangements are so basic and stripped down
column13: without any overzealous studio tricks or instrumentation that ties it to a particular year
column14: they feel timeless. Or
column15: more accurately
column16: out of time. I think the emotion is important
column17: too
column18: because these lyrics focus on simple human situations most of us have probably experienced.

column1: For a lot of people
column2: 1991’s International Pop Underground Convention in Olympia
column3: a six-day festival organized by Johnson and his K co-founder Candice Pedersen that featured performances from Fugazi
column4: Bikini Kill
column5: Built to Spill
column6: Unwound
column7: L7
column8: Bratmobile
column9: Mecca Normal
column10: and others
column11: made more sense
column12: and had more of a mythology to it
column13: than Nevermind
column14: which first hit later that same year. Beat Happening and their cohorts represented a part of the Pacific Northwest scene that was less interested in playing bigger venues or making it on MTV.

column1: And this still matters now
column2: in part
column3: because 30 years after the release of their debut
column4: there’s a lot of music that hearkens to the band and the K scene they helped spearhead. You can hear them in Girlpool
column5: Frankie Cosmos

but their real legacy is found in basement venues and DIY spaces and groups just learning how to play but not being afraid to do so in public.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22621/homepage_large.93218efe.jpg|9th House|33367.0|Muja Messiah|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-11-30 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:39.779835|"

You can scoff at astrology and still be moved by 9th House
column2: the long-awaited collaboration between Minneapolis-St. Paul hip-hop pioneers Muja Messiah and I Self Devine. The record’s title and some of its window dressings gesture at Jupiter’s movements
column3: but the artists find themselves planted firmly in the Twin Cities streets they’ve defined and documented over the past two decades.

column1: For those unfamiliar
column2: Muja made a name for himself in the early 2000s with a string of show-stealing guest verses
column3: before his solo LPs—like last year’s <i>God Kissed It
column4: the Devil Missed It—solidified him as the Cities’ sneering id. (He’s also written verses for several of your favorite yacht-owning rappers.) I Self Devine’s legacy stretches back even further: together with DJ Kool Akiem as the Micranots
column5: he was one of the first genuine Minneapolis stars
column6: to the point where his nod helped solidify Rhymesayers in its infancy.

column1: Rapping together for the first time at length
column2: it’s quickly apparent that Muja and Chaka invert the old duo dynamics. The two MCs still present the point and counter-point on a single theme
column3: but where the variance in many a group setting has come from each rapper’s writing
column4: it’s evident on 9th House mostly in the tone of the vocals. Self is gruff
column5: guttural
column6: and earnest
column7: and Muja’s voice is the audio equivalent of that .gif where Birdman rubs his hands together in front of doves and an explosion.

column1: That’s seen most clearly on ""Arrow Dynamics"": Muja’s ""Diagnosed: ADHD/ For white folks
column2: that’s a disability"" and Self’s ""Well-dressed niggas get hit
column3: like
column4: ‘Where the product at?’/ White trash pulling dime sacks out their Prada bags"" complement each other
column5: while in more similar hands they might combine to be too on-the-nose. The song’s hook
column6: though
column7: converges at the group’s de facto mission statement: ""Gun up on my hip
column8: I won’t bust it at my nigs/ But I guarantee I’m shooting at the cops
column9: though."" It’s clear
column10: and it’s potent.

column1: And it’s morbidly prescient: On November 15th
column2: a Minneapolis police officer shot and killed a 24-year-old black man named Jamar Clark. Multiple eyewitnesses say Clark was handcuffed when the fatal shot was fired; police deny that he had been handcuffed
column3: but have yet to release video of the incident. Protesters reacted swiftly
column4: shutting down the I-94 freeway and
column5: more recently
column6: occupying the 4th Precinct in North Minneapolis. It was there that five protesters were shot
column7: apparently by a small group of white supremacists. (No one was critically injured.) The following night
column8: more shots were fired at those assembled. At the time of this writing
column9: hundreds of people remain in the blocks surrounding the precinct
column10: and thousands have marched through downtown Minneapolis demonstrating against Clark’s killing
column11: the absence of video evidence
column12: and the police response to the subsequent shootings.

column1: Muja has even inserted himself into the protests
column2: demanding answers in Mayor Betsy Hodges’ foyer and clarifying that he’s a “concerned citizen” unaffiliated with any political movement. That sounds about right: 9th House is mostly an act of collage
column3: with pro-black
column4: anti-police sentiments dominating its most lucid moments. There’s malt liquor
column5: gold slippers
column6: and promises to ""suplex label reps
column7: but when the MCs cut through
column8: they do it with a knife that’s carefully pointed. On ""IOFWUCUC"" (an acronym for ""I Only Fuck With You ‘Cause You Crazy"")
column9: Self raps
column10: ""Dreaming of peace and violence/ Don’t wanna be a martyr/ Defiance in my blood running as clear as water."" For two men who would seemingly expect their closest confidants to read between the lines
column11: some anxieties are made refreshingly clear.

column1: The most striking part of 9th House
column2: perhaps even more than its politics
column3: is how it's equal parts loose and specific to its environment. The former quality is thanks to beats from J.Hard
column4: M¥K
column5: and Orko Eloheim
column6: the latter to the Holiday Inn on Eleventh Street and Rashad McCants. In an unsettling time for Minneapolis-St. Paul
column7:
9th House is the record the Cities have created for themselves.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22590/homepage_large.77da837b.jpg|Paranoid London|33355.0|Paranoid London|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Decks']|2015-11-30 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:41.222702|"

Since its inception
column2: acid house was received far more enthusiastically in the UK than in the U.S. Writing about his favorite tracks for Fact
column3: Ed DMX said: ""Even though nearly all the best records were made in Chicago
column4: the music took off in a big way over here
column5: [where] it was massively popular
column6: much imitated."" The UK top 100 for 1989 boasts the likes of Inner City's ""Good Life""
column7: Lil Louis's ""French Kiss""
column8: and British early adopter A Guy Called Gerald's ""Voodoo Ray"" while the U.S. charts bear out that we all but ignored our homegrown sound (though we charted Marshall Jefferson's “Move Your Body” as blanched by the Belgian act Technotronic as ""Pump up the Jam""). No historian or music critic would ever categorize 1989 as Chicago's ""second summer of love"".

column1: Beginning in 2007
column2: singles began emanating from a British label and act known as Paranoid London. The duo of Gerardo Delgado and Quinn Whalley
column3: flashed an unfettered enthusiasm for—and emulation of—the mad whinnying frequencies of the 303
column4: but coupled it to an ethos that in the 21st century might more closely align with punk. They didn't do any press
column5: didn't promo their music
column6: didn't upload mixes to Soundcloud to build buzz
column7: and when they released their debut album at the end of December 2014
column8: there was no digital version. While the group were much discussed in Europe and the UK
column9: there was nary a ripple nor mention made stateside.

column1: A year on
column2: the ten track album is now readily available digitally and on CD. For an electronic music culture increasingly bloated
column3: glitzy
column4: and insufferable
column5: Paranoid London is a refreshing punch to the nuts. The tracks that Delgado and Whalley craft are simple as a prison shiv
column6: not adding layers of gloss or paint to its acid-house
column7: but stripping it back to its basics. Almost every track is erected from the same blocks: handclaps bright as tin foil
column8: dry snares
column9: sharp hi-hats
column10: concussive kicks
column11: all of it buoyed by queasy undulations of bass. They emulate Trax and those shoddy
column12: shady days of Chicago pressings to the point that you expect a chunk of rubber to be embedded in the records themselves.

column1: There are spot-on acid house bangers like ""Headtrack"" and ""Paris Dub 3"" that evoke peak Junior Boy's Own releases as well as late-'80s Chicago. On the latter
column2: the duo collaborate with Paris Brightledge
column3: a vocalist on early tracks by Sterling Void and Joe Smooth. The coup de grace is the deadpan intonation of Mutato Pintado; on the wet cardboard thud of ""Transmission 5""
column4: he switches out words that range from the inane to the lurid: ""skin on my shoes...feeling good...lipstick...hair in my hand...late night..."" and at one point
column5: he croons about ""playing by the rules"" then suppresses a small chuckle.

column1: Playing by the rules of making classic acid house while also laughing at them
column2: setting up expectations and then undercutting them: It's what Paranoid London does best. “Lovin U (Ahh Shit)” is a love song but the title sends mixed signals
column3: approximating the cross purposes of hook-up culture. ""You've got the green light/ right past the stop sign"" DJ Genesis sings in her monotone
column4: juxtaposing ""forever loving you/ just a little bit."" Its sentimental in a way that works with the group’s decidedly cheeky unsentimental manner.

column1: Earlier this summer I got to see Paranoid London play live as part of Amsterdam’s Dekmantel festival. They were sandwiched between two legends: DJ Harvey and Derrick May. But after a weekend of DJs coolly manipulating laptops
column2: turntables and drum machines
column3: there was something visceral about PL's live set
column4: less clinical
column5: more chaotic. The crowd churned like a mosh pit rather than a dance floor and rather than throw cake into the crowd
column6: Mutato Pintado brandished a bottle of vodka lifted from backstage and began to pour full cups of it
column7:
passing it out to the crowd.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22451/homepage_large.8b1f0d01.jpg|A Love Supreme: The Complete Masters|798.0|John Coltrane|['Jazz']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Verve']|2015-11-25 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:41.398318|"

John Coltrane was a late bloomer. Born in 1926
column2: the same year as Miles Davis
column3: he spent his twenties in and out of small-time bands
column4: a promising journeyman moving between playing jazz and the more bar-friendly music that was starting to be called R&B. During these early years he had problems with narcotics and alcohol
column5: alternating stretches of heroin use with periods of binge drinking. Charlie Parker—every sax player's hero when Coltrane was coming up in the 1940s and '50s—had given the junkie life a romantic aura for some naive souls
column6: connecting drug use with creativity. But the underachieving Coltrane was a run-of-the-mill addict
column7: someone broke and in ill health whose habit clearly kept him stuck in place. He was fired from Miles Davis' band in 1957 for showing up on the bandstand dressed in shabby clothes and visibly drunk—by some accounts he took a punch from the trumpeter before being given his walking papers. And if Coltrane had spiraled and his career had ended there
column8: he'd be remembered now as a musician who flamed out just as he was discovering his voice.

column1: But that's not what happened. Everything changed for Coltrane in 1957 when
column2: as he wrote in the liner notes to his defining album
column3: A Love Supreme
column4: he ""experienced
column5: by the grace of God
column6: a spiritual awakening which was to lead me to a richer
column7: fuller
column8: more productive life."" During that year
column9: Coltrane stopped drinking and kicked heroin
column10: and from that point forward
column11: his career would unfold with an almost frightening amount of focus and intensity. These final 10 years are when Coltrane made his mark on the world of jazz as a leader
column12: and he was then seemingly always on the move
column13: in transition
column14: each moment glimpsed as a blur on a continuum rather than a fixed point in space. He wasn't just covering ground
column15: he was accelerating
column16: and every phase of his later career has the attendant feeling of stomach-dropping free-fall
column17: of being pushed forcefully into new places.

column1: A Love Supreme
column2: recorded with what was later called his classic quartet
column3: is Coltrane's musical expression of his 1957 epiphany. It's the sound of a man laying his soul bare. Structured as a suite and delivered in praise of God
column4: everything about the record is designed for maximum emotional impact
column5: from Elvin Jones' opening gong crash to the soft rain of McCoy Tyner's piano clusters to Coltrane's stately fanfare to Jimmy Garrison's iconic four-note bassline to the spoken chant by Coltrane—""a-LOVE-su-PREME
column6: a-LOVE-su-PREME""—that carries out the opening movement
column7: ""Acknowledgement"". By the time the record gets to the closing ""Psalm""
column8: which finds Coltrane interpreting on his saxophone the syllables of a poem he'd written to the Creator
column9: A Love Supreme has wrung its concept dry
column10: extracting every drop of feeling from Coltrane's initial vision. It's as complete a statement as exists in recorded jazz. Hearing it now as part of this exhaustive 3xCD set
column11: which gathers every scrap of material recorded during the sessions as well as a live performance of the suite from later the same year
column12: you get a clearer sense than ever before of the different forms A Love Supreme might have taken
column13: and how Coltrane's desire to communicate something specific and profound led to its final shape.

column1: A Love Supreme is also one of the most popular albums in the last 60 years of jazz
column2: selling the kind of numbers usually reserved for pop (it quickly sold more than 100
column3: 000 copies
column4: and has almost certainly sold more than a million since). If Miles Davis' Kind of Blue is the most frequently bought first jazz album for those curious about the genre
column5: A Love Supreme is easily number two. But though they were released just seven years apart
column6: there's a world of difference between the two records
column7: and the success of A Love Supreme is trickier to explain. For all its structural daring
column8: Kind of Blue also functions as an ambient record
column9: with slower tempos and late-night ambiance. A Love Supreme is harder to get a handle on. If you can think of Coltrane's work on a continuum
column10: from the gorgeous melodicism of ""My Favorite Things"" or Ballads or his album with Duke Ellington on one end and the brutal noise assault of the 1966 concerts collected on Concert in Japan on the other
column11: A Love Supreme sits perfectly at the fulcrum
column12: challenging enough to continually reveal new aspects but accessible enough to inspire newcomers.

column1: Coltrane may have structured the record for just this effect. He had already been further ""out"" than the music heard on A Love Supreme
column2: including some of the knotty extended jams like ""Chasin' the Trane"" recorded at his 1961 sessions at the Village Vanguard. He was fascinated with the innovations of Ornette Coleman from the minute he heard them in the late '50s
column3: and though he never completely abandoned chord changes
column4: he regularly flirted with atonality
column5: improvising outside of a fixed key. With A Love Supreme
column6: it was almost as though Coltrane knew he had to dial things back a little in order to share his message of spiritual rebirth with a wider audience. Though conventionally beautiful in many ways
column7: A Love Supreme is
column8: for many
column9: the exact point beyond which jazz becomes too experimental.

column1: It's possible to hear on this set how the album might have gone even further. At a time when a single track might have a dozen collaborators working on it over the course of weeks
column2: it's a little mind-boggling to consider that the music on A Love Supreme was recorded on a single day
column3: December 9
column4: 1964. This wasn't uncommon for jazz records of the time. But though they had the music in the can from that first day
column5: Coltrane wanted to try something else. So on December 10
column6: he called the young tenor saxophonist Archie Shepp
column7: and a second bassist
column8: Art Davis to play with his quartet. The six musicians then ran through two versions of A Love Supreme's opening ""Acknowledgment""
column9: so that Coltrane could explore what the music might sound like with another horn and additional low-end rhythm. Shepp was an up-and-comer deeply influenced by Coltrane; the two takes of ""Acknowledgment"" featuring Shepp find him serving as a kind of textural counterpoint
column10: his more brittle and biting tone commenting on the melody from an oblique angle and hinting at possibilities existing outside of the version recorded the day before. You sense a more abrasive road not taken
column11: one that almost certainly would have found a smaller audience.

column1: We hear a different perspective on the fantastic live version of the suite recorded in France five months after the album's release. Five months in '60s Coltrane time was like a decade in the career of other jazz musicians
column2: and he was already imbuing the A Love Supreme material with an extra intensity. Tyner's clanging chords on ""Resolution"" have a harsher edge
column3: and Coltrane's attendant soloing is much rougher and more pointed
column4: his notes seeming to attack the structure of the composition from several directions rather than floating along above it. This is the hard-blowing sound that Coltrane would show on Meditations
column5: another spiritually focused album-length suite recorded later in 1965 that never had a chance at A Love Supreme's level of mainstream acceptance.

column1: In the same year
column2: Coltrane would also record Om and Ascension
column3: two harsh and challenging pieces of music that strain against the boundaries of what most people would even consider music. Given what surrounds it
column4: and how sweet and gentle it so often is
column5: A Love Supreme was an expression of a very specific time and place
column6: a conscious attempt by Coltrane to communicate something to his audience that was broad enough to be understood but rich and complex enough to honor both where he was as a musician and the depth of the subject matter. A Love Supreme sounds like nothing else in John Coltrane's discography
column7: and indeed like little else in recorded jazz
column8: sitting at the nexus of so many competing musical ideas.

column1: The final piece of the A Love Supreme equation concerns the civil rights movement and black liberation
column2: and how those swirling ideas were inextricably tangled up with the jazz avant-garde.  Coltrane was never overtly political
column3: but he did allow his thoughts and feelings to bleed into his music. Coltrane met Malcolm X
column4: wrote a piece for Martin Luther King Jr.
column5: and his 1963 dirge ""Alabama""
column6: a piece with a close tonal connection to A Love Supreme's ""Psalm""
column7: was written to commemorate the four girls killed in the Birmingham church bombing that year. As the '60s wore on
column8: politically conscious ""fire jazz"" grew in currency
column9: much of it directly inspired by Coltrane's music
column10: but during his life he never quite felt the need to connect his music to specific social currents
column11: even as others drew inspiration from it in that context. Coltrane was seeking something broader
column12: communing with God as he understood it.

column1: For Coltrane
column2: that spiritual journey led him to <i>A Love Supreme
column3: which became the base he'd explore from during his short time left on Earth. Coltrane occupies a unique position in jazz history. He was famous
column4: especially in the jazz world
column5: but he wasn't really a personality. He was not inclined toward interviews and he wasn't very good at them
column6: preferring to let the music speak for itself. He didn't have the mystery of a Thelonious Monk
column7: the tragic genius of a Charlie Parker
column8: the cool comfort with celebrity or flamboyance of a Miles Davis
column9: the combative verbal dexterity of Charles Mingus
column10: the theoretical underpinnings of Ornette Coleman
column11: the comfort with the mainstream of Louis Armstrong
column12: or the symbolic stature of Duke Ellington. He led a quiet life
column13: putting everything into his music.

column1: His chaotic years mostly came when he was an unknown; by the time he was a major jazz figure
column2: almost his entire life was music. If he wasn't on stage or in a recording studio
column3: he was practicing or studying records. Seemingly every other story of an encounter with Coltrane in the 1960s involved him in a room with a saxophone in his hand
column4: playing scales. In his mind
column5: God had saved him
column6: and he was going to give back. A Love Supreme was his expression of gratitude
column7:
a hopeful prayer for a better world.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22602/homepage_large.e2c8fd1c.jpg|Monastic Living EP|30832.0|Parquet Courts|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rough Trade']|2015-11-25 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:42.100786|"

On ""No No No!""
column2: the opener of Parquet Courts’ new mini-LP Monastic Living
column3: Andrew Savage declares in a mangled grunt
column4: ""I don’t want to be called a poet/ Don’t want to hang in a museum/ Don’t want to be cited
column5: tacked onto your cause/ No
column6: no
column7: no/ I’m just a man."" From a band who've typically resisted disenchantment against the odds
column8: it’s an alarming statement of rejection. On 2012's Light Up Gold
column9: Savage and co-songwriter Austin Brown blazed through mundane minutiae–<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Aq1LtxdpQEo"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""train death paintings
column10: anti-meth murals""–yet saw beauty in the banality; on last year’s ""Content Nausea""
column11: released as Parkay Quarts
column12: Savage yelled denunciations of the digital era in excited bursts
column13: like a smalltown newsreader reporting alien landings. Pitched between stoner gags and urgent instructions
column14: their sizzling one-liners felt like a bulwark against capitalist dread
column15: the battle between righteousness and resignation. Monastic Living
column16: their debut EP for Rough Trade presumably ahead of a full-length in the new year
column17: is them saying
column18: ""We’re tired
column19: that’s enough.""

column1: ""No No No!"" is unique to the record
column2: in that it has words
column3: a hook
column4: a rhythm you could tap
column5: a sonic and philosophical destination
column6: and replay value. In the liner notes
column7: the track’s expanded lyric sheet blends cliché (""We’re just a band
column8: ""retreat into solitude"") and aphorism—""Perhaps silence is purity of spirit""—into a grave mission statement. The remaining eight tracks aren't just wordless but tuneless; they're sometimes baffling
column9: often boring
column10: and always deliberately so.

column1: Part of what makes ""No No No!"" work is that its litany of targets—""open letters
column2: long reads""—is broad enough to appeal to everyone’s digital unease. Parquet Courts are resolutely unchill (""Life’s lived best when scrolling least
column3: Savage sang on ""Content Nausea"")
column4: bewildered by the hot takes and the jostling think-pieces
column5: as are we all. But these are popular targets
column6: and without the counterweight of wit
column7: Parquet Courts' grand disavowal feels reactionary. On Monastic Living
column8: they make a personal decision to reject a web culture constantly renegotiating what it means to be socially conscious (""I don't want to be an essayist!"" begins Savage's salvo)
column9: and in doing so they reclaim art’s right to political neutrality. As statements go
column10: it’s fine but hardly revolutionary—a passionate shrug.

column1: Redeeming moments in the music are scarce. One is ""Vow of Silence""
column2: with its clattering drums
column3: pleading
column4: squealing guitars
column5: and haywire arpeggios
column6: which resemble the misfiring pistons of a manic brain. ""Alms for the Poor""
column7: comprising several seconds of a postpunk riff that dies suddenly
column8: sounds like the husk of a practice session; a chugging number called ""Monastic Living I."" is Battles without the epiphanies.

column1: Unlike that paragon of artistic rejection
column2: Lou Reed’s Metal Machine Music
column3: which actually coheres rather nicely
column4: the EP has little textural detail; the music is not immersive
column5: much less transcendent. It isn’t just a score to modern ennui but a work that itself feels indifferent. Yet it’s presented with a straight face: The band are touring the EP and we can buy it
column6: though I’m unsure why anyone would—perhaps its existence as a paid-for product is part of the statement. What it means for the band’s future is
column7: for now
column8: a mystery
column9:
though not the kind it is fun to unravel.

Even with assistance from the Internet
column2: some cult records still have to travel off beaten paths
column3: their pleasures imparted by friends in the know. Just how I came to know about a singer from San Francisco named Doug Hream Blunt four years ago
column4: I am not exactly certain
column5: though I suspect it was on a tip from either a member of Ariel Pink’s Haunted Graffiti or else Park Blvd. Records co-owner Jason Darrah. But the moment that pneumatic
column6: rinky-dink keyboard figure that opens ""Fly Guy"" wheezed and wormed into my ears

The sleeve art was nothing but a generic white sleeve with a gold sticker advertising the 'hit' ""Gentle Persuasion"" and it was hard to tell if it was a put-on or else proof that outsider music could remain relevant and vital in an age when any musician could upload his music to MySpace and be discovered
column8: when most clues could be tracked down with a simple Google search. I’m not the only one besotted by Hream Blunt
column9: as Ariel Pink is a champion

column1: Once hovering in obscurity and mystery
column2: My Name Is makes Doug Hream Blunt readily accessible thanks to David Byrne’s Luaka Bop imprint
column3: no stranger to tracking down itchy
column4: quirky folks like William Onyeabor and Tom Zé. Even as the comp clarifies some of the Frisco fog that enshrouded that self-released CD and its bootlegged 12""
column5: there remains a slippery
column6: eel-like quality to these 10 songs. We learn in the liner notes that in the mid '80s as a 35-year-old prone to taking odd jobs
column7: Blunt answered a flyer for a workshop called 'How to Form a Band.' Nevermind it was intended for Bay Area teens
column8: Blunt approached the classes with a similar sense of the naïf
column9: imparting that spirit onto the other adult students
column10: four of them women who comprise his band.

column1: There's the spirit of the Troggs
column2: the Shaggs
column3: and Half Japanese to the grooves
column4: something stupid yet undeniable
column5: unlearned yet impossible to replicate. The whinnying
column6: cyclical keyboard figure that Jeannie Killmer repeats ad nauseam on ""Fly Guy"" brings to mind '90s Ethiopian pop as well as what you might come up with at Guitar Center on a synth using the flute patch and your thumb. Even more charming and baffling are the lyrics
column7: where Blunt makes a streetwise observation about capitalism: ""The rich use paper then they charge you more
column8: talks about teaching the youth and then adds: ""Girl
column9: I just wanna chill.""

column1: A similarly simple yet inveigling melody and needling guitar sidewinds through the wobbly boogie of said hit
column2: ""Gentle Persuasion"". For all the speculation as to what it means ""to do the ninety-nine""
column3: the notes just equivocate it to the mystery dance itself. Still
column4: it takes a certain kind of Romeo to make a panty-dropping non sequitur of ""like ice
column5: your butt is like dice now
column6: daaaamn.""

column1: Charming as those two tracks are
column2: they both run past six minutes and verge on exhausting. But as ""Big Top""
column3: ""Caribbean Queen""
column4: and ""Break Free"" reveal
column5: Blunt sets about recycling both melodies onto other songs to where their appeal becomes threadbare. Perhaps in keeping with the Haight-Ashbury spirit of his home
column6: each song also contains extended
column7: aimless guitar soloing. And while he might have a two-track mind musically
column8: it's solely one track when it comes to his primary theme. Outside of the last song (an instrumental version of ""Fly Guy"")
column9: the other nine share a similar beat and subject
column10: the word ""girl"" uttered in every song. So even as My Name Is pulls back the curtain on Doug Hream Blunt’s mystery music
column11:
it also makes clear that the opposite sex will always remain one to him.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22552/homepage_large.280e8fad.jpg|The Wireless EP|33320.0|Punch Brothers|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Nonesuch']|2015-11-25 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:43.258610|"

Few modern roots musicians have amassed the critical acclaim and international popularity enjoyed by the honey-voiced
column2: quick-fingered mandolinist Chris Thile. As the frontman and principal songwriter of the progressive bluegrass trio Nickel Creek
column3: the California-born musician spent the early '00s pushing an invigorating
column4: risk-taking acoustic melange he dubbed ""newgrass""
column5: imbuing an art form commonly thought of as static with modernist quirks. Since then—Nickel Creek's 2014 reunion notwithstanding—Thile has shifted focus to Punch Brothers

column1: Guitar
column2: mandolin
column3: fiddle/violin
column4: banjo
column5: bass

column9: defiant fiddle

We don't always recognize it

column1: On Night of Your Ascension

column3: experimental ambient music
column4: and doom. This time around (thanks to help from arrangers Eric Chaleff

column11: rock

column1: Alongside Nadler
column2: harpist Mary Lattimore
column3: electro-acoustic sound artist-composer Olivia Block

column6: Cave
column7: Indian
column8: Bloodiest
column9: Anatomy of Habit
column10: Come
column11: Twilight
column12: and Mind Over Mirrors. Robinson leans heavily on these musicians to flesh out his compositions and give Ascension its shape and character. For the title track

column1: Gesualdo is also infamous for murdering his wife and her lover. Robinson bases the first half of the title track on Gesualdo's techniques which
column2: incidentally

The juxtaposition between the tune's classical and doom modes is clearly meant to invoke a sense of the friction between Gesualdo's towering creative presence and the internal torment that drove him to commit murder. Likewise
column4: for ""Run Priest Run"" Robinson looked to the case of Boston Catholic priest Father John Geoghan
column5: who was accused of sexually abusing over 130 boys
column6: convicted
column7: and murdered in prison in 2003 while serving a life sentence.

column3: this album's obvious equation of heaviness to violence and psychological despair comes off as heavy-handed.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: Night of Your Ascension faces rote themes like killing
column3: death
column4: and despair from a fresh perspective that aspires to be illuminating. It's also
column5: strangely enough

column11:
not unlike the album itself.

By 1995
column2: the post-Nevermind dream that any eccentric rock outfit could follow Nirvana’s path from indie outsiders to chart-toppling insurrectionaries was officially dead. The '90s mainstream would not be transformed in the image of the '80s underground after all
column3: and
column4: as it turned out

column1: For a moment there
column2: the Flaming Lips seemed destined to join the also-rans. Released in the fall of 1995
column3: Clouds Taste Metallic was the band’s seventh album

column6: whose fluke hit single—""She Don’t Use Jelly""—drove album sales into the low six figures and earned the triple crown of '90s TV appearances. Understandably trying to capitalize on this momentum
column7: the Lips loaded Clouds with more cheery and catchy songs about girls doing strange things with foodstuffs. But album sales floundered and
column8: by the fall of 1996

column1: Clouds Taste Metallic is the last album where the Flaming Lips just sounded like some oddballs from Oklahoma
column2: before Wayne Coyne
column3: Drozd
column4: and bassist Michael Ivins refashioned themselves as studio scientists and transformed into the blood-splattered
column5: laser-shooting
column6: Miley-collaborating freak show that’s topped festival bills since the dawn of the millennium. But the record stands as the peak moment in a fantastic four-album run that began with 1990’s In a Priest Driven Ambulance. It's a sturdy wood-paneled shrine to the band’s teenage rec-room touchstones
column7: channeling the shortwave frequencies of Piper at the Gates of Dawn
column8: the fuzz-toned boogie of The Slider
column9: the rustic splendor of After the Gold Rush
column10: the thundering thrust of Houses of the Holy
column11: and a Revolver-like balance of kid-friendly frivolity and strobe-lit freakery. Clouds' sad-eyed opener
column12: ""The Abandoned Hospital Ship""
column13: charts the Flaming Lips’ early '90s evolution in miniature: A creaky Coyne serenade (click-tracked by a wheezing film projector) gives way to a volcanic sludge-rock eruption
column14: but the maelstrom is eventually smoothed over by merry church-bell chimes and swooning choral harmonies. It’s the musical manifestation of what would later become a common Lips lyrical motif—even in the midst of chaos

column1: Here

column3: but its perma-grin melody invites you along for the ride. Coyne and Jones’ guitar noise is infused with character and humor
column4: like the spasmodic riffs that personify a patently absurd song like ""Guy Who Got a Headache and Accidentally Saves the World"" or the buzzing surges that power ""Lightning Strikes the Postman"". And there’s also something reassuringly earthbound about their sound—amid the high-octane blast of ""Kim’s Watermelon Gun""
column5: Jones drops in countrified fills like he’s plucking an electric banjo
column6: while the cuteness of ""Christmas at the Zoo"" is kept in check by a George Harrison-style refrain that emulates the weepy tone of a pedal steel.

column1: But if Clouds Taste Metallic pushes Coyne’s lyrical whimsy into overdrive

column3: stargazing songs like ""Placebo Headwound"" and ""When You Smile"" find Coyne simultaneously awed and humbled by his infinitesimal place in the cosmos. And the alternately rousing and defeatist ""Evil Will Prevail"" resonated all the more deeply in the aftermath of the April 1995 domestic-terrorist bombing in their native Oklahoma.

column1: The songs that fill out this expanded three-disc 20th-anniversary edition—part of the band’s Heady Nuggs reissue series—likewise capture the Lips at their most down-to-earth
column2: evincing an intimate charm that’s since been vanquished from the band’s increasingly futurist

column7: and Candlebox

column1: The wonderful 1994 EP Due to High Expectations… The Flaming Lips Are Providing Needles for Your Balloons (included here in its entirety) is anchored by an early
column2: slightly scruffier version of future Clouds closer ""Bad Days""
column3: but mostly imagines a parallel '90s where the Lips were signed to Drag City instead of Warner Bros. Woofer-blowing sing-alongs (""Jets Pt. 2"") collide with honky-tonked Alan Vega revamps (""Ice Drummer"")
column4: shout-outs to a then-unknown Bill Callahan (via the live in-store performance of Smog’s ""Chosen One"") and impromptu Christmas carols (""Little Drummer Boy""). The Needles EP is supplemented here by corrosive covers of Bowie (""Life on Mars?"")

column6: Sinatra (""It Was a Very Good Year"") and other ephemera

column2: a piano ballad that sounds like it was recorded into a dictaphone that is nonetheless one of the prettiest
column3: most poignant songs in the Lips canon. It also serves as a reminder of a time when Flaming Lips songs required two-minute preambles from Coyne to explain their meaning (in this case
column4: a half-true story about his stoned brother’s paranoid freak-out at a grocery store
column5: and his imagined superhuman ability to telepathically summon insects to attack meddlesome cops). But where the post-Bulletin Lips thrived by translating serious songs into circus-sized spectacle

column1: Heady Nuggs’ third disc—a bootleg-quality document of a May 1996 show in Seattle—is hardly lacking for expository banter
column2: though the real novelty is hearing the Lips rip through a set untethered to the ceremony and choreography that defines their shows today. It’s a grainy-but-radiant snapshot of the mid-'90s Lips live experience

(You may not be able to see the twinkling pinwheel Christmas lights that smothered their stages at the time
column4: but you can more or less hear them.)

column1: But a telling moment emerges from the epic distention of ""Psychiatric Explorations"" that closes the set proper. After stretching what was originally a three-minute song past the nine-minute mark (and seriously straining Coyne’s voice in the process)
column2: the Lips sputter out
column3: and within months
column4: their entire guitar-powered aesthetic would follow suit. Ronald Jones was gone just a few months later
column5: and before year’s end
column6: the band had turned into something else entirely. Compared to what followed
column7:
the Flaming Lips that made Clouds Taste Metallic were just a rock'n'roll band. But this reissue reminds us of what a uniquely wondrous and marvelous rock'n'roll band they were.

Footwork producer DJ Paypal doesn't appear on the surface to be the type of artist that treats his influences with any sort of mindfulness. From his trollish stage name to the plainly ironic bite of Pen and Pixel's distinctive
column2: lens-flare-heavy aesthetic on the cover of his new mini-LP Sold Out
column3: he reads on first glance like just another node on Internet Art's massive recombination engine
column4: which endlessly churns out kitschy (and occasionally brilliant) assemblages of random late-capitalist pop-cultural detritus.There's also the matter of the style he's working in: footwork is a particularly holistic musical form that until very recently has been virtually inseparable not only from the dance style that it soundtracks
column5: but also from the brutally segregated
column6: impoverished black neighborhoods on Chicago's South and West Sides where it was born.

column1: It's a minor revelation to find out that Paypal's far more sincere than his image would suggest. The way that the drums on Sold Out's titular opening track pulse in and out of focus is an expert move well out of reach of the average SoundCloud dilettante
column2: and throughout the album he displays the kind of rule-bending that only comes from closely studying the rules first. ""A lot of kids hear like five tracks and start making footwork
column3: and that’s not respectful

column1: Paypal's a member of the L.A.-born Brainfeeder coalition of artists representing a certain organic
column2: jazz-indebted segment of bass music experimentalists
column3: and like most of the best material to come out of the Brainfeeder camp
column4: it reconnects beat-based music with styles of pre-digital black music whose more radical avant-garde aspects have been forgotten over the years
column5: or dulled by overfamiliarity—bebop
column6: free jazz
column7: and especially the synthesizer-crazed soul and fusion artists of the '70s.

column1: ""Ahhhhhhh"" combines blissed-out piano riffs
column2: pitched up vocal harmonies
column3: and a burbling bassline. ""With Uuuuuuu"" and ""On a Cloud"" teasingly reference early synth-funk (the latter with a vocoder part that Paypal and coproducers Nangdo and DJ Taye blend into a crisp solo trumpet). Other parts of the record reach even further out—""Slim Trak"" folds in Brazilian samba drumming
column4: while ""Say Goodbye"" (featuring Keiska and Tielsie)
column5: drifts into a stoned-genius hybrid of dream pop and J-pop that's easily compelling enough to sustain an entire LP.

column1: At the same time
column2: Paypal's also a member of Chicago's venerable footwork music crew Teklife
column3: and his tracks never lose sight of the style's more utilitarian roots scoring YouTube footworking videos and high school hallway dance battles. The old slogan that ""music wants to be free"" is a truer fit for remix culture than the music piracy advocates that coined it. There's a point in the life cycle of every musical style where it has to expand its worldview and open itself up to new participants and new influences

column6:
it's not even a requirement that you dive more than surface deep into a style before you borrow it. But Sold Out shows what a difference it can make when you hold yourself to a higher standard.

Some of Norway's best producers seem to compensate for the region's chilly climate by gravitating toward sunny sounds
column2: from Todd Terje's escapist lounge-house to Prins Thomas and Lindstrøm's psychedelic nu-disco. This can't be said for 28-year-old producer André Bratten. Although he records in the same Oslo studio as Terje
column3: Thomas
column4: and Lindstrøm
column5: Bratten's new album Gode is insular and experimental
column6: from conception to execution. Gode is Bratten's second proper full-length record
column7: following 2013's inventively titled Be a Man You Ant and this past summer's Math Ilium Ion EP. It's also the most ambitious work of his career
column8: tackling social and historical injustices of the past—namely the serf-like arrangement between farmers and landowners in early 20th-century Norway.

column1: Now
column2: if you're thinking that a double LP about the pre-industrialized Norwegian agrarian economy isn't going to get club kids on the floor
column3: you're right. But this time around that's not Bratten's goal. He wants to tell a story with specific historical context within electronic music

column5: field recording
column6: or a programmed drum pattern
column7: however well-conceived

column1: But even if you'd never guess the album's larger themes without reading about it

column3: as well as 20th century classical musicians like Estonian composer Arvo Pärt
column4: and Italian composer Giacinto Scelsi—known for creating music that plays off a single pitch that generates almost imperceptible microtonal oscillations. Bratten is resourceful at assembling whatever sounds or styles needed to fit the need of the moment: ""Primordial Pit"" uses mostly live instruments to create a sweeping
column5: post-rock-like grandeur
column6: while ""Ins.""
column7: the album's shortest track

column1: For all this wandering
column2: the most overtly pleasing songs on Gode are the ones that call back to Bratten's roots. ""Space Between Left & Right"" has a techno pitter-patter that a patient nightclub crowd could easily appreciate
column3: while the album's title track evokes Boards of Canada at their prettiest. Another clear highlight is ""Cascade of Events""
column4: which features the Norwegian pop singer Susanne Sundfør
column5: who Bratten had previously remixed
column6: her voice shrouded in an analog haze. Having a voice like Sundfør
column7: who has had multiple number one albums in her home country
column8: gives Bratten an anchor to chain his more experimental inclinations to; it'd be fascinating to hear Bratten paired with Sundfør for more than one track.

column1: Given the intentions that Gode comes packed with
column2: it's tempting to view its success in terms of that story. Does Gode accomplish Bratten's goal of creating a tribute to the farmers who never had the opportunity to make art because of their circumstances? Quite possibly! But like a museum plaque explaining abstract art to a layperson
column3: background is only a tiny piece of a mostly visceral experience. What's easier to glean

column5: is that Bratten has made an expertly produced
column6:
emotionally honest record that defies genre and expectation. To understand that requires no homework.

column5: Whom I Have Always Hated has become one of their more heralded tracks

column1: This shift is as clear during opener ""The Nihilist""

column3: as it is during closer ""The Solipsist""
column4: where a kaleidoscopic melody spins like a spotlight inside a thrash metal bulwark. There are references to antecedents throughout: ""Stillborn Gods"" invokes Slayer
column5: while moments of ""Ozymandias"" sound like a Big Four mixtape. The legacy of Swedish death metal looms large
column6: too. But these are the foundations from which Horrendous now sprawl—with bright solos that whip in the wind
column7: with rubber-band basslines that run counterclockwise to the leads
column8: with whiplash rhythms that suggest a short-circuiting carnival ride.

column1: Through all of these twists and churns
column2: the band never seems to be showing off its dexterity
column3: or attempting transitions for their own sake. Horrendous have become masters of pacing and dynamics
column4: instinctively knowing when to let the album and audience breathe. ""Polaris"" progresses from doom metal to black metal to death metal and back to doom seamlessly
column5: as though a DJ had spent hours perfecting the cuts between it all. On the first five minutes of ""Acolytes""
column6: they plow through a grindcore sprint and settle into a dense and demanding death-metal section
column7: with a squealing little riff tucked carefully into a rhythm section that refuses to sit still. These additions lend the momentum of mystery to these songs
column8: which surprise every time you hear them.

column1: One of the most glorious moments on the album
column2: and in metal this year
column3: arrives as a revelation at the end of ""Acolytes"". Unexpectedly
column4: the guitar stalls
column5: locking into one glowing note as the drums retreat into a low-tempo tap. Then
column6: a new arching riff radiates outward
column7: as though the guitar has suddenly emerged from a mountain's shadow and into the midday sun. The drums double and triple their pace
column8: while Herring musters one final
column9: fade-away scream
column10: like a hero taking his leave of a scene. It's a beautiful passage
column11: as redemptive as anything on Deafheaven's Sunbather and as cathartic as the closing moments of a symphony.

column1: Though they sound quite different
column2: Anareta has a lot in common with my other favorite metal album of the year
column3: Tribulation's The Children of the Night. On their earliest albums
column4: both bands wrestled with the past
column5: rendering death metal anew as competent revivalists. But in 2015
column6: they have both stretched those traditions
column7: filling accepted frameworks with unlikely elements. The influences are still recognizable
column8: but the results are no longer obvious. This quest even comes written into Anareta's wonderfully narrative lyrics
column9: where the aim for mortal meaning serves as the cri de cœur. ""Forging a new reality/ Embrace the burning dawn in me
column10: goes the end of ""Acolytes"". Indeed
column11: metal can value faithful
column12: enthusiastic recreations more than heretical ingenuity
column13: and vice versa. But like Tribulation
column14: Horrendous show the value of compromise within a record that creates its own middle ground—and stands right there for eight tracks
column15:
stunning.

column14: stop being such a bunch of clowns. Get up and get over
column15: friend

column1: Or: ""We both know we ain’t kids no more

column7: Martin is as exacting of a songwriter as I’ve ever heard: like he did with the tracks he made for Taylor Swift (""Shake It Off""
column8: ""Blank Space""
column9: ""Style"") and Katy Perry (""I Kissed a Girl""
column10: ""Teenage Dream""
column11: ""Roar"")
column12: he relies on some enigmatic internal cadence
column13: clipping syllables like a hiccuping poet
column14: taking a tiny scalpel to his melodies. He keeps his lines pointy and balanced. ""Send-my-love/ To-your-new/ Luh-uh-ver."" The results are like encountering a person with perfectly symmetrical features—both instantly appealing and deeply
column15: existentially unsettling. The song opens with carefully plucked acoustic guitar
column16: and when the chorus comes in it’s as if someone yanked the curtains up on a dark room.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Adele leans on a familiar kind of outrage
column3: reckoning with a lover who broke every promise he ever made to her. There's unrequited love
column4: but then there’s love that changes shape; if you’re unlucky enough to be on the receiving end of that transaction—made unwilling witness to the mysterious
column5: alchemical shift in which devotion suddenly thins
column6: sours—true understanding is impossible
column7: a fool’s errand. This is the love that Adele sings of
column8: the kind where there’s nothing left to do but resign: ""I’m giving you up
column9: I’m forgiving it all."" Nurturing grudges is a young woman’s game.

column1: Almost every song on 25 addresses heartache in one form or another. ""Send My Love"" is anomalous in its confidence; more often
column2: Adele sounds excruciatingly aware of her own blunders and bereavements
column3: and the ways in which time has made them indelible. Sometimes
column4: Adele herself is the agent of grief
column5: like on ""Hello""
column6: in which she attempts to reach an ex-lover on her flip-phone. Surely
column7: on some level
column8: Adele knows the message she’s so hungry to deliver—""I’m sorry/ For breaking your heart""—is not the kind of sentiment that’s going to yield her much more than a slowly raised middle finger (the indignation of the recently forsaken is vast
column9: merciless). She is arguably more desperate to reach an earlier iteration of herself
column10: to correct something
column11: quiet some panic.

column1: Other times she is a victim of loss. In the piano ballad ""When We Were Young""
column2: which was co-written with Tobias Jesso Jr.
column3: she sings: ""Let me photograph you in this light/ In case it is the last time/ That we might be exactly like we were/ Before we realized."" The instrumentation swells
column4: quiets. The precise nature of that realization is not named
column5: but of course it doesn’t need to be
column6: or not explicitly (as Joan Didion wrote
column8: ""It is easy to see the beginnings of things
column9: and harder to see the ends.""). The song itself is a kind of homage to the booming
column10: soft-focus singer-songwriters who dominated AM radio in the 1970s (Barbra Streisand
column11: Shirley Bassey)
column12: and Adele’s vocal performance is astonishing

column1: Still: the cumulative effect is sometimes as treacly as the heavily frosted sheet cake being slid onto the buffet table in the carpeted banquet hall where this song will be blasting
column2: on a loop
column3: for all of eternity. Even your most adorable aunt—the one who loves a Yankee Candle—will eventually drain her flute of sparkling wine
column4: lean forward
column5: and be like
column6: ""Dog
column7: this shit is corny.""

column1: Taken as a whole document

column3: as far as I can tell—address the foibles of romantic love. It’s not so much that Adele’s lyrics are platitudinous (although they often are)
column4: it’s that the album’s prevailing sentiment eventually becomes wearying. In his book The Song Machine
column5: John Seabrook interviews Bonnie McKee
column6: the 31-year-old songwriter behind some of Katy Perry’s bigger hits and a frequent collaborator of Martin’s; McKee offers a pat
column7: sorry-dude response to the question of lyrical uniformity in contemporary pop. ""Most people still just want to hear about love and partying
column8: is what she tells Seabrook. A shrug—a ""Hey
column9: it’s not us
column10: it’s you! You dummies are the ones who want that!""—is implied.

column1: Perhaps that is what people want: Adele is presently on track to break N*Sync's record
column2: held since 2000
column3: of 2.24 million copies sold in the first week of release (on Friday
column4: more than 900
column5: 000 people downloaded 25 from the iTunes store alone). And perhaps these songs are trifles
column6: foregone conclusions that
column7: instead of facilitating or inviting a deepening
column8: allow for just one outcome: a peaceable head-bob
column9: a wistful smile. They are one-way
column10: dead-end roads
column11: emotional shortcuts to wells of loss and contrition. But regardless of how one might feel about the spiritual utility of pop music
column12: Adele’s instincts as a singer remain unmatched; she is
column13: inarguably
column14: the greatest vocalist of her generation
column15: an artist who instinctively understands timbre and pitch
column16: when to let some air in. It does not seem unfair to ask that dynamism of her songs
column17:
too.

Let me be the first to formally apologize for accidentally contributing to the execrable proliferation of analyses that Natalie Prass sounds like ""a Disney princess."" This writer was in attendance for a show where she took a moment to defend herself from the claim
column2: which was followed by a not-sober fellow yelling out an unprintable word and the name of this website
column3: a moment that made at least one person in the vicinity feel very uncomfortable. You can understand how she would take it as a backhanded compliment: There's something unavoidably infantilizing about the suggestion that your voice resembles a fictional cartoon monarch's
column4: even if Snow White could really sing.

column1: It makes her sound so… formal
column2: too
column3: and while Prass makes music inspired by classic artists like Dusty Springfield and Dionne Warwick
column4: she's no traditionalist. Covers of modern musicians like Janet Jackson and Ryan Adams have snuck their way into her sets
column5: and she even popped up on the AV Club last month to turn the gory chug of Slayer's ""Raining Blood"" into an inside-voice delight. Side by Side shows that playful side
column6: comprising two live cuts of songs from her self-titled solo debut
column7: as well as covers of Grimes
column8: Anita Baker
column9: and Simon & Garfunkel
column10: artists whose only obvious connection is ""singers that Natalie Prass decided to cover on her new EP.""

column1: Her take on Baker's ""Caught Up in the Rapture"" does away with those awesomely '80s gated drums and sparkling filter sweeps
column2: instead pushing the tempo and adding guitar for something a little more lively. On the original
column3: Baker welcomes the listener with open arms through some magical doorway
column4: where the evening of a lifetime awaits. Prass sings from a more present place
column5: like she's three beers into a muggy summer night at a Nashville bar. She makes the gentle folk-rock of ""Sound of Silence"" a little more lively
column6: nailing those melodies with her graceful
column7: nimble voice. ""REALiTi"" is done as a straight up ragtime jaunt
column8: and if her press release commentary on the cover (""[Grimes is] probably going to say 'what is this jazz shit' and hate it"") is maybe a little too accurately self-deprecating
column9: she at least commits.

column1: The live versions of ""My Baby Don't Understand Me"" and ""Christy"" strip away the dense orchestral instrumentation and let a Wurlitzer piano do the driving. The arrangements are cleaner
column2: and show her mastery over negative space. One knock on the self-titled record was that Prass sometimes sounded secondary to the orchestra
column3: but here the same can't be said. My favorite moment on the original LP was at the end of ""My Baby Don't Understand Me""
column4: where the repeated refrain of ""our love is a long goodbye"" built to a grand climax. On the live take
column5: she lets the groove ride a few seconds longer
column6: transforming the swelling romance into something steamier.

column1: Similarly
column2: the nighttime vibe of the unadorned ""Christy"" precludes all future Disney princess comparisons
column3: as she lets the lonesomeness of the lyrics (""Why does it have to be that she can take the hand of anyone she meets?/ Still
column4: the only one she sees belongs to me"") really sink in. In this
column5: Side by Side does what a good EP should—it reminds us of what she's skilled at
column6: while showing off some other strengths. There's even something like a mission statement to her music in the title
column7: and the song it's taken from: ""When I feel the magic of you/ The feeling's always new."" It's an old sentiment
column8: and the lyric belongs to another artist
column9:
but Prass makes it hers.

Under his Flying Lotus codename
column2: Steven Ellison continues to push his distinctive strain of abstract hip-hop into the direction paved by his Great Aunt Alice and Great Uncle John. You could hear the family history coursing through the interstellar spaces he explored with his cousin Ravi on 2010's Cosmogramma and that Herbie Hancock jam on last year's You're Dead!. But Ellison's advancement of creative jazz has been more crucial as curator of the Brainfeeder label
column3: which he founded in 2008 as an outlet for himself and his buddies down at Low End Theory in Los Angeles.

column1: Kamasi Washington's The Epic hinted at FlyLo's A&R prowess
column2: and Kneedelus puts an exclamation point on the imprint's new direction. The relationship between exploratory
column3: Grammy-nominated funk-jazz outfit Kneebody and pioneering Cali beat scientist Daedelus (born Alfred Darlington) goes back almost a decade
column4: evidenced by remixes on Bandcamp and a stage collaboration at the Jazz à Vienne Festival in 2009. Kneebody saxophonist Ben Wendel and Darlington are high school friends
column5: while Darlington and Flying Lotus go back to 1983
column6: Ellison's debut
column7: and Darlington's indelible remix of the title track.

column1: What all of this six-degrees business adds up to is this supernova of a record
column2: rounded out by Adam Benjamin on keyboard
column3: Shane Endsley on treated trumpet
column4: bassist Kaveh Rastegar
column5: and drummer Nate Wood. As a collaborative unit
column6: the friendship between the parties undoubtedly lends itself to the fluidity of these 10 original compositions. In some cases
column7: as on tracks like the rugged ""The Hole"" and the hypnotic ""Move""
column8: you can't really even tell where Kneebody ends and Daedelus begins. Darlington's deft rhythmic impulses come to the fore on ""Drum Battle""
column9: but in other moments
column10: the invincible horn section of Kneebody runs the show. On ""Loops""
column11: Endsley's trumpet is cat-like and cool
column12: as the group takes the scrambled-signal breakbeat Daedelus delivers to the snapping point around the horn's calm center like a hurricane eye. On ""Platforming""
column13: meanwhile
column14: Wendel's fantastic Art Pepper-esque tenor work is transformed into a wild
column15: distorted-violin sound. Elsewhere
column16: its Benjamin who is leading the charge on the seven-minute Mwandishi-flavored space-out ""Thought Not""
column17: and the haunting processed upright piano he plays on ""Not Love"".

column1: Yet its when Kneebody and Daedelus fuse that Kneedelus achieves its potential. And perhaps no other track really embodies that idea more than ""Home""
column2: the album's deep modal center that simmers together Tubby dub
column3: TNT-era Tortoise
column4: and Lalo Schifrin. It's no matter of happenstance the cover of Kneedelus is a shameless emulation of the design format of another game-changing jazz record label
column5: ECM. This album exists in a very similar atmosphere to some of Manfred Eicher's bolder production moves throughout the last 40-odd years (dig that Jack DeJohnette box set for proof). And above all
column6:
it's a vision offering one last reminder before the year is out that Brainfeeder is very serious about its place in the jazz world.

Joey Anderson came to house music first as a dancer: Not your average weekend clubber
column2: but a devoted student of a vernacular form
column3: house dancing
column4: that thrived in New York and New Jersey nightclubs in the 1990s—expressive
column5: fluid
column6: acrobatic
column7: and competitive. You can hear that influence in the sparse
column8: wiry productions that he has been recording since the beginning of this decade. They're not made for fist-pumping
column9: and they don't follow neat verse/chorus structures. They ripple and writhe unpredictably
column10: marked by an improvisational sense of movement. They seem to move of their own accord.

column1: Anderson comes from the same corner of the house and techno universe that has given us artists like Levon Vincent
column2: Anthony Parasole
column3: and DJ Qu
column4: a fellow dancer. Like them
column5: he favors analog drum machines
column6: hardware synthesizers
column7: and what sounds
column8: above all
column9: like a lot of playing of keys and twisting of knobs in real time. Much contemporary electronic music is composed visually
column10: assembled brick by brick on a computer screen
column11: but Anderson's snake-in-the-grass meanderings suggest live takes stacked one on top of another
column12: thanks to the magic of multi-tracking.

column1: ""18 Arms"" goes straight to the heart of his approach. True to its name (leave it to a dancer to come up with a title like that)
column2: it opens with a synthesizer pattern that squirms like an octopus' tentacles
column3: and as the track accrues its fistfuls of counterpoints and layers
column4: it becomes easy to imagine the producer as a one-man band. At any given point on the album
column5: three or more synthesizer parts are being woven together; drum hits are flaring up and being muted again; a hi-hat's pitch seesaws up and down. The cumulative effect of all these techniques is at once chaotic and elegant
column6: and fluid above all.

column1: But how the music is put together is ultimately less important than how it feels
column2: and Anderson's music is all about feel. It's hard to put your finger on the emotions they evoke
column3: but you're moved all the same. (""'Deep' to me is like the human condition that you don't talk about
column4: that you hold in forever until you are in front of that right person"" Anderson told Resident Advisor
column5: which might go some way towards explaining the slipperiness of his music's emotional register.) A song might be calm and meditative: the spacious ""Organ to Dust"" is a study in stillness in which quietly accelerating figures move like quarters spinning to a halt on the floor. ""Nabta Playa""
column6: named for a drained basin in the Egyptian desert
column7: is fleet and mysterious; in both sound and mood
column8: it's reminiscent of Drexciya's Afro-futurist fantasies
column9: and the Detroit icons' fizzy textures and frantic movements also inform ""Amarna""
column10: whose title refers to the tomb of the Pharaoh Akhenaten. It's the album's most unhinged track
column11: with wildly filtered drums that thrash desperately about. It sounds like music for punching mirrors; it moves like someone trying to escape his own shadow. True to the corporeal bent of Anderson's album
column12:
it locates emotion not in the mind but in the muscles.

""That's when my rape fantasies first started
column2: when I was in college

column1: As if his presence weren't unpleasant enough

column1: Still
column2: the inclusion of these samples is flat-out despicable and speaks volumes about how decades of desensitization have blurred not only the lines of good taste but of common decency as well. If N.V. is any indication
column3: actual murder has become indistinguishable from any other image we passively ingest from the safe
column4: numb remove of our computer monitors. Once artists adopt ""extremity"" as the cowardly affectation that it is
column5: they leave themselves little choice but to keep pushing the envelope. The musicians on N.V. would probably insist that they went this far precisely because they wanted to make the audience feel something.
column6: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">But to indulge them in a rewardless thought-loop by debating their intentions is to allow them to manipulate you and waste your time.

column1: It's a shame
column2: because N.V.'s lurid first-person homicide monologues overshadow its wealth of sonic character. Both of these acts are defined by their (arguably unparalleled) ability to create atmosphere
column3: which makes their yin-yang pairing a natural fit that
column4: on paper
column5: overflows with possibilities. Judging from their respective bodies of work
column6: there's no doubt that Dragged Into Sunlight and Gnaw Their Tongues could have rendered tunes like ""Visceral Repulsion"" scary—and taken the audience into a truly murderous
column7: sexually depraved headspace—through other
column8: more imaginative means. Pig Destroyer frontman-lyricist J.R. Hayes
column9: for example
column10: scares the daylights out of you and dives even further into the same thematic terrain but manages to get there without trampling on anyone's grave.

column1: Billed as a joint effort
column2: N.V. actually bears the stamp of two other significant contributors
column3: Godflesh/Jesu founder Justin Broadrick and Corrupt Moral Altar drummer-producer Tom Dring. Having produced the first two DIS albums
column4: Dring once again had a hand in shaping the sounds throughout the making of N.V.
column5: while Broadrick stepped in as co-producer and sonic overseer later
column6: during the mixing stages. By that point

column8: off-again back and forth with DIS and de Jong working out of their respective homebases in England and the Netherlands.

column1: Stretched as it was over time
column2: distance
column3: and multiple perspectives
column4: N.V. sounds surprisingly focused and
column5: musically speaking
column6: rather non-indulgent (perhaps because Broadrick
column7: Dring
column8: DIS
column9: and de Jong boiled the final product down to a 32-minute runtime). Broadrick's input is somewhat difficult to discern
column10: but de Jong's touch saturates this music. Even in the spots where Dragged Into Sunlight blasts away and it seems like there's no room to cram in any more sonic information
column11: de Jong is there
column12: hovering like a toxic
column13: mind-altering haze that burns your eyes

column15: and soaks into your skin -- sensations that are not without their appeal.

column1: Dragged Into Sunlight had already created a sense of psych-ward hysteria with the black-grind hybrid they established as far back as 2008's Terminal Aggressor
column2: and their ability to use raw ingredients like cymbal wash

column6: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">On N.V.
column7: they turn to Mories as a kind of set designer who fleshes out and brings spacial and tactile dimension to the Liverpool quartet's caustic exorcisms.

column1: Naturally
column2: as an almost supergroup-like meeting of the minds between three highly production-conscious acts
column3: N.V. is crammed with details that don't initially reveal themselves. But even if de Jong and Dragged Into Sunlight grasp the scale of the tragedies they've chosen to rub the audience's nose in
column4: the fact is they're contributing to trivializing the victims in these cases. Will listeners respond to N.V. the way we might once have tittered at the gross-out slasher fantasies on early Cannibal Corpse records

column1: At this stage in the game

column3: there is undeniably an art to N.V.'s execution.
column4: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">Together
column5: its participants combine layers of abrasion that can be rewarding if you can
column6: well
column7:
get past the visceral repulsion.

column3: and they are both as literal as their album titles. In his latest venture
