column5: the wise
column6: older veteran of an Atlanta rap scene that is currently worlds away from his grim motivational seminars. Church in These Streets doesn’t completely deliver on its compelling premise—a ""reborn"" Jeezy
column7: half-conscious but still the self-proclaimed ""God in these streets."" There are some moments that strike this note
column8: especially the spoken-word interludes that broadly touch on social issues like privatized prisons
column9: police brutality
column10: and even the toll of drug dealing on the lives of the hustlers and the buyers (especially striking on a record with a song called ""Hustlaz Holiday""). But they do just feel like moments
column11: a snapshot of a project Jeezy is unable to make.

column1: After a few years of toiling in major-label purgatory
column2: Jeezy’s new persona (and it is a ""persona
column3: not a guiding aesthetic principle) is good for a few effective
column4: if perhaps obvious
column5: metaphors and symbols. The song titles
column6: just like the album title
column7: give it all away: ""Lost Souls""
column8: ""Holy Water""
column9: ""God""
column10: ""Forgive Me"". He deserves credit for turning a new album around in just a year that’s influenced by his feelings and thoughts on the current political climate
column11: but it feels workmanlike and too deliberate to hold weight. It is conspicuously light on guests
column12: probably by design
column13: but Jeezy’s voice can wear during sustained listens
column14: and when Janelle Monáe shows up on the light
column15: totally un-Jeezy-like single ""Sweet Life""
column16: she’s anonymous.

column1: The vibe of the music seems to suggest that Jeezy wants to bring the dank and spacey stuff that Young Thug and Future work with into his playground
column2: but grounded in his declarative
column3: raspy voice. It's minimal
column4: exciting stuff
column5: the kind of creative pivot he executed so well just a few years ago overseeing CTE. ""Gold Bottles"" has a weak hook but features typically baroque production from London on da Track. ""God"" works that same apocalyptic tone of so many 808 Mafia productions: It’s a good song until you realize it’s essentially a redux of Future’s ""Sh!t"" from a few years ago.

column1: ""Just Win"" is another highlight
column2: riding a mournful horn sample that recalls socially aware blaxploitation movies and their rich scores
column3: specifically Willie Hutch and the soundtrack for The Mack. It also samples Les Brown
column4: a motivational speaker
column5: and the song's dynamic nails the highs and the lows of this record—it clearly wants to be a meaningful
column6: contemplative record

column8:
a triumphant kind of simplicity. Here that gets muted to muddied results.

Freddie Gibbs doesn’t believe in resting on his laurels. After dropping last year’s Piñata with Madlib at the helm — the rapper’s most commercially and critically successful project to date — he could have taken some well-deserved time off. Instead
column2: he toured non-stop and played festivals
column3: put out two EPs The Tonite Show with the Worlds Freshest and Pronto
column4: and last but not least
column5: became a father.

column1: Now with little advance notice
column2: and a raised middle finger to Q4 release schedules and anyone foolish enough to be making their best-of year-end lists early
column3: the pride of Gary
column4: Ind. is back with his third full-length studio album. A quick scan of the credits reveals the biggest difference between Shadow of a Doubt and his last LP—instead of one singular producer
column5: there’s over a dozen wide-ranging names contributing beats here from Canadian hitmaker Boi-1da to 808 Mafia’s Tarentino. While the final result is less cohesive
column6: and could benefit from trimming two or three songs
column7: there’s no denying Gibbs’ versatility.

column1: If there’s any question as to whether or not acclaim has mellowed the man who frequently refers to himself as both ""Gangsta Gibbs"" and ""Freddie Corleone""
column2: look no further than the two tracks that bookend the record. The sparse
column3: atmospheric ""Rearview""
column4: which opens with a ""Welcome to Los Angeles International Airport"" P.A.
column5: sees the rapper offer up a bullet point summary of his career to date before dismissing would-be copycats with trademark precision. In contrast
column6: ""Cold Ass Nigga"" sees Gibbs with two feet on the gas
column7: with frequent Kanye West collaborator Mike Dean providing a suitably urgent
column8: glitchy trap beat. It’s nothing like anything else in Gibbs’ vast catalogue (its closest spiritual companion might be ""Old English""
column9: his 2014 track with A$AP Ferg and Young Thug) and it’s proof that the 33 year old is still more than willing to push himself out of his sonic comfort zone.

column1: His lyrics capture the pursuit of the American dream like a Scorsese screenplay (drugs
column2: sex
column3: and all-too-frequent bloodshed included). He’s hardly the first artist to incorporate a sample from ""The Wire"" into a song
column4: but he’s one of few able to do so without it coming off cliché or rote (Boi-1da and Frank Dukes’ sinister piano loops greatly help). Another highlight is the understated
column5: introspective ""Insecurities"" produced by Dukes and Montreal’s Kaytranada (who teamed up with the rapper this year for the menacing one-off ""My Dope House"").

column1: As for the record’s handful of guest spots
column2: Gibbs has picked a mix of newcomers and veterans who complement but never overshadow him. Rising Miami-via-Toronto emcee Tory Lanez contributes a bleary-eyed hook to dealers’ anthem ""Mexico""; elsewhere
column3: L.A. R&B singer-songwriter Dana Williams propels ""McDuck"". On ""Extradite""
column4: the Roots’ Black Thought’s politically charged verse is sharply juxtaposed with Mikhail’s bright
column5: jazz-influenced production
column6: which eventually gives way to dialogue taken from a fiery speech on Ferguson by Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan. Then there’s ""10 Times""
column7: featuring Gucci Mane floating over the beat like plumes of blunt smoke (perhaps Gibbs’ own ""Freddie Kane OG"" strain)
column8: before West Coast veteran E-40 swoops in to gleefully extol the virtues of a woman ""thicker than a buttermilk biscuit.""

column1: On the outro of ""McDuck""
column2: we hear an excerpt from an interview he did with Snoop Dogg this past summer discussing Gibbs’ background. ""You just sound like you not from nowhere
column3: says Snoop to which the rapper replies
column4: ""I created that sound."" The cover artwork of Shadow of a Doubt might depict Gibbs’ face half-cloaked in darkness
column5:
but his roots and aspirations have never been clearer.

column2: serif;"">The debut album by Melbourne four-piece Jaala constantly shifts between time signatures
column3: but it's not a virtuoso showcase. The band's guitarist
column4: singer
column5: and songwriter Cosima Jaala has said that she would struggle to identify any tempo—with the exception of 4/4
column6: which
column7: in her words
column8: can ""go fuck a dead donkey."" Instead
column9: the record's rushing
column10: halting feel is her attempt to reflect life's complex rhythms. It's complemented by an unusual but brilliant pop palette that splutters with the chaotic energy of a Jackson Pollock.

column2: serif;"">The interplay between guitarists Jaala and Nic Lam
column3: bassist Loretta Wilde
column4: and drummer Maria Moles recalls Thrill Jockey's '90s Chicago set
column5: splashy as Tortoise and richly mellow as the Sea and Cake. ""Lowlands"" ambles around a crooked bass line; ""Order"" has a splayed ska-punk lilt that evokes Clash ballads. Jaala sings with a jazzy
column6: muscular intonation and a chalky squeak in her throat that recalls a punkier Amy Winehouse or Jeff Buckley
column7: and also owes a debt to the skittish incantations of Life Without Buildings' Sue Tompkins. When she screams
column8: as she often does
column9: it's not with rage
column10: but roller coaster joy. Considering how rampant the pace is—and Jaala's predilection for ""brain-melting shit""—Hard Hold is often remarkably soothing
column11: yet always surprising.

column2: serif;"">Jaala's lyrics are just as playful as her delivery
column3: full of twists and wonderful imagery. They often deal with the ties that bind humans—love
column4: obsession
column5: violence—and she's just as interested in stretching the bonds of language. On ""Hard Hold""
column6: she wrings the endless potential of a single syllable. ""It's hard
column7: a heart to a heart/ Too hard to unfold this hold with you
column8: she sings
column9: as if massaging out her own heartbreak
column10: working agility back into her ticker's knotted muscle. ""If sharing is a bowl of soup
column11: then you drunk it dry
column12: she tells her ex before she proclaims her newly discovered strength
column13: a moment heralded by the song's buoyant lope bursting into a frenzied thrash.

column2: serif;"">Swaying between downbeat and more anxious passages
column3: ""Salt Shaker"" captures Jaala's relief and guilt at leaving her humdrum seaside hometown. She licks salt off her hand to remind herself of the waves
column4: and observes: ""Those happy-holy-heinous houses/ They spread out and out for mileses."" She's a distinct voice
column5: and a versatile one
column6: too: ""Ticket"" is a serrated tirade against an ex who used her
column7: full of ugly screams and jagged riffs. But then comes closer ""Hymn""
column8: a tender devotional where the band's edges soften to glimmer like sea ripples reflected on a cave wall.

column1: Hard Hold is a clever record that rarely foregrounds that fact—perhaps because it was recorded in a week
column2: it hangs onto a scampering
column3: impromptu quality that only adds to its appeal. While they sound nothing alike
column4: Jaala's debut has a similar sense of fluid
column5:
approachable experimentation to a record like Bitte Orca: the kind of bright weirdness that seems to illuminate a whole new set of colors.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22539/homepage_large.b5a67258.jpg|Dark Sky Island|1353.0|Enya|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2015-11-20 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:53.039447|"

It can be difficult to differentiate between Enya records. Her early work still feels only slightly displaced from 4AD and ambient music; though Enya has never been comfortable identifying her music as ""new age
column2: it shares new age's fixations on geology and infinity
column3: which also appear in the music of contemporary acts
column4: from Oneohtrix Point Never to Mark McGuire. But as her career advanced her songwriting and the architecture of her albums solidified into a kind of extreme aesthetic discipline
column5: and her songs began to melt inextricably into each other. Dark Sky Island is her first album in five years
column6: since 2008's Christmas-themed collection ...And Winter Came. I can say with some confidence that it's her best record since 1995's The Memory of Trees
column7: but I'm not certain if that means anything to anyone
column8: including myself. Her albums generate a very specific environment
column9: one which envelops the listener regardless of the quality of her individual songs.

column1: Enya's music is primarily about distance: between minutes
column2: between people
column3: between stars. Her songs stretch accordingly
column4: synthesizers advancing and receding within them like shadows. Sometimes her music seems to move with the velocity of a glacier. Drums are employed sparingly. Either her vocal is the rhythmic engine of the songs (as in ""Orinoco Flow""
column5: or on this album
column6: ""Echoes in Rain"") or the rhythm is organized into arpeggios that sound like crystal
column7: and which are often generated from a Roland Juno 60 synthesizer. There are also sudden clusters of sampled timpani in her music
column8: but they provide shape to her songs more than they provide any animation. The way she constructs her music out of samples gives her otherwise warm and amniotic compositions a kind of Arctic and alien dimension.

column1: Her songs feel sharper on Dark Sky Island than they have in years. Its textures are glassier; the individual sampled string hits on ""Echoes in Rain"" sound like arthritic branches sprouting from a frozen earth. The ballads are heartbreaking. ""I Could Never Say Goodbye"" and ""So I Could Find My Way"" describe an incredible distance that can't be collapsed; in the case of ""So I Could Find My Way""
column2: that distance is the vastness between life and death. (She wrote it about her producer Nicky Ryan's mother.) Elsewhere she (somewhat invisibly) experiments; in ""Sancta Maria"" a synthesizer collides gently against more classical instruments in a way that seems to clarify each. She sings several interstellar ballads in Loxian
column3: a language her lyricist Roma Ryan invented
column4: though the language is mainly experienced on record as a blur of vowels. (These ""experiments"" of course merge seamlessly with the rest of her work; they're composed of the same glossy surfaces and drift through identical rhythms.)

column1: Her first two albums
column2: Enya and Watermark
column3: are much more digressive and rhythmically diverse than her later work
column4: including Dark Sky Island; for every gentle
column5: shapeless ballad
column6: there would be exercises in more precise
column7: classical forms
column8: or a song would unfold into a more distracted rhythm. Most of her songs since have been subject to a merciless symmetry. She drifts somewhat out of her aesthetic on Dark Sky Island's ""Even in the Shadows""
column9: which pulses like an artery from the double bass playing of Eddie Lee; as a result
column10: it's one of the best songs on the record. But it matters little. Though her approach has calcified
column11: the environments generated by her records are still singular
column12: a gentle
column13: untroubled
column14:
indefinite ambience that is very soothing to inhabit. It's like being embraced by the air.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22536/homepage_large.dc9f5d3b.jpg|City of Brides|33283.0|En|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Students of Decay']|2015-11-20 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:53.602480|"

In their five years of making music as En
column2: Maxwell August Croy and James Devane have built a career imbuing drone music with innocence and wonder—a little glimmer of light from the depths of a well. A co-president of the beloved
column3: minimalist-focused Root Strata label
column4: Croy devotes much of his time to building a sophisticated
column5: wonderfully weird roster of artists (Grouper
column6: the Alps
column7: and Driphouse have all issued LPs on the label): but he's also earned a reputation as a gifted electroacoustic auteur. Devane
column8: meanwhile
column9: comes from a guitar background
column10: tempered by a love for the digital greats (as his acoustic cover of Aphex Twin's ""Rhubarb"" attests). The duo’s latest
column11: City of Brides
column12: is their most cohesive—and perhaps paradoxically
column13: sonically varied—statement to date.

column1: Establishing a sense of momentum when nothing moves is one of the biggest challenges in drone music. On City of Brides
column2: Croy and Devane supply propulsion through juxtaposition: not just between the organic and the artificial
column3: but also between the serious and the playful. For every period of restraint—the two-part
column4: vaguely erotic shadow play of ""Songs for Diminished Lovemaking""
column5: for instance—there’s a burst of playfulness to balance it. On the buoyant ""Mendocino Nature Rave""
column6: the duo ventriloquize their motherboards to reproduce the sounds of dolphins
column7: bats
column8: and other wildlife
column9: while ""Hall of Mirrors"" sounds like a thrilling
column10: grim game of Peek-A-Boo
column11: constantly threatened by melodramatic synth swoops.

column1: There are no samples to speak of on City of Brides; every sound we hear is built from scratch. Each song is a crystalline Russian doll
column2: a stylistic experiment in layering sounds both comforting and caustic. ""Blonde Is Back"" is the most magnificent
column3: its warm swathes of synths simultaneously soothing and suffocating. The experience of listening to it isn’t that far off from being smothered by a fleece blanket.

column1: The diversity of the instruments here helps distinguish City of Brides from peers like Pete Swanson and Oren Ambarchi
column2: or influencers like La Monte Young. On ""Mark of the Slav""
column3: En use a koto to create a foggy soundscape before drifting out into the horizon. In addition to honoring its reputation for graceful precision
column4: En challenge the koto’s inherent solemnity by way of energetic arrangements that render it assertive
column5: even abrasive; its shattered-glass-strums break the reverent murmur of ""Secret Samba"". Indeed
column6: one could make a strong case for Croy’s playing as City of Brides’ secret weapon: a valuable source of energy on an extensive
column7: occasionally exhausting album.

column1: If you’re not a fan of drone
column2: City of Brides probably won’t turn you into an acolyte. The LP gets off to a sluggish
column3: vaguely narcotic start with ""Blades"" and ""Dead Ringer""
column4: two relatively straightforward ambient pieces that lack the standout quirks of later tracks. Those looking for a more leaden approach may walk away disappointed as well; Devane’s guitars never reach the intensity of
column5: say
column6: Sunn O))). Nevertheless
column7:
there are plenty of secrets refracted through City of Brides' glassine spaces—and peering through such a globally-inspired prism is arguably as compelling as any seismic axe riff.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22516/homepage_large.77ae3de7.jpg|Junun|33360.0|Shye Ben Tzur / Jonny Greenwood / The Rajasthan Express|['Global']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Nonesuch']|2015-11-19 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:54.158654|"

There are a lot of creative forces to keep track of on Junun. Receiving top billing is the Israeli singer and composer
column2: Shye Ben Tzur
column3: who wrote the songs. Then there's his backing band: the 19 performers
column4: hailing from distinct Indian-music traditions
column5: who form the Rajasthan Express. And you've also got Radiohead's Jonny Greenwood contributing rhythm guitar
column6: bass
column7: keyboards
column8: and drum-programming to the arrangements.

column1: Still
column2: aside from the album's complex backstory and multilingual lyrics (written
column3: variously
column4: in Hebrew
column5: Hindi
column6: and Urdu)
column7: Junun is readily approachable on its own. When Aamir Bhiyani’s rhythmically crisp trumpet peals out over programmed and acoustic percussion during the first minute of the album's opener and title track
column8: Junun establishes its celebratory side. (Instrumental virtuosity and rhythmic drive: check and check
column9: respectively.) Then the singer comes in
column10: delivering an attractive setting of Sufi mystic poetry. (Warmly humanistic vibe: check.) The song could easily coast from this point. But once a tempo downshift hits
column11: midway through
column12: the assembled performers sound even more exultant. (Are you dancing yet? I was.)

column1: It's the wealth of smart musical touches that make Ben Tzur's songs feel so emotionally legible. The bowed strings of ""Hu"" have a vulnerable quality that contrasts winningly with the song’s more full-throated vocal exclamations
column2: while Ben Tzur’s breathy flute playing complements Greenwood’s tinny digital programming on the opening of ""Kalandar"". And the gradual acceleration of a vocal-driven number like ""Eloah"" also contributes to the album’s impressive range of textures.

column1: ""Chala Vahi Des"" starts out with melancholic vocals delivered by Afshana Khan and Razia Sultan
column2: before throttling into a harmonium-and-drums groove. In the song’s final section
column3: Greenwood’s surprisingly funky bass playing enters into a dialog with the vocalists and drums. Also making an appearance
column4: during the chorus of the triple-meter tune ""Allah Elohim""
column5: are the ghostly
column6: sliding tones of the ondes Martenot—an early electronic-keyboard instrument that is one of Greenwood’s favorites. (He's used it on Kid A
column7: Hail to the Thief
column8: as well as in his score for There Will Be Blood.) Given the prominence of his guitar on the same track
column9: ""Allah Elohim"" is one of the rare moments on Junun that sounds directly influenced by Greenwood's other work.

column1: Concerning Greenwood's mostly background role: the sight of a famous British pop musician collaborating with lesser-known artists from another hemisphere can easily prompt charges of exploitative appropriation. But since Greenwood’s latest releases on Nonesuch have all focused on his work as a composer of film scores and classical music
column2: the pop-world conversation about cultural tourism doesn’t seem all that helpful here.

column1: A better reference point would be the tradition of modern composers looking to escape the ""Eastern"" and ""Western"" category trap. In his 2015 memoir Words Without Music
column2: American composer Philip Glass recalled how ""it was very common in the 1960s for Western musicians
column3: even composers
column4: to be completely ignorant of global
column5: or world
column6: music."" Glass
column7: for his part
column8: famously followed up his studies of the Western canon (at Juilliard and in Paris) by traveling to India
column9: where he eventually worked for Ravi Shankar. Other composers associated with the minimalist movement
column10: such as La Monte Young and Terry Riley
column11: spent decades investigating Hindustani raga with Pandit Pran Nath.

column1: As a post-minimalist himself
column2: Greenwood is a natural heir to that history. And so after happening upon a composer like Ben Tzur
column3: he’s apt to decide to ""discover more about him."" What Greenwood found was a composer splitting his time between the Middle East and India
column4: who has managed to develop a unique fusion form that is constructed from several traditions—including Bollywood-style brass exuberance
column5: the devotional Qawwali music of Sufi Islam
column6: and bowed-string instruments associated with the Manganiar community.

column1: The result is a mix that includes folk feel and studied arrangements. Naturally
column2: with Greenwood's participation comes that of longtime Radiohead producer Nigel Godrich
column3: who succeeds in presenting this detailed music with precision. While Greenwood's presence guarantees a certain level of interest
column4: the newsiest takeaways from this album involve the skill of Ben Tzur and the musicians of the Rajasthan Express. The ensemble’s playing and the leader's compositions make Junun an easy stretch—though
column5: crucially
column6:
not a condescending one—for listeners otherwise unfamiliar with the great variety of methods often obscured by ""world music"" market-speak.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22494/homepage_large.85133bfc.jpg|Hexadic II|3807.0|Six Organs of Admittance|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2015-11-19 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:54.569315|"

Several years ago
column2: after tiring of the predictable patterns he sensed himself settling into as a guitar player
column3: Ben Chasny of Six Organs of Admittance decided to design a theoretical framework that would force his hands into different positions. Chasny distributed a deck of poker cards in a circular array of sets of six
column4: corresponding to the notes of the guitar. The relative positions of the cards gave Chasny a ""tonal field"" in which to operate
column5: as well as a set of notes from which to pick
column6: some indication of time and tempo
column7: and lyrical rules for the songs themselves.

column1: Though Chasny describes it as a ""caveman"" appropriation of similar constructs by Anthony Braxton and John Cage
column2: it is involved and elaborate enough <a href=""http://www.dragcity.com/products/the-hexadic-system"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">to prompt a book
column3: The Hexadic System
column4: published by Drag City this year. And February's Hexadic
column5: his public debut with the system
column6: felt like an attempt to declare its formidable nature. Showcasing the scope of the system felt as important as the songs. Unapologetically loud and aggressive
column7: with more than a whiff of hardline Japanese psych
column8: it was an extreme indoctrination into a new approach. Recorded with a fully loaded quartet
column9: the largely instrumental Hexadic was not for the faint of heart or those accustomed to Chasny’s softer side.

column1: For Hexadic II
column2: though
column3: Chasny used the same results of the system to create new solo versions of the songs. He swapped the electric for the acoustic
column4: added soft murmurs of harmonium and electronics and strings
column5: and sang on almost all of the songs. The output gives the Hexadic System a new patina of accessibility. On the penultimate track ""Vile Hell""
column6: Chasny jumps between notes at unexpected angles
column7: sounding like Derek Bailey in a windstorm
column8: before he stops playing altogether. He lets a faint
column9: luminous drone linger until it spills over into ""Poor Guild""
column10: the record’s gorgeous finale. Violinist Jen Gelineau matches the drone’s tone
column11: and Chasny picks his way through it. In a keening falsetto
column12: he offers a series of elliptical
column13: evocative phrases—""tiny excess/ eye maligned/ depict
column14: transfix."" It is the most purely pretty moment in Chasny’s enormous catalogue
column15: the sight of an early bloom
column16: opening slowly after an arduous winter.

column1: The nine tracks on Hexadic II follow the same order as their Hexadic counterparts
column2: and careful
column3: comparative listening does reveal analogous aspects. It’s more rewarding
column4: though
column5: to consider the differences
column6: or to take the sets as entirely separate products of the same process. The disparity shows just how far Chasny may be able to take an idea still in its early stages of execution. Where ""Wax Chance"" was a diabolical
column7: noise-soaked dirge
column8: ""Exultation Wave"" is an exquisite gallop
column9: with multiple guitar lines and multi-tracked vocals suggesting the density of the earlier work without trying to match it. Likewise
column10: the two-minutes of no-wave roar from ""Maximum Hexadic"" unfurl here into eight minutes of circular picking and ghastly vocals for ""Anyone’s Dawn"". Chasny’s playing invokes the same Middle Eastern influences that Sir Richard Bishop has often conjured
column11: while his singing recalls the fragile coo of Richard Youngs. What was shocking is now sublime.

column1: In that way
column2: the Hexadic System feels like a prism for Chasny
column3: able to draw different elements of his influences and approach based on the input and circumstances. The results are novel and approachable
column4: a combination that enables Chasny to transcend the examples of Cage and Braxton
column5: at least in execution. Despite the complexity of the system that produced Hexadic II
column6:
the songs and sounds measure up to the setup itself.    

"|21189.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21189-hexadic-ii/|7.8|Grayson Haver Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22580/homepage_large.7024dcdc.jpg|Agitations|32666.0|Lotic|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Janus']|2015-11-19 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:03:55.168958|"

The 30-minute mixtape Agitations finds producer Lotic (aka J'Kerian Morgan) at his least accessible
column2: most grating
column3: and perhaps not coincidentally
column4: his most ambitious and stirring. ""Agitations was born out of the frustrations that come with touring... and feeling increasingly out of touch with club culture and with the music industry in general
column5: Morgan said in preface to his latest release. Accordingly
column6: the music distances itself from the cyclical payoffs and rhythmic underpinnings of the dance floor. This is miles away from anything that could be considered ""club culture."" There’s something acutely alien about the tracks Morgan constructs
column7: as if the producer is dealing in a musical language that's yet to fully emerge.

column1: Throughout Agitations

column3: smashed

column7: Agitations
column8: much like 2014's Damsel in Distress and this year’s Heterocetera EP
column9: again reveals Lotic as a sly
column10: playful producer. On <i>Heterocetera

column12: reshaping it radically
column13: and he alludes to this same sample again here in the opening moments of ""Carried"". This version sounds pared-down and pixelated

column1: Agitations might not be conventional dance music

column8: unstable clusters

Andrew Hung’s piercingly electronic Rave Cave 2 is an ambitious and personal autobiographical effort. The initial two tracks are named after places in Hung’s life—""Ashill"" which Hung lists as his residence on Bandcamp
column2: is a bright and inviting opening number. ""Gladstone Park Gang"" is a shout out to a park in North London
column3: and the title itself is reminiscent of a key pastime among bored British youth: hanging out in a drab park
column4: smoking weed
column5: and drinking disgustingly cheap cider.

column1: The second installment of his debut solo venture
column2: Rave Cave 2 interweaves themes from the original but stands strong on its own
column3: and is in fact denser and richer overall. ""Ashill"" forgoes the syncopated swing of Rave Cave’s opener
column4: ""Fables""
column5: but still embodies that cheeriness. Though the choppy and sharp melody initially seems out of joint with the accompanying smooth
column6: heady synth bass
column7: the more repetitive it becomes
column8: the more it settles in.

column1: Throughout this EP
column2: Hung emulates the juxtaposing elements found in the nature of youth
column3: a time in life when everything is confusing and you have to navigate a path through conflicting options. ""Repetition vs Time"" summons a childlike wonder and calm
column4: with an intentionally cheesy chorus and boom-bap beats invoking nostalgia for playing keyboards in high school music class. Towards the latter end
column5: the song is more reminiscent of video game menu music than anything else
column6: but perhaps this is intentional. Hung’s littering of 8-bit grace notes is ultimately refreshing
column7: and an apt ode to his work as one half of Fuck Buttons.

column1: ""That thing you want won’t make you happy"" is distinctly melancholic in comparison to the rest of the record. It carries the melody of a more somber '90s boy band ballad
column2: and closes with finger-picked acoustic guitar tinged with subtle reverb. ""Star Ferry Dub"" immediately starts off as a pounding antithesis to the previous song. It’s heavy on the ears and on the heart
column3: flashing a raw hedonism seldom found in the Rave Cave series. The song rings in the musical themes evident throughout the EP—we are reintroduced to the 8-bit ornamentation of ""Repetition vs Time"" and that thumping arpeggiated bass echoing ""Ashill""
column4: but this time the ghosts of these tracks are more lingering and intense. There’s so much going on at once that it’s hard to pin down
column5: but the complexities and wide sonic scape don’t sound excessive or sloppily piled on top of one another. They’re seamless
column6: intricate
column7: and intoxicating. Then
column8: the imperfect cadence fades and stutters into oblivion
column9:
leaving the listener aching for more. Andrew Hung’s story isn’t over yet.

Michael Eagle and David Cohn knew each other years back as a couple fellow Southern Illinois University students. Both were interested in doing nervy hip-hop that rendered personal neuroses into allusive
column2: bittersweet comedy (and vice-versa). They know each other now as transplanted Angelenos with deep mutual respect
column3: a faithful cult fanbase
column4: and a creativity-stoking environment of collective support—but those neuroses can still be hard to shake. They keep finding successful ways to exorcise those frustrations
column5: cracking jokes and facades at the same time. Naturally
column6: they'd have a lot to ricochet off each other
column7: something that sporadic teamups only hinted at.

column1: Time & Materials gives that dynamic a shot over the course of 26 short minutes
column2: proving more than anything that there's more depth still left unexplored. The album's recorded under the name Cavanaugh
column3: and the setting of this brief-but-deep album is intriguing
column4: in a J.G. Ballard-via-The Coup kind of way: the inhabitants and social structures of a Florida mixed-income project featuring units for both luxury condos and subsidized housing tenants. ""Mike and Dave"" are resident handymen who schlep from residence to residence
column5: glimpsing other people's lives while doing what they can to keep the same systems functioning for the rich and the broke alike. And in the process
column6: they channel the residents' class-war conflicts into their own combative moods
column7: fueling their own stress over money
column8: relationships
column9: and an uncertain future that keeps them from being the assertive successes they want to be.

column1: Time & Materials tackles sociological themes that would be sledgehammer-obvious in less-nuanced hands. But the duo draws you in by skimping on or misdirecting details. Serengeti disappears deeper into his lyrical role than Mike does—understandable from an MC who's been known to do half a live set in the guise of a cranky
column2: bellowing 50-year-old. But for his first full-length production job
column3: Mike sets a tone as raw-nerved and abrasively contemplative as the concept demands. A soupy drone on ""Typecast"" evokes the stress and sweat of the escape-seeking protagonists
column4: including guest turns by P.O.S.
column5: Busdriver
column6: and Future Islands' Sam Herring in his purposefully-awkward rap alter ego Hemlock Ernst. The creaking sludge of opening track ""Zorak"" underscores the TV-casualty free association of the lyrics.

column1: The big drawback of the production's distorted
column2: synthwave-on-codeine atmosphere is that it threatens to muffle the rewind-demanding intricacies of both MCs—Serengeti's motormouthed turns of run-on worldbuilding in particular get trickier to grasp. It's also not always clear whether the characters Mike and Serengeti inhabit are the maintenance guys or the people they cross paths with and intrude on by necessity. Of course
column3: the larger question is whether they're really inhabiting or observing outside characters at all—""I"" heavily outnumbers ""you"" and ""they"" in the whole narrative pronoun department
column4:
and the fraying seams of their own mind states stand out no matter who's being profiled.

Though his music sometimes exhibits the romantic sweep of chamber music and can be marked with skittering beats
column3: Venezuela-born producer Alejandro Ghersi’s work as Arca is defined above all by its fluidity and flexibility. You can hear conventional musicality inside of his tracks—melodies
column4: chord changes—but rather than being fixed on paper
column5: they are always in flux. Individual notes twitch and vibrate
column6: refusing to stay with a single pitch; rapidly shifting clusters hint at proper chords without ever quite committing to them; tempos speed up and slow down according to whims rather than the grid of a timeline. Arca’s deeply organic machine music is defined by Ghersi’s ability to find grace in imperfection.

column1: Ghersi has come a long way in a short time
column2: his career the sort of underground/mainstream hybrid that could only happen in the digital era
column3: when producers rapidly move from sharing home-recorded beats online to working with stars. Though his music has varied greatly
column4: you’ve always been able to hear his voice inside of it. The first music heard from Ghersi was a series of three low-profile releases in 2012 that made small waves among electronic music heads but were little heard outside of that circle. But among that group was someone working on Kanye West’s 2013 album Yeezus
column5: and Arca wound up contributing to four tracks
column6: including ""Blood on the Leaves"" and ""I’m in It"". That same year
column7: he also produced for FKA twigs
column8: helping to create a futuristic pop that was simultaneously dense and spare and defined by its elusiveness. Xen
column9: Arca’s 2014 full-length debut
column10: expanded Ghersi’s range further
column11: sounding like a bent version of modern classical music crumpled into a ball with a post-dubstep beat tape. Music created for a fashion show in Italy earlier this year spoke further to Ghersi’s ability to move between genres
column12: scenes
column13: and high/low art boundaries
column14: and his continued collaboration with artist Jesse Kanda on the visual aspects of his work make Arca a project with a rare thematic integrity. He’s developing quickly but building on a clear foundation.

column1: If Aphex Twin took the playful communal energy of early-'90s rave and turned it to highly personal art
column2: and producers of the early '00s like Fennesz and Tim Hecker showed how emerging software could be used to create new worlds
column3: Arca is making the abstract electronic music of our current moment
column4: music for an idea of humanity that exists outside of binaries. ""Xen is a genderless being
column5: he told The Guardian last year. ""It’s about resisting labels and integrating different sides of ourselves."" Accordingly
column6: Arca tracks are never one fixed thing: Conventional beauty is swirled together with ugliness
column7: aggressiveness exists alongside serenity
column8: chaos and form fail to cancel each other out. Mutant is an album of contrasts
column9: and Ghersi has an uncanny ability to let extremes interact with each other to create something new.

column1: The 20 tracks here stretch for over an hour
column2: but lines between them are unclear
column3: and when heard at once the record can seem like one long suite
column4: treating us to an array of sounds and moods. You can imagine ""Vanity"" as a piano solo
column5: so pretty and memorable are the central melodic motifs
column6: but Ghersi’s production on the track is essentially a series of controlled explosions
column7: the sound of a song breaking into a million pieces and re-assembling itself. ""Alive""’s drones are positively cavernous
column8: sounding like a memory of an ancient civilization bubbling up through a hole in the earth
column9: and he breaks up the static drift with splattering breaks that jolt the song at irregular intervals. The repeated vocal loop on ""Umbilical"" is one of the few sounds on the record connected to life on planet Earth
column10: but it’s mixed in with some of the album’s harshest and coldest electronics. As the tracks tick off and you lose track of how far into the album you actually are
column11: the clarity of Ghersi’s vision comes into focus. The broken-ness of the music takes on an empowering energy
column12: as oblong fragments bind together into gorgeously weird shapes and dynamic shifts that shouldn’t make sense feel perfectly logical.

column1: Compared to Xen
column2: Mutant feels less composed and less indebted to classical music. With many tracks on the former album you could squint a little bit and imagine them being performed by a daring new music ensemble
column3: à la Aphex Twin with Alarm Will Sound. But Mutant leans toward soundscape
column4: avoiding proper songs. There are moments in the back half
column5: particularly on ""Enveloped""
column6: where beats crop up and you can imagine them being used to back a pop production of some kind
column7: but even here the warped instrumental patch used for the melody is too strange and otherworldly for an artist that has ever been on the radio. It’s not an easy listen; this is glorious music that sounds like a living thing
column8: and it can be hard to connect the album to anything outside of itself. Spanish architect Antoni Gaudí said that the straight line belongs to man and the curved to God; on Mutant
column9:
Ghersi turns a fixation on porousness and instability into a kind of spiritual pursuit.

Kode9
column2: also known as Hyperdub label head Steve Goodman
column3: always creates multilayered tracks that sound built from another era or planet entirely. From his work driving the early dubstep scene to the formidable rise and influence of Hyperdub
column4: Goodman’s vision is one that is singular in its devotion to the connective tissues of electronic and dance music genres. In Kode9’s music (and littered throughout the Hyperdub roster) is a harmonious bridge between styles. His music is not without history and ideas
column5: and Goodman openly embraces it.

column1: The most complicated forms of techno and footwork are built simply
column2: from the ground up
column3: and on Nothing
column4: we hear the simplicity of each component and how it all comes together to make the music that we love. ""I’ve always tried to be open to the idea of music as transversal
column5: as impersonal – like a cloud
column6: or a virus that passes through populations
column7: Goodman told The Guardian. ""It might start with an individual producer
column8: but once it’s out in the world – as an entity that’s inhabiting
column9: parasiting
column10: using human bodies as hosts – somehow it attains a collective intelligence all of its own.""

column1: Consider the unnerving pull of a synth that sounds like a dying insect working in tandem with piano on ""Vacuum Packed"". The track builds into footwork-light with hyper-paced rhythms and a cutting beat that is maybe the record’s most danceable moment. ""Void"" is a slow-burning and dubby wonder that contains empty moments where his former musical partner Spaceape
column2: who died in 2014
column3: was originally intended to vocalize. ""Holo"" is the record's brightest and most enjoyable moment
column4: built on airy samples and a spastic beat that is difficult to forget. Nothing leaves you awash in the sounds of the everyday: The static of the television not turned entirely turned off
column5: the lull of old appliances stumbling to stay on after years of wear and tear.

column1: There is a precision and effort laced in his two previous albums
column2: 2006’s Memories of the Future and 2011’s Black Sun
column3: that clearly mark a singular producer’s craftsmanship. But on his latest work
column4: this point feels more eloquent from start to finish. Goodman described this record as one about zeroes and about ""nothing."" In that same interview with the Guardian
column5: Goodman said
column6: “If replication and distribution costs are tending towards zero
column7: this is one of the most important engines in the transformation of the music industry. We don’t know where it’s heading. ‘Nothing’ was like a little encryption key that enabled me to finish the album.""

column1: A quick glance at song titles confirms this trend
column2: at least stylistically. There is ""Zero Point Energy"" and ""Notel"". There is ""Void"" and ""Zero Work"". And there is the album closer
column3: ""Nothing Lasts Forever""
column4: a nearly 11-minute journey through the noise of silence
column5: a kind of John Cage tribute for the new millennium. Awash in static and the sporadic
column6: indescribable clanging of the day-to-day
column7: the track helps define the work as a whole in a clearer way than the songs before it. If
column8: as Goodman notes
column9: things are tending toward ""zero
column10: then this track is the literal manifestation of this idea. Still
column11: there is value in the zero and value in ""Nothing Lasts Forever"". In the absence of music
column12: in the zero
column13: there is still presence
column14: still sound
column15:
still something to hear (and even enjoy).

New artists face intimidating challenges after signing to major labels. For starters
column2: creating a debut that not only sees the light of day
column3: but is successful enough to warrant a follow-up. In certain cases
column4: that first album is everything they’ve been waiting to say for years
column5: but the second album is the bigger test
column6: as it proves that the artist has something to say beyond the cathartic release of emotions heard on their debut effort. For instance
column7: Logic’s 2014 debut
column8: Under Pressure
column9: was a detailed account of his chaotic Gaithersburg
column10: Md. origin layered with his method of coping with stress while trying to escape the situation before it consumed him. It was honest and
column11: on occasion
column12: impressive. The announcement of his second collection
column13: The Incredible True Story
column14: generated questions about how Logic could follow something as intricate and personal as Under Pressure. Where could he go? The answer: outer space.

column1: Under Pressure was evidence of Logic’s attention to specifics
column2: which he remains committed to on The Incredible True Story. You may have noticed him often wearing a NASA flight jacket leading up the album’s release
column3: similar to a movie director wearing a t-shirt or hat emblazoned with the name of his latest film. On The Incredible True Story
column4: he assumes the role of screenwriter and director
column5: claiming to have written a script for the album. It’s set 100 years in the future
column6: as the two narrators
column7: Thomas and Kai
column8: search for a planet named Paradise following Earth’s destruction. (Thalia
column9: who served as the Midnight Marauders-inspired virtual guide on Under Pressure
column10: returns as the computer for the ship driven by the narrators. Thankfully
column11: she’s still more Siri than HAL 9000.) During their journey
column12: the duo revisit the past through Logic’s music.

column1: Because Logic’s catalog serves as an artifact in the album’s narrative
column2: the early placement of ""Fade Away"" is calculated. Over a dreamy sample reminiscent of a doo-wop song
column3: Logic reflects on death’s inevitability: everyone dies eventually
column4: so strive to create something that lives on after you. ""Upgrade"" maintains the futuristic theme (The Fifth Element allusions and all) as Logic explains how success has altered both his day-to-day existence and his perspective.

column1: Despite being set in the future
column2: the album takes time to dip into the past. On ""Young Jesus""
column3: Logic and guest Big Lenbo trade verses over producer 6ix’s recreation of '90s hip-hop ambiance. Its highest points come on the second and third verses
column4: where Logic hands the song off to Big Lenbo like they’re performing live and sharing a mic. Logic’s introspective thoughts match the mellow calm of ""Innermission""
column5: as he longs for the ability to revisit certain moments just to dwell in them again. It’s a moment of clarity most folks arrive at as they get older: you’ll never be present in your memories again.

column1: This is another constant theme on The Incredible True Story—Logic’s evolution under the spotlight. ""City of Stars"" finds him at his most sincere. Once Logic’s harmonizing breaks
column2: his and 6ix's production becomes more aggressive as Logic unloads his frustrations with hip-hop
column3: including the fixation on the biracial MC’s appearance. ""I didn’t talk about my race on the whole first album/ But black versus white bullshit was still the outcome
column4: he rhymes
column5: clearly exasperated. He then takes aim at critics
column6: amateur and professional
column7: who chide Drake for harping on ""money and bitches"" yet praise 2Pac for doing the same. Logic is at his best when getting shit off his chest
column8: but even in the midst of these brazen admissions
column9: there are still missteps.

column1: From its off-kilter drag to his deployment of boast-riddled yells in the place of bars
column2: ""I Am the Greatest"" reeks of Drake’s If You’re Reading This It’s Too Late. Recycled flows and rhyme schemes are common in this era of hip-hop
column3: but there’s a fine line between homage and imitation. Furthermore
column4: while Logic has proven himself to be a talented MC who respects hip-hop culture and puts obvious effort into his work
column5: there’s very little on The Incredible True Story that's worth constant replays. The music is enjoyable and Logic’s ambition is evident
column6: but the final product just doesn’t attach itself to the memory.

column1: The Incredible True Story is a pleasant voyage to Paradise orchestrated by an artist who’s earned the approval of legends from Rick Rubin to Big Daddy Kane. Logic has the tools to create music that has longevity
column2: but has yet to unlock the characteristics that truly set him apart. If he’s able to tap into that
column3:
his subsequent releases will have the impact he aspires for.

Over the last couple of years
column2: f(x) have become one of the few K-pop groups with real international appeal and a sizable fan base in the States. The group's sophomore album
column3: 2013’s Pink Tape
column4: was a pop collage of ambitious sounds and ideas that tinkered with K-pop formulas
column5: and it still stands as one of the best records the genre has ever produced. Last year’s Red Light offered a decidedly edgier synthpop sound that leaned more toward the club
column6: though it didn’t quite meet the standard set by its predecessor. And during the promo for Red Light
column7: group member Sulli
column8: an actress and star for the conglomerate S.M. Entertainment
column9: was noticeably absent from scheduled media events. After talk of mental exhaustion and a temporary f(x) hiatus
column10: Sulli officially withdrew from the group in August
column11: leaving K-pop’s most consistent act in a state of flux.

column1: 4 Walls is f(x)'s fourth album and first with four members—hence the name—and it lands right where Pink Tape and Red Light intersect
column2: creating a sleek electropop fun-house filled with an eclectic group of generation-spanning pop singles that fit together as a long-playing piece. It’s also the first K-pop comeback to fully acknowledge a lineup change—going as far as incorporating it into the album's marketing and lyrics—but it doesn't change much about the group’s sound. This is a superficial rebirth; though the album’s lead single and title track has veiled references to changing and becoming new
column3: f(x)’s synthpop bounce remains steadfast and uncompromised. And though Sulli was undoubtedly a standout among the group
column4: her departure allows others to grab the spotlight: Now
column5: not only does rapper Amber have the opportunity to rap more
column6: she also gets the chance to use her alto range to flesh out harmonies and bring greater balance to records like ""Rude Love""
column7: an ambitious
column8: hook-heavy tune that rivals the group's most infectious songs.

column1: Many tracks on 4 Walls are sourced through Jam Factory
column2: a music publisher that uses American musicians to create lyrics and melodies for Asian markets. The company’s strength lies in penning sounds without borders
column3: and some of 4 Walls’ strongest collaborations involve producer LDN Noise
column4: who creates pop songs with bridges that function as hooks and transitions that overlap to keep songs stimulating. Album closer ""When I’m Alone""
column5: meanwhile
column6: was originally co-written by Carly Rae Jepsen for her recent E•MO•TION album. But the real X-factor is longtime f(x) collaborator
column7: writer
column8: and K-pop superproducer Kenzie
column9: who wrote two of the album's most curious songs: ""Papi"" and ""Cash Me Out"". A Berklee School of Music grad
column10: Kenzie navigates the cultural divide better than anyone.

column1: Listening to any K-pop record (or any foreign language record
column2: really) can prove to be a challenging experience for casual listeners simply due to the added communication barrier. You can also lose some key information in translation—even when you know what's being said
column3: there's a layer of context missing. Still
column4: just like any other type of music
column5: a listener has the opportunity to fill in some of that context on their own; stripping Korean of its code is no different than reinterpreting a really dense English lyric. 4 Walls is even more accessible because f(x) songs tend to have a lot of Western cues: Many of the melodies recall songs from the American pop canon and
column6: as with many K-pop songs
column7: there are English lyrics spliced in throughout (at one point
column8: Amber raps
column9: ""I was low key/ That’s the old me/ Now there’s Top 10 honeys tryna phone me"").

column1: Western pop fans don’t need to be heavily invested in the K-pop world to get the appeal of f(x)’s music
column2: and 4 Walls is an enjoyable listen even for those not looking to broach the language gap. Korean is a beautiful language with long multi-syllabic words that unspool in clumps and it carries American-stylized pop melodies fluently
column3: breaking up long vowel sounds to fit into sonic phrases. There are few better introductions to K-pop than f(x)
column4:
and 4 Walls is a strong introduction to f(x) 2.0.

In 1974
column2: surrealist filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky was tapped to direct his adaptation of Frank Herbert's monumental sci-fi novel Dune. The film was set to star David Carradine
column3: Gloria Swanson
column4: Mick Jagger
column5: Orson Welles
column6: Salvador Dalí
column7: and Amanda Lear. Meanwhile
column8: after the producers considered none other than Karlheinz Stockhausen
column9: Pink Floyd was slated to compose along with contributions from the French prog-rock outfit Magma. Jodorowsky was given a lavish budget but the film didn't make it past its intensive pre-production stage.

column1: As Frank Pavich's 2013 documentary Jodorowsky's Dune illustrates
column2: Jodorowsky and his production team put a great deal of effort into storyboarding and design
column3: with an eye for detail that would've made Stanley Kubrick blush. As it turns out
column4: the great irony of Jodorowsky's career is that he made his most widely-felt impact with a film he never even began shooting. To this day
column5: his work on Dune continues to reflect in popular cinema and culture. In a sense
column6: his version of Dune died giving birth to the genre-defining films that emerged in its wake. Alien
column7: for example
column8: was written by Dan O'Bannon and of course bore the unmistakable design aesthetic of Swiss painter H.R. Giger—both of whom had been brought in for Jodorowsky's production. This backstory
column9: of course
column10: frames Kurt Stenzel's score to Pavich's documentary and vice-versa.

column1: So many things could have gone wrong here had Stenzel attempted to encompass the pretense and grandeur of the subject at hand. ""We need to try
column2: he writes in the liner notes—the implication being that we as the audience should put forth our best effort both to imagine the film Jodorowsky envisioned and to honor the scale of what he was aiming to accomplish. But Stenzel's score—which consists mainly of a bunch of analog synths that he sequenced and mixed in real time (with no additional digital sequencing)—actually requires little effort from listeners.

column1: Given the psychedelic quality of Jodorowsky's most well-known films
column2: El Topo and The Holy Mountain
column3: it's no surprise that in the documentary the maverick Chilean director talks about wanting to mimic the effects of LSD with Dune. But his goals didn't stop there. Jodorowsky breathlessly describes how his film was to serve as a ""prophet""—not as a prophecy
column4: but as a living
column5: breathing entity with a consciousness of its own. ""For me
column6: he declares on camera
column7: ""Dune will be the coming of a God. An artistic and cinematographic God.""

column1: To Stenzel's credit
column2: although he does fall prey to a bit of reverence—most notably in passages that feature audio samples of Jodorowsky waxing poetic on what moviemaking means to him—the music doesn't strive to be anywhere near as lofty as that. Stenzel is wise to go for a more discreet
column3: at times even whimsical
column4: tone that supports the documentary's easygoing
column5: storytelling structure. It's too bad that Stenzel
column6: when he does opt to use Jodorowsky monologues
column7: doesn't get more creative with them by chopping them up or subjecting them to effects
column8: but the samples occur rarely and end up being incidental to the score's overall flavor anyway.

column1: Charmingly
column2: the liner notes include a list of all the synth gear Stenzel used
column3: just in case you're interested in geeking-out. But that would be missing the point. Stenzel's score doesn't stand out so much for the tools he used to create it as much as for the choices he made while using those tools. Pavich instructed Stenzel to go for a ""Tangerine Dream-type feel
column4: and as such the predictable path would have been to mimic the wheezing
column5: primitive synthesizer sounds that define sci-fi cinema of the '60s and '70s—sounds that now feel quaint at best and moldy at worst. Had Stenzel emulated the audacious bleeting style of
column6: say
column7: early Moog pioneer Richard Teitelbaum
column8: Emerson Lake & Palmer
column9: or any number of artists from the period
column10: he would have artificially encased this music in a temporal ambience it doesn't actually require in order to engage your attention. Ultimately
column11: not unlike the French electronic duo Air
column12: Stenzel has too much creative inspiration to settle for being a stylist
column13: and though he openly references the past
column14: he lands with both feet firmly anchored in the present.

column1: Pavich's documentary more or less consists of a string of interviews undercut with shots of old photos and storyboard drawings. Clearly then
column2: Stenzel's job was to keep the music moving along to match whatever pace Pavich set as appropriate for the audience's patience threshold. Stenzel shifts quickly but gracefully from one motif to the next
column3: weaving sounds in and out like a choreographer who prefers to stay offstage while guiding each ""dancer""—each new instrument
column4: melody
column5: textural element
column6: or structural change—into the fray on cue. By turns dramatic
column7: spaced-out
column8: otherworldly
column9: entrancing
column10: stately
column11: ominous
column12: hopeful
column13: playful
column14: and chatty
column15: most of the tracks on Jodorowsky's Dune run about a minute long and manage to cover more than one mood before they run that course. Taken as a whole
column16: they stream by yet never feel rushed
column17: and Stenzel establishes his dual knack for patience and economy very early on.

column1: In what is perhaps this album's defining moment
column2: a high-pitched synth line wails and echoes in a vast empty space. Stenzel gives it a character and shape not unlike those celestial bodies that appear to us via deep-space photography as giant
column3: colorful plumes. The lone synth line segues into a live drumset
column4: the first appearance of organic instruments and room ambience on the whole album. The drums don't last long
column5: and soon they too meld into vaguely Middle Eastern-sounding chants before the voices grow more distressed. Then
column6: a snarling
column7: heavily filtered electric guitar riff that recalls Tool's ""Forty-Six & 2"" makes its entrance before flaring out as quickly as it came. One might expect these elements to step on each other's toes. But
column8: as with just about every other sound that leads up to this passage
column9: Stenzel creates a sensation of smooth sailing
column10: even as he radically alters the scenery every few minutes. On Jodorowsky’s Dune
column11:
Stenzel takes you across topographic oceans that never rock the boat.

Purpose is less an album than a deliberate act of repositioning. As much as 2012's Believe was intended as Justin Bieber's micro-adjustment into adulthood
column2: the advance singles for Purpose
column3: ""What Do You Mean?"" and ""Sorry""
column4: are his first hits without any traces of teen-pop. They're designed much in the spirit of ""Where Are Ü Now""
column5: his single with Skrillex and Diplo from earlier this year

column7: respectively
column8: by MdL and Skrillex (who contributes six productions to the record)
column9: ""What Do You Mean?"" and ""Sorry"" are vivid tropical house tracks that sound like sunlight drifting down through palm fronds. Bieber's voice often resembles a breath contorted inexpressively through notes; here
column10: he lets it weightlessly fall through textures. They are his best performances to date
column11: allowing him to flex a rhythmic playfulness without communicating an iota of legible emotion.

column1: Purpose doesn't particularly follow up on the advances suggested by his previous release
column2: the 2013 R&B experiment Journals. That record was Bieber's first attempt at casting himself as an adult
column3: but its efforts
column4: alternately curious and anonymous
column5: went largely unnoticed. For its part

column11: and it doesn't do much to justify the severity of its perspective.

column1: The songs on Purpose have a similarly inanimate feeling; they seem to radiate more than they move. ""No Sense"" feels oddly hookless and almost willfully ugly
column2: and when Travis Scott surfaces toward the end of the track
column3: he registers as just another cold texture. Nothing here has the captivating
column4: lopsided construction of Journals' ""Confident"". ""No Pressure""
column5: featuring Big Sean
column6: comes close with its shimmering
column7: processed acoustic guitars—though the song might have appeared lighter and more nimble in the hands of someone like Usher.

column1: In general
column2: vagueness
column3: indecision
column4: and faint befuddlement suit Bieber best. ""The Feeling""
column5: produced by Skrillex
column6: describes a liminal
column7: unstable state (""Am I in love or am I in love with the feeling?"")
column8: and the track fittingly seems to slip in and out of focus. Halsey
column9: who released one of the worst singles of the year with ""New Americana""
column10: proves an ideal counterweight to Bieber

column12: when Bieber is allowed to remain a lithe and fluttery element zippering in and out of a canvas
column13: he sounds most comfortable.

column1: But when Bieber is required to slow down and emote
column2: he sounds adenoidal and aggressively blank. ""Life Is Worth Living""
column3: a piano ballad in which every chord seems indifferently faxed in
column4: is one of the many songs on which Bieber struggles to justify himself to the public. ""My reputation's on the line
column5: so I'm working on a better me
column6: he sings. As much as this record is part of his long campaign of rehabilitation

column8: he sings

column10: as if gesturing to a PowerPoint presentation.

column1: The second half of the album is monochromatic and depressing
column2: especially as it runs out to 20 tracks in certain versions. (Two of the bonus tracks
column3: ""Been You"" and ""Get Used to It""
column4: are pneumatic

A classic singer-songwriter never goes out of style. The soulful and enigmatic crooner Jamie Woon rediscovered this in the four long years between his charming-but-uneven debut album
column3: Mirrorwriting

column1: Like many artists in his position

column6: strong melodies

column1: Woon's vocals are rare and stunning

column3: and no synths or heavy-handed production is needed to make that effect possible. The instruments here play supporting roles. ""Movement"" transforms halfway through its length into a groovy
column4: throwback jam
column5: and the slinky
column6: snake-like bass guitar cocoons Woon’s voice without overpowering it. Later the horns gradually stomp in. Their sound is elastic and ominous
column7: pushing and pulling against the light fluidity of Woon’s ad-libs. And on ""Sharpness""
column8: the album’s lead single

column1: Channeling pieces of piano jazz and folk as well as R&B

column3: Tough Love. Many described the work as ""adult contemporary""—an insult

column6: songs like ""Kind Of … Sometimes … Maybe"" and ""Champagne Kisses"" offered surprises brimming underneath the surface. It’s smart music that doesn’t beat you over the head with its intelligence. If Woon’s last album was an attempt to incorporate the contemporary sounds he favored at the time
column7: this current album is a testament to the strength of traditional music composition: simple guitars
column8: slinky bass lines
column9: and sophisticated songwriting. Woon has

column13:
little else needs to be said.

column6: up and down-down-down"" chant. The song's title? ""Stripper Pole"".

column1: Ty has honed this musically refined yet lyrically raunchy aesthetic for years
column2: from his Raw & Bangin' tapes to his breakout single ""My Cabana""
column3: to the louche Beach House series to last month's made-in-a-day Airplane Mode. It's a balancing act very few have mastered—and Ty bows to or has recruited anyone who has here—but he does it on a hoverboard while texting two or 10 girls.

column1: To be sure
column2: it helps that his musical gifts are many: he writes hooks that lodge in your head for weeks and he arranges four-part harmonies like an R&B George Martin. His molasses-dipped voice never misses a note even when it darts up into falsetto. He's stoked about sweeping orchestrations
column3: '80s smooth jazz sax solos
column4: and acoustic songs with Babyface. His confidence is why he flies when he swings for the fences on his new album
column5: Free TC. On its dazzling highlight
column6: ""Miracle/Wherever""
column7: TC
column8: the album's incarcerated namesake and Ty's younger brother
column9: sings a vibrato-heavy hymn of perseverance over a prison phone. Midway through
column10: Ty joins in. After putting God first and damning the haters with the conviction of a newly born-again Christian
column11: he begins to pray. Musically
column12: the shift is exquisite. But what's truly special is Ty's porcelain
column13: Prince-like falsetto. Over dirty 808s and a stirring chord progression
column14: his pristine voice pops out of the ether singing about—what else?—lying with a woman in the
column15: uh
column16: biblical sense. Ty said he spent $60
column17: 000 of his own money on the Benjamin Wright Orchestra. If all that bought was the final 20 seconds of ""Wherever""
column18: he should consider it money well spent.

column1: Predecessors who've climbed that Lucite-heel littered stairway to heaven before Ty are thanked outright. On ""Blasé""
column2: the best song currently in radio rotation
column3: Ty sings
column4: ""I think I'm Nate Dogg."" Obviously. Love notes like ""When I See Ya"" sound ripped right from Nate's notebook. Another standout
column5: ""Credit""
column6: features Sevyn Streeter and recalls ""Be Careful""
column7: R. Kelly's collaboration with Sparkle. Kellz actually makes an appearance on the sleek and glittery ""Actress""
column8: which sounds far more like Hollywood than the Valley. ""Straight Up""
column9: the album's sexiest song
column10: samples Patrice Rushen's quiet storm classic
column11: ""Settle for My Love"" and finds Jagged Edge downgrading their classic proposal from the altar to the bar.

column1: Ty's up to his old ""how many hoes?"" tricks on Free TC
column2: too
column3:
even if a woman is responsible for writing ""Horses in the Stable"". You can credit both his fireside manner and his forthright delivery—there is no fine print in a Ty Dolla $ign song—for the fact that plenty of women will still slip into his silk sheet-covered waterbed despite his warnings.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22558/homepage_large.892f910b.jpg|Hell EP|27360.0|The Pains of Being Pure at Heart|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Painbow']|2015-11-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:04:05.130222|"

For all the instant good will they stockpiled with their woozily sincere take on ’80s and ’90s indie-pop
column2: the Pains of Being Pure at Heart have always invited doubts that they were
column3: at their core
column4: little more than gifted impressionists. Mostly they’ve let any criticisms about their originality bounce right off of them. Instead of trying to prove themselves more than the sum of their record collections
column5: they’ve simply continued showing off how vast those record collections are. 2011’s Belong expanded on their debut’s C86 jangle with blood-rushing alternative rock
column6: while last year’s understated Days of Abandon took an even deeper tour through the Hall of Semi-Obscure UK College Rock than their debut did.

column1: That tour continues on their new Hell EP. It’s one of the band’s most low-stakes releases yet: an original song
column2: which band leader Kip Berman first posted as a demo along with several songs that didn’t make the cut for Days of Abandon
column3: and two quick covers. In hindsight
column4: he might have done well to find room for Hell's title track on Days of Abandon; its chipper spirit would have helped lighten an album that sometimes begged for a pick-me-up. Like nearly every Pains of Being Pure at Heart track
column5: it’s obsessively specific in its influences
column6: with a sticky disco groove that nods to Orange Juice and the puppy-dog giddiness of an early Close Lobsters single. Even Berman's vocals feel like an homage; he sings in a warbled sigh that sounds a lot like Pete Shelley.

column1: Given how openly the band has always embraced their influences
column2: it’s surprising they haven’t recorded more covers—Berman often seems to be channeling other artists’ voices and accents anyway
column3: so it’s not much of a leap to sing their words
column4: too. Each of Hell’s covers serve as a statement of taste. One celebrates one of the quintessential overlooked British guitar-pop bands Felt’s “Ballad of the Band”
column5: while the other reclaims a familiar if underappreciated hit
column6: James’ “Laid”
column7: a treasure of a song that lost much of its cache when the American Pie franchise claimed it as its own.

column1: Both are too faithful to offer any real surprises
column2: and the band’s last album already owed so much to Felt that their “Ballad of the Band” almost feels redundant. “Laid” delivers more of a kick. Their version doesn’t quite capture the orgasmic glee of James’ original
column3: but it features a game lead vocal turn from A Sunny Day in Glasgow singer Jen Goma
column4: who’s been moonlighting with Pains since their recent lineup shakeup. Unlike Berman
column5: she’s not afraid to leave her own stamp on her cover
column6: and she punctuates the song’s most biting line with just the right amount of a punk snarl: “Dye my eyes and call me pretttttttty.”

column1: Pains’ debut album introduced a band that had not only clearly mastered their influences
column2: but seemed on the brink of doing something truly new with them. Six years later
column3: it’s now clear they have no interest in that; Berman is too reverentially devoted to his muses to risk bastardizing them. When a band’s output is this consistently pleasant
column4: it's petty to complain too much about originality
column5: but Hell is the group’s second overly safe release in a row
column6:
and it’s hard not to wish they’d start taking a few more chances. This band is talented enough to be aiming much higher.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22528/homepage_large.51a0e4f3.jpg|Skid Row|28709.0|James Ferraro|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Break World']|2015-11-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:04:05.660230|"

Even before the ongoing coast-to-coast exodus
column2: Los Angeles has always held a mythic allure to New Yorkers. To a nearly surreal extent
column3: every meaningful aspect of living in New York is inverted there
column4: like some kind of Gulliver's Travels opposite-land paradise–a place of endless cars and infinite residential square footage
column5: where generalized anxiety is something to be worked on rather than bragged about and people seem to enjoy going to bed at a reasonable hour.

column1: Despite all the breathless endorsements from transplants that swear that they've never felt so good before
column2: L.A. does have a substantial dark side–a populace dealing with PTSD after years of gang violence compounded by police violence
column3: the reactionary paranoia wafting in from Orange County
column4: its ongoing ecological disaster. It's a place where you can stand in the window of a multimillion dollar loft downtown and gaze out over an ephemeral shanty town that blooms and evaporates daily
column5: cocktail in hand
column6: feeling like nothing so much as a sci-fi villain.

column1: After producing a convincingly jittery
column2: grimy portrait of late-Bloomberg New York on 2013's <i>NYC
column3: Hell 3:00 AM
column4: James Ferraro has accomplished a similar likeness of his adopted hometown Los Angeles with its follow-up
column5: Skid Row. It comes as no surprise that his L.A. album is short on sunshine and mellow vibes
column6: and long on looming existential dread. There's not much of New L.A. in his portrait
column7: no bohemian Brooklyn expats chillaxing in a pleasant new climate. Ferraro's L.A. is a dystopian vision stitched together from its drought-stricken everyone's-a-reality-show present and the bad old '90s
column8: where the riots
column9: the OJ trial
column10: and the LAPD's corrupt culture blurred together to cast an ominous shadow on the city's carefully cultivated image.

column1: His urban pessimism remains undulled–as does his passion for oppressively ugly recording techniques–but Ferraro's switched up some of his musical approach. While Hell 3:00 AM sounded like a nightmare version of contemporary R&B
column2: Skid Row does something similar with L.A.'s native funk styles
column3: which have recently been revived in less bleak ways by the likes of Flying Lotus and Kendrick Lamar.

column1: Ferraro's take on funk strips away all of its organic sensuality and joy
column2: leaving a creepy husk that's still fascinating to inspect. ""White Bronco""
column3: which kicks off the record after one of the computer-generated spoken word introductions that have become something of a Ferraro trademark–this one featuring a pair babbling about gated communities and ""burning Priuses on the highway"" and conducting a transaction for an iced latte–slows a slow-jam groove down even slower until it sounds eerily narcotized and its minimalist synth bass riff takes on a menacing aspect. Ferraro's monotone listing of facts from the Nicole Brown Simpson murder trial mixed in with samples of TV news surrounding the Rodney King beating conflate the two sensational acts of violence like someone who's either heavily intoxicated or just suffered a head injury. At the two-thirds point of the song
column4: Ferraro hits a vocal lick that sounds like Snoop's ""'G' Thang"" flow
column5: and it feels like some kind of sick punchline.

column1: Ferraro's freer with hooks on Skid Row than he was on Hell 3:00 AM
column2: and there are songs like ""Thrash Escalate"" and ""Rhinestones"" that sound like they could slap if they were sped up a few percent. He might be starting to come to terms with his innate pop talents
column3: or it could just be a new tactic of dispensing hints of traditional pop pleasures into the gloom to keep his audience off balance.

column1: Skid Row isn't really about those singular moments though
column2: or about walking away from it with a hook stuck in your head. They're just elements in a solidly built cohesive whole that feels like a J.G. Ballard novel filtered through late-night Ableton sessions
column3:
and a worthy addition to the long line of punk albums about Los Angeles that render it as a city built on fantasy with a nihilistic streak that runs to its core.
