column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22549/homepage_large.43322b97.jpg|Know It All|32917.0|Alessia Cara|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Def Jam']|2015-11-16 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:04:06.160892|"

Alessia Cara has become a star very quickly. Her coming out party
column2: which came in the form of the loner anthem “Here
column3: ” exposed a receptive world to a soulful R&B sound. Cara’s lament about a less-than-enjoyable party made her a poster child for Introvert Nation at a time when shyness—thanks to writers like Susan Cain and various digital media outlets — has been recast as an identity unto itself.

column1: Def Jam
column2: Cara’s label
column3: soon released more of her songs
column4: several of them country-tinged pop that recall artists like Taylor Swift and Haim. In Cara’s case
column5: that sound tends to go hand in hand with bland
column6: vaguely “rebellious” lyrics. In the pop songs on her Four Pink Walls EP—including the potential megahits “Seventeen” and “I’m Yours”—Cara’s appealing personality is sometimes hard to unearth from under the layers of pop gloss that have been poured on top of her.

column1: But the EP seems to have been what the label was looking for
column2: at least as evidenced by the fact that its five songs have been transposed onto the front of Cara’s debut album
column3: <i>Know-It-All
column4: in the same order
column5: with very few changes made. The speed at which Cara is being groomed and prompted to put out new releases feels distasteful if sadly not unfamiliar
column6: something like an AAU prospect being coaxed to go pro before he’s entirely ready.

column1: In many ways
column2: though
column3: Cara is ready. Her winning personality shines in recent public appearances (watch her slay “Here” on “Late Night on Seth Meyers”)
column4: and her voice
column5: with its warmth and character
column6: can transform a so-so song into something far more compelling. She’s able to mine an otherwise simple ballad like “Stone
column7: ” from the second half of Know-It-All
column8: as if it were a rich emotional deposit
column9: bringing pathos even to a bland line like
column10: “I think I think too much.”

column1: Though “Stone” is the only song that explicitly features Sebastian Kole
column2: he contributed plenty as one of the album’s producers and a co-writer. Kole
column3: who has been in the factory songwriting system for a little while now also makes his own music. Two things jump out at a first-time listener: his gorgeous voice and painful earnestness. That helps explain why he’s helped construct such compelling vocal showcases for Cara
column4: but also why her punchiness has been overtaken by something more cuddly. (“Wild Things
column5: ” which transforms Cara’s grousing into a lame children’s book reference is the most obvious example.)

column1: A Times profile of Cara from May reveals something of Kole’s approach. As a songwriting exercise
column2: he compelled Cara to write confessionals as if they were meant for no one but her — and then email them to him. The sound of those emails may well be reflected in the soppy ballad “Stars.” “I need you
column3: baby I need to
column4: let down my guard
column5: and give you my scars/ Open up my heart and we could be stars
column6: ” she sings. It’s easy to see how this form of diaristic writing could be confused with the honesty that made “Here” such a winner. But writing from the heart does not automatically imbue lyrics with depth.

column1: Never is it more apparent that the factory approach is not allowing Cara to fulfill her potential than on “Scars To Your Beautiful.” The first verse is so arresting that I’m tempted to just quote it in full. It’s about a woman who deeply wishes to be beautiful and feels that she isn’t. The verse ends on a showstopping
column2: deeply upsetting line: “She tries to cover up her pain
column3: and cut her woes away/ Cause covergirls don’t cry after their face is made."" It is frustrating
column4: though sadly inevitable given Know-It-All’s tendencies
column5: that the chorus then reverts to uplifting pablum. The hook forces itself not only to redeem the devastation of the verse
column6: but to do so cloyingly
column7: without any kind of subtlety or empathy for the subject it rendered so well.

column1: The industry has always wanted its pop stars to be all things to all people
column2: and it’s easier to be kind and inspiring than it is to write songs that can be difficult to hear. But generality is the enemy of good songwriting
column3: which
column4: on some level
column5: Cara clearly knows. She urged her label to release “Here” as a debut single and thankfully they listened. As she gets older
column6: her voice should get stronger
column7: on her own songs
column8:
and in fighting to get the right ones made.

Three Lobed Recordings operates from the brightly lit basement of a one-floor midcentury home in a quiet subdivision of modest ranches outside of Greensboro
column2: the third largest city in North Carolina. When the label issued its first vinyl box set in conjunction with its 10th anniversary in 2011
column3: Cory Rayborn—Three Lobed’s owner
column4: a lawyer by day—joked of the operation’s at-home modesty by way of a sales pitch. “In this case
column5: ” he wrote of his staff
column6: “‘we’ means one human and three feline assistants.”

column1: Since the release of that collection
column2: the excellent <i>Not the Spaces You Know
column3: but Between Them
column4: Three Lobed has continued unabated with its curatorial quest through the weird annals of experimental American folk
column5: drone
column6: and rock. The pace has been methodical
column7: with four or so albums a year
column8: but the execution masterful. In that span
column9: Three Lobed has served as a syndicate for some of the world’s best
column10: relatively young solo guitarists—Chuck Johnson
column11: William Tyler
column12: Sir Richard Bishop
column13: and Tom Carter. There’s been shambling
column14: snarling folk-rock from Wooden Wand
column15: impish permutations of folk and metal from Horseback. Three Lobed issued one of the decade’s most transfixing drone records—On Jones Beach
column16: a bagpipe-anchored collaboration between members of the Necks and Sonic Youth—in 2012
column17: followed by two essential collections from Bardo Pond
column18: the free Philadelphia spirits that prompted Rayborn to launch Three Lobed in the first place. For an imprint so smitten with noisy records
column19: Three Lobed’s actual signal-to-noise ratio remains nearly perfect.

column1: Still
column2: four years and all those accomplishments later
column3: Three Lobed’s operations remain minimal
column4: with Rayborn and his cats working away in the basement after-hours. The small scale seems by now a point of pride
column5: a way to show that the persistent dedication of one person can help shape an entire scene. Indeed
column6: such modesty and minimalism offer significant returns for the roster of Parallelogram
column7: Three Lobed’s second vinyl set and a collection of 10 acts so strong it would feel like a fever dream for most any avant imprint. Bardo Pond splits a full-length with Yo La Tengo
column8: Six Organs of Admittance one with William Tyler. Transatlantic and trans-generational kindred spirits Michael Chapman and Hiss Golden Messenger face off
column9: while Kurt Vile and Steve Gunn back one another up on sides of their own. And for the five-record set’s white-hot point of dissonance and bedlam
column10: Thurston Moore and John Moloney duel as the duo Caught on Tape while Chris Corsano
column11: Alan Bishop and Bill Orcutt crash
column12: clatter and grind as a trio. Parallelogram presents a constellation of explorers
column13: separately ferrying the same enthusiasm and openness that have animated Three Lobed’s very catalog.

column1: Almost every act here has experience with a much larger label. In Sonic Youth
column2: of course
column3: Thurston Moore made major waves by moving to a major label a quarter-century ago
column4: while Michael Chapman issued Rainmaker on Harvest Records during the company’s first year
column5: the same year they issued Pink Floyd’s Ummagumma. Four have deals on Matador
column6: two on Merge
column7: one on Drag City and so on. Some of these bands may sell more records in a week of touring than Rayborn sells of all his releases combined in a year.

column1: But these five splits are available only in an edition of about 950 LPs. Through the label
column2: they’re offered only as a buy-them-all bundle
column3: though stores and the bands themselves will be able to sell individual titles. Coupled with those low numbers and a relatively high barrier to entry
column4: Three Lobed’s low-key status and individual-driven aesthetic seem to have made each act comfortable
column5: or free and clear to try something different out of their typical spotlight. As William Tyler
column6: who continues his recent streak of austere wonder with his two contributions here
column7: put it in an early interview about Parallelogram
column8: “I pretty much say yes to anything Cory suggests. He is a number one ace dude
column9: like a Yogi Berra-type figure in the subterranean rock scene.” Everyone on Parallelogram seems to respond to that same why-not directive.

column1: Yo La Tengo
column2: for instance
column3: shows a piece of their collectively complex musical mind rarely seen in a recording studio; their “Electric Eye” is a fierce 20-minute improvisation
column4: with stalled signals
column5: scraping guitars
column6: and muffled
column7: murmured vocals fighting against a militantly loping rhythm. Its counterpart is Bardo Pond’s “Screen for a Catch (Fur Bearing Eyes)”
column8: a sidelong beauty that seems to funnel almost every strength of their catalogue into one arcing collage. They move from bleary-eyed stoner drift to howling-guitar psychedelia
column9: from seraphic harmonies to acoustic-slide tangents
column10: closing with a high-and-mighty jam that fades into the middle distance. It’s like a patchwork homage to a label that exists only because they do.

column1: And just two months after releasing the biggest album of his career
column2: Kurt Vile pounds the piano keys through Randy Newman’s “Pretty Boy”
column3: a song that’s a bar fight waiting to happen. You can almost picture Vile
column4: a tumbler of brown liquor in his hand
column5: singing it this way at a bar after a show
column6: offering it as send-up to casual new fans who might have quaked his perpetual mellow. And when he digs into heartland country for a cover of John Prine’s gleefully apologetic “Way Back Then”
column7: he sounds carefree
column8: temporarily leaving behind his cool for a moment as an earnest balladeer.

column1: Steve Gunn adds guitar to that cover
column2: and Vile returns the favor for Gunn’s faithful and steely-eyed cover of Nico’s “60/40.” More intriguing
column3: though
column4: is “Spring Garden”
column5: a 10-minute fantasy featuring Gunn
column6: Vile and harpist Mary Lattimore on piano. In the last few years
column7: Gunn has morphed from a guitarist issuing long-form
column8: dexterous instrumentals through Three Lobed to a proper singer-songwriter and bandleader. But just a few months ahead of his own big Matador debut
column9: Gunn attempts to reconcile both past and present with this extended beauty. The trio delights in seemingly infinite refractions of a riff without distracting from Gunn’s soft-focus hook.

column1: As the title suggests
column2: Rayborn intended these pairings to highlight interesting
column3: perhaps overlooked similarities between sets of artists he treasures. And that approach works. Hearing Six Organs of Admittance and William Tyler on the same LP
column4: for example
column5: you notice how well both manage density
column6: or the lack thereof
column7: as a discrete aspect of dynamics. Tyler’s stunning “Southern Living” begins as a bucolic duet for acoustic guitar and sighing slide. But he slowly lets the notes hang until the space can handle no more sound
column8: until it all blurs into a messy web he then must pull apart. Likewise
column9: in the gorgeously distorted “Lsha”
column10: Chasny piles layers into the mix—his ghostly vocals and rapid fretwork
column11: broken keyboards and whirring synthesizers—until it merges into one signal. He then drifts from the din
column12: arriving at chords so soft and pretty they sound like bedside whispers.

column1: But the ultimate takeaway of Parallelogram might be the tension among all these acts
column2: not their similarities. Compare the guitar elegance of Tyler or Chapman
column3: especially on the latter’s stunning “Stockport Monday (Homage Tom Rush)”
column4: to the six-string aggression of Moore. Here
column5: he takes a familiar riff—in this case
column6: the pinging theme of his “Ono Soul”—and twists
column7: turns and tackles it in every way he can. Feedback and static
column8: squeals and divebombs: Moore searches for new ways to destroy his own melody. Usually so solemn
column9: Hiss Golden Messenger seems to bask in the springtime sun during a delicate
column10: groove-heavy take on J.J. Cale’s blushing “Wish I Had Not Said That”. He adds a lightness of soul at which the original only hinted. Corsano
column11: Bishop
column12: and Orcutt
column13: on the other hand
column14: torture <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6qAK7zylYgk"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Jack Bruce’s soft-rock flop “Politician”
column15: turning its creepy come-on into an off-putting
column16: oft-hilarious fuck-you. The cumulative effect of all these lines—parallel
column17: perpendicular
column18: divergent—is one of sheer wonder.

column1: There was a time not to long ago—when it became clear that most every act
column2: no matter how large or small
column3: could release their own records online—that people questioned what role
column4: if any
column5: labels might play in music’s future. Why would someone need an imprint if they could simply convince friends and fans to share a file or link? In many cases
column6: that has come to fruition
column7: allowing for the emergence of trends that might have been bypassed by the old
column8: slow system. But labels aren’t just big businesses. They are
column9: as in the case of Three Lobed
column10: people with a long-standing dedication to a sound they want to push into the world. And their involvement in those scenes can help connect dots or create ideas
column11: turning strange potential scenarios into five-record box sets that create new contexts for familiar acts. More than curation or tastemaking or filtering
column12: the usual quasi-canards invoked for label survival
column13: their real source of staying power might be their ability to invest in
column14: understand
column15: and help evolve a niche. For the last 15 years
column16: that’s what Three Lobed has done. Parallelogram is a trove of evidence
column17:
fit for a label too big for a suburban basement.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22521/homepage_large.d9cc81e5.jpg|People's Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm|6195.0|A Tribe Called Quest|['Rap']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Legacy']|2015-11-13 00:00:00|1990|2016-06-11 16:04:06.715494|"

Approaching A Tribe Called Quest's seminal debut in 2015 is a loaded venture. The Queens
column2: N.Y. trio (and sometimes ""y"" quartet
column3: counting Jarobi) is one of the most revered acts in hip-hop—and with good reason. As part of the Afrocentric and innovative Native Tongues collective—which included De La Soul
column4: Jungle Brothers
column5: Queen Latifah
column6: Black Sheep
column7: and others—they created and refined a template for '90s hip-hop that was street-astute
column8: worldly
column9: and more inspirational than aspirational.

column1: Even without the Native Tongues' legacy
column2: Tribe's heritage is not a light one. There's no stretch in saying that
column3: without A Tribe Called Quest
column4: the biggest rap artists of this year—Drake
column5: Future
column6: and Kendrick Lamar—would not exist as they do. Drake would not be Drake without Kanye West's 808s and Heartbreak; Kanye would not be Kanye without his Tribe influences. Without Tribe
column7: the Dungeon Family—birthplace of Outkast
column8: Goodie Mob
column9: and Future—arguably does not exist. And the improvisational looseness of Kendrick's opus is unthinkable without the innumerable branches of jazz and hip-hop sprouting from Tribe's experimentation
column10: which differed significantly from the cooler jazz-sample leanings of Stetsasonic and Gang Starr. There's no Mos Def
column11: no J. Cole
column12: no Common
column13: no J Dilla
column14: no Digable Planets
column15: no Neptunes
column16: and no Clipse as we know them. Tribe is that important. And this album—the first ever to receive a perfect ""5 Mic"" rating from The Source magazine—is where it all began.

column1: Arriving a year after De La Soul's 3 Feet High and Rising
column2: People's Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm showed Q-Tip
column3: Phife Dawg
column4: Ali Shaheed Muhammad
column5: and Jarobi to be whimsical yet grounded in reality. They weren't heady
column6: hermetic
column7: and puzzling like De La; in comparison to 3 Feet High's astounding range and informative sound collages
column8: People's Instinctive Travels was clean and focused. Where De La went wide musically
column9: Tribe went deep; where De La was deep and dense lyrically
column10: Tribe went wide and abstract. That both projects managed to do all they were able to do and remain fun is one of the great wonders of hip-hop's first golden age.

column1: Encountered now
column3: A People's Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm feels like a palette cleanser. Considered with Kendrick Lamar's layered and angsty self-examination on To Pimp A Butterfly

column1: ""I Left My Wallet In El Segundo""

"" Sexual fidelity and STD's are dealt with on ""Pubic Enemy"" via ""Old King Cole"" who ""wore the crown but not the jimmy hat"" until one day ""the fair maiden in the royal bedroom/ Caught the king scratching."" Sex and safe sex were at the forefront of Q-Tip's mind—props (women) are referred to often

Save me and my brothers?/ Hop inside the bed and pull over the covers?/ Never will we do that and we ain't trying to rule rap/ We just want a slab of the ham
column8: don't you know
column9: black?"" The lyrics are 25 years old. But were they released today they'd seem right on time

After a chance connection via a Facebook message
column3: Grammy-winning producer Jack Splash (Kendrick Lamar
column4: John Legend
column5: Jennifer Hudson) has teamed up with none other than Bobby Caldwell - yes
column6: that Bobby Caldwell
column7: the one with the 1978 classic ""What You Won't Do For Love"" has been sampled on approximately 21.9% of all hip-hop songs ever released—and the result is a smash
column8: taking equal parts funk
column9: pop
column10: smooth jazz
column11: and yacht rock
column12: (!) laying it all down on a solid retro-R&B framework. The group winks at the project's inherent adult-contempo cheese-factor with their moniker
column13: but really
column14: this is is the best freshest
column15: and funkiest adult-contempo cheese imaginable.

column1: The best thing about Cool Uncle is the fact that both participants don't strain to sound new. Instead
column2: they lean into their respective strengths. Given Splash's resume as a producer and arranger of R&B sounds (as well as his frontman work for funk group Plantlife) there's a ton of groove on this album
column3: interspersed with horns (the saxophone on the Mayer Hawthorne-featured ""Game Over"" is a highlight) and a bassist that does yeoman's work. The project is off-kilter and odd in appealing ways: On ""My Beloved"" Caldwell executes what has to be the first vampire lovesong by way of a week-long bender in Ibiza and sticks the landing. And his voice hasn't aged a day since the '70s.

column1: The record is bursting with features
column2: and most everyone carries their weight. Jessie Ware (on album standout ""Breakaway"") and former '80s-pop-star (""Let's Hear It For The Boy"")-turned gospel-artist Deniece Williams (""Breaking Up"") both contribute passionate performances whereas Cee-Lo (on ""Mercy"") kind of fades into the background. Mayer Hawthorne
column3: whose blue-eyed soul vocals tend to waver somewhere between ""convincing"" and ""nah""
column4: sounds as smooth and appealing as he ever has on ""Game Over"".

column1: This release
column2: coupled with solid 2015 output from acts like The Foreign Exchange
column3: Dawn Richard
column4: Estelle
column5: Kelela and others
column6: serve as a solid reminder that R&B is big and vital enough right now these days to contain multitudes: Soundcloud divas
column7: alt-R&B weirdos
column8: returning legends like Janet
column9: pubescent lotharios
column10: minimalist bleep-bloop-ass whisper-singers
column11: and beyond. Being an R&B fan right now means never having to settle for one kind of record
column12: or one sound. When one year gives you so many different options

You can debate exactly when Tim Hecker became a master of his chosen musical form
column2: but there's little doubt that he did at some point—at least as early as 2006's Harmony in Ultraviolet —and hasn't let go since. The variances between his works may seem incremental
column3: but line them all up and the amount of raw material he's turned to gold is remarkable. This kind of mastery means there are no minor releases in his discography
column4: at least in terms of quality. Even the two records collected here—the 2007 live CD Norberg and the 2010 7-inch Apondalifa
column5: both made in limited quantities to coincide with Australian tours—reach levels of interest and intensity below which Hecker seems incapable of falling.

column1: How exactly Norberg/Apondalifa fits in his stellar discography is a trickier question. Most reviews of Hecker's records compare them to their predecessors
column2: with good reason; his oeuvre forms an internal dialogue wherein individual albums reflect
column3: react to
column4: and play off of each other. But even though ""Norberg"" and ""Apondalifa"" reflect the headspace Hecker was in when Hecker made
column5: they feel isolated
column6: meant to stand alone. And where many Hecker albums have had specific focus—on a theme
column7: or a working method
column8: or a mood—these two pieces are more like simple displays of creative strength.

column1: Of the pair
column2: ""Norberg"" is more comprehensive
column3: a seamless 20-minute piece in which Hecker surfs around the sonic map without deviating far from his initial path. At times he flirts with aggressive noise; in other places he gets so beatific it's like he's meditating. But for most of ""Norberg""
column4: Hecker skates in the tantalizing space between those poles
column5: hinting at both without dropping off into either. When the piece ends in applause from the crowd
column6: it's almost shocking
column7: because—as in much of Hecker's work—you feel like you've spent the last 20 minutes inside of his head.

column1: Perhaps because it's shorter
column2: the 9-minute ""Apondalifa"" is more single-minded
column3: hewing to one discernible range of mood. But Hecker can blow up even the tiniest dots into widening vistas
column4: a feat he accomplishes here by varying textures rather than his tones. So even as the track feels relentless
column5: it also spreads out into phasing guitar chords
column6: low-end rumbles
column7: and slow waves of drone that circle a solid core. As important as those details are
column8: in a way they're also irrelevant
column9: because Hecker's touch and control are so deft they could transform any coal into diamonds. That's the ultimate value of Norberg/Apondalifa
column10:
a sharp reminder that Tim Hecker has had it all figured out for a while now.

ELO has been largely dormant since they released their thirteenth album in 2001. And yet
column2: their music continues to find new listeners
column3: whether through compilations
column4: car commercials
column5: soundtrack placements
column6: or G+ copies of Eldorado in used record bins. On one hand
column7: the band ought to have aged about as well as Emerson Lake & Palmer or Styx
column8: which is to say
column9: not very well. ELO’s best albums— A New World Record and Discovery in particular—are prime examples of the excesses of the '70s
column10: with all the pomp and studio wankery of the most ambitious prog rock imaginable. And yet
column11: Lynne deployed those techniques in service of songs that had all the exuberance and abandon of early rock 'n' roll. If he was making big statements
column12: then they typically amounted to ""I really want tonight to last forever / I really wanna be with you.""

column1: Given their propensity for cosmic imagery (have you seen their web site?)
column2: the title of their latest album sounds all the more wistful
column3: as though the absence of alien life is the saddest thing Lynne could ever imagine. That particular melancholy informs first single and album opener ""When I Was a Boy""
column4: which may sound slight but is animated by the kind of nostalgia often found in country songs. ""Radio waves kept me company in those beautiful days when there was no money
column5: Lynne sings
column6: as though flipping through old photo albums. ""When I was a boy
column7: I had a dream."" He’s still no wordsmith
column8: but there’s something bracing about his directness; any lyrical pretensions would ruin the reverie.

column1: On the other hand
column2: you have something like ""Dirty to the Bone"". With its florid harps and thrumming drums
column3: it’s an upbeat pop song in tone and tempo. But the lyrics are mean-spirited to a near-comical degree
column4: as Lynne describes one of those she-devils who seem to exist only in old rock songs: ""She’ll mess you up
column5: she’ll move around… she’ll deceive you till the cows come home."" That kind of cartoony straw-woman writing abounded in the '70s
column6: but the casual misogyny
column7: not to mention such threadbare cliché
column8: feels profoundly out of place now.

column1: Alone in the Universe fares best when Lynne is more generous
column2: when he can contrast the downcast sentiments of the lyrics with the effervescence of the music. After a rocky side 1
column3: side 2 picks up considerably
column4: thanks to light-speed ""Ain’t It a Drag"" and the zero-gravity ""I’m Leaving You."" Lynne may be a maximalist
column5: but he makes every element count. He still has a good ear for simple but driving rhythm sections
column6: and most of these songs use an acoustic strum to augment the beat and warm the track—a familiar
column7: but still effective
column8: technique. Likewise
column9: the sympathetic backing vocals on ""All My Life"" underscore the yearning in the songs
column10: making the simplicity of the lyrics (""I’m so glad I found you
column11: just want to be around you"") sound all the sweeter.

column1: Alone in the Universe doesn’t simply unearth that classic ELO sound like some ancient artifact. Instead
column2: it gently updates those elements to 2015
column3: the year Lynne celebrates his 68th birthday and his 52nd year in the music business. These songs sound precarious
column4: both musically and emotionally. Partly that is due to age and the slight quaver in Lynne’s vocals
column5: which aren’t quite as robust as they used to be. Partly it is due to technology. Lynne has always used to the studio to define his band’s entire identity
column6: and the difference between then and now is the difference between the air-brushed UFO on A New World Record and the CGI saucer on Alone in the Universe. There’s a gauzy thinness to the sound
column7: an inescapable two-dimensionality that occasionally hinders Lynne’s mission. Still
column8: this is a fine addition to their catalog
column9:
perhaps not as consistent as 2001’s Zoom but much better than these late-career revival albums tend to sound.

and they hit a nostalgic sweet spot that will never grow old.

column10: pregnant with Frances

column12: nodding off and holding his toddler. Footage of the three band members

column1: Montage of Heck: The Home Recordings carries the same unsavory aftertaste as the film
column2: with none of its attendant illuminations. The scraps here were dredged by Morgen and used to wallpaper the film

column1: This hits upon the main issue with releasing Cobain's home-tapes: As King Buzzo of the Melvins noted of this film

column7: or ""Frances Farmer""
column8: strummed and mumbled as he worked out the song's skeleton—are so inchoate that lavishing any kind of attention on them feels perverse. They serve to remind us that ephemera provide mute testimony of a life’s existence

column1: There is a precedent for this sort of release

column1: Cobain fan sites have complained that the Home Recordings crosses the line into exploitation

column3: and has been obliterated and trampled many times since. The Home Recordings marks the point where that exploitation enters the absurd. It’s a sad bookend to a captivating film

column8:
and register sadly that the essence is gone.

Until recently
column2: composer John Luther Adams and Wilco drummer Glenn Kotche would both have been regarded as unlikely draws in the world of classical music programming. During his years in Alaska—far away from the postgraduate-composition academy—Adams specialized in minimalist-influenced works that tended to avoid the driving pulse that made minimalism popular with a wide audience. For his part
column3: Kotche spent a lot of time touring with Jeff Tweedy.

column1: But things can change quickly (especially for a genre with such a long tradition). For Adams
column2: the reversal of fortune came with the mania surrounding his 2014 Pulitzer Prize-winning piece Become Ocean: a symphony-length orchestral approximation of maritime ebb and flow. Though Ocean didn’t represent an overhaul of Adams’s aesthetic
column3: it brought his environmentalist’s appreciation for the natural world to a new conceptual height. (The title also gave uninitiated listeners a hint regarding what to expect from his serene-then-raging compositions.) Meantime
column4: Kotche's 2014 classical album Adventureland felt distinguished—even in an active time for indie artists looking to prove their conservatory chops. (The drummer also performed brilliantly on composer Missy Mazzoli's album Vespers for a New Dark Age.)

column1: In the aftermath of his Pulitzer win
column2: Adams has been easier to spot. He’s since moved to New York
column3: where his pieces are programmed at Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall. Next year
column4: Adams will be the ""composer in residence"" at Knoxville’s Big Ears Festival—the all-genres-welcome avant-bash that also presents Wolf Eyes and Yo La Tengo. Given this
column5: it’s hardly surprising to find Kotche participating in a recording of Adams’s percussion-driven work
column6: Ilimaq.

column1: That title
column2: which is Inuit for ""spirit journey
column3: isn’t kidding around. Scored for three different ""stations"" of percussion instruments that the drummer moves between
column4: during a performance
column5: this recorded version also tosses in field recordings of nature
column6: ambient accompaniment
column7: and some live-electronic processing of Kotche’s playing. If that sounds like a busy experience
column8: it can be—but only when experienced as a whole. There’s a superficial stasis that masks much of the development here; if you dive into the 48-minute work expecting an instant hit of obvious Pulitzer-genius
column9: you might find yourself initially underwhelmed.

column1: The twelve-minute opening movement ""Descent"" sounds at first like one long bass drum roll—hurtling forward for a bit
column2: decelerating
column3: then pushing ahead once more. But its closing section presents odd groupings of notes for Kotche to navigate as Adams’s electronic environment undergoes subtle variations. The following movement
column4: ""Under the Ice""
column5: delights in a teasing ambiguity created by the blend of field recordings
column6: electronics
column7: and Kotche’s gentle cymbal work. The cumulative effect is so hypnotic and meditative that when clear
column8: descending pairs of notes appear in ""The Sunken Gamelan""
column9: they hit with the force of power chords.

column1: ""Untune the Sky"" brings everything from the composition’s first half hour together for a rite that finds Kotche wailing on an expanded kit
column2: and it’s here where the drummer’s technique is the most impressive. After that apex of clamor
column3: ""Ascension"" provides a calming coda of high-pitch drones. As a suggestive mirror-image of the piece’s opening ""Descent
column4: it’s satisfying and logical—though the chief virtue of this piece is Adams’s slow-motion way of arriving at grander
column5:
less predictable change.

On the same October day Pinkish Black released their third and best LP to date through Relapse Records
column2: the label also issued the final recordings of the members' earlier act
column3: a process stalled for five years by tragedy. Pinkish Black's anchors—the theatric singer and florid keyboardist Daron Beck and athletic drummer Jon Teague—formed The Great Tyrant a decade ago with bassist Tommy Atkins. A young
column4: exploratory and vaguely metallic outfit interested in doom and goth
column5: industrial and krautrock
column6: The Great Tyrant was working on The Trouble with Being Born when Atkins killed himself in 2010. Beck and Teague scrapped the sessions and started a new band
column7: taking the color of the blood-splattered walls where Atkins had died—that is
column8: pinkish-black—as a lurid tribute to the missing member. It's fitting
column9: then
column10: that The Great Tyrant emptied its archives on the same day Pinkish Black offered its latest
column11: greatest work to date
column12: Bottom of the Morning. As a duo
column13: Beck and Teague have finally found the sound and strength for which they've long searched. Fighting through a half-decade of despair
column14: the results on Bottom of the Morning almost feel heroic.

column1: Pinkish Black's previous two albums were hesitant and uncertain
column2: as though Teague and Beck were trying to define their shared aesthetic while teasing out a new duo chemistry
column3: too. Their fine 2012 debut packed in some excellent ideas and alluring sounds
column4: but the band—particularly Teague's voice—was obscured in effects. Though more forthright
column5: the subsequent Razed to the Ground found the duo again trying to do too much
column6: as they moved from slow-motion dirges to extravagant
column7: pulse-pounding doom.

column1: But Bottom of the Morning is
column2: at last
column3: the first unified
column4: unabashed Pinkish Black album. These songs are unveiled
column5: a message that's as clear with the hook-heavy
column6: march-like opener ""Brown Rainbow"" as it is with the beautifully brutal instrumental closer ""The Master is Away"". On these seven tracks
column7: Beck and Teague amplify the grandiosity
column8: directness and intensity of what they do. The keyboards can be as rich as a Tangerine Dream or Goblin record
column9: the melodies as creepy and contagious as John Carpenter. And Teague emerges as a powerhouse capable of summoning John Bonham
column10: Klaus Dinger and Billy Cobham. But the real coup here comes through Beck's voice. Even on The Great Tyrant's LPs
column11: especially the now-unearthed The Trouble with Being Born
column12: it was clear how capable he was
column13: though he wasn't yet quite in command of his talent. Here
column14: however
column15: his mix of near-monastic chants
column16: witchy incantations and operatic verses—now
column17: not crowded by manipulation or undercut with noise—serves as the record's compulsory core. You lean in close to hear what he's saying.

column1: It should come as little surprise that a band named for a friend's suicide embraces dark lyrics. Indeed
column2: these songs approach the nihilistic. ""Special Dark"" is little more than a string of negative participles and adjectives—""withered
column3: fractured … bleaker
column4: starker""—intoned in a dour murmur over blown-out bass and busy drums. At the start of ""Bottom of the Morning""
column5: Beck whispers and sings about wasting life and wasting time; at track's end
column6: he howls about endless cycles of false promises and futile attempts at self-improvement. ""Everyday's the same again
column7: he sings
column8: his voice stentorian but graceful
column9: like a latter-day Scott Walker. ""Everyday it's growing thin."" Since Atkins' death in 2010
column10: they've survived the death of several family members and severe sickness; the weight and worry of the world are central to these songs.

column1: But somehow
column2: those qualities are boons
column3: not burdens. Despite all the despair and misanthropy written into these words
column4: these songs often feel like conquests. The album itself is triumphant
column5: like a survivalist manifesto offered at the close of a markedly tough spell. Behind the grim declarations of ""Bottom of the Morning""
column6: for instance
column7: the twinkle of the organ
column8: the groove of the left hand's bassline and the dance of the drums suggest Miles Davis' On the Corner
column9: perhaps even Weather Report. And though ""Burn My Body"" is as lyrically macabre as the title implies
column10: bright synthesizer arpeggios and the back-and-forth motion of the drums offer the relief and release endemic to the narrator's final request. As the song ends
column11: the synthesizers and drums intimate a skyward ascension
column12: a last will finally honored. On Bottom of the Morning
column13: Beck and Teague have effectively stepped beyond the ghosts of the past
column14:
landing in a present where the results are now as compelling as the backstory.

It's strange to think that Rustie's debut album came out only four years ago; so much has changed since in its wake. When Glass Swords appeared
column2: in the fall of 2011

column1: Glass Swords wasn't just a dubstep or trap album
column2: of course; part of its genius was the way that it spun so many sounds and ideas into a bright
column3: high-energy electro-funk whose central contradiction—brittle in sound
column4: pliant in structure—turned out to be visionary. (Rustie deserves some credit for dreaming up the sound that SOPHIE and PC Music would run with: Without ""Hover Traps""
column5: there'd be no ""Lemonade"" or ""Hard"".) Perhaps that inventiveness is why it took the Glasgow producer nearly three years to come up with a follow-up: last year's Green Language
column6: a mixed bag that balanced his giddy hyper-funk instrumentals with relatively standard-issue trap. Distancing himself from that album

column11: and it represents a hard left turn back towards Rustie's carefully tended turf.

column1: There is no doubting who is in control of his vision this time around. There are no cloud-rap forays
column2: no ballads
column3: no grime MCs

column5: not unless you count the five songs credited ""(feat. Rustie)

column7: the funny thing about the distinction is how little difference is detectable between the songs ""featuring"" Rustie and those that are just by him. Both incorporate vocal chops frothed to high heaven
column8: like towering Everests of Cool Whip; both are topped by soaring
column9: tremolo-shaken synth leads; and both are driven forward by churning rhythms that split the difference between hardstyle's 160-BPM kicks and trap's lumbering syncopations.

column1: It is a rawer
column2: scrappier record than either of his prior LPs
column3: and the way he flips the bird at conventional notions of fidelity is almost punk. The high end often has the crinkly cellophane quality of low-bitrate MP3s
column4: and there's so much information being stuffed into the treble register that it occasionally registers as buzz. His drums are plenty forceful—his kicks and snares
column5: in particular
column6: sound like they've been pushed deeply into the red and then run through even more distortion
column7: just for fun—but it lacks the sub-bass of most trap
column8: preferring to muster all its energies for a mid-range wallop that thumps you in the sternum. The rolling toms of ""Big Catzzz"" sounds like he's recorded them off Fury Road with his iPhone.

column1: If his sonics are idiosyncratic
column2: his structures are less so. A typical track consists of a minute-long introduction
column3: 30 seconds of the main theme
column4: a minute of pullback
column5: a 30-second return to the main theme
column6: and
column7: finally
column8: a tidy denouement and fadeout. Everything in the song—the rolling drums
column9: the looped voices
column10: the smeared synths
column11: the crescendos of white noise—leads up to that big hit of adrenaline. What's even more striking is how similar the main themes sound
column12: once you subtract all the surrounding flotsam and jetsam. If you placed the album's biggest hooks side by side
column13: it'd sound like one song
column14: uniform in mood
column15: instrumentation
column16: and tone color.

column1: Is that a problem? It all depends upon your tolerance. If the idea of mixing Pop Rocks in your breakfast Mountain Dew sounds good to you (or if
column2: like Rustie
column3: you listen to happy hardcore to go to sleep)
column4: then EVENIFUDONTBELIEVE will be right up your alley. For the rest of us
column5: there are some genuine thrills (sorry
column6: thrillz) here: ""First Mythz""
column7: with its dolphin clicks and bullet-riddled hi-hats; the calmer ""Atlantean Airship""
column8: which sounds like Glass Swords-era Rustie curdled by acidic distortion. ""Peace Upzzz"" is one of the few songs that actually refuses a big payoff: It's all crescendo and no climax

column1: For those who aren't fully on board with Rustie's aesthetic
column2: exhaustion sets in quickly
column3: and the slope of diminishing returns is steep. And that's probably just fine with him

column5: from the ""features"" to the credits (""Written by Rustie/ Produced by Rustie/ Extra vocals by Rustie/ Guitar by Rustie/ Art direction by Rustie/ Photography by Rustie""). There is zero daylight between the artist and his vision

and you have to respect that kind of doggedness.

Frankie Cosmos (aka Greta Kline) writes songs that are as close to one gets to a pure hybrid of pop and poetry. Her acknowledgment of Frank O'Hara as a significant influence makes a good deal of sense; like O'Hara
column2: her work is both personal and abstract
column3: economical
column4: and infused with humanity
column5: ""between two persons"" rather than a communication between listener and artist. For those concerned with Kline's overtly twee aesthetic

column1: Fit Me In
column2: a compact and efficient EP portending a more fleshed-out full-band LP in 2016
column3: is an experiment in what Kline's songwriting would sound like given nearly all electronic instrumentation. A collaboration with frequent musical partner Aaron Maine of Porches
column4: Fit Me In is more in line with Kline's prolific home recordings than a full indie pop record like Zentropy (opener ""Korean Food"" appeared first on 2013's self-released Daddy Cool). Drum machine and synth-heavy
column5: this is true bedroom pop—so intimate as to show the rumpled coverlet and the minute
column6: ancient
column7: nearly unnoticeable stains on the carpet. As is Kline's wont
column8: these songs are little glimpses into her fully realized universe
column9: less verse-chorus-verse pop confections than open-ended
column10: contemporary poetic constructions that don't stop where the recording ends. Like poetry
column11: they require reading and interpretation and us to be engaged as listeners
column12: in communication with Cosmos; art that exists ""between two persons"" requires dialogue.

column1: ""Young"" in particular is arch and sly
column2: a response to media commentary that would seek to cast Kline as a fresh-faced ingenue
column3: a character in a box rather than a real
column4: complicated young woman. ""I heard about being young/ But I'm not sure how it's done.../ Something about fun
column5: she sings. You can interpret me
column6: she seems to be saying
column7: and I'll interpret you right back. In ""O Contest Winner""
column8: she boasts ""No need for a retest/ I know I'm a genius
column9: tongue firmly in cheek
column10: again pushing against others' expectations of her and her work. Such bragging is usually the province of hip-hop
column11: and to hear it in delicate indie pop context could feel self-conscious or appropriative
column12: but in Kline's subtle delivery it sounds both sincere and welcome
column13: both a refutation of the idea that female artists must always minimize their senses of self-worth and an awareness of the sheer absurdity of any declaration of ego.

column1: ""Korean Food"" and ""Sand"" are both tender etchings of the everyday nature of real love
column2: a theme Kline excels at exploring; her version of love is not grand or epic
column3: not forced into any particular narrative arc. She finds love in moment-to-moment minutiae
column4: in the smallest pleasures and least valued rituals
column5: without weighting those moments too heavily: ""And touch all the books outside the Strand/ Their oldest pages soft like sand.""

column1: There's a reason we're captivated as a society by well-written diaries—at their best
column2: sketches of others' lives as they live them allow us chances to slow down
column3: to connect and to understand one another that we rarely encounter in a highly relational world. Greta Kline is a master at the art of the musical diary—never confessional in a way that feels exploitative and lurid
column4: but tender
column5: intimate
column6:
and real nonetheless. We're fortunate she keeps letting us into her world in this way.

Founded in 1975 to release ""Little Johnny Jewel""
column3: the debut single by Television
column4: Ork Records had a brief but influential five-year run. The brainchild of West Coast weirdo Terry Ork and art school dropout Charles Ball
column5: the label was blessed with a number of big firsts. Ork released not just the first Television single
column6: but also the first music from poet and punk rock originator Richard Hell and the first singles by Memphis-based musician Alex Chilton following the dissolution of Big Star. This in addition to great power pop by Chris Stamey as well as new wave groups like Marbles
column7: Student Teachers
column8: and the Revelons.

column1: Compiled by Numero Group
column2: the lavishly packaged and thoroughly researched <i>Ork Records: New York
column3: New York collects the label's complete 13-single catalog along with a number of related releases that never made it to shelves during the label's existence. Among these are a scrapped single by New Jersey's the Feelies and a sidelined 7"" by the rock critic Lester Bangs that ultimately saw daylight via Spy Records
column4: an imprint run by John Cale.

column2: nostalgia for late '70s New York City can feel oppressive
column3: given its documentation in an endless stream of record reissues
column4: memoirs
column5: films
column6: and biographies. If you grew up during the '90s
column7: your entire cultural coming-of-age might have been spent surfing successive waves of the city's punk-era remembrance—from ""Saturday Night Live"" reruns to Julian Schnabel's Basquiat biopic
column8: the Strokes to LCD Soundsystem. But New York
column9: New York is a significant artifact.

column1: The music and photographs capture the formative moments of punk and new wave
column2: before those genres had been thoroughly defined. It's a glimpse at iconic personalities in a moment of vulnerability
column3: before they were fully hatched and before anybody cared. By contemporary standards
column4: these songs might not register as wild or controversial. In the context of the '70s—a time of slick pop and bluesy choogle—Ork's artists were from another planet. The first sound on Television's ""Little Johnny Jewel"" is not a squeal of feedback or an expertly rehearsed riff
column5: but the thin and elastic tone of Tom Verlaine's guitar plugged directly into the mixing board. Hell's ""(I Belong to The) Blank Generation"" is a bizarre throwback of a different kind—a skewed and slanted remake of the Rod McKuen's jazzy 1959 novelty song ""The Beat Generation"" that was a far cry from the buzz saw tones and pop minimalism of the Ramones.

column1: Listening back now
column2: the music is familiar because these sounds have become so deeply embedded in the DNA of today's indie rock. Chris Stamey's ""The Summer Sun"" is nostalgia-tinged bubblegum pop
column3: buoyed by jangling acoustic guitars and backing ""oohs/ahhs."" Chilton's singles are charmingly stoned and discombobulated proto-slacker rock. A one-off studio project
column4: Prix delivers the pained power pop that Ork probably wanted from Chilton
column5: but the singer was then unwilling to deliver. Others offer slightly fudged takes on the more established downtown bands. The Erasers' clean guitar tones and slanted melodies recall Television. The Student Teachers' stripped down and hookly ""Channel 13"" is not too far afield from Blondie
column6: whose keyboardist
column7: Jimmy Destri
column8: produced the band's single. These bands weren't necessarily biting a successful style
column9: just taking cues from their peers.

column1: Bangs' ""Let It Blurt"" is an outlier
column2: in that it is terrible. The music—a Beefheart-inspired and Quine-penned backing track—isn't the problem. It's the singing. Bangs slurs and blubbers about the details of a break-up. The details are ugly and unflattering. If Television's music attempted ecstatic transcendence
column3: ""Let It Blurt"" represents the opposite end of the spectrum—earthly woe
column4: gracelessness
column5: the sadness and confusion of lonely dudes. Perhaps this was the intent
column6: though. For what it's worth
column7: the critic seems aware that both the song and his lyrics are absurd.

column1: A California counterculture type lured east by Andy Warhol's Factory scene
column2: Ork met Verlaine and Hell when the latter was a clerk at Cinemabilia
column3: a Greenwich Village film memorabilia shop that he managed. He took an active interest in their musical pursuits
column4: set them up with guitarist Richard Lloyd
column5: and when they formed Television
column6: Ork became the band's first manager. In 1975
column7: when the group—by that point in its official
column8: Hell-less lineup—recorded a few 4-track demos
column9: Ork agreed to press a single. The record did well enough to warrant a second release
column10: Richard Hell's first two songs with the Voidoids. Because Ork was a good scenester but a poor businessman
column11: Ball came on to help professionalize the operation.

column1: Initially
column2: Ork's mission was to capture a local scene that had grown up around CBGBs but over time there wasn't much incentive to keep going. The bands were not popular and there was little hope of financial reward. It was hard for bands to get booked outside of New York
column3: even regionally. In the liner notes
column4: the Feelies' Dave Weckerman explains that there was only one new wave-tolerant venue west of the Hudson.

column1: Many of Ork's artists were not particularly fond of their singles on the imprint. At the time
column2: Television's Richard Lloyd told interviewers that he hated ""Little Johnny Jewel""—""It worked primarily as a demo
column3: Hell said of his single
column4: ""I can't stand to hear it."" But the lack of polish is what makes many of these recordings compelling. On Marquee Moon
column5: Television sounded immaculate and artful. Here
column6: the band is sloppy and primitive
column7: but also unconventional and free. On their debut album
column8: Crazy Rhythms
column9: the Feelies sounded tense and jittery
column10: but Ork's version of ""Fa Cé La"" is fast and blisteringly loud.

column1: Eventually
column2: the money ran out and Ork folded in 1979. Ball would go on to found the influential no wave label
column3: Lust/Unlust and Ork left both New York and the music business
column4: returning to the West Coast. Both have since passed on (Ork in 2004
column5: Ball in 2012). When the label fizzled
column6: punk and new wave were still very much underground. Of the bands that populated the CBGBs scene
column7: only Blondie and Talking Heads had found anything resembling national success.

column1: For all the talk of doom and gloom in today's post-Internet music world
column2: some comfort can be taken in the fact that
column3: even when people were still buying records
column4: Ork's prospects seemed equally grim. The label's biggest hit sold 6
column5: 000 units
column6: but
column7: according to the set's liner notes
column8: most releases were lucky to sell a third of that. If you're running an independent record label today
column9: those numbers might not be that far out of reach.

column1: In Ork's case
column2: the label wasn't ultimately a lark or a waste of money—the music was heard. These singles diffused out into the world and found their way into the hands of weirdos in far-flung locales. When promoting Hell's single in 1976
column3: Ork ran advertisements with the singer's phone number and suggested that people
column4: ""Call Hell."" ""I called him
column5: Minutemen bassist Mike Watt told author Michael Azzerad in the book
column6: Our Band Could Be Your Life. ""I said
column7: 'Is this Hell?' And he said
column8: 'Yeah.' And I got scared and I hung up."" That accessibility stuck with Watt
column9: though. ""That
column10: to me
column11:
was punk.""

When it came out three years ago
column4: Kate Boy's ""Northern Lights"" joined a new
column5: growing class of Knife-wielding groups. Purity Ring
column6: Chvrches
column7: and Niki and the Dove all made debuts that year that recast the Swedish duo's roiling
column8: synth-heavy formula into new electropop oddities. But the strutting ""Northern Lights"" stood out for a number of reasons: Those teeming
column9: plasticized synth melodies; that widescreen
column10: euphoric chorus; the promise that ""everything we touch turns to gold"" that on repeat listens sounded more and more like a threat. In spite of singer Kate Akhurst's voice bearing a borderline-scary similarity to Karin Dreijer Andersson
column11: Kate Boy's music remained irresistible
column12: dressing up Silent Shout's pressurized gloom in vivid
column13: maximalist clothes.

column1: Kate Boy's long-gestating debut
column2: One
column3: continues to hit those same targets
column4: for better and for worse. It includes ""Northern Lights"" and three other tracks culled from an EP quietly released earlier this year
column5: and none of the album's new offerings stray from those songs' well-established blueprint. Kate Boy loves pounding synths and a good shout-along chorus
column6: and so every song on One has both
column7: a technique that is as exhausting as often as it is potent. On ""Lion for Real""
column8: Akhurst's cries of ""It's adrenaline that you're traveling"" are matched in force by the synthetic drums that rally behind her like a militia
column9: an explosion of sound that practically demands you to move. ""Burn"" is similarly gratifying
column10: in a slower
column11: more consuming way
column12: Akhurst stretching her vowels out in a pained howl that sounds like an alternate universe in which Fever Ray was making Billboard-charting singles. Nothing on One really feels as immediate as ""Northern Lights""
column13: but Akhurst's ability to grab you by the throat with each chorus and the trio's playful use of texture—the descending wash of glassy synths at the end of ""Human Engine""
column14: the '80s-indebted guitar line that slinks through ""Higher""—make One an easy
column15: undemanding
column16: and ultimately unsurprising listen.

column1: This speaks to Kate Boy's credentials: Australian-born Akhurst has been working as a songwriter since the age of 16 and spent time in L.A. penning songs for Disney star Ashley Tisdale and ""Glee"" actor Charice in the early 2010s before migrating to Sweden
column2: where she met Markus Dextegen and Oskar Sikow Engström and formed Kate Boy (Engström has since been replaced by Hampus Nordgren). But where the group excels at assembling all the bones of a good pop song
column3: One's lyrical content is broad even by those same standards. Platitudes like ""It doesn't have to be this way/ We're different
column4: still the same/ Move your mind to a higher state"" are vague and don't manage to express much nuance beyond ""we're all human
column5: get it together."" ""Self Control"" reaches a bit further
column6: girding its narrator's insecurities as self-defense and providing an interesting counterpoint to the bright
column7: jagged sounds Kate Boy likes to plays around with. On ""Human Engine""
column8: they even shoot for a bit of self-awareness: ""We like the word 'dynamic'/ We like to use it a lot."" Still
column9: those moments are fleeting; sometimes the group even resort to baffling
column10: tech-referencing word salad
column11: as on ""In Your Eyes"": ""Activate emotion waves
column12: oppression down/ Activate the open changes flowing out.""

column1: But maybe Kate Boy's sleekly designed songs aren't meant to be ingested with so much scrutiny. They're aiming for the same big
column2: emotional targets as those aforementioned electropop peers here
column3: with enough brooding style to make it distinct. Besides
column4: the group has admitted that they're painting with broad strokes
column5: saying in an interview last month that their main goal is to create ""something that we can all feel empowered singing together."" There are enough dance-ready
column6:
skyward hooks on One to render that mission accomplished. Perhaps next time they'll have something worthwhile to say.

""I'll never be your dream girl
column2: sings Claire Boucher on ""Butterfly""
column3: the final song on Art Angels
column4: her most audacious album to date. Perhaps she's just being coy
column5: because for many she is exactly that. In the age of the female pop auteur

column8: and resists simplistic notions of who she can be on a record or a stage. Art Angels is a gilded coffin nail to outmoded sexist arguments that women in pop are constructed products
column9: a mere frame for male producers' talents—that because their music is immaculate
column10: they are somehow not authentic. These 14 tracks are evidence of Boucher's labor and an articulation of a pop vision that is incontrovertibly hers
column11: inviting the wider world in.

column1: Grimes shows that Boucher is the ultimate fangirl study: a D.I.Y. musician whose love of Mariah
column2: Katy Perry
column3: and K-pop has expanded her palette
column4: driven by her fascination with the possibilities of the synthetic and unreal
column5: and ultimately given wings to Art Angels. Here
column6: she closes the gap between the pop she's idolized and the pop she is capable of. Boucher has claimed that the record has two halves
column7: and indeed
column8: the songs line up most easily into beginning- and end-of-the-night dancefloor jams. The former is exemplified by the bright
column9: anxious ""Kill V. Maim""
column10: with its mocking cheerleader chant over blown-out beats and Boucher working both ends of her register in a propulsive celebration of vocal fry.

column1: Same for ""Flesh Without Blood""
column2: which is the sweetest fuck-off of 2015
column3: one that highlights that there is much more to Boucher's voice than Visions ever had a chance to reveal. The song is Boucher eating the lunch that Miley packed
column4: may it be #blessed with infinite stadium-EDM remixes. Post-Art Angels
column5: it's hard to imagine anyone will reject a Boucher-penned cut: This is an album
column6: but it's also a resume
column7: and someone who made ""California"" could certainly be making crossover hits for any marquee Nashville name
column8: while ""Easily"" suggests that Kesha co-writes should be in Boucher's future.

column1: The late-night closers and their arrangements are where Boucher shows her mastery and discipline as a producer. ""Realiti""
column2: ""Venus Fly"" with Janelle Monáe
column3: and ""Butterfly"" give her a new set of peers: Sure
column4: she's there with collaborator Monáe and Annie Clark as an auteur
column5: but purely as a pop producer she's as deft and clever as anyone we consider a master of Top 40 craft—be it Greg Kurstin or Diplo. The songs are graced with small details: curious skeets of beats
column6: buried samples that only appear once
column7: toxically cute '90s pop guitar. The songs build in unexpected ways
column8: but explode and gratify in the way we hope pop always will. ""Butterfly"" is a let-tonight-last-forever mutant bruiser with roiling sub-bass
column9: the chorus's side-chained pulse making it like an uncanny valley version of Kylie Minogue's ""Can't Get You Out of My Head"".

column1: All of this might seem as if Boucher has fashioned a whole-cloth reinvention and is gunning for the Top 40
column2: but neither of these things feel true. Art Angels is a natural progression from Visions; if you strained out some of the processing and murk of the latter
column3: you would find these structures lurking. Boucher's voice is recognizable and familiar
column4: but it's bigger and has more range and depth than on ""Oblivion"". This album foregrounds her
column5: samples her
column6: piles tracks of her half a dozen high to form melodies and countermelodies.

column1: One of the most notable and striking differences between Art Angels and its Top 40 kin is that these are not love songs. The album is an epic holiday buffet of tendentious feminist fuck-off
column2: with second helpings for anonymous commenters and music industry blood-suckers. Her conflicted
column3: vertiginous relationship with the fast fame that followed Visions seems to have led her to a place of DGAF liberation. Some songs
column4: like ""Kill V. Maim""
column5: course with a thrilling rage
column6: even a casual misandry. (""I'm only a man/ I do what I can
column7: she sings on the hook). Yet
column8: what's most exciting within Art Angels is the sheer will and fearlessness of Boucher's fight to be heard and seen on her own terms. She's not a human Tumblr
column9: as we called her (somewhat humiliatingly) in 2012; she's a human zeitgeist
column10:
redrawing all the binaries and boundaries by which we define pop music and forcing us to come along.

Myths 001 is the first of a planned series of collaborative EPs on Mexican Summer intended to pair ""mutual admirers and kindred spirits

column4: Devonté Hynes conjured vapory
column5: psychedelic R&B that played like a bizarro soundtrack to water-warped VHS recordings of early Cinemax After Dark broadcasts—the same aesthetic New Zealand's Connan Mockasin shot for on his own LP from that year

column1: There's enough variation in how Hynes and Mockasin approach their leftfield pop to create some interesting contrasts
column2: though. Hynes is the more polished and more versatile of the pair
column3: an industry songwriter-for-hire who
column4: for all his iconoclastic tendencies

column6: and next to the open-armed vulnerability of Cupid Deluxe

column8:
but he often cloaks them behind a smirk.

So the two make good foils

column10: but all that feels rushed is its 11-minute runtime. The production is nearly as luscious as Cupid Deluxe
column11: all soft-rock decadence and red-light ambiance
column12: and two of its three tracks

column14: are distinctively peculiar. ""La Fat Fur"" opens the EP with a gust of trembling post-punk
column15: imagining what Wire might have sounded like if they'd gone through a Prince phase in the '80s. ""Feelin' Lovely"" similarly has some fun scribbling across genre boundaries
column16: piling bluesy riffs and jazz-fusion keyboards and saxophones over an unusually funky quiet storm groove
column17:
playing like a funhouse homage to Marvin Gaye's Midnight Love.

The slow-burn closer ""Big Distant Crush"" could use a little bit of that eccentricity. It's the EP's most earnest number
column18: but also its most meandering
column19: five minutes of aimless heartache that can't help but feel like an attempt to pad an otherwise skimpy EP. There's enough here to demonstrate that Hynes and Mockasin have some chemistry
column20: but not enough to fully show it off. This is probably to be expected from an EP whipped up from scratch in just a week
column21:
but whichever artists end up on Myths 002 might do well to consider reserving a few extra days in the studio in case they hit it off.

Two years ago
column2: Neurosis founder Scott Kelly

column4: producer Sanford Parker

column6: a sort of supergroup that turned out to be defined as much by its intentionally haphazard improv streak as its members' heavy reputations. The music they produced combined easy-to-predict elements—like Kelly's churning

column1: Despite its seat-of-the-pants beginnings

Jones often frets about people continuing to refer to Trust Fund as a DIY outfit since he signed to Welsh indie Turnstile and received a small advance to make Seems Unfair in a studio rather than his bedroom. Although he's hardly breached intervention-worthy excess

column1: The relentlessly peppy pace carries along Jones' lyrics

column3: often with a similarly simple pathos to Waxahatchee's Katie Crutchfield. ""Michal's Plan"" outlines someone's failed intentions to swim every day; instead
column4: their bathing suit is ""wet and festering in a Tesco bag at the foot of [their] bed."" Seems Unfair is full of characters who seem to struggle with everyday minutiae

column2: brush my teeth
column3: and you'll be gone forever
column4: he sings. Twee is a worn-out

which isn't often a problem with modern indie rock acolytes.

It's hard to imagine a time when hardcore and metal were separated by fierce
column2: mutually exclusive tribal codes. At an early point in the development of hardcore
column3: to have long hair and a leather jacket at certain shows came with a genuine risk of physical injury. But even hardcore flagships like Sick of It All
column4: Agnostic Front
column5: the Crumbsuckers
column6: and the Cro-Mags put out albums that leaned towards metal
column7: while other hardcore pioneers like D.R.I.
column8: Suicidal Tendencies
column9: Corrosion of Conformity
column10: and Prong all eventually transitioned fully into metal bands.

column1: Despite these intertwined histories
column2: though
column3: it's easy to see why the division persists between these two camps: in general
column4: metal encourages you to get carried away—be it by ""Dungeons & Dragons"" fantasy
column5: exaggerated horror
column6: Satan
column7: or intellectual musing—while hardcore calls for you to keep your feet planted firmly on the ground. Hardcore bands also tend to fixate on their street credibility
column8: to the point that their music functions as an incessant pledge of allegiance

column1: True Will

column4: Obituary
column5: and Crowbar as its three primary influences

column7: Florida death metal
column8: and southern sludge
column9: respectively. In so doing
column10: White Widows Pact reminds us that metal and hardcore were always perfectly suited for mating with each other and that
column11: in fact

column1: Of course

column4: with varying degrees of creative innovation. Take even a quick glance at the Victory Records or Century Media catalog and you'll never run out of mosh breakdowns from bands fusing death metal with hardcore. Listening to True Will
column5: though

column1: Toward the beginning of the track ""Thirteen Years of War""
column2: for example

column3: and it erupts from the pustules of the adolescent humanoid alien

column5: who is the album's hero. The project spills over the limits of the album format
column6: too

column8: blogs

column1: The way Garden of Delete makes us question the assumptions behind all of our high/low binaries is part of its brilliance. OPN's music is generally understood to exist somewhere between nostalgia and irony
column2: its vaporwave fantasias and unlikely redemptions of '80s schlock-meisters like Chris DeBurgh suggestive of late-night trips down YouTube rabbit holes. But we're not in ""Chrome Country"" any more. Garden of Delete is unlike anything that Lopatin has done

column4: mood
column5: or scope. It is denser than his previous albums
column6: by several orders of magnitude. It is more varied
column7: and it is funnier—scarier
column8: too. So much beauty is crosscut with so much ugliness
column9: and so much sincerity interwoven with so many deeply nested layers of kitsch

column1: The album's base notes will be familiar from his previous work; they consist of cool
column2: frictionless pads
column3: airy choral presets
column4: and
column5: especially
column6: synthesized sounds that mimic acoustic instruments and revel in their own plasticity

column8: or the jazz guitar noodling of ""I Bite Through It"". This time out
column9: he ventures even deeper into the uncanny valley separating ""real"" sounds from mimetic ones. The references pile up in enormous slag heaps
column10: and a few in particular stand out: the growls
column11: chugging guitars
column12: and blast beats of death metal; the flanged riffs of nu metal; and the garish synth stabs and grotesque vocal processing of contemporary commercial electronic music. Two years ago
column13: after a bout of touring
column14: he told Pitchfork
column15: ""I feel like I better understand the tropes and guises of EDM now

column1: That's not to say the album is a collection of big-room bangers. But certain techniques common on the Electric Daisy circuit have wormed their way into the music: Elastic trance riffs
column2: vertiginous glissandi that zip upward like space elevators
column3: and
column4: especially
column5: the highly processed and contoured voices of which Skrillex is so fond. Nothing in G.o.D. follows the usual Pavlovian dictates of mainstream rave: There are builds and drops
column6: but they're always deployed in ways that throw the listener off balance. Instead of EDM's predictable roller coaster

column1: Garden of Delete is the first OPN album to come with a lyric sheet—no
column2: really—which is nice

column8: jokes
column9: flyers for prog-rockers Rush
column10: and musings on a style called ""hypergrunge""; a website for the (invented) hypergrunge band Kaoss Edge; a host of (active) Twitter accounts for all these characters; and various mind-bending videos. (Various phone numbers referenced are
column11: alas

column13: another the Winthrop
column14: Mass.
column15: police department.) This may all seem
column16: from the outside

column18: but dig deep enough

column20: in an interview

column23: ""It's nihilist/formalist. Kaoss/Edge."" You couldn't ask for a more succinct summary of his music's underlying principles.

column1: None of this would matter if the music weren't absolutely gripping—strange
column2: moving
column3: hilarious

column7: Korn's nu-metal chug

column9: it just kind of writhes in place
column10: neither rising nor falling. ""SDFK"" interrupts graceful bells and strings with a crushing death-metal interlude that abruptly falls silent. And if Trevor Horn ever produced Slayer
column11: it might sound something like ""Sticky Drama"". Your favorites will probably change over time

column1: It all clicked for me one Sunday morning in the pre-dawn stillness of the city. Returning from seeing off a family member at the airport at an ungodly hour

column4: their pixelated images moving almost in time with the album's throbbing synthesizers. As Lopatin's textures stretched and spasmed in my ears
column5: artificial light poured out onto the empty street in ungainly bursts
column6: like tiny droplets of the ongoing heat death of the universe. It was garish and gorgeous all at once
column7: a vision of capitalism at its tackiest accompanied by a soundtrack at once cutting and strangely empathic

column9: transfixed by the raw
column10:
oozing nowness of it all.

column6: where

column5: muddled pain
column6: she explained

column1: It's unlikely that Vulnicura Strings will replace anyone's original copy of the record—its existence feels more symbolic than anything else. Last week

As 2015 winds down
column2: the trend of repurposing samples of UK '90s pirate radio and early rave culture might have reached its tipping point

column4: it never sounds like an exercise in revisiting those old sounds. Perhaps Woolford's sensibilities come from approaching 40 and experiencing British rave culture firsthand. As he put it in an old interview

column1: Being coy
column2: playful

Modern Warfare's incredibly high peaks double as incendiary bombs and guilty pleasures.

The Necks have developed a near-mythic status. For a quarter century
column4: they've been building hour-long piano/drums/bass pieces that overflow with the tension of contrasts—beauty versus bedlam
column5: melody versus discord
column6: momentum versus inertia. Live

column10: the group’s albums sound meticulous but feel extemporaneous
column11: like synchronized exhalations from a group whose chemistry suggests rock'n'roll’s best songwriting tandems. Made by just three musicians of ostensibly modest avant-garde-scene means
column12: the Necks’ sets and records possess the same gripping power as a sitcom or documentary that might have cost millions of dollars and dozens of people to craft. The largely acoustic answer to New Zealand’s electric the Dead C
column13: the Necks make miracles of efficiency and magnetism.

column1: Vertigo is the Necks’ 18th album and second for the New York label Northern Spy
column2: the group’s first stable American home. Like many of its predecessors
column3: Vertigo runs as one uninterrupted track
column4: with 44 minutes roughly split between two interwoven movements. It does
column5: however

These additions largely shape a drone that fluctuates throughout the album and serves as a springboard for the group’s convulsive repartee. The exact nature of the sustained tone changes: Vertigo begins
column7: for instance
column8: with the growl of Lloyd Swanton’s bowed bass and dense sheets of piano runs. Near the halfway point
column9: though
column10: it’s a high-pitched synthesizer purr
column11: countered by a Wurlitzer organ whose every chord dissipates into space. Swanton emerges from the impasse with steady
column12: resonant bass sweeps
column13: briefly conjuring the spirit of Tony Conrad’s microtonal masterpieces. And just before track’s end
column14: an organ
column15: bass
column16: and Buck’s scraped drums cohere into a gigantic sigh
column17: so slow and resonant it suggests plate tectonics.

column1: But these interlocking phases are only the undercarriage of Vertigo
column2: the framework upon which the Necks’ usual
column3: brilliant instrumental interplay moves. When Abrahams inlays beautifully ascending melodies inside Buck’s percussive din early on
column4: the effect is magical. And when Buck divides Swanton’s long
column5: bagpipe-like tones with a stuttering
column6: trip-hop rhythm
column7: you listen in anticipation
column8: trying to foretell what might happen next
column9: only to be surprised by the Naked City-style ruptures Buck soon bangs out. This is the Necks at their finest
column10: playing group games of chutes and ladders and delighting in their instrumental ideas like they’re dancing.

column1: But Vertigo does stumble slightly through its rather obvious series of arcs: An opening swell cedes to a comedown that sends the members out into space
column2: only to reconvene a quarter-hour later. This back-and-forth motion defines much of Vertigo and
column3: by record’s end
column4: it gets a bit tedious. And
column5: in part because of the underpinning drone around which the trio works
column6: the Necks are busier and more restless here than in the past
column7: sometimes moving as if trapped inside a pinball machine. The Necks typically make elliptical music
column8: where restraint and suggestion power tension and momentum. Their last album
column9: 2013’s Open
column10: epitomized that. Vertigo
column11: on the other hand
column12: could do more with less—of
column13: say
column14: the tawdry horror-show electronics so prominent near the 12-minute mark or the shock-and-awe noise that populates the back half. The concept of working over and alongside a drone congests the Necks’ customary grace.

column1: The Necks have always confounded easy taxonomy. Their piano-trio semblance has often shoehorned them into jazz circles
column2: though their pronounced lack of swing and structure has infamously confounded critics in those circles. And though there seems to be a natural spot for the Necks in experimental spaces
column3: their presentation—three middle-aged men playing expensive acoustic instruments
column4: often in esteemed concert halls—can make them a strange fit for the underground crowd. Their love of extended pieces and clattering crescendos even suggests a place in post-rock
column5: though their music is often too incidental and illusory for the templates that term implies. With its part-time
column6: eerie John Carpenter glow and sudden noise-rock spasms
column7: Vertigo only renders the Necks as more vexing and unidentifiable. Though the Necks occasionally slip into predictability across this session
column8: Vertigo epitomizes their career-long unpredictability
column9: or their ability to start at one point and arrive somewhere entirely unexpected. Vertigo is a minor Necks record
column10: destined to stand forever in the shadow of the 2013 opus Open. But
column11: after a quarter century
column12: the trio’s explorations still sound as ecstatic as they do limitless. That
column13: at least
column14:
is another minor miracle.
