column1: Presumably
column2: the instrumental interludes are meant to give her tragic arc some breathing room
column3: like asterisks that break up a story. But one of the best things about the AMY documentary is that its pacing feels so natural—invisibly punishing
column4: just like life. The effect of this soundtrack is exactly the opposite. The power of her voice is undercut by the regular intrusion of the film score
column5: which doesn't reference her musically in palette or instrumentation. As a result
column6: the album feels like a powerful hand clasping a limp one. Winehouse had an essential personal relentlessness
column7: which her audience reflected back at her
column8: and the soundtrack to a movie that climaxes at her death has no right to hide or diminish that.

column1: Everyone already knew that Winehouse was a genius vocalist. To its credit
column2: this collection highlights her sardonic writing
column3: choosing songs where she translated her life cuttingly
column4: always with a twist. She was happy to project her true self outward just enough to disguise it as a persona; she was stuck on the same themes of self-aggrandizement and self-diminishment
column5: and she was almost supernaturally ahead of the story. As her pianist says in the documentary
column6: she ""needed music like a person
column7: and would die for it""—and she was ready to
column8: and did. ""Rehab"" was a distraction by way of being right on the nose; her many admissions (""It's not just my pride
column9: it's just 'til these tears have dried"") made us complicit. Back to Black uses depression as a euphemism for heroin in the title. Even ""Tears Dry on Their Own""
column10: her black-swan sequel to ""Ain't No Mountain High Enough""
column11: contains a withdrawal metaphor.

it's a diminishment—this time severe.

Slime Season 2 is Young Thug’s third full-length release in seven months
column2: rounding out a productive streak as formidable as any of his peers'. We already knew he was rap’s most wildly creative stylist: a rogue alchemist of undiscovered melodies
column3: an electrostatic bonding agent for new metaphors. Still
column4: until now
column5: it remained unclear whether he could broaden the scope of his talents beyond a song-by-song basis
column6: channeling the constant spray of ideas into something built to last. Slime Season 2 edges further in that direction
column7: a more carefully constructed work than its predecessor in every sense. And in small but significant bursts
column8: it’s the first of his releases to begin to flesh out a real idea of Jeffrey Williams beyond the blinding veneer of experimentation. This is the sound of 2015’s most dazzling bar-for-bar rapper hitting his stride.

column1: It’s a noticeable improvement over September’s Slime Season
column2: but not because Thug’s rapping is evolving at that speed. Both projects are culled from archives of work presumably stretching back at least a year; there is almost no hint of chronology among these tracks. But where SS1 felt rambling and uneven
column3: there is a clear sense of purpose to SS2
column4: applying the cohesion of Barter 6 to SS1’s pop promise. His engineer Alex Tumay executive produced the project
column5: and Thug benefits greatly from an editor: SS2 is nearly an hour and a half long
column6: but it flows. The mood is woozy and nocturnal
column7: Thug’s adlibs serving as his own echo in some damp subterranean cave. The production roster ranges from Atlanta’s most wanted (Metro Boomin
column8: Southside
column9: London On Da Track) to lesser-known collaborator Goose and—out of nowhere—Fool’s Gold blogwave holdover Treasure Fingers
column10: but all of their contributions blend into the tape’s murky cool.

column1: Thug's lyrics are studded with the glorious non sequiturs you expect: baffling asteroids of one-liners
column2: orbiting in isolation
column3: that either mean nothing or hint at vast cosmological secrets. (""I look good as your dad on a Friday
column4: from ""Thief in the Night""
column5: is probably the former; ""A wise man told me nothing
column6: from tape standout ""Raw (Might Just)""
column7: is unquestionably the latter.) But SS2’s most exciting developments are the rare moments Thug lowers his guard and focuses inward—something that’s only happened in glimpses until now. He darts between flashes of nostalgia
column8: frank meditations on faithfulness and jealousy
column9: nuggets of formative family history: ""My nephew saw his daddy sent out home to the sky
column10: he recalls on the queasy
column11: wobbling ""Beast"".

column1: But the moment that’s burned into my skull comes in the first verse of ""Never Made Love""
column2: a Rich Homie Quan duet left over from the Rich Gang era. Quan brings pathos to the hook and gets out of the way: The song's main attraction is Thug’s sincere and complicated grappling with defensive detachment that taps into a well of long-buried family trauma. With it comes perhaps the most vulnerable and mystically cogent mini-narrative of his entire catalog
column3: one I can’t help but quote in full: ""My lookout man was my right-hand man
column4: but he was wrong
column5: though/ Then I seen some diamonds come off of my neighbor’s porch/ And it was her/ She had a Louis Vuitton purse clean as detergent/ She had the same exact face as my brother’s nurse/ And he in a hearse/ I never looked at it for what it’s worth."" It’s pure poetry.

column1: Critics have called Thug’s music surrealist
column2: but SS2 presents him instead as a storyteller in the magical realist tradition
column3: drawing glimmers of nonplussed fascination out of the rational world. Within this context
column4: his habit for working in small-scale
column5: occasionally disjointed bursts
column6: recording each line spontaneously
column7: makes perfect sense. His thoughts fracture and wander down unpredictable paths
column8: forcing us to draw connections in non-linear ways.

column1: At its core
column2: magical realism suggests that the ultimate mystery in a logical world is man himself; its soft mysticism is a roundabout path to the heart. Above even the muddy
column3: waterlogged sonics
column4: the unifying thread here is intimacy. SS2 has Thug more transparent on love
column5: trust
column6: and heartbreak than ever before: ""She Notice"" and ""Hey
column7: I"" stand out above the rest
column8: unguarded and earnest and complicated as ever. He cheats
column9: he stumbles
column10: and then he attempts to deconstruct his own behavior
column11: tracing the tangled roots of how 2015 rap’s greatest enigma came to be. Nearing the end of a landmark year
column12: we still talk about Thug as a mystery: as transcending language
column13: or as the ultimate triumph of style over substance. But the last thing we hear on SS2
column14: closing out a chopped and screwed version of previously leaked ballad ""Love Me Forever""
column15: is a hopeful yelp: ""And I just wanna be loved!"" It doesn’t get clearer
column16: or more human
column17:
than that.

column9: not exactly rousing topics). When Morrison claimed Astral Weeks sounded ""samey"" in latter-day interviews
column10: he had a point: it was variations on a theme
column11: whereas His Band and the Street Choir shoehorns celebration
column12: sweet melancholy
column13: and reflection into 12 songs. Perhaps this doesn't make for a spiritually transcendent record but it is an album of sustenance

providing sustained pleasures for times of joy and sorrow.

Brooklyn rapper Kirk Knight begins his debut album Late Knight Special quite boldly
column3: with a sample from Sun Ra's Space Is the Place sci-fi film. For Knight
column4: Ra's otherworldly musings are irrelevant: He picks the sample because Madlib uses the same audio clip to end Madvillainy's absurdist ""Shadows of Tomorrow"". Knight's connection to the 2004 classic ends there: His narrative-driven lyrics don't resemble MF DOOM's post-modern syllabic wordplay in the slightest. But by leading with an obvious and familiar sample
column5: he indicates to the listener where his hip-hop allegiances lie. Unlike fellow Pro Era member Joey Bada$$
column6: Knight doesn't try to compete with his more accomplished forebears. At its best and its worst
column7: Late Knight Special is an unassuming project.

column1: That opening track
column2: ""Start Running""
column3: encapsulates much of its successes and shortcomings. Knight flows smoothly and competently
column4: but hardly any notable lines emerge
column5: and he spends much of the song simply telling the listener that he is rapping
column6: which doesn't work without artful twists of wordplay. It's the song's production—Knight's forte—that makes ""Start Running"" worthwhile: The light hi-hats allude to boom bap
column7: but Knight manages to avoid copycat '90s-worship. Throughout the album
column8: Knight shows that although he's learned from the past
column9: he's not living in it.

column1: The more daring Knight gets with his production
column2: the more interesting Late Knight Special becomes. When he cranks up the bass and ventures into the minor key
column3: he gets more intense on the microphone and sharpens his focus. ""Brokeland""
column4: for example

The Albatross became a self-fulfilling prophecy for Foxing. While the St. Louis band's relentless touring enabled the slow-build success of their debut
column2: the aching opening track on Dealer recounts the effect of Conor Murphy having to repeat ugly truths about himself night after night for the better part of two years: ""I am caught up in the guilt/ Making a living off of drowning."" Though Dealer is an artistic triumph and a significant advance from The Albatross
column3: it's even heavier
column4: more compositionally complex
column5: and more personally revealing than its predecessor. And that's why
column6: from its very first second
column7: Murphy sounds drained over the prospect of doing it all over again—Dealer is not an easy listen. It sounds like it was very difficult to make
column8: and reliving it is going to be even harder.

column1: It's in Foxing's nature to welcome a challenge. Of all the leading figures in the Fest-centered post-emo world
column2: they made the most demanding
column3: unique and self-assured debut. It certainly earned the genre tag—silvery guitar figures streaked and twinkled like tiny Explosions in the Sky
column4: while Murphy's keening vocals delivered confrontational and caustic lyrics with spasmodic
column5: burst-and-bloom dynamics. To paraphrase the slow-motion self-evisceration of ""Rory"" (think the Wrens' ""This Is Not What You Had Planned"" stretched to four minutes)
column6: he ripped his heart out while it was still beating and shoved it directly in your face. But Foxing are more interested in a renaissance than a ""revival""
column7: and they mirror the adaptive and forward-thinking qualities of their scene
column8: creating a new voice for familiar sentiments: There was certainly hints of Cap'n Jazz on Albatross
column9: but also actual jazz
column10: as well as Sufjan Stevens' baroque Americana and touches of avant-garde R&B.

column1: The Albatross darted fitfully and stretched out in all directions
column2: while Dealer pulls all of Foxing's influences inward. Inverting his typical role of making burly post-rock bands sound delicate
column3: producer Matt Bayles (Isis
column4: Caspian) boosts Foxing's fragility—Dealer is constructed like an expensive timepiece where you can see every exacting movement behind a thick
column5: glossy lacquer. Murphy's much-improved vocals negotiate the curvature of ""Weave""'s mournful melody and the band's syncopated sway—imagine what the Chicago late-'90s post-rock scene could've accomplished if they hooked up with the guys downstate in Urbana-Champaign. While there were short instrumental interludes on The Albatross
column6: ""Winding Cloth"" is a full-on string orchestration
column7: offering four minutes to absorb the shellshocked war reportage of ""Indica"" before segueing into the heavy-hearted poetry of ""Redwoods"".

column1: Foxing are willing to delay gratification or even deny it entirely if the song requires it
column2: and on <i>Dealer
column3: it often does. When Murphy and bassist/co-songwriter Josh Coll take on universal topics like sex
column4: religion and war
column5: they're framed through discomforting personal experiences: ""The Magdalene"" is the most dour song about losing one's virginity since ""Sic Transit Gloria…Glory Fades""
column6: drawing on strict Catholic upbringings that instilled what Coll described as ""the internal fear that spirits are in the room witnessing 'sin' in action"": ""Mother of God on the rosary/ Is she here with us?/ Does she want what she sees?"" The guilt carries on to the present day as Murphy becomes choked by the supposedly no-strings hook-ups in ""Night Channels"" and ""Glass Coughs"". Both build up from spare
column7: plaintive introductions to restrained screams and contained
column8: brassy cacophony—Murphy allows you to feel every pang and writhe of guilt

column3: if any
column4: indie rock bands have access to this kind of firsthand experience
column5: but that alone isn't enough to ensure it avoids ""Rooster"" or ""Support our Troops OH!"" overstatement on either end. Aside from a brief clatter of field snares
column6: there's little but a single
column7: clean guitar and Murphy's voice catatonic from both PTSD and self-medication: ""Could I give back the sounds of their children's screams?/ Let go of what I've seen?"" Dealer isn't a narrative
column8: but both his civilian and Coll's soldier could share the exhaustion of closer ""Three on a Match""—""For what we did
column9: my love

I'm sorry...the Lord won't let me in/ I'm survived by the weight of my own sins."" The devil and God aren't raging inside of Murphy and Coll anymore—Dealer is the arduous post-war reconstruction.

In a 1985 interview with Bill Flanagan (who also happens to contribute an essay to this set)
column6: Dylan claimed

column1: That approach partially explains why this massive trove exists in the first place. With the recent Led Zeppelin reissue sets

column1: One of the main points of Greil Marcus' book on ""Like a Rolling Stone"" is that the song could have been many things

I'm going out of my brain."") Some of the differences were subtle and some weren't

column1: These two years are Dylan at his wildest. He revolutionized popular music lyrics during this period
column2: bringing in surrealism and romanticism as channeled by the Beats and making it work in a pop context. One of the things he inherited from the Beats was a belief in spontaneous writing and trying to take lyrics more as dictation. Which is not to say he didn't revise—he did
column3: and often. But it's always been a mistake to put too much emphasis on the details of these words and what they might ""mean."" Sometimes they were selected because a turn of phrase was funny
column4: or because Dylan couldn't think of a better rhyme
column5: or sometimes simply because that's what came out. Later on in his writing
column6: he'd have discipline
column7: but this is what he sounded like when he was free.

column1: The structures of these lyrics probably owe something to Dylan's rumored drug experimentation during this period
column2: specifically with marijuana and amphetimines. People on speed use a lot of words and cram them into spaces too small to contain them; they follow digressions and join phrases and ideas that needn't necessarily be joined; the desire to make illogical connections leads
column3: on the one hand
column4: to paranoia—you start to see things that aren't there. But if these tendencies can be channeled just so
column5: they can lead to new structures. ""The sun's not yellow
column6: it's chicken"" goes one of my favorite lines in ""Tombstone Blues"" (heard here in a complete alternate take and another partial version). Nouns and adjectives get chopped up and mixed together

all at once.

A towering standout on Carla Morrison’s new album
column2: <i>Amor Supremo
column3: ""No Vuelvo Jamás"" is a pining anthem that opens with the Mexican singer-songwriter delivering a cascade of wordless syllables that sound less like a human voice than a wind instrument. Her overture is punctuated by an emphatic drumbeat and ominous piano chords

column2: careful
column3: patient crescendo

column8: in fact

column1: A native of the Baja California region of Mexico
column2: Morrison has been a central figure in the extremely tight-knit and defiantly independent Mexican pop community for just six years
column3: releasing a steady stream of EPs and LPs and winning two Latin Grammys for her 2012 album Déjenme Llorar. Although she has recorded with a range of Mexican artists—including the singer-songwriter Natalia LaFourcade

column1: In fact

column3: however

column14: which are forceful but not overpowering
column15: wounded yet strong
column16: pleading but never whiny. Even the way she sings a simple word like ""tí"" can stop you short.

column1: Morrison commands these songs
column2: cuts across the language barrier
column3: makes you understand something beyond the words. And the words are important here. In shedding her old musical palette
column4: she embraces trends and traditions that sound more international in scope
column5: and these songs draw from a range of influences
column6: including American soul and European pop. And yet
column7: she continues to sing exclusively in Spanish
column8: even when an English-language album might have more commercial potential. It’s a crucial decision
column9: one that implies there are certain emotions and ideas—certain big moments—that are specific to Mexico and expressible only in her native language
column10: whether it’s the particular sugar she tastes on her lover’s skin (""Azúcar Morena es tu piel"") or a personal struggle she knows she must overcome (""Esta lucha es solo contra mi""). All moments are big moments

and that epiphany makes Amor Supremo one of the most rewarding and genuinely moving pop albums of 2015.

If Julien Baker wasn't cracking something close to a smile on the cover of Sprained Ankle
column2: I wouldn't be certain that it was meant for public consumption. Much of the album was written in isolation—after Baker left Memphis for Middle Tennessee State University
column3: she worked on these songs in a soundproof booth within the campus music building. It was recorded in Richmond's Spacebomb Studios
column4: a destination du jour that birthed lusciously orchestrated countrypolitan records from Matthew E. White and Natalie Prass this year
column5: but these one-mic and one-take songs could have easily been tracked in an MTSU bathroom. Listening to it can occasionally feel like a violation of her privacy.

column1: This voyeuristic appeal plays a minor role in distinguishing Sprained Ankle
column2: though. More important is how Baker operates in existential ultimatums—life or death
column3: hope or despair
column4: oblivion or epiphany. It cuts through the bullshit rather than piling onto it
column5: and its clarity and honesty has instantly helped Baker reach across aisles. She recently opened for Touché Amoré
column6: a post-hardcore band of blazing intensity and extreme devotees that was previously on 6131 Records and more indicative of the music on Baker's label. By the end of November
column7: she'll be joining the tasteful-indie double bill of EL VY and Wye Oak.

column1: Sprained Ankle is a solo
column2: singer-songwriter album
column3: but very little of it would be considered ""folky."" She professes David Bazan
column4: mewithoutYou's Aaron Weiss
column5: and Ben Gibbard as idols
column6: but her guitar playing bears more of their influence than their vocals. She's a minimalist
column7: playing bassy clusters of melodic thirds
column8: flicking silvery harmonics
column9: palm-muting chords. It's gorgeously recorded and yet
column10: there's still the suggestion that these might've been demos—the scant overdubs of drums or harmonized vocals just drive home how lonely Baker is
column11: that she may have meant these to eventually be full-band arrangements one day.

column1: There are traces of other current acts in her sound—the album title is inspired by a lyric (""Sprinter learning to wait/ Marathon runner
column2: my ankles are sprained"") that instantly brings up the similarly ecclesiastical bloodletting of fellow Tennessean Torres
column3: while her thick
column4: close-harmonizing recalls Sharon Van Etten.  But considering her formative listening experiences and punk roots
column5: by the time she reaches the high notes over an aggressively strummed
column6: stock descending chord pattern in ""Everybody Does""
column7: her most apt comparison might be Dashboard Confessional. Before Chris Carrabba became a caricature of himself and an avatar for emo-as-a-Halloween-costume
column8: there really wasn't much else like him for the hardcore kids. Baker has the same kind of magnetism to get lines like
column9: ""I am so good at hurting myself""
column10: sung by a crowd of young acolytes. Baker's metaphors can also be similarly excessive and clunky at times (""I know I am a pile of filthy wreckage you will wish you never touched"").

column1: Obviously
column2: these songs are about resilience
column3: but Baker acknowledges her willingness to wallow in despair. ""Good News"" plays on the double meaning of hysterical: ""It's not easy when what you think of me is so important/ And I know it shouldn't be so important...I'm only screaming at myself in public/ I know I shouldn't act this way in public."" Later
column4: she asks to be swallowed and smothered by the parking lot as you drive away
column5: an echo of Morrissey's operatic curtain call during the 190-proof melodrama of ""I Know It's Over"".

column1: And like Moz
column2: Baker isn't without a sense of humor about herself. ""Wish I could write songs about anything other than death"" isn't the sort of thing you say unless you're self-aware. But it is important for people to see someone struggle through some serious shit to get to that point
column3: and if you prefer redemption songs to sound as raw as they feel
column4:
Sprained Ankle could bring you to your knees.

Loaded is a perfect rock'n'roll record: 40 minutes long
column2: five songs to a side
column3: and not a single wasted note. Originally released in 1970
column4: the Velvet Underground’s fourth album marked the moment where Lou Reed’s early gig as a Pickwick Records song doctor ceased to be an amusing footnote to the band’s story and became their governing principle. Loaded is the sort of proper album that feels like a greatest hits collection
column5: with each track thoroughly inhabiting and mastering a dominant rock archetype: the hippy-dippy
column6: harmony-rich singalong; the sneering
column7: street walkin’ prowler; the cheeky honky-tonk throwback; the wedding slow-dance standard; the dirty blues grind; the lighter-waving
column8: anthemic grand finale. Loaded remains the one Velvets album you can put on at a house party among mixed company without killing the vibe or sending people running for the door
column9: and it contains the only song in their repertoire—""Sweet Jane""—that you have any hope of hearing on an oldies station today.

column1: But being a perfect rock'n'roll album is a very different thing than being a perfect Velvet Underground album. Part of what makes the Velvet Underground’s official discography so unique is that each of the four dramatically different albums they released between 1967 and 1970 could be considered their definitive statement
column2: and yet each could also be considered the outlier. However
column3: in the latter sense
column4: that distance is amplified with Loaded
column5: and not just because Moe Tucker—the pounding heartbeat of the band—sat out the sessions to tend to her pregnancy
column6: necessitating a drumming-by-committee approach. When stacked against the dark
column7: droning psychedelia of The Velvet Underground & Nico
column8: the flesh-melting distortion of White Light/White Heat
column9: and the disarming quietude of The Velvet Underground
column10: there’s nothing overtly contrarian about Loaded. It’s the album that plays least into the myth of the Velvets as transgressive avant-rock outsiders and speaks most loudly to their reality
column11: as a working band playing half-empty bars
column12: desperate to deliver a hit to their antsy major label minders.

column1: That pressure was baked into the very title of the record
column2: a directive from their Atlantic Records bosses to produce a record ""loaded"" with potential hit singles—and the band delivered on every count
column3: except
column4: of course
column5: the sales part. In that respect
column6: Loaded stands as one of rock’s first truly meta artifacts
column7: prefiguring such label-baiting in-jokes as Neil Young’s Everybody’s Rockin’ rebuke to Geffen Records and Nirvana’s ""Radio Friendly Unit Shifter"". This is
column8: after all
column9: a rock 'n'roll album that advertises its populist intent with a song about rock'n'roll called ""Rock & Roll"". Past provocations gave way to carefree kicks: ""Head Held High"" is ""I’m Waiting for the Man"" fresh out of rehab; ""Train Round the Bend"" is ""Sister Ray"" sent to the confession booth. But while Loaded may constitute a concerted effort to play by the rules
column10: the Velvets come off like boarding school-bound delinquents who spend their class time stifling giggles and sneaking snarky notes. Whether answering the Beatles’ optimistic ""Here Comes the Sun"" with the withering ""Who Loves the Sun?"" or crashing the Byrds’ country-rock rodeo on ""Lonesome Cowboy Bill""
column11: Loaded feels as much like a sardonic comment on pop’s ruling class as a bid to join its rarefied ranks. Atop the immortal riff of ""Sweet Jane""
column12: Reed declares
column13: ""me
column14: I’m in a rock'n'roll band
column15: before adding a ""huh""—and
column16: after a million listens
column17: it’s still hard to tell if it’s being delivered with a smirk or a shrug.

column1: Alas
column2: all that contradictory tension proved emblematic of deeper fissures running through the band. As this six-disc box set expansion of Loaded makes clear
column3: the Velvets’ most airtight album ironically bears telling signs of their unravelling. Compiling remastered stereo and mono versions of the album
column4: demos
column5: alternate mixes
column6: outtakes
column7: a surround-sound DVD album mix
column8: and two live sets
column9: Loaded: Re-Loaded 45th Anniversary Edition highlights the painstaking tweaks and tinkering that went into making a seemingly effortless rock'n'roll album. Like the previous box sets in the Velvets’ current reissue campaign
column10: Re-Loaded is less about unearthing rare tracks (much of the bonus material here first surfaced on 1997’s Fully Loaded) than getting the story straight
column11: and properly contextualizing the output of a band whose official albums have been overwhelmed by a continuous stream of posthumous live albums
column12: rarities compilations
column13: and bootlegs. In the case of Loaded
column14: the stereo and mono mixes don’t exist merely to satisfy differing listener preferences
column15: but to present conflicting visions for the album. The former contains the extended versions of ""Sweet Jane"" and ""New Age"" that were eventually pared down for the official November 1970 release
column16: much to Reed’s chagrin; he had left the band shortly after recording was completed
column17: effectively sealing the album’s doomed fate before it even hit stores.

column1: Tellingly
column2: on Loaded
column3: Reed already sounds like he’s handing the keys to the band over to bassist Doug Yule
column4: who sings lead on four of the album’s 10 songs and plays much of the instrumentation. In contrast to John Cale
column5: the band co-founder he replaced in 1968
column6: Yule was never so much Reed’s foil as his eager understudy
column7: with a more naturally melodic voice that buffed away Reed’s rough edges. But that’s no slight: Yule’s smooth-talker act yields the album’s most subversive moments
column8: whether selling the bitter cynicism of ""Who Loves the Sun?"" as shiny
column9: happy
column10: ba-ba-da-ba pop
column11: or playing the hotel bar-prowling hustler on ""New Age"" who sycophantically woos a faded movie star for a one-night stand only to cruelly discard her as ""over the hill."" And as the outtakes disc reveals
column12: ""I Found a Reason"" could’ve easily wound up as a straight Dylan rip
column13: before Yule’s angelic harmonies helped transform it into the most gorgeously celestial ballad in the Velvets’ canon. (Partially due to outstanding contractual commitments
column14: Yule would soldier forth under the Velvet Underground name without any other original members for 1973’s largely forgotten Squeeze
column15: an album unlikely to enjoy its own 45th-anniversary box set moment.)

column1: More than just a collection of song scraps
column2: Re-Loaded’s demo stash lets us imagine how Loaded might’ve turned out without the hitmaking ambitions
column3: from the rough-hewn takes of future Reed solo standards like ""Satellite of Love"" to the organ-swirled fantasia of ""Ocean"" (the most prog the Velvets ever got) to a molasses-slow version of ""Sweet Jane"" that anticipates the Cowboy Junkies’ codeined cover. Meanwhile
column4: the first live disc—a remaster of Live at Max’s Kansas City—offers a glimpse of the arena-ready powerhouse the Velvets had become just prior to Reed’s exit. (The two sets that make up the show—one devoted to rockers
column5: the other to ballads—were recorded by Factory regular Brigid Polk on August 23 1970
column6: reportedly Reed’s last night fronting the band; the version included here omits two tracks from the 2004 double-disc reissue of the complete concert
column7: presumably to make it fit on a single disc.) If Loaded is the closest the Velvets ever got to becoming the Rolling Stones
column8: on Max’s Kansas City they practically turn into the Who
column9: as Doug’s brother Billy propels ""I’m Waiting for the Man"" and ""Beginning to See the Light"" with thundering Moon-shot drum rolls. But the recording is ultimately a faded snapshot of a live act in peak form at a career nadir: from the infamous intrusion of Jim Carroll trying to score some Tuinal to the idle audience chit-chat about the movie Patton that overwhelms ""Candy Says""
column10: the Velvets are rendered as mere background noise even for the few devotees who bothered to come out to their shows.

column1: The second concert included here—and of most interest to Velvets completists—predates the Max’s Kansas City show by a few months
column2: but exudes an even greater degree of finality. Recorded by a fan on a reel-to-reel
column3: the May 1970 set at Philadelphia’s Second Fret club sees Reed
column4: Yule
column5: and guitarist Sterling Morrison performing without a drummer (though Yule would hit the skins on a couple of songs). The stripped-down
column6: slackened presentation greatly distinguishes it from other live Velvets documents of the era
column7: while emphasizing certain subliminal textures
column8: like the krautrock pulse running through ""Cool It Down""
column9: or the tremolo wash on ""Train Round the Bend"" that essentially invents Spacemen 3 a good 12 years early. (There’s also a rare Reed-sung version of ""New Age"" with considerably different lyrics.) These curios aside
column10: Live at Second Fret is the sort of moldy bootleg you probably only need to hear once
column11: that is
column12: if you can even make it all the way through—the recording has the fidelity of a pocket-dial. But the decaying
column13: desolate presentation feels like an appropriate way to capture a band on the verge of disintegration. The set ends
column14: as Loaded does
column15: with ""Oh! Sweet Nuthin’""
column16: and the two versions crystallize the album’s story in miniature: one is the grandiose statement of a band with chart-topping aspirations
column17:
the other is the lonesome sound of a band that ain’t got nothin’ at all.

On an episode of ""WTF With Marc Maron""
column2: Mikal Cronin spoke about the scene he
column3: Ty Segall
column4: and Charles Moothart came up in during high school. As he explained it
column5: he would throw parties at his parents' house in Laguna Beach
column6: and their small circle of musician friends would write songs and start bands specifically for the events. Different combinations of the same people were getting together and exploring different vibes. ""You guys still do that

column11: Thee Oh Sees' John Dwyer

column1: Those high school bands weren't focused on long-term sustainability; they were momentary sparks of creative energy. To this day
column2: the best moment in the life of any new Segall project is the first spark. The introductory taste of new music from these bands offers the opportunity to parse how aesthetic and personnel differences define the music—to hear what separates it from prior work

column5: the band's stellar hook work
column6: the effortless way they can slink into a groove
column7: and Segall's ace drumming. With 2013's Fuzz
column8: the proto-metal-worshipping power trio became a proven entity—a well-oiled machine with a few strong songs. The lineup now features Ubovich

column2: II
column3: is a double album—a ballsy and potentially dangerous move for a band who operate best when their songs are kept tight. Their Fuzz track ""Loose Sutures""
column4: for example
column5: went a bit too loose and lost its momentum about halfway in. More than half of II's songs are over four minutes long
column6: and the longest one of the bunch is the most disappointing of them all. The final 14-minute track
column8: is an obligatory instrumental sequel to Fuzz's instrumental closer ""One"". Where ""One"" ramps up the power and velocity of its central hook
column9: ""II"" never quite figures out exactly where it's going. It changes course several times
column10: and along the way

column1: It's a bum note to end on
column2: but before they reach that final song
column3: Fuzz knock out some undeniable high points in their discography. Ubovich's bass provides the perfect dour counterbalance to Segall's dulcet vocal on ""Let It Live"". There's a premium on heaviness
column4: and ""Pollinate"" certainly delivers the thudding
column5: crashing goods. And if Fuzz occasionally felt too spare
column6: II is where they throw everything at the wall. All three men play synthesizers
column7: and in a few well-placed moments

column9: emphasis
column10: texture—at the moment a song begins to feel stale.

column1: It also helps that they're the rare band where any of the three members could serve as the frontman. While Segall's voice is undeniably the most impressive
column2: Moothart and Ubovich come across more gritty and grounded—perfect for songs about ""teeth twisting in the heatwave."" It's also refreshing to hear Fuzz bucking their former formula—their ""lead singers take turns"" approach goes out the window on ""Burning Wreath""
column3: which features Segall and Moothart trading lines and briefly harmonizing. It's a small moment
column4: but one that hints at how much this band are capable of when you consider how much talent they have between them.

column1: That's why it's disappointing when
column2: around the album's third side
column3: Fuzz's songs begin to feel anonymous—like they're retreading ground they'd already covered earlier in the album. Segall
column4: Moothart
column5: and Ubovich have done an impressive job of nailing this sound
column6: and somewhere in the stoner rock sprawl
column7: they have enough impressive moments and great songs for a truly strong album that's about half as long. They just don't do quite enough to differentiate their approach or justify the album's 67-minute run-time. There are definitely instances of them changing things up—""Red Flag"" is a two-minute punk song on an album that benefits from brief interstitials. Even considering all the high points and raw power

II falters under the weight of the band's ambition.

A well-regarded player in the Chicago jazz world
column2: bassist and composer Joshua Abrams has spent the last several years recording expansive trance music with his band
column3: Natural Information Society. That outfit’s records are driven by improvisation
column4: though not necessarily in the form of individual solos. Instead
column5: Abrams and his collaborators create hypnotic interlocking patterns
column6: rhythms
column7: and melodies that seem to spool forth endlessly without any single voice taking center stage. It is serene and peaceful music that relies on spontaneous invention
column8: but also on restraint.

column1: It’s a sensibility that is carried over to Abrams’ other pursuits. In the past several years
column2: the bassist has also established a reputation as a composer for film. Released digitally by Eremite Records

column3: the mood is not morose. Abrams’ score is mostly lighthearted

column3: which tracks a group of anti-violence activists working with communities in Chicago. Commissioned a mere six weeks before the film's Sundance Film Festival premiere
column4: it's the slightly less polished of the pair. However

column7: Abrams’ benefits from the presence of great musicians

column1: Watching the films
column2: Abrams’ music is never intrusive. It enhances a scene
column3: but never forces a mood. And while it’s probably not the first place you’d turn to experience his work
column4: it provides an example of his stylistic reach and musical ability. Natural Information Society’s music thrives amid the extended zone-out

column7: in miniature
column8:
the music can slot so naturally into somebody else’s story.

More than a few of the vicious old debates in ""new classical"" music have been settled. In 2015
column2: a composer isn’t obliged to choose melodic minimalism over atonal complexity
column3: or vice versa. If she wants to write something that ""addresses the times
column4: there’s no set aesthetic to follow. Execution is what the community of listeners has (generally) pledged to judge.

column1: You can hear this relatively new
column2: pan-stylistic freedom quite clearly in the music of Ted Hearne. As a political animal
column3: he’s a liberal populist; as a composer
column4: he’s a fan of preexisting texts and musical maximalism. His 2010 protest song-cycle Katrina Ballads set real life excerpts from an American tragedy—think of George W. Bush’s famous assessment ""Brownie you’re doing a heck of a job""—to a richly textured musical backdrop that blended jazz and classical vocal approaches with aggrieved electric guitar and frenetic chamber scoring. In 2013
column5: Hearne provided Erykah Badu with well-judged orchestrations of songs from New Amerykah: Part One (4th World War)
column6: which Badu performed live with the Brooklyn Philharmonic. (We’re still waiting for a proper studio recording of those.)

column1: With this album
column2: Hearne gives us a distillation of an experimental stage work about Chelsea Manning (and WikiLeaks) that was presented in 2014 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Composing once again atop found texts—including logs of Manning’s chats and leaked government documents that were selected and edited by the novelist Mark Doten—Hearne’s latest project gives us some of the composer’s most intriguing music yet.

column1: In the song ""s/as boy/as a boy""
column2: Hearne scores one of Manning’s haunting pre-arrest concerns—""i wouldn’t mind going to prison for the rest of my life/ if it wasn’t for the possibility of having pictures of me.../ plastered all over the world press.../ as boy""—by way of a somber cello-and-guitar riff that is frequently interrupted by percussive slaps. (The discrete instrumental parts swirl together with an affecting unease
column3: circa Manning’s line
column4: ""I'm just kind of drifting now."")

column1: Another highlight is ""Julian in a Nutshell""
column2: in which Doten creates lyrics from shards of questions delivered to Julian Assange by reporters. At first
column3: Hearne pairs Doten’s documentary cut-up fragments with airy individual string and vocal lines. As the journalistic narrative is better established—demanding that Assange define himself as either a ""journalist""
column4: an ""anarchist""
column5: or the victim of a ""smear campaign""—the vocal lines settle into sunnier harmonies. It’s the sound of the press finding an angle
column6: though Hearne’s subtly clattering orchestration isn’t as sold on the quality of the conversation.

column1: Inevitably
column2: this audio-only version of The Source also omits some key aspects of the ""multimedia oratorio""
column3: occasionally rendering an abstract production even more conceptually opaque. In director Daniel Fish’s filmed excerpts from the original staging
column4: we can see that The Source originally included a chorus of silent observers that surrounded the audience
column5: on video-projection screens. Looming large over the proceedings
column6: that visual chorus adds a measure of ghostly gravity to the long chunks of leaked military cables that Hearne’s actors recite through vocal filters.

column1: These bureaucratic passages certainly deserve grimly robotic accompaniment. (Think of lyrics like: ""An IED detonation was reported by C co 1-327 INF to Task force SPARTAN
column2: in the Salah Ad Din Province
column3: Ad Dawr
column4: vicinity. 38S LD 8930 1490."") But on the album version
column5: these long stretches of war-euphemism can wear thin. Without the ability to conjure the silent witnesses on a recording
column6: Hearne instead references the wider culture by inserting drops from pop songs. At best
column7: these feel unnecessary. At worst
column8: they’re distracting: Liz Phair’s ""Girls! Girls! Girls!"" isn’t contemporaneous with the WikiLeaks era
column9: nor is its consideration of gender politics particularly relevant to Chelsea Manning’s worries about being misgendered while serving some future prison sentence. This version of The Source could have benefitted from some stronger editing
column10: though when it connects
column11:
it can still resonate as some of the most expressive socially engaged music in recent memory—from any genre.

The title track of Sam Shepherd's debut album as Floating Points was inspired by a dream: A migratory bird strays from its flock and is swallowed up by the forest
column3: mimicking the way our atoms are absorbed into the fabric of the universe when we die (or so goes one theory
column4: anyway). We might find ourselves ""reincarnated as a SIM card in Singapore
column5: or as a beetle in Scotland
column6: as Shepherd told Pitchfork recently.

column1: He recorded the song ""Elaenia"" the very next morning
column2: and its improvised
column3: fluid form mirrors the dream's holistic vision. Made with just a Fender Rhodes electric piano and a handful of arcane synthesizers
column4: it bobs between gurgles and limpid
column5: lyric melodies. At more than seven minutes long
column6: it is the second-longest song on the album
column7: and also the most spare— just a handful of chords
column8: some rumble
column9: and a lot of nuance. Like an ocean swell
column10: it is simple on the surface but complex beneath
column11: and the same could be said of Elaenia as a whole.

column1: Though comparatively short—just seven songs totaling some 43 minutes—Elaenia is rich and welcoming
column2: balancing Shepherd's intelligence with intuition. Flitting between strange time signatures and simple pulses
column3: it utilizes mostly analog synthesizers
column4: pairing them with live instrumentation: electric bass
column5: guitar
column6: piano
column7: live drums
column8: and strings. It is as warm and fluid an ""electronic"" album as you will hear all year
column9: and it has a timeless feel: There's no reason it could not have been written and recorded 10
column11: or even 30 years ago.

column1: For long-time fans of the UK producer
column2: musician
column3: and DJ
column4: Elaenia feels both like a surprise and a logical extension of his previous singles and EPs. Rhythms are played
column5: not looped or sampled; the album skirts the edges of the dancefloor
column6: flitting between ambient miniatures and extended jams falling somewhere between post-rock and jazz fusion. But nothing here feels like a radical departure
column7: which is a testament to Shepherd's gradual process of refinement. He is trained in neuroscience and epigenetics
column8: but it would be just as easy to imagine him as a furniture builder who had spent the past six years working on a single desk. The underlying structure of his work has remained more or less constant for years
column9: but with every recording
column10: it gets a little smoother
column11: a little more perfect
column12: inching a little closer to its ideal form.

column1: Shepherd has cited Talk Talk as an inspiration
column2: and you can hear the influence of albums like Laughing Stock on the porous fabric of Elaenia. It's a record best heard loud
column3: because the quiet parts can be very quiet
column4: and its spirit lies less in melodies or even moods than in tiny details. With the exception of the cosmic jazz-leaning ""Silhouettes (1
column7: you're left less with hummable themes than with small
column8: passing moments: the burnished gleam of a lone Rhodes key hit hard
column9: a faint scrap of radio static
column10: soft notes that cling to each other like burrs.

column1: In keeping with the transfiguration theme
column2: the music seems to have no stable center at all. It moves like clouds in the sky
column3: slowly and imperceptibly shape-shifting
column4: and at any given moment
column5: what's being played matters less than how we arrived at that point. The sense of an unbroken line is paramount
column6: leading to the album's final thrill when it is suddenly yanked up at a 45-degree angle. In five minutes it goes from silence to jet-engine loud. Synthesizers snarl
column7: the string section goes into overdrive
column8: and the drum kit rolls on inexorably
column9: explosion upon explosion. The song
column10: ""Peroration Six""
column11: is the only one where you feel Shepherd and company really letting loose.  It's a revelation and a rush
column12: a full-on ""Fuck yeah!"" shouted into the coming storm. The last thing we hear sounds almost like a wrong note
column13:
and then it's all simply cut short. The silence is deafening; it feels like waking up from a very heavy dream.

The fact that you still can't mention Boots without also mentioning Beyoncé teaches two mournful lessons: 1) It's a mixed bag to start your career with a zeitgeist-definitive icon re-recording your best songs
column2: and 2) It's even harder when you struggle to find a distinctive voice on your own. Four-fifths of Beyoncé had Boots' stamp on it
column3: and since then the artist and producer
column4: whose real name is Jordan Asher
column5: has been busy. He's brought his surly
column6: gentle
column7: unfurling darkness to a feature-heavy mixtape
column8: a series of well-chosen collaborations—Run the Jewels and FKA twigs
column9: most recently—and now a first album
column10: Aquaria. It's hollowly explosive and impeccably engineered; it's a ball of static electricity
column11: its aesthetic distinct. And nevertheless
column12: Boots remains in his own shadow
column13: his debut album eclipsed by his debut.

column1: As a musician
column2: Boots has an ear for sweet melody and a percussive
column3: subtle
column4: muscular style. His instincts cleave to R&B easily
column5: and innovate from inside the genre; you can hear this happy marriage clearly on ""Haunted
column6: the Beyoncé meditation that was originally a Boots track called ""I'm Onto You."" Aquaria recalls that track's sound world directly: the instrumentation that rattles and slaps
column7: the vocal line narrow. Aquaria itself is a rock album cumulatively – its soul is Mad Max and Jesus' Son
column8: as if someone pushed Nine Inch Nails and Radiohead underwater and made them kiss – but Boots's primary instinct is genre agnosticism. This is an enormous benefit to the artists who work with him
column9: but it's often a detriment when he's left alone.

column1: As a rule
column2: Boots' instrumentals are much more persuasive and emotionally precise than his vocals. The slinky and rabble-rousing title track is a highlight
column3: and not coincidentally because Angel Deradoorian is paired against a great
column4: fat
column5: delicate clap in the beat. ""I Run Roulette
column6: another standout
column7: is hard-edged pop that rides the contrast between the pitch-black riot that serves as the backdrop and the verses
column8: which come very close to bubble-grunge.

column1: But Boots has an imprecise delivery as a vocalist. When he sings
column2: or just as often sing-raps
column3: you often forget what he's trying to say. Part of the difficulty lies in the lyrics. They're half-heartedly combative
column4: noncommittally weird
column5: full of half-clever neologisms: like the song title ""Oraclies
column6: for ""oracle"" and ""lies."" On ""Bombs Away
column7: Boots sings: ""All the wolves are famous/ Hide the rich and shameless/ Thirsty like an addict/ Hope is for the tragic/ Sell me down a new stream/ New world has new dream."" The same restless
column8: idle soothsaying comes in on ""C.U.R.E.
column9: a track that aches for a Run the Jewels guest verse (El-P is a co-producer on Aquaria) but
column10: with Boots at the helm
column11: sounds almost
column12: truly
column13: like Crazytown. There's a slightness in his voice that he doesn't use well; there's a melodic whimsy in his aesthetic that's best matched either with formidable guest charisma or else with his own production
column14: its taut anxiety left unverbalized
column15: slicing and revving away.

column1: As on WinterSpringSummerFall
column2: snippets of melody are briefly mesmerizing here; on Aquaria
column3: the old-fashioned slow-dance ballad ""Only"" is a beautiful lament. ""I am the only one alive
column4: he sings
column5: then switches: ""You are the only one alive."" Those are your options
column6: solipsism or fixation; the album whirls between the two poles to occasionally claustrophobic effect. Each song confines you to a small set of characters: a bassline
column7: a beat knocking
column8: a squidge of sonic interference
column9: a melody.

column1: For all of Boots' fluidity and technical proficience
column2: his solo work seems hampered by his attachment to pop
column3: which doesn't fit his elusive profile. Aquaria could explode live
column4: with two drummers at Boots' back. But in speakers
column5: the album feels just pop enough in intention that its pleasures seem noticeably absent; with a few strong exceptions
column6: the album could be a folder of songs waiting for someone else to bring them to life. Boots has talent enough to make a star
column7:
or to elevate a star to a new realm. You wonder who his next one will be.

Fetty Wap and French Montana are at different points in their careers. Both are northerners with cocaine-centric worldviews – French Montana comes from a rap outfit called Coke Boys and Fetty Wap's breakout single is called ""Trap Queen"" – but they don't share much else in common at the moment. Fetty's self-titled debut recently hit Number One on the Billboard 200 after a string of trap ballads became Top 10 hits
column2: and French is in the process of trying to muster up some much-needed buzz after a commercial flop and a series of mixtapes that failed to stick. They are also two very different types of trappers: French is a materialist with tunnel vision and Fetty is a hopeless romantic penning Pyrex love poems. They go about dealing in different ways
column3: but they traffic the same thing
column4: and on their collaborative mixtape Coke Zoo they find common ground in cocaine rap's tropes—and in their shared penchant for hook-driven songs.

column1: Coke Zoo disproves any notion that Auto-Tune is the great equalizer. When Fetty uses it
column2: his voice soars. When French uses
column3: phrases flat-line. It can be jarring going from Fetty's voice
column4: which is robust and full
column5: to French's
column6: which is flat and without depth. French hitches a ride on the Fetty bandwagon for many of his best contributions
column7: but his approach to writing is far more elementary (On ""Freaky"": ""I'ma hit it like a dog/ Then I'ma pass it to my dog"")
column8: and it's Fetty's knack for melody that makes songs like ""Power"" so appealing.

column1: Many of the ideas and sounds on Coke Zoo feel like Fetty Wap b-sides and leftovers: ""Sometimes"" is a leaked Fetty Wap song from July (""I Wonder"") with a French verse tagged on. ""Angel"" once again showcases the stunning skill set of the trap balladeer (""And I make all this guap just to show you it's ours"") before French Montana sucks out all of the energy with lifeless vocals and a mood-breaking verse. On ""Gangsta Way""
column2: a repurposed Chris Brown song with a French verse
column3: he takes an otherwise solid record and stifles its momentum. It's weird that French Montana
column4: who is one of the more interesting characters in hip-hop
column5: often writes such simple and boring raps
column6: and on Coke Zoo
column7: standing next to Fetty
column8: he somehow seems even duller.

column1: There are some outliers. Unsurprisingly
column2: French delivers his best performances on the French Montana songs
column3: where he gets to operate in his own space without Fetty creeping over his shoulder. The Lil Durk-featuring ""See Me"" is French's strongest use of Auto-Tune on the tape over a trudging rhythm
column4: sax
column5: and piano chords. On ""Concentration""
column6: he takes a minor piano riff (courtesy of the Mekanics and MIXX) and makes one of his signature repetitive
column7: bass-heavy jams. But as the chanting Fetty Wap joint ""Damn Chainz"" proves
column8:
there isn't much French can do better than his trapping Jersey counterpart. Coke Zoo is an interesting experiment that showcases why the stocks of these two rappers seem to be headed in two different directions.

Wolf Eyes have always had a B-movie aura. They’re like the Roger Corman of underground music
column2: churning out releases
column3: inspiring other low-budget noise-auteurs
column4: galvanizing scenes both locally in Michigan and globally in festivals and collaborations. Many of their blunt album titles have a schlock-horror feel: Slicer
column5: Dread
column6: Burned Mind
column7: Human Animal. That feel is in the music too. At turns scary
column8: funny
column9: dramatic
column10: and transfixing
column11: Wolf Eyes’ morphing sound has one constant: creepy
column12: thick tension.

column1: The trio’s B-movie game is in full effect on I Am a Problem: Mind in Pieces
column2: whose title sounds like either a pulpy confessional or a campy drug-education filmstrip. Song names feel like lost movies too: ""T.O.D.D."" as killer-robot sci-fi
column3: ""Asbestos Youth"" as mean-streets teen flick
column4: ""Cynthia Vortex AKA Trip Memory Illness"" as LSD-soaked journey into madness. Lyrics reference drowning heads
column5: toxic thoughts
column6: burning hairs
column7: suffocation cages. If this album getting released the day before Halloween is a coincidence
column8: it sure is a lucky one.

column1: Most importantly
column2: the music on I Am a Problem: Mind in Pieces contains all the ominous suspense of a classic horror movie. Each track oozes with eerie tones and seat-edge momentum
column3: such that something terrifying seems to always lurk around the corner. The album even mimics the narrative arc of a thriller: the first few tracks gradually heighten the plot
column4: until action explodes in the damaged-punk climax of ""Enemy Ladder"" and its tale of ""twisted lands of severed hands."" The denouement of ""Cynthia Vortex"" follows
column5: ending with singer Nate Young’s chopped-up groans that evoke a victim’s final gasps of air.

column1: Though he’s an equal partner in sound-crime with bandmates John Olson and James Baljo
column2: Young is the star of I Am a Problem’s cinematic tremors. His jaw-clenched snarls and subliminal seething get under your skin. Razor-like moans in ""Twister Nightfall"" curl sharply around a monster-march beat and Baljo’s guitar grind
column3: while Olson’s creaky noises on ""T.O.D.D."" rhyme with Young’s yelps. Even on ""Enemy Ladder""
column4: where frantic rhythms swirl into a cloud
column5: Young's bark center things like the piercing eye of a pulsing storm.

column1: Beyond his own vocal dexterity
column2: Young’s recent move toward more subdued music in his solo work (often under the name Regression) has steered Wolf Eyes to a place where small shifts can make huge ripples
column3: and hypnosis is as powerful as confrontation. One of the best Regression albums is aptly titled Stay Asleep
column4: and Young has developed a keen knack for sonically replicating nightmares—""I burn my dreams just to stay warm
column5: he sings in ""T.O.D.D.""—and making gripping music from dark shadows and subtle motion.

column1: In fact
column2: I Am a Problem: Mind in Pieces may be too somnambulant for noise-hounding Wolf Eyes heads
column3: or newcomers impatient for quicker cuts to the chase. You have to sit still a while and let the trio’s sonic images wash over you before their musical zombies rise from the dead to terrorize the stereo space. But give this album a fraction of the patience and attention that Wolf Eyes have put into it—effort on a par with their excellent previous effort
column4:
No Answer: Lower Floors—and you’ll be glad you stayed up late enough to see how it ends.

Though it wasn't as heavy as the brooding grunge it shared Modern Rock airwaves with at the time
column2: the peppier alterna-pop of the '90s often cut just as deep. Acts like the Lemonheads
column3: Juliana Hatfield
column4: and Matthew Sweet disguised depressive sentiments in plain sight by pairing them with chiming guitars and tuneful fuzz—you could sing along to some of their songs for weeks before even noticing they might be a cry for help. So it's easy to see why Laura Stevenson looked to power pop's flannelled era for her fourth album
column5: Cocksure. The New York singer-songwriter has never shied from self-effacing thoughts
column6: and by dialing up the pop she gives herself even more cover to let her antipathy run wild. It's her most disaffected record yet
column7:
but it's so spirited you could easily mistake it for her happiest.

Stevenson's '90s makeover represents a sharp course correction from her sleeper 2013 album Wheel. That record was a true singer-songwriter affair
column8: rooted in folk-rock and country and highlighted by ornate ballads flushed with tasteful strings and horns. She clearly poured a lot of time into it. Cocksure
column9: on the other hand
column10: is as assured and impulsive as its title. Though it's bookended by two big
column11: showy numbers that would have would have slotted seamlessly onto Wheel— ""Out With a Whimper""
column12: a Rilo Kiley-sized emotional wallop
column13:
and the regal grand finale ""Tom Sawyer / You Know Where You Can Find Me""—the rest is driven by swift riffs and bubblegum hooks. Listeners who thought Stevenson's former Don Giovanni labelmate Waxahatchee might have done well to lighten Ivy Tripp with another ""Coast to Coast"" or two will find plenty of instant gratification on this one.

Stevenson's old Bomb the Music Industry! bandmate Jeff Rosenstock rejoins her here in a producer role
column14: which might partially account for some of Cocksure's punk moxie
column15: but underneath the speedy tempos Stevenson is consumed by the same delicate subjects that have driven all of her solo records: emotional retreat
column16: the nagging fear that she's squandered her youth
column17: and the irrational disdain she feels for those who care enough to try to lift her from her funk. ""I'm fucking hideous and spiteful when I'm left to my devices
column18: she lashes out on ""Jellyfish""
column19: which juxtaposes the album's sweetest hook with its sourest image: Stevenson as a gelatinous blob sprawled flat on the couch
column20: motionless and essentially dead to the world but with a stinger pointed at anybody who might dare to poke her. She doesn't need to be told it's an awful way to live; she knows. ""I'm wasting away my life and gifts on being a piece of shit
column21: she concedes
column22:
if only so she doesn't have to hear somebody else say it.

That all might make the album seem like a buzzkill
column23: but it never is. One of the joys of the album is simply hearing her cycle through so many slight variations of '90s alternative
column24: and how she always manages to find the right shade to counter her dour mood. ""Happier
column25: Etc."" matches another plea to be left alone to slaphappy pop-punk. The exuberant guitars on ""Claustrophobe"" blast out of the same Kitty Pryde-postered garage as the Blue Album
column26: while the jangly ""Life Is Long"" channels the great
column27: underrated heroes of sad-sack '90s guitar-pop: the Gin Blossoms. That band may not be the hippest touchstone for a millennial songwriter
column28: yet perhaps more than any other they embodied the same mantra that Stevenson wears so well on Cocksure: When life gives you lemons
column29:
sugar the fuck out of them.

It's probably unfair to compare EL VY
column2: the new project from Matt Berninger (the National) and Brent Knopf (Ramona Falls
column3: Menomena)

EL VY provides our first look at Berninger divorced from that context and a clue toward deciphering how much of the National's appeal hinges on Berninger's GQuaalude musings and how much belongs to his band's gilded alt-rock.

column1: It's easy to say EL VY's first record

column4: the one he swung around so much on 2005 breakthrough Alligator. Elsewhere (""It's a Game"") he's comfortably forlorn
column5: trading on elegant little phrases (""It's a game/ And I can't wait to see you"") like he did on 2013's Trouble Will Find Me. Knopf's jaunty and hectic keyboard-heavy arrangements are a little indistinct and
column6: worse

column8: unable to choose between glam (""I'm the Man to Be"") and lounge rock (""Paul Is Alive"")
column9: between lush folk (""No Time to Crank the Sun"") and boozy bluster (""Sad Case"").

column1: We get glimpses of how Berninger might fare as a Bryan Ferry-esque put-on—he has the wardrobe for it—or as Greg Dulli-indebted horndog
column2: but only in the moments before Knopf's arrangements whisk him away. The particularly ill-fated opening trilogy—including ""I'm the Man to Be""
column3: the title track
column4: and ""Paul Is Alive""—reek of that fake-funky
column5: post-Beck period when major labels gave odd
column6: talented bands just enough rope to hang themselves; the results sound like Berninger and Knopf deemed Soul Coughing not haughty enough. There are cooing background vocals
column7: dirty organs
column8: harpsi- and power chords
column9: but it all feels random
column10: deployed only because something has to fill these spaces.

column1: Berninger
column2: for all his magnetism
column3: doesn't help matters. Absent his backing band's grandeur
column4: his poet-laureate-of-the-upwardly-mobile-schtick cedes way to a clever misanthrope in need of an editor and an Advil. The album opens with the unforgettable and irredeemable line
column5: ""I scratched a ticket with the leg of a cricket/ And I got triple Jesus
column6: straight from the Tweedy School of Left-Leaning Refrigerator-Magnet Poetry. He's still name dropping other musicians—the Beatles
column7: the Cramps
column8: the Minutemen—but he puts too fine a point on things when
column9: in the middle of ""Sleepin' Light""
column10: he declares
column11: ""Ain't no Leonard Cohen."" He's still funnier than he's given credit for (""You were supposed to bring me your brother's weed...this is heartbreaking!"") but he seems in on the joke less often. His haphazard proper nouns—""Silent Ivy Hotel""
column12: ""Happiness
column13: Missouri""—carry less import.

column1: Trouble Will Find Me was well-received
column2: but there was a sense
column3: even amongst National die-hards
column4: that this was the last time the band
column5: and Berninger
column6: could coast on that particular sound. Return to the Moon is an unhappy departure
column7: one that suggests that Berninger is as reliant on the National's luxe environments as they are on his all-the-wine sloganeering. And while there's nothing here that suggests Berninger and Knopf are truly incompatible
column8: there's equally little evidence that Knopf's spirited arrangements are suited to Berninger's spotlight-gargling word soup. ""Return to the moon/ I'm dying
column9: Berninger croons on the opening track. Yeah
column10:
man.

The British D.I.Y. scene that arose in the wake of punk had a weird relationship with mainstream pop
column2: one that continues to this day: This compilation was originally supposed to be called Now That's What I Call DIY!
column3: until Sony inspired its new name. The records compiled here by JD Twitch of the Scottish DJ duo Optimo weren't exactly a genre at the time
column4: but they had an ideology in common. Punk rock's Pistols/Jam/Clash wave had made a lot of noise about overturning musical orthodoxy
column5: but it was pretty much a single kind of noise. The D.I.Y. bands made it their business to overturn every received idea about songs and recordings: rehearsed harmoniousness
column6: formal structures
column7: polish of any kind. But they did like to dance
column8: or at least bounce
column9: and some of them liked tunes
column10: too. None of the artists on [Cease & Desist] DIY! were ever
column11: ever going to make it onto the charts--or so they figured at the time--but they wanted it to be known that they weren't rejecting pop values out of ignorance.

column1: If you were looking for these sorts of records fifteen or twenty years ago
column2: when anybody other than collectors still had them
column3: you'd paw through 7-inch bins from which the Buzzcocks and Young Marble Giants singles had already been nabbed. The sound came almost exclusively from England in the years of this compilation's subtitle. Its record sleeves were predominantly monochrome
column4: or black and white and pink
column5: although silkscreened artwork (as with the sole release by Sara Goes Pop
column6: from which ""Sexy Terrorist"" is taken here) was also acceptable. Uneven Letraset type
column7: or handwritten band names and song titles
column8: are a good sign; so are record labels with names like Fuck Off Records and It's War Boys
column9: and what-were-they-thinking band names. The Spunky Onions' ""How I Lost My Virginity""
column10: for instance
column11: comes from their ""split single"" with the Ghettoberries
column12: who were of course the same group.

column1: Twitch's sequence bends the usual rules for scene compilations. It's not all obscure artists—Thomas Leer
column2: whose electropop single ""Private Plane"" appears here
column3: went on to be half of the super-slick new wave band Act. Instead of surveying as many bands as possible
column4: it includes two different tracks by the cunningly named Distributors: ""TV Me
column5: a sort of answer song to the Normal's ""T.V.O.D.""
column6: and a curdled dub piece called ""Never Never"". It even ventures a bit outside of its own time range: a 1984 album track by the 012 is gerrymandered in on the grounds that it was recorded in 1981.

column1: All of those turn out to be fine decisions on Twitch's part
column2: because [Cease & Desist]  manages to pull together recordings by a bunch of desperately alienated artists into a remarkable
column3: eye-opening and ingeniously sequenced album. It's arranged into four four-song suites (there's no CD version of the album
column4: but there is a double LP)
column5: each with a distinct focus. The first side is four stone classics featuring piping-voiced women singers; three of its four bands are by splinter projects of the Homosexuals (whose 1978 ""Hearts In Exile"" single is a fountain from which a lot of this music springs).

column1: In particular
column2: ""C'est Fab""
column3: a 1982 single credited to Nancy Sesay and the Melodaires—a Homosexuals-related group never heard from before or since—justifies this compilation's existence all by itself. It's a struggle for supremacy between a rhythm section that's trying to play crisp
column4: bouncy funk and musicians who are doing their utmost to derail it (a singer squeaking uncertainly and out of tune at the very top of her range
column5: an out-of-control trumpeter streaking through the studio
column6: a male chorus with comedy accents
column7: somebody dropping in cascades of fist-hammered dub piano). Everybody ends up winning.

column1: That's followed by a set of tracks that use the materials of synth-pop to build weirder and more obsessive structures than the stuff that was starting to turn up on the charts. (The highlight there is Dorothy's ""Softness""
column2: an uncanny
column3: close-miked spoken piece whose backing band includes both Genesis P-Orridge and Alex Fergusson
column4: shortly before they formed Psychic TV.) The album's third side begins with three pieces inspired by the messiest extremes of Jamaican dub--a huge influence on that generation of British musicians--and ends with a song that recalls dub more or less by accident: the slow
column5: sneering 1978 single ""Violence Grows""
column6: by a wobbly band of teenagers called ""Fatal"" Microbes
column7: fronted by a monomaniacal-sounding then-14-year-old who went by the name Honey Bane. (By the end of 1981
column8: she would have a legitimate UK Top 40 single of her own
column9: ""Turn Me On Turn Me Off"".)

column1: The final suite of [Cease & Desist] highlights the D.I.Y. scene's connections to the punk rock sound and ethos that made it possible. In another compilation's context
column2: actually
column3: the Fakes' ""Look Out"" and the Prats' ""Disco Pope"" would just seem like ineptly performed punk songs
column4: which arguably they were. But the genius of D.I.Y. was that it made any bug a feature: these records' aesthetic framed every off-key vocal or mangled rhythm as a rebellion against the boredom of sonic orthodoxy
column5:
and they are never for an instant boring.

The world that these songs on exist in

column4: of course

column6: particularly on tracks like “Sick Machine” and “Death Condition
column7: ” the latter of which is laden with clunky

column1: But while Pictureplane’s signature ’90s-evoking female vocal samples might sing soulfully in the distance
column2: the record feels drained of the energy his previous albums showcased. The common setting on Techomancer is slowmo
column3: with most tracks favoring ethereal
column4: romantic ’80s synths over the pumped up
column5: choppy compositions on Thee Physical. Even the breakbeat intro on “Harsh Realm” cuts out a minute in
column6: favoring a more chilled out
column7: awkward see-saw synth progression before returning to the sound of the song’s start. The blaring airhorns and record scratching sounds on “Street Pressure” feel like they’re working against the soft
column8: sultry melody Egedy builds on that song
column9: like a jokey nod to traditional club music. All of this seems at odds with the sound Pictureplane has cultivated thus far. There’s a tame
column10: almost downtempo vibe to a lot of this record that keeps it from beginning to end in a sluggish
column11: not very dance-friendly territory.

column1: Technomancer is certainly Egedy’s most nicely produced output yet
column2: with his voice coming through stronger than ever on a lot of these songs. “Crack all the windows downtown
column3: it’s that new American noise
column4: ” he sings to a “renegade street trash” on the more traditional
column5: radio-friendly pop track “Riot Porn.” But the noise of Technomancer just plays too comfortably. Technomancer is very high concept in its man vs. machine dystopian themes
column6: but the darkwave-edged beats Egedy constructs
column7: while bleak
column8: don’t possess the same level of imagination. In seemingly trying to make more cinematic and visionary electronica he ends up making pretty lackluster
column9: slow-burning pop. On Technomancer Egedy’s typically wire-frayed
column10:
wall-of-sound ’90s mixtape sound feels stripped into something more pedestrian rather than futuristic.

From blockbuster biopic Straight Outta Compton to the Game's latest throwback
column2: Documentary 2
column3: California hip-hop history is big business nowadays. YG adapted LA gangster rap tradition to a modern production palette on My Krazy Life
column4: while Kendrick Lamar and Vince Staples deconstruct the genre’s tropes and ideologies. Yet far from Southern California's party-driven nostalgia and cerebral critique
column5: a Sacramento-based underdog on a shoestring budget has exploded underground
column6: offering a bleak
column7: confrontational take on street rap that’s at once urgent and unsettling. Yellow Tape Activities is Mozzy's third solo full-length this year
column8: and his snowballing fanbase suggests grim realism still speaks to present conditions.

column1: Although young
column2: Mozzy didn't arrive overnight; he's been recording for half a decade. As far back as 2010 tape Mozzarella Fella
column3: he displayed the skills of a gifted writer
column4: latching onto vivid imagery: ""Pour the Patron in the Ocean Spray cran-grape/ I'm well-buttered like a Grand Slam pancake."" But over the past two years his style really snapped into focus
column5: becoming leaner and more direct. Along with producer June on the Beat
column6: he cultivated a sound defined mainly by narrative style rather than melody or sonic technique.

column1: And this focus is one perpetually shaped by violence—think of Chicago's drill scene
column2: although Sacramento has a long history of its own brutal reality rap. Yet Mozzy takes his own path. His rapid evolution over the past few years reached an apotheosis with 2014's ""Next Body on You""
column3: on which Mozzy’s disconcerting lyrics insistently pressure the listener into the role of a crew hitman: ""Next body on you
column4: 'cause you don't never do it."" <span>June's production
column5: a canned loop that sounds like a forgotten arcade game theme
column6: sounds worlds away from the booming maximalism of Lex Luger; the song's teeth are entirely lyrical
column7: not musical
column8: and this juxtaposition backlights Mozzy's unflinching audacity. His unprecedented directness makes murder less abstract
column9: an absurdity transformed
column10: seen through the more familiar lenses of peer pressure and shared burdens.

column1: Yellow Tape Activities lacks the immediate highs of previous Mozzy tapes Bladadah and Gangland Landscape
column2: but the album retains the rare consistency for which the rapper is known. There are no Mozzy filler verses. Nothing here seems aimed at the pop charts
column3: although Mozzy's gift for a potent chorus suggests this isn't far from his reach. Opener ""Property of the Ave"" epitomizes his gift for morbid hooks
column4: tossing off sticky lyrics with unbothered ease: ""He ain't never bodied nobody on our behalf.""

column1: The darkness of his world is one brought to life by its unapologetic
column2: almost ascetic discipline
column3: focusing on a few major themes: loyalty
column4: purposeless murder
column5: and drug abuse. All are linked by an ever-present pain which can be spoken of in art but never expressed in reality. This comes through on the fatalism of ""Ain't Shit Happen"" (""You don't slide for your niggas like I do for mine/ Living on the borderline of suicide"") and the way he considers his mother's concern as just another threat (""I don't care about my life like my momma care""). These are strict parental-advisory raps. The very visual and ever-present violence is disturbing
column6: an art form pressed to its limit. He pushes gangster rap tropes in your face
column7: placing them in unexpected
column8: discomforting formulations.

column1: That this remains gut-wrenching despite years of gangster cliches is one aspect of his artfulness; that we keep listening despite the shock is another. In part
column2: this is owed to the musicality of his flow
column3: the particular way in which he packs in syllables and slant rhymes in memorable patterns. The stitching is wholly unique and feels brand new. It's present in the density of his slang
column4: which adapts nearby Bay Area terms and Chicago street slang but submerges them in a local dialect that takes time to decipher. Mozzy slides
column5: slithers
column6: wiggles; his illas will wolf on 'em
column7: back door 'em
column8: breathe on 'em; guns become drum sticks
column9: chop stixx
column10: yop sticks. This isn't simple decoration. Every verse is written with bar-to-bar purposefulness that leaves listeners hanging onto each line. Its as if his ideas were carved from cliche with a straight razor.

column1: Mozzy’s art is at once shockingly new and alarmingly bleak. Or really
column2: the situations he describes are bleak
column3: as Mozzy is an artist whose feet may still be intertwined with the world that shaped him. Rather than a glorification of violence
column4:
the unremitting effect of his music is ceaselessly dire—the upsetting vision of one man from Sacramento's tough Oak Park neighborhood.
