Grief is a watery emotion
column2: prone to slopping over the side of any container it occupies—and so it takes a project like Camella Lobo’s L.A.-based Tropic of Cancer
column3: music that moves fluidly
column4: to truly capture it. Stop Suffering
column5: which Lobo recorded and self-produced with mixing and mastering from Joshua Eustis (ex-Telefon Tel Aviv)
column6: is her first major work since 2013’s glimmering Restless Idylls LP
column7: and though it only comprises three tracks
column8: the tracks are so finely crafted that it's a work worth returning to
column9: playing again and again
column10: and exploring within. It is a work about grief
column11: yes
column12: but a work wholly without self-pity
column13: a work that urges slowly forward. It is a work about how grief ebbs eventually
column14: with attention and time.

column1: Lobo is an expert in how nearly microscopic musical changes can have an enormous emotional effect
column2: and the opening title track is a master class on this phenomenon. It's built on gauzy layers of synth-wash just a step or a half-step away from one another
column3: and as Lobo introduces a layer or pulls one back the subtle movement causes the whole track to shiver
column4: like a spider’s web trembling below the movement of tiny feet. Her timing has to be impeccable to achieve this
column5: and it is. Her vocal melody also stays within a relatively small range for most of the song
column6: functioning more as an additional instrumental/ambient layer—pushed back in the mix
column7: hovering suspended in delay—than a traditional vocal line winding around and through the instrumentation. It is a dense song with a dark heart that only truly shows itself near the end of the track
column8: but it never feels murky.

column1: ""I Woke Up and the Storm Was Over"" is more glacial in pace than the title track
column2: but with a minimal heartbeat ticking at its core. It stretches luxuriously
column3: like a cat's yawn
column4: all choral synth and tidal sweep and percussive shoegaze bass
column5: the sort that sounds like a big piano. On this one
column6: Lobo’s vocals sit more atop the mix
column7: more the focal point
column8: more the driver. There is something in it that feels immensely
column9: strangely hopeful.

column1: If the title track is slowly running water and ""I Woke Up and the Storm Was Over"" is the glacier formed as that water starts to freeze
column2: the closing track
column3: ""When the Dog Bites""
column4: is its iced-over final form. Droning and sparse in comparison to the highly textural tracks before it
column5: ""When the Dog Bites"" throws Lobo’s voice into final heavy relief. When the bass drum hits
column6: it feels like a communication across a vast expanse. The entire record feels composed in the way a classical piece does: a tale of grief in three movements
column7: a tale of the sick motion of heartbreak eventually becoming still and distant
column8: if not forgotten
column9: as one's own sense of self becomes more pronounced. It is a delicate and painful journey
column10:
and one worth taking at Lobo’s side.

The Virginia singer/rapper D.R.A.M. positions himself as a larger-than-life character. On the cover of his new Gahdamn! EP he appears in comic-book form
column3: standing several stories tall and smacking down a Godzilla-type creature. In the middle of the EP is a ""Redemption THEME""
column4: which sounds like the music you would hear as Mario finally rescues Princess Peach after many unsuccessful tries in other castles. In this narrative
column5: he's a righteous hero who exploded into the public consciousness with a song that sampled ""Super Mario World""
column6: had Beyoncé dancing
column7: and
column8: directly or not
column9: influenced Drake’s biggest hit since 2013.

column1: This triumphant storyline makes a lot of sense
column2: but <span>since D.R.A.M. has remained under the radar since
column3: it’s a fair question to ask: Can he escape ""Cha Cha""? The Gahdamn! EP
column4: much like this year’s previous #1 Epic Summer EP
column5: isn't designed to answer questions. It's a fun

column7: R&B
column8: soul
column9: electronic music
column10: and even rock for about half an hour. Nothing is as immediate as ""Cha Cha""
column11: but D.R.A.M. has other things up his sleeve. The remix of ""$"" replaces the original’s minimal piano and reverb with a bombastic horn section that builds around the earworm hook
column12: ""this be that shit that make a nigga get off his ass and get money."" It’s a swelling
column13: giant moment that seems to fit squarely with the persona D.R.A.M. is selling and the company he’s keeping.

column1: However
column2: he also goes some weird places. On ""Wit the Shits""
column3: D.R.A.M. resembles no one more than Biz Markie
column4: a punch-drunk presence on the mic who speak-raps his way around a song about doing drugs with a girl who also likes doing drugs. On the sweet
column5: vintage-sounding R&B cut ""I’ll Be Back Again"" he toes a line between silliness and earnestness
column6: singing the line ""I really be contemplating on coming inside of you
column7: punctuated with a ""woo!"" He recalls (and maybe parodies) the lighthearted bluntness of the most honest ""baby-making"" soul songs. (""I really be contemplating on making new life with you"" is another great line here.)

column1: SZA gives voice to the implied female presence on the other end of the gorgeous ""Caretaker""
column2: which originally appeared as an interlude on Donnie Trumpet and the Social Experiment’s Surf. This moment
column3: expertly sequenced as the EP’s penultimate track
column4: underlines the artist I think D.R.A.M. wants to be—an outsized musical omnivore who mixes Maxwell-style neo-soul with Too $hort-style frankness. He ends with the mission statement ""Okden""
column5: expressing a wish to collaborate with Kendrick Lamar (""but it must be special"")
column6: touching on working with Rick Rubin
column7: and managing a quick line about his appearnce: ""I step in places all dreaded like ‘he must be ghetto
column8: ’"" which is the closest we get to glimpsing the ""real"" D.R.A.M. outside of viral hits and the self-conscious weirdness.

column1: Gahdamn! is D.R.A.M.'s second release in the year that feels playful and low-stakes
column2: and it would be nice if he made something that felt more... complete. But even when he doesn’t re-capture the madness of his biggest hit
column3: he ignites a few other fires. Gahdamn! is a breezy sprint through many styles
column4: demonstrating a multi-faceted artist putting all his influences in a basket
column5: shaking them around
column6:
and seeing what comes out the other end.

Will Toledo isn't old
column2: but he's feeling his age. He's in debt; his friends are getting married; his hands are frozen; he's stuck in the city; and worst of all
column3: his songs are starting to sound the same. The world is moving past him
column4: blurring into formlessness
column5: and his music as Car Seat Headrest is an attempt to slow down and make sense of the rush.

column1: Teens of Style is technically a compilation
column2: comprising songs dating back to 2011 that were re-recorded for his Matador debut. (Teens of Denial
column3: a planned 2016 release
column4: will be his first Matador album of entirely new material.) You can hear the revised sound as a composite of the label's history: Guided by Voices' ear for cracked pop oddities
column5: Belle and Sebastian's emotional directness
column6: Yo La Tengo's intimate approach to jamming
column7: Stephen Malkmus' ability to get wordy without forgetting to rock out. As a songwriter
column8: Toledo is both present and detached
column9: capable of living in a moment while floating above it. A self-summarization comes on the brawny ""Strangers""
column10: when he deadpans a series of autobiographical quips: ""Car seat is a menace to the public
column11: ""Car seat is a genetic stop sign
column12: ""Car seat's nervous and the lights are bright.""

column1: On that song
column2: we find out the young Toledo fell in love with Michael Stipe: ""I took lyrics out of context and thought
column3: 'he must be speaking to me.'"" His confusion over purposefully abstract lyrics may have turned him into a literalist
column4: someone endeavoring to explain every twist and turn of his interior state. His lyrics are rapaciously intelligent
column5: with a knack for wry humor. Take a lyrical adjustment on the new recordings
column6: for example
column7: that reflects the shift in his life status: ""Times to Die"" swaps a couplet about sneaking his way to musical success into a meditation on the existence of a higher power
column8: like God or (even better) Matador founder Chris Lombardi (""Got to have faith in the one above me/ Got to believe that Lombardi loves me"")
column9: who will help decide whether or not Toledo is destined to be a cult hero.

column1: Teens of Style has a noticeably jagged quality; unbelievably
column2: it used to sound even DIY-ier. (The original versions can be found on Car Seat's Bandcamp.) The new recordings retain their rough edge
column3: but there's luminescence in the production—the percussion is crisper
column4: the guitars are brighter
column5: and Toledo's singing is a lot more pronounced. The effect is an album that's bookish
column6: but not sedentary. He sells abstruse metaphors and lyrical concepts with every ounce of himself
column7: like failing to do so would mean the end of the world. In this way
column8: he's a cousin of artists like Joanna Newsom
column9: Bright Eyes
column10: or Okkervil River
column11: who never let their prodigious literary intelligence get in the way of crafting something you might actually enjoy listening to.

column1: To (sort of) quote Brandon Flowers: He's human and rocker. The existential despair of ""Something Soon"" is crystallized in a blown-out chorus
column2: while he uses a hypnotic keyboard line to make the haunting ""Maud
column3: You're Gone"" a prom song for moody kids. A spectral choir comes through a radio at the start of ""Sunburned Shirts"" before breaking into a scratchy pop gem
column4: like George Harrison on anti-depressants (""I haven't looked at the sun for so long/ I forgot how much it hurt to""). Toledo's voice is weary
column5: and carries a shred of desperation—he sounds like a third-generation cassette tape recording of Julian Casablancas (who
column6: otherwise
column7: is his complete opposite as a frontman).

column1: Earlier this month
column2: I went to a Car Seat Headrest show held as part of the annual CMJ Music Marathon
column3: where dozens of bands go to make their reputations. But Toledo began the set lying on the floor
column4: with his microphone angled toward the ground
column5: as the band launched into ""The Ending of Dramamine""
column6: a 14-minute epic where he references Modest Mouse and sings about only thinking about himself. If you weren't standing right at the stage
column7: you couldn't see him. The words flowed from the void
column8: sung by someone so overwhelmed by the moment he would rather disappear. I couldn't absorb them all at once but what I remember is the crowd standing on their toes
column9: edging their way forward
column10: hoping to catch a glimpse. Then
column11:
he stood up.

The arc of Sun City Girls’ 26-year history was long
column2: but it bent toward chaos. Their music was an unpredictable pile-up of rock
column3: pop
column4: jazz
column5: blues
column6: psych
column7: noise
column8: improv
column9: and many far-flung global sounds—with special love for the music of the Middle East—delivered as ballads
column10: jams
column11: rants
column12: plays
column13: and pranks. Their dual passions for playing whatever they felt like and confounding any audience who would listen dovetailed perfectly
column14: such that even their biggest fans can cite Sun City Girls moments that they found baffling or even off-putting.

column1: This penchant for messiness helps explain why 1990’s Torch of the Mystics is Sun City Girls’ most famous and perhaps best-loved album. The most surprising aspect of this record is how well arranged and engaging the music is. Though the trio had roots in the Arizona hardcore scene of the early '80s
column2: no one ever pegged them as purveyors of three chords and the truth
column3: especially given the rambling releases that preceded Torch. But the three-chord riff that launches album opener ""Blue Mamba"" couldn't be more direct
column4: and remains Sun City Girls’ biggest-ever earworm.

column1: Torch of the Mystics is replete with moments like that—nuggets of hypnotic tunefulness stretched into songs that feel as classic and well-worn as the dusty cassettes the band uncovered on their travels around the globe (later mined for compilations on bassist/singer Alan Bishop’s Sublime Frequencies label). You can actually whistle along to most of Torch’s songs—one even starts with Bishop whistling the melody for you—and even the farthest-out tunes have discernible shapes that quickly burn into memory.
The most immediate images come from the guitar of Alan Bishop’s younger brother Rick. Earlier Sun City Girls albums hinted at his instrumental prowess
column2: but it’s on full display on Torch of the Mystics. His playing isn’t about technical know-how or honed chops—though he clearly has both of those—but rather finding epiphanies in repetition. The curling chords of ""Esoterica of Abyssynia"" are so dizzying they seem to fold in on themselves
column3: like a musical Möbius strip. Similar effects spin from the warped strings of ""Radar 1941""
column4: which sounds like a water-logged surf tune that washed up from the other side of the planet.

column1: An equal counterpart to Rick’s guitar is the malleable voice of his sibling
column2: Alan. The Bishops’ worldly travels clearly gave Alan an ear for all manner of singing styles
column3: and on Torch he displays the vocal capabilities to match them. At times he sounds like he’s channeling ghosts of singers past
column4: as in the worshipful warble of ""Space Prophet Dogon"" or the strikingly-beautiful scale-riding of ""The Shining Path"". The latter is a cover of Bolivian folk song ""Llorando se feu""
column5: and Sun City Girls’ treatment is typical of their magical way with covers. It retains the stirring mood of the original while transposing it to a more mysterious
column6: fantastical realm (in this case

column8: Vida (modular synth)

The Attic Tapes is a 20-song archival hodgepodge cobbled together from early recordings of the late British guitarist John Renbourn
column2: who died in March. Renbourn sourced the core of the tracklist from a tape labeled ""1962"" that he discovered in the attic of fellow folk revivalist Mac MacLeod
column3: pairing those few songs with various onstage collaborations from his salad days
column4: before he and his guitar-sparring partner Bert Jansch and their band
column5: Pentangle
column6: helped redefine the scope of modern folk. Renbourn had yet to sign a record deal
column7: so these takes are rough with their age and his youth. But the finale
column8: a live duet with Davy Graham of ""Nobody Knows You When You’re Down Out""
column9: is pristine
column10: with the thin
column11: lithe tone of the dual guitars rendered perfectly. Had Graham and a teenaged Renbourn somehow stolen into a proper studio back in 1962?

column1: Actually
column2: their Clapton Unplugged-like take on the American standard comes from an onstage rendezvous several decades after the heyday of the British folk revival. As a memento
column3: it is quite poignant. Not only did Graham serve as a de facto mentor to Renbourn
column4: but the younger guitarist opens this set with a hurried version of ""Anji""
column5: one of Graham’s trademark numbers. But as a set-closer
column6: it’s a bit of a bore
column7: the sound of two old friends romping through the blues for their own amusement but without much payoff.

column1: Alas
column2: that makes it a fitting close for The Attic Tapes
column3: a tedious if spirited set that lets us hear Renbourn learn where folk and blues had been rather than guide where it might go. It raises more questions about archival albums than it answers of Renbourn’s genesis.

column1: The Attic Tapes mostly confirms what we already know about Renbourn and
column2: really
column3: the bulk of his motley crew of fellow crooners and pickers: They loved the rawness and magnetism of American blues and folk music
column4: and they tried the best they could to recast it in their own image. There are a few originals here
column5: like the halting and smart blues reordering of ""Plainsong"" and the peppy ""Judy"". But mostly
column6: Renbourn plainly shows his roots. He turns Blind Boy Fuller’s doting but vaguely threatening ""Little Woman You’re So Sweet"" into the sprightly ""Beth’s Blues"". Like most every other pasty kid with a piece of carved wood and some strings
column7: he works his way through Blind Willie Johnson’s ""Lord I Just Can’t Keep From Crying"". He flits between the notes and lifts and leaps with his voice in a way that suggests he’s celebrating his own vulnerability
column8: a young man not old enough to know how painful it all could get.

column1: Likewise
column2: Renbourn’s take on <a href=""http://www.derrolladams.org/songs/portland-town.htmlhttp://www.derrolladams.org/songs/portland-town.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Portland Town""
column3: by itinerant and largely overlooked American banjoist Derroll Adams
column4: seems to delight in tragic lyrics about bad marriages and dead children. And his cover of <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RgY4GnLGsLQ"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Jackson C. Frank’s perfect anthem
column5: ""Blues Run the Game""
column6: is overly emphatic
column7: the verses brandished with unwarranted relish. It’s clear that Renbourn is an incredible guitarist
column8: capable of making intricate patterns seem effortless even at such a young age. His jejune takes on these hard old songs suggest that he was
column9: to date
column10: simply an instrumentalist short on experience.

column1: If you’re worried that The Attic Tapes is an opportunistic ploy to profit from Renbourn’s recent death
column2: like a youthful journal published without the deceased author’s consent
column3: don’t: Renbourn seemed enthusiastic about this project
column4: even penning playful and informative liner notes that trace his lineage and sources more clearly than the recordings themselves. According to Riverboat Records’ owners
column5: Renbourn died the day before they would have sent him the final artwork; he never had a chance to dig deeper for exact dates on these sessions.

column1: Aside from its redundancy
column2: though
column3: the real worry with The Attic Tapes stems from the way it reflects reissue-and-archival culture at large. Though many labels interested in such work do essential excavations of forgotten sessions
column4: albums and artists
column5: there seems to be an increasing tendency to regard most anything that’s survived as a masterpiece—as though time transformed it like common carbon into a rare diamond. Everything presumed to be lost doesn’t need to be found. The situation seems doubly pronounced when the music involves an artist we already know—or
column6: in the case of The Attic Tapes
column7: a panoply of them.

column1: In some way
column2: I wonder if our relatively new era of seemingly instant and infinite information about what our favorite singers had for breakfast or where they’re vacationing and with whom has made the salvage of such basement reels and attic tapes seem more paramount
column3: as though we’re retroactively rebuilding as much of the past as we can. That’s an intriguing endeavor
column4: but it doesn’t necessarily make for essential records. During his 50-year career
column5: Renbourn contributed to several of those
column6:
from Bert and John and The Pentangle to The Black Balloon. This makeshift reliquary—perhaps the final release in which Renbourn had a hand—is not among them.

""31"" builds like a '70s horror cut (or perhaps a porno flick?) around an unnamed woman breathing ""No"" as a solitary keyboard sound throbs creepily. ""33"" weaves around a sped-up recording of a voices chirping as if out of The Wizard of Oz.

Like Arthur Russell

column6: Cowley’s roots were avant-garde; where Russell's lineage came from experimental classical composers like Christian Wolff

column8: Wendy Carlos
column9: and Tangerine Dream. Unlike Russell
column10: however

column12: Cowley was to LGBT pioneer Sylvester—the mustachioed background figure who contemporized a disco diva’s hot soul with cool technology.

column1: Yet unbeknownst to even most of his disco fans
column2: Cowley also created synth compositions in the even-more-underground medium of gay porn. Muscle Up is the second of two releases compiling this work

column5: Paul Parker
column6: Loverde

column11: DVD
column12: and digital
column13: much of gay and straight porn music alike would be synth-centric.

column1: Like porn itself
column2: electronic music references reality while signaling a fantastical break from it. For gay men born in the '50s like Cowley
column3: synths suggested a refuge from repression
column4: an escape hatch from a world where police entrapped
column5: beat
column6: and jailed them; where they lost their jobs or unwillingly severed family ties. This is one of the reasons why synth-disco milestones like Summer's ""I Feel Love""—a track Cowley further intensified in his legendary 15+ minute remix—resonated so strongly with gay dancers of its era: Synth music was dream/sci-fi music
column7: and it competed with R&B at the bathhouses where its suspension of time and space heightened the otherworldliness of unlimited sexual expression central to pre-AIDS gay experience
column8: as if every man-on-man encounter after Stonewall and before Plague was a trip to the moon.

column1: Appropriately
column2: the first track of <i>Muscle Up
column3: ""Cat's Eye""
column4: begins with a whooshing interplanetary-wind sound
column5: and the ominous processional tom-toms that follow lets us know that sex is about to happen in the furtive way animals anticipate an earthquake. Cowley's keys ape ceremonial trumpets much like the pseudo-horn fanfare that opens Devo's Duty Now for the Future. That was 1979; this piece was allegedly recorded in '75. The recording is crude and there's a moment of cacophony when two martial drum patterns crossfade and collide
column6: but even this accidental frisson suggests porn's glitchy
column7: clandestine low-budget production values.

column1: As a former drummer who switched to synths (but plays everything here besides didgeridoo and a bit of bass)
column2: Cowley comprehended both discipline and exploration. There's little on Muscle Up that sounds robotic; ""5oz of Funk"" echoes the syncopated beat and bass from Patti Jo's ""Make Me Believe in You"". Only once do machines keep time
column3: on a 1975 instrumental demo version of ""Somebody to Love Tonight""
column4: a song that Cowley revisited four years later with Sylvester
column5: yielding understated but profoundly aching results. Even at this stage
column6: it's supremely sultry
column7: simmering with desires then considered utterly vile beyond the San Francisco bubble.

column1: Today
column2: the city's technology occupies a different kind of frontier
column3: one often driven by motives not entirely artistic. And so it's instructive to hear what one guy then just blocks away from where Twitter now resides created with far cruder but perhaps more sensitive
column4: pre-digital tools some 40 years ago. Rather than clean precision
column5: he gets dirty invention
column6: overheated homage. Instead of considered silences between notes
column7:
there's the strong suggestion of one man's impulsive sweat and spunk and stink. Cowley's interplanetary sex music is paradoxically earthy for the same reason his parallel cosmic club grooves were so righteous; because it reveled in freedoms long denied.

column9: one way down low—share the melody on""“Humyn Hymn""

column11: ""Chemical computer syringe/ Memories are fading away/ Rolling off the side of the bed

column1: It’s a fitting approach for a record which

column17: but Drewchin’s songs are more expansive and more free-form

column6: while synths pulse like an android heartbeat behind her. And she begins ""Mask Therapy"" by repeating the words ""identity crisis"" over rippling

and creating new musical forms to share their discoveries.

Anyone with an interest in left-of-center house or techno can find something impressive in the catalog of Stuart Li
column2: aka Basic Soul Unit. It's a testament to Li's chameleonic nature that he has proven a seamless fit with the cult Japanese deep house imprint Mule Musiq; the UK bass driven techno label Nonplus Records; Berlin behemoth Ostgut Ton; and Jamal Moss' purposefully abstract Mathematics Recordings. Each of these labels has successfully staked out a patch of deep and slightly weird dance music territory

column7: revealing pixelated weaknesses in the bigger picture.

column4: ""Restless in Thoughts"" works to makes disorientation seem balanced and appealing

column3: ""Unwavered""
column4: and ""Landlocked"" may look to broken beats
column5: classic techno
column6: and electro
column7: but they're all a little too bleak
column8: too clean and undynamic. ""Fate in Hand"" may well be an attempt to alleviate some of the grayness toward the album's end

column1: Each track of Under the Same Sky will undoubtedly find a home in a record bag or set list somewhere
column2: and rightly so

column4: though
column5: Under the Same Sky leaves you wanting more of a moody
column6: immersive experience
column7:
and less of its clean surfaces and precise negative spaces.

Technical progress is vital to metal's character. Metal bands have always pushed themselves to be faster
column2: heavier
column3: more challenging
column4: and more musically dextrous than their predecessors. That said
column5: it's still rare when an act genuinely succeeds at altering the meta-structure of the form. Anytime a Meshuggah or Dillinger Escape Plan comes along
column6: you can bet dime-a-dozen imitators will cheapen the impact of their innovations. To make matters worse
column7: today we're swarmed by retro-obsessed bands hell-bent on recreating the vibe and tone of
column8: well
column9: name any year and heavy metal subgenre. Not to mention that rampant sectarianism fosters a mentality where superficial differences between camps become paramount and crossing barriers becomes a transgression.

column1: Every now and again
column2: though
column3: a band comes along that sidesteps these conventions. With their debut album
column4: last year's Songs of Descent
column5: Nashville trio Yautja (named after the extraterrestrial creature from the Predator film series) reminds us that what we think of as metal today can be as boundless and mutable as the range that jazz had encompassed by 1970. A prog-minded act that combines grindcore and Amphetamine Reptile-era noise with the artier shades of hardcore and death metal
column6: Yautja doesn't just stack hairpin turn after hairpin turn—an approach that was tired by technical death metal's mid-'90s peak. Instead
column7: bassist Kayhan Vaziri
column8: guitarist Shibby Poole
column9: and drummer Tyler Coburn create a highly malleable
column10: mercury-like alloy that changes shape with liquid ease yet retains the solidity of its structure. (The way their music moves
column11: it might've been more fitting for these guys to name themselves after the villian in Terminator 2.)
column12: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">

column1: As its title suggests
column2: the new EP Songs of Lament was crafted as a companion piece to the full-length
column3: but there are some key distinctions. For starters
column4: Lament leans closer to a grimier
column5: more punkish production aesthetic. Meanwhile
column6: because Yautja came out of the gate with a flair for tempo changes
column7: the lean toward slower sections this time around doesn't seem drastic. With Songs of Lament
column8: Yautja once again shows that
column9: like the art of the fastball
column10: sheer speed is most effective when a band can mix up its delivery and hit you from unexpected angles.

column1: Case in point: Songs of Lament closes with the nine minute-plus ""Crumbling""
column2: which climaxes in a sludge/doom buildup where Poole and Vaziri churn out an ominous riff at a crawling tempo. When Coburn suddenly explodes into a flurry of fills
column3: followed by a blast beat and a jazzy double-time figure on the ride cymbal
column4: the song feels like it's taking off even as it trudges through muck. That one passage speaks volumes about Yautja's mindfulness when it comes pacing. In fact
column5: one marked contrast between Lament and its predecessor is that the EP plays like an extended suite of music. As for subject matter
column6: all three of Yautja's members write lyrics and supply vocals
column7: with Vaziri doing the lion's share of the barking. And while the cutting lyrical content does linger at the irate end of the emotional spectrum
column8: Yautja's nonpartisan musical approach lends the words a more sophisticated hue by default.

column1: Understandably
column2: Songs of Lament doesn't accomplish as much as its full-length companion does in terms of furthering metal's evolution. Moreover
column3: the new material is rendered somewhat two-dimensional by a mix that sounds flatter in comparison to Songs of Descent's full-fidelity production. Still
column4: the new songs certainly show what this band is capable of when it makes subtle tweaks in its approach to structure. Indeed
column5:
Songs of Lament extends the pleasures of the debut while whetting the appetite for what new wrinkles Yautja might have in store the next time around.

Madlib’s calling card is his ability to spin obscure funk into woozy rap instrumentals. With the lack of precision and attention to mood

column4: it seems the Cali composer has reined himself in a bit: 2014’s Piñata had all the grit you'd expect from Madlib

column7: in-the-pocket flows. He further restrains his sound on <i>Bad Neighbor
column8: a collaborative LP with rappers M.E.D. and Blu. This is a light-hearted jaunt
column9: with the rappers leaping from topic to topic
column10: as if passing a blunt between verses. Don’t expect anything profound here. At its core
column11: Bad Neighbor is about three dudes and their friends
column12: spitting verses over great beats without sweating structure.

column1: The producer fits well into this free-flowing group. He also feeds off seemingly random ideas
column2: connecting dots between misplaced vocal clips and Afro-rock samples
column3: and despite his talents he can be easy to take for granted. M.E.D. had a nice showing on 2004’s Madvillainy
column4: the revered outing from MF DOOM and Madlib
column5: but his output has been sparse from there. Blu has been incredibly prolific
column6: but many of his releases are marred with improper mixing and unfocused rhymes
column7: with as many standouts (Below the Heavens
column8: Her Favorite Colo(u)r) as bricks
column9: like Jesus. and the short-lived ucla. On their own
column10: all of these guys are good but sometimes get overlooked.

column2: the trio put out The Burgundy EP
column3: powered by the fluid single ""Burgundy Whip"". That song re-emerges near the end of Bad Neighbor
column4: but it feels like an afterthought compared with the stronger
column5: more vivid material around it. ""Peroxide""
column6: featuring Dâm-Funk and DJ Rome
column7: resembles ""Planet Rock""-era electro-funk
column8: and the MCs bounce nimbly atop its darting synthetics. ""The Stroll"" flashes a bright
column9: disorienting synth like a flood light
column10: the beat so full of little noises it's like an event itself.

column1: Anderson .Paak
column2: the grit-voiced singer/rapper who featured prominently on Dr. Dre's Compton and who recently dropped his own noteworthy EP
column3: appears almost out of nowhere on Bad Neighbor track ""The Strip""
column4: lending his strained voice to the proceedings. There are a few appearances like that

column6: allowing everyone to thrive on their own terms. On ""Finer Things""
column7: Foreign Exchange frontman Phonte Coleman sings the hook and raps about adult romance. MF DOOM shows up on ""Knock Knock"" to offer his signature disconnected one-liners. Bad Neighbor whizzes by in a blunted haze

column9: but it works well here
column10:
when the stakes are low and the mood is most important.

The Christine and the Queens project is guided by one woman
column4: the French synth-pop auteur Héloïse Letissier. At home she is a known quantity: She capped off a string of EPs and touring gigs with Lykke Li and Woodkid with her debut Chaleur Humaine in June of 2014. But the U.S. release this fall of Humaine
column5: repackaged as a self-titled debut
column6: marks her introduction to the American market: Some of the French lyrics were redone in English
column7: accompanied by a couple of Anglophone bonus tracks. As with the French edition
column8: the record starts with an unequivocal declaration of her arrival. ""I'm a man now
column9: she sings in a bold voice on ""iT""
column10: ""And there's nothing you can do to make me change my mind.""

column1: A few verses later
column2: she offers up a line whose regal
column3: gory quality seems worthy of Lorde or Kanye: ""I'll rule over all my dead impersonations."" Out of context
column4: it sounds like a very 2015 pop move: burying past incarnations of yourself that the public never even witnessed and calling yourself king from the off
column5: fueled by nothing but divine belief in your own selfhood. Letissier has the chops and charisma to pull off this role
column6: too: ""iT"" has gorgeous minimal production—just a sputtering beat
column7: tarnished synth glimmers
column8: and canny employ of sprite-like backing vocals. Her expressive voice leads the lone melody
column9: at first vulnerable and then rasping with defiance.

column1: But it's a feint: Letissier spends the next 11 songs pulling back from this grandstanding (which was inspired by her discarding her feminine identity as a teenager) to explore the nuances of her queer identity and what that means in private and public spheres. On the way
column2: she comes out with some pin-sharp lyrics to rival collaborator Perfume Genius' ""no family is safe when I sashay
column3: full of daring and vulnerable truths. ""Science Fiction"" unravels on spacey burbles that underpin the alienation she and her partner feel when out in public: ""They look at me when I stare at you... In this sea of eyes
column4: every move's a coup."" Letissier reclaims the discrimination she experiences for not passing as a prescribed gender ideal on ""Half Ladies""
column5: which moves between percussive gasps indebted to Michael Jackson and pared-back
column6: angular funk: ""Every insult I hear back/ Darkens into a beauty mark.""

column1: That particular image seems to reference the source of her own liberation. A few years ago
column2: beset by depression
column3: Letissier ran away from college in Paris and crossed the Channel to London
column4: where she was taken under the wing of three Soho drag artists. They heard her humming and encouraged her to make music
column5: so she locked herself away for weeks
column6: garrote-style
column7: as she taught herself to write. Letissier named her act Christine and the Queens in tribute to her saviors
column8: an act that also highlights her knack for self-mythologizing. At the end of Christine and the Queens
column9: there is a second arrival
column10: ""Here""
column11: a work of unbroken tension hooked around disintegrating
column12: crackling beats and an organ's glow. She sings
column13: in French
column14: ""I evolve in living trace.""

column1: The production of Christine and the Queens follows that mystical sense of becoming. Most of the songs are built from tapestries of microbeats that have an organic
column2: sinewy feel
column3: unfolding with the intricate flow of a centipede's spine. She often forms strong rhythms from a surprisingly delicate percussive backbone—""No Harm Is Done"" has a feather-light
column4: trap-indebted beat that sounds as though it was sampled from recordings of magnesium fizzling across water. Tiny shifts in impact or intensity can have a massive effect: The simple beat that hardens halfway through ""Tilted"" adds a new level of confidence to Letissier's tale of a wonky but thriving relationship. It's a constellation of experience
column5: the sense of a body being animated
column6: twitching and jerking into existence. Letissier literally espouses the power of movement on ""Safe and Holy""
column7: but the heavy beat and synth-scapes drown out the effect that flows naturally elsewhere.

column1: Letissier's melodic sensibility is as strong as her subtle percussion. ""Paradis Perdus"" is the work of a real pop scholar
column2: an interpolation of Christophe's 1973 song ""Les Paradis Perdus"" and the chorus of Kanye West's ""Heartless"" that unites their common sense of loss over soft piano and a knocking beat. ""Jonathan""
column3: Letissier's duet with Perfume Genius
column4: confronts a lover whose internalized shame means that their relationship is only acknowledged by night. It's a song of immense grace
column5: the funereal pace guided by exquisite synths and expanding strings. ""Can you walk with me in the daylight?"" Letissier asks
column6: her head held high.

column1: Christine and the Queens is a beautiful
column2: important negotiation of these liminal states at a time when the media is quick to bandy about the term ""post-gender"" as if the hard work is done. Her music is bold and fully formed
column3: but Letissier unpeels the façade of outer confidence to shine a light on the way that queer identity requires constant negotiation
column4: to deal with the world's often unforgiving gaze and the one that can come from within—on ""Safe and Holy""
column5: she admits that her own eyes ""mock and judge"" her. It's empowering
column6: bold
column7: and vulnerable
column8: and made for dancing. Chaleur Humaine translates as ""human warmth""
column9: and the album makes good on that intimacy. You get the sense of Letissier guarding her own precious
column10: burgeoning fire
column11:
and inviting listeners to share in its glow.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22410/homepage_large.cf0d3c31.jpg|Angels & Ghosts|1814.0|Dave Gahan|['Rock'
column3: Dave Gahan has been the predominant vocalist in Depeche Mode. As such
column4: Gahan's voice has only grown stronger over the years—deeper
column5: more controlled
column6: and more iconic. During this time
column7: that voice has mostly been employed in the service of someone else's songs
column8: that person being Depeche Mode co-conspirator and the band's primary songwriter Martin Gore. It only makes sense that at some point—namely
column9: around the time of 2005's Playing the Angel—that Gahan would want a more active role. Outside of the band
column10: he would eventually release two solo albums—2003's Paper Monsters and 2007's Hourglass—and two collaborations with Soulsavers (aka British producer Rich Machin).

column1: Angels & Ghosts is Gahan's second full-length album with Soulsavers. Much like 2012's The Light the Dead See
column2: the record offers an opportunity for Gahan to stretch his legs creatively and shake off some of the baggage that a band with a 35-year history like Depeche Mode invariably has to carry around. In doing so
column3: Gahan and co. largely abandon heavy electronics in favor of something resembling blues rock and gospel-infused Americana
column4: complete with churchy backup singers and quietly shaken tambourines.

column1: The album opens with ""Shine""—a kind of stomping
column2: slide-guitar heavy slow burner in which Gahan imbues a ridiculous line like ""when you look around
column3: it's so profound
column4: what we can do"" with a kind of gravitas that only someone with his particular pipes can pull off
column5: but it still feels like a lightweight version of Depeche Mode's ""I Feel You"". ""You Owe Me"" could be a distant cousin to Chris Isaak's ""Wicked Game""—all midnight hues and romantic yearning—while ""One Thing"" is the kind of piano-driven ballad that you could almost imagine popping up on a Depeche Mode record. ""Just lay down next to me
column6: Gahan sings
column7: ""We can watch those tasteless shows on our TV."" It's the kind of 'no one understands us and it's us against the world forever' track that Gahan has made a career out of perfectly articulating
column8: but in the end the entire thing gets punched in the face by a chorus lyric so hackneyed that one wonder how on earth it actually made it onto the record: ""You just need one thing/ Love.""

column1: As a frontman
column2: Gahan is a marvel of preening and grandstanding
column3: which means that he actually shines on tracks that aren't afraid to get all messianic and pump up the melodrama. In that sense
column4: the album's lead track
column5: ""All of This and Nothing"" (despite also famously being the title of a Psychedelic Furs song and album) is perfect for him. The song is populated by black waters
column6: heavy storms
column7: and ghosts that hover continuously outside of windows
column8: which means it's classic territory for Gahan. ""I'm all of this and nothing/ I'm the dirt beneath your feet/ I'm the sun that rises while you're sleeping/ I'm all you need"" he sings
column9: sounding for the first time like the kind of equally doomed and exalted kind of character that he embodies so well. If there's something decidedly lacking on Angels & Ghosts
column10: it's more of his famously gothy bravado. Gahan clearly has a predilection for casting himself as the tortured sinner (""One hand in my pocket/ One foot in the grave/ Standing here
column11: waiting to be saved"")
column12: but the nine tracks here—packed full of twangy guitars and tastefully deployed string sections—reach for a kind of holy redemption that they don't ever actually earn.

column1: Angels & Ghosts isn't a bad record
column2: but it's frustratingly tepid. Superfans will still find pleasure in hearing Gahan's voice tear through these songs. But at this point
column3: a truly radical departure—or even some kind of insanely catastrophic creative failure—would be more interesting than another selection of songs half-heartedly playing around with tired blues and gospel motifs. One certainly can't fault Gahan for needing his own private creative outlet
column4: but at this point just writing more flatly on-the-nose songs about sin and faith and redemption doesn't sound refreshing or the least bit fun
column5:
but instead like something you've already heard him tackle a million times already.

Rabit (Eric Burton) is from Texas
column2: and though his music has generally maintained a loose dialogue with UK grime
column3: it has also increasingly nurtured its own identity. His early work found an uneasy midpoint between violence and grace: On 2013's Sun Showers EP
column4: misty synths crept on cat feet
column5: surrounded by jabbing
column6: staccato rhythms. This year's Baptizm EP

column1: Communion is definitely not grime
column2: even with the genre's telltale signifiers—bruised 808 kicks
column3: broken-glass and gun-cock samples

column8: Communion feels genuinely unsettling: You emerge even after just a few minutes' worth of the album's unrelenting barrage of beats and palette of sampled shrapnel feeling dazed and punch-drunk. Needless to say

column1: The sullen melodies are studiously minor key
column2: and with the exception of the occasional desolate spoken-word fragment (""The flesh covers the bone""; ""There aren't any people"") there are no vocals
column3: just yelps of distress. In ""Fetal""

column5: between machine-gun rhythms and gibbering voices and a whinnying horse. These juxtapositions offer their own kind of enjoyment
column6: but he's not afraid to fight against pleasure
column7: either: ""Pandemic"" is plodding and heavy-footed
column8: and its climactic machine-gun volley is so intense that it is no fun
column9: but you suspect that's the point.

column1: It's not all brutal
column2: exactly. The opening ""Advent"" features a sad synth melody reminiscent of the Cure's ""A Forest""
column3: and ""Artemis"" toys with tentative vocal samples reminiscent of Laurie Anderson's ""O Superman"". ""Burnerz"" and ""Black Gates"" feel almost like traditional grime tunes
column4: with their concussive kicks and synth stabs
column5: and ""Trapped in This Body"" might be deconstructed drum'n'bass
column6: with pitched-down sirens and beaten-up tech-step framed by radiophonic bleeps. These are welcome respites; if the album has a drawback
column7: it's that the grim consistency of its palette and techniques leads many songs to blur together in your memory. Still
column8: I'm guessing that is by design. Communion plays out like a kind of fever dream
column9:
a delirium of cold sweat and disturbing visions in which there are only brief moments of daylight before you're plunged back into the maelstrom once more.

column3: Idaho—one month after the death of Kurt Cobain. Though this town is 500 miles southeast of Seattle
column4: almost an eight-hour drive
column5: that's not so far in this part of the country. You have your car
column6: and everything is spread out
column7: and you're always ready to cover ground when you need to. So despite the distance Boise could conceivably be considered part of the Pacific Northwest
column8: if you stretch the definition a little bit
column9: and the music scene there
column10: such as it is
column11: has some connections to its larger neighboring cities. There's a Boise band called Built to Spill led by Doug Martsch
column12: who used to be in an indie rock band based in Seattle called Treepeople.

column1: Two of the stories in the Pacific Northwest rock scene in the '80s and early '90s are the ramshackle D.I.Y. scene surrounding K Records and of course grunge
column2: which by this time had gone so far overground it was on its way to becoming a cliché. Martsch's songwriting has some parallels with the wide-eyed and playful perspective of indie pop
column3: but his twee impulses are tempered by his epic guitar work
column4: which is not connected to grunge proper but can be traced to one of the scene's influences
column5: J Mascis of Dinosaur Jr. Having made one album

column7: Built to Spill return to Seattle to record their follow-up
column8: There's Nothing Wrong With Love
column9: the record that would change everything for the band. ""That was the last record when I was able to make music without thinking a lot of people would hear it
column10: Martsch told SPIN in 1999. ""It makes a difference. I'd like to think it doesn't matter
column11: but it does.""

column1: That relative anonymity
column2: free from the nebulous expectations of what eventually became a sizable fan base
column3: gave Martsch license to write his most personal album. There's Nothing Wrong With Love
column4: newly reissued on vinyl after being out of print on the format for almost two decades
column5: has come to define a certain strand of indie rock
column6: leaving a cluster of threads picked up by Modest Mouse
column7: Death Cab for Cutie
column8: and many more. But beyond its influence
column9: it captures a truly original songwriting voice at the exact moment he realized what he had to offer. It's the album as snow globe
column10: a small place where interconnected stories happen and you can get a different perspective on them depending on your vantage point. Built to Spill had some great records ahead of them
column11: but they would never make another album with this level of intimacy.

column1: There's Nothing Wrong With Love finds Martsch on the cusp of true adulthood (his first child was born around the time it was made
column2: and his feelings around that are documented on ""Cleo"")
column3: but the past is close enough where he sees it with tremendous clarity. The songs highlight the tiny feelings and sensations that have no obvious consequences in the moment but somehow stay with you in every detail. And Martsch has a special talent for pinpointing the tossed-off moments that others might connect to. As a kid
column4: I was excited to learn about the constellations— where they were supposed to be
column5: how the dots were connected
column6: the mythology they represented—but I quickly realized the only one I could make out was the Big Dipper. I spent 20-something years with that meaningless thought pinging in my head
column7: and then I heard a song on this album that started with the words ""When I was little someone pointed out to me/ Some constellations but the Big Dipper's all I could see"" (""Big Dipper"") and suddenly this stray private thought became a shared experience
column8: one wrapped inside an ultra-catchy power pop song.

column1: Nuggets like this
column2: borne of Martsch's keen sense of introspection and emotional generosity
column3: are the lifeblood of There's Nothing Wrong With Love. On ""In the Morning"" he explores the difficulty of enjoying the present moment when filled with anxiety about the future (""Today is flat beneath the weight of the next day
column4: next day
column5: next day
column6: next day"") and how instinct takes over in moments of uncertainty. All the album's hyper-specific lyrical details—and there are many—check out. ""Seven Up I touched her thumb
column7: she knew it was me"" (from ""Twin Falls"") might sound impossibly precious from another songwriter

If there is one characteristic that has defined the music of the New Zealand group the Chills over the course of their 35-year
column2: on-and-off
column3: up-and-down existence
column4: it’s their ability to summon a kind of effortless beauty. Their best songs occur in soft focus
column5: the vocals of frontman and sole consistent member Martin Phillipps hushed and controlled
column6: his guitar lines sturdy and gleaming like gold thread. His best melodies arrive as easy a sigh—gliding steadily through the center of ""Satin Doll""
column7: spinning through ""Tied Up in Chain"" between tumbling piano. Where their contemporaries in the New Zealand scene of the early '80s capitalized on shambling charm (the Clean) or loose
column8: looping jangle-pop (the Bats)
column9: the Chills were gentler and—especially as their career progressed—more regal
column10: the corners of their songs filled with almost baroque detail. They feel designed to soundtrack some storybook undersea kingdom
column11: sumptuous and mystic.

column1: This is remarkable
column2: considering the group’s history is shot through with turmoil and darkness. Founding drummer Martyn Bull succumbed to leukemia shortly after recording ""Pink Frost""
column3: the haunting meditation on death for which the group is best known. Forever tipped as the breakout band from the Dunedin indie scene
column4: they cycled through as many as 15 different lineups
column5: releasing an endless string of singles and EPs for New Zealand’s storied Flying Nun label
column6: but always seemed to collapse when they were finally hitting their stride. Case in point: they inked a deal with Warner Bros. in 1990 and scored a modest success with the smart and self-aware ""Heavenly Pop Hit"" from the utterly immaculate Submarine Bells but they failed to capitalize on the momentum. The intervening years delivered more EPs
column7: compilations
column8: and even a box set of rarities
column9: but nothing like actual forward movement
column10: And then there was the darkness surrounding Phillipps himself: After grappling with immobilizing depression in the late-'90s
column11: he turned to heroin
column12: and contracted hepatitis C after sharing a needle with a fellow user who carried the disease.

column1: So
column2: it’s both a surprise and relief to hear Phillipps in full fighting form on the title track from Silver Bullets
column3: the first Chills full-length in 19 years. The song—and the album that contains it—handily erases everything from 1990 forward and seems to pick up exactly where Submarine Bells left off: guitars wreathed in reverb
column4: organs heaving
column5: Phillipps’ voice
column6: as quietly assured as ever—even if what he’s singing is tinged with militance. ""And if it’s true they kill a heinous vampire/ Charged with magic charm/ If forced to fight your evil empire/ We have the means to harm."" Much of Silver Bullets strikes this kind of oppositional stance
column7: Phillipps positioning himself as a kind of kiwi pop Tom Joad
column8: pushing back against larger forces that threaten to swallow the less-fortunate whole. Often
column9: the political is personal: on the roaring ""I Can’t Help You""
column10: Phillipps grapples with the knowledge that he’s done harm to others
column11: working through his feelings as his guitar and a whistling keyboard turn somersaults in the foreground. On the elegiac ""Underwater Wasteland""
column12: he uses environmental destruction as a metaphor for social Darwinism
column13: describing plesiosaurs and sea serpents with a kind of awestruck wonder. The music that surrounds him is rich and whispering: guitars that spiral like paper streamers in a breeze
column14: drums that seem smothered in feathers. Combining delicate grace with ornate detailing is no easy feat
column15: but on Silver Bullets
column16: Phillipps manages it again and again.

column1: But the album is not without its missteps. Phillipps’ songs are most effective when his enemies are faceless and generalized—it’s better suited to the album’s storybook mystique. The leaden bromide ""America Says Hello"" comes off like a conspiracy theorist’s 3 a.m. Facebook rant. Ditto ""Tomboy""
column2: a song about a girl who’s picked on by her classmates whose graceful melody and good intentions are undone by Phillipps’ numbing repetition of the title. And ""Molten Gold""

column4: feels rote compared to the richness that surrounds it.

column1: The album is best when it’s at its broadest

column3: eight-minute ""Pyramids / When the Poor Can Reach the Moon"". It’s the most ambitious song in the group’s entire catalog
column4: and one whose firm grasp of melody and dynamics more than justifies its length. The tension builds for a full five minutes
column5: the rich getting richer and the poor getting smarter
column6: until it arrives at its glorious
column7: sun-drenched conclusion when
column8: instead of violence and chaos
column9: the gates to the mansion are flung open
column10: guitars and pianos sparkle
column11: the oppressed are liberated and
column12: in Phillipps’ words
column13: ""the poor can reach the moon."" The net effect is warm and rousing
column14: speaking to the power of hope in the face of darkness. After three decades of near-misses and dark alleys
column15: Phillipps has finally embraced his role as king of the underdogs. On Silver Bullets
column16:
he fights back the only way he knows how: with beauty.

VHÖL are the ideal modern metal band—they fuse battle-tested forms of metal with impressive arrangements and a progressive fire that traditionalists and revivalists can't match. Their personel is bulletproof—John Cobbett and Sigrid Sheie hail from San Francisco's prog-power masters Hammers of Misfortune
column2: Mike Scheidt is the vocalist and guitar player behind YOB
column3: and Aesop Dekker is the black metal punker from Ludicra (where Cobbett also played) and Agalloch. All four involved have a rare
column4: vital chemistry

column1: One of the strongest tracks on their underrated self-titled debut was ""Arising""
column2: which added a healthy dose of thrash
column3: Thin Lizzy
column4: and Rob Halford to VHÖL's alien version of black metal. Sky continues in this direction

column6: he bends a conventional galloping rhythm just enough to render it strange. ""3 AM"" begins with 30 seconds of straightforward thrash

column1: Sky's real gem

There are big-bottomed rhythms and soloing that climaxes like the volcano George Lynch posed on for Dokken's ""Just Got Lucky"" video. Only metal could make this high-minded absurdity work; it's the intersection of straight-faced practice and boundless joy

Ryan Lee West felt moved to a brief outburst back in August. The Leicester-born
column2: London-based producer who makes music as Rival Consoles tweeted in protest of the ongoing boom of deep house
column3: asking artists to quit contributing to the genre
column4: currently in vogue. ""There's probably enough to last us till 2089
column5: he wrote.

column1: West's ire makes sense
column2: if only because the music he makes as Rival Consoles feels diametrically opposed to the luxuriant
column3: lengthy bath evoked by deep house. West is a musical engineer in the mold of luminaries like Aphex Twin and relative newcomers like Dave Harrington
column4: and the soundscapes he's constructed on his third LP
column5: <i>Howl
column6: are spiky and imposing
column7: too solid to sink into. The music is always shifting
column8: so it's impossible to lose track of time while listening. You're always aware that any given composition is morphing
column9: is in flux. Reams of electronic producers luxuriate in the safety of creating a comfortable atmosphere. But Howl is impossible to ignore
column10: and hard to forget.

column1: That's partly because West so often feels comfortable disrupting his own patterns. ""Afterglow"" seems as if it's going to build on an early synth loop
column2: but what at first seems like the track's foundation turns out to be its foyer: halfway in
column3: and suddenly we're in an entirely new room
column4: one that's louder
column5: brighter
column6: more expansive. Our understanding of his pieces broadens as they move through time
column7: so that once they're nearly over we apprehend the entire structure as if by a drone camera hovering above.

column1: That vivid view is studded with allusions: the title track makes extraordinary reference to trains and tunnels
column2: and at times the dusky track ""Pre"" recalls the snaking sounds of a film projector. West has said that he's a fan of ""sloppy things and rough things happening in music
column3: but even the little blips and isotopes here feel as if they've been cast in concrete
column4: accidents granted purpose. In contrast to the last two Rival Consoles LPs
column5: Howl was largely forged from hardware (as opposed to digital technology)
column6: and the record's analogue origins would be obvious even if you knew nothing about its genesis.

column1: West is a labelmate of Nils Frahm and
column2: this year alone
column3: has toured with Clark and Nosaj Thing. He shares with all three the instincts of a classical composer. Howl's closer
column4: ""Looming""
column5: is a six-and-a-half-minute mini-epic that reflects the depth of emotion that West says he poured into Howl. But the catharsis it induces comes as much from the musician's restraint and sense of composure as anything else. What isn't there is as important as what is.

column1: West's grumbling about deep house might make him seem like a dinosaur. But he doesn't seem bothered by its existence; he's complaining about a surplus
column2: and
column3: like a true progressive
column4: his momentary gripe stands as mere prelude to more concerted action. His music—rocky
column5: spiky
column6: warm
column7:
titanic—drives us to re-evaluate whether referring to someone as a dinosaur might not be quite as pejorative as we thought.

On their 2010 album Blackjazz
column3: the Norwegian jazz/prog collective Shining absorbed metal into their aesthetic
column4: and it seemed to focus them. On earlier records the band
column5: organized around multi-instrumentalist Jørgen Munkeby
column6: were more elusive
column7: but Blackjazz was an album made entirely of jagged shapes
column8: like the irregular
column9: violent architecture of a cliffside. I<span>t feels aggressively assembled
column10: as if its ideas of metal and jazz were less harmonized than magnetized together. The follow-up
column11: 2013’s One One One
column12: reduced them into an atomically unstable industrial rock band. While thrilling
column13: the album could have the remoteness of a formal exercise.

column1: International Blackjazz Society sounds like a compression of these two approaches
column2: but it evolves into something distinct as you listen. Unlike One One One
column3: the songs here don’t simply accelerate until they expire. There’s more space in the arrangements
column4: and the songs expand into the room they’re afforded. Some of this shift can be credited to new drummer Tobias Ørnes Andersen
column5: who plays industrial music with more patience and tension than previous drummer and founding Shining member Torstein Lofthus. ""Thousand Eyes"" feels like stoner metal
column6: of all things; the riff is a little more drunk than the band usually allows. ""House of Warship"" is free jazz
column7: which is actually new territory for Shining; even their freest moments on previous records seemed premeditated
column8: a kind of organized collapse. Whenever Munkeby plays saxophone on International Blackjazz Society the songs sound as if they’re sprouting fractals.

column1: Still
column2: even as the band relaxes into new atmospheres there’s an extreme
column3: ascetic discipline on display. The architecture of their music is modernist
column4: a series of inelastic and inorganic shapes colliding with the velocity of a distant level of ""Tetris"". On International Blackjazz Society’s final track
column5: ""Need""
column6: you can feel this refined performance begin to rupture. It’s as unhinged as it is straightforward; as it acquires mass in the choruses it seems to list off the ground into some new
column7: uncertain gravity. <span>For all the blur and motion of their music
column8:
this hint of deeper chaos might be the album's most exciting moment.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22514/homepage_large.6d15c402.jpg|Karamika|33291.0|Karamika|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ESP Institute']|2015-10-22 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:04:52.363202|"

In the mid-'70s
column2: Brian Eno was so taken with the strange sounds emanating from Dieter Moebius and Hans-Joachim Roedelius's studio in the rural village of Forst—both the duo music they made as Cluster as well as their trio with Michael Rother as Harmonia—that he traveled from England to Germany to record with them. The results of that meeting only came to light in the past few years (it's fully documented on the forthcoming Harmonia box set) but the meeting sprang to my mind while listening to Karamika.

column1: Karamika is a duo of British musician George Thompson (who does numerous remixes as Black Merlin)
column2: and Gordon Pohl
column3: who's one half of Düsseldorf act Musiccargo. At times
column4: their work together evokes the chilly sounds of early-'80s minimal wave and some of John Carpenter's analog synth soundtracks. But the snaking
column5: immersive 12 tracks that comprise their debut often brings to mind the primitive
column6: visceral early electronic music that Cluster themselves made back when they were still known as the woolly
column7: circuit-bending band Kluster.

column1: Karamika's music is reactive in that sense
column2: pulling away from the use of readily available software and computers to revisit an era when these electrical surges weren't so easily tamed and manageable. ""Ton 01"" begins with a slowly undulating sine wave and throb
column3: and when the metronomic drumming enters it brings to mind Florian Schneider and Ralf Hütter's first forays as Kraftwerk. As the track moves along
column4: a noisy guitar appears
column5: reminiscent of the one that worms through Neu!'s ""Hallogallo""
column6: showing where early electronics grappled with rock instrumentation
column7: each pushing the other into strange new realms.

column1: There's nothing especially novel about emulating the likes of Cluster
column2: Kraftwerk
column3: or Neu! in 2015 (nor would it have been back in 2005)
column4: but it's hard to get the parameters right. The exploratory spirit remains intact
column5: but Karamika's resultant tracks feel more focused and they are judicious in adding new layers and noises to the initial framework so that it doesn't all collapse under the weight. More often than not
column6: the deeper you travel into the pieces
column7: the more mesmerizing they become.

column1: A sense of claustrophobia and dread lurks beneath the surface throughout. As ""Ton 04"" moves through its nine minutes
column2: the throbs gather in density until they feel like a migraine. The cavernous clattering on ""Ton 07"" begins as an early experimental piece might. Disembodied voices appear on the album highlight ""Ton 9""
column3: and at the peak of tension a child's laugh comes in
column4: which has a horror-film effect
column5: prickling the skin rather than breaking the tension. In that way
column6: Karamika's homage to their German forefathers forgoes the utopian spirit of some of those albums. Instead
column7: Thompson and Pohl hint at the isolating
column8:
disconnected present.

Despite popular perception
column2: !!! never quite fit with the dance-punk explosion of the early-to-mid-'00s. While an endless procession of angular Gang of Four imitators came and went
column3: !!! carved out a space for themselves as disco true believers
column4: foregoing the calculated dourness of the '80s for the joyous excesses of the decade prior. Few of their peers were releasing epic singles that stretched for almost 10 minutes (2003's now-classic ""Me and Giuliani Down by the School Yard (A True Story)"")
column5: or essentially trolling fans with something as simple as their name (""It's pronounced 'Chk chk chk'
column6: ""Actually
column7: it's any three monosyllabic sounds in rapid succession
column8: etc.). And no other group had a frontman as gleefully irreverent as Nic Offer
column9: who is not opposed to busting out a dutty whine onstage in board shorts and a midriff-baring T-shirt. Making the uncool cool became second nature for !!!
column10: yet another quality that separated them from the pack.

column1: But !!! have repeatedly suffered from bad timing—they're unable to distance themselves from that one
column2: fairly brief moment midway through their career where they found themselves part of something bigger
column3: and that lens distorts the way their music in received. As If
column4: !!!'s sixth studio album
column5: is very much a reaction to that crisis of identity
column6: a mostly successful attempt at re-establishing themselves as the premier suppliers of fun
column7: kinetic
column8: sprawling indie disco.

column1: !!!'s secret weapon has always been their sense of humor—from their beginnings in the late '90s
column2: when Offer basically had the wardrobe of an off-duty American Gladiator
column3: to the tongue-in-cheek career highlight ""Pardon My Freedom"" from their politically-charged second LP Louden Up Now
column4: whose chorus of ""Like I give a fuck about that motherfuckin' shit"" serves as a mini manifesto for !!!'s entire ethos.

column1: There's nothing quite as special as ""Pardon My Freedom"" on As If
column2: but opening track ""All U Writers"" delivers the album's first chuckle amidst it's pounding dance beat: ""I knew I shouldn't have kissed him in a Chevrolet
column3: sings a plaintive female voice
column4: as Offer's distorted and stuttering vocals provide the song's structure. There's immediately a sense that !!! aren't necessarily trying to recreate past greatness but are pushing their sound and style in a new direction. The clearest example of this—and subsequently the best
column5: if strangest
column6: track on the album—is ""Every Little Bit Counts""
column7: a straightforward rock-pop party song that would fit snugly on a Haircut 100 record circa 1983. The track has a big
column8: broad
column9: singalong chorus
column10: a fist-pumping drumbeat and Orange Juice-like jumpy guitars
column11: and it's unlike anything !!! have put forth up to date. ""Freedom! '15"" serves as a spiritual sequel of sorts to Louden Up Now: ""Freedom!/ How's that working for you
column12: baby?"" sings Offer and his band of sarcastic backing singers
column13: condensing the last decade of American political apathy into six minutes of funk.

column1: Speaking of which
column2: As If  leans a little too heavily on the groove in the middle
column3: with moments like ""Funk (I Got This)"" fading into the background
column4: but it's reinvigorated towards the end by the riveting ""Lucy Mongoosey""
column5: which uses another singalong chorus as an anchor
column6: an introspective pause among all the dancing. The final track
column7: ""I Feel So Free (Citation Needed)""
column8: features Offer's slowed-down
column9: slurred vocals narrating the construction of the song itself: “It's quiet around here without a kick drum” he states
column10: before said drum comes into the mix and transforms it into a heady
column11: weirdo
column12: funny
column13: controlled mess
column14: much like !!! themselves. With a little luck
column15: As If will be the turning point !!! are looking for
column16:
the beginning of a new path without the dance-punk baggage they've been toting around for the last decade.

Let's get ""A Thousand Miles"" out of the way. Fourteen years ago
column2: Vanessa Carlton made a very popular song that will follow her around forever. Fair enough; it's very catchy. But times have changed. Can't Vanessa? She recently told CBS News that she ""learned a lot"" since her debut album
column3: ""which is mostly that you don't know anything."" That's as good a place as any to reset
column4: which she does with the refreshingly raw Liberman.

column1: Like the bulk of her recordings
column2: it's still comprised of her honeysuckle voice and piano licks
column3: but Liberman (so named after Carlton's grandfather
column4: one of whose paintings of nudes hangs in her home and served
column5: she says
column6: as a sort of inspiration) either lets those components stand alone or accentuates them with mild indulgences
column7: like blunted brass or hand claps. The bare songwriting is not something you would identify as avant-garde
column8: but Carlton's inclinations are a lot weirder than they used to be. Take the album cover
column9: which with its thick white border and bold black type resembles a Gentlewoman magazine cover. This isn't quite an album of Swiss design-inspired art jams
column10: but maybe it's her version. The single ""Operator"" has Carlton using the huskiness of her voice to sound threatening in a way that makes you wonder what a truly severe Vanessa Carlton album might sound like.

column1: Still
column2: Liberman is excellent on its own. Carlton's voice is the key attraction on songs that register between low-key pop
column3: rock
column4: and folk. Early single ""Blue Pool""
column5: for example
column6: touches on each in a way that feels refreshingly old school
column7: as though pop radio these days was comprised of Fleetwood Mac and the Mamas and the Papas. The song's latter third is given over entirely to arpeggiating keyboard runs in a way you don't notice at first
column8: because it's so atmospheric and catchy. But it's also odd—is this a sketch of a song? An extended outro? What is it doing here?

column1: The album is pockmarked with quirky decisions like this and it's better for it. Were Liberman the creation of a heretofore-unknown artist
column2: it's difficult to imagine an album of such earnestness generating the kind of pre-release interest that would deem it worthy of CBS News. But that's the pickle of early success. The flipside is that it's also harder to imagine fans of punkier singer-songwriters like Angel Olsen or Tobias Jesso Jr. embracing her. She should share a stage with Perfume Genius. They both have beautiful voices and something to say.

column1: For Carlton
column2: that message is a simple
column3: almost sisterly
column4: ""You got this."" ""That's the way it is
column5: love
column6: she sings on ""House of Seven Swords""
column7: breaking the fourth wall with some mild real talk. This is the person I want to hear tell me ""shit happens""; the confidence in her voice is very reassuring. Perhaps that is the source of some of Carlton's magic
column8:
that she herself is delivering the shaman's prayer she sings about on album opener ""Take It Easy"". ""When heaven wraps around you/ And she will/ Take it easy"". Don't mind if I do.
