In the 1960s
column2: French yé-yé pop stars had a particular shtick. They were teenage girls
column3: dressed up in bows and baby doll dresses
column4: singing flirty songs about love and adolescence penned typically by adult male songwriters. France Gall sang of swallowing ""lollipops""
column5: Chantal Kelly sang of telling an older lover she’s only 15
column6: Clothilde was forced to sing bloody fables. When the songs weren’t sexually charged jokes
column7: they were melodramatic pop ballads about youth
column8: from Chantal Goya’s unpredictable heartache to Sylvie Vartan’s simple dance-driven desires.

column1: And then there was Françoise Hardy. She wasn’t quite a black sheep of the genre
column2: but she certainly complicated the formula. The Parisian singer auditioned for Vogue Records at 18 and went on to top charts with her very first release
column3: a 1962 self-titled record now known as Tous Les Garcons Et Les Filles based on its hit song. From there
column4: the infamously timid Hardy became one of the few French pop stars of the era to cross over
column5: jetting from England to France to record
column6: serving as a muse to designers like Yves Saint Laurent
column7: and inspiring Bob Dylan and Mick Jagger.

column1: That debut showcases Hardy at her simplest
column2: wringing rockabilly-tinged pop magic from modest jazz percussion and steel guitar. Hardy wrote most of her own material
column3: setting her far apart from her peers
column4: and on her debut she penned every song but two. Her lyrics would never hew this close to yé-yé traditions again: See the ""whoa-oh-oh"" echoing on tracks like ""Il Est Tout Pour Moi"" and her cover of Bobby Lee Trammell’s ""Oh Oh Chéri"". The title track ""Tous Les Garcons Et Les Filles"" remains an iconic vision of Hardy's aesthetic: frank music for romantic wallflowers. ""They walk in love without fear of tomorrow
column5: she sings in French of the young couples she watches on the street. ""Yes but me
column6: I’m single with a tormented soul
column7: yes but me
column8: I’m single because nobody loves me.""

column1: The five albums that make up Hardy’s reissues are really compilations of four-track
column2: seven-inch singles. Because of this
column3: some of these records feel disjointed
column4: a side effect from compiling songs that weren’t initially made to sit next to each other. Such is the case for her next three records
column5: Le Premiere Bonheur Du Jour
column6: Mon Amie La Rose
column7: and L’Amitié. Still
column8: each has a different story to tell about Hardy’s musical influences at the time. Le Premier Bonheur Du Jour pulls from American girl groups
column9: echoing the Crystals and the Ronettes on ""L’Amour D’Un Garçon""
column10: ""Nous Tous""
column11: and ""On Dit De Lui"". Elsewhere
column12: the record boasts electric organ arrangements on snappy jazz-inspired tracks like ""L’Amour Ne Dure Pas Toujours"" and ""Comment Tant D’Autres"".

column1: On Mon Amie La Rose she explores a Morricone influence that was inchoate on Tous Les Garcons Et Les Filles. ""Mon Amie La Rose""
column2: based on the poem by Cecile Caulker and Jacques Lacome
column3: and ""La Nuit Est Sur La Ville"" are terrifically spooky and cinematic
column4: the latter depicting Hardy wrestling with cheating with a man on a lonely dark night. Elsewhere
column5: she dips her toes in plucky Western country-rock on ""Pas Gentille"" and ""Tu Ne Dis Rien"". But with L’Amitié she zigzags between all these references: She’s the cowgirl guitar-heroine on her cover of ""Non Ce N’est Pas Un Rêve""
column6: a dreamy wall-of-sound pop charmer on ""Le Temps De Souvenirs""
column7: and folk singer on ""L’Amitié"".

column1: No matter her inspiration
column2: Hardy’s music is bound together by her point of view
column3: which is part of what makes her fascinating. Her songwriting is profoundly lonely
column4: frequently insecure. Observers have emphasized Hardy’s anti-social nature as a celebrity
column5: but you can hear it even in her music. Like all introverts
column6: she seems most alone when surrounded by others
column7: her insecurities ricocheting off those around her. On Tous Les Garçon Et Les Filles' ""La Fille Avec Toi"" she reaches out to an ex only to see him with another girl
column8: bemoaning how beautiful she is. ""I dream of losing myself
column9: if only I can lose myself with you
column10: she sings on L’Amitié’s ""Tu Peux Bien"". On Mon Amie La Rose’s underrated star track ""Tu N’As Qu’Un Mot A Dire""
column11: she pines for an old lover
column12: singing the verse in hushed tones like someone hugging the sidelines before rushing desperately to the forefront for the chorus
column13: filled with shrill
column14: swooning violins: ""You just have to say the word and I’ll return
column15: she cries
column16: breathing urgency into a word as simple as ""toi.""

column1: It wasn’t until her fifth record La Maison Où J'Ai Grandi that Hardy grew into a more grown-up
column2: baroque sound
column3: one that matched the depth of her sorrow and its complexities. It was her most well-produced
column4: well-written record to date
column5: cohesive in sound and subject matter. Over harpsichord and Hardy’s own Spanish guitar
column6: she echoes the previous four albums' worth of lip-quivering romantic longing
column7: reflecting on what it means to lose love once you find it
column8: or when it doesn’t live up to your fantasies. On ""Si C’est Ça""
column9: her whispery voice and hushed guitar playing operate on the same frequency. ""Maybe this is the moment I prefer
column10: the moment
column11: despite it all
column12: where everything could suddenly switch
column13: where life could change at last
column14: she sings to a lover who is leaving her on ""Surtout Ne Vous Retournez Pas"". ""So I say nothing."" The girl whose greatest fantasy was once having a hand to hold now wishes to let it go.

column1: What always made Hardy’s music stand out from her yé-yé peers is how it tackled adolescent desire: Hardy was often consumed with romantic extremes. She reveled in chest-clutching longing
column2: but her adorations came from a place entirely her own. Her obsession with love was devoid of older
column3: male sexualization or control
column4: a privilege not many others of her era enjoyed.

column1: Hardy’s songs feel timeless in how they emphasize a universal dream for pure love. Is this music antique in its sound? Surely. In its sentiment? Hardly. Aside from a few anachronisms (""I’m fine with the movies
column2: for rock
column3: the twist and the cha-cha
column4: she sings on her first album’s track ""Je Suis D’Accord"") this is '60s pop devoid of vintage signifiers; nobody goes steady
column5: nobody sings of dying an old maid
column6: there is no cutesy
column7: wink-filled posturing. Sometimes
column8: especially in Hardy's choice to cover male singers
column9: her music feels almost devoid of gender. For a genre so tethered to young women of a certain time period
column10: this is a feat.

column1: On Le Premier Bonheur Du Jour’s quick little track ""Le Sais-Tu?""
column2: Hardy finally sings directly to the object of her affections
column3: but she’s forgotten what she yearned to express. She keeps stopping to sing
column4: ""did you know?"" as if stuttering: ""I so dreaded
column5: did you know
column6: this second
column7: which made me think of the end of the world ... One in which you’re there
column8: holding in your hands without maybe even realizing it: my destiny."" There’s a reason her music crossed so many country and language barriers
column9: and it wasn’t just because she looked like a model and hung out with the Rolling Stones. These songs map a sort of adoration that derives its intensity from youth but lingers with us for the rest of our lives. Not many pop stars sing about that these days. To the joy of romantic loners everywhere
column10:
Françoise Hardy built her career on it.

The sound Dan Friel has created is so uniquely specific
column2: it's easy to oversimplify: distorted nursery-rhyme melodies over cracked drum-machine beats. But dig just a little below the surface and there's a lot more going on. At various points Friel evokes noise
column3: industrial
column4: punk crossed with techno
column5: video games
column6: even jazz. On Life
column7: his fourth full-length
column8: he covers that range more thoroughly than ever
column9: which perhaps explains the album's all-encompassing title. Pretty much his entire musical existence is locked in these grooves.

column1: The title might also refer to the fact that Friel has literally created life—this is the first album he's recorded since his son Wolf was born in 2013. Friel's music has always had childlike qualities
column2: but here he makes that connection explicit. He opens with a sweet
column3: woozy jingle called ""Lullaby (For Wolf)""
column4: following later with the even-more sugary ""Theme""
column5: which could pass for an outtake from Raymond Scott's Soothing Sounds for Baby. The warped
column6: off-speed crunch of ""Sleep Deprivation"" would fit on any Friel album

column1: The rest of Life may not be about kids
column2: but every track contains some simple melodic nugget that any toddler would happily hum along to. The best songs revel in that anthemic innocence
column3: particularly the catchy ""Cirrus""
column4: an immediate earworm on the level of Friel's 2012 insta-classic ""Valedictorian"". The two title tracks are nearly as memorable
column5: though a lot more abrasive

column1: But again
column2: hearing Friel through a single thematic prism is unwise. Some sections in Life sound like hip-hop bathed in nitrogen
column3: or even like lost Bomb Squad beats. Friel's way of taking his melodies off on tangents evokes jazz solos; his obsession with gritty texture gives some pieces
column4: like the clanging ""Bender""
column5: the musique concrète feel of a busy construction site. And for all its machinistic beats
column6: Life can also sound like a sloppy punk band rattling basement walls. That's especially true during ""Jamie (Luvver)""
column7: Friel's wordless cover of a Joanna Gruesome song
column8: which gives the already-energetic original a huge shot of late-night caffeine.

column1: What unites all the styles in Friel's sonic fryer is playful momentum. His main instrument
column2: a Yamaha Portasound keyboard
column3: is literally a toy
column4: and throughout Life it sounds like he's rolling around on the floor. Most of his songs include a constant whirr
column5: and leave you with the echo of that eternal buzz—an effect that I imagine is a mirror of Friel's bleeping brain. Give Life some time and you might find it infecting your synapses

too.

The Promise Ring didn’t write the book on emo; they just named it. One has to assume Nothing Feels Good graces the cover of Andy Greenwald’s genre exegesis
column2: subtitled ""Punk Rock

column4: and Emo""

column1: The world of Nothing Feels Good doesn't pinpoint specific
column2: identifiable emotions. It is a state of being
column3: one where an overactive mind and overstimulated body aren’t exactly at war
column4: but struggling to attain common ground. It’s feeling like your heart is pumping Mountain Dew straight to your brain and your central nervous system can’t be trusted. Davey von Bohlen himself is at a loss for words to describe it: many of Nothing Feels Good’s inscrutable
column5: quotable lyrics are a result of internal miscommunication: ""I got my hands on the one hand
column6: and I don’t know where to put them""
column7: ""I married a room

column9: ""how do I explain your body to the rest of my day?""

column1: The Promise Ring were in their very early twenties in 1997
column2: when Nothing Feels Good was released. They retained the urgency and velocity of their rawer
column3: punkier debut 30° Everywhere (also being reissued)
column4: matching it to the nervous energy of an entire freshman dorm at a midwestern public university on a Friday night. The Promise Ring can barely contain themselves here
column5: their biggest difference from von Bohlen's previous band Cap’n Jazz
column6: who didn't even try. This touch of restraint amidst chaos makes the Promise Ring a quintessential emo band
column7: and it's the rhythm section that sets them apart from proper indie rock. Compare Nothing Feels Good to the predominant bands of the era—Yo La Tengo
column8: Built to Spill
column9: Pavement
column10: and Belle and Sebastian weren’t exactly known for their exuberance
column11: earnest embrace of pop or crisp musicianship
column12: and while Sleater-Kinney and Fugazi were the only two bands with tighter rhythm sections
column13: their concerns were far different than those of the Promise Ring. This was ""college rock"" but with a different set of reference points: Imagine if Fugazi’s ""Do You Like Me?"" were written from the mindset of ""Call Me Maybe"".

column1: And so when skeptics conflate the Promise Ring with more pop-punk oriented peers like Saves the Day or the Get Up Kids
column2: drummer Dan Didier and bassist Scott Beschta (sorely missed on subsequent LPs) are the best counterargument. ""Is This Thing On?"" starts Nothing Feels Good in a full sprint and from that point forward
column3: Didier rarely repeats himself for more than four bars
column4: filling every moment with syncopations
column5: triplet fills
column6: or double-time cymbal crashes. Beschta likewise forgoes indie's preferred thumbing of simple root notes
column7: treating bass as an active melodic and rhythmic participant. It’s not music you can really dance to
column8: but it encourages extroversion and restless giddiness just the same.

column1: The sheer likability of Nothing Feels Good may result in its slightly underrated status—it lacks the mythic aura of Cap’n Jazz
column2: isn’t granted the same hushed reverence of Diary
column3: nor is it as currently influential as American Football

column5: or as expansive and progressive as Clarity. But it's still subtly innovative—the unconventional song structures showed emo could become pop without verses and choruses
column6: while their open-C tunings lent a warm beauty to even the friskiest songs.

column1: More importantly
column2: von Bohlen neutralized early emo's chest-beating with his off-key lisp and playful
column3: poetic language
column4: bridging the abstractions of Tim Kinsella’s Joan of Arc and Owls with Mike Kinsella’s plainspoken mash notes in American Football. Even when ""emotional hardcore"" was presented as an way out of its excessively aggro roots
column5: it was still music meant to be taken very
column6: very seriously—loud and fast and extremely earnest
column7: not entirely concerned with melody
column8: driven by an intense
column9: cloth-rending yearning for spiritual deliverance. The guy at the center of Promise Ring songs is idealistic and well-read
column10: but approachable; we come barrelling into a house party during ""A Broken Tenor"" and all of a sudden
column11: one of the kitchen drinkers is quoting Sylvia Plath’s ""Daddy"".

column2: white and blue (""Red & Blue Jeans"")
column3: whereas on ""B Is for Bethlehem""
column4: those colors represent flesh and blood. Conflating place and people names would soon become one of the emo's most tired cliches—the Promise Ring themselves were already guilty of it by Very Emergency (""Jersey Shore
column5: ""The Deep South""). Still
column6: Nothing Feels Good is charged with the honest enthusiasm you feel upon discovering how much there is out there beyond your hometown
column7: where every new city and every new person seems impossibly fascinating.

column1: With sensations this intense
column2: the potential for burnout is perilously high. Greenwald’s book views it as a foregone conclusion for emo bands and fans alike
column3: and there’s a lot of evidence backing up this view—nearly all of the genre's legendary bands flamed out spectacularly

column5: or evolved into more sedate
column6: wistful projects (including Von Bohlen’s own Maritime). ""I don’t know if anything at all will be alright
column7: von Bohlen sings on the title track
column8: likely referring to the pressures of adulthood. But he was unfortunately prophetic: the Promise Ring would suffer a near-fatal van accident in 1999 and tried to put a happy face on things with the Botox’d power pop of Very Emergency. A year later
column9: von Bohlen was suffering from severe migraines before a fist-sized tumor was discovered and removed from his brain
column10: followed by an insertion of a prosthetic plate in his skull to replace an infected fragment. On the subsequent Wood/Water
column11: the Promise Ring signed to Anti-

column1: Meanwhile

The Promise Ring never did cash in during the subsequent gold rush (the closest they got was von Bohlen’s cameo on Bleed American); at least their place in the history books is literally secure. And rightfully so: from the first moment of ""Is This Thing On?""

column4:
a tireless advocate for the thrills this style of music alone can provide.

What Gun Outfit do sounds secret and borderline ineffable. Like many bands to come out of Olympia since the '80s
column2: they understand their place in rock history: their four LPs bear the mark of musicologists who know their ""Bad Moon Rising"" from their Bad Moon Rising
column3: their ""Kool Thing"" from their ""2 Kool 2 B 4-Gotten""
column4: their ""Some Velvet Morning"" from their Some Velvet Sidewalk. Levitating hooks and an emotional heaviness co-exist in their impressionistic songs
column5: like the light-and-dark glow of a perpetual magic hour. As a singer
column6: Carrie Keith (who also plays guitar) has absorbed as much from Lucinda Williams' pained rasp as from Kim Gordon's spacious monotone. And it's telling that her notably crazy-legged fellow guitarist Dylan Sharp once played in a corrosive hardcore band called Spiritual Warriors
column7: an allusion to the surrealist filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky. The connection underscores the subtle late-capitalist critique in his plainspoken lyrics
column8: a soft-pedalled but deeply felt ideological edge. Gun Outfit are a seemingly modest band who sound alternately chained or freed by their devotion to thinking big-picture

column1: As ever

column4: drifting landscapes

column6: homemade electric sitars—Dream All Over has the blue-sky sensibility of a soul-searching road trip. There's gorgeous outlaw poetry on Keith's imagistic ""Legends of My Own""
column7: a tale of a woman reborn alone in a foreign land. ""When I put my blanket down/ I'm going to dream all over
column8: Keith sings; it's an inspired metaphor for the act of becoming
column9: and the cool composure with which she draws out the line ""I wear a mask but not to hide"" is its own kind of empowerment.

column1: That abstract feminism also comes through on the LP's bare
column2: sun-staring centerpiece ""Angelino"". Keith's symbols of ""a kingdom in ruins"" and ""all of the cowgirls on the losing end"" are more graceful ways of saying ""fuck the patriarchy
column3: but if you listen close to them they bite. Dream All Over's incantatory folk-rock cushions pleas for the systematically oppressed
column4: meditations on apathy
column5: poverty
column6: greed
column7: slavery
column8: death. In the survivalist's love song ""In Orbit""
column9: Sharp sings ""You and I/ Are not the only satellites/ Circling an uninhabitable void/ For our whole lives."" At least they are together.

column1: Gun Outfit's music has gotten slower with each release
column2: an inversion of (or response to) how human life has evolved since their band formed nine years ago. They reject the pace of our times
column3: where everything happens so much. When they do evoke the modern world—like the 3D-printed gun that appears in the lyrics to closer ""Only Ever Over""—there is an ominous
column4: no-future edge to it. They seem to acknowledge the planet is doomed
column5: while drawing a strange relief from facing facts. ""Oh world
column6: what lesson do you teach?"" Sharp sings on the poignant ripper ""Worldly Way"". ""Console yourself with sadness/ Befriend your misery."" It made me think of an essay by the poet Melissa Broder
column7: in which she explores the idea that depression is the over-evolution of the mind.

column1: Perhaps this is why Gun Outfit—a band that will validate your pain as much as it will comfort you—still has such a fervent cult following underground. Punks love Gun Outfit because punks are inherently a little shattered. It's easy to carry a heavy heart when you live in a state of constant confrontation
column2: when ""anxiety's your default
column3: as Sharp tosses off on the relatively upbeat ""Gotta Wanna"". Gun Outfit understands what it is to feel unsettled
column4: to need some calming. On ""Only Ever Over""
column5: after making the grand
column6: dour
column7: and quietly hilarious assertion that rock'n'roll and literature are dead
column8: Sharp sings: ""Cup a little coal/ Try to make it glow/ We're going to have a fire before we go.""

column1: In a recent interview
column2: Sharp gave one of the best definitions of punk that you're likely to hear this year—that it's broadly ""about being humble and resisting the illusion that everything's fine."" In this framework
column3: Gun Outfit fit as logically alongside folk tradition as Sonic Youth

column6: which should have made Gun Outfit as popular as contemporaries like Kurt Vile or Angel Olsen. The comparison now feels more spiritual

column8: filmmakers
column9: bands
column10: labels

column12:
and create a universe for it to exist in.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22137/homepage_large.832e17e1.jpg|American Tragic|30961.0|Wax Idols|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Collect']|2015-10-20 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:04:58.755563|"

As the frontperson and creative force behind Wax Idols
column2: Hether Fortune has cultivated an aesthetic of icy cool—punk rock bravura shrouded in multiple layers of gothy frost. The last Wax Idols record—2013’s sophomore effort Discipline + Desire—was an exercise in sustained tension informed
column3: at least in part
column4: by her training as a professional dominatrix. As a result
column5: the record played like an extended tease—tantalizing the listener with heavily eyelinered pop stylings but still keeping things at a cool remove
column6: always stopping just shy of delivering the kind of massive hook that could have potentially knocked everyone out of their collective creepers.

column1: In contrast
column2: American Tragic is a much more empathetic affair
column3: fully stocked with songs that bear the trappings of gloomy post-punk and the appropriate gray shades of goth
column4: but wraps them around words that articulate real human feelings. While previous Wax Idols tracks sometimes felt like excuses to show off an aesthetic
column5: Tragic manages to unpack a number of complicated ideas
column6: particularly about how much our personal identities are defined by our relationships. And while it would be easy to attach a personal narrative to songs like ""Goodbye Baby"" and ""Lonely You"" (based on the fact that Fortune reportedly went through an ugly divorce prior to making this record)
column7: the album strives to be much more than a classic breakup record. In the end
column8: it’s a record about getting over.

column1: The album opens with ""A Violent Transgression""—a bit of reverby melodrama in which Fortune sets the tone for the record by singing ""This is an absolute negativity/ A sudden
column2: irrevocable plunge"" before ultimately concluding that ""Desire/ It’s violent."" The violence of wanting—both wanting in and ultimately desperately wanting out of a relationship—lies at the heart of American Tragic. The most compelling tracks are those that deal with the queasy malaise of missing something you know is ultimately bad for you. On the glorious ""Lonely You""—a bit of Anglophilic guitar pop that sounds like some long-lost ""120 Minutes""-worthy single that never was—Fortune pauses to pine for a lover that is better left in the dust. ""It was a sorry gilded cage/ That bound our hearts together
column3: she laments
column4: ""Now I just want to push the weight of you away forever."" Elsewhere
column5: on ""Goodbye Baby"" the notion of a collapsing romance is both devastating and empowering: ""I’m not wasting time/ I’m taking my heart back/ I’m taking what’s mine.""

column1: If Fortune sounds newly empowered here it’s for good reason. American Tragic is
column2: in every way
column3: a very personal missive. She wrote and recorded everything herself (except the drums
column4: played by Rachel Travers) and the collection unspools like a clever synthesis of dark new wave and late-'80s post-punk without ever sounding too much like an obvious pastiche of either. ""At Any Moment"" approaches Sky Ferreira levels of mainstream pop accessibility
column5: while ""Deborah"" gives a twist on the classic doomed heroine ode (""Had you pegged for a gay boy but you were just a playboy"") and wraps it up in Cure-like guitar lines and a sprinkling of drum machine handclaps. On the other hand
column6: ""Severely Yours""
column7: with its references to sexual power dynamics and submission (""You can be the Marquis tonight"")
column8: is a little too on the nose for someone who has already mined this kind of territory so thoroughly in the past (and there should be a moratorium on non-ironic references to crucifixion and martyrdom for any kind of goth-approved record that isn’t actually Pretty Hate Machine).

column1: Mostly though
column2: Tragic avoids living up to its namesake by sidestepping cliché and never overstaying its welcome. At a relatively brief nine tracks
column3: the record is a perfectly paced blast of dark pop that deftly reflects Fortune’s growing prowess as a songwriter—here offering everything from slow burn dirges on romantic grief to perfectly executed synth jams about emotional freedom. As a result
column4: it’s not a surprise that she increasingly draws comparisons to women like Chrissie Hynde and Siouxsie Sioux—powerful forces who knew how to strike a perfect balance between authority and vulnerability. By opening up and shedding some of her icy veneer on American Tragic
column5:
Fortune places herself in very good company.

As John Carpenter began to lose interest in making films
column2: he entered into an unexpected renaissance as one of the most influential icons of the synthesizer age. Carpenter himself will tell you how accidental that status is: He only began composing and recording the scores to his films—starting with his first one
column3: 1974’s Dark Star—in order to avoid having to pay someone else to do it. His use of electronic instruments
column4: even his signature minimalist style—all of it sprang from budgetary concerns.

column1: But Carpenter’s scores—specifically the ones for Halloween and The Fog—developed a cult following among synth geeks
column2: and this burgeoning fan base has inspired him to try his hand at making music without a movie to compose it for. Encouraged by his musician son and his discovery of modern digital recording software
column3: he released his first solo album
column4: Lost Themes
column5: earlier this year. Although the tracks are smoothed out by bland Logic plugins
column6: it was a pretty decent evocation of his soundtrack work.

column1: If Lost Themes provided an opportunity to reflect on Carpenter’s influence on several generations of electronic musicians
column2: the selection of remixes by other artists tacked on as bonus tracks makes that influence explicit. Now
column3: Sacred Bones has fleshed out the set out with a couple more tracks and Lost Themes Remixed stands as a companion volume to the original record.

column1: Remix albums are tricky things
column2: and the ones that fail (and most of them do) do so for the same few reasons: too many stylistically disparate remixers
column3: too much reverence for the the source material
column4: remixers who are clearly in it for the easy paycheck. Lost Themes Remixed avoids all three. Carpenter’s status seems to have inspired the nine remixers to bring their A game
column5: and Sacred Bones selected committed experimentalists like Prurient
column6: Zola Jesus
column7: and Blanck Mass (aka Fuck Buttons’ Benjamin John Power) who wouldn’t play too nice with Carpenter’s recordings.

column1: Stylistically
column2: pretty much any artist who’s going to want to remix John Carpenter is going to have a few things in common
column3: including a pervasive gloominess and an affection for throbbing
column4: single-note bass lines played on analog synthesizers. As a result
column5: LTR manages to hold together as a unified stylistic statement in a way that isn’t common for remix collections.

column1: Despite the project’s singular focus
column2: LTR doesn’t just reflect Carpenter’s influence on contemporary musicians
column3: but the range of artists that he’s inspired. Prurient transforms Carpenter’s New Age-leaning ""Purgatory"" into a harsh
column4: icy soundscape. The Blanck Mass reworking of ""Fallen"" sounds like slasher-movie music from some grimy
column5: glitched-up cyberpunk future. Zola Jesus and Dean Hurley reconfigure Lost Themes’ most classically Carpenteresque track ""Night"" into vocal house for vampires.

column1: Interestingly
column2: some of the remixers seem to be correcting Lost Themes’ deviations from Carpenter’s signature formula. In its original form
column3: ""Abyss"" highlights both Carpenter’s knack for building complex arrangements out of deceptively simple parts and his weakness for really corny synth patches. Foetus mastermind J.G. Thirlwell swaps them out for the kind of assaultive analog sounds that set the tense mood of Carpenter’s early films (and which themselves were considered corny at the time). One one hand there’s something offensive about the idea of somebody trying to fix an artist’s new work by making it sound more like his old stuff. On the other hand
column4:
I have to admit I like the remix more.

For all the fervor that's supposed to define its spirit
column3: black metal essentially amounts to a set of affectations bundled together into a genre. This is especially apparent when artists outside of Scandinavia adopt hallmark signifiers like facepaint
column4: illegible band logos that look like cobwebs
column5: Satanism
column6: ratty production values
column7: and a harsh
column8: staticky brand of guitar distortion that sounds like static. Not unlike the way rappers across the globe aspire to a constellation of mannerisms that first coalesced in the Bronx
column9: today's black metal artists
column10: regardless of where they're from
column11: mold themselves after an attitude that blossomed within a distinctly Nordic headspace during the genre's early-'90s Second Wave.

column1: Still
column2: it comes as something of a surprise that Austin Lunn of the U.S.-based solo act Panopticon harbors such an open fascination with vague
column3: mythical notions of ""the North."" His last album was titled Roads to the North
column4: this new album Autumn Eternal includes a track titled ""Into the North Woods""
column5: and several Panopticon releases feature wintry
column6: foreboding landscapes as cover art that will immediately strike a chord with aficionados. But the ""North"" that Lunn invokes is actually his adoptive home of Minnesota. And
column7: though the multi-instrumentalist has made a personal principle out of staying reclusive
column8: his isolation shouldn't be mistaken for the misanthropic fury that has driven black metal's most notorious antiheroes.

column1: As Autumn Eternal
column2: Panopticon's seventh full-length
column3: again makes clear
column4: Lunn is an artist capable of appropriating core aesthetics from a number of genres while simultaneously honoring them—a balance that requires no small measure of dexterity. Lunn's manifesto-like notes on Bandcamp betray a sensitive heart that he wears on his sleeve. Clearly
column5: Panopticon's music isn't motivated by hate or nihilism
column6: and one can easily imagine a Henry David Thoreau-like figure retreating to the woods to contemplate personal
column7: spiritual
column8: and environmental concerns while Bon Iver's Justin Vernon nurses his love wounds in the cabin next door. More importantly
column9: Lunn's work lacks the creepy jingoism that some of his Nordic peers have embraced on the slippery slope to Nazi/white supremacist sympathies. The bands that have flirted with ugly racial undertones have
column10: of course
column11: enjoyed the twin benefits of titillating fans and repulsing detractors
column12: cultivating an aura of danger while hiding safely behind suggestion.

column1: Lunn has no need for such coyness because his heart is in an entirely different place. To be fair
column2: it's not like you can understand what he's singing about. And whether or not his intentions truly give this music a more humanistic vibe than other black metal fare is debatable. But his musical agility certainly does set Panopticon apart
column3: Autumn Eternal in particular. As he has in the past
column4: Lunn infuses atmospheric black metal and European melodic/symphonic death metal with prog rock
column5: post rock and
column6: perhaps most audaciously
column7: bluegrass. On paper
column8: those combinations reek of calculation
column9: but Lunn has long proven his ability to blend them into a seamless
column10: irony-free sound
column11: a sound he continues to forge ahead with on Autumn Eternal. Black metal bands have been paying homage to Viking folk tradition for years now
column12: but the results have often been laughable. When Lunn incorporates acoustic roots expressions from the hills of Kentucky
column13: it comes off neither as an academic exercise nor as an attempt to parody his overseas counterparts.

column1: In fact
column2: there's no denying the earnestness of Autumn Eternal opener ""Tamarack's Gold Returns""
column3: which prominently features violin work by Johan Becker of Chicago's Austaras alongside Lunn's own dobro playing. Where artists following the metal playbook would have fashioned the tune as a one-minute intro
column4: Lunn and Becker go on for a full three minutes-plus before the music gives way to a minutes' worth of a found-sound ambient recording of Lunn spending time in nature. After that
column5: a hail of ornate
column6: baroque-style metal kicks in with lead guitars wailing dramatically over double bass drum rolls before Lunn makes his vocal entrance. Piercing but also bottom-heavy
column7: Lunn's voice emanates brute animal power. He also allows for long instrumental sections where he refrains from singing
column8: which only highlights its impact when he starts to howl.

column1: Autumn Eternal concludes the trilogy that Lunn started with 2012's Kentucky and continued with Roads to the North. Listeners who have followed Panopticon since that point or before will no doubt quibble over whether he's gone too far—or maybe not far enough—with the stylistic variety this time. Other than the myriad twists and turns on the epic ""Sleep to the Sound of the Waves Crashing""
column2: Lunn generally approaches the new material as if he's streamlining his approach rather than going for more audacious or pointed ways to combine his influences. During one of the blast-beat sections on ""Waves Crashing""
column3: the mix suddenly strips down to the point where it feels like you're listening to the drums from inside the unflattering acoustics of a rehearsal space while the guitarist tests a new reverb pedal from the adjacent room. Becker's violin on the song switches gears from a rustic Scottish/Irish vibe to film score melodrama. ""Pale Ghosts""
column4: meanwhile
column5: finds a space for Mono-esque shoegaze within the DNA of furious black metal riffing before the song takes flight into a dreamy passage anchored by a melancholic guitar arpeggio.

column1: Lunn has a way of making these and other elements sound perfectly at home with one another. In truth
column2: nothing on Autumn Eternal jumps out as incongruous
column3: which suggests that Lunn is simply expanding—not trying to radically alter—the black metal formula. Still
column4: by renouncing its obligatory celebration of malice
column5: Panopticon gives the form a much-needed makeover
column6: and with Autumn Eternal
column7:
Austin Lunn further uncovers musical potential that's long been overshadowed by too much bad-boy posturing.

Joanna Newsom's Divers is an album about a profound love
column2: but it hardly features any love songs. The singer/songwriter recently explained to Uncut that her marriage in 2013 had invited death into her life
column3: ""because there is someone you can't bear to lose

column6: and then that death contains love inside of it."" There is only one domestic vignette on the record
column7: towards the end of ""Leaving the City""

column9: though
column10: her high dims: ""The spirit bends beneath knowing it must end."" 2010's Have One on Me traced the death of a relationship as Newsom tried and failed to defeat a proud man's human nature. On Divers
column11: she attempts to defeat time to stave off death.

column1: To bear the weight of its subject
column2: Divers fits to scale
column3: ornate and roaming after the intimacies of Have One on Me. The arrangements—tackled by Newsom along with eight different musicians
column4: including Nico Muhly
column5: Ryan Francesconi

column9: jaunty blues

column12: acoustic arrangements of ""The Things I Say"" and ""Same Old Man""
column13: the lilting harp and piano of the title track casts her lover as a deep sea diver and measures the distance between them
column14: ""how the infinite divides."" The meticulous internal rhymes in the chorus of ""Leaving the City"" contract against the tug of her harp
column15: a cascade of tiny parts that form a huge
column16: billowing whole
column17: like tiny bones in a vast wingspan. ""The longer you live
column18: the higher the rent
column19: she sings inside the frenzy.

column1: Divers makes a landscape out of this abstract fear of loss. On the courtly ""Anecdotes"" and ""Waltz of the 101st Lightborne""
column2: she is part of a battle fought by birds to try and wrest control of time. ""You Will Not Take My Heart Alive"" is the most Ren Fair piece here
column3: on which Newsom contemplates ascension to some transcendent plane
column4: ""[severing] all strings to everyone and everything."" Its sister song ""A Pin-Light Bent"" descends sadly back towards reason and reconciliation of her unsuccessful quest to outrun time. ""In our lives is a common sense/ That relies on the common fence/ That divides and attends
column5: she sings with palpable mourning
column6: accepting that her life
column7: ""until the time is spent
column8: is a pin-light
column9: bent."" Where this kind of cosmic existentialism could come off like a stoner marveling at the moon
column10: Newsom pulls it off with balance of poetry and reason. Her fantastical world is sometimes hard to get your head around
column11: but it brings surreal
column12: sometimes sci-fi delight to a record that's otherwise often lyrically despairing.

column1: Where Newsom's second and third records each overhauled what came before
column2: Divers is a refinement that draws on elements of each of its predecessors. The shapes of her records often get misinterpreted as concepts themselves
column3: rather than the sign of a writer attuned to her work's needs. Ys from 2006 was the five-song suite; Have One on Me from 2010
column4: the three-disc opus. On its surface Divers is more conventional
column5: a single disc where nine of its 11 songs are under six minutes long
column6: but it also happens to be a wild
column7: genuine concept album. The final song
column8: ""Time
column9: As a Symptom""
column10: ends with Newsom in raptures
column11: commanding white stars
column12: birds
column13: and ships to ""transcend!"" On the very last burst
column14: she clips the word to ""trans—"". The first word on opener ""Anecdotes"" is ""sending."" It is a perfect loop.

column1: Most artists on their fourth album settle into atrophy
column2: or at least comfort
column3: Newsom delivers such complex
column4: nuanced music

column6: that she is only her own yardstick. (In a recent interview about Divers
column7: David Longstreth cited The Milk-Eyed Mender as one of the reasons he quit college: ""[What] am I doing here if someone is already out there making music like this
column8: on this level?"") Her consummate craft is a given; what surprises every time is her ceaselessly renewing sensitivity for life's vicissitudes and the fantastic ways she finds to express them. Divers is not a puzzle to crack

column10: the way it's both irrational and very real. Nothing will stem the fear of a loved one's death
column11: which western culture does little to prepare us for until the very end

column13: Newsom emerges straighter-spined
column14:
and invites you to stand alongside her.

In many ways

column4: pyrotechnics

column8: Oxygène

column10: arpeggio-laced fantasias

column12: but they often veered dangerously close to kitsch.

column1: The French musician's last new album was in 2007
column2: but now he returns
column3: borrowing a page from Giorgio Moroder's playbook
column4: with an album clearly designed to introduce him to a new generation. There are 16 songs on Electronica 1 and 15 collaborators (""Automatic""
column5: a co-production with Yazoo's Vince Clarke

column1: Fellow synth maestro John Carpenter represents the electronic old school along with Anderson and whatever surviving members of Tangerine Dream are now using the name. The classical pianist Lang Lang lends a little high-culture gravitas
column2: and Pete Townshend is here for some reason. Then

column1: But this diversity presents our first problem. Because unless you approach Electronica 1 as a collection of unrelated songs designed to be cherry-picked for playlists—and given the generic title
column2: maybe that's the point—there's little to hold it together. In the first three songs we're taken from buzzing
column3: high-energy techno-pop with Boys Noize
column4: a billowing schaffel number with M83
column5: and a weird New Order-goes-New Age pastiche with Air
column6: and it never gets more coherent than that
column7: unless you count Jarre slathering filters and bright
column8: buzzing synths on everything like so much Cool-Whip as a common denominator.

column1: And that brings us to our second problem: apart from a few songs—the moody ""Automatic""
column2: with Vince Clarke
column3: and maybe the goth-leaning Gesaffelstein track—the music just isn't very good. ""Suns Have Gone"" is an anodyne electro-house bouncer featuring a mopey Moby. The Tangerine Dream tune features some nice
column4: pinging synths
column5: but there are literally dozens
column6: if not scores
column7: of Tangerine Dream records you'd be advised to reach for first. ""Rely on Me"" saps Laurie Anderson's voice of its arch

column1: Maybe the song that makes the most sense is the Armin van Buuren collaboration ""Stardust""
column2: and that's because the trance icon is most like Jarre himself in his fondness for whooshing effects
column3: gleaming synths
column4: and big
column5: emotional-button-pushing chord changes. Of all contemporary electronic styles

column8:
Electronica 1 is mostly a matter of superimposing one style upon another—sort of like tracing shapes on the pyramids with lasers.

Few albums of the last five years provided as profound a feeling of escape as Olga Bell’s breakthrough album Krai. For the Brooklyn-based composer and electronic musician
column2: the effect of its process was the opposite: The piece
column3: meant as a ""concert"" work and funded by a grant from the American Composers Forum
column4: was her way of re-accessing her earliest memories as a young child in Moscow (she moved from there to Alaska when she was seven)
column5: as well as exploring the remotest corners of her ancestral land through extensive research. The fruits of her labor are near-uncharacterizable: Bell melds Russian folk melodies with pop
column6: traditional Eastern European forms with jagged
column7: prog-rock onslaughts
column8: and integrates non-Western vocal styles—from Altai-style throat singing to throaty
column9: piquant harmonies recalling the 4AD tapes of the Bulgarian State & Television Female Vocal Choir.

column1: By embracing a musical world that feels more in line with her present—and self-consciously down to earth—her new five-song EP
column2: Incitation
column3: provides something more immediately parsable than Krai. Like her 2011 full-length Diamonite

column5: Bell is not wrestling with demented mirror reflections of herself; the busy and tangled vocal counterpoint is gone. The digital instruments act as extensions of her strong solo voice in the center of the mix—the pointillistic MIDI synth figurations (think Glasser) on the periphery
column6: the booming electroacoustic percussion and subdued bass. Incitation has an economy of purpose and more serious bent than her previous electronic work
column7: in which Bell made a strong break from her years training as a concert classical pianist and paid tribute—in ecstatic
column8: self-aware or outright jokey tones—to her new life as a composer and performer in New York City.

column1: Instead of rushing to keep in time with skittery
column2: double-time drum machines
column3: Bell aims for the austere on this EP
column4: embracing the melismatic melodies and damaged electronic architecture favored by Björk and so many after her. The richly textured drum sampling is the most modern element
column5: indebted to artists like FKA twigs who have drawn threads from R&B toward IDM and other realms of the avant-garde.

column1: The lyrics are epigrammatic
column2: and often solemn: They seem to address either her narrator’s self-doubt
column3: or moments of impasse with a lover. In any case
column4: some other soul or specter is always at play as an antagonist
column5: even if it seems like it’s just Bell moving outside herself. In ""Rubbernecker""
column6: the simple repeating piano riff forms an eccentric rhythmic relationship with the drum loop
column7: perfectly underscoring Bell’s fraught diary entry of impressions from a recent national fly-over (the refrain: ""My soul
column8: how hard you're driving/ Get along/ Watch your own road""). Likewise
column9: on ""Goalie""
column10: a synth evoking woodblocks hammers nervously away
column11: as gutted
column12: uneven drum beats pull in and out at random. Bell’s melodies come through with pealing clarity
column13: but her emotions seem harder to pin down: ""For all the tiny muscles in your hand
column14: you don’t shake like I thought you would.""

column1: If Krai was on the verge of being irreducibly complex
column2: Incitation risks cutting to the chase too hastily. The songs make an impression only after several run-throughs
column3: and the appeal of some (the title track and ""Pounder I""
column4: especially) waxes and wanes across their duration
column5: sometimes feeling too risk-averse. It feels good to be drawn closer by Bell—to be trusted—but one can’t help but wish for some more complications to the narrative. The music is comfortable
column6:
hinting in plenty of promising directions but hesitating from going all the way toward them.

Batida
column2: the umbrella term for the variant strains of dance music coming from the ghettos perched in the hills surrounding Lisbon proper
column3: roughly translates to ""my beat"" in Portuguese. As DJ Marfox
column4: the scene's unofficial current figurehead
column5: explained earlier this year
column6: it's also ""the same word for when your heart beats when you have a car crash."" It's perfect sensory context for the heavily percussive polyrhythms streaming from these isolated projects
column7: mostly filled with emigrants from Angola
column8: São Tomé E Príncipe
column9: and other former Portuguese colonies: jarring
column10: frantic
column11: but alive.

column1: But for years
column2: there was no platform for batida producers to release any of this stuff; it existed communally—in the Quinta do Mocho and Quinta da Vitória and other remote housing projects
column3: built hastily after Portugal's 1974 revolution brought a sea of immigrants from former colonies to the crowded city—or not at all. Then came Príncipe Discos
column4: a tight-knit local label fiercely devoted to ""100% real contemporary dance music coming out of this city
column5: its suburbs
column6: projects and slums."" Since their first release in 2011
column7: DJ Marfox's Eu Sei Quem Sou EP (or ""I Know Who I Am"")

column9: community-driven sounds.

column1: The label's latest is Alma Do Meu Pai
column2: a six-track EP from DJ Firmeza
column3: a producer and DJ born in Portugal but of Angolan descent. At 20
column4: he is one of the batida scene's younger members
column5: but his first solo release on the label is refined and mature. Within the Príncipe catalog
column6: Firmeza is more of a minimalist than peers like DJ Nigga Fox. Melody is almost never a factor on Alma Do Meu Pai
column7: which translates to ""Soul of My Father"" in honor of his recently deceased dad. His focus is percussion above all else—sparse
column8: efficient
column9: streamlined. Closing track ""Suposto"" evokes a soca rhythm whittled down and deconstructed; a lilting flute traipses through the remains
column10: head-faking towards melody before it becomes a percussive element itself. You don't see it coming.

column1: Most batida tracks are short
column2: two-minute bursts
column3: suited for dancers' wandering attention spans. But the title track ""Alma Do Meu Pai"" clocks in at over six minutes
column4: churning and lurching at a breathless 143 BPM. At a glance
column5: it's repetitive; it's easy to let it all blur together and submit to its current. But with focus
column6: you notice subtle deviations in rhythm
column7: the layers
column8: the way the percussive components move in connection with one another. But instead of cold metallics
column9: this stuff feels warm
column10: organic
column11: very much human
column12: as though each element of a track is part of a larger conversation.

column1: It's tempting to explore Alma Do Meu Pai in parallel with underground dance genres like footwork or grime. The movements function in socially similar ways
column2: forging stunningly unique sounds and dances from urban tensions. But batida is different. As Pedro Gomes
column3: one of Príncipe's four label heads
column4: emphasized: ""This is not techno
column5: this is not house
column6: this is not dubstep
column7: this is not grime—this is this
column8: it's not anything else
column9: so if you want this... present this for what it is."" Alma Do Meu Pai
column10: then
column11: is a calm
column12: strange
column13: and deceptively simple study in what can be wrung out of rhythm. It is music for dancing
column14: and for contemplation. And though it is not an explicitly political record
column15: the fact that we are hearing it at all
column16: from the remote projects of Lisbon the city itself forgot
column17:
is a political act in itself.

Cult Leader’s Useless Animal EP from last year included a cover of Mark Kozelek & Desertshore’s ""You Are Not My Blood""—which wouldn’t be all that remarkable if Cult Leader wasn’t a metallic hardcore band. With that cover

column6: minimalist guitar

Over the last decade
column2: Beach House have been remarkably consistent: at regular intervals
column3: they put an immaculate new record into the world
column4: and each tends to satisfy the same need. Until now
column5: their pace of releases has indicated a grasp of the spot their music held in listeners’ hearts; the world that Alex Scally and Victoria Legrand build on their records is a place we want to revisit
column6: but the spaces in between records has felt essential to that magic. They are in their own way a theatrical band
column7: and what’s more theatrical than a well-placed pause?

column1: Which all makes the appearance of Thank Your Lucky Stars
column2: the band’s second full-length in as many months
column3: surprising. Depression Cherry is still very much in view
column4: and as fans
column5: it feels a bit like the cast to a hit show suddenly reappearing for one more encore after the house lights have switched on and we were filing out. Thank Your’s nine songs were recorded at the same time as Depression Cherry
column6: and they do have a slightly darker edge: Legrand said that the album was more ""political"" in nature and that they felt the need for these songs to exist on their own
column7: separate from the long-lens telegraphing of the typical album release cycle.

column1: Their sound feels purposefully smaller
column2: tamping down the reverb that made Teen Dream
column3: Bloom
column4: and Depression Cherry feel like they were recorded in great stone cathedrals. You can hear them experimenting more with ""off"" notes in their otherwise-immaculate arrangements. On ""Somewhere Tonight""
column5: Legrand lets a sour note sneak into one of her organ runs
column6: and ""One Thing"" opens with a heavy cloud of electric guitar that feels more tethered to snaking cables and rattling amps than usual. Spiritually
column7: the album feels closer to the mood the duo cultivated before they signed to Sub Pop: These songs feel pneumatic
column8: dusty
column9: like they are pulling a blanket around themselves in a heatless attic to ward off a threatening chill.

column1: The mood is also bleaker in spots
column2: as if joy and comfort had vanished from the songs along with the reverb. ""All Your Yeahs"" is closer to the midnight sulk of Johnny Jewel and Chromatics than their usual open-air romanticism. And ""Elegy to the Void""
column3: the album’s clear standout
column4: might be the most death-obsessed Beach House have ever been: The organ processional that wells up in the song’s intro has a funereal tinge
column5: while Legrand sings darkly of ""Sons and daughters/ Bending at the altar/ Disappearing in the mirror."" The song offers a series of gorgeous images—a ""black clock
column6: looming distant"" and ""freckle-faced young virgin""—as it surges into a slow-motion burst
column7: Scally’s normally crystalline guitar breaking apart like a DNA strand uncoupling.

column1: But Thank Your is still undeniably a Beach House album
column2: a familiar mix of warm tones and chilly sentiments. With the imprint still fading on Depression
column3: Thank Your’s impact is undeniably dulled
column4: causing a strange ""too much of a good thing"" problem. You start noticing surface similarities that you wouldn’t pay attention to otherwise: Play the arpeggiated keyboard figure that opens this album’s ""Common Girl"" next to Bloom’s ""On the Sea""
column5: for instance. Their music is built on echoes: even their self-titled debut felt like covers of chansons you didn’t remember. Timing isn’t everything
column6: of course
column7: and Thank Your Lucky Stars
column8: as surprising a gesture of generosity as it is
column9: is still welcome. But Legrand and Scally
column10: who know their way around a stage
column11:
would do well to gracefully exit left for a while and give this run of music some time to sink in.

Claire L. Evans is as fascinated by and enamored with ideas of ""the future"" as she is skeptical and critical of them. She's an ardent ""science fiction apologist
column2: a busy writer
column3: an editor at VICE's science and tech journal Motherboard
column4: and a co-creator of 5 Every Day
column5: an app that provides users with ""a no-nonsense events calendar and exploration engine"" in and around Los Angeles. She's smart as hell
column6: bursting with talent
column7: and pretty damn cool
column8: to put it plainly
column9: someone you can't help but pay attention to when she speaks. Her Twitter is patently great.

column1: Evans is also a member of YACHT
column2: an erstwhile solo project started by Jonah Bechtolt in 2002. Over the course of two albums for James Murphy's DFA label
column3: 2009's See Mystery Lights and 2011's Shangri-La
column4: the pair shared vocal and songwriting duties
column5: crafting disco-touched pop songs exploring cosmic anomalies
column6: hallucinatory excursions
column7: and utopian ideals. It never mattered much that the basis of their sound started as an homage to LCD Soundsystem—hell
column8: even the music video to ""Summer Song"" was an homage—because their attitudes and charisma elevated the music. At their best
column9: YACHT gave us Devo's wit
column10: Blondie's grace
column11: and Tom Tom Club's playful energy
column12: all wrapped in a knowing grin and a clever concept.

column1: Four years later
column2: YACHT has changed
column3: sort of. Evans
column4: now the sole lead singer
column5: is pictured alone on the cover of I Thought the Future Would Be Cooler
column6: and the title makes clear that she now has something to say. It all seems promising on paper: Evans' credentials posit her as a strong
column7: intelligent voice
column8: and YACHT's punky dance-pop would ostensibly sit well within the latest '80s resurgence. And yet not quite.

column1: For one
column2: although her tone has shifted drastically
column3: the music has remained as upbeat as ever
column4: even goofy in places. At the beginning of I Thought the Future Would Be Cooler
column5: Evans sings
column6: ""I only learned who I loved when I left them all in the past
column7: and by its end she's shouting
column8: ""Give me entertainment! Death by entertainment!""<span> It makes for a jarring match. When we're told of ""mediated war zones and countries full of death"" over breezy post-disco grooves and light Rhodes chords in ""Matter""
column9: it's like a friend making an off-color joke over text—you're pretty sure they're being sarcastic
column10: but it definitely didn't sound that way.

column1: There is some solid songwriting on Future. The juxtaposition of bubblegum new wave and tender synth-pop in ""Don't Be Rude"" feels effortless and inventive
column2: and ""Miles & Miles"" is a rousing throwback to those DFA albums. Bechtolt's co-production with Rob Kieswetter recalls Midnite Vultures electro-funk on ""Hologram"". But for every decent takeaway
column3: we're confronted with ""I Wanna Fuck You Til I'm Dead"" or the spastic
column4: vibe-killing chorus of ""Ringtone""
column5: nonsensical amalgams that range from tactless to tone deaf to straight obnoxious. They're YACHT's uncanny valley: lifelike approximations of late-'90s power pop
column6: early '00s Top 40
column7: and blog-house mp3s that somehow aren't lifelike enough.

column1: I Thought the Future Would Be Cooler has good intentions. As Evans told LA Mag
column2: ""The central thesis is not that we're disappointed that we were promised jet packs. It's more like
column3: I don't care about jet packs if we still don’t have basic human rights."" Songs comment on our increasing tech obsessions
column4: societal violence and inequality
column5: and future fatigue with effusive hooks
column6: lending each decidedly familiar arrangement a fresh immediacy thanks to upgraded production values. Their messages
column7: however
column8: are in turns vague ruminations
column9: condescending truisms
column10: or just foregone conclusions for anyone with an interest in current events. Future is YACHT's would-be critique of our pre-dystopian
column11: post-Internet culture
column12:
but it rarely comes off as more than a charismatic cover band singing us yesterday's news.

Raury made his big debut in 2014 with the folk-leaning EP Indigo Child
column2: which was anchored by its single and centerpiece ""God’s Whisper"". That EP was a daring first statement with soulful alternative rock jams supercut with real
column3: recorded fights he had with his mother. It was stuffed with big ideas
column4: but it often had trouble wrangling them. Still
column5: it effectively established Raury as this sort of genre migrant who existed adjacent to the rap world without sounding much like it. The singer-songwriter has a real sense for composition and a knack for ambiguity
column6: and he
column7: like his stylistic forebear André 3000
column8: remains at arm's length from hip-hop
column9: never quite a full-fledged rapper but certainly draped in the tropes of the genre
column10: reaping the benefits of everything cool and useful that comes from identifying with it. He is literally indie rap
column11: and his debut album
column12: All We Need
column13: searches further for perfect balance.

column1: All We Need isn't the transcendent Raury project that’s been foreshadowed since he became a blog darling
column2: the one that reconciles genre distinctions and renders them obsolete. It isn't ahead of its time or magnificent in scope. Instead
column3: much like Indigo Child
column4: it's merely an exhibition for a young creative still figuring out the true extent of his genius with as many hiccups. The wrinkles haven't been ironed out yet; his genre-mashing can be scatterbrained and even hollow. Sometimes
column5: like on the RZA-featuring ""CPU""

column7: like on Big K.R.I.T.-featuring ""Forbidden Knowledge""
column8: it completely misses the mark. Raury emerged with a fully formed aesthetic
column9: but his sound
column10: albeit fascinating
column11: still needs time to incubate.

column1: From start to finish
column2: All We Need scans as Indigo Child Redux with similar pacing and nearly identical tropes. This one is anchored by its single
column3: ""Devil’s Whisper""
column4: which puts a slightly darker tint on the hand-clapping-around-the-campfire folk of its predecessor. The album is mostly a reprise of his boho hippie rap tunes
column5: wandering in and out of folk territory with lots of stringy acoustic riffs
column6: hedging toward rock with hip-hop spirit
column7: casually blending influences like a Tumblr kid that grew up in a post-Napster world. The writing is angst-y and centric to a wide-eyed
column8: teenage worldview: chasing girls and soothing parents and saving the Earth. On the opening title track
column9: he sets the tone for his flower child vibes: ""Don’t hate
column10: my brother/ God is our friend/ I walked for miles and/ I see no end/ To the hate.""

column1: Many of the songs call for unity and love with several mentions of an impending Armageddon
column2: and Raury tackles these huge topics with ambitious arrangements. On ""Revolution""
column3: he pleads for divine intervention over strum-heavy riffs
column4: throbbing 808 bass
column5: hand drums
column6: and vocal chops. On the slow-moving ""Peace Prevail""
column7: which has a tempering rhythm and melting bass
column8: he borrows André 3000's flow to rap about being a rap outlier (""Been by myself since the White T’s/ Been by myself since Dem Franchize Boyz did that dance on that hoe in the white tee"") before praying for peace with a chorus of voices at his back. There’s significantly more rapping here than on his last release
column9: and while dextrous rapping isn’t exactly his forte
column10: there are moments where he finds his flow. It doesn't feel like he's gotten that much better at what he does
column11: but he seems to be figuring it out. He's got people like Rage Against the Machine's Tom Morello and underground Atlanta rapper Key! on the album to help him. With an album replete with Spanish guitar jams
column12: wide-eyed hip-hop
column13: and psychedelic rock k-holes
column14: there isn't much ground left for Raury to cover. Now
column15:
he must figure out how to do it all just a little bit better.

Weyes Blood is the project of multi-instrument folk musician Natalie Mering. She recorded the four-song Cardamom Times EP on a reel-to-reel deck in her Rockaway
column3: N.Y.
column4: home studio; it sounds like a lush
column5: pristine folk-rock gem rescued from the 1960s. The playing is patient and assured
column6: and you can't say enough about her voice
column7: a dusky
column8: soulful soprano that draws you into her world as well as into a larger tradition. She has the kind of voice that’s both distinctive and familiar
column9: and it fits perfect with her style: the arrangements are at once classic
column10: sneakily innovative
column11: and entirely her own.

column1: Cardamon Times follows Mering's second album
column2: 2014's The Innocents. It's more pure
column3: and the overall sound is less composed. Instead of a complex studio creation
column4: it comes off like an overheard monologue in the woods. The rural
column5: solitary video for the stunning five-and-a-half-minute closer ""In the Beginning""
column6: which was shot on Super 8 film in Northern Canada and finds Mering wandering the countryside by herself
column7: captures this feel.

column1: Cardamom sounds a bit like an archival folk collection but it's filled with suprising details. The lengthy ""Take You There"" opens with a minute of melancholic organ drone; for the rest of the track
column2: she sings over the fluctuating keys without any percussion. Opener ""Maybe Love"" has pretty
column3: Sundays-like guitar strums and eventually
column4: at songs's end
column5: noise is layered beneath ghostly multi-tracked voices. On ""Cardamom""
column6: her voice is almost distorted beside crystal clear guitar picking and a piping flute. As you listen more closely
column7: subtle touches distance Mering's music from the purely nostalgic.

column1: Her lyrics feel personal. Cardamom Times mostly focuses on love
column2: lost and found and lost again. ""Maybe Love"" includes the touching
column3: realistic detail: ""I like seeing you notice me/ When I’m feeling better about/ You and me."" The old-timey sounding ""Cardamom"" snaps into the present when she sings: ""I like your band
column4: can I hold your hand this time?/ Do you find what I do kind of cool?/ Would we last a minute or two?"" Nothing seems permanent here
column5: even when the music is timeless.

column1: ""In the Beginning""
column2: her best song to date
column3: features a melancholic but catchy melody and an arrangement of guitars and organs and her voice. She sings about a field of stars. She sings about suffering and changing
column4: of bittersweet meetings that happen at the wrong time. She asks ""Have you ever walked in on a Queen before?"" She admits she's not trying to relate at the moment. And she just keeps going
column5: and it's astonishing. Her music seems so simple at first
column6:
but it keeps deepening.

For decades
column2: the theme from the film Halloween has been about as well-known as a piece of music can get
column3: but it's only lately that iconic horror filmmaker John Carpenter has embraced the spotlight as an electronic musician and quote-unquote composer. Listen to any record by the one-time Pittsburgh-based duo Zombi
column4: though
column5: and it's obvious that keyboardist/multi-instrumentalist Steve Moore and drummer A.E. Paterra wear their film-geek affinities on their sleeve. The band's name is
column6: in fact
column7: derived from the Italian title of George A. Romero's Dawn of the Dead
column8: which was filmed at Moore's hometown shopping mall and scored by Italian prog rock outfit Goblin
column9: a huge influence on Zombi along with Carpenter and other film composers such as Fabio Frizzi and Riz Ortolani.

column1: Paterra and British documentary/video game composer Paul Lawler recently collaborated under the moniker Contact
column2: while Moore has embarked on a side career scoring films on his own
column3: most recently supplying the score for Belgian director Jonas Govaerts' 2014 horror movie Cub. Relapse Records is
column4: in fact
column5: releasing Zombi's fifth full-length Shape Shift and the Cub soundtrack on the same day. It's impossible to ignore the common thread between the two albums
column6: and since the Cub score doesn't do enough to re-contextualize Moore's approach to harmony
column7: it only serves to reveal his limitations in Zombi. But
column8: as Moore has made clear in recent press
column9: he and Paterra have always considered Zombi a post-rock outfit that happens to use the vocabulary of soundtracks. In their view
column10: their work has more in common with
column11: say
column12: Battles or Trans Am than it does with those aforementioned cinematic influences.

column1: Indeed
column2: Zombi's third album
column3: 2009's Spirit Animal
column4: combined the stately gesturing of Genesis' 1974 prog epic The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway with the ominous intonation of film music. Somehow
column5: Moore and Paterra managed to evoke the murky synthesizer ambience of the 1970s while also infusing their music with a decidedly modern aura. Though Shape Shift marks the first time since 2006's Surface to Air that Moore and Paterra made music in the same room with one another
column6: the throbbing analog synth pulse of album opener ""Pillars of the Dawn"" suggests that the pair might have lost their ability to draw on their influences without getting stuck in the past. Paterra's drums very precisely recall the tone and feel of drummer Neil Peart's performance circa Signals
column7: Rush's 1982 head-first dive into synth-driven rock. From a purely sonic standpoint
column8: it's an impressive feat to recapture the acoustic fingerprint of Peart's drums without using sample triggers
column9: but you can't shake the sensation that you've just stepped out of a time machine and landed in the wrong year.

column1: In that way
column2: Shape Shift initially comes across as pandering to retrophilia when Moore and Paterra have already demonstrated that they're clever enough to not have to resort to that kind of thing. That said
column3: it doesn't take long for the band's underlying attitude to breathe life into this material. Two tracks in and it becomes clear that Moore and Paterra play with a fire that their musical forbears lacked. Paterra in particular—the way his drumming both drives the music and makes room for it to breathe
column4: the nuanced variations in the way he strikes the snare
column5: hi-hat
column6: and the bell of his ride cymbal—gives Shape Shift a gritty
column7: utterly human quality that complements Moore's synthetic palette. In general
column8: Zombi favor mid-tempo grooves that require a lot of reserve
column9: but Paterra reminds you at all times that you're listening to a rock band with an underlying sense of millennial angst
column10: even if that angst is never explicitly articulated.

column1: We are
column2: after all
column3: talking about long-winded mathy instrumental music here. But that's the thing: at some point while listening to Shape Shift
column4: it dawns on you that you can actually hum all of these tunes. Sure
column5: there are times when Moore and Paterra let their instincts to impose changes for their own sake get the better of them. Not far into the 8-minute-plus ""Interstellar Package""
column6: a groove built out of an oscillating low-pitched synth throb grows to a majestic crescendo that prematurely gives way to six minutes' worth of undifferentiated drone
column7: a move that short-circuits the tune's potential payoff. Nevertheless
column8: in their own way Moore and Paterra write catchy music. That their tastes position them as soundtrack-buff outsiders at the fringes makes the cohesion
column9: listenability
column10:
and passion of Shape Shift that much more of a triumph.

column6: Cool & Dre
column7: Havoc
column8: Just Blaze

column10: Hi-Tek
column11: Jeff Bhasker

which can actually sound novel in 2015. The biggest lie he keeps telling is that any album he makes is definitely going to be his last. Can’t leave rap alone—the Game needs it.

column5: she makes the process sound like an exorcism. Each song was captured in one take
column6: and the whole album recorded in a daylong session. Her lyrics are collaged-together English translations of the songs' source material
column7: which mostly concern seduction and infatuation. After a certain point
column8: her singing becomes wailing. Her screams are pained and
column9: to borrow Khan's word
column10: ""orgasmic."" When it came time to name the project
column11: she shrugged and told Carey
column12: ""It’s Sexwitch
column13: innit?""

column1: The material for the album was unearthed during a fruitful crate-digging trip
column2: when Khan and Carey obsessed over some rare psychedelic tracks from other countries. They found two songs from Iran: ""Ghoroobaa Ghashangan"" (on the Light in the Attic comp Zendooni) and ""Helelyos"" (a song by Iranian singer Zia that's appeared on several Iranian pre-revolutionary pop compilations). Two songs are featured on the Raw 45s of Morocco comp: ""Ha Howa Ha Howa"" and ""Kassidat El Hakka"". The original version of ""Lam Plearn Kiew Bao"" is from Thailand and can be found on a Soundway comp. These songs' messages of liberation and passion are well suited to Khan's voice
column3: especially at its most intense.

column1: Compared to The Haunted Man
column2: Khan's untethered presence on Sexwitch is a departure. Her Bat for Lashes work foregrounds structure and melody
column3: but here she takes key phrases and molds them
column4: repeating and inverting them. When necessary
column5: she makes her voice percussive
column6: especially when she emphasizes the repeated words ""my dark girls"" on ""Helelyos"". Khan's performances are equal parts wild and controlled
column7: and TOY have no trouble nailing these songs. They're funky on ""Ghoroobaa Ghashangan"" and their percussion work on ""Kassidat El Hakka"" is satisfyingly heavy. To Carey's credit
column8: this album sounds great
column9: too.

column1: But since every song on Sexwitch is a cover
column2: it begs the question: What do Sexwitch's versions add? Occasionally
column3: they feel overlong. Repetition is key to this music
column4: but after several cycles
column5: tracks begin to plod
column6: broken up only by Khan's vocal work. The Sexwitch interpretations lose vital elements from the originals like horns
column7: organs
column8: and bells.

column1: The most successful cover is arguably the closer: Skip Spence's ""War in Peace"". It's an excellent choice
column2: and it offers Sexwitch the opportunity to simmer
column3: jam
column4: and gradually ramp back up. ""War in peace
column5: Khan sings
column6: adding
column7: ""What a funny combination."" The song is proof that they can thrive in the sweet spot between unchained freewheeling psychedelia and something more regimented and precise like ""All Your Gold"". But then again
column8:
why tame a band that's hell-bent on staying untamed?

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22276/homepage_large.ab66fe9b.jpg|Eyes of Love|33201.0|The Edge of Daybreak|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Numero Group']|2015-10-15 00:00:00|1979|2016-06-11 16:05:09.212787|"

There’s a moment near the end of the Edge of Daybreak’s Eyes of Love where the LP’s structured soul gives way to a brief
column2: fluid jam session. It happens on ""Your Destiny""
column3: and it’s the freest moment of a recording made in five hours in a Virginia federal prison.

column1: Released in 1979
column2: Eyes of Love was recorded in one take on a $3
column3: 000 budget at the Powhatan Correctional Center in State Farm
column4: Va. The band members were all inmates
column5: incarcerated for armed robbery and assault
column6: with sentences ranging from six to 60 years. The musicians
column7: some of whom played in other bands before they were locked up
column8: were allowed to play instruments at the prison complex. They covered songs by the Isley Brothers
column9: Slave
column10: and Earth
column11: Wind & Fire. Jamal Jahal Nubi
column12: the Edge of Daybreak’s lead singer and drummer
column13: entered the Virginia prison in 1976 and established another group called Cosmic Conception with Edward Tucker and William Crawley. He’d later form Edge of Daybreak with fellow prisoners Harry Coleman on additional vocals
column14: James Carrington on keys
column15: Cornelius Cade on guitar
column16: McEvoy Robinson on bass
column17: and Willie Williams on percussion. The band didn't have equipment to overdub
column18: so they brought in backup musicians to play instruments when the regulars had to sing.

column1: A few local media outlets covered Eyes of Love upon its release. Only 1
column2: 000 copies were pressed. ""PM Magazine""
column3: a now-defunct television news show
column4: produced a segment called ""Cellblock Rock"" that aired footage of Edge of Daybreak’s recording. The album arrived as the outside world was moving away from brassier sounds for the likes of disco and nu-wave. Up the road in Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: musicians like Chuck Brown and Trouble Funk were putting their own unique twist on black music. Their blend was called go-go
column7: a percussive strain of funk designed to keep the beat going without breaks.

column1: In a way
column2: the Edge of Daybreak seemed influenced by the homegrown genre
column3: and at certain points on Eyes of Love
column4: you sense the band’s urge to break away from the literal and figurative structures that contained them. Given their circumstances
column5: it would’ve been easy for the group to create something sullen. Yet on Eyes of Love
column6: it’s as if the band wanted to uplift themselves through song
column7: and to forget their living arrangements if only for a few hours. These songs are optimistic
column8: touching on the brilliance of love and glorifying romance in all its sugary splendor. Songs like ""Let Us"" and ""Let’s Be Friends"" recall the 1960s doo-wop era
column9: while ""Edge of Daybreak"" and ""I Wanna Dance With You"" are extensive dance grooves.

column1: Thematically
column2: Eyes of Love is about a group of guys making the best of a tough situation. That a collection of inmates even recorded an album is a testament
column3: and the fact that it’s so well done is a plus. The inmates couldn’t just go to the studio. Prison personnel required Alpha Audio—in nearby Richmond—to record the band at the Powhatan complex. They had to sing and play their instruments simultaneously
column4: and get everything right the first time. The album’s last song
column5: ""Our Love""
column6: was recorded as prison guards told the band to wrap up recording. The group members were taken back to their cells as soon as the last song finished. Despite the duress
column7: there aren’t any noticeable hiccups on the LP
column8: making me wonder what could’ve been if the band had more time to perfect it.

column1: By the fall of 1980
column2: keyboardist Carrington was transferred to another prison. Then vocalist Coleman. Then Cade
column3: who was moved to Powhatan’s North Housing Unit
column4: essentially breaking up the Edge of Daybreak. There were talks of a sophomore album
column5: but with the musicians in separate prison facilities
column6: it was impossible to rehearse. In the end
column7: Eyes of Love would be the group’s swan song. Thirty-six years later
column8: it’s still a living testament to what can be done in tumultuous conditions. It’s a push to make a way
column9: and to persevere
column10:
even when the light is dim.
