0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22440/homepage_large.ad0bbb63.jpg|Let's Jam 1 EP|22489.0|Zomby|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['XL']|2015-10-15 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:09.932165|"

In the two-plus years since 2013's With Love
column2: Zomby has experimented with a new mode: silence. Or
column3: at least
column4: relative silence
column5: as the irascible producer has been dormant after keeping a near constant release schedule since debuting in 2007. It's been for the best
column6: really
column7: as London's grime underground
column8: including upstarts like Visionist and Logos
column9: took the genre to new
column10: exciting places just as Zomby's twinkling arpeggios started to feel too familiar. Now Zomby returns
column11: first with a one-off single this summer with grime godfather Wiley and now with Let's Jam!!
column12: a series of two four-track EPs
column13: his first work for stalwart independent XL Recordings.

column1: Anyone hoping for fireworks upon Zomby's return is likely to be disappointed
column2: as Let's Jam!! is slight both by XL's standards and the strictures of dance music 12""s. Zomby has referred to at least one of the tracks here (""Acid Surf"") as a ""DJ tool""—a simple
column3: repetitive piece meant to aid DJ mixing—and much of Let's Jam 1 proceeds in this manner
column4: offering up slight variations on simple riffs. DJ tools are a common
column5: simple convention
column6: but they usually aren't packaged with promotional airhorns (nor do they tend to come out on XL Recordings
column7: or at least not since the early '90s)
column8: so it's fair to assume that Zomby sees these as somewhat more substantial than that term implies.

column1: Locating that substance proves difficult. On Let's Jam 1 Zomby (finally!) abandons his signature sound for something that amounts to a walking tour of early rave conventions—of the early history of XL
column2: coincidentally or not—adding little to the equation. Opener ""Surf I"" is essentially a harmless electro sendup
column3: featuring a low voice grunting the track's title while short melodic lines phase in and out. The problem is that
column4: even for a low-stakes genre exercise
column5: ""Surf I"" is badly lacking in dynamism
column6: deploying that same curt vocal sample on the first downbeat of every other measure of the track while a short bassline repeats. It is noticeably repetitive in a realm in which repetition is basically the entire point.

column1: No
column2: if you're looking for the type of subtle shifts and melodic changeups that are part and parcel to the very concept of dance music you'll have to wait for ""Surf II""
column3: a similar concept but with just enough rhythmic interplay and moving pieces to register as improvement. If for some reason you should want to bridge these Zomby offers aforementioned tool ""Acid Surf""
column4: which sounds like a parody of Zomby doing an acid track: a zippy 303 bassline
column5: a sample of someone sternly declaring ""acid""
column6: and lots of airhorn. ""Slime""
column7: a coarse interpretation of the hoover bass sound
column8: is a far better fit for Zomby's eerie sense of melody.

column1: There's less to say about Let's Jam 2
column2: which returns Zomby to his default style—sparkling synths
column3: fizzy square wave bass
column4: pools of reverb—with diminishing returns. The best of the four tracks
column5: ""Bloom""
column6: wouldn't sound out of place on Local Action or Keysound Recordings or any of the other London labels releasing lush
column7: forward-thinking bass explorations
column8: but nor would it stand out. (More troublingly
column9: you could say the same about its placement on Zomby's past two albums.) Grime has gotten vaster and braver in Zomby's absence; long reverb tails and gunshot percussion don't quite cut it anymore.

column1: Let's Jam!! does unload some of With Love's portentous conceptualism. It's nice to see Zomby return to the short
column2: understated format under which he's released some of his most potent material; With Love suggested that his gilded
column3: buzzy sound is difficult to scale. No points just for showing up
column4: though
column5:
and Let's Jam!! finds Zomby far too conservative working through two distinct periods of UK dance history.

"|21148.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21148-lets-jam-1-ep-lets-jam-2-ep/|4.9|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22442/homepage_large.09c7d696.jpg|Grievances|30867.0|Kowloon Walled City|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Neurot']|2015-10-15 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:10.654612|"

No one but a person who’d experienced abject powerlessness and the passive acceptance of degradation could have created Grievances. It’s the third full-length by San Francisco’s Kowloon Walled City
column2: a post-metal group that Scott Evans fronts as both singer/guitarist and producer. Wearing that many hats in a band suggests a position of authority
column3: but you’d never guess that listening to Grievances. Evans subsumes his riffs within vast
column4: oppressive swathes of empty space. He submits his voice to a process of industrialized monotony. His guitar doesn’t gently weep—it curls up
column5: plays dead
column6: and still isn’t able to halt its cataclysmic spasms.

column1: Yet Grievances sounds anything but weak. Kowloon’s last album
column2: 2012’s Container Ships
column3: showed a shift toward refinement that felt more like a half measure
column4: but here
column5: Evans and crew have hit on something profound. It isn’t a concept album per se
column6: but it does have an overarching theme: the psychic
column7: social
column8: and spatial anxieties of the modern workplace. But Grievances isn’t about run-of-the-mill disgruntled employment as much as it’s a haunting meditation on humanity’s disassociation from the product—or
column9: in our increasingly cyber-centric world
column10: the service—of its labor.

column1: ""You sell it like a poet
column2: Evans howls on ""The Grift""
column3: the centerpiece and high point of the album. It’s an accusation of self-commodification
column4: seemingly aimed both inward and outward. It’s more than that
column5: though; as a trainwreck of AmRep-style noise rock is sculpted into minimalist shapes
column6: that structure becomes a metaphor for hollowness of all kinds. ""The fiction sells
column7: Evans reiterates
column8: and when he slams the ""confidence game"" of modern interpersonal commerce
column9: his sardonic use of ""confidence"" is even more lacerating than his sly insinuation of melody.

column1: At just over three and a half minutes
column2: ""The Grift"" is the runt of the album. Song lengths stretch onward from there
column3: including Grievances’ title track
column4: which crawls along for nearly seven minutes’ worth of forlorn rage. While Evans levels the charge ""No love/ No memory/ Just admit it""
column5: fellow guitarist Jon Howell locks into a pneumatic
column6: dehumanized groove that sputters out in gasps of dead air. Bassist Ian Miller chugs and claws; drummer Jeff Fagundes (replaced by Julia Lancer since this recording) puts the brakes on spacetime. If Godflesh and Codeine had ever conspired to hybridize
column7: it might have come out like this: bleak but bare
column8: mechanistic yet melancholic.

column1: Grievances is inalienably heavy
column2: but it’s not sludge in the conventional sense. On ""Your Best Years""
column3: the distortion is more clotted than fuzzy
column4: with immaculate slabs of dissonance left dangling overhead. But it’s ""Backlit"" that sums up the huge step forward Kowloon has taken with Grievances. Arid and static at first
column5: it builds into a monument to grim resignation that feels weathered and ancient right out of the gate. ""Wear out your weaknesses
column6: Evans half-commands
column7: half-implores; later he adds
column8: ""Wear all your weaknesses."" Resistance is futile
column9:
but in that steadfast futility there is strength.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22305/homepage_large.4a7f78fc.jpg|VEGA INTL. Night School|28027.0|Neon Indian|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Transgressive'
column2:
'Mom & Pop']|2015-10-14 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:11.127059|"

Alan Palomo of Neon Indian recorded VEGA INTL. Night School over the span of four years at a number of crash pads across America
column3: but most crucial to the album was a self-described ""magical winter"" the singer spent on a Carnival Fantasy Cruise ship with his brother
column4: who played in the house band. (Insert chillwave joke here.) The album contains enough reggae and Balearic tropical breeze to prove Palomo doesn’t shy away from pleasing the lido deck
column5: but beyond the kitsch
column6: <span>an extended stay in a floating
column7: inescapable city is an apt metaphor for VEGA INTL. Night School
column8: where the inherent danger of total immersion is offset by generous hospitality.

column1: Palomo acts a gracious host
column2: delivering the most deluxe
column3: comprehensive Neon Indian album yet. He's presenting the 51-minute record as a ""double album"" and the interstitial bits ensure the beat never stops. <span>The production values are higher
column4: and there’s even more of Palomo's queasy pitch-shifting
column5: 16-bit synths
column6: and disembodied samples—more of everything. Palomo might have seemed like someone stumbling onto a recipe with Psychic Chasms
column7: but now it's clear that this is Palomo’s foundational music
column8: his blues or funk.

column1: Palomo's riff on the idea of ""night school"" is the album's unifying thematic construct: stay up after midnight
column2: and you’ll learn about how human nature really works. In this way
column3: the progression of Neon Indian is best seen as Palomo moving from PG-13 to NC-17—if you dial the Neon Indian hotline he set up for this album
column4: what you hear is a voice purring ""hey there
column5: sexy."" Everyone’s committing crimes of passion on VEGA INTL.—a missed phone call occasions a ""CSI"" investigation on ""Annie"" and on ""Baby's Eyes"" Vega harbors a charismatic murderer. Elsewhere
column6: we're exposed to a polyamorous tryst in ""Smut!"" after a chance meeting behind the red curtain in the porno section of a video store.

column1: So consider VEGA INTL. Palomo finally freeing his dirty mind
column2: even as the music maintains a veneer of innocence. Neon Indian is an inherently nostalgic project
column3: and Palomo views the musical cross-pollination of the early '80s as unfinished business rather than something to romanticize. Era Extraña framed Palomo as the rock star he could often seem on stage
column4: engaging in the pouty
column5: guitar-centric forms of post-punk—shoegaze and MTV-friendly goth in particular. Conversely
column6: VEGA INTL. recalls the synthesists who took ""post-punk"" as a mandate to leave punk rock behind. The reggae bump of ""Annie"" and ""61 Cygni Ave"" recall Scritti Politti and the Police
column7: and there’s plenty of Tom Tom Club and Blondie in the album's bubbly disco.

column1: The cumulative impression of VEGA INTL.
column2: then
column3: is that of a Carnival Cruise night based around New York's Danceteria
column4: circa 1982
column5: a place and time of glaring blight as well as utopian all-night clubs where synth-pop
column6: disco
column7: funk
column8: R&B
column9: and early hip-hop were feeding off one another. Any artist trying to capture the spirit of that specific era has to reckon with Prince
column10: a personification of the idealism of early '80s pop
column11: and Palomo finally gets there at the end of the record: ""News from the Sun (Live Bootleg)"" recalls both the insular psychedelia of Around the World in a Day
column12: the ""is it really live?"" crowd noise of ""Purple Rain""
column13: and the communal ecstasy of Sign 'o’ the Times. Before the final leap into a daredevil key modulation
column14: Palomo delivers the record’s final line: ""We’re all just waiting for something—'til love touches you like a hand in the dark."" Those words encompass the starry-eyed ideal as well as the unsavory reality of how people tend to find love. Morning might bring to light all of the shameful things that have just gone down
column15:
but ""News from the Sun"" assures that whatever happens on this fantasy cruise stays there.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22505/homepage_large.9c514306.jpg|BYLUG World|33285.0|Doughboyz Cashout|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-10-14 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:11.691820|"

To succeed in rap in 2015
column2: you have to be good with the Internet—or prolifically bad
column3: at bare minimum. It helps if you can meme-ify your personal brand
column4: through Vine dance sensation or hashtaggable one-liner. The West Detroit supergroup Doughboyz Cashout
column5: meanwhile
column6: have not used their Twitter account in nearly two years. They don't have a Wikipedia page. They're signed to Jeezy's CTE World imprint
column7: but haven't released an official single on the label since 2013's ""Mob Life"" remix
column8: to say nothing of a full-length project. But the Doughboyz—whose membership has ranged from four to eight members since the group's 2006 inception—are currently the biggest street rappers in Detroit
column9: and the best rap group in the Midwest.

column1: Doughboyz' latest
column2: BYLUG World (short for ""Boss Yo Life Up Gang"")
column3: is a relatively minor release in the group's nearly decade-long career. It's not as consistent as last year's excellent We Run The City 4 tape
column4: and lacks the immediate hits of 2012's Free Roc
column5: their best work. There's nothing resembling a crossover play in the vein of ""My Young Niggaz""
column6: a DJ Mustard-produced collaboration with Jeezy and YG; in fact
column7: label boss Jeezy shows up exactly zero times here. But for longtime fans and those nostalgic for turn-of-the-century Cash Money and No Limit
column8: there's a lot to love.

column1: To the uninitiated
column2: BYLUG World may sound anachronistic: the stabby piano
column3: the rubber-band bass
column4: and bounce are pure Mannie Fresh worship. Most of BYLUG World's production is handled by Payroll Giovanni
column5: who doubles as Doughboyz' most popular solo rapper; you can hear the eerie ricochet of Fresh in most of his tracks here
column6: from menacing opener ""BYLUG Baby"" to the stripped-down murder piano of ""OVL"". But like Fresh's best work
column7: the production leaps out while providing space for the tape's rotating cast of rappers. And ultimately
column8: storytelling is at the heart of Doughboyz' appeal. BYLUG's sole time-stamped moment
column9: ""Netflix""
column10: should be a goofy throwaway about Netflix and chill
column11: but its novelty is redeemed by Payroll's deft but unshowy bars: ""She was intimidated when I pulled up
column12: for example/ She couldn't find the coupe door handles.""

column1: The tape's blunt edges are softened by the occasional warbling melody from Clay Baby—the closest thing Detroit has to a Nate Dogg
column2: who delivers the tape's best hook on ""Fell Off""—and a handful of smooth
column3: contemplative synth-scapes from former Taylor Gang producer Cardo. On YG-featuring ""Day Ones""
column4: he evokes a screwed-up
column5: waterlogged AraabMuzik
column6: and on his G-funk-leaning ""Street Heaven""
column7: Payroll offers a coolly specific narrative that recalls Curren$y: ""Meanwhile
column8: I'm cracking smiles at Mr. Chow's/ Out in Cali
column9: would I like another drink?/ Yes
column10: gladly."" But the celebration is shaded by struggle and countered with knowing paranoia: ""Lately I been having dreams of trucks and 7s/ And nightmares of the Feds wanting me in their possession."" This tightrope walk of aspiration and consequence is the Doughboyz' formula stripped down to its essence. Even at its core
column11:
it hits as hard as ever.

column2:

Some of the best and weirdest alt rap in the country is coming out of Hellfyre Club

column1: milo has a knack for using quips as a lens through which to stare into the void

A lot has changed since French producer Ludovic Navarre released his multi-platinum album Tourist in 2000 under the name St Germain. A wildly successful hybrid of dance music and jazz
column2: it put St Germain on tour for over two years

column4: there have been three French presidents

column9: Human After All

column1: Fans of St Germain's old work might find little that's instantly recognizable from Tourist
column2: which was part of Navarre's strategy. ""I had to stop completely

column5: Brian Eno

column7: Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner
column8: Wilco's Nels Cline
column9: TV on the Radio
column10: Amp Fiddler
column11: and more have already sought this fusion. Navarre did well to draw on the talents of kora player Mamadou Cherif Soumano and the fleet-fingered guitarist Guimba Kouyate

column1: But the most interesting results on the album seem as if they could easily exist without Navarre's so-called ""French Touch."" Perhaps if Navarre had returned circa 2007

column1: But this approach—and Cottrell
column2: specifically—got lost on Soma

column11: never above her.

column1: This directness carries over to Cottrell’s two solo numbers

The wonderfully frail ""Sparrow"" ponders the space between eternal devotion and the disappointment that mortality inevitably brings. You can imagine it as an antediluvian tune Harry Smith might have collected or a number fit for Windhand’s vintage guitar vortex—a testament to Cottrell’s command of songs when she’s given space to sing them.

column7: the tones bending and fluttering into surreal patterns. During ""Kingfisher""
column8: Windhand hover in a half-acoustic
column9: half-electric haze
column10: suggesting folk rock lost on a narcotic trip. Still
column11: even as the jam lurches ahead
column12: the singer and the song seem in control
column13: as Cottrell judiciously delivers her sermons at the start and in the middle. She then slips into the background

column15: Cottrell drifts in and out of ""Hesperus""
column16: appearing

column1: Early this year
column2: Cottrell released a self-titled set of solo recordings. With her voice multi-tracked and manipulated

Halfway through Majical Cloudz's set at the 2014 Pitchfork Music Festival
column2: the music cut out
column3: leaving singer Devon Welsh alone with a live microphone in front of 6
column4: 000 people. The scene put a new spin on an old bad dream: Not only had Welsh shown up to class without clothes on
column5: but the classroom had become a baseball field and everyone on it was a little bit drunk.

column1: After a couple of dumb jokes (the packing peanuts of any good showman)
column2: Welsh canvassed the audience for requests and ended up singing an a capella version of an already startlingly intimate song called ""Bugs Don't Buzz"" from the band's 2013 album Impersonator (""If life could be forever one instant/ Would it be the moment you met me? No
column3: my love"").

column1: For some bands
column2: the moment might've constituted disaster
column3: but for Majical Cloudz it was a logical endpoint to their music
column4: which functions as a kind of emotional strip show: Welsh knows it's a performance but he still ends up naked. When the song was over
column5: the crowd clapped with embarrassed hesitation: Should we be watching this? And should Welsh be doing it?

column1: The band's new album
column2: <i>Are You Alone?
column3: picks up where Impersonator left off: Stark
column4: ethereal instrumentals buoyed by Welsh's unflinching voice. Musically
column5: their roots are in English romantics like Depeche Mode
column6: themselves a moody electronic gloss on the lieder that composers like Franz Schubert were writing 150 years earlier. Philosophically
column7: they chart a junction of new age and hardcore punk
column8: both of which prize a radical scraping away of excess in their search for truth. Majical Cloudz want empathy and they want it now.

column1: I call them a ""band"" but should note how they stretch the definition of the word. As a singer
column2: Welsh performs with the confidence and intimacy of someone holding a hairbrush in front of their bedroom mirror—the music is mostly in his head. His counterpart
column3: Matthew Otto
column4: is less visible but equally important. A former student in an electroacoustic studies program that emphasized sound design as much as composition
column5: Otto doesn't try and approximate backing musicians so much as create vapor trails where backing musicians might've stood. If the name Majical Cloudz has any bearing on their sound
column6: it's because of him: He's the air Welsh breathes.

column1: Alone is less stripped-down than Impersonator
column2: but it feels less confrontational
column3: too. The band recently went on tour opening for Lorde
column4: and seem to have figured out how to broaden their sound while softening it at the same time
column5: all without losing the detonating high that made Impersonator so remarkable. Songs like ""So Blue"" and ""Downtown""—both standouts—are easy to imagine as more fully fleshed out pieces of music
column6: conveying size without occupying space. Like photographic negatives
column7: you can still see the image but the inversion of blacks and whites lends it a kind of alien melancholy.

column1: Like Impersonator
column2: Alone is a sad album
column3: but its sadness is a kind of tall tale
column4: the details of which are overblown for dramatic effect. At times its lyrics sound less like expressions of personal darkness than advertisements for darkness in general
column5: written in lettering so big you could read it from the highway. In a recent interview with Pitchfork
column6: he professed his admiration for Andy Kaufman
column7: an artist usually classified as a comedian but whose work tends to function more like social performance art. The connection makes sense: Like Kaufman
column8: Welsh tends to scramble performance and sincerity
column9: laying himself bare in a way that seems more honest when he's onstage than it might in so-called real life. At peak he becomes a kind of Puberty Incarnate
column10: bearer of feelings so awkward and yet so incandescent that they seem like a joke and a dare at the same time.

column1: A few weeks ago
column2: I blew off part of an afternoon to see the Pixar movie Inside Out
column3: which follows the inner life of a young girl named Riley as personified by five fundamental emotions: joy
column4: fear
column5: anger
column6: disgust
column7: and sadness. The emotions—characters unto themselves—run around Riley's head jockeying for control
column8: turning each new experience into a color-coded orb later filed away in Riley's labyrinthine memory.

column1: Early on
column2: Sadness—a dumpy
column3: self-effacing Midwestern woman—is portrayed as a kind of negative-force King Midas
column4: unwittingly ruining Riley's memories by turning them a cool
column5: melancholy blue. The movie's revelation is when Joy—cannily represented as part-Tinkerbell
column6: part passive-aggressive control freak—starts to realize that Sadness isn't a threat to Riley but a necessary catalyst for her growth
column7: not a barrier to Joy but a bridge. Toward the end
column8: a new feeling pops out of Riley's psychological conveyor belt: The yellow of Joy and the blue of Sadness
column9: swirled together like ribbons inside a marble.

column1: The moral is simple
column2: but in a culture obsessed by happiness
column3: it seems surprising
column4: too: Maybe sadness isn't just an O.K. feeling to have
column5: but an essential part of our emotional balance. Without it
column6: we live in monochrome.

column1: I kept thinking of Majical Cloudz
column2: whose music—like Inside Out—seems to recast sadness as a feeling that doesn't damage the self but helps keep it whole. Now
column3: when I see that album title (Are You Alone?)
column4:
it seems less like a grim rhetorical question than an invitation—the kind of thing you might ask someone who is alone but looks like they could use a little company.

Prins Thomas' Paradise Goulash is seamless like a DJ set and wildly idiosyncratic like an independent radio broadcast. Spanning three CDs totaling nearly four hours' worth of music
column2: it represents a colossal amount of effort:  I don't even want to think about the licensing headaches involved in putting it together
column3: what with its 57 songs
column4: many of them out of print
column5: including one dating all the way back to 1968. Unlike many commercially available mix CDs
column6: it's clear from the intermittent tempo-nudges and occasional stretches of near-chaos that this one was mixed by hand—with all the risks
column7: and all the added hours' worth of flubbed takes
column8: that mixing in real time and without recourse to the sync button entails.

column1: But despite all this
column2: Paradise Goulash never feels like work; it is an invitation to sit back and let Thomas do the driving
column3: and it covers a lot of ground. The first mix begins with lyrical Norwegian jazz and the third mix concludes with Kurt Vile's ""Baby's Arms""; along the way
column4: we're treated to Spanish guitar
column5: Balearic ambient
column6: '70s Europop
column7: French/African electronic music
column8: dub techno
column9: acid
column10: deep house
column11: Detroit techno
column12: Swedish space rock
column13: Italian synth pop
column14: and a conceptual artist's cover of Arthur Russell's ""This Is How We Walk on the Moon"". It's the kind of mix you might plan a dinner party around
column15: but beware—somewhere in the middle stretch
column16: there will be dancing on tables
column17: and it will probably be barefoot.

column1: Thomas is known for his eclecticism
column2: so the range isn't surprising. What is surprising is how seamlessly it flows. Even his oddest selections seem designed to seduce
column3: and whether he's riding the mix hard—one Ricardo Villalobos track weaves in and out for nearly 20 minutes—or simply playing out songs in full
column4: his sleight-of-hand skills are such that you never really notice the changes.

column1: Disc one begins with jazz
column2: detours through groovy funk rock
column3: and then stretches out to explore all manner of sounds you might have heard Ibiza's DJ Alfredo spinning in the early '90s. A five- or six-song stretch of chilly drum machines
column4: slow-motion acid
column5: and world-music accents that climaxes in A Split - Second's chugging New Beat is particularly inspired; it seems to open up a kind of wormhole in time and space
column6: collapsing multiple places and eras into a single idea. As for the tranquil denouement
column7: Kurt Vile and that Arthur Russell cover may be notable talking points
column8: but the most remarkable find here might be Il Guardiano del Faro's ""Ma Ci Pensi
column9: Io E Te""
column10: an Italian easy-listening song from 1980 that sounds like John Carpenter at the Ice Capades.

column1: Those are a few of the highlights
column2: anyway; every listener will doubtless pick up on different moments. The sheer volume of material
column3: combined with Thomas' knack for teasing out a given tonal or rhythmic idea across long stretches begins to lend repeated listens a kind of hallucinatory air. Where am I? Didn't I just hear this? Does this stairway lead up or down? It's rare that a mix so accurately replicates the sense of disorientation that you get from a marathon stretch of clubbing
column4: but on Paradise Goulash
column5: the windows are blacked out
column6: you can't find your friends
column7: who knows what time (or day) it is
column8:
and you wouldn't have it any other way.

Off That Loud is billed as as the first EP for Hyperdub from DJ Spinn
column2: but this designation obscures the footwork producer's long history in the Chicago underground electronic scene. Spinn
column3: born Morris Harper
column4: has been pressing energetic
column5: beguiling footwork onto record for decades

column10: crackling track in 1998 called ""Mutha Fuc*a"" that Dance Mania misattributed to DJ Thadz. He also had a hand in eight of the 14 songs on Rashad's masterpiece

column1: Spinn's lack of marquee status often seems due to his eagerness to work with others

column4: rapid-fire kicks. Footwork remains a niche concern—Planet Mu honcho Mike Paradinas recently told Dummy Magazine footwork albums sell so poorly he can only afford to drop two a year—but ""Throw It Back"" could chameleon its way onto a playlist of arena-sized EDM songs as easily as it could provide a soundtrack for dancers facing off at Battlegroundz on Chicago's South Side.

column2: with its cross-stitching rhythms

column7: and then pass the mic to Danny Brown
column8: who raps: ""I don't know 'bout where you from but this is how my hood work."" Brown's squawk has colored downtrodden tales about growing up in Detroit
column9: but he sounds utterly at home on ""Dubby"". As Spinn adeptly blends foreign sounds into a distinctly Chicago genre
column10: Off That Loud shows his ability to help footwork thrive outside its birthplace. Spinn earned his veteran bona fides years ago
column11:
but Off That Loud feels like a new beginning.

All Odds End

column8: interior melancholy.

column1: The Mantles

column3: first garnered notice with their eponymous 2009 debut. The record mediated indie-pop
column4: pastoral '60s psych
column5: and the various locales known for jangling in the 1980s

column7: All Odds End sounds especially confident in that decision. Many indie pop songs endear with their sense of delicate
column8: precarious construction
column9: but here the individually shambolic parts coalesce into a substantial whole. All Odds End suggests an ensemble of players who don't need to hold back; they choose to
column10: together.

column1: Olivares' metaphors for resisting change and liminal places usually have a lackadaisical tone
column2: but the lyrical focus connects to how the band has drifted toward anachronism. Many of the Mantles' early regional peers have dissolved or resettled in L.A.—which ""Best Sides"" deals with in veiled terms—and the group never demonstrated much interest in consistent release schedules
column3: touring
column4: or otherwise playing the indie career game. Indeed

column6: it's easy to hear All Odds End as a defensive retreat inward

column2:
'No Solace']|2015-10-13 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:17.527883|"

Mgła are the exemplars of Polish black metal. They play melodic black metal that isn't immediate in its beauty
column3: though a dark elegance does surface. Groza
column4: which they released in 2008
column5: was a promising debut
column6: and on 2012's With Hearts Toward None they began to come into their own in terms of composition and lyrics. Exercises in Futility
column7: their third full-length
column8: improves upon Hearts' template
column9: with guitarist/vocalist Mikołaj ""M."" Żentara and drummer Maciej ""Darkside"" Kowalski delivering their most spirited performances to date. It doesn't just set the standard for black metal in their home country
column10: it's one of the finest black metal albums this year.

column1: As its title implies
column2: Futility is focused on a pessimistic
column3: defeatist worldview. The opening line is ""The great truth is there isn't one
column4: a tone-setter if there ever was one. If we're to believe them
column5: Mgła would prefer to be in hell shouting at the devil
column6: not the purgatory of life. As M. laments on ""II"": ""I wish it was classic fire and brimstone/ But clearly there is a very special plan/ Paved with havoc and shattered virtues/ As if there were any other paths."" Futility's lyrics are a cut above basic sadboy depressive tropes
column7: especially in a section of ""V"" masked as an ode to the working class: ""Blessed be the tailors
column8: the masks are cut to fit/ Blessed be the woodworkers
column9: the crosses and the gallows/ Blessed be the forgers of iron
column10: and the spikes and the barbwire/ Blessed be the stone cutters
column11: it took a quarry to bury the dreams.""

column1: They're lyrics don't offer much hope
column2: but M.'s guitar work suggests anything but failure: his playing draws from metal's wells of depression as well as the affirmative lights that can coexist with it. Mgła are the true heirs to Dissection's style of black metal; the melodies are huge without dipping into the saccharine. Even when M. gets into his nastiest playing
column3: it never feels like he's wading in the tar pits of despair for despair's sake.

column1: Mgła also balance their bursts of nihilistic euphoria with mid-paced sections that show discipline without sacrificing majesty. ""II"" uses this contrast as a springboard—the slower melody naturally builds into the brighter
column2: faster vortex where hypnotism is a means of getting towards something bigger
column3: not an end unto itself. ""V"" is another master study in these shifts—the slower sections are their darkest grooves
column4: and when they race off
column5: they run farther and faster than anything on the record. You imagine the duo would hate to be compared to post-rock
column6: but both post-rock and black metal also-rans could stand to learn a lot about dynamics from them. Mgła's emphasis on the mid-paced is one testament to Celtic Frost's continued influence on black metal; it also lets the beauty of the riffs exfoliate
column7: and those who got into black metal for its prettier
column8: more accessible side would find much to appreciate here.

column1: M.'s riffwork puts Mgła above most black metal groups
column2: but it's Darkside's drumming that launches them into a class of their own. His cymbal work is key
column3: bringing with it a formidable delicacy. ""II"" begins with a drum fill that serves as Darkside's own mini-suite
column4: with the rides and crashes pinging louder than his tom fills. Maybe it's because we're not used to hearing cymbals used so prominently that they resonate this much; Darkside sees his kit as an extension of M.'s melodic prowess and not just an anger-management tool. Where most black metal drummers focus the most energy on bass drums or snares
column5: he transfers that intensity towards guiding cymbals into a nervous dance. On ""V""
column6: M.'s ecstatic melody becomes a light of rapture with Darkside's touch
column7: elevating what's already seemingly in the heavens. Across Futility
column8: he brings detail you'd expect from a solo project headed by drum-focused multi-instrumentalists like Leviathan or Panopticon.

column1: It's rare to see two players so clearly meant for each other
column2: and Mgła's accomplished performance on Futility transforms the lyrical content into a call to action. Great metal can harness strength from hopelessness; turning that strength into art is a blustering triumph. ""The great truth is there isn't one"" may be a swift roundhouse
column3: but it's one that it will sober you up to find your own purpose. And on ""IV""
column4: M. howls ""Every empire/ Every nation/ Every tribe/ Thought it would end/ In a bit more decent way
column5: a sentiment that can be applied to more than the collapse of states; it's the radical acceptance that there is no such thing as a clean break. No
column6: Futility doesn't sell you the promise of a better world taken like gummy vitamins. But by offering no promises
column7: it does open you up to take control for yourself
column8:
and what's more positive than that?

A Deerhunter album rollout usually coincides with some pithy and provocative statements from Bradford Cox on pop culture.  He sort of obliged on Fading Frontier
column2: calling most modern pop music ""totally unredeemable"" in an interview. But other than that
column3: he seemed serene: ""<span>Fifteen years I spent proving myself

column5: after the grotty
column6: pissed-off Monomania and Cox's catastrophic car accident comes Deerhunter's most content
column7: warm and plainspoken work to date.

column1: Cox drew an ""influence map"" for this record
column2: one which included R.E.M.
column3: Tom Petty
column4: and INXS. All of these names together clarify something about Cox's intentions: These are amongst the most agreeable rock artists to ever become stars
column5: and Fading Frontier sounds like Deerhunter attempting to create songs that are equally enjoyable in an objective way as ""Free Fallin'"" or ""Need You Tonight"" or ""The One I Love""—ones where if you hear them in a restaurant or car or house party

column1: Deerhunter reunite with Halcyon Digest producer Ben H. Allen
column2: who forgoes his trademark aquatic ambience and booming low-end to approximate the embossed sound of Jeff Lynne or Scott Litt on ""Breaker"" and ""Living My Life"". Even compared to the contemporary indie rock elite working with late-'80s pop-rock at the moment
column3: Fading Frontier sounds happily centrist. Opener ""All the Same"" shares a title with a Real Estate song
column4: as well as their chiming
column5: interlocked guitars and chipper melodic resolutions. The waltz-timed number with tinny drum machine and slide guitar also happens to share a title with Beach House (""Take Care""). These are crisp and professional recordings
column6: midtempo strides with cleanly strummed open chords
column7: broad harmonies and hooks
column8: unbeholden to any particular subgenre or time period. Meanwhile
column9: the harpsichord and high-capoed guitars of ""Duplex Planet"" and ""Carrion"" show a clearheaded psychedelic side of Deerhunter that's more Paisley Underground than Velvet Underground.

column1: Cox has called Fading Frontier his ""domestic"" record
column2: but you shouldn't expect a facade of contentment: ""All the Same"" finds Cox turning his attention to a friend's father
column3: who ""changed his sex and had no more"" out of boredom and loses his wife
column4: kids and will to live as a result. Meanwhile
column5: the foggy ambience of ""Take Care"" parts to reveal Cox singing about burnt dry ice and rotting corpses. The title is not a tender promise
column6: it's a sarcastic
column7: suicidal salutation. Even if Cox hadn't spent much of the past year in recovery
column8: Fading Frontier would likely still obsess over mortality; this is a Deerhunter record
column9: after all
column10: and so we end up with sturdy
column11: industrious pop-rock songs about creeping death
column12: survival and revival. Cox has urged us not to confuse ""I"" with me
column13: but  has spent a significant portion of his life in and out of hospitals
column14: and both ""Snakeskin"" and ""Duplex Planet"" feel inspired by his convalescence."" I don't ever want to go back again to the old folks' home
column15: he sighs on the latter
column16: and it feels like an echo of the riddle he posed on Halcyon Digest's ""Basement Scene
column17: '"" where he claimed
column18: ""I don't want to get old"" and ""I want to get old"".

column1: Perhaps he did mean both.  Note the play on words of the closer ""Carrion""
column2: or hell
column3: the double meaning of ""remains"". If it doesn't initially seem like there's as much at stake as there was on Halcyon Digest or the singleminded commitment of Monomania
column4: Fading Frontier is Cox reckoning with the dissonance of being relatively young man of 33 with a band who's already in legacy-building phase. But the tough talk on ""Snakeskin"" comes from someone whose mere physicality is considered a major health risk and confrontational by default (""I was born already nailed to the cross""). If there isn't a Deerhunter sound

column6:
best summed up in ""All the Same""—""take your handicaps/ Channel them and feed them back/ Until they become your strengths."" The weird era continues.

Halfway through the Drive-By Truckers' new live record
column2: Patterson Hood abruptly stops singing four minutes into “Goode’s Field Road”
column3: a dark song with a paint-by-numbers Truckers premise: a junkyard operator makes some bad decisions and ends up committing suicide to avoid being sent to jail. “He was a god-fearing man
column4: he was a family man
column5: he was a hardworking man
column6: trying to raise his family and support everybody the best he could in difficult times and a troubled economy in North Alabama
column7: ” Hood says
column8: now preaching in front of the band’s minor-chord sludge. By the time Hood finishes expounding on various histories—social
column9: economic
column10: cultural—of his beloved Lauderdale County
column11: the reason for his very un-rock 'n' roll professorial digression becomes clear: sometimes a story can’t be told in just a song.

column1: There are two or three moments like this at every Drive-By Truckers concert
column2: when Patterson Hood the storyteller interrupts Patterson Hood the songwriter
column3: cramming background information that his songs—novelistic in detail
column4: cinematic in scope—can’t quite contain on their own. That’s because at their heart
column5: the Drive-By Truckers are a storytelling band. It’s easy enough to compare Hood to a prolific novelist and Cooley to a modernist poet
column6: but most of their songs could just easily be labeled: based on a true story. That’s the central tenet of the Hood and Cooley’s indignant premise when they first started the Drive-By Truckers in the post-grunge mid-late 90’s: the idea that a young scrappy band can write heroic songs about their grandparents. Why look further than that?

column1: The stories collected on It’s Great to be Alive!
column2: the sprawling
column3: three-plus hour document of the Drive-By Truckers’ 2014 three-night stand at San Francisco’s Fillmore Auditorium
column4: are tall-tales mumbled by friends at the bar
column5: family legends passed on through generations
column6: anecdotes from neighbors romanticized and made grand. As such
column7: a Drive-By Truckers concert can feel like a punk staging of the Southern oral tradition that takes place on front-porches and in rocking chairs. Hood and Cooley act out the role of grizzled elders with countless tales up their sleeve
column8: taking turns swapping their story-songs without any semblance of a setlist. That’s why Truckers shows can also be occasionally exhausting: Sometimes you might just not be in the mood to hear Grandpa Hood launch into that seven minute story about Mary Alice and her chemo treatments again.

column1: This is hardly the first live record the Truckers has released in its near 20-year history. It is
column2: however
column3: the first time the band has tried to faithfully replicate what it feels like to attend a Drive-By Truckers concert. The material
column4: which spans from “Runaway Train”
column5: a song by the pre-Truckers late-80’s incarnation Adam’s House Cat
column6: to a half-dozen selections from last year’s English Oceans
column7: is performed by the slimmer
column8: five-piece lineup the band has used since 2012
column9: after various departures
column10: firings and lineup changes. On stage the band has reworked much of its back-catalogue to fit its current streamlined incarnation
column11: which has grown more sophisticated and elegant in the studio as of late (their last few records contain more piano and banjo than distorted guitar feedback). An unhinged rant like “Sink Hole” is now a precise polemic
column12: whereas the mournful pedal-steel coda to “A Ghost to Most” is now a freewheeling
column13: two-guitar improvisation. The modern-day Truckers are particularly good at such shape-shifting
column14: switching from sloppy to stately from one song to the next.

column1: It’s Great to be Alive! is the sound of a veteran band in complete command of its back-catalog. “Box of Spiders” is reimagined as a country-soul centerpiece
column2: another song that gains multitudes when prefaced with Hood’s four minute story about his relatives. “Sounds Better In The Song” is a revelation in its prickly full-band arrangement
column3: and “The Living Bubba
column4: ” Hood’s ode to a stubborn musician slowly dying of AIDS
column5: sounds more moving with each passing year
column6: an anthem of persistence and survival for a road-weary band still chugging on.

column1: A carefully curated setlist can go a long way
column2: and the tracklisting here benefits a great deal from some post-hoc sequencing. Tales of defeat and struggle promptly segue into stories of defiance and hope. Soul ballads bleed into rockabilly raves. A song like “Goode’s Field Road” is followed by “Uncle Frank”. Although Cooley’s “Uncle Frank” takes place more than 50 years before Hood’s “Goode’s Field Road”
column3: the two stories may nearly be identical: North Alabama tragedies filled with depression and heartless bureaucracy that conclude with suicide. The one-two pairing serves as a quiet
column4: powerful comment on Southern change and progress
column5: or lack thereof. Like the best live records
column6: It’s Great to be Alive! is a carefully curated document that does a great job pretending to be a raw
column7: unfettered documentation of a single night.

column1: As its partially sarcastic
column2: partially dead-serious title suggests
column3: It’s Great to be Alive! serves as a pointed testament to the Drive-By Truckers’ longevity and continuing relevance. A little less than half of the songs on the record come from the band’s post-Jason Isbell period
column4: from their 2008 subtle masterwork Brighter Than Creation’s Dark onward. The subtle interpersonal drama in recent songs like  “Primer Coat” and “Mercy Buckets” are every bit as urgent as older
column5: anthemic statements like “Tornadoes” and “Women Without Whiskey”. Musicians will forever insist that their more recent work holds up alongside their classic material. It’s Great to be Alive! is proof that the Drive-By Truckers’ discography is the rare case where such wishful thinking actually proves true.

column1: “Tell me another story
column2:
” Cooley sings towards the very beginning of their latest live record. “Tell me about the lows and the highs.” The Drive-By Truckers spend the rest of It’s Great to be Alive! proving that they’ve always honored that modest request better than anyone.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22373/homepage_large.e954a7ae.jpg|Central Belters|2801.0|Mogwai|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rock Action']|2015-10-09 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:22.570831|"

In the vinyl-revival era
column2: the box set exists for primarily completists and Record Store Day hoarders—by repackaging entire discographies in 180-gram reissues
column3: they forsake curation for comprehensiveness. But in their initial '80s iteration as CD-stacked behemoths
column4: box sets were actually designed for the casual fan. The earliest paragons of the format—Bob Dylan's Biograph
column5: David Bowie's Sound+Vision—presented expertly compiled overviews of a veteran artist
column6: weaving in hit singles
column7: choice album tracks
column8: rarities and live cuts to form a chronological portrait of their evolution. Sure
column9: they could be prohibitively expensive
column10: but in the days before you could access everything through a YouTube deep dive
column11: box sets made life easy. When faced with the prospect of schooling yourself on an artist 20 albums deep into their career
column12: a three-disc round-up of the best stuff offered maximum return for the least hassle.

column1: So in that sense
column2: there's something quaintly anachronistic about Central Belters
column3: a three-disc (or six-LP) compendium celebrating 20 years of Mogwai. The Scottish art-rockers are ideal subjects for a box-set distillation—they've released eight proper albums
column4: not to mention a handful of soundtracks and stand-alone EPs. They're the sort of reliable band—both in terms of line-up stability and rate of output—that's no doubt lost some old-school fans along the way
column5: and picked up some new ones (2014's Rave Tapes was their first album to crack the UK top 10)
column6: so both camps could benefit from a refresher on what they've missed.

column1: While Mogwai's means have changed over the years
column2: the mood of their records has remained consistent. Pretty much every single Mogwai track resides somewhere on the spectrum between rainy-day melancholy and blood-boiling rage; the only laugh to be had in their discography is in the title of 2003's Happy Songs for Happy People. But they've been so good at recreating that despairing atmosphere on an album-by-album basis
column3: that it's easy to overlook how much they've actually deviated from their formative script. Mogwai are an instrumental band
column4: except when they're not; they're noise-loving sonic sadists
column5: except when they're being tenderly delicate; they're slowcore saddos
column6: except when they're making motorik synth-pop. They're a band you think you know
column7: until you realize you don't recognize them anymore.

column1: Mogwai have evolved in baby steps—each of their records has yielded a track or two that opens up new avenues for the band
column2: without radically altering their essence. But the quasi-chronological
column3: best-of compilation that comprises Central Belters' first two discs has the effect of making that transformation seem much more pronounced and dramatic. The set charts a mostly linear progression
column4: from the stormy psychedelic surges of 1996 single ""Summer"" to last year's neon-tinted dream-pop anthem ""Teenage Exorcists"" (featuring Stuart Braithwaite's most unabashedly melodic vocal performance to date)
column5: but emphasizes the aesthetic outliers in their canon. On any given Mogwai record
column6: the vocal tracks make up maybe 10 per cent of the tracklist; here
column7: it's more like a third
column8: lending this set a more vibrant energy than their albums proper.

column1: Greatest-hits compilations in general are something of an endangered species
column2: given that streaming-service playlists can now generate them for you
column3: but there's still something to be said for getting a band's own take on what they deem essential. (To wit
column4: the ""Intro to Mogwai"" mega-mix on Apple Music features 25 songs; only 12 of them are featured among Central Belters' 34 tracks.) For one
column5: there's a conspicuous lack of tracks from 1997's Young Team
column6: the album that first brought the Glasgow group international attention and solidified their noise-rock bonafides. Yes
column7: Young Team is ably represented by its seismic 16-minute closer ""Mogwai Fear Satan""
column8: but there's seemingly no room for its equally explosive counterpart ""Like Herod""
column9: a song that pushed the well-worn indie-rock quiet/LOUD template to atomic extremes. (Perhaps Mogwai have come to see ""Like Herod"" as their ""Creep""—an early
column10: simply structured
column11: attention-seizing track to which they no longer feel a connection.)

column1: A career survey of Mogwai feels incomplete without ""Herod""
column2: but
column3: otherwise
column4: Central Belters' first disc maps out the band's early peaks: the sad-eyed space rock of ""New Paths to Helicon Pt. 1""
column5: the creeping
column6: tension-tweaking build of ""Christmas Steps""
column7: the mountain-scaling triumphalism of ""2 Rights Make 1 Wrong""
column8: and the chrome-gilded grandeur of ""Hunted By a Freak""
column9: which marked the breakthrough moment where Mogwai's epic canvases began to make room for a more finely tuned pop sensibility.

column1: The second disc covers the era from 2006's Mr. Beast to last fall's Music Industry 3. Fitness Industry 1 EP
column2: over which the band's guitar-powered onslaughts gradually gave way to synth-driven experimentalism. Even with the benefit of a cherry-picked tracklist
column3: Central Belters still can't mask the inertia that set in for Mogwai in the late 2000s
column4: with tracks like Mr. Beast's ""Friend of the Night"" and The Hawk Is Howling's ""I'm Jim Morrison I'm Dead"" following a well-trodden path from desolate piano meditation to cymbal-crashing climax. However
column5: the robo-Pavement groove of Hawk highlight ""The Sun Smells Too Loud"" points the way to the electro excursions of 2011's Hardcore Will Never Die But You Will and last year's Rave Tapes
column6: wherein Mogwai toyed with cruise-controlled Krautrock (""Mexican Grand Prix""
column7: ""How to Be a Werewolf"") and sci-fi soundtrack ambience (""Remurdered"")
column8: and seemed to genuinely loosen up after so many years of painstaking post-rock crescendo-climbing. And with the aforementioned ""Teenage Exorcists""
column9: Mogwai proved themselves capable of writing a proper pop song
column10: even if it took them nearly two decades to figure it out.

column1: Central Belters' third disc is given over to B-sides
column2: EP deep cuts and outtakes
column3: but compared to the carefully curated
column4: crafty sequencing of the first two discs
column5: it feels randomly cobbled together. And though it zig-zags between eras—encompassing everything from the elegiac Come On Die Young era castaway ""Hugh Dallas"" to the band's ragged 2008 collaboration with Roky Erickson
column6: ""Devil Rides"" to a sampling of their Zidane and Les Revenants soundtracks—the overall tone is more dour and mournful. All but one of these tracks have been officially released (the exception being the loungey
column7: laid-back instrumental ""D to E"")
column8: so it's hardly some unearthed treasure trove that warrants a separate presentation. Integrating these tracks into the chronological greatest-hits sequence would've made for a more satisfying overview.

column1: But then that would've meant dropping the disc three finale—the 2001 single ""My Father My King""—halfway through the collection
column2: and it's the sort of song that's nigh impossible to follow. A perennial Mogwai show closer
column3: ""My Father My King"" is the band's wordless cover of the traditional Jewish prayer ""Avinu Malkeinu""
column4: and it's biblical in every sense of the word
column5: using the hymn's dual circular melodies to form a cyclonic 20-minute scorcher. It's the Mogwai song to end all Mogwai songs—and
column6: really
column7: the band never attempted anything as audacious
column8: or brutally savage
column9:
from that point on. Its late-game appearance here reinforces Central Belters' raison d'etre: to trace the throughline between Mogwai's old and new testaments for lapsed fans and new converts alike.

When moves to defund Planned Parenthood attempt to confine female desire

column1: No matter what

column4: a spellbound rave about some heavenly girl whose inner fire she's powerless to resist: ""Desire is coming at me lately

column9: she jokes that she's turning into Medusa

column11: this bitch is goin' crazy/ She'll make you turn to stone.""

column1: Despite all this
column2: Sore enshrines Monks' persistent faith in the transformative power of sex and love. There's a Celtic
column3: Pogues-ish tinge to ""Green""

column6: and the record's loveliest lyric: ""I need food and I need light
column7: and darling I need you/ Just because my heart is clean doesn't mean it's new/ I scrub it up with love anthems written for teens
column8: like by the Libertines."" ""Next Gold"" is festive celebration rock
column9: as Monks swears she'll ""stay chasing dreams tied to the road
column10: spurred by the lingering taste of a car makeout session on her lips. She knows
column11: though
column12: that you can't outrun human nature. ""I wanna change
column13: she bawls on the piercing ""Purple Rage"". ""You can put it on my grave.""

column1: Sore has a definite gothic sensibility
column2: but it's rarely self-serious—only closer ""Burned By the Cold""

the place where the good stuff festers.

Nowadays
column2: a bow usually comes with an arrow in hand and a film camera behind it
column3: though history shows us they've been used as musical instruments ever since 13
column4: 000 BCE
column5: a good deal before Katniss ever picked one up. The concept is pretty simple
column6: just string a cord through a bent stick. Then run it over stuff: other strings
column7: other wood
column8: your hands
column9: etc. That’s it. To this day
column10: they’re still frequently used in Africa
column11: including Swaziland—the once-homeland of Cara Stacey.

column1: To call Stacey well-versed as a musician is an understatement. The South African multi-instrumentalist
column2: composer
column3: and researcher received two master's degrees in musicology and musical performance from various universities in London and Edinburgh—and she's still working on a doctorate. With all that knowledge under her belt
column4: Stacey gives South African music a dizzying
column5: beautiful spin
column6: wielding both an uhadi bow and an umrhubhe bow on eight-song voyage Things That Grow. The difference between the two is their resonators
column7: the section of the bow which broadcasts their otherwise quiet sound. The uhadi is a long bow where the player attaches a gourd to the bow
column8: moving it towards and away from their chest to let out pitch-varying overtones. The umrhubhe is a short bow where the player places their mouth on the bow
column9: manipulating their tongue and throat muscles to highlight harmonics coming off the string. The sound hums with an unusually comforting tone
column10: like a saw being sharpened or the coarse bellow of a violin in need of rosin.

column1: Despite its rootsy instrumentation
column2: the album is a raw collision of experimental classical with jazz. Because Cara Stacey didn't grow up in the rural Eastern Cape
column3: nor was she set in the traditional ways of one of South Africa's most traditional instruments
column4: she’s able to explore the bows’ sounds. Opener “Oscillations” hears her scratch the string repeatedly
column5: building up a wall of buzz until the gentle padding of drums come into focus and
column6: almost immediately after
column7: the carefree whistle of someone strolling through the woods. “Durée” places the notes of her bow at the forefront again
column8: even while upright bass begins to grow
column9: so that its resonator captures her every move. There’s the occasional harsh scratch—think a single pinkie nail on a chalkboard—on a few songs
column10: but otherwise the bows act like a never-ending scroll for the other instruments to hammer out a Morse Code message of complex meditation. Joined by Shabaka Hutchings (clarinet
column11: tenor saxophone)
column12: Seb Rochford (drums)
column13: Ruth Goller (bass)
column14: Hugh Jones aka electronic musician Crewdson (concertronica)
column15: and Dan Leavers (synths)
column16: Stacey darts between animal-like calls over the course of the record
column17: especially on nearly 10-minute album closer “Fox”. On Things That Grow
column18: her companions play sensitively
column19: keeping an eye on her use of the bow as to never overpower it
column20: even with the studio space carefully capturing its nuances. “Sunbird”
column21: full of warm strings and bizarre looped synth
column22: keeps her bow ringing at its core
column23: while it begins to take on the form of a short-seizing robot. Even the eerie bass of “Dark Matter” should go full Wed 21-era Juana Molina on Stacey
column24: its latin-style grooves taking the lead
column25: but they refuse to let it drown her out.

column1: Things That Grow relies heavily on the improvisation of her bandmates and the fluidity with which their melodies play out. The only work composed beforehand by Stacey were melodic aspects and her individual bow parts. Yet that lack of cohesion can drag certain moments of improvisation down. The metal tapping in “Music of the Spheres” veers towards aimlessness in context of the album as a whole. Designated improvisational sections step back for someone else’s solo that occasionally lacks the confidence needed to take over. But improvisation doesn’t have to be indecisive. A track like “Circadian Clocks” treads minimalist repetition with Philip Glass in mind
column2: and
column3: when Stacey reaches far enough
column4: she explores configurations other bow players have yet to publicly investigate
column5: namely bringing the quiet bow into a buzzing room filled with conflicting instruments. For that alone
column6:
Things That Grow sees her shoot the image of the bow farther than we’ve come to understand it in the Western world today.

Louis Carnell
column2: if you’re into neat categorizations
column3: is a grime producer. But his debut album Safe squirms out of all such neat categories. Hailing from suburban south London
column4: Carnell is of grime’s second generation
column5: scholarly about its history but not hidebound by its rules. His more conventional productions have leant towards the energetic and darkside—see his 2013 track “Snakes”
column6: the murky swing of its beats accompanied by the crack of gunshots. But increasingly
column7: Visionist has shed conspicuous genre trappings and shucked off layers
column8: too
column9: tending towards something more minimal
column10: introspective and haunted. His two I’m Fine EPs
column11: released on the New York-based label Lit City Trax in 2013 and 2014
column12: were ethereal and virtually beatless
column13: barely grime at all. They explored
column14: said Carnell
column15: the five stages of grief—the journey from denial to anger to acceptance
column16: known to psychiatrists as the Kübler-Ross model. About the precise nature of his loss
column17: though
column18: Carnell was keeping schtum.

column1: Since
column2: Carnell has joined forces with Bill Kouligas of the Berlin-based label PAN to create a new sub-label Codes—a sort of reboot of his earlier label Lost Codes
column3: dedicated to outliers in the grime matrix. And now the debut Visionist album appears on PAN
column4: and comes with a theme not unlike I’m Fine—billed as “a personal portrait of anxiety” that traces the onset and passing of a panic attack. This subject came as a little bit of a surprise
column5: as I interviewed Carnell in 2014 and he struck me as coolly self-assured in that way that you might easily read as arrogance. Still
column6: reflect on the crisp meticulousness of his music—those deft flurries of icy melody
column7: vocal samples diced as if by scalpel—and perhaps you can perceive a telltale tension in his hand
column8: a yearning for precision and control.

column1: As with the I’m Fine EPs
column2: Safe finds Carnell working extensively with the human voice. Broadly
column3: his approach with vocals recalls that of Burial: both filch acapellas from pop and R&B records before bending them out of shape and turning them to new ends. In Burial’s productions
column4: though
column5: vocal lines generally remain vocal lines
column6: while what Carnell does with them feels rather more baroque. On Safe
column7: these voices are assembled as melody lines – cloned
column8: layered and pitched way up until they form a fluttering polyphony
column9: or glitter like jewels in a crown. (Perhaps a closer reference point for Carnell’s sampling technique would be Fatima Al-Qadiri’s Asiatisch; indeed
column10: the pair collaborated on an earlier Visionist track
column11: “The Call”
column12: their breathy melodies arranged as point and counterpoint).

column1: The track titling—“Tired Tears
column2: Awake Fears”
column3: “Let Me In”
column4: “Constraint”—indicates something of the territory that Safe seeks to cover
column5: a landscape in which love equals imprisonment and feelings skirted or repressed. Around beautiful melodies
column6: Carnell arranges more dissonant sounds to imply pain or unease. On the opening “You Stayed”
column7: a diva's cry is encased in a prison of cascading
column8: pointillist melodies and queasy timbres. On “Victim”
column9: metallic percussion pounds without mercy
column10: while up in the higher registers
column11: synthesized strings sketch out a sad elegy and voices curl into gasps
column12: sobs and whimpers. Sometimes
column13: vocal lines repeat themselves
column14: numbly circling as if frozen in some kind of Stygian limbo—see the closing refrain of “Too Careful To Care”
column15: a cry of “In my head…” that repeats over and over
column16: pitched alternately high
column17: low and midrange
column18: as if in search of some sort of escape route. Elsewhere
column19: Carnell’s disembodied cries strike more graceful notes
column20: as if their wordlessness allows them to softly alight on truths over which mortal sentences clumsily stumble.

column1: Key to Carnell’s style is a sense of spaciousness
column2: although Safe is more filled out
column3: less minimal than the I’m Fine material. Still
column4: it is seldom predictable. The breathtaking
column5: gothic “1 Guarda” moves forth on ticking hats and dull rumbles that sound like rotating granite pillars
column6: and where there are beats
column7: they upset expectations. Floor-trembling bass bombs erupt spasmodically throughout “Constraint” and ""Safe""
column8: while “Let Me In” rolls forth on the sort of booming trap undercarriage you might expect to hear blasting from a passing jeep—although everything above that is a mirage

column11: and this is where Safe is at its very prettiest. “Sleep Luxury” is a washed-out grime lullaby adorned by twinkling harp and the ripple of running water
column12: while the cold chimes of “Sin-cere” appear to fantasize a music box sculpted wholly from ice.

column1: This year has been a banner year for producers working at grime’s outer reaches. On the one hand
column2: the likes of M.E.S.H. and Rabit have released records that intensify grime’s alien skitter into something harsh
column3: mechanical
column4: and abstracted. In parallel

column6: pioneered by Mumdance and Logos’ Different Circles imprint
column7: pulls away layers
column8: lifts grime off the road and into the stratosphere. Safe draws on elements of both
column9: but more than any of his peers
column10: Carnell has succeeded in making a statement that feels not just a flexing of experimental techniques
column11: but something rich and human
column12: too. Perhaps its closest recent antecedent is Arca’s Xen
column13: another record dealing with the desire to shed one’s skin
column14: slip free of this prison of the flesh. Diaphanous of texture but heavy of spirit
column15: Safe revolves upon this tension
column16:
the pressure point of a soul under strain.

column1: The siloed existence of Circle Star Records is an explicit effort to clear up that confusion. Its artists don't fit neatly into Stones Throw's traditional output

column6: Ariel Pink

column1: The most exciting tracks here have rougher reference points. The undergirding riff on ""Rollercoaster Baby""

column1: Spot the Influence can be a critic's shell game

But the fact that Brettin's many reference points are so obvious suggests a problem with the music of Mild High Club: the act's identity is so loose that listeners will have trouble ignoring its artistic antecedents. If this is musical pointillism

column5: say
column6: Stones Throw

and chalk it up to another good-but-not-great album from a label that still hasn't quite figured out a unified new direction.

column1: Casual fans won’t be overcome with excitement upon learning the band’s Florasongs EP was culled from leftovers from the Terrible World sessions. Even for Decemberists diehards
column2: an addendum to the band’s most forgettable album probably wasn’t high on the wish list
column3: and the EP reaffirms what Terrible World already made clear: that Colin Meloy brought an abundance of songs to these sessions
column4: but not much in the way of a big picture. Unlike its full-length counterpart
column5: though
column6: Florasongs has brevity working in its favor. These days
column7: the Decemberists sound best in small doses
column8: and at just five songs and 19 minutes long
column9: the EP goes down easier than its predecessor.

column1: If the EP has a unifying thread
column2: it’s the band’s wide-eyed fascination with '80s college rock. Filled with ringing guitars and taut melodies
column3: ""Why Would I Now?"" moves with the swift efficiency of Elvis Costello’s King of America-era output. A shanty caressed with accordions
column4: ""Riverswim"" plays like it was traced over the Pogues’ ""Dirty Old Town"". And though Decemberists have so fully internalized R.E.M.’s playbook by now that they could probably turn around a Lifes Rich Pageant tribute album on two days’ notice
column5: ""The Harrowed and the Haunted"" is one of their most elegant homages
column6: building to the same lovely
column7: slow reveal as R.E.M.’s dreamiest numbers. Even the Communist Russia setting of ""Fits & Starts""
column8: the EP’s lone rocker
column9: feels like a throwback to the Reagan era in its own way. ""I was watching on the apparat/ Some comely little apparatchik felled
column10: Meloy sings over pounding pianos. As rowdy party songs go
column11: it’s hardly AC/DC
column12: but it’s about as close as he’ll get.

column1: As The King Is Dead proved
column2: there’s still some pleasure in hearing a relatively reigned-in Decemberists. But while the band wears restraint well
column3: Florasongs never overcomes the sense that they’re selling themselves short
column4: penning good-enough songs when they used to shoot for grand
column5: great ones. This is a band that once thrived on risks. The Crane Wife shouldn’t have worked but it did. The Hazards of Love shouldn’t have worked and
column6: by and large
column7: it didn’t
column8: and ever since they've been playing it safe. After five years of bowling with bumpers
column9:
maybe it’s time for them to start taking chances once again.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22302/homepage_large.3a0607ec.jpg|GO:OD AM|30111.0|Mac Miller|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2015-10-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:26.211714|"

Who is Mac Miller? On Blue Slide Park
column2: he was a childish ""frat rapper"" who made dumb jokes about smoking weed and referred to the vagina as a ""cooter."" On the claustrophobic Watching Movies With the Sound Off
column3: he was rapping in a pitched-down voice alongside Earl Sweatshirt and Ab-Soul about friends lost
column4: drugs consumed
column5: depression
column6: and the trappings of success. And on the transparent
column7: relaxed GO:OD AM
column8: he sounds like someone’s troubled little brother made good: from the album’s opening horns
column9: you can sense that this is a victory lap for Mac
column10: a homecoming.

column1: From start to finish
column2: this is his most refined and well put-together project. Getting through the 16 tracks on Blue Slide Park was like an endurance test
column3: and even the deeper and much-improved Watching Movies started to sound interchangeable before it ended. The beats on GO:OD AM have a New York
column4: boom-bap feel
column5: with lots of jazz samples and harder drums
column6: and it’s both more varied and more upbeat
column7: from the trap-sounding beats of  ""When in Rome"" or the Chief Keef-featuring ""Cut the Check"" to love songs like ""ROS"" or the Miguel collaboration ""The Weekend"". Miller said he recorded 400 songs for Watching
column8: and sometimes you couldn’t help but wonder about the selection process (""Objects in the Mirror""?) but on GO:OD AM
column9: he’s learned to self-edit.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Mac offers a music industry ""Scared Straight"". ""I’ve seen some motherfucking shit
column3: he warns on ""Two Matches"". The interlude before ""God Speed"" includes a voicemail from his brother
column4: checking in on him at a low point in his life
column5: and later on in the song
column6: he admits: ""White lines be numbing them dark times/ Them pills that I’m popping
column7: I need to man up/ Admit it’s a problem
column8: I need a wake up/ Before one morning
column9: I don’t wake up."" It’s funny to hear a 23-year-old who just kicked his habit and could be considered a kid himself refer regretfully to ""all the kids doing drugs"" on ""In the Bag""
column10: but Mac has enough of his sense of humor intact to keep the album from playing like a D.A.R.E. campaign on wax.

column1: On ""God Speed""
column2: the album’s standout track
column3: he pays tribute to the close friends in his Most Dope Family
column4: especially his right hand man Q
column5: and it’s genuinely touching. ""Everybody saying I need rehab/ So I’m speeding with a blindfold on/ It won’t be long before they watching me crash/ And they don’t wanna see that
column6: he raps
column7: thanking the people that got him through the toughest time of his life. He’s never preachy
column8: though: He sounds refreshed and rejuvenated
column9: like someone who has been going for daily walks
column10: eating veggies and drinking fruit smoothies every day.

column1: Many songs here reference his status as a white rapper
column2: signaling his awareness of the rap game’s perception of him: ""I’m a white rapper/ They always call me shady
column3: he says on ""Brand Name""
column4: just a few minutes into the album. ""I know niggas think you white and you not about to go in with these bars
column5: chimes in Domo Genesis on ""In the Bag"". There’s a kind of authenticity to him that has been there since the beginning
column6: if you look for it: He doesn’t rap about breaking the law
column7: because he’s not about that life. He’s a corny white rapper (meant as a compliment) who loves his family
column8: friends
column9: and hometown. We might not learn a lot of specifics about him
column10:
but there’s a lot of honesty in his music if you look for it.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22432/homepage_large.35f512a6.jpg|Beach Music|32330.0|Alex G|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2015-10-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:26.803774|"

Alex Giannascoli reached audiences beyond Bandcamp for the first time last year with DSU
column2: a mostly upbeat collection of bedroom-spun indie rock that showcased a 21-year-old Philadelphian with a knack for songcraft and a tinkerer's curiosity. Under the moniker of Alex G
column3: he has made seven full lengths
column4: most of which he put out himself. Beach Music is his Domino debut and
column5: as he is poised to reach an even larger audience
column6: he lets his weirder and darker instincts run rampant.

column1: Giannascoli opens the curtains on Beach Music with a restless experiment that sounds like a cruddy bootleg of Aphex Twin trying to make beats for Scratch Acid. Distant yelling
column2: electronic beats and lo-fi guitars all meet in a track that's less than a minute and sets the ground rules that this will not be Alex G's big
column3: accessible breakthrough. He segues into ""Bug""
column4: a traditional indie rock recipe of acoustic strums and stereo-panned electric guitars sprinkled with harmonics. The song is moody and intriguing
column5: and just when you think it might be a good playlist candidate for a road trip with your parents
column6: he warps his voice into Chipmunk territory on the line ""bug in the crosshair"".

column1: Alex G has often used pitch-shifting
column2: but he deploys it more than ever on Beach Music. ""Brite Boy"" sends his voice up a few notches to play a girl whose affection the title character will spurn and whose help he will reject
column3: while ""Station"" brings his voice down so he can embody a homeless man breaking into a liquor store.  And ""Salt"" features both high and low voices
column4: like tribes of ogres and elves uniting in song.

column1: These moments bring to mind the similar voice trickery of Ween
column2: who formed just about 50 miles north of Havertown
column3: Pennsylvania
column4: where Giannascoli grew up. The difference between the two lies in their motivation: Ween used the trick for comic effect
column5: but Alex G doesn’t seem like he’s goofing around. Ween wrote in the liner notes for The Pod that they were huffing Scotchgard while recording—though they've since said they were bluffing—but Alex G makes no narcotic admissions whatsoever.  Regardless if the composition process involved new chemicals or not
column6: it's clear that a lot of nefarious characters are lurking in these songs. Giannascoli's style has been compared to Elliott Smith in the past
column7: and that's often been true of his presentation
column8: but on <i>Beach Music
column9: it's as if the characters from Smith's darker songs have wandered over to Giannascoli's world
column10: and they're a lot worse for wear.

column1: Most of the songs have one-word titles and the lyrics are both vague and evocative. These traits come together best in the haunting and sweet ""Mud"". For this track
column2: Giannascoli reaches beyond the pitch-shifter and gets an actual additional human being
column3: Emily Yacina
column4: to harmonize with him. When the pair repetitively whisper-sing
column5: ""I know something you don't know
column6: "" your mind leaps to the worst conclusions of what this ""something"" could be
column7: as nauseous keys creep into the arrangement and overtake the sounds of fingers skating up and down the frets of an acoustic guitar.

column1: Some of the songs also feature the slightly atonal jangle that Pavement eventually claimed as their sound when they became a full band. What is remarkable about Beach Music is that some of these arrangements beg for you to dismiss them
column2: the way you might have the very first time you heard Pavement
column3: but what at first feels sloppy and clogged is actually intricate upon closer inspection. Complicated arrangements and gorgeous melodies reveal themselves  to you as rewards for your patience. Over time
column4: even the alien voices begin to sound natural
column5:
even inviting.
