column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22382/homepage_large.e9aac5ac.jpg|Where All Is Fled|29955.0|Steve Hauschildt|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kranky']|2015-10-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:27.360205|"

Steve Hauschildt was always the quiet Emerald. While John Elliott was headbanging away to rhythms that only he could hear and Mark McGuire adopted the traditional grimace of rock'n'roll axemen since time immemorial
column2: Hauschildt stood stock-still behind his synths
column3: like a member of Kraftwerk who had strayed from the assembly line. Since the Cleveland synth-and-guitar trio's 2013 split
column4: Elliott has poured his energies into his Spectrum Spools label's considerable output
column5: and Mark McGuire has put out six or seven new records
column6: some with a considerable shred quotient. Hauschildt
column7: meanwhile
column8: has mostly kept his head down. Last year he released S/H
column9: a double-CD collection of studio experiments
column10: live cuts
column11: and CD-R favorites
column12: but Where All Is Fled is his first album of new material since 2012's Sequitur. That album surprised many listeners
column13: given the way that it balanced Hauschildt's customary ambient burble with pert drum-machine programming
column14: vocoder
column15: and synth-pop flourishes. But Where All Is Fled swings the pendulum back towards his sweet spot
column16: musically speaking: gentle arpeggios
column17: chiming leads
column18: sunrise synths poised on the brink between sublimity and kitsch. It's his most emotionally potent offering yet
column19: taking the gentle ecstasy of previous records and drawing it into a deep
column20: soul-cleansing reverie.

column1: Hauschildt lays all his cards out on the table with ""Eyelids Gently Dreaming""
column2: a graceful piece built around a melodic chord progression
column3: steady as an IV drip
column4: that sounds a lot like Stars of the Lid—is the title a giveaway?—rendered with synthesizers instead of guitars and strings. ""Anesthesia""
column5: a weightless shimmer that sounds like something off Cocteau Twins' Victorialand run through a very expensive reverb unit
column6: suggests what you'd get if King Midas picked up an opiate habit. And the unabashedly sentimentalist title track wouldn't be out of place in an On Golden Pond reboot
column7: what with its teary-eyed piano melody. Still
column8: there's a strangeness to the overall sound—the piano pocked with stuttering artifacts
column9: Fennesz-style distortion looming beneath—that sets it apart. Even when he's reaching for his hanky
column10: he's careful to keep one hand on his synth
column11: tweaking away in search of the perfect patch.

column1: But it's not all so slow-moving; On tracks like ""Vicinities""
column2: ""Edgewater Prelude""
column3: and ""The World Is Too Much With Us""
column4: Hauschildt channels his energy into arpeggios that spin like sparkling dynamos. ""Arpeggiare"" is particularly lively
column5: with dizzying delay taps suggesting Frippertronics in zero-G. His newfound focus on pulse sometimes leads him to forms approaching a kind of drum-free dance music. The cosmic ""Sundialed""
column6: with its wild
column7: chromatic leaps
column8: is not so far off from Lindstrom's super-saturated space disco
column9: and ""Caduceus"" is reminiscent of John Beltran's Ten Days of Blue
column10: Detroit Escalator Co.'s Black Buildings
column11: and other examples of techno at its most yearning. And fans of Pub's ""Summer""
column12: a now-obscure dub techno single from 2000
column13: will be thrilled by how uncannily Hauschildt has recreated that song's watery bliss.

column1: While it's true that much of the album represents a refinement of ideas and processes that Hauschildt has been playing with for years
column2: at least one song
column3: ""Lifelike""
column4: points to possible avenues for further development. Like ""Aqueuus""
column5: it's a wonderfully watery meditation on the kinetics of bubbles. Chimes and plucks peel off into rippling delay chains
column6: and the shimmering melodic line suggests a lullaby for jellyfish; it's a picture of biology as rapture
column7: of physics as ecstasy. We've always known that Hauschildt could make amazing sounds. The question
column8: going into this album
column9:
was whether he could give them purpose and meaning—whether he could put his technical mastery into the service of music at once experimental and lyrical. Where All Is Fled answers resoundingly in the affirmative.

"|21095.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21095-where-all-is-fled/|7.5|Philip Sherburne

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22368/homepage_large.facd011f.jpg|Da Reality Show|10852.0|Young Dro|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Entertainment One']|2015-10-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:28.102506|"

Grand Hustle rapper and former T.I. sideman Young Dro has been surprisingly good at maintaining relevance in an ever-changing rap landscape. To anyone not paying attention
column2: his return to the mainstream with his viral Vine hit ""FDB"" in 2013 was probably out of left field
column3: but in truth he's been around the whole time: producing a steady stream of mostly solid mixtapes and using his always slightly-offbeat eccentricity to keep the songs exciting. Da Reality Show
column4: Young Dro's third major-label album
column5: is an acknowledgement of Dro's place in the current rap landscape; it's at once an album that could have easily dropped shortly after 2006's Best Thang Smokin'
column6: yet still feels refreshingly new without being forced.

column1: Dro has been making music since the early '00s
column2: but we're coming up on 10 years since his first major album
column3: and Da Reality Show is a celebration of and a reflection on a life well-lived
column4: full of goofiness
column5: giddiness and sobering reminiscence.  He's feeling himself—""I kilt the streets and made history""
column6: he boasts on ""Coupe""—and very few are as good at doing that as Dro is
column7: with as many undertones. On the song ""Dead""
column8: he raps: ""Hope yo ass be ready for the fed/Hope yo ass be ready for the lead/Hope you ready for the hospital bed/dopeboy
column9: dopeboy
column10: now the nigga dead"" as a way of calling out another dealer as a sucker. It's typical braggadocio
column11: but in it also is a glimmer of awareness about the inevitabilities of trap life.

column1: This introspective honesty carries the back half of the album.  ""I know how it feel to be numba one/I know how it feel to be numba nothin’”
column2: he raps soberly on “Feeling Myself”. Dro seems comfortable enough with who he is to put his real self on record
column3: and the record carries the gravity that comes with seeing both the highs and lows a long rap career can bring.

column1: He also has a natural sense of how he fits into the sounds of rap radio today without compromising his essence.  The album finds Dro perfectly at ease with the sound of current Atlanta and making it work for him instead of the other way around. The Zaytoven-assisted ""Ugh"" is a melodic and busy hymnal
column2: and amid Zaytoven's menagerie of sounds
column3: Dro's is the best instrument. He glides through it
column4: crooning then rapping like his words are drum kicks to making playful ad-libs and ad-libbing on top of those ad-libs. It's an effortless energy and showmanship that he carries into the next track ""Parallel Park"". The church organs that surround the song are appropriate; Dro captures your attention and is as theatrical in his style as an Atlanta Megachurch Preacher.

column1: Da Reality Show would have probably been better off holding onto this momentum
column2: because the traditional attempts at inspirational anthems in the back half feel a little forced
column3: and lack the freewheeling excitement of the rest of the album. At the end
column4: however
column5: Dro allows himself to really get sentimental on ""Hood Gospel""
column6: reflecting on lost love and the murder of his mother. The pain is audible in his voice
column7: but so is the full-hearted joy and wonder at his rise from those traumatic experiences to where he is now. It is a beautiful moment and a reminder that behind all the boasts about exotic-colored cars and women
column8:
there is a man who just wants to share his testimony.

"|21080.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21080-da-reality-show/|7.4|Israel Daramola

column3: the L.A.-via-D.C. singer Kelela spoke about the challenges of performing electronic music in a live setting. ""I feel like I just want my emotions to be at the forefront of my performance
column4: and if anything distracts from that

column6: she told The Cut
column7: riffing on the experience of seeing the veteran of digital feelings
column8: Björk
column9: on stage. That kind of resonant tactility also goes a long way when it comes to listening to electronic music

column1: Her new EP
column2: Hallucinogen
column3: uses the gristle and guts of feeling as a thematic base for exploring new textures in music. Like Cut 4 Me

column5: sensitive
column6: hi-definition approach to R&B. Some of the producers are the same (Kingdom
column7: Nguzunguzu’s MA) and some are new (Arca
column8: Kendrick and Drake collaborator DJ Dahi)
column9: but these partnerships hew to what’s now the Kelela template: soulful songs with unpredictable
column10: assaultive drum patterns
column11: whorls of whimsical synthesizer effects
column12: and so much processing on the vocals that it sounds like you’re listening to a transmission from tomorrow. The deconstructed clatter of FKA twigs—who also worked with Arca—might be from another dimension altogether
column13: but Kelela
column14: whose music feels like there is blood flowing through it
column15: looks to a future with a decidedly human shape.

column1: Kingdom
column2: who co-produces the EP’s sole uptempo track
column3: ""Rewind""
column4: is a student of Timbaland’s slick approach to pop-R&B. Alongside Kelela and Nugget
column5: he channels that
column6: as well as the bounce of Jazze Pha
column7: for the song
column8: which is the EP’s lead single and a showpiece for Kelela’s much-improved singing. ""All the Way Down"" pulls rap producer DJ Dahi into completely different terrain; the shudders of hi-hat trills provide the seams
column9: but the print he’s working with is studded with twinkling synths that gives way to a droning. Dahi’s beat doesn’t explicitly recall Aaliyah
column10: but Kelela's voice does—she riffs on the melody and phrasing and pillow talk-closeness of the late singer’s 1999 track
column11: ""I Don’t Wanna"" (incidentally
column12: a Jazze Pha production).

column1: More pressing is the existential rumble that bookends the EP. ""All I know is all I’ve got/ Is it hard to face all we lost?
column2: Kelela questions on the desolate opener ""A Message"". Arca’s hollow kickdrums prod the song along at a ragged crawl
column3: allowing Kelela to wring out a melody with her voice while he fills the space with funereal
column4: yawping organ-like patches. It’s the only song on the EP
column5: aside from closer ""The High""
column6: in which Kelela sings without heavy reverb or effects
column7: heightening its somber quality.

column1: ""And I’ll do anything for the high
column2: she urges a placid lover on the latter
column3: the piercing hook contrasting with her hushed verses. In content—and maybe even in producer Gifted & Blessed’s tranquil heartbeat—it’s a song that feels spiritually descended from the Weeknd. And there's another connection: writing on Pitchfork about the Weeknd’s music and its inherited ambience
column4: Hannah Giorgis described a ""long Ethiopian musical legacy of tortured pining
column5: and it’s instructive to think that Kelela—whose family is also from Ethiopia—may have absorbed a similar propensity for mournful music.

column1: If you consider that Kelela’s roots are in soul and R&B
column2: the emotional side of her music makes sense. The mechanics of dance music might inspire feelings in listeners
column3: but within the genre
column4: overrun with the egos and opinions of ""bro-teurs
column5: her emotions are revolutionary. She is a transparent creator
column6: unafraid of tainting the canvases of her mostly male collaborators with the imperfect
column7:
vulnerable contents of her brain and heart.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22232/homepage_large.a76c3d5e.jpg|The Agent Intellect|31429.0|Protomartyr|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hardly Art']|2015-10-07 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:29.242291|"

In what feels like an odd moment of prescience
column2: roughly halfway through The Agent Intellect
column3: the harrowing third album from the Detroit band Protomartyr
column4: the Pope pays a visit. It’s 1987 in Pontiac
column5: Mich.
column6: and Pope John Paul II is visiting the Silverdome
column7: delivering Mass to the 100
column8: 000 faithful who’d come to hear him speak. Among them was a young Joe Casey who
column9: 25 years later
column10: would grow up to become Protomartyr’s frontman. The event was historic—it set an attendance record at the arena—but what Casey remembers about it in ""Pontiac 87"" isn’t the beauty of the sermon or the spectacle in the ceremony
column11: but the ugliness boiling just beneath the surface. On his way into the arena
column12: he sees ""money changing between hands
column13: and on his way out
column14: a riot
column15: where ""Old folks turn brutish/ Trampling their way out the gates towards heaven.""

column1: This is the universe Protomartyr inhabits
column2: one where violence hovers constantly at the periphery
column3: where peace and hope gradually curdle and turn ugly
column4: and the desperate people who once clung to them eventually fall prey to their worst impulses. The emotionally brutal Under Color of Official Right from 2014 took place against the crumbling skyline of Detroit
column5: where deadbeat fathers disappeared into bars while their children planned revenge at home and politicians made backwards deals that benefited no one but themselves. On Intellect
column6: Casey’s got bigger matters on his mind. The first character we meet on the record is
column7: literally
column8: the Devil
column9: but he doesn’t have red horns and a trident
column10: and he’s not cackling in a smoldering cavern. He’s a teenager in his bedroom at home
column11: full of promise and almost dewy-eyed naiveté until his peers shun him and all of his grand plans fail
column12: and he’s left at the end of the song vowing
column13: ""I will make them feel the way I do/ I’ll corrupt them ‘til they think the way I do."" If Right was about the evil that men do
column14: Intellect goes one bigger and asks why they do it. The answer
column15: again and again
column16: is rooted in hurt
column17: pain
column18: neglect
column19: and disappointment.

column1: Intellect draws its energy from the panic of mortality. Casey lost his father to a heart attack and his mother to Alzheimer’s disease as he was writing the record
column2: and their presence on Intellect provides some of its most wrenching emotional moments. His mother arrives strong and determined on the grim
column3: booming ""Why Does It Shake?""
column4: swearing
column5: ""Lithe in thought and pumping blood…I’m never gonna lose it
column6: but suddenly the song collapses and decays. It concludes with the chilling appearance of ""the stranger"" who
column7: in Casey’s words
column8: always wins—""He enters the temple/ It falls/ It always falls."" The song’s title comes from something Casey’s mother said
column9: noticing the tremors of old age in her hands. That sound of the ticking clock makes all of the violence and drunkenness on Intellect seem that much more desperate
column10: that much more futile.

column1: Throughout the album
column2: the band rises to meet the weighty subject matter. On Right
column3: songs arrived in brute slashes
column4: but on Intellect they’re textured and spacious. Guitarist Greg Ahee cloaks ""Cowards Starve"" in a Morricone-like cowboy flange
column5: gradually gathering tension until the song detonates in the chorus. ""Dope Cloud"" rides a razor-wire post-punk guitar line as its protagonists accumulate treasure only to be met with Casey’s bleak reminder
column6: ""That’s not gonna save you
column7: man."" And in ""Ellen""
column8: a love song written from the perspective of Casey’s father to his mother
column9: they beautifully underplay
column10: supporting the song’s sweet sentiment in feathery chords.

column1: But it is Casey who has undergone the greatest evolution. Casey has described his stage demeanor as ""30 minutes of a fat guy yelling at you
column2: but on Intellect
column3: he’s more measured
column4: and his writing has developed an almost Joycean grasp of detail and narrative. The second verse of ""Pontiac 87"" feels like something that could have turned up in ""The Dead"": a crowd of regulars pile into the Detroit bar Jumbo’s (familiar to Protomartyr fans from its appearance on No Passion All Technique) the day after Christmas. Casey describes the scene with such stunning narrative economy you can almost see the lines on their faces: ""Remembering a Jumbo’s night
column5: December 26th/ Weird faces filled up the bar
column6: half sober/ Outside
column7: a steady snow—all new white."" He’s also become a powerful
column8: passionate singer. His delivery throughout Intellect has gravity and nuance; he’s able to make a sing-along out of the line ""Social pressures exist/ And if you think about them all of the time/ You’re gonna find that your head’s been kicked in."" He goes from baleful and bereft to nasty and snarling
column9: commanding “Destroy the gateway
column10: bind them up
column11: break the circuit
column12: cast them out.”

column1: And what he’s driving at
column2: again and again
column3: is that we do all of those things when we feel like trapped animals
column4: when we’ve thrown our full bodies into life and it’s given us nothing back but loneliness and poverty and emptiness
column5: and each advancing year is less time we have to do something of substance. It’s a profound and uncomfortable truth
column6: and it’s one that The Agent Intellect unflinchingly stares down.

column1: All of this is highlighted to shattering effect in ""Uncle Mother’s"". At first
column2: it seems like another in a long line of Protomartyr bar tableaus
column3: the battered working class piling into a dive to suck down Old Styles until the world seems bearable again. The revelation of the song’s true meaning comes in what at first feels like a throwaway detail. At the start of the song
column4: Casey advises
column5: ""Welcome to Uncle Mother’s/ Leave your children in the car."" From there the carousing begins
column6: and the usual boxes are checked: there’s a drug deal in the kitchen and bad doings in the back corner. But at the end of the song
column7: Casey repeats himself
column8: and turns a declarative into a question: ""Welcome to Uncle Mother’s/ Are your children still in the car?"" In that moment it becomes clear that the subject of the song isn’t the drunks—it’s the children. That subtle shift is what gives the record its almost palpable sense of humanity
column9: of sorrow
column10: of compassion. On The Agent Intellect
column11: we are all the children
column12: shivering alone in an empty station wagon in a bitter Detroit night
column13:
waiting in vain for someone to come and take us home.

Stretch music
column2: according to New Orleans jazz musician Christian Scott
column3: is an approach that engenders a more absorbent and sensitive kind of jazz. ""We are attempting to stretch—not replace—jazz's rhythmic
column4: melodic and harmonic conventions to encompass as many musical forms/languages/cultures as we can
column5: he says on his website. He titled his fifth album after the concept
column6: but this sensibility is visible even in his earliest work as a leader; the title track of 2007's Anthem is jazz in its instrumentation
column7: but it also obeys the rhythms and structures of post-hardcore
column8: a series of contrasting shapes which build an atomically tense and spectral space
column9: like a cathedral at night.

column1: His description of ""stretch music"" somewhat resembles the omnivorous jazz approaches of bassist/singer Esperanza Spalding and pianist Robert Glasper. It's similarly collaborative and elastic. But Scott's genre splicing is not as mosaic as Glasper's. It’s doesn’t lock different genres together in unusual patterns as much as it melts them down into asymmetrical and indivisible sculpture. It's almost curious to call it ""stretch music"" when it feels as if jazz isn’t so much expanded here as collapsed into small
column2: oblique jewels.

column1: Later in his mission statement
column2: Scott describes his intention to draw unusual instruments through distortion. This is how Stretch Music begins: A piano
column3: played by Lawrence Fields
column4: struggles through noise
column5: as if pressing and blurring against a force field. Instruments undergo a kind of metamorphosis in Scott’s aesthetic
column6: which is reflected in the album cover: his trumpet bends and warps into elastic shapes.

column1: On record
column2: Scott’s playing is patient and crisp
column3: and it seems the product of spatial reasoning
column4: more concerned with the area around his notes than their actual occurrence. He is sometimes accompanied by the ribbony flute phrases of Elena Pinderhughes
column5: which contrast pleasingly with the routine collapse of the backdrop.

column1: This collapse is occasioned by the percussion
column2: played by Corey Fonville and Joe Dyson
column3: Jr.
column4: alternately on drums and SPD-SX pads. Snare rolls are enhanced into dense exaggerations
column5: glitching in and out of compressed rattles which physically approach vortexes of static. It lends the songs the accelerated yet organized rhythms of accident; it reminds me of sparks convulsing from a severed cable.

column1: Sometimes the instrumentation is more obscure
column2: as on ""Tantric"" and ""Perspectives""
column3: each chord landing and shimmering with a kind of blurred phosphorescence. There are also more typical fusion exercises
column4: as on ""West of the West""
column5: where Matthew Stevens’ guitar recalls the metallic echo of Sonny Sharrock.

column1: When Scott played at this year’s New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival
column2: he said ""West of the West"" describes the sense of dislocation he felt when he lived in L.A.
column3: a place that seems unlocked from its own geography
column4: released into imaginary and aggressively blank space. His music is the opposite of dislocated; it is thoroughly articulated
column5:
busy and compressed. The reach of Stretch Music can often feel literal—even as the threads warp and drift a deeply woven structure is preserved.

Whenever Shopping are asked whether they’re a political band

column3: they say: of being delivered by a queer woman of color

column1: There’s no shortage of academic texts citing the radical nature of movement
column2: but the trio’s second album
column3: Why Choose
column4: is blissfully direct and free of added intellectual ballast. When so much modern discourse is a teetering layer cake of opinions
column5: it’s bliss to hear Rachel Aggs celebrate idleness in one breath—over the awkward twangs of ""Time Wasted""—and then demand urgency on ""Why Wait""’s anxious
column6: accelerated disco hi-hats. As she puts it in the latter
column7: ""Why choose when I just want it both ways?/ When I could just take it all?/ I wanna do it my way.""

column1: To that end
column2: very few of Shopping’s post-punk moves are novel
column3: but the trio maintain an exhilarating
column4: crafty pace
column5: having upped the detail and twisted the structures of their songs since 2013’s Consumer Complaints. The almost uniformly plain guitar tone used throughout is a great showcase for their bright and endlessly varied post-punk tangles. Their nimble songs barely touch the ground
column6: other than the occasional coldwave synth breeze
column7: or seawashed motorik splash à la Electrelane
column8: touches that make for lovely
column9: errant starbursts in Shopping’s otherwise tightly martialed constellations.

column1: A sense of street-smarts survival runs through Why Choose: The rattling guitar of ""Wind Up"" and ""Knocking"" is scrappy as a young bare-knuckle boxer. ""Take It Outside"" runs on caustic pep
column2: mocking the language of empty threat with drummer Andrew Milk delivering weary pleas to ""break it up."" By contrast
column3: the record’s sincere
column4: personal moments don’t posture. On the brisk ""I Have Decided""
column5: Agga adopts a deep
column6: unyielding tone to declare
column7: ""You won’t change my thinking/ This means nothing to me.""

column1: Shopping are in constant conversation

column3: the second half of a dialogue they started on Consumer Complaints. On that record’s ""For Your Money""
column4: Milk played the role of a young man hooking up with rich older guys; here he plays the moneyed party
column5: allowing the band to turn the uncertain power dynamic of user and used inside-out again. He reels off his character’s anxieties at the arrangement
column6: concluding: ""You go home empty-handed when you go home with his type
column7: but there's no implied judgement of the situation. Shopping’s idea of choice doesn't mean one agenda at the expense of another
column8: but establishing a welcoming space for all comers. It works because their naturally scatty
column9:
riotous spark means they could never sound neutral.

The history of the mouth harp is vast: It is believed to have originated in Asia
column2: possibly as early as the 4th century BCE
column3: and its spread extends from Vietnam to Finland
column4: from Siberia to Cameroon. The Dutch musicologist Phons Bakx has compiled a list of more than 1
column5: 000 names for the instrument
column6: including the English-language terms trump
column7: gew-gaw
column8: mouthfiddle
column9: Omaha flapjack
column10: and marranzano pancake. It's most commonly known in English as the Jew's harp—a name whose etymology has flummoxed scholars for decades. Spaniards have called it the pio pollo (""squeaking chicken"") and the Dutch
column11: the Gedachtenverdrijver (""thought dispeller""). But among its most evocative names might be the Italians' scacciapensieri
column12: or ""worry killer""—a name whose meditative connotations go to the heart of the Italian producer Donato Dozzy's contemplative new album
column13: which is built entirely around the instrument.

column1: It's an arcane concept
column2: but Dozzy—whose most common mode is techno—is no stranger to constraints; his last LP
column3: the Spectrum Spools-released Sintetizzatrice
column4: was made using only the singer Anna Caragnano's voice
column5: run through kaleidoscopic
column6: dubwise processing. His approach is similar here
column7: wreathing the instrument's gravelly flange in an airy filigree of reverb and delay. Sometimes he sets the mouth harp front and center
column8: as with the opening ""Personal Rock""; Dozzy has described how he recorded the album on the slopes of mountains and overlooking the Mediterranean Sea
column9: and ""Personal Rock""
column10: bookended by buzzing bees and distant thunder
column11: swims in that sense of place. On ""For Arnaud""
column12: the instrument's steady plucks are stretched and warped by subtle delay and chorus effects; the brightness of the tones and the brisk
column13: skipping pulse are light and invigorating
column14: like an early fall morning.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Dozzy opts for abstraction. ""Cross Panorama"" sounds like it comes from the same tapes that yielded ""Personal Rock""
column3: but this time electronic echo all but swallows the source material
column4: and the reverb's resonance throws off great
column5: yearning harmonics. In ""Concert for Sails""
column6: the instrument is nearly eclipsed by the gentle creaking and slapping of ropes in the harbor. And in ""The Net""
column7: short
column8: clipped tones are tossed down a ricocheting delay chain
column9: evoking the influential dub techno project Vainqueur
column10: while the grinding title track might almost be a cover of Aphex Twin's iconic ""Digeridoo"".

column1: It's generally a meditative set
column2: and only on the album's final track
column3: ""Exit the Acropolis""
column4: does Dozzy return to the sound with which he's most closely affiliated: Tapping out clicks like 808 hi-hats
column5: and weaving three or four layers of mouth harp into enveloping contrapuntal pulses
column6: it's the perfect approximation of Berghain-styled techno. In his notes on the album
column7: Dozzy speaks of trance states and all-night rituals
column8: and here
column9: he successfully unites centuries
column10: if not millennia
column11:
of tradition into a hypnotic whirlwind. Not bad for a sound made entirely from a strip of bent metal.

Montreal producer Kaytranada put out a remix of Janet Jackson's 1993 single ""If"" in the fall of 2012
column3: but the edit
column4: which reimagines the misty original as bubbling
column5: whimsical house

column9: floating in on an elastic bassline

It’s playful and funky and sensual; it sounds like something Janet would make for herself. And even though it’s been out in the world for three years

column1: Probably the only downside to Janet’s 11th album Unbreakable—aside from it running about three tracks too long—is that it doesn’t contain that kind of axis-shifting single. Missy Elliott gives it a try

column4: Unbreakable is a synthesis of ideas Jackson’s collected and tested throughout her career. ""2 B Loved""
column5: with its cavalcade of hoots and hollers

column1: ""No Sleeep
column2: the dusky R&B single
column3: is quintessential Jam & Lewis-abetted Janet. A sweet melody and ribald Isley Brothers sample builds a sultry Quiet Storm groove. Even the silly J. Cole feature can't prevent it from being one of the best songs of the year
column4: a conscious curving of the melismatic summertime bombast of chart-toppers like the Weeknd
column5: Jidenna
column6: OMI
column7: and Bieber. It came out in June

column3: acoustic guitar sway of the title track sets the tone: these are giddy
column4: grateful grown-woman songs. Janet's settled into a new relationship and
column5: if songs like ""After You Fall"" and ""Broken Hearts Heal""
column6: are any indication
column7: ruminating with love on her brother's life and death. On the former she dips into her lower register whilst singing over a somber piano line; on the latter
column8: an uptempo pop song filled with sunny harmonies
column9: she tilts her voice skyward
column10: singing a song of praise about childhood memories and afterlives with an Arabic 'inshallah' on the hook. Jackson
column11: now married to a Qatari businessman
column12: remains private about her personal life but has reportedly converted to Islam. And that one word coming from a pop icon does more for a post-9/11 world than Unbreakable's social-message songs like ""Black Eagle""
column13: and especially ""Shoulda Known Better""
column14: a start-stop fist-pumper about reading beyond the headlines that's two choruses and a verse too long.

column1: This ability to synthesize what music needs instead of catering to its whims is what has made Janet Jackson an enduring pop star. Unlike Madonna
column2: whose presence and work open up much-needed conversations about sexuality
column3: commodity
column4: and the gendered age biases of pop music
column5: Jackson
column7: exposes these conventions as construct. Unbreakable might be her most demure album in years
column8: but that doesn't mean it's not sexy. Its strength comes from savvy instead of gimmickry

which individually might be markers of their time but are ultimately ageless.

It’s been over 15 years since childhood friends Joshua Homme and Jesse ""the Devil"" Hughes founded their cartoonish
column3: carnal blues-rock project
column4: Eagles of Death Metal. When Homme's not manning the drum kit or the mixing board for Eagles (he’s produced each one of their LPs) he fronts Queens of the Stone Age
column5: one of the biggest hard rock bands on the planet. So it makes sense that listeners would categorize the group as a Queens of the Stone Age side project. But EoDM has never been Homme’s show—this band has always been about Hughes
column6: the strutting
column7: showboating
column8: irredeemably decadent presence at its center
column9: the greasy cog around which the freak show turns.

column1: The arrival of Zipper Down coincides with the documentary The Redemption of the Devil
column2: which details one hell of year in Hughes' life
column3: one in which he becomes ordained as a Protestant minister
column4: prepares to marry former adult film star Tuesday Cross
column5: ventures further to the right on the political spectrum (he's a noted gun fanatic)
column6: enters a custody battle for his kid
column7: and
column8: somehow
column9: finds time to cut a new Eagles record. The film attempts to answer a question faced by every aging rocker at some point in their lives: when you’ve had your fill of sex
column10: drugs
column11: and scuzz-rock
column12: who do you turn to for guidance? In Hughes’ case
column13: there are only two logical responses: the guy upstairs
column14: and the guy behind the bar.

column1: On Zipper Down
column2: it's clear that Hughes’ certificate of ordination doesn’t exclude him from the party; as outlined on album closer ""The Reverend""
column3: his spiritual leanings are all part of his divine mission to get us all to ""boogie-woogie"". In interviews
column4: he's preached the gospel of pure methamphetamine and public sex acts
column5: while openly accepting the fiery abyss that lies in wait. In other words
column6: he’s prepared to pick up the tab for every bender (and miserable morning after) detailed on Zipper Down—but only once the party’s over. Accordingly
column7: most of the songs aren't about angels or demons
column8: but rather girls who like to shake their asses (""Got a Woman"" and its ""Slight Return"" on side B)
column9: girls who like to swing their asses (""Silverlake (K.S.O.F.M.)"") and two-timing heartbreakers (""I Love You All the Time""
column10: ""Oh Girl""). Homme supports the songs with one shuffling
column11: snare-heavy beat after the next
column12: peppered by handclaps and the odd cowbell.

column1: But Zipper Down’s tongue-in-cheek humor belies the dark self-awareness of two guys well-versed in the study of human depravity. A closer look at the puffed-up
column2: pivoting highlight ""Silverlake""
column3: for example
column4: reveals it not as a paean to the fashionable Los Angeles neighborhood
column5: but rather a tale of a wannabe hipster trying to weasel his way into the hotspot-du-jour by having his girl get with the bouncer (""So if you date this guy/ He's gonna let us in!"")
column6: only to suffer an existential crisis in the end. Likewise

column8: foggy-headed cover of Duran Duran’s one-night-stand anthem ""Save a Prayer"" revisits the album’s coital motifs through a confessional lens

column1: Despite these more reflective moments

column3: frequently recycling structural and instrumental elements from past songs. The haggard guitars and handclap-heavy backbeat of ""Got a Woman"" recalls Death by Sexy highlight ""Chase the Devil""
column4: while ""The Deuce"" shares a bluesy foundation with Peace Love Death Metal's ""So Easy"". This repetition isn’t to the Eagles’ detriment: theirs has always been a goofy project
column5: one grounded in humor
column6: wit
column7: and sass rather than paradigm shifts. Easy rockers like the sawtoothed
column8: shimmying  ""Complexity"" prove that the tricks aren’t necessary
column9:
as long as your hips are moving.

Paul McCartney's team-up with Rihanna and Kanye West on ""FourFiveSeconds"" earlier this year was met with surprise and bewilderment by some
column3: but if you go back far enough you'd see it's just par for the course in the mind of Macca. Ever since the Beatles covered the Cookies back in '63
column4: McCartney has been testifying to his love of R&B. ""Smokey Robinson was like God in our eyes
column5: he once said. There was a reason Billy Preston's Rhodes solo fit so perfectly in ""Get Back""
column6: after all. Paul McCartney was an R&B lover before he was ever a Beatle.

column1: In McCartney's solo material
column2: however
column3: you have to fast forward to 1982's Tug of War and 1983's Pipes of Peace to hear how that R&B influence evolved in his distinctive sound. It is within these two misunderstood albums in the Macca canon that the square root of ""FourFiveSeconds"" can be discovered
column4: particularly upon the release of this latest pair of deluxe editions as part of the ongoing Paul McCartney Archive Collection series.

column1: In one sense
column2: Tug of War plays out like the album we might've gotten had Lennon and McCartney taken up Lorne Michaels' famous $3
column3: 000 offer to reunite on ""Saturday Night"" in 1976. George Martin sits at the controls on a Fab Four-related project for the first time since Wings' ""Live and Let Die"" (unless you count the 1978 soundtrack to the unmentionably awful ""jukebox musical"" Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band). The specter of Lennon's tragic death and the unresolved differences between the two lifelong friends loom large across much of this material
column4: especially the jubilant ""Ballroom Dancing""
column5: the symphonic title track and ""Here Today"". The latter is the album's most direct reflection on Lennon's death
column6: and it's a song McCartney has been regularly incorporating in his concerts the last couple of tours. Whatever Paul might not have said in the press at the time of Lennon's assassination
column7: he certainly said here.

column1: The nucleus of Tug
column2: however
column3: is McCartney's yin-yang pair of collaborations with Stevie Wonder. Of course we all know ""Ebony and Ivory""
column4: pure ground-zero Macca schmaltz tethered by a goofy yet endearing analogy to the synchronicity between the piano's keys. Strangely enough
column5: the song's message has grown more urgent over the years
column6: while the utterly Triple A orchestrations of the music itself grows as dated as that Joe Piscopo/Eddie Murphy send-up on ""Saturday Night Live"". The key moment comes earlier on the album with ""What's That You're Doing?""
column7: a tour de force of Hotter Than July-era Wonder funk that can be seen as the ColecoVision to the PS4 of ""FourFiveSeconds"".

column1: Some critics derided McCartney for aging gracelessly upon the release of the electro-tinged Pipes of Peace in '83
column2: right as he turned 41. However
column3: a good listen to the album today reveals some ways it was ahead of its time. With the ballad ""So Bad""
column4: McCartney confirmed his aforementioned Smokey worship by paying homage to Robinson's ""Quiet Storm"" era
column5: emulating the Motown great's cool falsetto to such perfection that Smokey himself had a little bit of a rough time emulating it on his own cover from The Art of McCartney. Then there is ""Tug of Peace""
column6: an early
column7: primitive version of a mash-up that brought together the title cuts of these underappreciated albums. The blend is clunky
column8: but it foreshadows his electronic music work as the Fireman and on Liverpool Sound Collage.

column1: Then there's ""Say Say Say""
column2: written in collaboration with Michael Jackson. The song was a simpatico matching of minds
column3: combining Paul's harmonies and Jackson's meticulous sense of rhythm. Mark ""Spike"" Stent's magnificent 2015 remix of ""Say"" on the bonus disc of the Pipes reissue stretches the groove to nearly eight minutes
column4: buoyed by a rocksteady 4/4 handclap beat that conjures up visions of the New York City Breakers dancing in your head. On ""The Man""
column5: the Macca/Jacko duo sways a little closer into Paul territory with its strummy acoustic charm and Wings-esque bombast
column6: showing that beyond ""Say Say Say"" and ""The Girl Is Mine""
column7: they were a potent creative team before it all imploded in a dust of Beatles royalties and Nike ad money.

column1: The extras dug up for the Tug of War reissue (the Super Deluxe Edition of each also contain DVDs of era-appropriate ephemera) make for some interesting listening—demo versions of ""Wanderlust"" and ""The Pound Is Sinking""
column2: and a version of ""Ebony"" with just McCartney on electric piano. But those pale in comparison to the veritable alternate LP included in Pipes of Peace. The previously unreleased ""It's Not On"" sounds like Ween
column3: while the tremolo guitar that floats across another rare cut
column4: ""Simple As That""
column5: could be the secret template for The Smiths' ""How Soon Is Now?"". Elsewhere
column6: proper album tracks like ""Average Person""
column7: ""Keep Under Cover"" and ""Sweetest Little Show"" in demo form sound like they could have been leftovers from Ram. In all
column8: this reissue series continues to shine a new light on McCartney's varied solo output
column9: finding new stories they tell."|21028.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21028-tug-of-war-pipes-of-peace/|6.7|Ron Hart

column1: In McCartney's solo material
column2: however
column3: you have to fast forward to 1982's Tug of War and 1983's Pipes of Peace to hear how that R&B influence evolved in his distinctive sound. It is within these two misunderstood albums in the Macca canon that the square root of ""FourFiveSeconds"" can be discovered
column4: particularly upon the release of this latest pair of deluxe editions as part of the ongoing Paul McCartney Archive Collection series.

column1: In one sense
column2: Tug of War plays out like the album we might've gotten had Lennon and McCartney taken up Lorne Michaels' famous $3
column3: 000 offer to reunite on ""Saturday Night"" in 1976. George Martin sits at the controls on a Fab Four-related project for the first time since Wings' ""Live and Let Die"" (unless you count the 1978 soundtrack to the unmentionably awful ""jukebox musical"" Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band). The specter of Lennon's tragic death and the unresolved differences between the two lifelong friends loom large across much of this material
column4: especially the jubilant ""Ballroom Dancing""
column5: the symphonic title track and ""Here Today"". The latter is the album's most direct reflection on Lennon's death
column6: and it's a song McCartney has been regularly incorporating in his concerts the last couple of tours. Whatever Paul might not have said in the press at the time of Lennon's assassination
column7: he certainly said here.

column1: The nucleus of Tug
column2: however
column3: is McCartney's yin-yang pair of collaborations with Stevie Wonder. Of course we all know ""Ebony and Ivory""
column4: pure ground-zero Macca schmaltz tethered by a goofy yet endearing analogy to the synchronicity between the piano's keys. Strangely enough
column5: the song's message has grown more urgent over the years
column6: while the utterly Triple A orchestrations of the music itself grows as dated as that Joe Piscopo/Eddie Murphy send-up on ""Saturday Night Live"". The key moment comes earlier on the album with ""What's That You're Doing?""
column7: a tour de force of Hotter Than July-era Wonder funk that can be seen as the ColecoVision to the PS4 of ""FourFiveSeconds"".

column1: Some critics derided McCartney for aging gracelessly upon the release of the electro-tinged Pipes of Peace in '83
column2: right as he turned 41. However
column3: a good listen to the album today reveals some ways it was ahead of its time. With the ballad ""So Bad""
column4: McCartney confirmed his aforementioned Smokey worship by paying homage to Robinson's ""Quiet Storm"" era
column5: emulating the Motown great's cool falsetto to such perfection that Smokey himself had a little bit of a rough time emulating it on his own cover from The Art of McCartney. Then there is ""Tug of Peace""
column6: an early
column7: primitive version of a mash-up that brought together the title cuts of these underappreciated albums. The blend is clunky
column8: but it foreshadows his electronic music work as the Fireman and on Liverpool Sound Collage.

column1: Then there's ""Say Say Say""
column2: written in collaboration with Michael Jackson. The song was a simpatico matching of minds
column3: combining Paul's harmonies and Jackson's meticulous sense of rhythm. Mark ""Spike"" Stent's magnificent 2015 remix of ""Say"" on the bonus disc of the Pipes reissue stretches the groove to nearly eight minutes
column4: buoyed by a rocksteady 4/4 handclap beat that conjures up visions of the New York City Breakers dancing in your head. On ""The Man""
column5: the Macca/Jacko duo sways a little closer into Paul territory with its strummy acoustic charm and Wings-esque bombast
column6: showing that beyond ""Say Say Say"" and ""The Girl Is Mine""
column7: they were a potent creative team before it all imploded in a dust of Beatles royalties and Nike ad money.

column1: The extras dug up for the Tug of War reissue (the Super Deluxe Edition of each also contain DVDs of era-appropriate ephemera) make for some interesting listening—demo versions of ""Wanderlust"" and ""The Pound Is Sinking""
column2: and a version of ""Ebony"" with just McCartney on electric piano. But those pale in comparison to the veritable alternate LP included in Pipes of Peace. The previously unreleased ""It's Not On"" sounds like Ween
column3: while the tremolo guitar that floats across another rare cut
column4: ""Simple As That""
column5: could be the secret template for The Smiths' ""How Soon Is Now?"". Elsewhere
column6: proper album tracks like ""Average Person""
column7: ""Keep Under Cover"" and ""Sweetest Little Show"" in demo form sound like they could have been leftovers from Ram. In all
column8: this reissue series continues to shine a new light on McCartney's varied solo output
column9: finding new stories they tell."|21028.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21028-tug-of-war-pipes-of-peace/|6.1|Ron Hart

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22369/homepage_large.92c90a51.jpg|Taking Flight EP|30667.0|Ryan Hemsworth|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Secret Songs']|2015-10-06 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:34.000519|"

No matter what source material he’s working with—be it a Gucci Mane verse
column2: a Mitski song
column3: or a Pokémon sample—Ryan Hemsworth wants you to know that he loves this stuff
column4: sincerely and without reservation. He’s more than just an armchair curator
column5: though; in the last few years
column6: he's developed both a well-defined aesthetic and a deft hand. Where other DJs seek the thrill of juxtaposition alone
column7: Hemsworth excels at making divergent tracks feel of a piece. Whether he’s flipping Tinashe or Blink-182
column8: it always sounds like Ryan Hemsworth.

column1: Lately
column2: Hemsworth’s evangelism has found a new platform in Secret Songs
column3: a quasi-label where he handpicks tracks from up-and-coming producers for an audience of the faithful. He’s built Secret Songs into a sort of anti-PC Music; in place of ironic distance
column4: there’s a loving embrace—the label’s mantra states that this is a ""friends only"" affair. Naturally
column5: the songs tend to hew to a type
column6: which is to say that any of them could cleanly slot into Hemsworth’s DJ sets. One of these tracks
column7: ""Keep U Warm"" by Seattle producer Lucas
column8: was an early standout
column9: a set of disparate sounds
column10: ranging from wind chimes to cricket chirps
column11: sequenced with the delicacy and precision of a music box. For his latest project
column12: Hemsworth teams with Lucas for a collaborative EP that serves as Hemsworth’s first Secret Songs release. The end result finds the two producers engaging in a generous give-and-take that plays to each of their strengths.

column1: The biggest surprise here is that the largely unknown Lucas often sets the tone. Whereas Hemsworth’s recent solo work favors crisp
column2: clean lines
column3: these tracks tend to crackle
column4: buzz and fade. Melodies waft in as if through an open window and often drift off just as unceremoniously. Vocals are treated past the point of intelligibility
column5: serving as textures that rub up against other elements in the mix. Given the gauzy sonic palette
column6: emotions feel implied
column7: rather than announced—not a bad look for Hemsworth
column8: who can occasionally veer into preciousness on his own. There’s a sort of hazy sheen over Taking Flight that makes even the big crescendos feel slightly blurry
column9: like vaseline smeared on a camera lens.

column1: Thankfully
column2: Hemsworth’s knack for pulling heartstrings remains intact
column3: as does his skillful
column4: trap-influenced drum programming
column5: if it's used judiciously. While ""From Grace"" is the only track on here that feels like it’s built for the dance floor
column6: there are points in all of these songs where
column7: for a brief few seconds
column8: things snap into focus rhythmically before retreating back into the haze. Lucas likes to work with snippets of found sounds and every rattle
column9: flutter
column10: and squeak here feels like it’s adding up to something
column11: nudging the song toward a resolution. Drums are often employed only to stitch together all the sounds floating in the mix
column12: suddenly making you aware of a beat that was there all along. This is warm and unhurried electronic music that's built for Sunday mornings.

column1: At just over 20 minutes
column2: Taking Flight is hardly ambitious
column3: but it's a casual experiment that manages to feel vital throughout. It serves as one hell of a calling card for Lucas
column4: whose previous output is limited to a handful of SoundCloud tracks. Meanwhile
column5: a guy who’s made a career out of bending other people’s songs to fit his aesthetic gets to demonstrate that he’s just as adept at doing the exact opposite. And in allowing a less seasoned artist to eat away at the edges of his sound
column6:
Hemsworth has somehow managed to bring his gifts as a producer into even sharper focus.

"|21082.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21082-taking-flight-ep/|7.3|Mehan Jayasuriya

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22365/homepage_large.08d7ca18.jpg|No No|29706.0|Co La|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Software']|2015-10-06 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:34.652004|"

Sampling isn't a lost art form just yet
column2: but it's fair to call it a diminished one. This has happened even as the sample itself remains a staple of modern music production: how Young Chop has access to an orchestra
column3: how every bedroom producer from Los Angeles to Berlin owns an 808. Those sounds are meticulously recorded and integrated into popular software. Sampling itself—the act of sourcing
column4: manipulating
column5: and arranging previously recorded sound—is more esoteric; certainly there are fewer producers rewriting the history of jazz and funk (DJ Premier
column6: the Bomb Squad) or expanding the cosmic vistas of the dance floor (the KLF
column7: the Orb). The practice remains more common in dance music
column8: but it's still notable when someone returns to the old methods
column9: and licensing concerns crowd many out. Instead
column10: sampling has followed a path opposite that of most musical trends: from the unobtainable feel of early studio instruments to widespread pop deployment to the obscure and niche.

column1: Baltimore's Co La belongs to a shrinking group of composers—Flying Lotus and Bibio among them—for whom sampling remains a singular muse. His last album
column2: Moody Coup
column3: was a genteel patter that stitched together everything from ASMR-like frivolity to reggae toasting. His third-ish album (he's had several cassette and low-run releases) and second for Software
column4: No No
column5: arrives with a harsher mandate
column6: aiming to explore the banging
column7: echoing sounds of the club. This makes for a louder
column8: tenser listen
column9: even as Co La's methods remain largely unchanged: all of No No's sounds are recognizable
column10: or at least conceivable. There's nothing truly alien here
column11: and you'd always feel comfortable at least guessing at a sound's source.

column1: Increasingly
column2: those sources are drums
column3: or things that sound mostly like drums. There's a lot of diffuse banging on No No—only rarely does a deep kick-like sound arrive on time—and it sounds like Co La is one of a growing pool of producers inspired by the rhythmic daring of artists like Pearson Sound and Jam City. This manifests itself in tracks such as ""Crank""
column4: which rises from a clutch of voices into a surprising
column5: hands-in-the-air throb
column6: and ""Gush""
column7: which revels in a suspended state before perforating the bubble with rapid bursts of percussion.

column1: Of course
column2: No No isn't dance music; Co La seems unwilling to commit to that level of structure. So while you could see a deft turntable hand or a devout remixer turning this club-ready
column3: there are lots of potent moments (""No No"") and transfixing loops (""Barricade""'s pitched dollops) that are abandoned too quickly. Elsewhere
column4: as on opener ""Squeeze""
column5: the percussive elements feel placed at random
column6: and the track
column7: untethered
column8: scatters away. I miss the gentleness of Moody Coup
column9: and when the latter half of ""Tragedy"" opens up with a laughing voice and a rich piano lament I realize how stern and abrasive much of No No sounds.

column1: That's probably intentional
column2: given the playfulness that's baked into Co La's methods and sound sources. This is avant-garde music at its core
column3: and the precision with which these sources are treated and deployed means Co La probably has more in common with
column4: say
column5: Steve Reich than with DJ Premier. No No asks a lot of listeners
column6: that we unpack all of these fun inferences even as we're being assaulted by the 143 different sounds Co La casted into the vestige of a snare drum. No No
column7: on balance
column8:
is worth the effort.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22306/homepage_large.6b85ce7b.jpg|V|27255.0|Wavves|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.'
column3: Nathan Williams became the latest musician to show you can take the boy out of indie but you can’t take the indie out of the boy: He got in a fight with his major label. Williams uploaded ""Way Too Much""
column4: a single from his then-untitled new album
column5: to SoundCloud
column6: only to see Warner Bros. take it down. Without disclosing Warner’s motivation behind the takedown
column7: he implied the label was threatening to sue him
column8: and wrote
column9: ""Its so obnoxious to work tirelessly on something and then have a bunch of ppl who just see me as a money sign go and fuck it all up.""

column1: On this
column2: Warner was right: V is definitely not a record that’s going to make them a lot of money. That would require Williams writing the pop-punk crossover LP of his career—a little more Paramore
column3: a little less Psychedelic Horseshit. Instead
column4: what we have is an angry collection of songs more indebted to his recent collaboration with Cloud Nothings and the brute-force approach of his earlier releases
column5: where punk catharsis was achieved by saying the same lyric over and over. (Say ""I’m so bored"" five times fast and you
column6: in fact
column7: will feel bored.)

column1: V was inspired by a breakup
column2: as well as the band’s hellaciously bad habits: 100 beers and two bottles of Jameson a night for the four-piece group
column3: a period of ""just drinking
column4: straight drinking
column5: ” as Williams says in the album’s press materials. Accordingly
column6: V sounds like a hangover. Every song starts somewhere dismal
column7: and ends up somewhere that’s only a little hopeful—a process akin to the recovery from a hangover
column8: when by the end you're mostly happy not to be drooling and vomiting on yourself. Multiple tracks refer to headaches both physical and spiritual. Williams’ budget has outsized the lo-fi recordings he made his name with
column9: but he hasn't deviated much from the core formula. Though there’s room for easy-breezy surf rock (""Heavy Metal Detox"")
column10: insistent riffage (""Flamezesz""
column11: ""Pony"")
column12: and shuddering sounds ripped from a horror movie (""Redlead"")
column13: the predominant aesthetic is dirty and discordant backed by big harmonies—the sweet spot from which all memorable Wavves songs emerge.

column1: It’s a faster record
column2: too: V abandons Williams’ previous attempts at balladry
column3: with all slow moments preceding the eventual assault. At times
column4: the pace works to his advantage. Williams writes a killer hook
column5: and it’s easy to hear crowds slamming along to the feel-bad vibes of ""Heavy Metal Detox""
column6: ""All the Same""
column7: ""Way Too Much""
column8: and ""My Head Hurts"". A line like ""I lost my job today
column9: but it’s all the same"" (""All the Same"") is delivered much more happily than ""It gets better"" (""Pony"")
column10: a reminder that he’s better reveling in angst than trying to convince us it doesn’t matter.

column1: When he leans into his ennui
column2: V achieves momentarily thrilling peaks. Williams is a child of singers like Billie Joe Armstrong and Tom DeLonge
column3: pop-punk brats great at sounding snotty next to a massive chorus. The best songs remind you of his keen ability for penning sonically fractured
column4: melodically appealing ""woe-is-me"" anthems that won’t bruise you too badly in the pit. (The best songs were written with the other members of the band
column5: too
column6: suggesting a necessary camaraderie.)

column1: Still
column2: V is a slight regression from the subtle growth he showed on 2013’s Afraid of Heights. Songs like ""Demon to Lean On"" and ""Cop"" weren’t just excellent songs—they showed the crystallization of the Wavves project into something mature
column3: a word that’s rarely been used to describe Williams or his music. V will make you think he’s lapsed back to his #worstbehavior. Take a characteristic line like ""Everything sucks if you don’t get your way"" from ""Tarantula""—it’s like he fell through a portal from 2009
column4: and is back to playing the perpetual brat. V is a perfectly capable record
column5: one that showcases what we’ve come to expect—and in many cases
column6: enjoy—from Williams and his band. Even so
column7:
you wonder where else they might have gone.

The opening to Age of Transparency  teases us with memories of 2013's ""Play By Play""
column2: still the greatest song Arthur Ashin (aka Autre Ne Veut) has ever recorded. ""Baaaaaaaaaaaabe
column3: he warbles
column4: his voice soulful
column5: strained and knowing
column6: before he slides into a reprisal of ""On and On""
column7: remaking the upbeat single into an exercise in jazz improvisation and bare-boned composition that goes just long enough before it chokes out into a sputter. A theme for the album is wrapped within; this set of songs extends something beautiful to its limits and then tries to will it beyond its end. Sometimes to a fault.

column1: Ashin's showiness as a singer is part of his grandeur; his voice has always managed to pull a song together. Yes
column2: he's been lumped into the inner mines of ""bedroom R&B"" or ""PBR&B""–the latter of which is an innocuous title for a genre
column3: an easy way of associating the soul of R&B with the electronic embrace of indie–but he has always had his eye somewhere outside the bedroom. His singing feels directed to a shrine rather than the club
column4: and he's able to emote despair and acute yearning through the rawness of his voice
column5: not in spite of it. It can be unsettling to hear that singular spark start to work against him now.

column1: The disconnect could very well come from the fact that he's now surrounded by a proper choir
column2: and on his most sonically incoherent album yet. On ""Get Out"" he is navigating a track that feels primed for cinematic pop glory
column3: but the song flags as it goes on and his flights of melodic inspiration begin to feel like a parody of a blues singer. On ""Over Now""
column4: a glitchy sample turns a dreary lullaby to the death of something or other into a vacuous wall of static; what is clearly meant to be a captivating mess of noise becomes literally difficult to listen to. ""Switch Hitter"" turns a menacing pop framework
column5: with its elastic guitars and looming synths
column6: into something that feels half-baked. Where these songs hit their most visceral moments is where they can feel their most contrived.

column1: Joel Ford (Ford & Lopatin) and Young Ejecta appear on production again
column2: but Ashin has graduated from his former roommate's Software imprint to a bigger label with a bigger budget
column3: and with that his sound has become cleaner
column4: denser
column5: and glossier
column6: barring some of the organic simplicity that he's benefited from in the past. His lyrics remain simple and poignant
column7: but some of what surprised us on Anxiety has lost its newness here. The sudden moments of rapture–the ones that that pushed through layers of electronic ambience–remain
column8: but are less frequent and more predictable.

column1: That said
column2: when it does all come together on this album
column3: it really is quite gorgeous. ""Panic Room"" is some of his best writing musically and lyrically. The lines ""I don't want to feel like you're not here with me/ Even when you say that you are not here with me"" are heart wrenching on their own. Lay them on a wave of synths and the flutter of percussive rolls and the track is as enveloping as ""Play By Play"" or ""Counting"" were before it. ""World War Pt. 2"" dabbles with some frantic pop sampling before retreating
column4: underscoring the fevered pull of a line like ""heartbreak is not enough."" ""Age of Transparency"" is another highlight. In these moments
column5: where he approaches the brink and opens his arms to it
column6: the messiness of his intense and manic music mirrors the messiness of life.

column1: The title of Age of Transparency acts as Ashin's commentary on the way we live our lives out in the open
column2: and his music seeks to pull you through uneasy
column3: emotional dregs with its every turn. But what once felt intimate has started to lean to over-exertion. Here we see what happens after the fireworks have burst
column4:
when its casing is left smoldering and you're hoping for more. 

"|21044.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21044-age-of-transparency/|6.0|Puja Patel

Girl Band’s debut EP
column2: 2012’s France 98
column3: was good but unremarkable
column4: the sound of four young Irish guys experimenting with dissonance but rarely straying from ten-a-penny post-punk gloom. By contrast
column5: last year’s ""Lawman"" was the sign of a band that had found their own sharp footing. Writhing
column6: sexy
column7: and strange
column8: the Dubliners soldered frenzied hi-hats to an industrial mess that recalled early Liars
column9: and Dara Kiely had found his yowling voice located somewhere between his apparently unhinged jaw and spirit. The revelation was nothing compared to what the song did for Kiely himself. During a period of poor mental health
column10: the euphoria he experienced from writing the song (which dealt with a recent breakup) triggered within him a superhuman complex. ""I had this thing
column11: this
column12: ‘You are your own god
column13: you are your own master’
column14: this extreme idea
column15: he said. ""It was the most amazing feeling I have ever had… I thought I could control the weather. Everything.""

column1: Kiely spent a while living in a tent in his back garden
column2: and the episode became so severe that his mother took six months off work to care for him
column3: encouraging him to write when he couldn’t do anything else. Eventually
column4: he had a breakdown and checked into a hospital
column5: and emerged
column6: he says
column7: genuinely at peace. The rest of Girl Band had continued to write while he was away
column8: and on Kiely’s return
column9: he fitted observations from his journal to their squall. His wit hadn’t vanished alongside his sense of reason. ""The Last Riddler"" repeats verbatim the moment where he asked a doctor for their favorite band. Given the reply ""ABBA""
column10: Kiely presented him with a piece of paper that read ""the winner takes it all
column11: along with some cryptic advice: ""Think about it."" Elsewhere he’s more fragmented: He ""snorted a wasp and told them to eff off"" on ""Pears for Lunch""
column12: where he struggles with body dysmorphia and has a self-loathing wank in front of ""Top Gear"". Acutely attuned to the goings-on of the natural world
column13: he scraps with pigeons
column14: toys with fetid food
column15: and watches a girl “[race] her slugs to the salt lines."" His tragi-comic tidbits combine to a universal portrait of idle squalor and degradation that trumps his realist peers
column16: and aligns him with absurdists like Captain Beefheart or cult poet Patricia Lockwood.

column1: Should you laugh? Holding Hands With Jamie is as discomfiting as Kiely’s mental state. ""Pears for Lunch"" swells with dangerous fearlessness
column2: recalling '90s news reports of bad amphetamines that made hopped-up kids think they were Icarus
column3: while at the end of ""The Last Riddler""
column4: Kiely’s screams and explosive bursts of roiling guitar and drums give the impression of a man running amok with a chainsaw. ""Paul"" picks up the conversation between techno and industrial music that Girl Band started on their cover of Blawan’s ""Why They Hide Their Bodies Under My Garage"" and takes it somewhere utterly godless and glorious: seven minutes of ravenous
column5: gathering violence comprised of screaming guitar
column6: lurching bass
column7: and superhuman effort from drummer Adam Faulkner.

column1: Where this spring’s The Early Years EP—led by ""Lawman""—either went hell for leather or slowed the pace entirely
column2: on Holding Hands… Girl Band have mastered suspense. ""Baloo"" chugs like Battles’ Mirrored retooled from corroded scrap metal; ""In Plastic"" has a pendulous
column3: borderline romantic quality. They self-produced
column4: and the record often sounds as if it was recorded on the other side of a warehouse wall
column5: like muffled industry contained within a rubbery membrane. This strange distance could be frustrating
column6: but it becomes an integral part of Girl Band’s sound
column7: which feels unique right now. Traces of Liars’ DNA persist
column8: as do similarities to those tireless Texans Shit and Shine
column9:
but it’s hard to think of another guitar-based band conjuring fear this exhilarating and volume this rapturous.

""I’d give my body to Satan if I could only keep my soul
column2: Nicole Dollanganger sings in a whispery
column3: desperate voice on ""Angels of Porn (II)""
column4: a song about how the singer seems to have been trapped in a food and cum-stained dungeon for days. ""But I can’t seem to find the split between them anymore."" This is the sort of subject matter that made her music popular among her Tumblr followers in the first place

column1: Over nimble electric guitar and booming kick drum

column3: ""fucking the soul of the south

column4: and Lana Del Rey’s dark

column7: white Victorian house from The Texas Chainsaw Massacre was at first glance. ""I’ll be your sister
column8: your young bride
column9: your angel
column10: your slave
column11: she sings to her vinyl glove-clad
column12: cop lover in a whisper on ""Mean"". She sings of drinking the titular liquid and getting chained up in bed on the fuzzy ""Alligator Blood"" and she’s bleeding to death during knife play on the pretty
column13: minimalist guitar ballad ""American Tradition"" but ""it doesn’t matter
column14: 'cause my baby is still the winner."" Her angelic

column1: Her elemental lyrics help elevate her record above kinky bad-girl tropes: With every act of violence inflicted on Dollanganger
column2: she reveals how corrupted she can be as well
column3: proving she’s just as a strong and sadistic of a hunter. She never really lets any of the dark sentiments exist in a vacuum
column4: which is important considering the violence she mines for aesthetic and emotional affect. Dead bodies get fed to the Earth’s starving animals
column5: animals get fed to starving humans; she sees a father’s violence in his son’s eyes and sings that ""history repeats our whole damn lives.""

column1: Her portrait of tortured sexuality and death is tethered to an ambiguous portrait of backwoods living
column2: a North American wilderness where anything and anyone can be hunted. Natural Born Losers plays like a work of wicked anti-pastoralism from the perspective of a bad girl who stares out at her rustic life with not wide-eyed romanticism but sad familiarity and resignation. ""This same place is getting old but dreams are fulfilled where the purple grass grows
column3:
Dollanganger sings on ""White Trashing"". ""And I can see it all just beyond our window.""

When Panagiotis Melidis
column2: the Greek producer who records as Larry Gus
column3: first began releasing music
column4: his primary mode of expression was parroting other artists to create sample-heavy pastiche. His productions encompassed everything from Afrobeat to hip-hop; after signing to DFA
column5: his first two albums for the label were somewhat unsteady attempts to turn bits and pieces into a cohesive whole
column6: taking cues from prototypical psych pop outfits like El Guincho and Animal Collective. His last album
column7: Years Not Living
column8: was a more conceptually confident (if sometimes muddy-sounding) stew of African-influenced grooves
column9: slathered-on samples
column10: and his own heavily layered vocals.

column1: Though he’s pared down the clutter and clamor somewhat since his initial DFA outing
column2: Melidis is still no stranger to chaos
column3: as evidenced by the mishmash of styles on his new album
column4: I Need New Eyes. Like Years Not Living
column5: it’s made up of immersive grooves and smartly deployed samples. But the music borders on the emotionally drippy
column6: with lyrics lamenting the ever-present fear of failure inherent in creative work—a feeling he describes somewhat cheekily in the album’s first track as a ""black veil of fail.""

column1: As a writer
column2: Melidis is often either obtuse to the point of sounding glib (""children are all foreign shores"") or absurdly abstract (""all the tigers breathe with the fires from above""). He smartly offsets his own straightforward singing with vocal samples from other sources
column3: and his strongest songs piggyback off of other influences: ""A Set of Replies"" sounds like an earnest adaptation of the Pixies' ""Where Is My Mind""
column4: elevated by sweetly reedy details and percussive pinging
column5: while the sugary ""The Sun Describes""
column6: with its warbling vocals and tropical percussion
column7: is a melancholy reimagining of his early Avalanches rip
column8: ""Contours Sway"".

column1: In some ways Melidis is the consummate consumption-driven producer
column2: whose wide-ranging tastes fuel an obsessive thirst for sounds and ideas: in interviews
column3: he seems comfortable driving the narrative that his music is a sum of influences
column4: gamely referencing Prince
column5: Raymond Queneau
column6: Marc Maron
column7: Lucio Battisti
column8: and Seinfeld. (The album’s title is itself a veiled reference to Proust.) He’s an artist who’s attracted to ambiguity
column9: and who’s attributed one of his most profound moments of inspiration to listening to Madlib while in the grip of sunstroke.

column1: Anyone seeking out that woozy
column2: half-sick
column3: half-euphoric feeling will find it all over I Need New Eyes. The album’s sweeping final track
column4: ""Nazgonya (Paper Spike)""
column5: is a satisfying culmination
column6: a swirling
column7: unambiguously warm callback to psychedelic pop. Of all the songs on the album
column8: it’s the most straightforward
column9: and therefore the most successful. The problem is that Melidis’ ear for busy atmospherics and his desire to say something deep don’t quite mesh; this music is like that huge spinning wheel on ""The Price Is Right""—efficient
column10: colorful
column11:
deadening.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22438/homepage_large.a387535e.jpg|Meow The Jewels|31319.0|Run the Jewels|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mass Appeal']|2015-10-02 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:39.150525|"

Cats are the Internet's favorite pets for many reasons
column2: not least of which is their endless mystery. By some estimates
column3: felines were first domesticated around 12
column4: 000 years ago—and yet
column5: even now
column6: we humans don't fully understand something as simple as their purr. There are theories. A purr can translate to contentment
column7: sure
column8: but it could also indicate hunger
column9: or fright. Most intriguingly
column10: those low rumbles may double as a healing mechanism for cats and people alike: purrs vibrate at frequencies between 20 and 140 hertz
column11: which happens to be ideal for mending bones
column12: muscles
column13: tendons
column14: and ligaments. If purrs do indeed have such powers
column15: Run the Jewels' new cat-sampling remix album could very well be the most physically restorative record ever made—there are a lot of fucking purring sounds on this thing.

column1: Before it became an IRL curio featuring the production talents of everyone from Prince Paul and Dan the Automator
column2: to members of Portishead and Massive Attack
column3: to hip-hop heavies Just Blaze and the Alchemist
column4: Meow the Jewels was merely another LOLcat goof. In the runup to last year's Run the Jewels 2
column5: El-P and Killer Mike decided to have a bit of fun with online feline culture as well as fan-gouging pre-order-package culture by offering to “re-record RTJ2 using nothing but cat sounds for music” for $40
column6: 000. Soon enough
column7: modern crowdfunding mentality kicked in and a Kickstarter raised $66
column8: 000 to get the idea off the ground. The way in which this project lines up with the duo's paradoxical ethos
column9: where they're able to spit the most cartoonish puff-chest bars alongside deadly serious tales of death and strife
column10: can be observed in a recent El-P tweet: “did we make the silliest
column11: occasionally most grating possible remix album? of course. and we did it for you
column12: mike brown and eric garner.” (All profits made by the album will go to charity.)

column1: It's easy
column2: and not wholly inaccurate
column3: to dismiss Meow the Jewels as a well-meaning wisecrack that went several steps too far. Even El-P himself told Deadspin
column4: “I would never even insult the world by saying [the album is] 'good
column5: ' but it's certainly the high-water mark for cat-sound records
column6: I think.” So while the way these remixers warp meows
column7: hisses
column8: scratches
column9: yelps
column10: and purrs into passable rap beats is impressive
column11: only a few songs rise above the level of novelty. Part of this has to do with the fact that
column12: you know
column13: this is 42 minutes of rapping over cat sounds
column14: but it's also hard to compete with El-P's original Earth-scorching production
column15: perhaps his finest beatmaking in a career that has spanned two decades.

column1: While some tracks unwisely try to replicate the source material's dystopian energy
column2: the best moments come when remixers go blissfully off-script. Portishead's Geoff Barrow empties out the beat of “Close Your Eyes (And Count to Fuck)”
column3: replacing it with a disorienting
column4: subwoofer-shaking purr
column5: a tiny cat-collar bell
column6: and some stray yowling for good measure—it sounds like what “Grindin'”-era Neptunes may have done with this odd opportunity if given the chance. But best-in-show honors goes to frequent Grimes collaborator Blood Diamonds
column7: whose featherlight beat for “All Due Respect” injects some appropriate
column8: non-corny levity into the proceedings
column9: which can otherwise feel weirdly dark.

column1: But Meow the Jewels isn't really about music at all; instead
column2: it's a major milestone in cats' slow-but-inevitable climb to the status of Hip-Hop's Favorite Animal. In the '90s
column3: I grew up with Snoop Doggy Dogg (whose grace and ease in life and on record always seemed more cat-like anyway) and DMX espousing canine superiority. It was a particularly masculine—and perhaps
column4: um
column5: overcompensating—pose during an era of unparalleled hip-hop machismo. There was a sociological element to this: The use of snarling pitbulls as a way for underprivileged men to exhibit control while caught in an unjust system of power. But
column6: for DMX at least
column7: the obsession could also get strange and ugly—the rapper has been charged with dozens of counts of animal cruelty since his heyday.

column1: This century
column2: as hip-hop continues to grow up and expand its borders
column3: the genre's once-strong walls—between mainstream and underground
column4: masculine and feminine—continue to crumble into dust. Run the Jewels itself is a sterling example of this
column5: a duo that could bury any given meathead rapper with outlandish tough talk while also out-smarting any indie-rap dork with vitriolic politics and heart. Meow the Jewels is the result of what happens when cats are afforded more respect and notoriety (largely thanks to umpteen YouTube videos) as hip-hop's subversive streak is allowed to flourish (largely thanks to umpteen YouTube videos). Paving the way to this moment were fellow rap rebels Lil B—the form's most committed rule-breaker—and his adopted tabby cat KeKe
column6: who released a wild
column7: purr-sampling track three years ago; Danny Brown and his beloved bengal Siren; and Tyler
column8: the Creator's tendency to put cat heads on every shirt he can sell. Cats are fascinating in part because of their autonomy: They will most certainly lie down
column9: but not on your command. This is the same independent spirit we desire in our artists. The European philosopher Albert Schweitzer once said
column10: “There are two means of refuge from the miseries of life: music and cats.” It's high time hip-hop figured this out
column11:
too.

Battles’ third album
column2: La Di Da Di

column7: processed vocals of Tyondai Braxton: part man

column10: energetic

column14:
glassy cube. It also meant they had a de facto ""frontman.""

But Braxton left while Battles were recording the followup

column17: Kazu Makino

column31:
and others.

That’s a lot of cooks

column38: vocals and additional hands aren’t necessary. These are expressive
