column45:
but it’s squarely Battles. The various vocalists on Gloss Drop gave that collection a kind of chaotic or ""various artists"" feel—here there’s a solidity and feeling of forward motion.

It’s at its best early
column48: which starts with a wash of colorful feedback before moving into a tight pulse of keyboards that sound like guitars
column50: and rumbling drums and bells. (This is echoed in the final song of the collection

column1: The best songs bring to mind super specific images (here were a few of mine: a landscape of yellow parakeets

there's not much like it.

Hip hop is nothing if not rich in drama. Beyond even the competitive feuding
column2: the best rap music chronicles its makers' highs and lows
column3: detailing the gnarly realities of difficult lives lived triumphantly. Hip hop and theater
column4: with their shared fondness for linear narrative
column5: should make for more frequent bedfellows
column6: but it took until this year for the two genres to combine to properly resounding effect. Debuting at the Public Theater to raves earlier this year and accumulating hype ever since
column7: the rapped musical Hamilton tells the story of the United States founding father born and orphaned in the Caribbean
column8: who used a prodigious writing talent to catapult himself off the island of St. Croix and leave as deep a thumbprint in United States history as has been made.

column1: Hamilton could not have been an easy show to write
column2: even for a theater savant like Lin-Manuel Miranda
column3: the 35 year-old Grammy-winning author of In The Heights and recent MacAuthur ""Genius Grant"" recipient. The play is composed of 46 individual songs
column4: here split between two discs (Acts I and II) that make up the album. Adopted by Miranda from Ron Chernow’s biography
column5: Alexander Hamilton
column6: the songs are vehicles for Hamilton’s life experiences
column7: and great pains have been taken to maintain the accuracy of an already-fascinating story amidst the likewise-necessary shimmer of theatrical performance. Pairing early US history with one of the country’s youngest musical art forms
column8: one born of the underprivileged especially
column9: could have been as painful as listening to one of your history teachers ""bust a rhyme
column10: but Miranda’s command of both golden era hip hop and showtunes allows him to turn the pomp and circumstance of even congressional proceedings on its head.

column1: Though ostensibly a rap record
column2: from the show opener
column3: ""Alexander Hamilton""
column4: it’s immediately apparent that we are still essentially in musical-theater territory. Theatrical dialogue must be clear and audible to reach its audience—even when presented in song—which denies the cast the freedom to indulge in grand tonal flourishes or vocal tics. Miranda and his cast’s delivery is steadfast and well-enunciated
column5: the flows delivered with a watchmaker’s precision. It helps that the song itself is a bracingly economical synopsis of Hamilton’s early years: The treacherous hurricane that destroyed St. Croix
column6: the letter he wrote  to his absentee father that published by a local paper and caused such a fervor on the island that a group of businessmen took up a collection to send the then 17 year-old Hamilton to New York for college.

column1: Disc one is the more jovial of the pair
column2: chronicling Hamilton’s rise to prominence
column3: and flexing a number of smile-inducing touchtones. Over beatboxing and a drum breakdown replicating hands banging on a lunch table
column4: we get introduced to eventual Hamilton murderer
column5: Aaron Burr. ""My Shot"" is Miranda spouting couplets in a manner a little too close to slam poetry for anyone’s good
column6: but a number introducing ""The Schuyler Sisters""
column7: (one of whom Hamilton would marry and another of whom he’d keep a suspiciously affectionate pen pal correspondence with) sounds like it could have been a last-second album exclusion for one hit wonder and infamous Wyclef protégés
column8: City High. ""Wait For It"" moves with a dancehall lilt and ""The Ten Duel Commandments"" pays homage to the Notorious B.I.G.’s ""10 Crack Commandments"".

column1: Disc two is Hamilton’s unraveling
column2: covering
column3: among other things
column4: his affair with one Maria Reynolds and the very public fallout that followed and the death of his 19-year old son in a duel defending his father’s honor. Musically
column5: there are direct allusions to LL Cool J and Mobb Deep (""I’m only 19 but my mind is older
column6: Phillip Hamilton spouts on ""Blow Us All Away""
column7: a near-quote of ""Shook Ones Pt. II"") and an a capella verse from Miranda on the second-to-last track ""The World Was Wide Enough"" is thoroughly reminiscent of the prayers that used to close out DMX albums.

column1: The Hamilton cast recording was executive produced by Black Thought and ?uestlove of the Roots
column2: who know maybe better than anyone the intricacies of presenting hip hop over live instrumentation successfully. These are
column3: however
column4: still very much showtunes. An audience for musical theater comes to hear a story first and foremost (they bury the backing musicians in a pit
column5: for goodness sakes) and the songs of Hamilton work to that end with every bar
column6: even when seamlessly formatted for storyline
column7: as in the case of the show’s freestyle battles by way of cabinet debates.

column1: As an educational tool
column2: Hamilton is a new standard
column3: a piece that will very likely do more to cement Hamilton’s legacy into the consciousness of the general public than any history class ever could. Kaplan would be wise to commission volumes of these kinds of hip hop-driven biographies from Miranda and force him into some kind of lifetime contract. As an album
column4: however
column5: the audio removed from visual context
column6: it’s a lot to digest. It’s 46 songs of verbose
column7: intricately delivered raps
column8: spun from a story with enough character to have already made it a New York Times best-seller. There’s a lot of ground to cover regardless of medium.

column1: The closest thing to it in popular rap in recent memory would be Kendrick Lamar’s Good Kid
column2: M.A.A.D. City. Just like Hamilton
column3: GKMC is an album that requires time and attention
column4: and rewards that investment handsomely. Hamilton
column5: though
column6: is an album for a very specific audience. It’s for theater lovers
column7: sure
column8: but more generally for people who probably wish they were watching a production of Hamilton. There’s an argument to be made that GKMC’s songs
column9: too
column10: work best within the context of the entire album
column11: as a holistic production to be devoured whole hog. But many of those songs are able to live on their own as great radio singles in a way Miranda’s songs never could. For Hamilton there is no such debate. You need the whole of it
column12:
from curtain rise to call.

Julia Shapiro (Chastity Belt)
column2: Bree McKenna (Tacocat)
column3: and Stacy Peck (Pony Time) open their album screaming ""Childbirth!"" and ""Women's rights!"". Peck pounds her drum kit while Shapiro draws out each phrase
column4: McKenna joining in on the latter. It's a puzzling forty seconds
column5: and at first the track feels either unnecessary or like a joke. But if it is a joke
column6: it feels both vital and too close to home when you consider that 241 representatives of the GOP recently voted to defund Planned Parenthood.  It's just as well the punk trio keeps shouting on repeat as if the subject had no meaning.

column1: Ultimately Women's Rights plays like an album created to deflect hopelessness with crude humor
column2: and Childbirth are indiscriminate in their choice of topics
column3: as long as they're ripe for comedy. They'll tackle anything from online dating to Seattle's influx of tech culture
column4: brought to you by Amazon (All band members reside in the PNW). Shapiro opens ""Tech Bro"" with a cheerful guitar riff only to begrudgingly admit
column5: ""I'll let you explain feminism to me/ Tech bro
column6: tech bro/ If I can use your HDTV
column7: proving that you can be disgusted by gentrification
column8: but intrigued with its trappings at the same time. During ""Siri
column9: Open Tinder""
column10: McKenna's backing vocals are reduced to the simple instructions ""Swipe left!"" or ""Swipe right!"" only to exclaim
column11: ""Which one are you?!"" upon encountering a group photo. All over the album
column12: repeated lyrics are interrupted with one liners to highlight peak ridiculousness.

column1: However
column2: it's not just dudes under attack here. Tracks like ""Let's Be Bad"" and ""Breast Coast (Hangin' Out)"" – where lyrics like ""Hanging out/ Doing stuff/ With my boyfriend"" and ""I love him cause he's hot""
column3: read like a dig against Bethany Cosentino – are perfect for all the times when perfectly curated Pinterest boards
column4: UGG boots
column5: and pictures of pumpkin spice lattes on Instagram make you want to scream. In order to level the playing field
column6: we're gifted the single ""Nasty Grrls"" – a laundry list of disgusting habits that ""nice young ladies"" shouldn't indulge in
column7: like wiping away boogers and never washing bras
column8: amongst others transgressions of hygiene. (Hate to break it to you
column9: but we do dip everything in ranch.)

column1: Then
column2: of course
column3: there's the matter of the band's namesake. They're quick to point out that once you've reached spawning age
column4: women's conversations are downgraded to a competitive arena. Take ""More Fertile Than You"" where Shapiro outright brags
column5: ""I've got eggs by the dozen and you got none"". But by far
column6: the highlight of the whole album is the hilarious and dark ""Baby Bump"".  The line
column7: ""I'm that horrifying person from your past/ I'm a party creep/ Why are we still friends?"" delivered by a snide friend to an expectant mom
column8: rings painfully true. Those of us who choose to abstain from motherhood often feel we become nothing more than grubby
column9: little deviants who snort coke off a key in your bathroom. When will we settle down?

column1: With all of these cultural touch points
column2: it's clear that Childbirth are not concerned with maintaining relevance over the next ten years. Women's Rights is an album created entirely for the moment
column3: which keeps the spirit lighthearted even when they're dealing with heavy-handed subject matter. You know exactly what they're referencing
column4: and they're quick to make you laugh. The problem is
column5: it's easy to feel clobbered by the album's bluntness and their variety of topics don't differ much from the first record. Shapiro and McKenna's back-and-forth calls get tedious and the feeling become less ""Well
column6: that's funny!"" and more ""Okay
column7: we get it"". But there's a point somewhere in there
column8: too. Women are subjected to such a barrage of expectations and judgements that it's fucking exhausting even when it's funny
column9:
and sometimes you have to mock everything because you feel powerless to change it. It makes you so angry that you have to keep repeating yourself.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22315/homepage_large.54ec0efd.jpg|Outfit Of The Day|33212.0|Moscow Club|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fastcut']|2015-10-02 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:41.266573|"

There was a moment a few years ago when Japan’s independent music scene seemed poised to break out internationally. Between 2011 and mid-2013
column2: artists from all over the nation were making inroads abroad -- shadowy project Jesse Ruins signed to Captured Tracks
column3: while outfits such as Sapphire Slows and Hotel Mexico were regulars on MP3 blogs such as Gorilla Vs. Bear
column4: with many more rising up beneath them. It was during this period that Tokyo’s Moscow Club started sharing their music online
column5: earning attention for their genre-hopping releases. The quartet also saw the potential in front of Japan’s indie community
column6: prompting them to spearhead a compilation in 2012 highlighting unsigned artists. “It is so exciting that there are still so many undiscovered amazing talents creating their own sound somewhere on this little island
column7: ” they wrote at the time.

column1: Moscow Club’s second full-length album
column2: Outfit Of The Day
column3: arrives long after the community they championed left the international spotlight. No moment can last forever
column4: and many of the bands from that fruitful span have broken up
column5: changed drastically or simply stopped doing anything (Moscow Club themselves vanished for two years
column6: returning this summer). Outfit features collaborations with many of the artists from that period
column7: and lends the album a feeling of a tribute for a time that slipped away
column8: but also serves as a reminder of the talent that still exists.

column1: Above all else
column2: Moscow Club -- and the artists in the same orbit -- stood out because they knew how to write a solid
column3: catchy song. Outfit starts with “Band Of Outsiders
column4: ” a fleet-footed indie-pop song packing every hooky idea it can into just over two minutes. This is the lane where Moscow Club excels
column5: and Outfit features plenty of guitar-anchored tracks skipping towards sticky choruses. They especially shine when glossing up their jangle with synthesizers. The extra twinkle adds an emotional pining central to numbers such as “Carven” and “Celine” (owing to a band-wide interest in fashion
column6: the album boasts a fashion theme
column7: down to the Instagram-born title). The latter -- written by lead singer Kazuro Matsubara after hearing a Tokyo train station melody and featuring backing vocals from Amanda Åkerman of Swedish group Alpaca Sports -- showcases Moscow Club at their best
column8: capable of a chugging number that progressively ups the drama.

column1: Although hazy
column2: melancholic indie-pop is their strength
column3: part of Moscow Club’s appeal has always been their eagerness to branch out
column4: resulting in glistening dance numbers or straight chillwave. Their ambition remains
column5: as one of Outfit’s finest comes on the slow-burning “Tour De Moskow.” The title gives away one key point of inspiration -- though
column6: if you forget
column7: the breathing samples throughout serve as a reminder - but its shuffled beat also pays homage to Frankie Knuckles’ “The Whistle Song” and nods to electro group Telex. It’s a lot to juggle
column8: but Moscow Club balance it all just right. More of a curveball
column9: though
column10: is “Carven (Orchestral)
column11: ” a four-minute orchestra version of the more straightforward “Carven.” It’s an interesting interlude
column12: albeit one that could have shaved a minute off.

column1: Outfit
column2: as mentioned
column3: isn’t just a Moscow Club creation
column4: but a collaborative effort featuring names central to the Japanese independent scene. Some of them appear on the songs proper -- Eri Nakajima of Osaka indie-poppers Wallflower sings on “Margaret
column5: ” while Ryota Komori plays saxophone on “Saint Laurent
column6: ” bringing the chaotic edge of his main band Miila and the Geeks to Moscow Club’s world. Two members of Kyoto’s now-defunct Hotel Mexico pop up too
column7: although only lead singer Ryuyu Ishigami appears on track
column8: as former bassist Kai Ito provided words for two songs. Yet the names behind the scenes are just as important
column9: helping to write the lyrics gracing Moscow Club’s music.

column1: It adds up to a very solid collection
column2: and one bringing to mind a time that feels long gone. Western media tends to cover Japanese acts veering to an extreme side
column3: whether that be harsh Japanoise or
column4: in more recent years
column5: cuter and weirder fare rarely taken seriously as music. The embrace of art confirming existing images of the country -- as strange
column6: as colorful
column7: as different -- is a disservice to bands such as Moscow Club
column8: who sing in English and don’t play up being Japanese for just that reason. Outfit Of The Day is a solid collection of indie-pop with some detours
column9:
and a reminder of how good the often overlooked indie community in the country can be. 

"|21048.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21048-outfit-of-the-day/|7.0|Patrick St. Michel

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22285/homepage_large.d5ac1316.jpg|New Bermuda|30011.0|Deafheaven|['Metal']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Anti-']|2015-10-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:42.571815|"

Nothing about the band Deafheaven makes literal sense
column2: starting with their place in the world. They are a black metal-ish band
column3: but black metal fans either hate them or engage in constant
column4: spirited discussions about why they don't. Their breakout
column5: 2013’s Sunbather
column6: took basic notions about black metal and shoegaze from their first album Roads to Judah and airlifted them into a rarefied emotional realm where track lengths dissolved into the whole along with straightforward interpretations: George Clarke’s lyrics compressed earthbound experiences—depression
column7: material envy
column8: struggles for purpose— into wild
column9: leaping abstractions about love
column10: oceans of light
column11: tears. This was music that yearned palpably to leap across distances
column12: closing gaps like a firing synapse.

column1: New Bermuda
column2: if anything
column3: is more overwhelming than Sunbather. The roiling peaks of that album—say
column4: “Dreamhouse” or ""The Pecan Tree”—are the resting temperature of this one. They have shaped a suite of songs into one pliable and massive 47-minute arc
column5: one that is as easy to separate into distinct quadrants as the stream from a fire hydrant. Clarke still screams euphoniously
column6: leaning into long vowel sounds and open tones so that phrases like “on the smokey tin it melts again and again” function as color more than as thought. (You could never discern the words without the aid of a lyric sheet
column7: anyway.) They are a band that works best in colors
column8: as the titles of the albums and the salmon color of Sunbather’s cover attest: On New Bermuda
column9: they revisit an ecstatic sound world that resembles
column10: as Clarke puts it on opening song “Brought to the Water”
column11: “a multiverse of fuchsia and light.”

column1: Having discovered this multiverse
column2: New Bermuda finds them shaping it. The album is shorter and more compressed than Sunbather
column3: and doesn’t telescope into “loud” and “quiet” sections quite as clearly. There is still a nauseous sort of beauty to their chord voicings: the lurches into minor key on “Luna” feel as heavy as their swings back into major
column4: like the motion of a great
column5: creaking iron gate. The second half of the “fuchsia and light” lyric is ""surrenders to blackness now
column6: ” and if Deafheaven’s music at its best represents a brilliant collision of beauty and despair
column7: the battle feels pitched at higher stakes than it did on Sunbather. Clarke’s voice is sharper and mixed lower
column8: clawing at the smooth walls of the music like something wretched trying to escape a pit.

column1: The lyrics suggest that this confining space might resemble the sort of manicured suburban prison that Sunbather was set inside: ""There is no ocean for me. There is no glamour. Only the mirage of water ascending from the asphalt. I gaze at it from the oven of my home. Confined to a house that never remains clean
column2: ” runs a passage from “Luna”. But listening to Deafheaven
column3: you don’t feel the particulars of this dilemma any more than you notice the pebbles of a gravel driveway from the window of an airplane. The music acts as an incinerator for any malaise you bring to it. It is a warm blur of noise
column4: and fans of many different kinds of moody sensual guitar musics can close their eyes and place themselves inside it: If you have at any point worn a Deftones
column5: Cure
column6: My Bloody Valentine
column7: or an Explosions in the Sky t-shirt
column8: there is room for you inside here.

column1: But Deafheaven reach further and further on this album: The drowsily sliding guitars on the long coda to “Come Back” conjure the easy warmth of Built to Spill. An organ wells up as the guitars fade
column2: like something Ira Kaplan would do on a Yo La Tengo record. The thick palm-muted chugging on the beginning of “Luna” is reminiscent of the Slayer of Seasons of the Abyss. The undistorted downstrokes on “Gifts for the Earth” are a visitation from Joy Division
column3: while the flagrant wah-pedal abusing guitar solo on “Baby Blue” is pure Load-era Kirk Hammett.

column1: All of these references
column2: which bring together many bands that wouldn’t normally have much to do with one another
column3: points to something dreamlike and uncanny in Deafheaven’s grand sound. At a moment when guitar-centric music feels less central to the conversation
column4: and great indie-rock bands have retreated into hardy local scenes
column5: Deafheaven play like a beautiful
column6: abstracted dream of guitar music's transportive power. The year's most jolting guitar-centered rock records have reimagined the guitar's place in the constellation slightly—on Tame Impala’s Currents
column7: the guitar glimmers distantly at us from beneath a glass
column8: darkly—a distant shape moving beneath the larger
column9: more legible shapes of the compressed drums and programmed synths. On Kurt Vile’s b’lieve i’m going down
column10: it is part of a general out-of-time way of life
column11: a devotion to anachronism and lived-in symbols that keeps the confusion of the outside world at bay.

column1: Deafheaven
column2: meanwhile
column3: unabashedly treat the roar of electric guitars as a holy experience. But they have earned their sense of awe
column4: and you can see audiences returning it tenfold in their live performances. The transcendence their music gazes towards has a long spiritual lineage. To wit: I pulled my earbuds out while listening to New Bermuda this morning in a store where Boston's ""More Than A Feeling"" was playing. The transition was seamless. They were aiming at the same horizon spot
column5:
made for the moment when you begin dreaming.

"|21022.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21022-new-bermuda/|9.0|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22394/homepage_large.ae30db52.jpg|Big Grams|33207.0|Big Grams|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Epic']|2015-10-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:43.111421|"

As a solo rapper
column2: Big Boi has been pushing steadily against the old preconception that he was the less-daring half of Outkast. On all three of his solo albums—Speakerboxxx counts— he happily explored his quirks
column3: establishing himself as someone more than just Andre 3000's more stolid counterpart. With Sir Lucious Left Foot: The Son of Chico Dusty
column4: he pulled off an incredible
column5: boisterously funky reintroduction. Vicious Lies and Dangerous Rumors paired him with Wavves
column6: Little Dragon and Phantogram among others
column7: and if the results were mixed
column8: it was further evidence of Antwan Patton's voracious ear.

column1: Vicious Lies paved the way for this full Phantogram collaboration. The indie-pop duo featured on three of the songs on Vicious
column2: but on Big Grams they hit a bit more of a stride. This isn't a Big Boi-on-Phantogram beats project
column3: and Phantogram's Sarah Barthel is nearly as central as the OutKast rapper as a lead vocalist. The two trade spots as lead vocalists playfully and Barthel's hooks are integral throughout. Barthel tries some rapping
column4: and the results aren't actively embarrassing.

column1: ""Run for Your Life""
column2: the lead track
column3: is sparse and spacey
column4: and the synth sounds lifted from Stevie Wonder's Moog on ""Boogie On Reggae Woman"". Big Boi's raps aren't deep on Big Grams
column5: but they are captivating: His strategically fluttering drawl
column6: doled out in pitter-patter bursts
column7: is a trademark as recognizable as it is versatile. On ""Fell in the Sun"" he punches quickly with a staccato: ""I whip the yellow Cadillac
column8: I like my seats way back / I bust the sunroof open
column9: beams hit the Braves cap.""  This track
column10: the lead single
column11: is the obvious standout
column12: and it's here that the collaboration clicks fully. Phantogram's Josh Carter builds up a throbbing wall of synths atop a snappy drum loop
column13: and like elsewhere
column14: horn stabs punctuates: proof
column15: perhaps
column16: that everything Big Boi does deserves a little funk.

column1: ""Put It On Her"" is one of two tracks on the outing not produced by Carter
column2: and it's certainly the better and more natural of them. (That soulful pump fake of an intro turns out to be a subtle 9th Wonder calling card.) The Skrillex-featuring ""Drum Machine""
column3: however
column4: sticks out like a sore thumb and bogs down the end of the album. For a record that's so smoothly collaborative elsewhere
column5: ""Drum Machine"" sounds contrived and clunky. Luckily it is tacked on the end
column6: making it entirely skippable.

column1: The Run the Jewels feature on ""Born to Shine"" fares better
column2: and not just because of Big Boi's pivotal role in Killer Mike's career. Mike's verse steals the show—""Ric Flair'in' / Long fur coat wearin' / Rolex rockin' / Silk shirt wearin'""—while Big Boi happily takes a backseat. This may be a hallmark of Patton's career:  He's continually building up evidence that he doesn't care so much about being the lead as he is interested in being in the middle of something new and different. Given Atlanta's persistent vitality as a hotbed for innovative hip-hop
column3: it's nice to know that one of the city's elder statesmen is off doing his own thing
column4:
carving out another little path for himself long after he helped pave the main road.

"|21166.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21166-big-grams/|6.4|Jay Balfour

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/22354/homepage_large.f50773ca.jpg|Five Years 1969-1973|438.0|David Bowie|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Parlophone']|2015-10-01 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:43.856320|"

""Not only is this the last show of the tour""
column2: David Bowie announced at London's Hammersmith Odeon on June 3
column3: 1973 by way of introduction to ""Rock 'n' Roll Suicide""
column4: ""but it is the last show we will ever do."" The recording of that nugget of rock history appears in this box collecting most of Bowie's music from the years of his ascent
column5: so let's take him at his word for a moment.

column1: Imagine that Five Years (allegedly the first of a series
column2: though Bowie has always announced many more projects than he's released) was all the documentation there was of his musical career—that he'd entered the public sphere with his 1969 single ""Space Oddity""
column3: retired from the stage after the Ziggy Stardust/Aladdin Sane tour
column4: and vanished to a Tibetan mountaintop following a loving salute to his roots
column5: Pin Ups. He'd certainly be some kind of glam-rock legend
column6: even more than his friend and rival Marc Bolan. He probably wouldn't have the enduring cultural cachet he commands in our world
column7: but there would still be a fervent cult around his three great albums and three iffy-to-good ones
column8: and even more interest in his live recordings and ephemera. To put it differently
column9: Hedwig and the Angry Inch would be the same; LCD Soundsystem wouldn't.

column1: In our world
column2: though
column3: Five Years is only a slice of a much longer curve. The earliest album in the box
column4: 1969's David Bowie—a.k.a. Space Oddity
column5: a.k.a. Man of Words/Man of Music—wasn't Bowie's recorded debut
column6: or even his first self-titled album. (In fact
column7: there could theoretically be a Five Years 1964-1968
column8: tracing his evolution from rock 'n' roll wannabe to fussy vaudevillean
column9: although it would mostly be kind of awful.) It was
column10: however
column11: a follow-up to his first successful single
column12: a haunting novelty record about a lost astronaut that had been released a week and a half before the moon landing. The young singer/acoustic guitarist behind these songs obviously has a mountain of charisma
column13: a gift for hooks
column14: and a taste for the language of experimental science fiction
column15: and not the faintest idea what to do with them most of the time. So he wears his influences on his sleeve (""Letter to Hermione"" is intensely Tim Buckley-ish; ""Memory of a Free Festival"" is a hippie rewrite of ""Hey Jude"")
column16: and constantly overreaches for dramatic effect.

column1: As it turns out
column2: what he really needed was a good hard rock'n'roll band. Bowie assembled a very short-lived group called the Hype with guitarist Mick Ronson and bassist Tony Visconti; by the time they recorded The Man Who Sold the World in April
column4: they'd picked up drummer Mick ""Woody"" Woodmansey
column5: and gone back to using their singer's name. The Man Who Sold the World is the dark horse of the Bowie catalog. There were no singles issued from it
column6: and the title track didn't really become a standard until Nirvana covered it decades later. But toughening up the arrangements made Bowie's stagey warble vastly more effective
column7: and a lot of his artistic risks paid off: the album's opener is a ferocious eight-minute metal sci-fi opus
column8: ""The Width of a Circle""
column9: with some of the most overtly homoerotic lyrics a pop musician had ever intoned (""He swallowed his pride and puckered his lips/ And showed me the leather belt 'round his hips"").

column1: The theme of shifting sexual identity became the core of Bowie's next album
column2: 1971's scattered but splendid Hunky Dory: ""Gotta make way for the Homo Superior
column3: he squeals on the gay-bar singalong ""Oh! You Pretty Things""
column4: simultaneously nodding to Nietzsche and to X-Men. He'd also made huge leaps as a songwriter
column5: and his new songs demonstrated the breadth of his power: the epic Jacques Brel-gone-Dada torch song ""Life on Mars?"" is immediately followed by ""Kooks""
column6: an adorable lullaby for his infant son. The band (with Trevor Bolder replacing Visconti on bass) mostly keeps its power in check—""Changes"" is effectively Bowie explaining his aesthetic to fans of the Carpenters. Still
column7: they cut loose on the album's most brilliant jewel
column8: ""Queen Bitch""
column9: a furiously rocking theatrical miniature (Bowie-the-character-actor has rarely chewed the scenery harder) that out-Velvet Undergrounds the Velvet Underground.

column1: The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars from 1972 was the record that made Bowie the star he'd been acting like for a while
column2: although its reputation isn't quite the same as its reality. It was mostly recorded before Hunky Dory was released; it purports to be a concept album
column3: but doesn't actually have a coherent concept. (""Starman""
column4: ""Suffragette City"" and ""Rock 'n' Roll Suicide"" were all late additions to its running order.) It is
column5: nonetheless
column6: a fantastic set of songs
column7: overflowing with huge riffs and huger personae. ""Five Years"" opens the album with Bowie's grandest sci-fi apocalypse yet
column8: Mick Ronson shreds his way to the guitar pantheon
column9: and the band's flamboyant performance of ""Starman"" on Top of the Pops famously gave the next generation of British pop musicians a bunch of funny tingling sensations. The whole album
column10: in fact
column11: is as erotically charged as an orgone accumulator: Bowie was probably the only person who could have remained sexually ambiguous after declaring ""I'm gay
column12: and always have been.""

column1: Aladdin Sane
column2: recorded while Bowie and the Spiders were touring their asses off in an attempt to get America to love them the way England already did
column3: is effectively Ziggy Stardust II
column4: a harder-rocking if less original variation on the hit album. There's a paranoid sci-fi scenario (""Panic in Detroit"")
column5: a blues-rock stomp (""The Jean Genie"")
column6: a bit of cabaret (""Time"")
column7: a blunt sex-and-drugs nightmare (""Cracked Actor""). The big difference is that where Ziggy ended with a vision of outreach to the front row (""Give me your hands
column8: 'cause you're wonderful!"")
column9: Aladdin is all alienation and self-conscious artifice
column10: parodic gestures of intimacy directed to the theater balcony. Bowie overenunciates his cover of the Rolling Stones' ""Let's Spend the Night Together"" to turn it into a caricature of a disinterested Casanova; his sneering rocker ""Watch That Man"" is a better evocation of the Stones themselves.

column1: Then there's Pin Ups
column2: a quick-and-sloppy covers album that's more interesting in theory than in practice. The repertoire is the songs he'd heard in London clubs when he'd been starting out as a professional musician (less than a decade earlier)
column3: and that had shaped his idea of rock: music by the Yardbirds
column4: the Who
column5: the Pretty Things
column6: and the like. (In other words
column7: not so much his idols as contemporaries who found their audience before he did.) But the original versions of every one of those songs are vastly better
column8: because Bowie doesn't have much to say through any of them
column9: and covers up for it through cruise-ship-entertainer oversinging. His art
column10: in those days
column11: was an art of persona
column12: and songs like ""Sorrow"" and ""See Emily Play"" didn't have much to offer it. The band was falling apart
column13: too: the Spiders' drummer Woody Woodmansey had been replaced by Aynsley Dunbar (a veteran of the same London scene)
column14: and Ronson and Bolder were gone by the next time Bowie recorded.

column1: Bowie released six studio albums in the '69-'73 period
column2: but Five Years is a 12-disc set. The Ziggy film soundtrack
column3: a document of that allegedly final stage performance that was first released a decade later
column4: appears in its expanded
column5: two-disc 2003 form
column6: complete with a 15-minute ""The Width of a Circle"" and unnecessary Jacques Brel and Velvet Underground covers (still no sign of the songs on which Jeff Beck played at that gig
column7: though). Live Santa Monica '72
column8: a radio broadcast that was bootlegged for decades and officially issued in 2008
column9: is included here too. Ziggy Stardust itself appears in both its original mix and co-producer Ken Scott's 2003 remix
column10: which is frankly not all that different.

column1: The selling point here for Bowiephiles who probably have all of that stuff already is the two-disc Re:Call 1 (its title cheekily adapts the old RCA Records logo's typeface)
column2: a collection of material that only appeared on singles. Some of them are triflingly different mono mixes
column3: but there are a few fascinating oddities: both the never-previously-reissued 1970 dud ""Holy Holy"" and the much sharper 1971 remake that nearly made it onto Ziggy Stardust
column4: both the frequently-reissued 1972 killer ""John
column5: I'm Only Dancing"" and the just-as-good 1973 remake that nearly made it onto Aladdin Sane
column6: and a peculiar '71 single (released under the name The Arnold Corns) with larval versions of ""Hang On to Yourself"" and ""Moonage Daydream""
column7: both of which were heavily rewritten for Ziggy. Still
column8: Re:Call 1 is far from a complete collection of the officially issued recordings that Bowie made in the 1969-1973 era: there's no ""Sweet Head"" or ""Lightning Frightening"" or ""Bombers""
column9: for instance
column10: and it'd have been nice to include the version of ""The Supermen"" that he re-recorded in 1971 with the Spiders from Mars' classic lineup.

column1: Five Years doesn't really reconsider or recontextualize Bowie's first classic period—that was more the job of EMI's Ziggy Stardust and Aladdin Sane reissues a decade ago
column2: and their 2009 Space Oddity reissue. (The book included with the new set features producers' notes from Tony Visconti and Ken Scott
column3: contemporary reviews of the albums and the final Ziggy show
column4: and reproductions of ads
column5: but nothing especially revelatory.) It's just a collection of some superb records
column6: and some less good ones
column7: from an interesting era of a major artist. If those five years had been all we'd gotten of Bowie
column8: this would be an essential artifact. But they weren't
column9:
and the wonders that followed them make the scope of this box seem both over-inclusive and incomplete.  

"|21066.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21066-five-years-1969-1973/|8.2|Douglas Wolk

""Not only is this the last show of the tour""

column3: 1973 by way of introduction to ""Rock 'n' Roll Suicide""
column4: ""but it is the last show we will ever do."" The recording of that nugget of rock history appears in this box collecting most of Bowie's music from the years of his ascent
column5: so let's take him at his word for a moment.

column1: Imagine that Five Years (allegedly the first of a series
column2: though Bowie has always announced many more projects than he's released) was all the documentation there was of his musical career—that he'd entered the public sphere with his 1969 single ""Space Oddity""
column3: retired from the stage after the Ziggy Stardust/Aladdin Sane tour
column4: and vanished to a Tibetan mountaintop following a loving salute to his roots
column5: Pin Ups. He'd certainly be some kind of glam-rock legend
column6: even more than his friend and rival Marc Bolan. He probably wouldn't have the enduring cultural cachet he commands in our world
column7: but there would still be a fervent cult around his three great albums and three iffy-to-good ones
column8: and even more interest in his live recordings and ephemera. To put it differently
column9: Hedwig and the Angry Inch would be the same; LCD Soundsystem wouldn't.

column1: In our world
column2: though
column3: Five Years is only a slice of a much longer curve. The earliest album in the box
column4: 1969's David Bowie—a.k.a. Space Oddity
column5: a.k.a. Man of Words/Man of Music—wasn't Bowie's recorded debut
column6: or even his first self-titled album. (In fact
column7: there could theoretically be a Five Years 1964-1968
column8: tracing his evolution from rock 'n' roll wannabe to fussy vaudevillean
column9: although it would mostly be kind of awful.) It was
column10: however
column11: a follow-up to his first successful single
column12: a haunting novelty record about a lost astronaut that had been released a week and a half before the moon landing. The young singer/acoustic guitarist behind these songs obviously has a mountain of charisma
column13: a gift for hooks
column14: and a taste for the language of experimental science fiction
column15: and not the faintest idea what to do with them most of the time. So he wears his influences on his sleeve (""Letter to Hermione"" is intensely Tim Buckley-ish; ""Memory of a Free Festival"" is a hippie rewrite of ""Hey Jude"")
column16: and constantly overreaches for dramatic effect.

column1: As it turns out
column2: what he really needed was a good hard rock'n'roll band. Bowie assembled a very short-lived group called the Hype with guitarist Mick Ronson and bassist Tony Visconti; by the time they recorded The Man Who Sold the World in April
column4: they'd picked up drummer Mick ""Woody"" Woodmansey
column5: and gone back to using their singer's name. The Man Who Sold the World is the dark horse of the Bowie catalog. There were no singles issued from it
column6: and the title track didn't really become a standard until Nirvana covered it decades later. But toughening up the arrangements made Bowie's stagey warble vastly more effective
column7: and a lot of his artistic risks paid off: the album's opener is a ferocious eight-minute metal sci-fi opus
column8: ""The Width of a Circle""
column9: with some of the most overtly homoerotic lyrics a pop musician had ever intoned (""He swallowed his pride and puckered his lips/ And showed me the leather belt 'round his hips"").

column1: The theme of shifting sexual identity became the core of Bowie's next album
column2: 1971's scattered but splendid Hunky Dory: ""Gotta make way for the Homo Superior
column3: he squeals on the gay-bar singalong ""Oh! You Pretty Things""
column4: simultaneously nodding to Nietzsche and to X-Men. He'd also made huge leaps as a songwriter
column5: and his new songs demonstrated the breadth of his power: the epic Jacques Brel-gone-Dada torch song ""Life on Mars?"" is immediately followed by ""Kooks""
column6: an adorable lullaby for his infant son. The band (with Trevor Bolder replacing Visconti on bass) mostly keeps its power in check—""Changes"" is effectively Bowie explaining his aesthetic to fans of the Carpenters. Still

column9: a furiously rocking theatrical miniature (Bowie-the-character-actor has rarely chewed the scenery harder) that out-Velvet Undergrounds the Velvet Underground.

column1: Aladdin Sane

column2: although its reputation isn't quite the same as its reality. It was mostly recorded before Hunky Dory was released; it purports to be a concept album
column3: but doesn't actually have a coherent concept. (""Starman""
column4: ""Suffragette City"" and ""Rock 'n' Roll Suicide"" were all late additions to its running order.) It is
column5: nonetheless

column7: overflowing with huge riffs and huger personae. ""Five Years"" opens the album with Bowie's grandest sci-fi apocalypse yet
column8: Mick Ronson shreds his way to the guitar pantheon
column9: and the band's flamboyant performance of ""Starman"" on Top of the Pops famously gave the next generation of British pop musicians a bunch of funny tingling sensations. The whole album
column10: in fact
column11: is as erotically charged as an orgone accumulator: Bowie was probably the only person who could have remained sexually ambiguous after declaring ""I'm gay
column12: and always have been.""

column1: Aladdin Sane
column2: recorded while Bowie and the Spiders were touring their asses off in an attempt to get America to love them the way England already did
column3: is effectively Ziggy Stardust II
column4: a harder-rocking if less original variation on the hit album. There's a paranoid sci-fi scenario (""Panic in Detroit"")
column5: a blues-rock stomp (""The Jean Genie"")
column6: a bit of cabaret (""Time"")
column7: a blunt sex-and-drugs nightmare (""Cracked Actor""). The big difference is that where Ziggy ended with a vision of outreach to the front row (""Give me your hands
column8: 'cause you're wonderful!"")
column9: Aladdin is all alienation and self-conscious artifice
column10: parodic gestures of intimacy directed to the theater balcony. Bowie overenunciates his cover of the Rolling Stones' ""Let's Spend the Night Together"" to turn it into a caricature of a disinterested Casanova; his sneering rocker ""Watch That Man"" is a better evocation of the Stones themselves.

column1: Then there's Pin Ups
column2: a quick-and-sloppy covers album that's more interesting in theory than in practice. The repertoire is the songs he'd heard in London clubs when he'd been starting out as a professional musician (less than a decade earlier)
column3: and that had shaped his idea of rock: music by the Yardbirds
column4: the Who
column5: the Pretty Things
column6: and the like. (In other words
column7: not so much his idols as contemporaries who found their audience before he did.) But the original versions of every one of those songs are vastly better
column8: because Bowie doesn't have much to say through any of them
column9: and covers up for it through cruise-ship-entertainer oversinging. His art
column10: in those days
column11: was an art of persona
column12: and songs like ""Sorrow"" and ""See Emily Play"" didn't have much to offer it. The band was falling apart
column13: too: the Spiders' drummer Woody Woodmansey had been replaced by Aynsley Dunbar (a veteran of the same London scene)

column1: Bowie released six studio albums in the '69-'73 period
column2: but Five Years is a 12-disc set. The Ziggy film soundtrack
column3: a document of that allegedly final stage performance that was first released a decade later

column5: two-disc 2003 form
column6: complete with a 15-minute ""The Width of a Circle"" and unnecessary Jacques Brel and Velvet Underground covers (still no sign of the songs on which Jeff Beck played at that gig

column1: The selling point here for Bowiephiles who probably have all of that stuff already is the two-disc Re:Call 1 (its title cheekily adapts the old RCA Records logo's typeface)
column2: a collection of material that only appeared on singles. Some of them are triflingly different mono mixes
column3: but there are a few fascinating oddities: both the never-previously-reissued 1970 dud ""Holy Holy"" and the much sharper 1971 remake that nearly made it onto Ziggy Stardust
column4: both the frequently-reissued 1972 killer ""John
column5: I'm Only Dancing"" and the just-as-good 1973 remake that nearly made it onto Aladdin Sane
column6: and a peculiar '71 single (released under the name The Arnold Corns) with larval versions of ""Hang On to Yourself"" and ""Moonage Daydream""
column7: both of which were heavily rewritten for Ziggy. Still
column8: Re:Call 1 is far from a complete collection of the officially issued recordings that Bowie made in the 1969-1973 era: there's no ""Sweet Head"" or ""Lightning Frightening"" or ""Bombers""

column1: Five Years doesn't really reconsider or recontextualize Bowie's first classic period—that was more the job of EMI's Ziggy Stardust and Aladdin Sane reissues a decade ago
column2: and their 2009 Space Oddity reissue. (The book included with the new set features producers' notes from Tony Visconti and Ken Scott
column3: contemporary reviews of the albums and the final Ziggy show
column4: and reproductions of ads
column5: but nothing especially revelatory.) It's just a collection of some superb records
column6: and some less good ones
column7: from an interesting era of a major artist. If those five years had been all we'd gotten of Bowie
column8: this would be an essential artifact. But they weren't
column9:
and the wonders that followed them make the scope of this box seem both over-inclusive and incomplete.

and the wonders that followed them make the scope of this box seem both over-inclusive and incomplete.

Top Dawg Entertainment first signed Jay Rock in 2005
column2: in the wake of the Game's The Documentary. At the time
column3: the Dr. Dre-sanctioned multiplatinum album seemed to promise a resurgence for Cali gangsta rap
column4: which might reclaim the throne it abdicated in the mid-'90s after the death of 2Pac. Instead
column5: Game’s Shady/Aftermath/G-Unit connection combusted spectacularly with the record still fresh in stores and L.A.’s stronghold broke
column6: as Snoop became a ward of the Neptunes
column7: Dre tinkered with a third album we’ve only just come to hear this summer
column8: and everyone else fought nobly but ultimately lost footing in the mainstream for good.

column1: This was the climate that Jay Rock found himself facing when he geared up to release his debut studio album Follow Me Home. The album's singles stalled
column2: its release date languished
column3: and it only saw release in 2011
column4: when it sounded like a formalist relic amid the then-just-emerging DJ Mustard
column5: YG
column6: Ty Dolla $ign and Tyga. It stalled at retail
column7: quietly matched for sales (but surpassed in acclaim) by Kendrick Lamar’s insular
column8: world-weary Section.80
column9: released the same month.

column1: Four years later
column2: Kendrick is the sun around which more than just TDE revolves: his gold and platinum successes have bushwhacked a space for young poetic everymen to coexist at radio. Jay Rock might not ever be top dog at his label again
column3: but the lessons of his first failure to launch – that a magnetic persona and perspective outstrip shiny celebrity cosigns and cookie cutter image constructs every time – are crucial to the success of the TDE machine. Jay Rock’s taken the message to heart on his sophomore album 90059
column4: which dramatically shifts the focus of his studio work from making him look tough and cool to illuminating the human struggles beneath.

column1: good kid
column2: m.A.A.d city’s “Money Trees” introduce a lot of listeners unfamiliar with Jay Rock’s history to his talents
column3: so it’s fitting that the pre-album single to 90059 is a sequel: ""Money Trees Deuce."" The song is an excellent point of entry into the new album’s mood; its panoramic view of West Coast street life is more nuanced than old Jay Rock records
column4: and the production freely traverses styles. The jazz rap of “Money Trees Deuce”
column5: Dilla homage of “Fly on the Wall”
column6: post-Dre Cali thump of “Necessary”
column7: Southernplayalistic future soul of “Wanna Ride”
column8: and Shaolin swordplay of “90059” collide
column9: each a little bit of seasoning in this gumbo
column10: as Rock notes on track three.

column1: 90059’s expanded palette allows the rapper to stretch out too
column2: and he dazzles with limber diction and stunning
column3: cinematic imagery. Opener “Necessary” unfurls the story of a drunken drive-by in lurid detail: “On Forgiato rim tire
column4: automatics spit fire/ Yack in the black canister
column5: look at this bastard go/ It don’t take much to aim
column6: fingers be snatching souls”. Later
column7: “Telegram (Going Krazy)” uses an almost imperceptible hairpin slight of tongue (“I see the telegram goin’ crazy/ I tell the ‘Gram I’m goin’ crazy”) to trip off the story of a couple drifting apart because one is freer with her emotions on social media than she is in close quarters with her lover.

column1: Jay Rock’s concepts are braver and weirder here
column2: his words more arresting and illustrative
column3: but the major reinvention of 90059 is his delivery. On “Easy Bake”
column4: Rock hovers around the high end of his register to counteract Kendrick’s deeper
column5: richer tone. He’s singing a lot now
column6: too
column7: and not in the gruff gangster-on-Easter-Sunday mode of Follow Me Home. The melodic turns on 90059’s “Telegram (Going Krazy)” and “Money Trees Deuce” are unfussed and soulful
column8: while the title track has a drunken Ol’ Dirty Bastard energy  completely unfamiliar to Rock's catalog. The album’s bolder vocal turns are credited to a “Lance Skiiiwalker”
column9: but Lance is about as distinguishable from Rock as T.I. was from T.I.P. or Biggie from bizarro Biggie on “Gimme the Loot.” Cuts like “Gumbo” and “The Ways” juggle all of these tricks to showcase a lyricist gracefully in control of his instrument. It's a heartening showcase
column10:
and a reminder of just how much vitality there is in TDE's orbit.

It’s been seven years since Mercury Rev's last album
column2: and even by this long-suffering band’s standards
column3: the ensuing period was tumultuous. When we last heard from them
column4: they seemed to be tentatively stepping away from their Catskills-scaled orchestro-rock on 2008’s Snowflake Midnight and its ambient companion piece Strange Attractors. And more recently
column5: they revisited their avant-garde film-school roots
column6: performing live improvized soundtracks to screenings as the Cinematic Sound Tettix BrainWave Concerto Experiment. But given the recent upheaval in Donahue and Mackowiak’s personal lives
column7: The Light on You finds Mercury Rev taking comfort in the familiar. The band spent much of 2011’s touring behind a deluxe reissue of Deserter’s Songs
column8: and
column9: in many respects
column10: that campaign continues here. But on The Light In You
column11: the proverbial deserters throw themselves a celebratory homecoming after years in the wilderness.

column1: The album charts a gradual
column2: linear journey from darkness to light
column3: with the first half featuring the weightiest
column4: most affecting songs the band has produced since 2001’s (vastly underrated) All Is Dream. For the first time in Mercury Rev history
column5: bassist/producer Dave Fridmann was not involved in the recording
column6: but after 25 years of working with him
column7: Donahue and Mackowiak have a pretty firm grasp on how recreate his seismic sound. So even if the opening ""Queen of Swans"" begins as typically twee Donahue ode to a mythical goddess
column8: its helium-huffing chorus is followed by a rupture that sounds like an orchestra tumbling into a fault line.

column1: While that song serves as a reintroduction to Mercury Rev’s symphonic might
column2: they wield it to more devastating effect on ""Amelie""
column3: where mounting string swells accompany a junkie’s plea for forgiveness (""I’ll break the habit/ it’s my last score"") that seems destined to go unanswered; the gorgeous
column4: ELO-esque sweep of ""You’ve Gone With So Little For So Long"" doesn’t gloss over the tale of impoverished hardship couched within. And with the six-minute epic ""Central Park East""
column5: Mercury Rev provide a staggering reminder of what made Deserter’s Songs so captivating: They conjure a sense of intense isolation amid vast
column6: breathtaking vistas. It’s the sort of song that’s intimate enough to let you see the cold breath coming from the mouth of Donahue’s park-prowling protagonist
column7: while expansive enough to conjure the glow of the skyscrapers surrounding him.

column1: But The Light in You eventually lets go of urban tensions to revel in the psychedelia of nature. Delivering the sundazed serenades ""Coming Up for Air"" and ""Autumn in the Air""
column2: Donahue sounds like someone who can get a contact high just from watching the leaves fall. On the latter track
column3: he sings
column4: ""I guess this must be what it’s like/ to be in Beatle George’s mind
column5: which actually proves to be a relatively subtle namedrop compared to what follows.

column1: In what might be the most bizarre turn in this band’s disjointed trajectory
column2: The Light in You’s final third sees Mercury Rev refashion themselves as the house band on some alternate-universe ’60s teen dance show
column3: complete with exuberant brass fanfares
column4: sitar accents
column5: and bongo-powered go-go-dancer breakdowns. In their time
column6: Mercury Rev have covered enough oldies-radio standards to fill several jukeboxes
column7: but here Donahue practically turns into a pitchman for a Time-Life box set—on ""Are You Ready
column8: he’s getting down to The Rascals and The Pretty Things and episodes of Shindig! and Solid Gold; ""Rainy Day Record"" awkwardly extols the life-changing virtues of listening to misanthropic ’80s post-punk on vinyl in the context of a cheery paisley-soul romp. (Even if you happen to enjoy Jonathan Donahue
column9: rap music
column10: and The Fall
column11: you don’t need to hear Jonathan Donahue rapping about The Fall.) In light of all this band has gone through over the years
column12: it’s understandable that they’d want to let loose
column13: have some fun
column14: and reconnect with the feeling of discovering a favorite band for the first time. But as The Light in You’s dichotomous halves prove
column15:
Mercury Rev are much better at being trippy than being groovy.

column7: a place we would almost certainly not be talking about were it not for Fetty Wap; he's fiercely loyal to his longtime Remy Boyz 1738 crew

column9: a rapper we would assuredly not be talking about were it not for Fetty Wap. He's almost singlehandedly revived the ride-or-die thug love ballad with a serotonin-soaked ditty—now double-platinum—that turns a negative situation (having to cook dope to make a living) into not just an unforgettable date but a symbolic proclamation of undying

column1: If there's any hurdle in Fetty's way at this point

column1: With Fetty Wap

column1: The first thing you might notice on Fetty Wap's tracklist isn't what's there—if you've kept up with his output over the last year and a half
column2: there's a lot you'll recognize here—but who isn't. Drake's hastily added guest verse to ""My Way"" from earlier this year is missing; the album version features a verse from Remy Boyz' Monty
column3: who appears on nine of the album's 20 tracks
column4: the only guest aside from relatively unknown M80. As a whole
column5: Fetty Wap adopts the same self-assured stance: Fetty's formula definitely ain't broke
column6: and he doesn't seem in a hurry to fix it. In what can only be described as a flex

column1: That's the thing: you could shuffle these tracks endlessly and the album would probably have the same effect. It's not that there are any missteps here
column2: really; if you like what you've already heard from Fetty
column3: you'll like these songs. There are variations
column4: to be sure—second single ""679"" borrows some West Coast bounce
column5: functioning as a clubby palate cleanser in the way that ""Fight Night"" did for Migos. ""I Wonder"" and ""Boomin"" successfully skulk into drill's shadowy corners. But for the most part
column6: Fetty doesn't venture too far outside his comfort zone.

column1: Still
column2: when the highs are this high
column3: it's hard to complain. ""My Way"" is still 2015's ultimate trap lullaby
column4: lilting in hypnotic spirals. ""RGF Island"" turns somber keys into a hard-earned celebration

column7: he crows
column8: reassuring his fed-up trap queen that his crazy life will all be worth it when they can enjoy it together. Fetty approaches everything in his music with the earnest devotion of matrimony: his trap queen
column9: his money
column10: his beloved Remy Boyz. So though it's tempting to wonder what may have happened had 300 recruited labelmates Young Thug or Quavo
column11: or beatmakers du jour like Metro Boomin or Zaytoven
column12:
it's only right Fetty insisted on keeping things in the 1738 family.

It's entirely possible that when Jack White allegedly threatened to beat up Black Keys drummer Patrick Carney in a New York City bar earlier this month he was doing some street-team marketing for the new Dead Weather record. Because whenever White steps behind the drum kit of this scuzz-rock supergroup
column2: he hits with a crazed intensity that suggests he’s looking to pound a different sort of skin. Since the release of the band’s previous album
column3: 2010’s Sea of Cowards
column4: White has embarked on a solo career that’s seen his work turn both more intimate and extravagant; in this light
column5: the Dead Weather have come to represent the hanging side of beef on which he can unleash his pent-up aggression.

column1: Tellingly
column2: White and his mates—Kills vocalist Alison Mosshart
column3: City and Colour bassist Jack Lawrence
column4: and Queens of the Stone Age guitarst/keyboardist Dean Fertita—have announced they have no plans to tour in support of Dodge and Burn. This news would reinforce the notion that this group essentially functions as an exorcism of its members’ most feral tendencies before they return to their day jobs. Theirs is a blues defined not by chord progressions but physical reactions
column5: embodying the music’s storied tradition of howls and moans and demonic possession into a fierce
column6: physical sound. There’s a restlessness to Dodge and Burn
column7: from Mosshart’s seething vocals and Fertita’s spasmodic guitar solos to Lawrence’s corroded basslines to White’s abrupt breakdowns. Even when songs are built around a shopworn sentiment

column1: The Dead Weather’s cabin-in-the-woods creepiness can verge on the contrived—like on ""Three Dollar Hat""

column3: and losing. But the band’s theatricality mostly complements the agitated tone of the songs and the dubby
column4: dread-of-night ambiance of White’s production
column5: particularly in those moments when Mosshart and White go head-to-head. The mid-album knockout ""Rough Detective"" sees the two trading verses and pushing one another to hysterical extremes; instead of dropping the typical guitar solo after the second shout-it-out chorus
column6: the song yields a carnival-like melee of chopped-up chatter and pitch-shifted squeals. And when White asks
column7: ""what’s happening?""

column1: Like its predecessors
column2: Dodge and Burn can leave you wishing for more interaction between the two leads—the duets are always the highlight of any given Dead Weather record
column3: the moment when all that simmering tension boils over. But Mosshart once again handles the heavy vocal lifting with menace to spare
column4: be it the frisky sing-speak of ""Mile Markers""
column5: the predatory soul stomp of ""Let Me Through""
column6: or the violent mood swings of ""Open Up""
column7: which upends its desolate opening verse with a riff straight off an early Rush record. And given her commitment to staying in character
column8: it’s doubly strange how

column10: the Dead Weather completely abandon their monochromatic schematic.

column1: Dodge and Burn is capped by the ill-fitting ""Impossible Winner""
column2: a sensitive piano ballad that’s practically Oasis-like in its orchestral ascent (and which
column3: in light of the equally stately ""The Last Goodbye"" from the last Kills record
column4: prods Mosshart further toward her destiny as a torch-song chanteuse). It’d be one thing if there was anything else on this record—or in the band’s entire discography

the song feels less like a graceful break-of-dawn denouement than the musical equivalent of being awakened in the middle of the night by a flashlight to the face.

column7: and while Peaches has carved out a substantial career for herself in both the music and art world
column8: the straight press largely moved on.With Rub

column1: The overarching themes of Peaches' work—gender identity and expression
column2: queer sex
column3: leftist politics—are now more than ever at the forefront of our culture
column4: which means her lyrics sound less transgressive than they might have even five years ago: ""Can't talk right now/ This chick's dick is in my mouth"" she deadpans on the album's title track. But Peaches has always been able to use her outré
column5: sometimes downright silly
column6: personality to shed light on real issues
column7: like society's patriarchal disgust at the natural state of a woman's body. In the same song
column8: when she sets up a scene of ""circle jerk girls who spray/ we've got a male in the middle and we bukkake""
column9: she may be the only female pop musician working today who sings about sex while firmly and intentionally diverting the objectifying male gaze. While it may not always be pretty or elegant

column1: But is Peaches' music secondary to her politics? Interestingly
column2: the first voice you hear on Rub isn't Peaches'
column3: but the distinctive whisper-moan of Kim Gordon. On album opener ""Close Up""
column4: Gordon purrs for Peaches to get closer to the camera as she raps/speaks about her sexual exploits (the song's video features Gordon coaching Peaches through a shit-smearing wrestling match). The track's catchy
column5: powerful bass drum beat threads throughout Rub

column1: Rub's centerpiece is ""Free Drink Ticket""
column2: an altogether strange offering that doesn't quite mesh with the rest of the album. With her voice downpitched to sound more masculine
column3: Peaches delivers an almost stream-of-consciousness diatribe against a pretentious club promoter. It sounds jarringly personal

column6: ""Dumb Fuck"" is a call for feminists everywhere to ditch their boyfriends for Roland MC-505s.

column1: ""I Mean Something""
column2: the album's closer and duet with fellow Canadian/frequent collaborator/ex-roommate Feist
column3: sees Peaches defiantly state Rub's most telling line: ""No matter how old
column4: how young
column5: how sick/ I mean something."" Is that a hint of desperation? Aggression? Bravado? Perhaps
column6: realistically
column7: a mixture of all three
column8:
both an assertion of Peaches' rightful place in the trenches of the culture wars and an artistic plea for attention.

column4: but even those put off by it have got to admire the band’s temerity. Though Harmlessness’s primary fascinations lie with familiar subjects—overcoming depression
column5: navigating changing relationships
column6: finding a place in the world—the band detours from that safe territory to confront listeners with an uncomfortable moral quandary about whether taking a life is ever justified. The song sympathizes with Diana’s crusade while acknowledging the gruesome irony of celebrating a murderer.

column1: Of course
column2: Harmlessness does the safer subjects well
column3: too. One of Bello’s many songs about wrestling himself from depression’s grip
column4: ""Rage Against the Dying of the Light"" builds to a hooky alt-rock riff
column5: then pivots right into the album’s celebratory highlight
column6: ""Ra Patera Dance""
column7: which channels the grizzled cheer of Good News-era Modest Mouse. Harmlessness is loaded with these kinds of seamless transitions
column8: and the band’s smart sequencing keeps the record moving with brisk efficiency. ""Haircuts for Everybody"" takes just a minute and a half to build to its brutally pretty climax.

column1: Where TWIABP’s last album ended with an epic seven-minute closing statement
column2: ""Getting Sodas""
column3: Harmlessness doubles down with two of them (actually
column4: two and a half
column5: if you count the lovely little hidden track tacked on to the end of ""Mount Hum""). Stacking so many moments of grandiosity on top of each other should be overkill
column6: but it isn’t; each suite pays off triumphantly. With Harmlessness
column7: the World Is a Beautiful Place have accomplished a rare feat: a lofty
column8:
loaded album with the grace and momentum of a far leaner one.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22422/homepage_large.43c2edbb.jpg|Blurse|33248.0|Chevel|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Stroboscopic Artefacts']|2015-09-28 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:55.520004|"

Chevel is a young European producer with fashionable friends—he's had a long working relationship with fellow Italian Lucy—good DJ bookings
column2: his own label (Enklav)
column3: and a fair amount of hype. He also has something a lot of precocious upstarts don't: a deep and evolving catalog
column4: counting 15 singles and now three albums to his name. His latest
column5: Blurse—out on Lucy's excellent Stroboscopic Artefacts label—is a bold
column6: confident step away from the dance floor material he's been honing and into deep
column7: abstracted structures and pristine sound design.

column1: Blurse opens the way a lot of techno records do—with a grimy
column2: compressed kick drum—and that's about the last time Blurse proceeds the way a lot of techno records do. The second kick arrives nearly a second later
column3: an eternity on a dance floor. By the 90-second mark Chevel seems to have lost interest in the kick drum entirely
column4: taking a mid-track siesta with the swirling harmonics and buzzing synths/insects. The drums come back—they almost always do—but these kind of aberrant structures define Blurse
column5: which sees Chevel continually chart his way to abstraction and back again.

column1: Blurse
column2: then
column3: is kin to a certain strand of hypnotic
column4: percussion-heavy dance music that sits at the edges of house and techno
column5: the kind only touched by adventurous and skilled DJs. There are elements of Pearson Sound's coptering drums
column6: of Objekt's cryptic architecture
column7: even of the spacey suspensions of early dubstep masters such as Loefah. And
column8: impressively
column9: Chevel never veers too far into the avant-garde; Blurse
column10: with its hard gray surfaces and dubby quivers
column11: is always identifiable as techno in some mutated form. Chevel is walking a tightrope here
column12: maintaining structure while unmooring most of a track's conventional building blocks.

column1: There's fun to be had in the details
column2: too. The end of ""Watery Drumming"" features wildly rippling echoes as what sounds like an actual clock keeps time. ""Down and Out"" consists mostly of short
column3: pitched percussion sounds and little stabs of an electric piano; skipping around the track with your mouse you're as likely to find utter silence as anything. The gorgeous ""Loop #33"" sees gooey
column4: molten synths rise from beneath the cracks in the percussion.

column1: Concrete melodies are a little thin on the ground
column2: so Blurse can sound homogenous. The record sometimes lacks the dynamism of works by the aforementioned artists
column3: at times bordering on ascetic and clinical. But this style
column4: which results in a lot of short
column5: compact tracks
column6: lends itself well to the album format. Which might be the point: Chevel has released two EPs and a 10-inch this year
column7: all of them showcasing his steady progression but aimed more squarely at the dance floor. Blurse has the precision of a practiced producer and mischievousness of a rogue. It's the result of a young producer not just making techno but taking it apart
column8: rearranging it
column9:
breaking it.

"|21129.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21129-blurse/|7.7|Andrew Gaerig

Read the liner notes of Dr. Dre’s Compton and you’ll see the name Anderson .Paak appear six times: He produced or sang on songs ""All in a Day’s Work""
column2: ""Issues""
column3: ""Deep Water""
column4: ""For the Love of Money""
column5: ""Animals""
column6: and ""Medicine Man"". It's the biggest look of Anderson’s career so far by a million miles
column7: one that seemingly came from a chance encounter with the iconic producer. According to Mass Appeal
column8: Anderson attended a studio session when his recent song
column9: ""Suede""
column10: caught Dre’s attention. ""He comes in
column11: and I’m just sitting in the room
column12: and I saw him play it over and over again
column13: Anderson told the publication. ""At the third time
column14: he was ready to work.""

column1: Until now
column2: though
column3: the California singer/producer had achieved marginal success: Following his 2012 debut under the name Breezy Lovejoy
column4: Anderson’s follow-up—Venice—showed his promise as a storyteller
column5: but the album was largely undercooked and whizzed by without much impact. Anderson has released a few singles and projects on Bandcamp

column1: The Anderson .Paak EP is the artist’s first release since Venice
column2: and it's appearance is timely. Running just four tracks and less than 20 minutes
column3: The Anderson .Paak EP is a quick listen
column4: but it demonstrates Anderson’s talent and charisma. His raspy inflection evokes Bilal’s sensuous tenor and the lyrics explore mostly light fare—blowing weed

column1: Even when he discusses serious topics
column2: like on the two-part ""Cheap Whiskey.70’s Reisling""
column3: Anderson does so in the smoothest way possible. ""Wish I had a chance to write ya
column4: he croons
column5: presumably talking about an absent father figure. ""I wish I didn’t look just like ya."" Produced entirely by Los Angeles/Chicago duo Blended Babies
column6: who have worked with the Cool Kids and Ab-Soul and credit OutKast and Eric Clapton as influences
column7: the music is laidback

column10:
but it's a worthy precursor to something greater.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22298/homepage_large.8c654953.jpg|Caracal|28790.0|Disclosure|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Island']|2015-09-25 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:05:56.771380|"

Looking back
column2: the intro to Disclosure’s Settle almost reads like a warning to their future selves: ""As much as you like to control your environment
column3: the reality is
column4: everything changes."" Sure enough
column5: Guy and Howard Lawrence’s sophomore full-length Caracal arrives just two years later but in a markedly different pop landscape—thanks in no small part to the brothers' own influence. Their pristine syntheses of UK garage
column6: Midwestern vocal house
column7: and hook-happy pop structures re-oriented the British pop charts and trickled into the American ones
column8: opening the doors for pop-adjacent neo-house acts like Duke Dumont
column9: Years & Years
column10: and Rudimental (not to mention for Sam Smith). Disclosure have never really been the types to throw curveballs: they do what they do
column11: and they do it impeccably. But it’s understandable they’d start feeling restless
column12: especially as the scope of their influence rendered their own tunes increasingly indistinct. ""That sound is everywhere now
column13: Guy
column14: now 24
column15: admitted in an L.A. Times profile this summer. ""The same old bass lines
column16: the same old samples. We’re a bit bored by it.""

column1: Scrubbed of much of its predecessor's overt 2-step and house homage
column2: Caracal suggests the duo's also grown bored of the conversation that's surrounded them from the start: how dance and pop music can and ""should"" relate. On one hand
column3: here were two young men making wide-reaching dance tracks that weren’t reliant on drops
column4: builds
column5: or any of festival EDM’s creatine-crazed trappings. These guys scanned as ""tasteful
column6: for better or worse. But on the flip side were classicists and underground dance fans who pegged the duo as milquetoast gentrifiers of scenes they were too young to fully appreciate
column7: repackaging history with the context and kinks ironed out. There is some sting in the charge
column8: but it's not entirely fair: Disclosure’s work has always made the most sense within the framework of pop
column9: in terms of both form and demographic. In that sense
column10: calling Disclosure contrived or formulaic misunderstands how pop works. Their music may be one-size-fits-all
column11: but it’s also immaculately crafted and catchy as fuck
column12: smudging the divide between the universal and the personal to the point where ""Latch"" somehow seemed to grow more poignant the more ubiquitous it became.

column1: Those dance classicists will likely be less territorial with Caracal: the brothers have dialed down the BPMs significantly and turned toward slow-burning
column2: R&B-inspired grooves. But as they’ve edged away from giddy neo-nostalgia toward a sound with less identifiable anchor points
column3: they’ve begun to blend into the background. On ""Omen""
column4: the brothers reunite with Sam Smith for a single presumably meant to reprise the massive success of ""Latch"". And it’s fine—plodding along at a stately downtempo strut with a hint of a 2-step hitch
column5: Smith’s voice a bit mired in that familiar elastic bassline. But it’s nowhere near as immediate
column6: or as gripping; here
column7: when Smith sings of missed opportunities for emotional connection
column8: ""Latch""’s obsessive I-will-never-leave-your-side-god-dammit conviction feels like a distant memory. Much of Caracal is vaguely pleasant music you can put on in the background while you’re working—but is that really what we look to Disclosure for?

column1: Meanwhile
column2: where Settle set the tone for years of pop hits to come
column3: Caracal seems content to fall back amidst the pack. Opening track ""Nocturnal"" is a showcase for R&B’s man-of-the-moment the Weeknd
column4: and it wouldn’t sound out of place on Beauty Behind the Madness. Its synth arpeggios seem to aim for Frankie Knuckles and Jamie Principles’ ""Your Love""
column5: but the vibe is closer to late-'00s Hype Machine dance tracks (halfway through
column6: the track practically breaks into its own Classixx remix). This makes sense
column7: in a way: much of the Billboard pop and R&B charts over the last year have embraced this sound
column8: from Nick Jonas’ ""Jealous"" to Jason Derulo to the current bumper crop of vaguely Balearic ""tropical house"" singles and remixes. But for Disclosure
column9: the move feels like a step backward
column10: an aim at broader relevance that’s only watered down what once made them feel thrilling.

column1: There are bright spots: lead single ""Holding On"" retains their signature bounce and features stunning vocals from jazz songwriter Gregory Porter
column2: and ""Good Intentions""
column3: with its understated Miguel appearance
column4: is the best example of their smoothed-out new direction
column5: keeping a brisk pace but leaving more open space. Still
column6: it’s getting harder to shake the sense that these redemptive guest spots have become a crutch for a lack of ideas. Both of the album’s two featureless tracks feel instantly forgettable—particularly ""Jaded""
column7: a beige wash of cheeseball lyrics that chastise a dishonest companion with all the depth of the ""Why You Lyin"" Vine.

column1: When Disclosure’s hype was at its peak circa Settle
column2: they were often compared to turn-of-the-century acts like Basement Jaxx and Daft Punk—acts who successfully recontextualized older house and disco influences into something reverent and contemporary. But a significant part of both groups’ appeal—and
column3: crucially
column4: part of the outright critical revulsion at the time
column5: too—was their lack of self-seriousness
column6: their willingness to get a little cheesy. Those guys’ nostalgia embraced the kitsch along with the classicism; they had fun. The Lawrence brothers have good taste
column7: sharp instincts
column8: and pristine craftsmanship: playfulness
column9: not so much. Even the album’s most unbuttoned track falls flat: ""Bang That""
column10: a (relatively) raunchy promotional single now relegated to the bonus tracks with a gratuitous sample of 313 Bass Mechanics’ ""Pass Out""
column11: feels a bit cringey
column12: like Kidz Bop does ghetto house. Ultimately
column13: Caracal just doesn’t feel much fun
column14: and even its highs are nowhere near Settle’s polished bliss. Once trendsetters
column15:
here the Lawrence brothers too often fade noncommittally into white noise.

"|21034.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21034-caracal/|6.6|Meaghan Garvey
