Ryan Adams' cover of Taylor Swift's 1989 is a lot of fun to think about and talk about
column2: but not much fun to listen to. It is
column3: in other words
column4: a pure product of the Internet—a robust
column5: cross-platform
column6: thinkpiece-generating app that testifies mostly to Adams' ability to get attention. You have to hand it to him for knowing what he's doing: His album choice churns up some nice
column7: irony-rich soil for culture and music critics to wriggle around in. Even though Taylor Swift has been a songwriter first and foremost throughout her career
column8: 1989 was where she collaborated more intensely with superstar producers like Max Martin and Shellback to help her cross over from Queen of Pop Country to the center of the pop world proper. The move worked spectacularly: 1989 is among the best-selling albums of the post-Napster era. And now Ryan Adams has transformed it again
column9: into... a run-of-the-mill Ryan Adams album.

column1: It's an odd object to engage with. Adams is entertaining
column2: always has been
column3: and he's carved out what is by now a fascinating career
column4: filled with a few widely beloved heartland rock albums and a great many weird one-offs that have won him a devoted cult. 1989 is on the one hand an example of the latter
column5: but it's presented in the style of the former. He throws himself into the album completely—the arrangements are fully realized and he sings with care and precision
column6: revealing his admiration. But he also reveals some fairly crucial points about how good songs are put together.

column1: Every recorded song is the end point of a long road with many possible forks in it—a series of small decisions about chord changes
column2: melody lines
column3: lyrics
column4: and arrangements. Swift's 1989 songs are written for a specific kind of production—the melodies are clipped
column5: percussive
column6: and designed to hit with force at very specific times. They are written to be electro-pop songs
column7: which rely more on big dynamic changes and repeating cells of melody.

column1: At its best
column2: Swift's 1989 crackles with life
column3: and highlights what it feels like to be young and looking at the world from a very specific moment; Adams transforms those feelings into a wistful and generic feeling of weariness. To put it in the context of an artist to whom Adams is often compared
column4: 1989 shows why Springsteen went synth-pop on Born in the U.S.A. in 1984—the songs demanded it. The songs that sound like anthems were meant to be anthems; Springsteen's stark demos of the songs are instructive but they weren't the finished product. Remember
column5: too
column6: that he tried to turn his dark folk masterpiece Nebraska into a full band album but realized it needed to come out as an acoustic demo. Which is to say that ""Out of the Woods"" is ""Dancing in the Dark""
column7: not ""Atlantic City"".

column1: Swift knows this about her own material
column2: and the demos of 1989's songs she included on the album show how dramatic the transformation can be. In Adams' hands
column3: they are flat
column4: flavorless rockers
column5: and when the music isn't simply boring it crosses the line into actively grating. He wants ""Blank Space"" to be a Big Star-style heartfelt ballad
column6: but the melody feels thin
column7: rushed
column8: and monochrome in this setting. He delivers ""Shake It Off"" in a grim and determined tone that would be appropriate if he were singing about how conservative politics have decimated rural families at the inaugural Farm Aid—but when paired with a repeated refrain of “haters gonna hate
column9: it sounds ridiculous. And Adams' ""Style"" is downright garish
column10: coming off like Bono fronting Survivor
column11: the dark side of the album's titular year.

column1: Adams' 1989
column2: for all its sincerity and technical execution
column3: is ultimately hollow because it's nothing but context. There's everything surrounding it (the unexpected match of singer and song
column4: the details of the release) and there's what you bring to it (your relationship to the music of Swift and Adams
column5: your demographic profile
column6: your feelings on rock and pop and covers in general) but there's no essential reason for it to exist. This is why Father John Misty's rush-released version of ""Blank Space""
column7: wherein he remade Swift's song in the style of the Velvet Underground
column8: was such a brilliant example of a recorded song as music criticism. His track was a hilarious (and
column9: importantly
column10: still musically enjoyable) reminder that Adams' entire album is a gesture. It's a formal exercise. You listen and think
column11: ""Ah
column12:
I see what he did there"" and then you forget about it.

Throughout its long
column2: slow journey west
column3: Mariah’s Utakata no Hibi has been an album without context. After a dormant period at home among Japan’s vinyl geek underground
column4: the 1983 record began to spread farther in 2008
column5: when the tastemaking Scottish DJ duo Optimo shared a cut online. That song
column6: ""Shinzo no Tobira""
column7: which they first heard in a Tokyo record store
column8: has since earned a cult following worldwide for the ethereal lines it traces between Asian and Middle Eastern tonalities
column9: folklorish Armenian lyrics
column10: and futuristic Japanese synthpop leads. Its soundscapes are like those once dreamt by Brians Eno and Wilson. But for all the love ""Shinzo"" and its parent album have found in tiny nightclubs and Internet testimonials
column11: surprisingly little has been asked or answered about its origins. It's almost as though Utakata—now reissued by Palto Flats—has at last arrived on our shores not simply through a crate digger’s time warp
column12: but from some other world altogether.

column1: Or maybe a few of them: As befits an album that owes its broader discovery to a Shinjuku record store called Eurasia
column2: Utakata’s plainspoken lyrics are sung in alternating Armenian and Japanese. In this regard—and most others—the record bears no resemblance to Mariah’s previous five
column3: wherein a revolving door of popular Tokyo session men dabbled in everything from prog rock to jazz funk. By 1983
column4: the project was being led by Yasuaki Shimizu
column5: a relentlessly exploratory musician best known for the saxophone takes on Bach’s Cello Suites he would later record in both Japanese mines and Italian palazzos. His brilliant solo outing from the previous year
column6: Kakashi
column7: is Utakata’s only obvious relative. But that earlier work’s East-meets-West patchwork of genres
column8: moods
column9: and scales feels much more cut and dry than the seamless marvel Shimizu would soon create. Given how difficult it remains to find a fair comparison for any of Utakata’s seven songs
column10: let alone synthesize the picture they form together
column11: it’s an album that has well earned its reputation as an elusive classic.

column1: The long tally of pleasant surprises begins with opener ""Sokokara…"" (""From Here…"")
column2: in which slash-and-burn no wave guitar and a frantically overloaded player piano somehow only add to the springtime optimism suggested by the song’s marching beat
column3: blossoming synths
column4: and Shimizu’s skyward warble. ""Hana Ga Saitara"" (""Were Flowers to Bloom"") is a more eloquent draft of the dubbed out
column5: sax-led post-punk that was then beginning to bubble up in England rock clubs
column6: here powered by brass skronk and proto-techno synths. And ""Fujiyu Na Nezumi"" takes the British nursery rhyme ""Three Blind Mice"" and translates it into Japanese
column7: Armenian
column8: and a poetic syntax of spare bass
column9: sustained synths
column10: and simple percussion—indicating not so much the album’s sense of humor as the childlike wonder animating its every move. Mixer and engineer Seigen Ono would later work the boards for artists like John Zorn
column11: Arto Lindsay
column12: and King Crimson
column13: but the way he focuses Shimizu’s playtime ruckus of international instrumentation and production techniques remains the accomplishment of his career.

column1: Utakata’s most impressive feat of synthesis
column2: however
column3: lies in its coupling of East Asian and Middle Eastern sounds. The most explicit instance occurs in early highlight ""Shisen"" (""A Vision"")
column4: which weds gorgeous piano pentatonics and koto court music with Armenian vocalist Julie Fowell’s mesmerizing mantra
column5: ""Our eyes as one."" When the lone
column6: cavernous drum and piercing sine waves enter
column7: the effect is devastating. The twinning effect is at its subtle best on the famously DJ-friendly ""Shinzo no Tobira"" (""My Life Is Big"") that first got Optimo’s attention
column8: where unforgettable melody walks the fine line it all but invents between its authors’ musical heritages.

column1: In 2015
column2: it remains a rare and enchanting thing to hear a piece of convergence culture this effortless—which
column3: after all
column4: may be one reason Utakata still sounds so otherworldly. Another could be the fact that the album owes its existence to a creative moment in Japanese pop that remains virtually unknown to the English-speaking world. Thanks to '80s electronic pioneers Yellow Magic Orchestra’s continued chart success and the glory days of the Japanese economy
column5: the mainstream entered a renaissance of open-mindedness and ludicrous recording budgets
column6: producing an abundance of records that answer Shimizu’s sonic adventures with ones every bit as bold and compelling. Maybe Utakata belongs
column7: then
column8: not to some wondrous alternate history
column9:
but a real one we’re just beginning to uncover.

""I know my soul was born to do some cool things
column2: testifies AK over the wood flute-and-maracas loop of ""Rain Dance (Phase One Intro)"". The Underachievers
column3: his duo with Issa Gold
column4: practice the kind of esoteric mysticism that once flourished in some far-flung corners of '90s rap
column5: from the feverish jabberwocky of Leaders of the New School’s T.I.M.E.: The Inner Mind’s Eye to the pan-African zealotry of X-Clan’s To the East
column6: Blackwards
column7: and the backpacker bohemianism of Zion I’s Mind Over Matter
column8: Mystik Journeymen’s The Black Sands Ov Eternia and Abstract Tribe Unique’s Mood Pieces. It’s an ethos that largely dissipated by the end of that decade as rap moved on. But the Underachievers have not only revived it
column9: they’ve stuck with their spiritual bent through four projects
column10: including 2013’s revelatory Indigoism
column11: last year’s uneven but satisfying Cellar Door: Terminus Ut Exordium
column12: and now Evermore: The Art of Duality.

column1: At first
column2: Evermore appears to offer more of the same
column3: as they rap about being miseducated in school
column4: dabbling in street hustles
column5: and feeling alienated from society. ""We lost in this world
column6: but it’s hard to relate
column7: says AK on ""Chasing Faith"". They strive to use their experiences to educate others through hip-hop music
column8: celebrating the use of ""natural"" herbs such as marijuana and ‘shrooms
column9: but acknowledging that they’ve struggled with harder substances. They underline the importance of their metaphysical lessons by acknowledging in ""The Dualist"" that ""We all sin.""

column1: AK and Issa Gold complement each other. Vocally
column2: AK has a more sour tone and a barking delivery that sounds like he’s dispensing real talk. Issa Gold has a mid-range baritone that lightens when he gets excited
column3: as if he can’t wait to finish rapping one line and start the next. Both are strong lyricists
column4: but for much of Evermore

column6: school indoctrination
column7: and the banality of social media and Western pop culture are repetitively disparaged.

column1: These observations are delivered over serene production. ""Shine All Gold"" matches an acoustic guitar loop to a bass drum bounce
column2: then closes with an ambient techno beat. The next two tracks
column3: ""Chasing Faith"" and ""Star Signs""
column4: pick up that downtempo thread and build backgrounds full of melancholy and yearning. ""The Dualist"" breaks the holistic spell with the kind of mid-'90s boom-bap classicism on which the Underachievers and other Beast Coast artists built their reputation. The warm electric keyboards and synthesizers of ""The Brooklyn Way"" make for a particularly glorious peak. ""Hands up if you live for love
column5: chants Issa Gold.

column1: For much of Evermore

column4: ""Don’t fuck with the snakes
column5: and AK adds
column6: ""Really pop up on a nigga blocka/ If he think he hotta ‘cause a nigga conscious/ Got to keep a chopper just to cease the nonsense."" The duo descends into a hellish inferno until they reach the ninth circle of ""Allusions"". ""Got a bitch in the Bay that loves the ‘shrooms/ She be screamin’ AK when I shove the broom
column7: brags AK. Issa Gold adds
column8: ""Smoking fuego with your dame/ Been like a whole 20 minutes
column9: can’t front
column10: nigga still don’t know her name /30 minutes later
column11: had my pinky in her brain/ She like
column12: I thought you was different
column13: all of you rappers just the same/ She ain’t complain.""

column1: The latter songs throw everything that precedes it into doubt. Are the Underachievers just rap dudes lusting for weed
column2: bitches
column3: and cash like everyone else? They’re obviously aware of the contradictions
column4: but Evermore: The Art of Duality places these adventures in a present-tense context. Perhaps they’re simply acknowledging their flawed humanity. Just as likely
column5: they don’t yet realize that their perspectives on sex and violence can be as tough to break as the mental prisons that damaged their troubled youth.

column1: The Evermore journey is an engaging one
column2: but it would have slid into a new age torpor if not for the spate of ugliness near the album’s end. The coarse ""Generation Z"" shenanigans give the earlier ""Chasing Faith"" added urgency. We now know why the Underachievers strain to ascend their earthly selves. ""I done came far
column3: still got a lot further to go
column4: raps Issa Gold on the final track
column5:
""Unconscious Monsters (Evermore Outro)"". ""Trying to leave a mark by giving everything that I know.""

We’re often told rap is a young person’s game
column2: but one of the year’s most noteworthy rap albums was helmed by a fifty-year-old. Jay Z is comfortably in his forties; Kanye will be forty in two years. And somehow Juicy J is forty but he seems particularly ageless—there’s When the Smoke Clears-era Three 6 Mafia
column3: there’s Juicy J accepting an Oscar and appearing on his own show on MTV
column4: then there’s 2011 Juicy J
column5: attached to Wiz Khalifa’s Taylor Gang troupe
column6: rapping with Kreayshawn
column7: spawning catchphrases (""you say no to drugs—Juicy J can’t!"")
column8: and releasing free music at a furious clip
column9: keeping up with the Lil B's of the world and rappers half his age.

column1: Juicy J didn’t have to come back
column2: but he did
column3: and his career reached a logical conclusion with his third solo record
column4: 2013’s Stay Trippy
column5: which was surprisingly great then
column6: and holds up now. At the time
column7: it wasn’t hard to see some cynicism in Juicy J’s late-career moves—he appeared to be angling for the blog-space that spent so much time covering guys who directly bit his original style (somewhere SpaceGhostPurrp is sighing). But Juicy J is from blue-collar Memphis
column8: all he does is work.

column1: On the heels of the largely forgettable Blue Dream & Lean 2
column2: 100% Juice drops all pretense and opens with the clearest mission statement possible: ""There’s too much stupid-ass shit happening right now
column3: it’s time to turn up."" From there
column4: it’s business as usual: dense
column5: booming dark beats
column6: hooks that mostly consist of a phrase shouted like a salutation
column7: cataloging of various drugs taken and sexual escapades
column8: then an occasional guest to break it up.

column1: While Juicy J’s re-emergence came on the heels of Lex Luger
column2: Mike WiLL
column3: and Young Chop beats
column4: now he’s playing in a contemporary field consisting of 808 Mafia
column5: Sonny Digital
column6: and Metro Boomin. Juicy J’s greatest asset has been his ability to make his surroundings his own. The same way he ran through those 2011 Lex Luger beats
column7: he slides right into the spacey
column8: trap-noir of 808 Mafia—""Still"" runs a piano loop sounding straight out of Halloween as Juicy J sticks the landing on a vivid line like ""she got my wife-beater on as a nightgown"" and the punchline ""you just looking for a quick come-up
column9: I can feel it in the air like Phil Collins."" How Juicy J rattles off these lines
column10: in a way not unlike the now-infamous Migos triplet flow
column11: but with an ascending and descending cadence that emphasizes the right syllables
column12: is indicative of how effortless this comes to him. He never sounds tired
column13: never phones it in. He’s the consummate pro.

column1: Juicy J is funnier than most rappers and capable of getting the most ludicrous hooks stuck in your head (""I drop them beans in my lean"" will haunt you for days) and he’s the rare rapper who commands respect from the people around him. Boosie’s vicious
column2: borderline-disgusting verse on the ""Film"" remix is impossible to not run back a dozen times
column3: demonstrating the intensity with which artists approach a Juicy J feature. Same goes for Lil Herb
column4: who pops on ""Ain’t No Rapper""; the change of scenery breathes new
column5: vibrant life into the Chicago emcee’s scratchy
column6: traditional gangster tropes. 100% Juice
column7: while not a revelation
column8: is sturdy and solid. A great artist can endlessly remake the same sounds and make it work
column9:
and the self-contained good time of 100% Juice adds a few new wrinkles.

If you're new to Young Thug
column2: don't start with Slime Season. An odds-and-ends compilation with no coherent vision
column3: the tape finds Thug rapping at a high level
column4: but performing less consistently as a songwriter. It's not clear he even wants to be a songwriter on all these records; one gets the impression the tape's been compiled ex post facto
column5: a few fully-fleshed out classics mixed in with studio dross. Some feel more like workouts
column6: perhaps cut quickly during marathon recording sessions. (Initially Slime Season was to be produced entirely by London on da Track. ""Ask 300""
column7: the beatmaker tweeted—a reference to Thug's label—when questioned about the more diverse production lineup of the final tracklist.) The bulk of these songs are for Thug completists
column8: or those convinced of his infallibility. Nevertheless
column9: Thug remains one of hip-hop's most exciting stylists
column10: consistent even amid inconsistency
column11: and there are moments worth savoring.

column1: Part of the problem is that Thug's catalog has already been flooded with leaks and unofficial releases. Some of them—""Hey I"" is a particular standout—are superior to many of the records here. Thug's biggest fans would be better off compiling their own greatest hits from the pile
column2: and Thug neophytes will find this year's Barter 6 or last year's Rich Gang tape a much more consistent entryway. It's unclear why certain records made the cut and others didn't. The inclusion of Wayne feature ""Take Kare"" (which has been out since last year) may be yet another pointed dig at Thug's idol (the two have since had a falling out)
column3: but it was also an anticlimax. <span id=""docs-internal-guid-75788b7f-fc3e-df01-8ae9-4fa79909f9ec""><span>""Power""
column4: produced by London on da Track
column5: seems like something left on the cutting room floor from the Barter sessions
column6: and if it was
column7: it's easy to hear why: where each Barter record made up a discrete facet of the album's sound
column8: ""Power"" sounds a little bit like three of them at once—consummate filler.

column1: In the rush to fete Thug for his radical talents
column2: <span id=""docs-internal-guid-75788b7f-fc3f-5f6d-74e8-ae6eab276d75""><span>it's important to draw distinctions between what records work
column3: and which ones do not—or those which sort of work
column4: if you look at them from the right angle. Part of the joy of his art is that you can draw together your own version of his canon from a scattered field
column5: picking up on the pieces that most attract you. (This is not a quality limited to Thug; it's been this way since the Internet began to reward rappers
column6: like Lil Wayne and Gucci Mane
column7: who could flood the market without drowning in it.) The most evident gem here is ""Best Friend"". Its hook is inspired by a viral vine (Tokyo Vanity
column8: the meme's creator
column9: has released a ""Best Friend"" record of her own)
column10: and its surreal video is sly and artfully unpredictable. The Ricky Racks-produced record
column11: which builds upon disorienting sound effects and hypnotic pizzicato strings
column12: draws you in while bringing you no closer to figuring it all out
column13: a contradiction at the heart of the Young Thug project.

column1: Thug's best songs are carefully structured
column2: even if they appear effortlessly thrown together
column3: and the most effective moments tend to be subtle
column4: sidling up to the listener. Each of the song's parts—melodies
column5: backgrounds
column6: hooks
column7: choruses
column8: and flows—lock in to give the song a shape as particular as a fingerprint. Many songs on Slime Season don't chase this goal; at the album's opening
column9: Thug's drawn to repetitive
column10: headbanging patterns and the results are for hardcore fans only. The opening tracks
column11: the Sonny Digital-produced trap banger ""Quarterback"" and the Southside-produced ""Rarri""
column12: are interesting but lack replay value. A few of the harder-edged songs do work: ""Freaky"" might be its best experimental moment
column13: with Wondagurl's unstructured
column14: percussive beat bringing Thug's songcraft and improvisational rap style to the fore.

column1: But the album's true highlights don't arrive until its close
column2: with the one-two punch of ""Draw Down"" and ""Wood Would"". On the former—which has been out for some time—Thug  strategically deploys different flows to shape the song
column3: while his unpredictable figurative language keep the listener on their toes: ""Pull up with that K out of the coupe! I like my bitch brown like a mu'fuckin' boot!"" he says at one moment
column4: or later: ""Put that pussy on my head like a fuckin' Motrin!"" Disguised in his squall of a delivery
column5: they're not conveyed as jab-you-in-the-ribs punchlines; they're playful and impossible to anticipate
column6: chasing novelty rather than cliche
column7: lending the song an uncertain
column8: volatile air.

column1: As for ""Wood Would""
column2: it's the album's strongest
column3: and stands among the best in his catalog. With its sample skipping like a stone as its drums slam in place
column4: it's low-key and unassuming
column5: evading direct translation and shifting in and out of lucidity. Yet Thug wears his heart on his sleeve through one of pop's oldest tools: an undeniable melody. It says everything he doesn't need to
column6:
as if everything you didn't know were clear as day.

"|21099.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21099-slime-season/|7.6|David Drake

Here is your weekly reminder of time's unending march: 2016 marks 15 years of music from Clifford ""T.I."" Harris. Since 2001
column3: the Atlanta rap icon has been churning out hits—be they of the ""mixtape street classic"" or ""mainstream feat. Rihanna"" variety—and thanks to those hits
column4: he has resisted a slow fade into obscurity. In fact
column5: he has packed his dance card to the gills
column6: what with his recent appearance in Marvel's Ant-Man and the usual busywork that a globe-trotting
column7: ""Blurred Lines"" appearing
column8: Iggy Azalea co-signing (and then disowning) Grand Hustle label head has to slog through. While his hardcore fans remain supportive (did you know that T.I. has never had an album that didn't sell at least 250
column9: 000 copies?) it wouldn't really shock anyone if he decided to phone it in as an artist by now.

column1: In recent interviews though
column2: Harris is adamant on returning to his old ways and Da' Nic
column3: the new five-song EP meant as a warm-up for the forthcoming Dime Trap
column4: showcases this shift effortlessly. Trap will be the first album Harris will record under his original TIP nickname
column5: which he eschewed for T.I. way back when in order to avoid confusion with Q-Tip of A Tribe Called Quest. As a release
column6: Da' Nic isn't going to pacify any longing you might have for *Trap-A-Holics voice* REAL TRAP SHIT
column7: but it's a strong record from one of the better rappers we have these days and a breath of fresh air from a guy who was treading the path of ""reality show dad"" just a few years back. If the last few T.I. releases have sounded complicated and unnecessarily heavy
column8: Da' Nic sounds like the guy most of us met on 2003's Trap Muzik finally heading back to his old neighborhood to sit on the porch and talk some shit.

column1: Like many others
column2: T.I. has occasionally fallen beneath the weight of the Major Label Rolodex. (Just because you can put Usher or Chris Brown on a song doesn't mean you should
column3: dig?) On Da' Nic there's only one feature: The London on Da Track-produced toe-tapper ""Peanut Butter and Jelly""
column4: which features guest verses from ""Young"" rappers both new (Thug) and old (Dro).

column1: More than anything
column2: this record sounds like the work of a seasoned veteran who's annoyed that everyone isn't giving him his dues as a good rapper. Even on his most bloated releases—2007's T.I. vs. T.I.P being the best example—count on T.I. for at least one moment where he showcases his ability to ramp up his verses when he even senses that people are sleeping on him. On Da' Nic
column3: that moment is ""Ain't Gonna See It Coming""  (""No
column4: I'm not that old nigga think that he run it/ And talkin' bout what he did back in the day/ I'm just as vicious as ever
column5: I'm brilliant and clever and still 'bout that action today""). It's refreshing to hear him serve notice.

column1: Let's be honest: While the EP is a welcome return to form
column2: it's still five songs. You aren't going to find hidden treasure here. However
column3: for those who have said they want the old T.I. back—the Lil' Flip- and Shawty Lo-obliterating King of the South who spit acid when he wasn't making the girls dance
column4:
all while wearing a Braves fitted cocked on his head at an angle that doesn't make any logical sense—Da' Nic promises some hope for his upcoming The Dime Trap.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22272/homepage_large.127674a8.jpg|Everything Dies|1249.0|Des Ark|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Graveface']|2015-09-24 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:06:00.279358|"

Des Ark's Aimée Argote can shred with the best of them when the mood strikes
column2: though on Everything Dies
column3: it doesn't. For most of the last decade
column4: Argote's band has existed as a Jekyll/Hyde operation
column5: oscillating between thrashing noise rock and hushed folk. Depending on her lineup
column6: a Des Ark show might find her making a mockery of ear plugs
column7: contorting her body into impossible positions to force the cruelest sounds from her instrument
column8: or playing for a crowd seated on the floor
column9:
inviting them to squeeze in closer in order to hear her over her unplugged guitar.

Argote makes either extreme feel like her natural state on stage
column10: though capturing both on the same record has proved more of a challenge. 2011's <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15418-dont-rock-the-boat-sink-the-fucker/"">Don't Rock the Boat
column11: Sink the Fucker positioned scorching punk uncomfortably against pretty but sometimes overworked songs that lost some of the intensity of Argote's solo performances. On Everything Dies
column12: she avoids that whiplash. Though it was recorded in bits and pieces at six studios in five states over a span of several years
column13: with a range of collaborators including Swans' Thor Harris
column14: Engine Down's Jonathan Fuller
column15: and Saddle Creek journeyman Andy LeMaster
column16:
it coheres like the product of a single session.

No track benefits more from this unified approach than ""Ties"". Argote has been kicking that song around since at least 2007
column17: when it first appeared under the misleadingly silly title ""Covert Conspiracy of Spanish Speaking Cats"" on a solo session Argote recorded for the Durham station WXDU. On its Everything Dies' update
column18: she's accompanied by imposing guitars and drums that give the song thrust
column19: underscoring Argote's violent imagery without drowning out the dread in her voice. It's the most devastating song she's ever written
column20: a chilling documentation of the tolls of loving an addict—the promises they might break
column21: the things they might steal
column22: and the bruises they might leave. ""Here it is
column24: ""The bathtub where you'll find the love of your life
column25:
choking up his own blood."" The words seem to fight her as they leave her mouth.

Not all of Everything Dies is so bleak—it couldn't be. ""French Fries Are Magical"" plays like a prolonged hug
column26: as does the album's most unabashedly pretty number
column27: ""Street Woods"". And the one song on the record that does live up to its irreverent title
column30:
a communal rejoice that falls somewhere between the Polyphonic Spree's rainbow sing-alongs and the radiant pop of Feist's The Reminder.

As on Don't Rock the Boat
column31: there are moments on Everything Dies where you can't help but wonder how a songwriter this good has existed so far below the radar of so many listeners. In a recent interview with After Ellen
column32: Argote shed some light on why that might be
column33: explaining that she prefers to play queer-friendly venues and safe spaces removed from the threats and harassment that women face at traditional venues. ""I don't really feel like I need to cultivate a male audience
column34: she explained. ""My songs are written for women and they're written for queer people; those are the people I've been closest to in my life
column35:
who I obviously want to share my music with … Really what I would like to do is create spaces that are safe for everybody and since I identify as queer I think it helps.""

Those comments sparked some distracting backlash from male commenters somehow upset that a woman might want to target her music at her own community
column36: but they reveal a lot about these songs. For all the turmoil it confronts
column37: Everything Dies really does create that sense of safety. Nearly every song extends a hand to the abused
column39: or the otherwise marginalized and reassures them they'll be all right. ""I'll bandage up your arms
column41: and leave you where the wounded lay
column42: she offers a lover on ""Coney Island Street Meat"". Argote cycles through nearly every emotion imaginable in these songs
column43:
but the one that drives her the most is concern.

"|21009.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21009-everything-dies/|7.5|Evan Rytlewski

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/22326/homepage_large.47456868.jpg|Samantha|28039.0|Toro Y Moi|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2015-09-24 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:06:00.940407|"

Part of the fun in following Chaz Bundick’s musical trajectory is hearing how he changes up his style from one project to the next. From Causers of This on
column2: each Toro Y Moi release has been a subtle shakeup: 2011’s stellar Underneath the Pine laser-cut the corners of chillwave down to a fine point; 2013’s Anything in Return turned his songwriterly impulses into disco and pop gems; and
column3: most recently
column4: he channeled early experiments with garage and indie rock into this past April’s What For? But each project somehow sounds distinctly like Toro Y Moi
column5: bound by Bundick’s unflagging production chops. The latest Toro Y Moi project
column6: Samantha
column7: is a free mixtape that piles together recordings from as far back as 2012 and as recent as last month. It serves as a neat way of tracking Bundick’s progression as a musician while prominently highlighting his talent for both beat-driven and atmospheric production.

column1: Samantha is filled with unexpected turns. Sparse one- and two-minute instrumental sketches serve as interludes
column2: creating a sense of flow with soul and R&B samples (""Stoned at the MoMA""
column3: ""Prayer Hands""
column4: the Ciara-quoting ""Boo Boo Mobile""). Bundick ventures into ambient on glitchy
column5: sedate closer ""welp
column6: tour’s over"" and ""ambient Rainbow""
column7: with the latter layering choral vocals and soothing washes of sound to mesmerizing ends. It’s a testament to Bundick’s innovation that he’s still finding ways to contort his signature sound into new shapes. Even when songs do call back to his previous work
column8: as on ""Us 2""
column9: which pairs a churning hip-hop beat with sugary synth pads that sound lifted from his 2011 cover of Cherrelle’s ""Saturday Love""
column10: they still put a fresh spin on the approach.

column1: The songs on Samantha are about the ups and downs of relationships
column2: placing most emphasis on the downs. Bundick even goes so far as to tack an extended sample of The Notebook onto the end of creeping
column3: Washed Out-assisted ""Want""
column4: a move that very narrowly evades tipping over into schmaltz. On the trap-influenced ""The Usual""
column5: he laments the frustrations of being a workaholic in a relationship
column6: an unusually frank moment from Bundick. Elsewhere
column7: Kool A.D. spins off into woozy
column8: emotionally conflicted verses (""I got problems acting like a fuckin’ grown up
column9: he grouses in Auto-Tune on ""Real Love"")
column10: while rising Atlanta rapper Rome Fortune relays relationship fallouts on two of the tape’s best tracks
column11: ""Pitch Black"" and Puff Daddy-sampling ""Benjiminz"". Samantha lightens up by the end
column12: as on the sweetly jittery ""Enough of You""
column13: but the main theme seems to be that relationships are complicated messes that can lead to comfort and love as easily as pain and heartbreak.

column1: That Samantha comes in the wake of the guitar-driven What For? makes the mixtape particularly welcome
column2: like a palette cleanser to prepare us for wherever Bundick goes next. Even if he's purging his hard drive of one-offs that didn’t fit anywhere else
column3: with a free-form structure
column4: winning collabs
column5: and appealingly nocturnal ambience
column6:
Samantha is a welcome addition to Bundick’s catalog.

"|21059.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/21059-samantha/|7.5|Eric Torres

Micachu and the Shapes revel in making enjoyable noise. Since their relatively conventional-sounding art-pop debut Jewellery
column3: the band has pushed their experimentation further every new release
column4: from crafting homemade instruments to recording live arrangements alongside orchestras. And now
column5: just a year after releasing her harrowing avant-garde score for the film Under the Skin
column6: Mica Levi has returned to her band to release Good Sad Happy Bad.

column1: Perhaps in the aftermath of composing a soundtrack for a major motion picture
column2: Levi wanted to bring simplicity back to Micachu
column3: as Good Sad Happy Bad toys with a warped minimalism that feels new even for this band. The record counteracts the fuzzy
column4: almost punk rock energy of their last album Never
column5: settling for soft
column6: acoustic guitar and childlike keyboard arrangements. Even the production of the record is spare and unedited
column7: with warbled vocals and frequent inclusions of studio chatter on songs like ""Dreaming"" and ""Crushed"".

column1: The record feels intimate and casual in this unrefined state
column2: but the line between relaxed and lazy is shaky on Good Sad Happy Bad. When all the tinker-toy elements align
column3: it works beautifully
column4: as on ""L.A. Poison"" with Levi singing softly about the loneliness of urban life over mechanically looped strumming guitar and a simple kick-drum. ""Oh Baby"" sounds like a murky
column5: blues-leaning lullaby
column6: as if its keyboards are being played underwater while Levi croons above them. But the off-key
column7: off-tempo energy of tracks like ""Hazes"" and ""Relaxing"" feel thrown together and messy
column8: even if it was purposeful.

column1: The biggest shift here is to be found in Mica Levi’s voice
column2: which is strained and echoed as she sings wearily about bad feelings. You can barely understand her at times
column3: but Good Sad Happy Bad is fundamentally a gloomy self-help record
column4: with its assurances delivered realistically. ""It’s gonna be okay
column5: Levi repeats in a chipper
column6: sing-song voice at the end of ""Sad"". On ""Thinking It"" Raisa Khan relays how she wants to get better at working out and being healthier so she can enjoy her old age. On ""Sea Air""
column7: all Levi wants to do is breathe in the ocean air because ""all that crap means nothing to [her].""

column1: Although Good Sad Happy Bad is certainly the band’s least polished-sounding record
column2: the combination of the scattered arrangements and Levi’s ruminations on sadness shrewdly underline the topsy-turvy feeling suggested by the title. Even with the band’s music messily chopped
column3: looped
column4: and jangled
column5: the emotional messages always ring clear. ""It’s only suffering
column6: Levi sings on ""Suffering""
column7: her voice suddenly lilting the phrase as the song gains tighter
column8:
harder percussion and guitar as the song nears its end. ""That keeps my conscious clean.""

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22393/homepage_large.725f9dcb.jpg|What a Time to Be Alive|27950.0|Drake|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Epic'

Superstar team-ups almost always seem better in theory. History suggests they are nearly twice as likely to produce a resounding dud as a working piece of art
column3: and yet the prospect never ceases to excite us. When rumors began to swirl weeks ago that Drake and Future might be releasing a joint project
column4: the Internet went into a frenzy. Watch the Throne parallels were drawn
column5: fake cover art circulated
column6: and a website countdown appeared as if to wish it into existence.

column1: What a Time to Be Alive materialized on Sunday
column2: and the mixed results won't surprise anyone who has already noted the decided lack of chemistry between these two. There's been a Drake feature on every Future album
column3: but none of them are particularly riveting
column4: and on What a Time it's clearer than ever that they have difficulty sharing the same space. Many tracks are just Future songs with Drake verses tagged on (Future gets almost double the airtime)
column5: and Drake often sounds out of his element. When Future gets rolling on songs like ""Digital Dash"" and ""Live From the Gutter""
column6: Drake is a bystander. The tape was allegedly born out of an impromptu
column7: six-day recording session
column8: and too many moments on it feel like they were thrown together in that time span. Drake probably shouldn’t be on a song called ""I’m the Plug""
column9: for example
column10: and the hook on ""Big Rings"" is terribly bland and awkward. This wasn't created with the care or the dutiful curation we've come to expect from both artists when solo.

column1: But that spontaneity is kind of the point of What a Time to Be Alive. Unlike Watch the Throne
column2: which was presented as a grand statement album from self-coronated heads of rap royalty
column3: What a Time is a tag-on release
column4: a one-off that intentionally exists in the shadows of its 2015 predecessors as a bonus disc. Designating it a tape seemingly alleviates the pressure to curate. Meanwhile
column5: Drake’s cushy Apple deal allows him to disseminate it for retail via iTunes and premiere it exclusively on his OVO Sound show on Apple Music’s Beats 1 Radio. It’s a low risk
column6: high reward proposition.

column1: Both artists offer slightly watered-down versions of themselves: Drake offers snarky responses to his recent ghostwriting allegations (""I might take Quentin to Follies
column2: ""The pen is working if you niggas need some ghostlines
column3: etc.) and Future mentions internal struggles (""When you say you love a nigga do you really mean it?/ When I was sleepin' on the floor you shoulda seen how they treat me/ I pour the Actavis and pop pills so I can fight the demons
column4: ""I watched my broad give up on me like I'm average""). It’s an odd juxtaposition
column5: especially with Drake returning to the stiff
column6: pinched ""<i>yes

Three tracks into the new U.S. Girls album
column2: Meghan Remy is awoken by a phone call from a girlfriend. She tells her about the bad dream she just had
column3: in which her father emailed her a digital folder containing nude images of Remy taken when she was a child. But the really weird thing about it was—as Remy notes with a combination of embarrassment and pride—""I was kinda hot stuff. I mean
column4: I don't know
column5: I looked good—so it was kind of confusing."" What follows is a brief conversation about the peculiar relationship dynamic between fathers and daughters compared to moms and sons—Remy's friend concludes that if she had been born a boy
column6: she'd be ""one of those sons that turns into a fascist dictator
column7: while Remy retorts
column8: ""instead of just another woman with no self-esteem."" Her sardonic punchline is punctuated by a burst of canned sitcom laughter—and
column9: much like that infamous Rodney Dangerfield scene in Natural Born Killers
column10: the device elicits more squirms than chuckles.

column1: But on Half Free
column2: that bizarre exchange counts as comic relief. And even though this interlude—titled ""Telephone Play No. 1""—appears just six minutes into the record
column3: it's still a necessary respite. By that point
column4: we've already heard from the unhappily married wife of a man who had previously bedded her two sisters (""Sororal Feelings"")
column5: and a widow grieving her soldier husband's death over a riotous reggae groove (""Damn That Valley""). And there are several more tales of women with no self-esteem to come—unflinching portraits of ladies reeling from inattentive
column6: cheating
column7: or absentee lovers. So the seemingly random appearance of ""Telephone Play No. 1"" actually makes more sense as the album plays out. It's simply a verbal manifestation of what Remy's proper songs do musically: take us into the spaces that are supposed to provide us with solace—home
column8: family
column9: relationships—and make them feel awkward and uncomfortable. (As the dejected narrator of ""Sororal Feelings"" declares through a deceptively sunny harmony: ""Now I'm going to hang myself/ Hang myself from my family tree."")

column1: Likewise
column2: Remy's music has always thrived on the conflict between the familiar and foreign. On previous U.S. Girls releases
column3: her pop and experimental sensibilities—part Shangri-Las
column4: part Sun Ra—were often at war with one another. (Take 2011's U.S. Girls on KRAAK
column5: where the Ronettes-style romp ""State House (It's a Man's World)"" gets rudely elbowed into the free-form subterranean skronk of ""Sinkhole""
column6: as if two opposing spirits were fighting for control of Remy's soul.) But
column7: by building upon the grotto-bound R&B introduced on 2013's Free Advice Column EP (whose hip-hop-schooled producer
column8: Onakabazien
column9: returns here)
column10: Half Free further fortifies the common ground between Remy's diamond-cut melodies and avant-garde urges. The album sounds like your favourite golden-oldies station beamed through a pirate-radio frequency
column11: seamlessly fusing '60s-vintage girl-group serenades and smooth '70s disco into dubby panoramas and horror-movie atmospherics.

column1: But even as its backdrop mutates from deep-house throbs to psych-rock guitar solos
column2: Half Free always focuses your attention to where it should be: on Remy's radiant voice and vivid storytelling. She's the sort of songwriter who can set a 3D scene in a single line that simmers with suggestion—the first words we hear on the record are ""Well there were a four of us in a real small space/ Sharing more than just a family name
column3: and you can immediately feel all the humidity and unease hanging in the room. The cinematically scaled production on Half Free only intensifies the domestic dramas playing out within her lyrics: the steady
column4: string-swept build of disco reverie ""Window Shades"" mirrors the emotional breakthrough of its protagonist
column5: a woman scorned who finally summons the courage to confront her philandering partner; the drizzling
column6: slow-percolating beat of ""Red Comes in Many Shades"" provides the gray-skied ambience for Remy's tale of a doomed affair with an older paramour
column7: all while her ""tears fall like rain."" And though ""Sed Knife""—an upbeat power-pop revision of a 2012 B-side—may seem like an outlier here
column8: its images of kitchen-table tensions fit right into the album's theme.

column1: The women at the center of these songs are indeed half free: they're prisoners to bad choices
column2: cruel circumstances
column3: and duplicitous men—but they're starting to take control of their situation. And with the epic closer ""Woman's Work""
column4: Remy leaves them with a neon-tinted
column5: mirror-ball-twirling anthem to herald their impending liberation. ""You arrived in your mother's arms/ But you will leave riding in a black limousine
column6: Remy seethes at a departing ex who's off to live the high life—or the afterlife—without her
column7: but the defiance in her voice suggests she's richer for it. ""A woman's work is never done/ She doesn't sleep 'til the morning comes
column8: chimes the Greek chorus behind her—and when applied to a creatively restless
column9: audacious voice like Remy
column10:
it sounds less like a complaint than a promise.

On London Zoo
column2: the 2008 album from Kevin Martin's experimental dub project the Bug

column4: ""You & Me""
column5: was voiced by light-stepping Trinidadian singer-poet Roger Robinson. After that track
column6: Martin and Robinson joined forces as King Midas Sound and followed with the 2009 full-length Waiting for You. Their latest project is a series of four EPs collaborating with an outside artist

column1: Those familiar with Martin’s brand of concussive dub and Fennesz’s elegant dance between electronic glitches and dulcet guitar washes might be taken aback by the hushed tones of this pairing. There’s very little of Martin’s telltale drum programming
column2: while Fennesz’s singular guitar tone is hard to parse amid the hash of gray static that envelops almost everything here. Kiki Hitomi
column3: who previously lent her voice to both the Bug and a KMS remix
column4: does her best Beth Gibbons impersonation on the melancholic trip hop of ""On My Mind""
column5: but its one of the few tracks with a discernible pulse. Robinson whispers a line about ""hold[ing] each other tight"" but everything about his voice on the record suggests the phantasmal
column6: a now-departed ex-lover who returns only in a dream. When he slurs about searching for safe ground on the eerie ""Lighthouse"" it seems to have been recorded from inside an abandoned one.

column1: Edition 1 mimics the depression and subsequent grind and quiet desolation of a breakup so precisely that it's hard to take in all at once. And while the effect of such distant vocals works early on in the album
column2: by the back half
column3: it just sounds like every vocal was recorded over a poor cell phone connection
column4: tinny and small. Robinson details the depression of a breakup in maddeningly mundane detail
column5: muttering about going through the days in a ""weed fog""; subliminal rhythms fade in and out but the expected bass surge never arrives. The album fully comes to life only on the haunting 14-minute instrumental ""Above Water"".

column1: The dark melodic guitar elements on the record sound like Fennesz
column2: but very little else is instantly traceable to him. Much of his discography involves collaboration with distinct artists like Ryuichi Sakamoto
column3: Jim O’Rourke
column4: and Sparklehorse
column5: but what’s remarkable here is how Fennesz dissolves into the bleak landscape
column6: his signature sound rendered indistinct
column7:
a loss of identity that mirrors the album's main theme.

Two of the best Dischord albums didn't actually come out on the legendary punk imprint. In 1994
column3: Atlantic released Jawbox's For Your Own Special Sweetheart and that same year Epic issued Shudder to Think's Pony Express Record. Both groups had made their names on Dischord
column4: and ""selling out"" was a fraught move for anyone from that world. While neither record made much of a mainstream impact
column5: they were masterpieces that used a major label's resources to magnify
column6: not dilute
column7: an innovative sound formed in a close-knit Washington
column8: D.C. punk scene. Jawbox had a unique approach to that aesthetic with their jazzy time signatures and noise-rock textures
column9: and their major label debut arguably represents the pinnacle of D.C. post-hardcore
column10: catching it just as it made its way into the alt-rock era.

column1: But if Jawbox reasonably fit into the mainstream three years after Nirvana broke
column2: it wasn't meant to last. Beck's Mellow Gold also came out in 1994
column3: leading the way for the stoned
column4: sample-happy kitchen-sink pop that was about to push ideological punk-derived music aside. In the twilight of grunge
column5: Sweetheart could get away with being defiantly noisy and raw. Two years later
column6: Jawbox's self-titled finale
column7: which is now being reissued
column8: showed some signs of capitulation to an omnipresent college-radio sound. A certain passively disaffected mien creeps in here and there
column9: an awkward fit for a famously earnest
column10: intense
column11: and hardworking band. But a few dated details detract little from the songwriting
column12: where rampaging fury is tempered by calculating musicianship
column13: pitch-conscious singing
column14: and precise ethics disguised as cut-up squawks of code.

column1: Jawbox signed with Atlantic in order to play music full-time
column2: not necessarily to become famous
column3: and their contract wasn't onerous. They had a lot of freedom on Sweetheart and anatomized their sound on its greatest song
column4: the angelically bruising ""Savory"". Nothing about it is hard-charging in the manner of classic hardcore punk; everything coils and squirms in an ominous quiet punctuated by deafening detonations. All of this is still true on Jawbox: J. Robbins' warm
column5: chesty voice oscillates between an ominous croon and an octave-leaping peal. His guitar's spidery treble clashes against Bill Barbot's gnarled
column6: almost bluesy licks
column7: bent out of shape by a high-pressure rhythm section. Zach Barocas lays a volatile foundation
column8: drumming around the beats at a slant
column9: and Kim Coletta's bass embeds more zooms and fillips in outwardly brawny
column10: inwardly delicate masses of sound.

column1: But ""preserved"" is an apt term
column2: as the record sounds more canned than its predecessor
column3: losing some of its palpable danger. Though the guitar attack can be ferocious
column4: the former dynamic range is squeezed in. Barbot's guitar work is perhaps more inventive than ever before
column5: but instead of exploding into being
column6: it more often sidewinds in and out of the mix. Relaxed
column7: almost boho passages on ""Mirrorful""
column8: ""Desert Sea""
column9: and ""Livid"" sound more like the Breeders and Pavement than Embrace and Rites of Spring
column10: early emo-core bands that influenced Jawbox. My favorite song on the album is also their prettiest ever
column11: ""Iodine""
column12: a sleepy
column13: melancholy ballad where Robbins sings
column14: with unusual tenderness
column15: over a limpid melody painted in liquid trails of guitar. There's even a hidden song
column16: an unironic (if not overly reverent) cover of Tori Amos' ""Cornflake Girl"". You can't get much more ""120 Minutes"" than that.

column1: Signs of the times aside
column2: there is plenty of peak Jawbox to be found. ""His Only Trade"" churns as thrillingly as ""Jackpot Plus!"" from Sweetheart
column3: with Robbins' fiery vocal performance matching the urgent lyrics: ""Someday he's gonna wake up in a burning house and wonder what to save and wonder who to blame."" ""Empire of One"" finds a deep
column4: exhilarating pocket in jungle drums and terse call-and-response vocals. ""Capillary Life"" is notably grand and subtle
column5: with a multi-staged depth and scope elapsing in the usual three-or-so minutes. J. Robbins chants and spits like he means it.

column1: But what did he mean? ""Best of all
column2: as he sings
column3: ""it's open-ended."" You'd call the lyrics stream-of-consciousness if they weren't so focused
column4: the phrases and delivery so sharply wrought. Robbins' cryptic tirades have a moral dimension and an aesthetic one; they accuse and self-lacerate; they are wary of systems and alert to betrayals of trust. Two frames in particular stand out. On ""Won't Come Off""
column5: Robbins sings
column6: ""One second cut from the arc of a swan dive
column7: pulled out tight to the pitch of a taut line
column8: as if encapsulating his band's situation and style: An arc of force that has been pulled straight
column9: thrumming with the strength of its own will to bend back. ""At the bottom
column10: they all want proof
column11: and at the top
column12: no one's making room
column13: Robbins adds on ""Chinese Fork Tie""
column14: as if diagnosing his position between an equally restive underground and mainstream.

column1: After their self-titled album
column2: Jawbox's Atlantic sub-label disintegrated and mainstream music moved on from cleaning up punk bands. In their relatively brief existence
column3: they made made a lasting impression on incoming waves of math-rock and post-punk bands with dissonant textures
column4: awkward stop-start dynamics
column5: and knotty instrumental phrasing. And if it's not their best album
column6: their self-titled swan song
column7: frequently cutting through its temporal trappings with that old desperation and drive
column8:
still holds up.

No band makes a show of underground camaraderie like Destruction Unit. The group tends to invite friends on stage
column2: uniting players from typically insular realms like hardcore
column3: minimal synth
column4: and metal in the service of further saturating its already dense
column5: imposing performances. There’s a tagline for this
column6: New American Heavy Underground
column7: which you can find on t-shirts. And the catalog of Ascetic House—an art collective and tape label tied to Destruction Unit—likewise corrals sounds from the shadowy margins of accessibility. Eroding those superficial scene divisions dovetails with broader visions of liberation: Destruction Unit celebrated the release of its latest album
column8: Negative Feedback Resistor
column9: with the pioneering prison abolitionist group Critical Resistance
column10: for instance. But for all of that refreshing commitment to activism and exploding aesthetic cliques
column11: the album sounds rather familiar
column12: an echo of its last full-length statement
column13: Deep Trip
column14: and the usual proto-punk touchstones.

column1: Destruction Unit's current lineup solidified by 2013’s Void. Previously
column2: the handle was a vessel for vocalist and guitarist Ryan Rousseau
column3: a refugee from the Reatards. With a new lineup
column4: the Arizonan outfit favored up-tempo
column5: punchy beats inherited from hardcore; riffs pitched to near-total scree; and barren
column6: windswept passages reminiscent of the group’s forbidding but awesome Sonoran Desert surroundings. It was an estranged sort of psychedelia
column7: distinguished by what felt like elemental terror from the American southwest
column8: but with Destruction Unit’s latest album the same approach risks exhaustion. Repeatedly evoking an arid landscape is perilous work; inspiration could evaporate.

column1: That said
column2: Negative Feedback Resistor is assaultive in a way that Void wasn’t. This is in no small part due to the rhythm section
column3: which defaults to an up-tempo beat that lurches and bludgeons in the insistent style of Motörhead or even Discharge. With their reliance on halftime breakdowns and sharp drum patterns
column4: Destruction Unit sound inspired by hardcore
column5: but they leave out the concision. That’s too bad. The three-minute highlight ""If Death Ever Slept"" could lead a savage seven-inch. Instead
column6: it’s easy to miss after the album’s midway slog through redundant nine- and seven-minute numbers.

column1: This lack of dynamics works better in the band's cataclysmic live show
column2: where the band has few peers. But Negative Feedback Resistor’s relentlessness made me pine for Void’s atmospheric excursions. There are a few hazy
column3: impressionistic moments
column4: notably the introduction to ""Judgment Day""
column5: but they feel appended rather than interwoven. And
column6: as with many traits of Negative Feedback Resistor
column7: the same could be said for Deep Trip. Indeed
column8: Destruction Unit’s prior album opened with a song that pivots abruptly from sprint to halftime in much the same way as ""Disinfect"".

column1: Negative Feedback Resistor also harks to space-rock like Hawkwind
column2: not to mention that the core riff for ""Salvation"" is essentially identical to the Stooges’ ""I Feel Alright"". Rousseau’s words are mostly inaudible
column3: morphed into queasy
column4: feverish missives
column5: but the ongoing allusions to drugs and the bible indicated by song titles and lyrical snippets are frustratingly pat and disappointing. Off record
column6: the band’s ideas about getting free are much more urgent
column7: inventive
column8: and contemporary than those psych clichés. Sadly
column9:
the band's stylistic conservatism has such a blurring effect on their records that any three tracks contain its total rewards.

Kurt Vile has a persona
column2: and you know him by now: He is the weird quiet kid in the corner
column3: the one who seems at first lost in his own world and disconnected from everything around him
column4: but turns out to be smart
column5: observant
column6: and low-key hilarious. So while his albums draw you in with the vibe—the impeccably recorded and mixed songs that shuffle bits of folk
column7: new wave
column8: or country in the mix but are always squarely down-the-middle rock—you return to them for their human qualities
column9: the way they offer a manner of seeing the world
column10: a glimpse at a perspective that feels both voyeuristic and easy to connect to your own life.

column1: You have to feel for Vile when he does early interviews for one of his records and he’s asked to characterize them. Music writers look for a story
column2: an angle
column3: a hook
column4: and he gamely tries to give them one
column5: a reason why an upcoming record is different from his last few. In the case of b’lieve i’m goin down
column6: he pointed out that it was darker
column7: an album from the night
column8: written in the lonely quiet hours after his wife and two children had gone to sleep. (My favorite quote on this came from his interview with Rolling Stone: ""It’s definitely got that night vibe…KV’s Night Life—it’s my sequel to Donald Fagen’s The Nightfly""). But Vile’s albums mostly vary in smaller details; they are collections of songs that generally draw from a similar handful of influences
column9: and Vile’s style as a guitarist
column10: songwriter
column11: and especially a vocalist keep them relatively uniform. His arc so far has been a process of refinement
column12: of gradually figuring out settings in which the songs work best.

column1: On b’lieve i’m goin down
column2: that means he’s incorporated a bit of banjo and a bit more piano and has eased off just slightly on the reverb. The essential quality of his music is no different
column3: but the banjo picking draws out a bit of folkiness
column4: and piano shifts things slightly from capital-R Rock to singer-songwriter territory. But many of these songs could have just as easily been found on either of his last two full-lengths
column5: which in his case is not a bad thing.

column1: Something that has changed over the years is that Vile has grown steadily funnier
column2: and his lyrics have grown more sophisticated. Humor was always part of his music
column3: but on b’lieve i’m goin down it’s an animating principle. Lines like ""When I go out I take pills to take the edge off or to just take a chillax
column4: forget about it/ Just another certified badass out for a night on the town"" scan as goofy on the page
column5: but in the context of the arrangement of ""That’s Life
column6: tho (almost hate to say)"" they become something else entirely. The song is a dark
column7: doom-laden thing
column8: with fingerpicked guitar out of ""Can’t Find My Way Home"" and a bleak undercurrent of synth
column9: something in the realm of Nick Drake in ""Black Eyed Dog"" mode. In this setting
column10: Vile’s tossed-off musings
column11: where punchlines alternate with striking imagery (""I hang glide into the valley of ashes"")
column12: remind you that every sage worth a damn knew that life was absurdly funny and tragic simultaneously.

column1: The quotable lines are many. It’s been a while since I heard a description of a hangover as evocative as ""A headache like a ShopVac coughing dust bunnies""; ""I’m an Outlaw""’s banjo accompaniment might make you think of a folk ballad
column2: but Vile’s outlaw is like one you’ve never seen
column3: one ""on the brink of self-implosion
column4: alone in a crowd on the corner
column5: in my Walkman in a snow globe going nowhere slow."" ""Pretty Pimpin"" describes a moment of existential confusion in front of the bathroom mirror
column6: with Vile brushing a stranger’s teeth before realizing ""they were my teeth
column7: and I was weightless""—whoops. ""Lost my Head there"" has a piano riff like the theme from an early '80s sitcom
column8: but played a step too slow
column9: like you’re about to watch the usual ridiculous ""Three’s Company""-style misunderstanding happening in drug-induced slow motion. But then it turns out to be a tune about its own creation
column10: and Vile’s description forever colors how you hear it: ""I was buggin’ out about a couple-two-three things/ Picked up my microphone and started to sing/ I was feeling worse
column11: than the words come out/ Fell on some keys and then this song walked out.""

column1: As compelling as Vile’s words can be
column2: much of the magic lies in his delivery. Like Tom Petty
column3: Bruce Springsteen
column4: and Bob Dylan
column5: Vile’s singing voice has acquired an unstable accent of indeterminate origin that shifts to suit his musical decisions
column6: rather than connecting to genre or region or even his own upbringing. Most often
column7: he’s got a nasally twang unlike that of any other native Philadelphian
column8: and it helps his low-key murmur cut through the wooly mid-tempo haze. That twang makes his music feel more grounded and conversational
column9: and there’s also a bit of a ""Hey
column10: it’s me again"" quality the first time you hear it on a new album
column11: an aural watermark that never leaves you any doubt that you are listening to a Kurt Vile record.

column1: Vile’s signature qualifier is ""I guess…""—the phrase shows up frequently in his songs. It’s easy to believe he’s never quite sure of what he’s seeing or exactly how he’s feeling. Vile’s version of reality is always slightly confused
column2: a blurry approximation of what’s out there
column3: one in a state of constant revision. This could strike some as lazy
column4: like he can’t be bothered to whittle the blunt stick of his music down to a fine point
column5: and it’s this perpetually fuzzy quality that leads people to label Vile a spaced-out stoner. But from another angle the uncertainty feels honest
column6: an acknowledgement that a great deal of life involves making it up as you go along. Or as Vile puts it on ""Dust Bunnies""
column7: ""There ain’t no manual to our minds
column8: we’re always looking
column9: baby
column10: all the time.""

column1: Vile now plays ""rock"" in the most '70s sense of the word—album oriented
column2: guitar solo-friendly
column3: very much about long-haired dudes sitting in a room playing instruments. That he’s hitting his peak as an artist at a time when rock music of the type he practices is falling out of favor and is becoming just another genre instead of the center of the musical universe only adds to his appeal; this is not an artist concerned with being in step. Vile’s relevance to the music world at large rises and falls
column4: but he keeps plowing ahead
column5: secure in the knowledge that in an examined life there will always be more to explore
column6:
another bleary morning with another unfamiliar face looking back at you over the bathroom sink.

In his new memoir

column4: having only recently changed their name from Joy Division to New Order in the wake of Ian Curtis’ death
column5: opted for a change in direction that would forever alter their career. ""Our music had become so incredibly dark and cold
column6: we couldn’t really get any darker or colder
column7: he says. ""I remember quite clearly sitting in a club in New York one night
column8: around three or four o’clock in the morning
column9: and thinking how great it would be if we made music
column10: electronic music
column11: that could be played in one of these clubs."" The rest
column12: of course
column13: is history. New Order would go on to become one of the most successful and innovative dance acts of all time
column14: creating an aesthetic that split the difference between guitar-heavy post-punk and club-ready dance music. Some 30 years later
column15: New Order continue to develop and refine the template they essentially created with surprisingly positive results.

column1: Music Complete is New Order’s 10th studio album
column2: and for all intents and purposes
column3: it’s the first thing they’ve recorded since 2005’s Waiting for the Sirens' Call (2012’s long-delayed Lost Sirens was essentially a hodgepodge of Waiting outtakes). It also reflects a series of shifts within the band
column4: created after the departure of bassist Peter Hook and reintroducing original keyboardist Gillian Gilbert back into the fold. For longtime fans
column5: the acrimonious departure of Hook is potentially worrisome
column6: as his melodic basslines were so integral to many of New Order’s most beloved tracks. As it turns out
column7: they needn’t have worried too much. New bassist Tom Chapman
column8: who formerly played with Sumner in Bad Lieutenant
column9: creates a pretty faithful simulacrum of Hook's signature sound both live and on record. Having largely eschewed the heavy guitars that weighed down much of their output for the past decade
column10: New Order embrace electronics again on Music Complete
column11: conjuring the kind of synth washes and house-y piano runs that could have easily pulsed across their records during their mid-'80s heyday
column12: making for what is arguably the most refined record they’ve released since 1989’s Technique.

column1: The 11 tracks on Music Complete essentially touch on all the things that New Order do best
column2: from the wistful melancholy of the record’s first single
column3: ""Restless""—a lovely ""Regret""-like bummer ode to the perils of never being satisfied—to the pounding eurodisco of ""Tutti Frutti""
column4: it is as if the band tried to assemble a record based on all of their most iconic vibes. In large part
column5: they manage to succeed. On even their most classic records
column6: New Order can be amazingly inconsistent
column7: the truly great songs always eclipsing the simply forgettable ones. In this way
column8: Music Complete is no exception. ""Plastic"" is the most inspired bit of dance music the band has recorded in years—a sprawling seven-minute bit of Moroder-ish synesthesia in which Sumner’s perfectly affectless vocal—""It’s official
column9: you’re fantastic
column10: you're so special
column11: so iconic""—plays against tastefully employed bits of Chic guitar jangles and a classically New Order-ish bassline that somewhere is making Hooky's head explode. It’s really the only track on the record that belongs on the same kind of rarefied dance floor as classic New Order jams like ""True Faith"" and ""Fine Time""—which means it’s the kind of slick
column12: slightly chilly
column13: and grandly magisterial electro pop that is essentially begging to be remixed into some kind of ecstatic 12” version that can play on a loop for days.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: ""Singularity"" opens with what literally sounds like an old Joy Division outtake—an ominous bassline and some warped guitar lines that sound as if they were being played in a room just adjacent to the actual recording studio—before exploding into a digitized electro banger
column3: while ""People on the High Line"" could be a distant cousin to Republic’s ""World""
column4: complete with chorus-echoing female backup vocals. ""Tutti Frutti""—one of three tracks featuring additional vocals from La Roux’s Elly Jackson—reaches for a similar state of dancefloor euphoria and almost gets there. As always
column5: Sumner’s lyrics are hit and miss (""You got me where it hurts / but I don’t really care/ ‘Cause I know I’m OK / Whenever you are there."") but he always manages to sell it effortlessly. In fact
column6: effortlessness has always been New Order’s greatest trick. The best tracks on Complete are the kind of tastefully deployed dance track that the band has spent decades articulating—perfect
column7: polished
column8: airtight—but one can’t help but wish that Music Complete had a few more of them on board.

column1: The record’s weakest tracks are generally the most tepid. ""Academic"" and ""The Game""
column2: while certainly not terrible
column3: suffer from being both unmemorable and somehow overly familiar
column4: sounding like a dozen or so other fine but mostly unremarkable New Order tracks haunting the latter halves of previous albums. Elsewhere
column5: ""Stray Dog""—a track featuring a long spoken word passage growled by none other than Iggy Pop—would make for an appropriately larky B-side
column6: but is something of a momentum killer when placed squarely in the middle of a pop album. The record does end on a high note though
column7: with the swooning ""Nothing but a Fool"" adding the requisite dollop of perfectly-metered melancholy and album-closing ballad ""Superheated"" (featuring Brandon Flowers in what one can only imagine is his ultimate wet dream of a guest spot) bringing all the feelings to a charmingly earnest song about lost love that sounds like it could/should have played during the penultimate scene of a John Hughes movie (in the best way possible).

column1: For longtime fans
column2: Music Complete is something of a return to form for New Order—complete with appropriately chic minimalist artwork courtesy of Peter Saville. The record’s carefully considered aesthetic and meticulous production bear all the hallmarks of the band’s most iconic work. Still
column3: it’s hard to know if anyone other than the band’s legions of devotees will find most of this material truly arresting. Music Complete certainly doesn’t do anything to diminish New Order’s formidable legacy
column4: but it doesn’t necessarily expand upon it either. That being said
column5: it still sounds like classic New Order
column6: and now over three decades deep into their career
column7:
it's kind of amazing that nothing else really does.

In 2004
column2: when Dungen released their third and still-greatest LP
column3: Ta Det Lungt
column4: the Swedish quartet was just one good act amid a minor psych-rock renaissance. At the time
column5: a number of bands were finding inspiration in progressive rock from the '60s and '70s and pushing those sounds toward fuzzier and more frantic extremes. This was also the year that Santa Cruz's Comets on Fire released their well-loved record
column6: Blue Cathedral
column7: and around the same time that Dead Meadow
column8: Pearls and Brass
column9: and Boris were putting out some of their best music.

column1: Ten years later
column2: a lot of these groups have split up
column3: moved on
column4: or faded from view
column5: but Dungen have proven surprisingly durable
column6: even a bit influential. It’s hard to listen to Tame Impala’s Innerspeaker and Lonerism without hearing some parallels to the Swedish band
column7: particularly in the sense of rhythm and the doubled upper-register vocal melodies.

column1: Allas Sak is Dungen’s first release in five years and seventh album overall. Not too much has changed since their last record
column2: 2010’s Skit I Allt. Like that album
column3: Allas Sak is split almost evenly between Swedish-language pop songs and instrumentals. And like all preceding Dungen records
column4: it sounds awesome. Led by singer
column5: multi-instrumentalist
column6: and engineer Gustav Ejstes
column7: the band is able to perfectly dial in the organic tones of vintage '60s pop
column8: even when working with computer-based recording software.

column1: While Dungen have never quite bested Ta Det Lungt in terms of pop uplift and songwriting
column2: the band have also never made a truly bad record. Rather
column3: they have remained remarkably consistent
column4: so much so that by the time 4 came out in 2008
column5: audiences had probably started to take them for granted—one more record
column6: one more Keith Moon-style drum fill
column7: one more expertly-fuzzed guitar solo. But after half a decade off
column8: Allas Sak provides some great evidence for why Dungen have endured while so many of their peers have trailed off.

column1: Though Ejstes initially wrote all of the songs and even performed most of the band’s music
column2: over the years Dungen have gradually become a group effort
column3: with a dedicated band including guitarist Reine Fiske and drummer Johan Holmegard
column4: and bassist Mattias Gustavsson. As a result
column5: they’ve gotten progressively jammier from album to album. But while Dungen’s music has its share of sprawling moments
column6: it’s seldom aimless. Even in their most improvisational passages
column7: the band’s songs move with intention—one solo or spaced-out interlude setting up the next climax or scene shift.

column1: Of the record’s instrumentals
column2: only the guitar-driven freak-out ""En Dag På Sjön"" sounds like it was clipped from a spontaneous jam session
column3: while the rest are deliberate and composed. On ""Franks Kaktus""
column4: Ejstes performs the lead melody on a flute
column5: trading riffs with the guitar and guiding the band in and out of a bongo-laden groove. As smooth as the music is
column6: though
column7: it doesn’t come off as arch or ironic. Indeed
column8: you can hear evidence of Ejstes earnestly vibing out every time his notes go slightly sharp—the wind equivalent of a bent guitar note or scrunchy face. On ""Flickor Och Pojkar""
column9: a delicate Rhodes piano melody is gradually augmented with string and acoustic guitar flourishes that sweep across the stereo field. The music recalls the work of film composer Ennio Morricone in its attention to arrangement and sonic detail.

column1: This obsession over small moments and gestures is important to the Swedish band’s music. A lot of psychedelic rock is focused on the big-picture freak-out—the zonked experimental and spontaneous moment where the music becomes combustible and uncontrollable. And while Dungen are capable of producing those moments
column2: the band have always set their primary focus on hooks
column3: both in a rhythmic and melodic sense. Just about any four bars of a Dungen song could be sampled and looped as the foundation for something else.

column1: And though the group’s music appropriates sounds and production styles from the past
column2: it’s hard to think of a particular act from the '60 or '70s that Ejstes is consciously emulating. <span id=""docs-internal-guid-d5e32603-f19f-ef1d-8b7b-bda4f97ad703""><span>Rather
column3: Dungen use retro-minded instrumentation and recording techniques to convey fairly modern musical ideas
column4: removed from the established sounds of classic rock and psych. The rhythm section
column5: in particular
column6: takes a strong influence from the feel and pulse of hip-hop. In this
column7: they’re a little like Stereolab
column8: another band that drew heavily from vintage experimental music
column9: but who would never be mistaken for revivalists.

column1: It's true that over the years Dungen have not changed very much. The band has remained in a more or less fixed position
column2: while styles
column3: temperaments
column4: and audiences around them shifted. Ejstes has been right to stick to his guns
column5: though. Today’s Dungen record might sound a lot like yesterday’s Dungen record
column6: but yesterday’s Dungen record was good. And while the execution has at times wavered over the years<i>
column7: Allas Sak finds the band fully re-engaged in the sound that it has staked out over the past decade—performing music that’s still as beautiful
column8: optimistic
column9: strange
column10:
and singular as ever.
