Electronic producer Natasha Kmeto has described her new album Inevitable not as a conceptual project
column2: but as a reflection of herself. Within the past year
column3: she's spoken frankly about her coming out experience
column4: a development in her sexual identity that has found its way into her music. Her awareness developed in large part on the dance floor
column5: manifesting in a colossal yet loving environment that also served as a space for personal catharsis. Inevitable brings this catharsis to her listeners.

column1: Kmeto's vocals have always been a tool in the production of her past works
column2: but they ring out with clear and present force on Inevitable. Her singing is forthright but also verging on breaking
column3: as if she was struck by a sudden wave of vulnerability. From the record’s first seconds
column4: she telegraphs how different the stakes are for her: On opener and title track ""Inevitable"" she pleads ""When you coming back
column5: baby? When you coming back?/ I will love you down
column6: baby
column7: when you’re coming back."" The unadorned sound and raw sentiment send a powerful message: Take me for who I am.

column1: Inevitable sounds sharper and smoother than Crisis
column2: but it still feels raw
column3: like the sort of music that is ripped in desperation out of the heart and guts—the truly messy parts—of its creator. There is an unfinished charm to her music; the components of the tracks sound like they don’t (or shouldn’t) mesh together. Kmeto’s voice shimmers on ""Inevitable"" while the slow
column4: rumbling and minimalist instrumentation dies just short of a climactic peak. It seems incomplete
column5: but Kmeto saves it with the vividness of her lyrics and the quiver of her voice.

column1: Kmeto has been compared to Grimes and Maya Jane Coles
column2: but those comparisons feel flimsy at best. Kmeto is better understood next to the criminally underrated Cooly G. Both make music lyrically fueled by desire
column3: exploring the possibilities of unspoken meaning found in mood
column4: in space and silence
column5: and in carefully considered lyricism. The music builds as the stakes do as well.

column1: On ""I Thought You Had a Boyfriend""
column2: one of the strongest tracks on the record
column3: Kmeto sings about a confusing romantic connection. ""Your eyes
column4: lingered on me as you said goodbye
column5: she sings at the outset. ""And our hands held a little bit longer than what would seem polite."" Kmeto sounds at once frustrated and open
column6: and as the song progresses
column7: the synths build and build to an overwhelming wall of sound. Is it the rising bite to Kmeto’s words as she sings on the chorus that makes the song so unsettling? ""I thought you had a boyfriend/ I thought you had a man
column8: she says. ""I thought it wasn’t like that/ I thought you had a plan."" After two verses
column9: the synths wash over the listener like a tidal wave of emotions as she repeats the chorus again and again. Kmeto doesn’t ask a question
column10: but she does demand an answer.

column1: Other strong songs on the record fit this same structure. ""Closer Comes My Love"" at first sounds like a sensual slow jam
column2: but peaks in cacophony. ""Peak""
column3: more of a traditional dance track
column4: has straightforward lyrics that pair seamlessly with the slight dubstep flourishes found in the track's final minutes.

column1: Unlike her young peers also creating soulful jams (Tinashe
column2: Jhené Aiko)
column3: Kmeto’s music refuses to slink into the background. On Inevitable
column4: Kmeto’s personal awakening blooms into her music
column5: both lyrically and structurally. As queer identity gets shoved aside with the mainstreaming of electronic music
column6: as if the queer community didn't fuel the genre's formation
column7: it's more vital than ever to have voices like Kmeto's bringing it to the forefront. This
column8: without question
column9: is a record of discovery and confusion as much as it is about the power of confidence in understanding and loving oneself. Inevitable is a collection of slowly ripping cords
column10: the underlying tension manifesting on tracks as if Kmeto must manage simmering emotions and can’t
column11:
or maybe won’t.

Austin producer Spencer Stephenson
column3: aka Botany

column9: psych and krautrock

column12: sometimes brainy explanations in interviews about what his mood-driven soundscapes are all about.

column1: Dimming Awe

column4: scours away the haze of his underrated 2013 debut Lava Diviner (True Story). That album

column7: the latter of which distinctly recalls FlyLo circa When the Quiet Comes. Milo is a good foil for Stephenson: The looped sampling of a laugh track and French chansons on ""Au Revoir"" neatly align with Milo’s meandering
column8: stream-of-consciousness verses. ""Au Revoir"" and ""No Translator"" are also Stephenson's first time working with a rapper

column1: Stephenson has said that much of this album was improvised
column2: his way of taking cues from jazz favorites like Herbie Hancock and Pharoah Sanders. You can hear it in the improv drumming that clatters around in the background of ""Birthjays"" and the synth ad libbing that drives ""All Is Rite""

column4:

On the cover of Honeymoon

column5: gazing behind her through face-obscuring shades. As an artist
column6: she's never shied away from the obvious
column7: but the image feels almost too on-the-nose

column9: that's exactly what Honeymoon gives us—it is Lana Del Rey's purest album-length expression

column1: Accordingly
column2: Honeymoon is a dark work
column3: darker even than Ultraviolence
column4: and the pall does not lift for its 60-plus minutes. It's an album about love
column5: but ""love""
column6: as Del Rey sings it

column8: when she croons ""Our honeymoon/ Say you want me too""
column9: she's dopily hopeful as Brian Wilson singing ""We could be married/ And then we'll be happy."" The album luxuriates in this bleak space between dream and reality

column2: or rather <i>who
column3: we are here for. It knows that we want big
column4: sad
column5: fucked-up epics. It's rare to get to a chorus within the first minute
column6: and until that point it's usually just Lana
column7: maybe a little guitar or some cinematic strings. The programmed drums of ""High by the Beach"" and ""Religion"" wait nearly a minute to enter
column8: and ""Terrence Loves  You"" is even sparser. Many tracks expand sleepily past the five- or six-minute mark

column3: Hotel California
column4: The Hissing of Summer Lawns. She sings about it all—the sprawl

column4: ""Freak""
column5: and ""Art Deco"" she sounds beyond longing

column2: and riffing on
column3: America since the beginning

column9: and as architecture critic Christopher Hawthorne writes
column10: ""can take you from a world-famous piece of architecture to a weed-choked lot
column11: from a realized ambition to an abandoned one
column12: in the space of a few blocks.""

column1: In the following verse
column2: she replaces blues with ""news"" and substitutes ""Pico Blvd.""
column3: which is working class for its duration
column4: bi-secting Koreatown and running through Ecuadorian
column5: Salvadoran
column6: Russian
column7: and Mexican communities. The juxtaposition is startling and canny. In the space of one lyric

column9: real city running parallel to the gleaming
column10: manufactured one
column11:
sketching an arterial map of a city coursing with ambition. It reminds us of something that was the very issue with Del Rey that irritated some early on—she knows exactly what she is doing. Honeymoon just synthesizes ideas she's been vamping on from the beginning into a unified work. She figured where she was going long before she got there; with Honeymoon she has finally arrived.

While he's best known as one half of the Black Keys
column3: Dan Auerbach's built himself quite a resume of extracurricular actives in the past few years

but works best as a one-off event.

It is hard to know what to make of Sleep
column2: the new eight-hour album and therapeutic project from the perennially audacious British composer Max Richter. On one hand
column3: the purpose is simple: Richter intends for the listener to press ""play"" on the full-length digital version
column4: nod off to sleep somewhere between the patient piano chords of ""Dream 1"" and the vocal-and-organ ululations of ""Path 3
column5: and re-emerge after eight hours of music to a gentle crescendo of stretching strings
column6: wordless harmonies
column7: and long-tone bass near the close of ""Dream 0"". By consulting with famed neuroscientist and past collaborator David Eagleman
column8: Richter has created a slow-motion
column9: electronics-and-chamber-ensemble hybrid meant to reinforce and reflect natural sleep cycles. ""An invitation to dream
column10: Richter has called it.

column1: On the other hand
column2: the third-of-a-day span between the beginning and the end isn’t some inert
column3: sustained tone
column4: simply meant to maintain a snooze. Instead
column5: it’s an ever-shifting set of meticulously performed pieces that both affirm and expand Richter’s reach as a composer. He webs together string quartets and electronic drones
column6: tense duets for piano and violin
column7: and somnolent keyboard meditations. Richter brings most of his interests as a composer to bear here
column8: too. He blends an Arvo Pärt-like sense of motion with deep
column9: low notes and shimmering drones that reflect his past in electronica and adoration of Brian Eno. His love of high-minded concepts
column10: previously reflected by the likes of his essential The Blue Notebooks
column11: meets his exquisite
column12: human touch as a pianist.

column1: So should you use Sleep as directed
column2: as ""a landscape … where people could fall asleep""? Or should you sit upright and let the beguiling Richter ease your daylight hours? Can you actually do both?

column1: Richter
column2: of course
column3: is not alone in his quest to help listeners rest better. Sleep is an active avenue of both art and commerce—in large part
column4: it would seem
column5: because we do not get enough of it. The ceaseless streams of social media feeds and on-demand entertainment have intensified that diagnosis. According to Sleepless in America
column6: a National Institutes of Health-supported documentary aired last year by National Geographic
column7: the average person now dozes thousands of hours less than they once would have
column8: a condition that comes with profound physical and mental symptoms. Instead
column9: we spend billions of dollars every year on ways to get more sleep
column10: from medicines that induce it and conditions that foster it to beds that support it and systems that monitor it. We write books meant to reward children for falling asleep
column11: and in a rather Orwellian twist
column12: we weed out employees whose sleep disorders might disrupt productivity.

column1: And when we do get it
column2: we brandish it
column3: whether bragging about how good it felt
column4: analyzing our dreams
column5: or funneling pieces of the experience into art. A recent show in New York sampled centuries of art inspired by hypnagogia
column6: that surreal state of mind just between wake and sleep; in 2013
column7: the hotel chain Ibis introduced a feature to guests that tracked their nocturnal movements and transformed them into a lysergic piece of ""Sleep Art"". Sleep fascinates exactly as it frustrates
column8: creating a reflexive cycle that never actually ends.

column1: For these 31 uninterrupted pieces
column2: Richter accepts the extraordinary challenge of not only aiding sleep but also translating the act into art—that is
column3: he scores a scene he sets himself. If you listen while you’re awake
column4: many of these pieces conjure dreamy states
column5: where ideas seem fluid and flexible and the world around you seems somehow softer. ""Aria 2""
column6: which arrives in the piece’s final third
column7: turns a sublime piano phrase into a seemingly infinite maze
column8: as though you could follow it forever and never go anywhere. Strings and electronics wash around the melody in waves
column9: oscillating glacially between a few glowing notes like Sigur Rós at their most romantic or Stars of the Lid at their most staid.

column1: ""If You Came This Way"" suggests the sweeping
column2: soaring motion of a symphony
column3: though muted and slightly distant
column4: as if it were being played in another room of the same building. The action grows grand only for an instant
column5: testing the limits of your reverie only to galvanize it a moment later. And the gorgeous ""Song / Echo"" seems to do for chamber pop what Grouper has long done for folk rock—disassemble it and scatter the elements in a cloud
column6: making something so wide and gentle that you think you might be able to live inside it. You can snooze in any of these songs. Just don't think about all you will miss.

column1: In talking about this eight-hour nightlight of sound
column2: Richter has often lamented the pace of the modern world and the torrent of information that many of us must face each day. ""We have to curate our own information space and that’s quite a big deal to do
column3: he told The Quietus. ""You’ll still have to make tons and tons of choices and spend so much of the day reading all these different messages which will give you tons of reading. So sometimes a pause is a good thing.""

column1: That idea aligns Richter with the researchers and marketers trying to give people a chance to check out for eight consecutive
column2: recuperative hours
column3: yes. But his use of the word ""pause"" also reflects the way I’ve enjoyed Sleep the most—not as a sleep aid but instead as a relaxing agent. Most of this music is indeed calming not to the point of boredom
column4: where I need to sleep through it
column5: but so that I simply want to sit still and listen and ponder. And though Richter took considerable pains to make Sleep seamless
column6: the payoff of hearing it as a whole (a rather exhausting proposition
column7: ironically) versus the resources required to do so is incredibly low. The music shifts between and slowly recycles parts
column8: so you consistently wind up at some place very close to the start. Instead
column9: I like to push ""play"" in random places and listen for an hour or so
column10: a move that allows me to hear Richter at glorious work and gives me the chance for the restorative ""pause"" for which he’d hoped. This music is absorbing. You'll want to pay attention
column11: to shut out other concerns. The stretch between the narcotic ""Chorale / Glow"" and the twinkling ""Non-eternal"" is perhaps my favorite segment for this reason; it’s an immersive sampler of Richter’s past successes and some new ideas
column12: blurring into one.

column1: Sleep
column2: then
column3: is simply too didactic as a name. It’s a command that tells us how to enjoy something that clearly has other uses. That handle
column4: combined with Richter’s conceit
column5: has turned the record into a kind of clickbait story
column6: too
column7: which seems entirely antithetical to Richter’s point. (""That 8-Hour Sleep Album—Explained
column8: offers the Time headline.) Pause and Rest come closer to Richter’s ultimate goal of simply taking some time out from the whirlwind around you. At its best
column9: Sleep feels like compositionally rigorous new age music. It’s a place in which you can settle for a while
column10: with or without a pillow
column11:
and emerge only when you are ready to rejoin the restive world.

Sam Binga's defining characteristic as a producer seems to be generosity. To his fans—he's maintained a frenetic release pace since early last decade (often under his Baobinga alias)—but mostly to other artists
column2: as the majority of those releases feature collaborations with vocalists or other producers. This tends to be the first thing anyone mentions about Binga
column3: and while it's refreshing
column4: especially in electronic music
column5: to see an artistic approach other than Genius Lone Wolf
column6: it's also resulted in a highly variable catalog that has obscured anything resembling a signature touch or sound. Wasted Days
column7: Binga's proper debut record
column8: again features a host of MCs and offers a robust 17 tracks (a four-sided LP version is trimmer) but stands as his most realized and bountiful work yet
column9: synthesizing two decades of UK bass music into something vigorous and modern.

column1: Binga is a child of UK rave culture
column2: and his production style has flitted between drum'n'bass
column3: grime
column4: and dubstep. Grime's resurgence
column5: as both a pop and underground phenomenon
column6: has refocused UK music's relationship with dancehall culture
column7: as MCs have increasingly stepped back into the booth. Before grime
column8: though
column9: MCs played a large role in DJ sets
column10: toasting over jungle and UK garage sets. It's this loose
column11: improvisational feel that defines Wasted Days
column12: as vocalists shuffle through tracks Binga has tailored to showcase their slurring patois. Their muddied taunts and boasts offer crucial texture and melody to Binga’s drum-heavy chambers
column13: leaving the tracks in a liminal space between structured song craft and narrative-driven rap.

column1: Putting a precise name on Binga’s productions proves difficult. They have the tempos and streamlined tech-y-ness of modern-day drum’n’bass (the album is on Critical Recordings
column2: the pre-eminent home for underground drum’n’bass in 2015)
column3: eschewing cut-up breakbeats in favor of sound design. Its slithering melodies and dub-heavy sound recall grime and dubstep
column4: and rap and footwork has seeped into Binga’s work just as it has general UK dance culture. It’s the rare record for which the imprecision of the term ""bass music"" is a positive.

column1: At times Wasted Days feels like someone shined a spotlight into whatever dungy corner Kevin Martin’s the Bug project has inhabited the past few years
column2: fumigating the living room and disinfecting the kitchen. The two share a love for UK soundsystem culture
column3: but Binga’s version is far less blunted and menacing. On tracks like ""Mind and Spirit"" and the title cut (featuring frequent Martin collaborator Warrior Queen) Binga’s productions advance in sustained
column4: athletic bursts
column5: moving explosively between verses. Opener ""Believe"" largely consists of a rapid bursts of sub-kicks
column6: leaving plenty of headroom for MCs Redders and Rider Shafique’s id-driven swagger.

column1: On ""Stormy Weather"" and ""Reclaim"" (which features fellow bass explorer Om Unit) Binga manages to ease off the gas and offer more contemplative work without sounding lame or maudlin. They offer just enough variety
column2: even if the combination of Binga and the MCs suggests harder/better/faster/stronger is the correct impulse. What’s remarkable though is how well Wasted Days comes together
column3: and how easy it is to return to a 17-track collaborative album of indeterminate style; the degree of difficulty in actually pulling this off shouldn’t be understated
column4: and you need look no further than the last Bug album to see how easily this kind of project can bog down. Wasted Days manages to provide a grand stage not just for the MCs but
column5: at last
column6:
for Binga’s talents as well.

The composer
column2: keyboardist and singer Julia Holter has pursued her strange
column3: dreamlike visions across three albums of experimental pop
column4: all released in the last three years. In that time
column5: she's also worked with electro-pop act Nite Jewel and psych-folk cult favorite Linda Perhacs
column6: and in all of this activity
column7: you hear her restlessly pinpointing and subsuming new
column8: piquant sounds. Those sounds range widely
column9: from French impressionist classical music and 17<sup>th</sup>-century madrigals to Talk Talk's jazz-infused post-rock
column10: from the avant music-drama of Robert Ashley and Meredith Monk
column11: to the pop songwriting that evolved in the hills of her Los Angeles hometown in the 1970s. But though these names remain on the tip of your tongue as you listen to her music
column12: none of them describe Holter; they are only points on a broader and more inscrutable map.

column1: Her latest album
column2: Have You In My Wilderness
column3: is by some measure her sunniest and most accessible. There is no overarching concept uniting the music
column4: no references to Euripides or '50s MGM musicals. As Holter told Stereogum
column5: she ""[made] up stories for every song"" for Have You
column6: but this being Holter
column7: our glimpses of each ""story"" are brief and foggy
column8: and the vignettes themselves are often plagued by ambiguities (""I hear small words from the shore/No recognized pattern"")  and moments of overpowering grief or wonder. More questions are asked than answers given in her often-unrhymed prose poems
column9: and statements fold into themselves dizzyingly: ""Figures pass so quickly that I realize my eyes know very well/It's impossible to see who I'm waiting for in my raincoat"" (""Feel You""). Like a good student of the art music world
column10: Holter clearly hopes that listeners will nurse their own impressions.

column1: The music has also shifted
column2: gaining warmth and weight while remaining enigmatic. Loud City Song was a mess of stylistic dissonances working in the service of one discrete story (borrowing mostly from the 1958 film for the musical Gigi)
column3: but Have You… is tied together by music so airy it feels in danger of floating right past you. Despite the heavy cloak of reverb
column4: the record has the clear sound of a small rock band playing the studio
column5: highlighting the inventive but uninvasive upright bass and percussion of Devin Hoff
column6: Corey Fogel and Kenny Gilmore. The haze is also dialed back on Holter’s vocals
column7: making them crystal clear at crucial moments.

column1: Despite the breezy
column2: poppy feeling of  the singles ""Feel You"" and ""Sea Calls Me Home""
column3: the choruses are not as immediate as those on the earworm-heavy Ekstasis or Loud City Song. But in looser
column4: through-composed songs like the sensual torch ballad ""Night Song"" and jazz-fusion-inflected ""Vasquez
column5: Holter find other
column6: deeper ways to hold our attention. In ""Betsy on the Roof"" –  an inspired reworking of a song Holter previously recorded on 2010’s Live Recordings – she drifts in and out of muted speaksong
column7: sliding from pealing
column8: Newsom-like tones into throaty speech. The chorus (""’Uh oh
column9: ’ she said/What of this cloud?"")
column10: though
column11: is belted and raw-sounding
column12: and in the wordless coda her gossamer crooning recalls either Christine McVie or Judy Collins.

column1: But what ultimately makes Have You in My Wilderness transcendent – and unique in Holter’s catalogue – is its intimacy. The atmosphere is often light-hearted or even parodic: In the  giddy ‘70s singer/songwriter melismas of ""Sea Calls Me Home
column2: the husky
column3: Marlene Dietrich-like delivery of ""How Long?"" or the jokey
column4: clap-trap country shuffle of ""Everytime Boots
column5: you hear Holter trying on sounds like costumes
column6: sometimes for only a bar or two. Ironically
column7: the more she shapeshifts
column8: the more we seem to get to know her. For an artist who could sometimes seem forbidding or remote
column9: Have You In My Wilderness feels humane
column10: and with each new release
column11: it seems like a bit more of the personal is teased out of Holter's stately
column12: high-concept approach. Have You In My Wilderness embraces the specific
column13: rather than the eternal
column14:
and in her narrowed focus you can sense a palpable self-confidence and a hard-won precision.

In Jeff Chang’s 2014 book Who We Be: The Colorization of America
column3: he likens the race to co-opt hip-hop and other subcultures in order to capitalize on a wider consumer base as something of a gold rush. Lady Gaga positioned herself as a benevolent ally to the marginalized despite being white
column4: thin
column5: blonde
column6: and rich. Feminism
column7: once an ideological haven
column8: has now become a buzzword bastardized beyond recognition because we insist on aligning its values with celebrities. What keeps the status quo—particularly as it pertains to money
column9: power

column1: Part of the appeal of Mykki Blanco

column3: hissing
column4: convulsing sound and explosion

column6: minimal
column7: hi-hat-driven stutter of ""Childish"". And one of C-ORE’s real standouts is the ""LBCD""
column8: by Psychoegyptian. ""My rap name used to be Little Soda
column9: Little Child Soldier

column1: Earlier this year

Alessia Cara struck an introvert’s pose on her April debut
column2: ""Here""
column3: and found herself famous. The single’s sound perfectly matched the attitude of its lyrics: a minor-key piano loop anchored a surprisingly powerful series of verses about a miserable party experience. ""Really
column4: I would rather be at home by myself
column5: Cara sang

column7: Taylor Swift
column8: and Drake co-signed her. The New York Times profiled her.

column1: Less than six months later
column2: she's made a fast transition from ostensible outsider to insider. An ""antisocial pessimist"" who’d rather not have been invited to the party in the first place is quite suddenly the toast of the pop scene
column3: her songs in heavy rotation on Beats 1. Cara finds herself a priority for Def Jam. They’ve quickly capitalized on her success with an EP
column4: Four Pink Walls
column5: which packages ""Here"" next to four other songs

column1: Cara has a strong voice but lacks the power of an Ariana Grande
column2: let alone a Mariah or a Whitney. Nevertheless
column3: the label seems to think she’s best off belting anthems on the familiar subjects of teenage-dom. ""Seventeen"" kicks off the record with a vocal loop
column4: a simulated handclap
column5: and stirring chords that build into a hook about listening to your parents and appreciating your youth. Sometimes you can hear Cara’s spiky attitude poke through the sweet
column6: pop polish. For instance
column7: in response to her mother’s earnest advice about staying grounded
column8: Cara rolls her eyes: ""Yeah

column1: But—spoiler alert—she accepts the advice
column2: and it becomes the song's focus. This sense of giving in to conventionality is also present on the record’s other anthem
column3: the even catchier ""I’m Yours""
column4: which
column5: with its fluttery melodies and earthshaking chorus
column6: could have fit in nicely on the Haim album. Some of ""I'm Yours"" is seemingly meant to reflect an antisocial pose—this time toward a guy—but it's more poutily flirtatious than anything else. ""Oh how rude of you
column7: to ruin my miserable
column8: and tell me I’m beautiful
column9: she sings. ""I'm mad at you for being so cute.""

column1: There’s no reason to expect Cara to be permanently frozen into a charmingly grouchy position. But the specificity of ""Here"" has given way to blander
column2: faux-outcast posing. ""Seventeen"" and ""I’m Yours"" are both well-constructed pop songs
column3: sugary lyrics and all
column4: and it’s easy to imagine them as huge hits. The worst track here
column5: as its name suggests
column6: is ""Outlaws"". Its cheerful
column7: burping horn and tinkling keys don’t seem to do anything for Cara
column8: as she croons that her partner is ""the shine into her star."" She sounds properly Stepford-ized
column9: almost completely without her personality.

column1: That leaves us with the title track
column2: a boom-bap
column3: neo-soul closer that shares more musical DNA with ""Here"" than anything else on the EP. And suddenly
column4: the girl with her own opinions and feelings is back. She sounds comfortable vocally
column5: and you can hear shades of Lauryn Hill (who Cara has said she admires) and Erykah Badu. This is also the track where Cara lets us back into her shyness. She tells the story of her sudden fame
column6: going ""from ‘when boredom strikes’ to ‘Ms. Star on the Rise
column7: ’"" she sings. ""But those four pink walls
column8: I kind of miss them
column9: man.""

column1: The four pink walls are her bedroom
column2: where she was first discovered posting clips to YouTube
column3:
before she was snatched up by Universal Music Group. Early fans of those raw recordings may be less than happy that she's given into the customary tropes of bubblegum pop. And Cara herself sounds a little unsure about leaving behind the walls she knew so well for ones that may end up holding her back.

column1: This is first time we can hear what Powers actually sounds like—the piercing clarity of Savage Hills Ballroom has to be a reaction to the muffled bedroom ambience and warped kaleidoscopism that respectively defined The Year of Hibernation and Wondrous Bughouse. column1: While Savage Hills Ballroom awkwardly stretches to make universal points from Powers' personal distaste

column3: the tag ""alternative rap"" comes with many connotations: this rap subverts mainstream politics; this rap has a message; this rap is different; this is #RealHipHop. It’s often a distinction used by rap elitists and purists to separate rap with a supposed intellectual bent from the rap they consider low brow or obtuse. It can be an ugly

column5: one that stands at the center of rap’s greatest schism; it has been a defining label in many rap class wars.

column1: But sometimes the term categorizes rap acts that truly exist on the fringes of the genre
column2: acts that stretch the boundaries of how rap can sound with progressive and daring compositions. Producer Chief Xcel and emcee Gift of Gab have been one such creative force as Blackalicious

column4: often Afrocentric message that’s more prudent than preachy over dynamic production. From 2000 to 2005
column5: the tag-team released a trio of strong LPs—Nia
column6: Blazing Arrow
column7: and The Craft—but parted soon after to pursue individual interests. On Imani
column8: Vol. 1

column3: Questlove’s drums
column4: a DJ Shadow interlude

column6: and rapid-fire rapping all arranged carefully on a funky sonic canvas. The pair’s last album

column9: but in its quest to be an experimental marvel
column10: it over-thought its thesis
column11: occasionally doing too much
column12: sonically and technically. The first of a projected trilogy
column13: <i> Imani
column14: Vol. 1 takes important lessons from both

column1: Blackalicious is most effective when Gift of Gab’s knotty multisyllabic schemes unspool without decryption and nestle neatly in the nooks and crannies of Xcel’s soulful romps
column2: and on songs like ""Ashes to Ashes"" and ""I Like the Way You Talk""

column4: one of the most underrated technicians of his time
column5: can still trade bars with the best of them
column6: but what makes <i>Imani

column1: Imani is the Swahili word for ""faith"" and on the opener of the same name Amde of the Watts Prophets spells out the album’s mission statement: ""Never let life’s troubles block your flow/ Have faith and get where you’re trying to go."" Blackalicious has always promoted positivity

column1: When Chief Xcel and Gift of Gab are both producing at max output

Cologne's Jens-Uwe Beyer has a thing for big statements: His 2012 recording Red Book drew out a single
column2: unbroken techno groove to nearly 80 minutes—a metaphorical ""journey by DJ"" that could
column3: in fact

column7: texture
column8: or tone. Now

column10: he strikes a balance between these approaches. It is an invitation for the listener to travel but as travelogues go
column11: The Emissary features no panoramic views
column12: no grand vistas
column13: no monuments
column14: no scenes of splendor. It's more of a soothing blur flashing past

column1: There are two principal modes at work across the album's nine tracks: pulse and echo. ""It Started on Wednesday"" uses both at once

column1: These tracks aren't terribly sophisticated; as per Kompakt's Pop Ambient dictate
column2: the album is content to take a pretty simple idea—ambient music as comfort food—and stretch it as far as it can. But there are also promising signs that Beyer isn't quite content to leave things there. As ""Moonshine Tangerine"" fades out
column3: a scrappy guitar figure
column4: run through tremolo

column11:
that every journey is also the story of a journey not taken—teasing snapshots of the world beyond the train's windows as it comes fleetingly to rest.

Mary Halvorson owns one of the more easily identifiable guitar sounds you will encounter
column2: in any genre. That is partly due to an ingenious effect: a delay pedal that she uses as a startling
column3: mid-note pitch-shifter. But if she didn’t have anything to offer beyond that novelty
column4: her playing wouldn’t sustain the three modern jazz groups she currently heads (a trio
column5: a quintet and a septet)
column6: as well as her sought-after work in various other ensembles—including two different bands led by jazz guitar luminary and occasional Tom Waits sideman Marc Ribot. With her quick
column7: experimentalist’s mind
column8: Halvorson resembles the great composer
column9: saxophonist and teacher Anthony Braxton (an early instructor of hers
column10: with whom she still collaborates). On her new album Meltframe
column11: a set of guitar covers
column12: she is simultaneously employing two suggestions from her former professor’s syllabus: develop a solo act
column13: and don’t forget to engage with the past.

column1: Halvorson is well respected in the jazz community for the speed with which she can conceive of strong ideas. In the midst of a fleet improvisation you might hear her becoming progressively enamored of some small portion of a given melody
column2: selecting it for additional repetition within the flow of a solo. Next
column3: she’s slowing the tempo and turning the fragment into a rollicking vamp
column4: while switching her amplifier’s tone. As you’re appreciating the rhythmic change
column5: you may not immediately notice that she’s also creating a new path back toward the full theme. But when she returns to the original hook
column6: the culmination is as satisfying as any single effect she may have used for punctuation along the way.

column1: Meltframe’s tracklist was refined during her stint as the opener for an acoustic tour by King Buzzo of the Melvins. If at first it seems like a self-consciously idiosyncratic grab bag (Duke Ellington and Ornette Coleman?)
column2: as usual
column3: Halvorson has a plan. She links these two composers in the album’s sequencing via mournful tune-selection
column4: but uses different methods of attack to preserve a distinction. Slide-playing and tuning quirks grace her performance of Coleman’s ""Sadness"" (while recalling something of the composer’s own ""harmolodics"" concept). Then
column5: she slows Duke’s ""Solitude"" way down
column6: using a delicate reverb to provide the sparest of pulses. Her playing shines in both performances. Nor is a conceptual subtlety the only thing Meltframe has going for it. The opening number is a finger-busting
column7: grungy take on Oliver Nelson’s ""Cascades""—a song aptly titled
column8: given its quickly swooping figures. Those familiar with Nelson’s soulful hard-bop sound may be tempted to wrinkle a nose at the interpretive move
column9: here
column10: but they shouldn’t: Halvorson’s recourse to the distortion pedal successfully underlines what an imposing riff-writer this composer was. A high energy approach also predominates during the back half of Halvorson’s exciting reinterpretation of McCoy Tyner’s ""Aisha"" (which features on the John Coltrane album Olé Coltrane).

column1: Halvorson also tosses recent pieces by contemporaries like Tomas Fujiwara and Chris Lightcap into her mix. These cuts don’t always carry the melodic jolt of the certified classics
column2: but Halvorson’s performances show how today’s jazz still works with an awareness of popular textures
column3: including indie rock (as with the noisy drone section she creates when playing Lightcap’s ""Platform""). Surely
column4: Halvorson’s most personal statements are still found on the albums where her own compositions rule. Though by liquefying some of the curatorial borders that surround jazz in the popular imagination
column5:
Meltframe refocuses our attention on an essential malleability that is the genre’s core tradition.

column5: but there’s value in his ability to repackage styles and sounds into something that requires little to no unpacking. After releasing a solid buzz-building free studio album

column7: last year

column9: Rodeo
column10: a master class in the pyramid scheming of rap industry politics.

column1: Travis Scott studied carefully at the Kanye West School of Maximalism
column2: where sounds are expensive and songs are sumptuous with rich
column3: interlocking details and meticulously selected guests. Since releasing his debut EP
column4: Owl Pharaoh
column5: in 2013 (and perhaps even before) he’s been honing a sixth sense for emphasizing gravitas. His greatest trick is making songs feel big and important. But Scott has cobbled together a composite identity to compensate for lacking his own. He’s quickly earned a rep as a shameless biter
column6: an aesthetic bender with no regard for ownership or authorship—a claim given credence by Rodeo’s second single

column1: This has become the enduring criticism of Scott’s work so far: That he’s a skilled impersonator posing as a creative
column2: a mime playing puppetmaster. (There are at least three alleged reports of creative theft
column3: which led to this takedown in Deadspin.) But this narrative overshadows the more glaring holes in his music. Travis Scott isn’t good at rapping—he often bawls out clunky phrases that dawdle into banality (""Always hit the gas like I broke wind"")—and his self-proclaimed status as an auteur isn’t dictated by his own talent
column4: but by the talent of those surrounding him. ""Who do I owe? Nigga
column5: no one
column6: he boasts on opener ""Pornography""
column7: when he’s actually deeply indebted to those in or adjacent to the Kanye Think Tank and the others he’s wrangled based on that affiliation.

column1: One thing Scott does very well is squirm through openings onto bigger platforms
column2: which is a talent in and of itself. He is one of rap’s premier young capitalists
column3: an opportunist deft in the use of social currency
column4: turning a friendship with Illroots creator Mike Waxx into a relationship with T.I. and finagling a meeting with Kanye West out of networking with his engineer
column5: Anthony Kilhoffer. The strength of his catalog is almost exclusively dependent on the strength of his connections.

column1: Rodeo is the culmination of Travis Scott’s amassed networking efforts. The credits are a Who’s Who of the big names in rap and its neighboring genres: Narrated by T.I.
column2: it tells a nebulous tale of Scott’s meteoric rise and the perils of fame. The lush and often gorgeous production comes courtesy of current league leaders in rap hit-making Metro Boomin
column3: Sonny Digital
column4: and Zaytoven
column5: with add-ons and attachments from a host of heavy hitters like Mike Dean
column6: DJ Dahi
column7: Hit-Boy
column8: Wondagurl
column9: Southside
column10: FKi
column11: and TM88. There’s standout work from Frank Dukes and Allen Ritter. Sometimes
column12: like on ""Oh My Dis Side"" or ""90210""
column13: beats jack-knife in two
column14: revealing stunningly posh second acts. Sometimes
column15: like on the nearly eight minute epic ""3500""
column16: they have shimmering piano outros. The Pharrell-produced ""Flying High"" fastens a surging
column17: slow-rolling coda onto a wailing beat. The sound is a kind of big-budget alt-trap with lots of accents and gloss
column18: like if Future’s Dirty Sprite 2 was executive produced by 2010 Kanye
column19: and it often pays big dividends.

column1: Many of those dividends
column2: though
column3: feel as though they arrive in spite of Scott. He’s easily outmaneuvered by charismatic rappers of note Juicy J
column4: Quavo
column5: and 2 Chainz (""Crib bigger than your imagination""). Pop singers the Weeknd and Justin Bieber both steal the show with singsong rap-like verses on their respective features. Even Chief Keef and Toro Y Moi make their presences heavily felt
column6: upstaging the Houston rapper in the process. Travis Scott’s verses are often without substance and chock full of choppy cadences
column7: and songs without guests
column8: especially ""I Can Tell""
column9: are undone by the monotony.

column1: To be fair
column2: Scott isn’t without his merits. He is most effective when he harshly distorts his vocals to create texture
column3: and in the company of others he can serve as a welcome change of pace. He has an ear for programming. But Rodeo’s best songs—""Maria I’m Drunk"" and ""Nightcrawler""—mostly succeed because they overcome his contributions. He's still a middling talent
column4:
and comes across as rebellious youngster that’s been given the keys to dad’s Porsche and simply asked not to wreck it.

""I am suddenly in very serious financial trouble
column2: Aaron Funk
column3: better known as the producer Venetian Snares
column4: posted on Twitter and Facebook at the end of August. ""If you've ever enjoyed my music
column5: I badly need your help asap."" Two weeks later
column6: his fans had delivered and
column7: shortly thereafter
column8: so did Funk. At face value
column9: Thank You for Your Consideration could be seen as Funk's version of ""pulling a Beyoncé""—which
column10: as of 2015
column11: is often shorthand for the way new music is released. But unlike Bey
column12: or Drake
column13: or Björk
column14: the Winnipeg producer's new record was neither accompanied by a plea for remuneration (fans had already donated without any promise of a reward)
column15: nor was it part of a larger marketing scheme (the album was posted on Bandcamp
column16: rather than released via Funk's longtime label
column17: Planet Mu). Instead
column18: like much of Funk's work that came before
column19: Thank You for Your Consideration's release was enigmatic
column20: raw
column21: and
column23: sincere: ""Thanks for having my back and caring about me and the music I make

column1: For about a decade beginning in the late '90s
column2: Funk was a restless creative force—dropping album after album of breakcore beats in a deluge that resulted in some of the decade’s most arresting electronic music. At his creative peak—arguably 2005's ambitious
column3: classically-inspired Rossz Csillag Alatt Született—it wasn’t uncommon for Funk to issue several releases a year. But eventually
column4: his output slowed to more human levels. Four years passed between 2010’s My So-Called Life and 2014’s My Love Is a Bulldozer and
column5: in that time
column6: Funk himself seemed to cede momentum to artists whose own sounds softened or refined parts of the one he helped create (Death Grips
column7: Gobby
column8: the Range
column9: and the Vaporwave aesthetic all owe much to the road he paved).

column1: One might guess
column2: then
column3: because of the nature of its release and Funk's prolific recording schedule
column4: that Thank You for Your Consideration is cobbled together from different stages of his career
column5: or simply a collection of tracks he never planned to release at all. As he told XLR8R last year: ""I think I still make the same amount of music
column6: I just barely show it to anyone anymore."" While that may be the case
column7: unlike other odds-and-ends albums
column8: Consideration's 14 tracks come off as remarkably—and appropriately—considered when taken as a whole. While last year's My Love Is a Bulldozer saw Funk experimenting with his own vocals to beguiling results and this year's Your Face showed a more condensed side to Snares' sound
column9: Thank You for Your Consideration bursts with the explosive strangeness and mathematical focus that defines much of his best work. The album's intricately programmed drums have the loose feel of much of his mid-2000s aesthetic and Funk's dynamic time signatures spin like rogue gyroscopes feeding off their own entropy.

column1: The album opens with ""Smersonality""
column2: a wobbly production whose groove is driven by spazzed-out synths and jazzed-up beats. For longtime fans
column3: it's a return to form; for newcomers
column4: it may recall Zach Hill by way of Aphex Twin. Venetian Snares' music is often purposefully difficult to swallow in large doses
column5: but more often than not there's a cleverness and humor that rewards deeper listens. ""Koopa Cookies""
column6: whose name portends the glitchy chiptune that erupts from the song's placid opening
column7: plays like a boss battle where Mario's mushrooms aren't of the legal variety. Further down the road
column8: ""Thousand Mile Stare"" is a jungle track with a vocal sample as sinister as its razor-blade synths. Funk has also always been capable of tempering high-octane drum and bass with less combustible fare. ""Beside the Past by a Lake""
column9: for example
column10: uses a retro-futuristic palette to paint a scene that's as soothing as it is unnerving without feeling disjointed.

column1: While the unnamed circumstances that led to Thank You for Your Consideration are no doubt terrible for Funk's personal life
column2: the fact that a plea can be answered
column3: and that an artist can return that favor in kind just weeks later
column4: is the sort of story that illustrates the adaptability of the Internet. While jaded listeners may view each new leak and mixtape as the next piece of a perpetual PR machine
column5: Consideration is an argument for a more human view of technology. (As is clear from a recent FACT interview
column6: there's perhaps nobody more jaded by the music industry
column7: or music criticism
column8: than Funk himself.) From the patient
column9: apocalyptic drone of ""09sept09"" to the synapse-sizzling electro of ""Ötvenöt 3""
column10: Thank You stands for itself. But it's difficult to ignore the context: ""Still royally screwed
column11: yet you've made me so feel supported and loved
column12: he wrote when linking to the album. Like much of Funk's best music
column13:
it's a statement filled with tension and contradiction.

In the 2013 film
column2: Memphis
column3: Willis Earl Beal stars as a singer who drifts through the woods and walks the streets alone. He visits a church and a strip club
column4: soaking in the city by himself. Beal’s recent work feels born out of that movie
column5: its meandering pace and self-assessing narrative a direct complement to the flick’s equally meditative theme. In Memphis
column6: Beal’s character hits a minor breakthrough
column7: his face bathed in blue light as he sings in one of the film’s pivotal scenes. Beal never achieves such catharsis on Noctunes
column8: his latest album. Instead
column9: he casually floats by in a billowing wave of airy soul that never quite lands.

column1: Noctunes
column2: Beal’s seventh album in five years
column3: moves slowly—very slowly—as he tries to channel the same ethereal ambience Marvin Gaye once did. Like the album title suggests
column4: these are evening tunes. That they induce sleep if played at low volume is perhaps on purpose. The music just sort of hangs around without any progression
column5: making the album seem longer than its already not short 63-minute runtime. This is a bedroom recording in the truest sense: as it plays
column6: you can almost see Beal sitting in a dark room
column7: calmly peeling off each note. That makes Noctunes a pretty heavy listen
column8: except these songs aren’t as structured as previous efforts. The light melodies accentuate Beal’s best feature—his dynamic
column9: gospel-inflected baritone—as he sings about personal struggles. And while he draws you in by the sheer magnitude of his timbre

column1: He’s got plenty to talk about
column2: though: In August
column3: Beal was arrested in Portland
column4: Ore. on charges of criminal mischief and harassment. He’s struggled with alcoholism
column5: been homeless
column6: and was plagued with health complications that forced him from the Army. Last year
column7: Beal had a very public fallout with his then-label
column8: XL/Hot Charity
column9: and spent time couch surfing on the West Coast following his divorce. He addresses those romantic perils toward the middle of Noctunes—on consecutive tracks ""No Solution""
column10: ""Stay""
column11: ""Say the Words""
column12: and ""Love Is All Around"". On ""No Solution""
column13: in particular
column14: Beal sounds especially contrite. He references a ""lost"" wedding ring and the dissolution of his marriage. By ""Love Is All Around""
column15: he gives in to some sort of finality: ""Those haunting words that she said/ ‘Go the fuck away.’"" The singer processes these emotions on Noctunes
column16: though his thoughts don't always shine through
column17: given the album's milieu and paltry backdrop. These should be great deep blues songs
column18: but they’re missing the cohesion of that genre at its best. Noctunes is muddy and unfocused
column19: and not inspirational at all. Instead
column20: the tracks are drab and make the album almost impossible to endure.

column1: Beal's output has never been polished
column2: but at least on his fascinating debut
column3: there was a certain earnestness to his music. With Beal
column4: there was something alluring about the lo-fi hiss of ""Sambo Joe from the Rainbow"" or ""Too Dry to Cry"". Noctunes resembles a half-baked effort to recapture some sort of personal peace. A noble exercise
column5: but in Beal’s attempt to exorcise old demons
column6:
the LP comes off way too moody and far too methodical to resonate long term.

Credit her time in Tu Fawning for that enhanced presence. During her solo hiatus Repp dedicated herself to that Portland band

even if her gut doesn’t fully believe it yet.

That same hard-fought resolve carries through even the album’s most sorrowful moments

Akira Sakata is a longtime student of multiple avant-jazz traditions. The piercing intensity of his alto saxophone and clarinet playing occasionally harkens back to the mid- and late-'60s work of John Coltrane
column2: Eric Dolphy
column3: and Albert Ayler. But the Japanese musician's simultaneous attention to psych rock and some of the more meditative aspects of global free improv has helped him build a catalog of improvised music that sounds beholden to no school. (He even funked it up with Miles Davis' great fusion-era guitarist
column4: Pete Cosey
column5: on the unmissable 2001 album Fisherman's.com.) His skill as a synthesist is so great that it can sometimes feel self-effacing
column6: with Sakata often appearing more concerned with a given group's success than individual heroics.

column1: Given this
column2: it's only fitting that Sakata wound up collaborating with Jim O'Rourke
column3: the unassuming experimental magus responsible for this year's Simple Songs (as well as
column4: in large part
column5: Sonic Youth's late-period renaissance). Their first recorded collaboration—a generally frenetic
column6: double-live 2011 set titled and that's the story of Jazz…—placed O'Rourke's guitar and Sakata's reeds alongside the free-time pulse of drummer Chris Corsano and bassist Darin Gray (the duo known as Chikamorachi). This time
column7: they've added Japanese noise-electronics eminence Merzbow to the mix

column2: Flying Basket begins quietly
column3: with Sakata lingering over a few notes and phrases. O'Rourke also avoids heading straight for the shredding post-punk that dominated his playing on this ensemble's last recording. Merzbow
column4: too
column5: starts softly; nearly a tenth of the album has passed before his prickly shards pervade the album. This slow
column6: muted intro helps lend weight to the explosions that pop up throughout.

column1: The piece tenses and slackens
column2: passing through fits of raw soloing and quiet drones and extended technique texture. The overall feel is graceful; during one passage that finds Sakata on clarinet
column3: he manages the trick of grouping some pinched notes into phrases that sound like charming exclamations. The interplay here
column4: just before the record's midpoint
column5: is so nuanced and powerful that the ""everyone go fully nuts"" ending seems somewhat less impressive than it otherwise might. Still
column6: Flying Basket is another valuable document of a vital
column7:
contemporary avant-team-up. Anyone who has been following O'Rourke's varied activity since moving to Japan should want to hear this—along with more of Sakata's own discography.

Pop music was built on a whole lotta ""yeah."" Because saying ""yeah"" is the most casual
column2: innocuous form of rebellion—there is no easier way of showing you don’t give a fuck than abdicating the responsibility required to enunciate the ""s"" in ""yes."" Seeing it through to the end is a show of diligence and commitment. So when Ought singer-guitarist Tim Darcy drops a fulsome ""yes"" in the middle of ""Beautiful Blue Sky""—the spectacular centerpiece track of his band’s sophomore album
column3: Sun Coming Down—he’s sure to savor it. Amid a song whose chorus reads like a laundry list of 21st-century blights (""Warplane/ Condo/ New development"") and excruciating water-cooler chit chat (""How’s the family?/ How's your health been?/ Fancy seeing you here!"")—Darcy declares
column4: ""I’m no longer afraid to die/ Because that is all that I have left/ Yessssss
column5: stretching out that last letter like pizza dough on a woodblock.

column1: It’s an alarming admission
column2: one that reads like the last will and testament of somebody who’s been so numbed by the dispiriting
column3: clockwork demands of modern life that choosing death feels like the only empowering
column4: self-actualizing move at their disposal. But Darcy invests his ""yes"" with an ecstatic sense of clarity
column5: as if he was John Lennon meeting Yoko Ono for the first time. Though Darcy is a poet whose voluminous verbiage often overwhelms his melodies
column6: it’s no insult to say that simple ""yes"" is the greatest lyric he’s written—because it so perfectly crystallizes his band’s essence and purpose.

column1: Ought make indie rock that sounds like how urbanity makes you feel: nervous
column2: antsy
column3: sometimes hostile
column4: yet intoxicatingly vibrant. And Darcy
column5: likewise
column6: gesticulates like a dutiful office drone who’s played by the rules his whole life but just can’t take it anymore. Ought’s 2014 debut
column7: More Than Any Other Day
column8: was an album of slowly unfurled epiphanies
column9: stoking simmering tension into fiery
column10: exultant release. Those sort of affirming moments are a little harder to come by on the more chaotic and caustic Sun Coming Down
column11: but the album’s relentless drive and uncompromising attitude constitute their own special kind of thrill. If More Than Any Other Day was about the hard-fought
column12: triumphant ascent
column13: Sun Coming Down is the giddy
column14: daredevil ""wheeeeee!"" down the other side of the peak.

column1: A lot has changed for Ought since the release of their first album—not the least of which is their lead singer’s surname. (Darcy was billed as Tim Beeler the last time out.) More significantly
column2: what was once a casual project among university roommates was promoted to workhorse touring act
column3: and Sun Coming Down sounds like the sort of record that was hastily hashed out in between transatlantic jaunts. But that’s not to suggest the album sounds unfinished or is lacking focus—rather
column4: the new album takes full advantage of Ought’s fully revved
column5: road-tested engine and increased horsepower
column6: in a strike-while-the-iron’s-hot move. Gone are the hazy ambient ballads
column7: quirky congeniality
column8: and taut goose-stepped grooves that
column9: on More Than Any Other Day
column10: counterbalanced the band’s wiry freneticism. Here
column11: Ought doubles-down on their oft-cited early-'80s Fall and late-'80s Sonic Youth reference points
column12: handily destroying any inkling you might have had about this band following the likes of Clap Your Hands Say Yeah or Vampire Weekend into big-tent-indie territory.

column1: Sun Coming Down’s more aggressive attack pushes Darcy out of his usual agitated-everyman mode to deliver more cryptic narratives in a theatrical snarl that
column2: at times
column3: verges on Mark E. Smith karaoke. But while Ought’s influences may be obvious
column4: you’re never really sure where they’re taking them: the fearsome rapid-fire rants
column5: clanging guitar tangle and jackhammered drums of ""The Combo"" turn oddly celebratory in the wake of the song’s surprisingly cheery chorus (""Jubilation
column6: darling!""); the bee-swarm buzz and frantic accelerations of ""Celebration"" are undercut by Darcy’s wonderfully fey
column7: Fred Schneider-worthy exhortations (""Okay... let’s do it!""). Other songs are subjected to more abrupt change-ups: ""On the Line"" alternates between ponderous tone poem and garage-punk rave-up
column8: before settling into a sublime third act that recalls the steady
column9: galloping build-up of Patti Smith’s ""Gloria""
column10: while ""Passionate Turn""—the only time here Ought attempt to channel the nocturnal grace of More Than Any Other Day’s knockout ballad ""Habit""—turns from swooning
column11: stumbling serenade into a menacing
column12: militaristic march for its final verse/chorus run.

column1: Even the songs that remain locked into formation undergo subtle yet substantial mutations. The opening sprint of ""Men for Miles"" sees Darcy rewriting his verse melody with each pass and
column2: as the band lean their full weight into the song’s motorik momentum
column3: his unyieldingly abrasive guitar noise gives way to hypnotic
column4: third eye-prying bliss. And the aforementioned ""Beautiful Blue Sky"" may initially sound like Ought’s answer to ""Marquee Moon""
column5: but spiritually speaking
column6: it’s their ""Once in a Lifetime""
column7: a song that paints a vivid picture of cubicle-bound 9-to-5 conformity before providing you with the sledgehammer to smash it. The transmission may be a little more distorted this time out
column8: but
column9: with Sun Coming Down
column10: Ought’s underlying message is the same as it ever was: you have the power within you to change your lot in life. When you feel like there’s no way out

just say ""yes.""

John Lydon doesn’t seem like the jealous type. But I like to imagine that when he relaunched Public Image Ltd. six years ago

column1: What the World Needs Now… is an improvement on 2012’s This Is PiL primarily because Lydon’s vocal theatrics and calisthenics are even more entertaining this time. He rants

column4: screams

column1: Other mid-tempo tunes on What the World Needs Now… don’t fare as well. The line between compelling repetition and tedious wheel-grinding is pretty thin for this group

column3: he can’t save them all. Things never quite fall apart completely
column4: though it does become tough to find a heartbeat inside the fuel-deprived ""Big Blue Sky"". It doesn’t help that the tune’s disengaging loops and arena-rock choruses last for over eight minutes.

column1: Those kinds of struggles come during What the World Needs Now...'s second half
column2: which makes the album feel a bit like a five-mile race run by a sprinter. Things end on a pointed note
column3: though
column4:
as Lydon solves the riddle of his own album title: ""What the world needs now/ Is another fuck off!"" Anyone ensnared by Lydon’s past work will find enough here to hope he and PiL continue to seek those kinds of answers.

Over the past decade
column2: Broken Social Scene alumna Emily Haines has played the role of post-Internet philosopher
column3: struggling to retain her individuality in a world growing more developed and technologically dependent by the day. The binary between authenticity and artificiality has remained a perennial interest for the Toronto-based musician
column4: and it comes up yet again on her band Metric's latest album Pagans In Vegas with zero subtlety. In one corner waits the natural
column5: manifested in dressed-down guitars and Haines’ lilting soprano. In the other
column6: the machines state their case through forays into disco drudgery
column7: stiff synths and Siri singalongs. Over the course of 13 tracks
column8: these two forces collide
column9: with the latter ultimately winning out.

column1: Pagans in Vegas deepens the new-wave  dalliances of its predecessor (2012's Synthetica) with their slinkiest
column2: slickest palette to date. Depeche Mode’s influence is impossible to ignore – opening track ""Lie Lie Lie"" and mid-album highlight ""Too Bad
column3: So Sad"" take their rhythmic cues from the bluesy strut of ""Personal Jesus""
column4: while ""For Kicks"" channels the nocturnal throb of ""Precious"". The cartoonish 8-bit bleep-bloops adorning tracks like ""The Shade""
column5: meanwhile
column6: belie a quirkier
column7: '80s-arcade inspiration.

column1: This gives listeners the chance to experience Metric in an unprecedentedly cheery context
column2: but in the case of ""The Shade""
column3: it comes at the cost of stirring up traumatic memories of Adam Sandler’s god-awful video game movie Pixels. Fortunately
column4: the group make up for it with lead single ""Cascades""
column5: a glitched-out dance track that casts Haines as some type of forlorn
column6: sleep-deprived android
column7: whispering against the percussionists’ paranoid
column8: thumping percussion. It’s the perfect synthesis of Fantasies’ meaty fretwork and Live It Out's glossy electronics
column9: as well as a rare moment of stylistic equilibrium.

column1: As with past albums
column2: Haines continues to seek lyrical inspiration from everyday Sisyphean struggles. On ""Too Bad
column3: So Sad""
column4: she finds herself in a restless transit ""back and forth between the desert and the sea""
column5: qualifying it with a shrug: ""who I was and I will always be"". Love proves an equally futile endeavor; on ""For Kicks""
column6: Haines offers the least-comforting parting words imaginable to a former interest
column7: cooing that she’d stay true ""if it was easy"" (par for the course in the Tinder age). ""I want it all!"" she crows on ""The Shade""
column8: and as the album progresses
column9: Haines’ self-awareness emerges as the most intriguing aspect of the album's character.

column1: In a recent interview with SPIN
column2: Haines revealed that Metric have already prepared an answer to Pagans In Vegas: a follow-up album recorded entirely with all analog instruments. Up to this point
column3: the band’s maintained a long-lasting marriage to the zeroes and ones
column4: but that appears to be changing. The shift would be more compelling if it didn't feel so literal. In <i>Pagans in Vegas
column5:
humans and machines exist in a binary relationship. The reality is both more nuanced and fertile than that.

Wald marks a new beginning—maybe even a new new beginning—for Pole
column2: the solo alias of the Berlin producer and mastering engineer Stefan Betke. It is his first album in seven years
column3: and its predecessor
column4: Steingarten
column5: was itself a kind of reboot. Early on in the Pole project
column6: Betke was remarkably productive: In just six years he recorded five albums
column7: and the first three of those were instant classics
column8: despite the fact that they were all essentially variations on the same theme—an alchemical fusion of dub bass and static crackle. But with albums four and five
column9: as Betke sought to escape the strictures of his own signature
column10: he seemed to find only detours rather than a viable way forward (2001's R
column11: featuring remixes from Burnt Friedman and Kit Clayton
column12: has held up rather well; 2003's Pole
column13: featuring the rapper Fat Jon
column14: has not). A four-year break followed
column15: and it must have done him good
column16: because Steingarten
column18: was among the best work of his career. Abandoning the midrange murk and omnipresent white noise in favor of crisp sounds
column19: elastic rhythms
column20: and vast space
column21: it felt like vacuum-sealed krautrock
column22: and as a celebration of texture and tone color

column1: Perhaps Betke's unwillingness to repeat himself explains why he followed Steingarten with yet another extended silence
column2: one broken only in 2011 with a trio of EPs
column3: Waldgeschichten (German for Forest Stories). That title
column4: like Wald
column5: refers to the walks in the woods where Betke apparently looked for inspiration. That image may bring to mind Wolfgang Voigt's Gas project
column6: whose foggy swirls of classical samples were inspired by the Black Forest and its role in German Romanticism. But the two artists' impressions of the woods couldn't be more different. Where Gas is either dark and claustrophobic or starlit and idyllic
column7: Pole's Wald evokes porous thickets and branches stripped bare by the elements.

column1: As is customary in his work
column2: texture reigns supreme. Instead of melodies
column3: there are clusters of tone—glassy drum-machine pings
column4: brushed metal
column5: scraped flint
column6: the atonal shimmer of a guitar being strummed above the nut. In ""Käfer""
column7: a junkyard guitar provides the semblance of a through-line across a landscape of crickets and electrical interference; a synthetic melodica takes the lead in ""Moos (Live)""
column8: and wheezing organs lend both color and a viscous sense of substance to many of the album's tracks. Only in ""Myzel"" and ""Fichte""
column9: whose chiming leads are faintly reminiscent of Autechre
column10: does a melodic sensibility begin to creep back into the heavily abstracted landscape.

column1: The three songs designated as ""Live"" aren't concert recordings
column2: but live-in-the-studio updates of tracks previously released on the Waldgeschichten EPs. That method—recording in real time
column3: both hands on the mixing desk—is Betke's enduring debt to dub. Those dub mechanics have a lot to do with the music's flexible rhythms and odd syncopations
column4: which contribute to the mercurial sense of flow: There are almost always more elements in play than you can track
column5: and whatever silvery filament you choose to focus on
column6: your attention will soon be hijacked by something else. Still
column7: there's nothing hectic about the listening experience; thanks to its relaxed pace and gently abstracted shapes
column8: Wald is every bit as contemplative as the forest walks that inspired it. It has an unfettered sense of motion that
column9: for an artist who was once
column10: by his own admission
column11: stuck in a rut
column12:
sounds like the sweetest kind of freedom.

For all the characters Nicole Schneit slips into on Parting Glances

column2: too

column4: she cracks the last word into two syllables

column7: she sings

column1: ""I’m a bad man for coming around/ But you invited me here
column2: Schneit proclaims on the enigmatic ""Frank""

column6:
but they're enough to hook you along for the ride.

Low will always be considered the quintessential slowcore band

column1: Admittedly
column2: Low’s last album The Invisible Way

column1: The opening track ""Gentle"" is a discomfiting funeral dirge that sets an unnerving mood early on. The instrumentation combines static-y bits of industrial percussion with rich

column5: ""gentle

column7: torture
column8: stable and silence""
column9: underscoring the song's fitful
column10: uneasy energy.

column1: That mood settles into the album

column3: luscious backing vocals and sparse

But there’s a real immediacy and liveliness to Alan Sparhawk's vocals and playing there that’s been missing from the group’s more recent records. His singing is so full and present on songs like ""Spanish Translation"" and ""Lies"" that it feels like a renewed bid for your undivided attention. And as much as they are able to make a conventional ""pop"" song then ""No End"" is it. For all intents and purposes it’s a pretty standard
column6: under three-minute
column7: get-in and get-out love song
column8: and based on the words alone

column1: Most bands don’t have either the stamina or the creative drive to make it up to and past the 20-year mark. The ones that do rarely find new things to say. As its enters its third decade making music
column2: Low has reached a comfortable but engaging stride creating music that consistently seems to be at odds with itself. Ones and Sixes is all at once beautiful
column3: ugly
column4: tense
column5: warm
column6: inviting and repellent. It’s an emotional and sonic juggling act where even the slightest bum-note would draw attention to itself. As always with Low

the beauty is all about the details.

From its cover

column2: ""Savage Coast""

column13: a relaxing cut suffused in dreamy chords
column14: it's the eerie

column16: even at their most roiled
column17: Grind's waters invite extended immersion. It's both one of the year's most sumptuous techno long-players and a masterful example of an unusual

Everything you need to know about Strawberry Switchblade
column2: the Scottish duo of Rose McDowall and Jill Bryson
column3: is right there in the name. The group
column4: who grew out of the late '70s Glasgow punk scene paired brightly-colored
column5: synth-driven new wave melodies with lyrics that often spoke of sadness and loss. That polarity between light and darkness became even more apparent in the group’s acrimonious dissolution in 1986

column7: but over the course of the duo's brief run
column8: it deepened
column9: moving beyond a childlike fascination with fairies into the realm of straight-up black magic (in one oft-repeated story

column1: Fortunately

column15: with brittle keyboards filling in for banjos and McDowall’s lonesome voice floating upward like campfire smoke. And while the title ""Crystal Nights"" takes on an ominous meaning in light of the allegations about McDowall’s hobbies

column2: and that’s mostly it—what makes Cake Knife so consistently endearing is how effortless it all sounds. That the only bum note is a chirpy cover of ""Don’t Fear the Reaper""

While a comically cartoonish bass and hyperactive synths jitter and pop around her

column10:
beckoning you inside.

column2: Joan Shelley discovers the ceiling of her evocative voice and dares to test it. The title track of the Kentucky singer-songwriter’s beguiling third album
column3: ""Over and Even"" is a gentle canter. Cymbals splash idly against a steady electric guitar
column4: and a banjo babbles in the distance
column5: as though it soon hopes to join Shelley’s fireside chat. The song itself
column6: though
column7: is an anxious number
column8: where images of domestic bliss disintegrate into feelings of longing. At first
column9: Shelley offers scenes of nesting bliss in her warm contralto—smoldering embers and full cups of coffee
column10: handwritten letters and thoughts of friends. But during every other verse
column11: her voice becomes a thin and nervous soprano
column12: as if she’s barely able to utter her own words. With the song's last words
column13: she admits to an abiding loneliness: ""I miss your scent and sight
column14: she sings
column15: her voice about to break. ""How can I write this?""

column1: Shelley weaves that feeling of vulnerability throughout the dozen songs of Over and Even
column2: an album that is alternately more confessional and prismatic than her previous output—and better for it. Shelley comes from an American folk background
column3: with a history singing songs endemic to her rural region. She records
column4: for instance
column5: with <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/features/the-out-door/9226-age-and-time/4/"" target=""_blank"">Maiden Radio
column6: a trio that works through standards with traditional instruments and commingled country voices. While her earliest solo records spoke to that pedigree
column7: last year’s Electric Ursa took bona fide compositional risks. ""Something Small""
column8: for instance
column9: grew like a post-rock phoenix
column10: while ""Remedios"" suggested a lullaby bound forever in hypnagogia. She embraced elliptical songwriting
column11: too
column12: webbing together evocative phrases to suggest a story more than share it. If Electric Ursa began with a folk core
column13: it ended with folk in fragments.

column1: On Over and Even
column2: however
column3: Shelley returns to her roots without fully retreating beneath them. Accompanied by fingerstyle guitarist and musical archivist Nathan Salsburg
column4: she favors a refined simplicity. ""My Only Trouble"" is a duet for strummed-and-picked acoustic guitars and her leaping-and-diving voice
column5: while ""Easy Now"" is a big-chord ballad
column6: where reassuring piano lines offer support behind lithe
column7: bluegrass-like runs. Even the more fully produced numbers
column8: like the organ-lined and electric ""Ariadne’s Gone"" or the Will Oldham-backed beauty ""Stay on My Shore""
column9: seem only to dress up simple structures
column10: to cast them in a full studio glow.

column1: The lyrics follow suit
column2: too
column3: with Shelley letting listeners in as she previously didn’t—hence
column4: the hint of unease that ends ""Over and Even"". ""My Only Trouble""
column5: for instance
column6: is sensual but bothered
column7: with confessions of intimacy chased by admissions of worry. Likewise
column8: ""Stay on My Shore"" betrays a human neediness that Shelley might have once clouded or cloaked. As Oldham chases her through the verses
column9: their musical push-and-pull reinforces the give-and-take of any good relationship or
column10: as they sing with their last shared breath
column11: ""the pages of our story."" That clear lifetime theme returns during the gentle ""Not Over by Half"". Meant both as a mournful dirge and an anthem of expectations
column12: the song positions a death as a reminder that everyone else still has the chance to live. ""Here on the mountain I’m thinking of you
column13: Shelley sings in one of her most vivid bits of writing yet. ""The birds are all singing
column14: screaming of youth."" She keeps the listener almost as close as the subject.

column1: This tension between plain old songs and structures and an interest in omitting details and accessorizing sounds enlivens Over and Even from start to finish. Shelley started with folk and then pushed away from it
column2: to Electric Ursa’s spectral and soft version of roots-rock. But now in the middle
column3: where the songs are direct but bent just so
column4:
she’s more compelling than she’s ever been.

Rick Ross's unlikely ascendance from one-note joke to kingpin was dazzling to watch
column2: but all commercial rap empires end
column3: and the sun seems to be setting on the once-untouchable Maybach Music Group. 2014's Mastermind debuted at #1
column4: but the hot air balloon of confidence that powered his best records felt deflated. Leading up to its release
column5: he got more press for his loathsomely tone-deaf justifications of ""U.O.E.N.O""'s rape lyric
column6: which cost him his sponsorship with Reebok
column7: than he was for radio hits. Besides ""Sanctified""
column8: an album cut featuring Big Sean and Kanye West
column9: little of Mastermind has lingered in the public consciousness. As for Hood Billionaire—the second album Ross released that year—did you recall that existed?

column1: Times are tough for rap supervillains
column2: it seems: even Rick Ross's nemesis 50 Cent is declaring bankruptcy. And Black Dollar
column3: Ross' first new project in a year
column4: feels slightly recalibrated to reflect the new hard times. A ""grounded"" Rick Ross would be unthinkable
column5: but he has scaled back
column6: mostly on the production
column7: which leaves behind the booming
column8: slow-moving productions of Lex Luger and his many imitators. ""Foreclosed on my past life
column9: he bellows on the opening track ""Foreclosures""
column10: an early highlight and the most compelling music he's made since his Rich Forever peak.

column1: The song offers the welcome surprise of hearing Ross treat money as something that eats away at relationships and breeds distrust
column2: instead of green rectangles he enjoys tossing out of helicopters. There are not-so-veiled references to contract issues with his own artists: ""That paper get funny when publishing's involved/ Mechanicals never matter
column3: 'cause that was your dog."" Rapping about music-industry arcana like ""mechanicals"" and publishing is not a surefire recipe for excitement
column4: but Ross' sonorous voice still breeds drama. His delivery is so convincing that the man who once air-lifted his mansion from Miami to Boca Raton sounds halfway-believable as a financial advisor: ""I never met an artist who fully recouped/ These the deals the deal dealers wanna deal to you!"" he raps through gritted teeth.

column1: That voice of his
column2: and the way he makes it leap and tremble with joy
column3: can momentarily make you believe anything. At his best
column4: Rick Ross isn't just a fantasy-fulfillment rapper
column5: or a maximalist hitmaker: He's a performer
column6: in the purest sense of that word. On ""We Gon Make It""
column7: his voice climbs in excitement
column8: and the gusto
column9: the control
column10: and thunderous conviction of his performance recalls the promos cut by the greatest WWF wrestlers. There is a trace of Dusty Rhodes in how he savors pauses
column11: pounces on ripe-sounding words
column12: sometimes at the expense of intelligibility. On ""Turn Ya Back""
column13: he spits every repetition of the word ""back"" like it's a mouthful of poison. ""Money and the Powder"" repurposes the chanted chorus from Scarface's classic ""Money and the Power""
column14: and by the time Ross is done with it
column15: the phrase has melted into simply ""money and the POWWW!""

column1: This energy has always been the electrifying current enlivening even his silliest lyrics—on ""Bill Gates""
column2: he reiterates his dearly held dream of a world with ""Wing Stops on every corner."" It is what allows him to somehow to diss ""Freeway"" Rick Ross—the very real gangster whose identity Ross co-opted—and 50 Cent in the same bar on ""Geechi Liberace"". There are dull
column3: rote spots on Black Dollar—""Money Dance"" retreats into a soft-focus world of bowties
column4: marble floors
column5: and cocktail-jazz pianos that is about as exciting as eavesdropping on senior executives. And the reduced ambitions also mean that there are no calling-card songs here
column6: no tarmac-sized beats or immediate chanted hooks. It's clear that Ross is regrouping. But the project serves as a reminder: This a good energy to have around
column7:
still.
