column1: A close listen to The RCA Victor and T-Neck Album Masters underscores how the Isley Brothers may have been reliable but they were never static. They were keenly aware of emerging trends—shamelessly exclaiming ""It's a Disco Night"" in 1979 but threading in hot analog synths á la Rick James on 1982's The Real Deal as they slowly drifted into a quiet storm—and listening to these albums back-to-back underscores progression
column2: not complacency. The presence of the outlier of 1959's Shout! emphasizes just how far the group travelled. Here
column3: the group—just a trio of Ronnie
column4: O'Kelly
column5: and Rudolph Isley—slipped exuberant R&B in between blues and Tin Pan Alley standards
column6: the kind of tunes acceptable to the supper club audiences that constituted a pop crossover in the late '50s.

column5: the Isley Brothers learned how to cannily blend their commercial aspirations with pure soul while at Motown
column6: a pivotal moment missing on this big box. Instead

column21: when the trio doubled the size of their lineup and found funk.

column1: 3 + 3 is the breakthrough
column2: the album where the bespangled bell-bottomed soul renegades of the '70s were unveiled—not coincidentally
column3: it's the first released on Epic—but it's a record where the fizzy ""That Lady"" sits next to a cover of James Taylor and the Isleys find a way to bring soul to Jonathan Edwards' ""Sunshine (Go Away Today)"" and Seals & Crofts' ""Summer Breeze""
column4: two of the most sensitive of the '70s SoCal soft sounds. More than anything
column5: this illustrates how the Isleys' phases overlapped: they found their groove thing but weren't quite ready to leave covers behind
column6: not when those covers were successful and broadened the audience. They needed the security of one other hit—1974's Live It Up
column7: whose title track went to four R&B while a cover of a Todd Rundgren ballad sat on its second side—before they cut their first album of all originals
column8: 1975's The Heat Is On. With its ""Fight the Power""—an anthem of defiance that seemed more political than its lyrics actually were; it was a rebellion that jumped demographics—they had their biggest-ever crossover hit and it's one firmly grounded in funk: its attitude and melody hooked in a larger audience.

column1: The Heat Is On proved to be the apex of the Isley Brothers' chart success
column2: at least as far as the crossover pop audience was concerned. Hit albums still followed—1976's Harvest for the World
column3: 1977's Go for Your Guns
column4: and 1978's Showdown all went platinum or better
column5: all accompanied by major R&B hits—but the Isley Brothers were now firmly an R&B act
column6: one who were still stars but stars for a specific demographic. Retroactively
column7: these records do have a crossover appeal
column8: due in no small part to their lasting legacy within the R&B demographic
column9: a legacy echoed through samples that underpinned crossover hip-hop hits of the '90s. After Showdown
column10: however
column11: the last run of Isley records on T-Neck—1979's Winner Takes All
column12: 1980's Go All the Way
column13: 1981's Grand Slam and Inside You
column14: 1982's The Real Deal
column15: 1983's Between the Sheets—are records divided between smooth quiet storm and cloistered disco fallout
column16: records that substitute adventure for calculation. By most measures
column17: these albums aren't as strong as what came before
column18: particularly the hot streak of the mid-'70s
column19: but when listened to in succession
column20: they're not drastic disappointments; they underscore the fleet-footedness of the Isley Brothers
column21: how they followed fashion and wound up reflecting their times.

column1: This eager elasticity is why Eric Weisbard uses the Isley Brothers as his R&B case study in his revelatory book Top 40 Democracy: The Rival Mainstreams of American Music. Weisbard argues that the Isleys were crowd-pleasing showmen from the start
column2: a group keenly aware that a broader appeal meant steady work
column3: so they were happy to go wherever their audience went
column4: no matter what sound took them there. Through its sheer variety
column5: The RCA Victor & T-Neck Album Masters does provide supporting evidence for this thesis but the wonderful thing about the box is how the Isley Brothers never sound crass or mercenary as they hop from church-inflected R&B to funk to quiet storm. The Isley Brothers never abandoned their identity as they rolled with the changes
column6: finding sly ways to make fads seem like divine inspiration. If they never did manage to deliver an outright classic album—3 + 3 and The Heat Is On come very
column7: very close—this box suggests using this metric as a yardstick for measuring greatness is a fallacy. What the Isley Brothers achieved can't be contained in a single album nor can it be adequately summarized in a hits collection. They seized all the tumult
column8: all the excitement
column9: all of the sounds of their time and turned it into enduring commercial art whose endurance and depth is best appreciated in a set like this
column10:
where the actual records can be heard in their entirety.

column1: A close listen to The RCA Victor and T-Neck Album Masters underscores how the Isley Brothers may have been reliable but they were never static. They were keenly aware of emerging trends—shamelessly exclaiming ""It's a Disco Night"" in 1979 but threading in hot analog synths á la Rick James on 1982's The Real Deal as they slowly drifted into a quiet storm—and listening to these albums back-to-back underscores progression
column2: not complacency. The presence of the outlier of 1959's Shout! emphasizes just how far the group travelled. Here
column3: the group—just a trio of Ronnie
column4: O'Kelly
column5: and Rudolph Isley—slipped exuberant R&B in between blues and Tin Pan Alley standards
column6: the kind of tunes acceptable to the supper club audiences that constituted a pop crossover in the late '50s.

column1: This was standard practice in 1959 because kids didn't buy long-players
column2: adults did
column3: yet this divide between respectable material and rip-roaring rockers like their original ""Respectable"" gives Shout! a slight musty air. The Isleys traded the standards for the twist while at United Artists in the early '60s
column4: a swap that emphasized their youth but still carried traces of stiffness due to UA and the Isleys chasing dance crazes. Like so many artists
column5: the Isley Brothers learned how to cannily blend their commercial aspirations with pure soul while at Motown
column6: a pivotal moment missing on this big box. Instead
column7: this set has their fledgling mid-'60s singles for their own T-Neck
column8: 45s heard on the compilation In the Beginning. Released in 1971—the date explains why Jimi Hendrix
column9: the trio's guitarist in 1964 and 1965
column10: looms over the band itself on the cover art—In the Beginning crackles with the rumblings of the intense grit of funk
column11: goosed along by Jimi's proto-psychedelic guitar
column12: music that points the way toward T-Neck Isley Brothers more than Motown's This Old Heart of Mine. Ernie Isley picked up the thread Hendrix lay hanging

column14: a wild
column15: loose-limbed groove that functioned as the Isleys' repudiation of Motown and embrace of Sly and the Family Stone funk.

column5: all giving them their biggest hit to date. Maintaining momentum proved tricky

column9: so the group caught the rays of the hippie sunset in the early '70s

column14: and Marvin all posed like Earth-minded singer/songwriters on its burnished cover. Givin' It Back coincided with the rise of album-oriented radio and
column15: as there was now an audience consuming albums as albums
column16: the Isleys began structuring their long-players as immersive experiences. A flirtation with Philly Soul followed in 1972—<b><i>Brother

column19: but it's an anomaly on a record where the second side contains just two songs
column20: one of which is a 10-minute workout on Carole King's ""It's Too Late""—and then came the 3 + 3 makeover
column21: when the trio doubled the size of their lineup and found funk.

column1: 3 + 3 is the breakthrough
column2: the album where the bespangled bell-bottomed soul renegades of the '70s were unveiled—not coincidentally
column3: it's the first released on Epic—but it's a record where the fizzy ""That Lady"" sits next to a cover of James Taylor and the Isleys find a way to bring soul to Jonathan Edwards' ""Sunshine (Go Away Today)"" and Seals & Crofts' ""Summer Breeze""
column4: two of the most sensitive of the '70s SoCal soft sounds. More than anything
column5: this illustrates how the Isleys' phases overlapped: they found their groove thing but weren't quite ready to leave covers behind
column6: not when those covers were successful and broadened the audience. They needed the security of one other hit—1974's Live It Up
column7: whose title track went to four R&B while a cover of a Todd Rundgren ballad sat on its second side—before they cut their first album of all originals
column8: 1975's The Heat Is On. With its ""Fight the Power""—an anthem of defiance that seemed more political than its lyrics actually were; it was a rebellion that jumped demographics—they had their biggest-ever crossover hit and it's one firmly grounded in funk: its attitude and melody hooked in a larger audience.

column1: The Heat Is On proved to be the apex of the Isley Brothers' chart success
column2: at least as far as the crossover pop audience was concerned. Hit albums still followed—1976's Harvest for the World
column3: 1977's Go for Your Guns
column4: and 1978's Showdown all went platinum or better
column5: all accompanied by major R&B hits—but the Isley Brothers were now firmly an R&B act
column6: one who were still stars but stars for a specific demographic. Retroactively
column7: these records do have a crossover appeal
column8: due in no small part to their lasting legacy within the R&B demographic
column9: a legacy echoed through samples that underpinned crossover hip-hop hits of the '90s. After Showdown
column10: however
column11: the last run of Isley records on T-Neck—1979's Winner Takes All
column12: 1980's Go All the Way
column13: 1981's Grand Slam and Inside You
column14: 1982's The Real Deal
column15: 1983's Between the Sheets—are records divided between smooth quiet storm and cloistered disco fallout
column16: records that substitute adventure for calculation. By most measures
column17: these albums aren't as strong as what came before
column18: particularly the hot streak of the mid-'70s
column19: but when listened to in succession
column20: they're not drastic disappointments; they underscore the fleet-footedness of the Isley Brothers
column21: how they followed fashion and wound up reflecting their times.

column1: This eager elasticity is why Eric Weisbard uses the Isley Brothers as his R&B case study in his revelatory book Top 40 Democracy: The Rival Mainstreams of American Music. Weisbard argues that the Isleys were crowd-pleasing showmen from the start
column2: a group keenly aware that a broader appeal meant steady work
column3: so they were happy to go wherever their audience went
column4: no matter what sound took them there. Through its sheer variety
column5: The RCA Victor & T-Neck Album Masters does provide supporting evidence for this thesis but the wonderful thing about the box is how the Isley Brothers never sound crass or mercenary as they hop from church-inflected R&B to funk to quiet storm. The Isley Brothers never abandoned their identity as they rolled with the changes
column6: finding sly ways to make fads seem like divine inspiration. If they never did manage to deliver an outright classic album—3 + 3 and The Heat Is On come very
column7: very close—this box suggests using this metric as a yardstick for measuring greatness is a fallacy. What the Isley Brothers achieved can't be contained in a single album nor can it be adequately summarized in a hits collection. They seized all the tumult
column8: all the excitement
column9: all of the sounds of their time and turned it into enduring commercial art whose endurance and depth is best appreciated in a set like this
column10:
where the actual records can be heard in their entirety.

column7: lured by the music of the Delta
column8: Bayou
column9: and Appalachia. He played gorgeous
column10: doleful folk rock in Megafaun
column11: complemented the cohorts of Matthew E. White and Hiss Golden Messenger
column12: acted as bandleader for the Blind Boys of Alabama
column13: and produced for Indigo Girls’ Amy Ray. In 2011 he released Hungry Mother Blues
column14: a low-key solo instrumental record that chased Ry Cooder and John Fahey. Southland Mission is a more full-bodied commitment.
column15: serif; font-size: 15px; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: 24px; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; word-spacing: 0px; background-color: #ffffff;"">Whether simple banjo fare
column16: outlaw stompers
column17: or reeling strut
column18: each one of Cook’s modes is an easy and infectious exertion. And like any good missionary
column19: Cook’s fervor is infectious.

column1: Although Southland Mission is studiously steeped in tradition
column2: it wears it lightly. Recorded in the Blue Ridge Mountains
column3: the warmth of the Durham
column4: N.C. community behind the record (the likes of Matt McCaughan
column5: Mountain Man’s Amelia Meath) beams through as its own kind of congregation
column6: though there’s occasionally a homespun gospel duo here
column7: too
column8: in the golden tones of Sophie Blak and Jeanne Jolly. They’re crucial to the record’s two-part centerpiece: chastising Cook for procrastinating on ""Sitting on a Fence Too Long"" before coming to ""Lowly Road""
column9: a bluesy spiritual reckoning
column10: which ends with a call-and-response as the duo welcome him home. Like Hiss Golden Messenger’s Lateness of Dancers
column11: Southland Mission handles doubt with the possibility of redemption
column12: reinforced by the record’s persistent
column13: joyous uplift.

column1: Cook navigates the extremes of the squeezed middle class on Southland Mission
column2: staring down what it looks like to fight or flee. ""1922"" is a cover of a Charlie Parr song about the Piedmont musician’s parents’ Depression-era experiences
column3: where ""ain’t it sweet"" becomes ""ain’t that the way it is."" Fed up of giving all his money to the government
column4: a boy leaves his dead end job
column5: gets beat up in a new town
column6: and
column7: dead broke
column8: has no choice but to go back home: ""Times are hard here and I can’t roam/ But I ain’t got nothing more."" Every verse ends with Cook addressing some ""boys
column9: like it’s a tale of bar stool bravado
column10: though choice is never treated as an act of heroism on Southland Mission. ""Nothing sacred
column11: nothing saved/ Get your ass on the morning train or get the hell out the way
column12: he sings on ""Great Tide""
column13: an empathetic epic that swings between tender moments and brisk
column14: reeling jubilation.

column1: Ultimately
column2: choosing to stay and stoke life’s intimacies wins out over fleeing. ""Anybody Else""
column3: a duet with Frazey Ford
column4: sees Cook resisting easy reassurances in favor of a deep and nourishing love. ""Gone"" is a parable about how you might as well give it all you’ve got when you can’t take anything with you. To have is not necessarily to hold
column5: and when possession is transient
column6:
belonging is all you have. Southland Mission lights up tradition with rare and overt joy and palpable gratitude. It’s an open invitation from a man who’s found home. Say yes.

'Miscreant']|2015-09-11 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:06:31.187503|"

For those of us queer music lovers who came of age in the 1990s seeing Pansy Division—one of the few visible gay punk bands of that era—opening for Green Day on 1994’s Dookie tour was a kind of surreal
column3: watershed moment. Though it seemed crazy at the time
column4: it actually wasn’t the world’s most unusual pairing—both bands had at one point shared a label and each made pop punk songs that were equal parts snotty and catchy—but Pansy Division were an overtly and aggressively gay band with a cult following
column5: while Green Day were riding high on their mainstream major label breakthrough. Even though Green Day's audience seemed flummoxed by Pansy Division—I remember people around me asking ‘Are they serious?’—the fact that it was happening at all felt pretty revolutionary. Indie rock was still mostly the unwelcoming domain of straight white dudes. With the occasional exception of seeing Pansy Division
column6: God Is My Co-Pilot
column7: or the mighty Team Dresch
column8: being an openly queer person at a mainstream rock show still felt like an open invitation to getting your ass kicked.

column1: It’s hard not to think about Pansy Division when listening to PWR BTTM—the gloriously queer garage punk duo of guitarist Ben Hopkins and drummer Liv Bruce. Formed after the two met at Bard College in upstate New York
column2: queer-identified PWR BTTM make very loud and occasionally very messy music without ever adopting some kind of faux masculine posturing. In fact
column3: that band pretty much eviscerates said posturing with their live sets
column4: in which the two loudly rip through their arsenal of pop-punk missives while flaunting a very rudimentary kind of drag—thrifted dresses
column5: globs of glitter
column6: and kabuki smears of makeup. What saves the whole enterprise from just being a well-played bit of cultural commentary is PWR BTTM's music—they write really catchy songs and they play the shit out of them.

column1: The eleven tracks on Ugly Cherries
column2: PWR BTTM’s full-length debut
column3: mostly vacillate between two-minute rave-ups about boys (""I Wanna Boi""
column4: ""All the Boys"") and two-minute ruminations on the lack thereof (""West Texas""
column5: ""C U Around""). On ""I Wanna Boi"" Bruce recites a list of needs for potential partners (""I want a boy who thinks it’s sexy when my lipstick bleeds/ I want a boy who can go all night without stopping/ I want a boy knows exactly what he needs"") against a stomping guitar/drum track that wouldn’t sound out of place on an early White Stripes record. He even goes as far as to share his email address just in case any qualified applicants want to get in touch. The song
column6: like much of the rest of Ugly Cherries
column7: is certainly funny
column8: but it isn’t a joke.

column1: In fact
column2: the record is hearteningly earnest. The band’s best songs are about articulating the goofy
column3: anything-goes joy of being young and open
column4: quite literally
column5: to anything. And while the basic guitar/drum setup doesn’t allow for much subtlety
column6: Hopkins and Bruce manage to wring impressively dynamic tunes out of the most basic power riffing. ""We can do our makeup in the parking lot/ We can get so famous that we both get shot
column7: Bruce sings on ""Dairy Queen"" as the song morphs into a loud/quiet/LOUD jam. On ""1994""—a track that
column8: not coincidentally
column9: sounds like it could have been recorded in 1994—Hopkins sings that ""These days it pays to be so strange and I’m like nothing"" before the song cracks open into a series of falsetto’d ""ooohs
column10: handclaps
column11: and arena-size guitar shreds.

column1: And though it all seems simple and sweet enough at first
column2: Ugly Cherries’ real strength lies in the way it addresses the fears and foibles of the young and queer-identified
column3: both for better and for worse. While the glee expressed on the record feels like a middle finger aimed directly at the hetero establishment
column4: there is an endearing vulnerability at work as well—an understanding that the world is not always your friend. On ""Serving Goffman"" the duo celebrate the merits of being unafraid to make a fool of oneself in the name of making art and finding love
column5: while acknowledging that it comes at a cost. ""I held my breath in a suit and a tie because I didn’t know I could fight back
column6: sings Bruce
column7: ""I wanna put the whole world in drag but I’m starting to realize it’s already like that."" Elsewhere he notes that ""I found out people aren’t that mean but it still feels like they're laughing at me/ When they're just saying hello."" The world has certainly changed
column8: but there is still always a price to be paid for simply being yourself.  Their songs aren’t just a prolonged wink and a nod
column9: but rather complicated statements on what it means to be young and queer and confused and somehow othered.

column1: ""Why are you so handsome
column2: gaymazing
column3: and nice?"" asks Hopkins of a lover on the record’s closing track. It’s the kind of question that might have been impossible to ask in a non-ironic way back in 1994 and it’s exactly the kind of thing that makes Ugly Cherries such a special listen. The record is not only catchy as all hell
column4: but it’s also sweet and openhearted and not one bit cynical. It’s a queer record to be sure
column5: but mostly it’s just a really fun rock record—and one would hope that at this point in time
column6:
those two things shouldn’t be mutually exclusive.

For a band like FIDLAR
column2: the idea of artistic growth seems kind of oxymoronic

column5: chillaxed last few strummed seconds of ""Punks""
column6: the second track from their sophomore LP Too
column7: frontman Zac Carper muses
column8: ""Relationships are fucking wack/ They make me want to smoke crack/ And girlfriend or boyfriend can suck my dick/ Masturbate
column9: let's make it quick."" It's a perfect encapsulation of FIDLAR's outlook (the band name is an acronym for Fuck It
column10: Dog
column11: Life's A Risk)
column12: one that they already cemented on their enjoyably party-hardy self-titled debut
column13: a hormonal love letter to getting fucked up and fucking up. And while a title like Too might lead you to believe that FIDLAR are wisely committed to not fixing what isn't broke— there are more scuzzy guitars and songs about bad medicine
column14: bad habits
column15: and stupid decisions (all of which happen to be song titles)— it seems to have bigger things in mind for itself.

column1: FIDLAR were initially met with the obvious-but-apt comparison to kindred West Coast spirits Wavves
column2: and Too seems to greatly admire Nathan Williams' transition from disaffected skate rat to pop-punk Beach King. It's a crisper

column4: FIDLAR have made a concerted effort to clean up

column6: an incarnation that likely won't scare away too many fans as it aims to convert new ones. Gone is the feral scrap and the forays into sunburnt surfabilly
column7: replaced by a more MTVU-friendly approach that only feels ""grown-up"" in the sense that it's graduated from 40s in the high-school parking lot to Smirnoff in the frat house basement.

column1: It's too bad Too doesn't boast more numbers like highlight ""West Coast""
column2: a song about getting wasted on the road. But FIDLAR aim a little lower
column3: offering dated-sounding blues stompers (""Punks"")
column4: Black Lips-lite junkie laments (""Overdose"")
column5: interminably bratty nose-thumbing (""Sober"")
column6: questionable arena rock (""Bad Habits"") and a weird little detour into the British Invasion (""Why Generation""
column7: which is hopefully supposed to be taken as tongue-in-cheek). The hooks feel forced this time

column1: But it's undeniable that Too comes from a good place. Most of the record revolves around Carper's road to sobriety
column2: and the many inherent pitfalls and setbacks faced along the way. ""I figured out when I got sober that life just sucks when you get older
column3: he sings on ""Sober""
column4: and it's a brief but affecting peek inside the head of a guy on the other side of addiction and staring down his thirties. A song like ""Leave Me Alone"" carries more weight when you realize it's about Carper's intervention
column5: but too often
column6: the songs break down into digestible little nuggets of stoner wisdom. So while Too is at times brave
column7:
that doesn't necessarily make it compelling.

Prince's hype-man instincts defy categorization every bit as much as his vocal and instrumental talents beggar description. Though he's fallen off since the 1980s—who
column3: in his shoes
column4: wouldn't?—it's this artist's strange and frequent urge to over-promise that helps keep everyone harping on Sign 'O' the Times as his apogee. Yet here we are again. An album title like HITNRUN Phase One promises a fair amount
column5: not least the possibility of a concept worth serializing. And that's before the album is announced by its creators as being ""experimental"" in construction. Though after stripping away the promotional language from this streaming-only platter
column6: exclusive to Jay Z's Tidal service (for now)
column7: one finds something far less earth-shaking: a casual
column8: slightly-weirder-than-usual release with one very good R&B song (that's reportedly been kicking around in his vault for a while)
column9: stranded in the album's penultimate slot.

column1: To get to that very good song—at least in the manner that Prince and his young co-composer
column2: producer
column3: and mixer Joshua Welton intend—you'll plug through a half-hour sequence that contains a throwaway intro
column4: a trio of putative party-starters cluttered with the confetti of modern-dancefloor production-debris
column5: two reworked (as opposed to improved) songs from 2014's superior Art Official Age
column6: and a tweaked version of the ""Fallinlove2nite"" standalone single that failed to make that prior album. (Ditching Zooey Deschanel's backing vocals doesn't much elevate that breezy tune's mild charm.)

column1: Among the remains
column2: ""Hardrocklover"" would seem to be an opportunity for one of pop's most reliably sensuous guitarists to make up ground. But the song seems strangely subdued and bored with itself. While the lyrics (""Turn my guitar up so I can make this woman scream"") suggest that the inevitable appearance of guitar-heroism will be climactic
column3: Prince's unfurling of his distorto-wail cape feels rote. The loopy-but-hard-hitting funk of ""X's Face"" is initially promising
column4: though it too is thin on development. Elsewhere
column5: the (mostly) instrumental ""Mr. Nelson"" riffs with a modicum of inspiration on remnants from Art Official Age standout ""Clouds"".

column1: On a first listen
column2: you might suspect that the album's opening sequence of not-disastrous (but not-terribly-memorable) EDM-influenced jams is going to be the focus of HITNRUN Phase One. Though this
column3: too
column4: is part of a formula: compare Prince's almost-rap flow on ""Shut This Down"" to that of 1992's ""My Name Is Prince""
column5: and it's easy to see that the artist has a template for approaching ascendant pop trends. There are stray
column6: tasty touches in this opening salvo—a brief electric-bass clinic in ""Shut This Down""
column7: the integration of saxophone
column8: rhythm guitar
column9: and digitally programmed curlicues in the last minute of ""Like a Mack""—but experimental this ain't. Not for the artist who wrote and recorded ""Crystal Ball""
column10: anyway. (By point of comparison: Prince has also made newly available some truly chancy and obscure work from the late 1990s—like the extended paranoid-freakout ""The War"" and the mostly-acoustic album The Truth—on Tidal.)

column1: Disappointments and missed opportunities aside
column2: it's still great to have an official
column3: Prince-sung version of ""1000 X's & O's"" (an old composition once <a href=""http://www.princevault.com/index.php/A_1
column4: 000_Hugs_And_Kisses"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">intended for Rosie Gaines). When Prince sings in an environment unmolested by contemporary cliche
column5: he gives us more than at any other point on HITNRUN Phase One—including that iconic
column6: multi-tracked one-man choir
column7: in addition to lyrics that
column8: while they might not be much on the page
column9: snap with a seductive pull when placed in his mouth (""Every drop of sweat on your brow/ Is well-earned/ So you best believe""). Even if
column10: this time around
column11: you can forget the familiar discographical parlor game of comparing each new Prince record to earlier triumphs—this one isn't his best album in the last twelve months
column12:
let alone years—songs and performances like that one show why it remains unwise to count him out.

Repentless
column2: the 12th album from the thrash metal institution Slayer
column3: comes at the most fraught time in the band's career. Founding guitarist and songwriter Jeff Hanneman's passing in 2013 from cirrhosis of the liver looms large; it's impossible to overstate the impact he had on the group. His hardcore influences
column4: and the way these influences warped the group's early NWOBHM style
column5: formed the more extreme wing of thrash that would later inform death and black metal. Hanneman's death is Slayer's greatest concern
column6: but it's far from the only one. Founding drummer Dave Lombardo quit in 2013 allegedly over money concerns
column7: and Paul Bostaph
column8: who played on Slayer's '90s records
column9: returned to replace him. Bostaph is no slouch
column10: but Lombardo is a once-in-a-lifetime talent
column11: whose ferocity set the standard for metal drumming as a whole. The two remaining members
column12: bassist/vocalist Tom Araya and guitarist Kerry King
column13: also seem to be somewhat at odds with the future of the band. King's never short of bluster and says Slayer will soldier on; Araya is a little more apprehensive. How much either's letting on is hard to determine
column14: but there's definitely a rift.

column1: There's also a clear waning in popularity. Slayer headlined this year's Mayhem Fest
column2: which was plagued by attendance problems. It was depressing to see a legendary band barely filling amphitheaters and having to downgrade the venue in San Antonio
column3: one of the most solidly metal cities in the States. King was also open with his disdain for the fest's lineup
column4: and his online spats with tour organizer Kevin Lyman kept the metal news site Blabbermouth going this summer. And Repentless is not Slayer's first album to be released on September 11—God Hates Us All came out the day of the attacks. In the case of God
column5: it was an unfortunate but morbidly appropriate coincidence; with Repentless
column6: it seems calculated to appeal to the basest shock values of metalheads. So
column7: yes
column8: it's easy to be cynical about a new Slayer record.

column1: Despite all of this
column2: Repentless is solid—far from a classic
column3: but the best possible outcome. King and Araya may be drawing from the same well as they always have
column4: but no one knows how to make a Slayer song like they do. Three decades on from Hell Awaits
column5: ""Delusions of Saviour"" shows they still know how to create a lurching intro
column6: minus Satan yelling ""WELCOME BACK!"" It leans heavy on the wah
column7: but King doesn't overdose on it like Kirk Hammett would. The title track and ""Take Control"" display steadfast worship to their own speed; the product is quality
column8: and Repentless does benefit from focusing on that speed Hanneman fostered. But ""When the Stillness Comes"" recalls ""Spill the Blood"" from South of Heaven and ""Dead Skin Mask"" from Seasons in the Abyss
column9: two of Slayer's slower classics. Araya works within his vocal limitations to complement King's rhythms to honor Slayer's slower side without straining or parodying himself. Sticking close to the Slayer playbook was probably the most sensical move—King and Araya have every chance to overindulge or lose the plot but don't. Most songs on Repentless will remind you of a specific track from Slayer's past
column10: and there's enough diversity within their own style.

column1: Losing two key members will irreversibly change dynamics
column2: and Repentless isn't immune. Exodus' Gary Holt
column3: Slayer's live guitarist since 2011
column4: contributes solos
column5: but King played almost all of the guitar here. There isn't the chaotic back-and-forth that Hanneman and King wrestled with in their prime. In fact
column6: the solos are oddly conservative by Slayer standards. They fit
column7: but Hanneman's loose touch is noticeably missing. King is essentially playing off himself—he can't be the more metallic foil to Hanneman's punk ear. Granted
column8: he does wrangle a convincing homage to Hanneman's punkiness in ""Atrocity Vendor"". It's oddly a more fitting tribute than ""Piano Wire""
column9: which Hanneman had a hand in writing. ""You Against You"" is another punky track that could have been slipped in Undisputed Attitude
column10: and that it comes right after ""Wire"" and ""Atrocity"" suggests that Slayer made a little Hanneman suite in his honor.

column1: Bostaph is a dependable presence
column2: which is both a compliment and a slight. ""Vices"" and ""Take Control"" could have benefitted a little bit from Lombardo's intensity on the double bass. Still
column3: he came into probably the toughest assignment of his career and knocked it out. Bostaph's return also brought back some of the more groove metal tendencies that Slayer adopted in the '90s
column4: most evident in ""Implode"". ""Implode"" worked as a one-off single before it was known it was goning to be on the album
column5: but it doesn't mesh with Repentless as a whole. It even brings down the second half of the record
column6: which doesn't have a ""Stillness"" to compensate. For a band that made a genre-defining album that doesn't break 30 minutes (Reign in Blood)
column7: Slayer have lost a bit of their editing touch.

column1: Will they continue after this record? If they do
column2: and they're likely to milk at the very least a couple tours
column3: Repentless doesn't spell their end. If they hang it up
column4: at least they didn't end their career on an embarrassing note. Slayer
column5: even with their recent turmoil
column6: have had good fortune compared to their other peers in the Big Four. Their decline is more gradual
column7: the kind that merely comes with age; they never fell off like Metallica and Megadeth did. They've managed to produce one good record without two irreplaceable members; even so
column8:
Repentless doesn't quite answer if they've still got it for the long haul.

South African singer-songwriter Yannick Ilunga
column2: aka Petite Noir
column3: appeared on the Solange Knowles-curated Saint Heron compilation
column4: but even with the alt-R&B scene growing broader as it grows larger
column5: he still doesn’t quite fit in. There are elements of dance music
column6: rap
column7: and rock scattered throughout his debut album
column8: La Vie Est Belle / Life Is Beautiful
column9: but none of those labels quite describe his sound. And while Ilunga frequently incorporates elements of his half-Congolese
column10: half-Angolan ancestry
column11: his music shouldn’t be shoved off into that condescending
column12: colonialist hangover
column13: ""world music."" ""Psychedelically-tinged baroque contemporary African pop with heavy goth undertones"" is a mouthful
column14: so ""noirwave
column15: a descriptor coined by Ilunga himself
column16: works as well as anything.

column1: Ilunga introduces us to his sound with a literal fanfare. Following an impressionistic
column2: semi-abstract intro that sets up Ilunga’s predilections for complex rhythms and sensual modulated textures
column3: La Vie Est Belle explodes with the chorus to his first single
column4: ""Best""
column5: which tops an achingly cathartic post-punk hook with an off-kilter brass arrangement that comes in from out of nowhere to flip the song’s buttoned-up synthpop mood on its head. The horns are jarring
column6: bracing
column7: and just dissonant enough to add a manic edge to the song. They sound like maybe they were inspired by Ennio Morricone
column8: or maybe by Neutral Milk Hotel
column9: or maybe by any number of brass bands you can find playing on streets from New Orleans to Kinshasa.

column1: For listeners of a certain persuasion
column2: trying to trace La Vie Est Belle’s sounds back to their influences can be a distractingly entertaining way to appreciate the record
column3: especially when the trail gets as intriguingly ambiguous as that horn part. (Such as Ilunga’s supple
column4: swooningly expressive baritone
column5: which can sound a little like Dave Gahan and a little like David Bowie’s more lucid moments of the '80s.) It’s a tough game to keep up
column6: though. All those different pieces come at you at a rapid pace
column7: and it’s hard to keep an eye on the individual threads when Ilunga keeps pulling your attention back out to the entire tapestry.

column1: In a pop music landscape where eclecticism has become the status quo
column2: Ilunga’s not only pulling from a broader range of sounds than all but a few other players in the game
column3: he’s able to synthesize them into a seamless sonic entity that stands entirely away from the pack. La Vie Est Belle is a gorgeous
column4: complex trip
column5: not just aesthetically but emotionally. By turns
column6: it’s abysmally abject
column7: bravely hopeful
column8: unguarded
column9: canny
column10: sexy
column11: and profound—the kind of richly
column12: messily variegated album that only comes around a few times a year. Yannick Ilunga feels like pop music's future—borderless but deeply rooted
column13:
challenging but pleasurable— and La Vie is strong enough to have earned Ilunga the right to call his revolution whatever he wants.

Michael Benjamin Lerner spent two years learning about vintage synthesizers and forgetting about guitars and drums
column2: but the resulting Ad Infinitum sounds surprisingly like classic Telekinesis. Lerner's flirtation with synths and machinery began on his 2013 album Dormarion
column3: hinting that that he might someday trade indie pop for synthpop. As far back as his 2009 debut
column4: he pled for the attending physicians of ""Calling All Doctors"" to ""replace my heart with a machine."" With Ad Infinitum
column5: the operation is complete.

column1: Detailing his transformation in a piece for Medium
column2: he says he spent much of the past two years amassing and learning how to use a collection of vintage synths
column3: as well as hook them up with newer technology to make new music. ""This proved to be incredibly time-consuming and
column4: at times
column5: a ridiculously difficult task
column6: "" he writes.

column1: All of that ridiculous difficulty was time well spent: he has made some beautifully textured music with moods that recall the original '80s heyday of synthpop. ""Edgewood"" sounds like an outtake from Speak & Spell and the instrumental ""Ad Infinitum
column2: Pt. 1"" recalls the grandeur and evocative melodrama of the first side of Disintegration.

column1: Lerner also produced the album—a first for him—with some assistance from Eric Elbogen of Say Hi. But the problem with taking on so many new responsibilities is that something's got to give. In this case
column2: it's the lyrics. They're often vague and seem like they were the final pesky pieces that he fit into the process. He utters the word ""forget"" in more than half of the songs with lyrics
column3: and ""future"" on three separate occasions. Though Lerner has learned well how to make these sounds
column4: he doesn't elevate the form enough.

column1: ""Sleep In""
column2: with its light hip-hop beat and elfin ba-ba-ba-ba-ing is Ad Infinitum's most innovative track. Lerner gets in his own way on this song though
column3: when he employs an actual Speak & Spell machine. Whether it's a nod to the aforementioned Depeche Mode debut or not
column4: it feels forced. (Though it doesn't induce as much of an eye roll as Limp Bizkit's Speak & Spell experimentation
column5: it's not quite as cool as what Robyn and Röyksopp do with the machine.)

column1: Despite all of this
column2: the songs still sound very much like Telekinesis. Lerner's songwriting is direct and even with all of this gadgetry he has a knack for a simple
column3: effective melody. The harmony on ""Farmers Road"" is locked in tightly
column4: and ""Ad Infinitum
column5: Pt. 2"" feels like it's threatening to break into ""Shining Star"" in the chorus. The tunes are sturdy
column6: and depending on how ambitious Lerner is with this tour
column7: he could easily put any of these songs into his comfortable power trio arrangement. He could even do them on an acoustic guitar
column8: as he is wont to do.

column1: Lerner has reportedly said that he started collecting vintage synthesizers because he felt like he had already gotten all of the songs out of the guitar that he could. The songs he summons from the synths offer proof that there were more songs left in him
column2: but he's still digging in the same mine. Ad Infinitum might be the sound of an artist challenging himself
column3:
but it's not the sound of an artist challenging his listeners.

column2: where the pair improvised on stage together. Video footage of the events show the men bathed in stark white light

column9:
where they either prick the attention or provide a soundtrack to other things going on. This just drifts along in its immaculately chiseled way.

column2: Beirut singer and songwriter Zach Condon has shed some light on the backstory behind the odd

column1: It would be easy to assume that reinvention was foremost on Condon's mind. After all

column1: Unlike this formative work

column3: more functional quality that is worlds away from his former brass chorale leviathans. column4: and all of the later pop music that bent it out of shape.

column3: simplistic grooves is modest

column8: exactly

column1: The answer would seem to be mood

column3: however

column5: not being formalized and committed to wax. On midtempo flotsam like ""Pacheco""

column8: with their syncopated guitar rhythms.

column1: No No No may sound ineffectual after a cursory listen

column3: with its borderline West Side Story-quoting chorus

column6: and doesn't demonstrate Condon searching for something else to fill that void. While it definitely unifies itself around and gains some affective power from sounding unfinished
column7:
it still sounds it.

If singer Adrian Toubro had something important to say on Lower's debut EP Walk on Heads

column10: he broods

Farao
column2: aka Norwegian multi-instrumentalist

column4: and songwriter Kari Jahnsen

column1: Like her countrywoman Jenny Hval
column2: Jahnsen's work defies categorization and commodification at every turn. It's not in the least bit easy to create music that sounds truly like you and nobody else
column3: but Jahnsen manages to do so. The instrumentation on Till It's All Forgotten is rich—electronics
column4: horns
column5: synth strings
column6: piano
column7: a standard guitar-based rock band
column8: vocal manipulation—and though all that layering and texture could feel heavy and cluttered
column9: it rarely does. Jahnsen has an ear for structure
column10: always pulling when the song could have pushed
column11: turning right when it could have turned left
column12: never relying on ABABC to get her through. Opener and title track ""TIAF"" is a perfect example—it's a lush

column14: off-time percussion that jars the song out of complacency.

column1: The lyrical themes on Till It's All Forgotten always circle back to the gaps in human communication and the desire that grows in those damp
column2: mossy spaces left open between us because we're too scared of our own shadows to look into them. It's an album about slippage

column5: which was released as a single with an unsettling and intimate video depicting the solitary and intense relationship between two teenage girls as they explore a landscape abandoned by adults

column8: something all of us can relate to but few of us would brag about.

column1: It's this commitment to quotidian territory  that makes Till It's All Forgotten so engaging. The delicate ""Hunter"" could read as a love song but is instead about the process of dehumanizing another. The haunting ""Feel"" could be simply about sexuality but is instead about the desire for deep connection with someone else. The sprawling ""Warriors"" refuses to lapse into epic inspirational platitude; it is about the exhaustion of being perpetually ready to fight. Jahnsen takes well-covered general themes and distills something small and strange out of each; her instrumentation is huge and complicated while her lyrics remain resolutely human-scale.
Jahnsen played and arranged many of the instruments on the album herself
column2: and the album is like an expansive and bizarre terrarium in which Jahnsen has carefully called for the placement of each element. She places tinny synth microtones next to big wooden piano notes on ""Fragments""
column3: a song about human complications

column7: I suspect
column8:
makes her work so consistently complex and worthwhile.

column1: Like Over Me

It’s to the point where Cold Beat effectively resemble two discrete bands: an endearingly scrappy garage-rock act and a mechanistic
column4: melancholic electro-pop outfit. However

Lorely Rodriguez's evolution over the past half-decade mirrors the twists and turns of indie rock itself. She first appeared as a member of Brooklyn's Celestial Shore
column2: a quirky art-rock quartet rising in the wake of Dirty Projectors and Vampire Weekend. After debuting her Empress Of alias with a series of color-coded song snippets on YouTube

column1: It's that last point that provides the real revelation on Me. True to its title

column3: where she lived alone for five weeks at a friend's house in a remote small town. The intense isolation provided the opportunity to reflect upon her life back in Brooklyn with great clarity

column1: The bulk of Me forms a concept album of sorts documenting the life cycle of a relationship. She takes us from the sloppy hook-up sex of ""Make Up"" (""Nothing comes between us/ But a piece of latex/ When you tear my clothes off/ Like I was a paycheck"") to the obsessive dependency of ""Everything Is You"" (""All I want to be is you""). She chronicles the lapse into domesticity on ""Need Myself"" (""Can we stop watching the TV?/ Can I get up off of my knees?"") to the intoxicated post-breakup haze of ""To Get By"" and the heartache-induced insomnia of ""Icon"" (""Close my eyes/ I see your face/ I just keep myself awake""). Rodriguez's writing is loaded with vivid details (""I can hear you grind your teeth/ When you're laying fast asleep"")
column2: but the scenery will feel familiar to anyone who's languished in a partnership after the thrill is gone
column3: and agonized over the decision to break free.

column1: If the songs on Me resemble diary entries
column2: the pages have been torn out and shuffled
column3: so that events fall out of order. We are continually shifted between pre- and post-breakup experiences
column4: which mimics the experience of sorting through a failed love. After all
column5: our memories rarely materialize in chronological order—a fleeting fond reminiscence of an ex has the power to momentarily override the longing and pain that fueled it. The narrative goes beyond Rodriguez's candid lyrics into the production itself
column6: which offers dramatic commentary or reinforcement. When she confronts some cat-calling bros on ""Kitty Kat""
column7: the track responds to her simple plea of ""let me walk away"" with a cluster of claustrophobic synth jabs. And the tripped-up groove of ""To Get By"" comes off like a bad trip in the middle of a nightclub
column8: where your stomach turns queasy
column9: knees wobble
column10: and the faces of the dancers around you become slow-motion psychedelic smears.

column1: But Rodriguez is equally adept at channeling her inner turmoil into euphoric release
column2: like on the Herculean house romp ""How Do You Do It"" and the pitch-shifting space-disco delirium of ""Threat"". On the latter track
column3: Rodriguez effectively coins Me's don't-look-back mission statement by declaring ""our memories are a threat""—and by the time that chorus is punctuated by the blare of synthesized trumpets
column4: her troubles are already forgotten. Rodriguez may spend much of Me inside her mind
column5:
but it’s as much an invitation to get out of our heads.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/22207/homepage_large.f0617dee.jpg|Brace the Wave|586.0|Lou Barlow|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Joyful Noise']|2015-09-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:06:39.606371|"

Thurston Moore once told me in a magazine interview while discussing the pivotal figures of '90s indie rock that ""Lou Barlow essentially invented lo-fi."" His comment might not be literally true (Guided by Voices
column2: Daniel Johnston
column3: and countless others toyed with a similar level of fidelity)
column4: but there was something about the way Barlow made hiss and mistakes synonymous with his personality that made him special. It was part and parcel with the beautiful-loser tag he cultivated throughout his solo work. He wasn't espousing any discernible ideology
column5: except maybe an inclination to find beauty in rough edges
column6: and if to not self-consciously fuck up his work
column7: at very least to accentuate its ugliness at moments. Barlow's work
column8: in other words
column9: has rarely been feel-good
column10: and Brace the Wave
column11: his first new collection of songs since Sebadoh's comeback 2013 LP Defend Yourself
column12: is no exception.

column1: This is music for late-night self-reflection
column2: if not quite the self-loathing of the younger Barlow. While the elephant in the room throughout Defend Yourself was the dissolution of Barlow's marriage
column3: Brace the Wave is somehow even more personal
column4: delving into the minutiae of his collapse. On the opener ""Redeemed""
column5: Barlow reveals to a newfound love
column6: ""I need a place to hide/ Somewhere I can bring my thoughts to you/ And be redeemed."" The track builds slowly
column7: hitting its emotional peak as he laments
column8: ""Memories are made of razor blades""
column9: and the gentle acoustic strum turns brittle and forceful.

column1: Redemption is a recurring theme throughout Brace the Wave
column2: as Barlow's loves
column3: past and present
column4: collide in dreamlike succession. There is almost a sense that Barlow is watching his life flash before his  eyes: The twitchy ""Nerve"" pines for idyllic times as Barlow mischievously recounts
column5: ""I remember we were hipsters sleeping with our cats/ Young and thin and fucking crazy/ Fine 'til something cracked."" On the stomp and stammer of ""Boundaries""
column6: he disarmingly concedes
column7: ""You made yourself available/ I crawled into your arms.""

column1: One of the first songs Barlow ever released
column2: on Sebadoh's Weed Forestin'
column3: was ""Ride the Darker Wave"". On the track
column4: rife with wanton aggression
column5: Barlow implores flippantly
column6: ""Hello tomorrow today/ Ride the darker wave."" Contrast this with ""Wave""
column7: the semi-titular track of Brace the Wave
column8: which reads like an ambivalent breakup note
column9: as Barlow enumerates his own defects (""When I'm not home for ages/ I look for ways to fade"") while abjectly entreating ""I leave you alone but don't go""
column10: before accepting the inevitable (""I don't heed the warning signs/ It's our time""). It's a devastating recognition of a relationship long past its expiration date
column11: and like the rest of Brace the Wave
column12: echoes the complexity of ending an adult relationship with dignified resignation.

column1: Barlow isn't the yearning aesthete any longer
column2: and he doesn't act like one. But what's most remarkable about this album is
column3: despite the high gravitas of the subject manner
column4: it still manages to capture the yearning and imagination of youth
column5: and never loses touch with the redemptive qualities of interpersonal connectedness. Life and relationships rarely offer easy answers
column6:
and Brace the Wave doesn't either.

"|20946.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20946-brace-the-wave/|7.1|John Everhart

Through his work first with Lifter Puller
column2: then with the Hold Steady
column3: and later as a solo artist
column4: Craig Finn has created a universe as big as America
column5: a stage that stretches from Minneapolis to Ybor City
column6: from the bars of Chicago to behind bars in Memphis. It’s a world populated by hoodrats and club kids
column7: by dealers and party girls
column8: by guys who look like André Cymone and women named Robbie Robertson (""but people call me Robo"")
column9: by the financially desperate and the spiritually confused. Each new song and each new album expands that universe significantly
column10: implicitly or explicitly adding new chapters to ongoing stories as Finn hangs out off to the side
column11: narrating from the periphery of the scene.

column1: It can be forbidding to pick up these narrative strands at this late date
column2: but at his best Finn’s songs swallow you up in that word entirely. His lyrics continually provoke a spark of recognition
column3: as he invites you to connect the dots between a new song and an old one. Listening to ""Sarah
column4: Calling from a Hotel""
column5: from his new solo album
column6: is a bit like eavesdropping on a friend who has landed on rough times. ""Hadn’t seen her since the races at the ending of last summer
column7: Finn sings over a sparse coffeehouse strum. ""We watched the horses run up on each other/ She looked pretty."" Is this the unnamed subject of ""Chips Ahoy!""
column8: from the Hold Steady’s 2006 breakthrough Boys and Girls in America
column9: the clairvoyant who ""can tell which horse is gonna finish in first""?

column1: If so
column2: the tone of chapter is much darker and more dire than migraines and emotional detachment. Faith in the Future is a character-driven record
column3: even if it doesn’t restore Finn to the heights of his mid-2000s heyday. It’s full of prominent proper names: Sarah and Maggie
column4: Christine and Sandra. St. Peter even shows up
column5: because this is a Craig Finn album. The names are mundane
column6: not exotic. You probably don’t know anyone named Charlemagne
column7: but you’re likely Facebook friends with a Christine. There’s not a single hoodrat on Faith
column8: but there are plenty of people caught between the youthful indiscretions of the past and the adult consequences of the present.

column1: That pretty much describes Finn these days. Even during the disastrous Bennigan’s gig in ""Roman Guitars""
column2: he comes across as more grown up
column3: imbuing his narrators/stand-ins with a maturity that pushes them even further into the margins—the fate of all thirty- and fortysomethings. He’s no longer talking to the kids
column4: and he’s not coming up the stairs or coming from the streets. Instead
column5: he has entered what you might call the Peter Wolf phase of his career
column6: when the old band has sputtered out and the frontman tries to re-establish himself as a serious songwriter. And if you don’t know who Peter Wolf is
column7: well
column8: then you’ll realize there is a certain unglamorous anonymity that comes with respectability.

column1: The catch
column2: of course
column3: is that the Hold Steady and the J. Geils Band were great groups—exciting and clever and bold and even fun as they wallowed in rock’s less reputable urges. Downplaying riffs in favor of texture
column4: Faith in the Future plays it much safer
column5: which means there’s more emphasis on the words than on Finn’s delivery of them. Finn’s solo debut
column6: 2012’s Clear Heart Full Eyes
column7: attempted to match his songs to amiably twangy arrangements
column8: which in retrospect was an intriguing experiment
column9: but there’s no comparable strategy in place for enlivening these songs. There’s a lot of bland acoustic strumming
column10: as though the austerity of the arrangement were meant to reinforce the slice-of-life songwriting
column11: but anyone who has ever skipped ""Citrus"" or bristled over Live at Fingerprints knows that acoustic isn’t Finn’s best setting. He doesn’t always have to have a rousing bar band behind him
column12: but he does need something that will lend his lyrics more immediacy and higher stakes.

column1: The best songs succeed despite the music
column2: not because of it. ""St. Peter Upside Down"" may be the most compelling song of his solo career
column3: a sharp juxtaposition between romantic regret and religious sacrifice that somehow grows more burdened
column4: more beat down with every iteration of its chorus. Finn has
column5: of course
column6: plumbed similar territory in the past
column7: but instead of redundant
column8: it plays like the culmination of his obsession with Catholicism
column9: as though he’s adding an epilogue to his previous spiritual inquiries. As it proceeds
column10: Faith in the Future becomes more and more a benediction for the scene
column11: a goodbye to all that. The perfectly titled ""I Was Doing Fine (Then a Few People Died)"" sounds impossibly world-weary
column12: as Finn gets drunk with an old friend (possibly
column13: hopefully even Sarah herself). ""She said some nights I wonder if anything means anything
column14: and the only consolation he can offer is
column15:
""I never said I was Jesus.""

""The intelligence resides in the work
column2: not the individual
column3: explains Kerry Leimer in the liner notes to Artificial Dance
column4: a retrospective collection that highlights the unpredictable alchemy of his early 1980s studio project Savant. The Seattle experimentalist is best known for the woozy ambient music he has released as K. Leimer
column5: but Savant’s approach was something like an avant-garde jam band re-imagined as musique concrète. Riffs
column6: grooves
column7: and rhythms were crafted on a wide array of instruments—electric bass
column8: drums
column9: Oberheim DMX
column10: Prophet 5 synthesizer
column11: and objects identified in the credits with names like ""Percussion (Wood
column12: Silver
column13: Plastic)
column14: ""Guitar (Prepared
column15: China)
column16: and ""Guitar (Cloud Guitars)""—and then broken apart
column17: looped
column18: layered
column19: run through primitive effects
column20: and reassembled at last by the razor-wielding producer across lengthy spools of reel-to-reel tape.

column1: The recombinant approach had something in common with Brian Eno’s work during the period
column2: particularly his David Byrne collaboration My Life in the Bush of Ghosts (Eno
column3: too
column4: was fond of fanciful instruments like “snake guitar”)
column5: and the results similarly hovered somewhere between funk
column6: loosely speaking
column7: and more abstracted forms of ambient sound. Debut single ""Stationary Dance""
column8: with its breakbeat structure and a voiceover sampled from an instructional LP
column9: anticipated cut-and-paste artists like M|A|R|R|S and Coldcut by six or seven years
column10: while the watery B-side
column11: ""Sensible Music""
column12: sounds today like a more muscular
column13: lo-fi version of Talk Talk’s later work. Listeners familiar with Leimer’s solo catalog will detect echoes of that music here: the glassy synthesizers of his ambient recordings trace serpentine paths through Savant’s songs
column14: and the rolling
column15: otherworldly drum programming of K. Leimer’s 1983 album Imposed Order bleeds through into the stop-start rhythms of ""The Neo-Realist"" and ""Indifference"".

column1: But the bulk of Savant’s catalog sounds like nothing else that had come before. These tracks
column2: where skeletal dub rhythms underpin an array of daubed-on splotches of electric bass and Clavinet and atonal guitar
column3: feel less like ""songs"" than amorphous organisms where a rippling pulse is the only constant. The structure can be hard to follow but in a fascinating way—long and convoluted 10-bar phrases are not uncommon
column4: and it often feels like a rug is being pulled out from under you
column5: even when the bassline plunges deep in the pocket. ""Shadow in Deceit"" begins with a flurry of bells and post-punk bass and gradually transforms
column6: via interlocking marimbas
column7: into a vivid template for Four Tet’s brand of new-age techno. ""Heart of Stillness""
column8: with its unsteady pitter-patter percussion and dripping guitar tones
column9: has an even headier rainforest vibe; it feels like sound just on the cusp of coalescing into music
column10: or perhaps vice versa.

column1: Given that the bulk of the album’s tracks were made between 1981 and 1985
column2: it’s harder to judge the final three cuts
column3: all previously unreleased
column4: which date from between 2009 and 2014. ""Facility"" is dark and alluring
column5: and it’s not hard to imagine it appearing on a contemporary label like R&S. But the context differs so radically from the early work that the later songs might as well constitute a different project altogether. But that’s OK—the 11 songs that comprise Savant’s prime output amount to some of the most striking and original American electronic music of that period
column6: so much so that it seems almost inconceivable that it went largely overlooked until now. Had a tastemaker like Detroit’s Electrifying Mojo gotten his hands on Savant’s slim catalog
column7: who knows how things might have turned out. Artificial Dance is enough to make you rethink what you thought you knew about that era—and to make you wonder what else might be out there
column8:
just waiting to be rediscovered.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/22187/homepage_large.338f7052.jpg|Welcome to JFK|33106.0|Chinx|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Entertainment One']|2015-09-08 00:00:00|2015|2016-06-11 16:06:41.382633|"

Over the course of his Hurry Up and Die and Cocaine Riot mixtape series
column2: the Queens rapper Chinx pieced together a gruff
column3: promising sound. Versed in the foreboding thump of Atlanta trap but very much New York in spirit and form
column4: Chinx at his best (the mischievously weird ""I'm a Coke Boy""
column5: from Cocaine Riot 2)
column6: suggested that Coke Boys could be more than just French Montana's goon squad. Then one May morning the unthinkable happened: Chinx was killed as shots were fired at his car outside of a venue he’d just performed. He was only 31
column7: married with three children and a fourth on the way.

column1: As a method of coping with the loss
column2: his manager and close collaborators gathered to honor their friend the only way they knew how: workshopping the sessions he’d left behind. As a result
column3: Welcome to JFK is a different kind of hip-hop debut. Instead of pointing the rapper toward the places he could go
column4: JFK hint at places he might’ve gotten. From the dejected Auto-Tuned opener ""Experimental""
column5: in which Chinx sings ""I swear I want this to last us a lifetime""
column6: to the foreboding closer ""Die Young""
column7: the specter of mortality haunts the proceedings.

column1: Despite all of this
column2: it's a testament to Chinx's still-growing pop smarts that Welcome to JFK is sometimes a lot of fun. ""Experimental""’s mournful opener is quickly offset by a stream of upbeat shots at radio play. ""Thug Love"" and ""The Other Side"" spring for help from outside singers
column3: the former calling Jeremih for the chorus and the latter tapping Ty Dolla $ign in full goon regalia. The real gem of the batch is ""Yay""
column4: a bratty bit of spiteful money counting that is concise and catchy without sacrificing Chinx’s dopeboy veneer.

column1: For the stretch of songs from the wistful pep talk ""How to Get Rich"" through the closing Coke Boys posse cut ""Die Young""
column2: Welcome to JFK tenses up and eases off the good times. Chinx walks his audience behind the triumph of ""Go Get It"" and ""Yay"" to illuminate the hard decisions and paranoia that accompant success on the streets. ""Pray"" pairs him up with Chicago Coke Boys affiliate Lil Durk as each ponders mortality and their legacy. In the latter
column3: Chinx raps chillingly about a nightmare in which he gets shot in the head
column4:
only to dive into a chorus essentially eulogizing himself. Welcome to JFK doesn’t allow much comfort. The album is by turns a succession of punchlines so snarky it’s upsetting Chinx won’t be around to write more of them and an unnerving trip into a mind coming to terms with the ever-present reality of sudden death.

"|20924.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/20924-welcome-to-jfk/|7.3|Craig Jenkins
